author: {'steamid': '76561198049215210', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 431, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1712282828}
review:
The trailers are deceiving. They make it look like this game is a frantic power fantasy with non-stop explosions. Like 2D DOOM or Just Cause with tanks. It is not.

It is actually one of the most tense and deep real-time stealthy tactical games I've ever played. Around the middle of the campaign I was strapped in a tiny mech hiding between buildings, trying to distract and lure out an overwhelming force to pick them off one by one. Each shot was a careful tradeoff, revealing my position but pulling more enemies away from the real target of the mission.

Brigador does destruction in a totally unique way. 100% of the map can be leveled at any time if you try hard enough, but every structure is a tactical decision. You can tear down the wall standing between you and your target to skip a whole line of defenses, but when it's time to get out that crucial piece of cover will be gone. Low barriers let hovercrafts pass while blocking ground units. A carefully punched hole can be an escape route under cover of smoke to get behind your enemies. It can also be the mistake that gets you surrounded. Tearing things down is noisy and attracts attention. The complexity of the gameplay-impacting interactions between weapons, structures, terrain, sound, light and enemy AI must have taken ages to get right. 

it's amazing that a game with this many weapons manages to make them all feel unique. The only thing they have in common is that they're all completely overpowered - when used in a very specific situation. The chaingun is the closest I've seen a game get to what footage of an A-10 warthog feels like: It vaporizes anything on the receiving in an overwhelming blaze of light and sound, and within half a second you're out of ammunition and every enemy on the map knows where you are. The irradiator silently kills enemies through walls without making a sound - at short range, and only if they haven't been alerted enough to put their shields up first. Ammunition is scarce no matter what weapon you choose.

Brigador's creator described it as a "Kool-Aid man simulator", and at the very best that's what the game is. The Kool-Aid man bursts through walls like they're paper, but he's still made of glass. And he's also been accused of war crimes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092127187', 'num_games_owned': 715, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 172, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1711592400}
review:
While there are some interesting ideas here and a pretty great soundtrack, everything else about it isn’t perfect. 

Starting with the gameplay, there is a large variety of different mechs, weapons, and pilots that can be used each feels slightly different from the other and not unique enough to be its own thing. The controls are also bad, I played around with the various control schemes they have and none of them felt good the main issue is that despite being top-down of sorts it’s also 3d meaning it is very easy to miss shots seems lined up because you’re shooting too high or low, it doesn’t feel good trying to line it up and even when it is it doesn’t feel satisfying. The main loop of the gameplay is quite boring, there is a lot of walking around and stomping on barriers which is both slow and unsatisfying, each level is very similar to the others mainly being just a large square. There isn’t too much combat and when it’s there it isn’t enjoyable.

There is a campaign and a freelance mode, the campaign leaves much to be desired as it is a more limited version of the freelance. In the campaign you get a set loadout or a few and are in a square room, there are some interesting stories about the militarized nature of the society and the lack of care for civilians but generally speaking, it is very barebones, you can unlock lore for in-game currency which adds to it a bit but it isn’t enough to keep me engaged or more interested. The freelance mode allows you to make your loadouts which is much better, these missions are very repetitive though all have the same goals with extremely little variety.  

Visually it looks good, the style is distinct, and stands out well creating some life into the world. The areas are done to be believable and feel lived in. The mech designs are well done and distinct, you won’t confuse them or their capabilities. The soundtrack is similarly well done with a fast pace to it to match what should be fast-paced gameplay. 

Much of this game doesn’t work on any level and I struggled to play through much of it before deciding to give up.

[h1]★★☆☆☆[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198008262866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 73, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1712180511}
review:
Very fun game, and can get quite challenging. While it looks like a twin stick shooter, it really doesn't play like one. Especially on some missions where you are limited to certain mech types, you really need to play tactically, use all your abilities, use the environment for cover, etc. Missions are usually quite short.

In each campaign mission you have a choice of 3-4 vehicles, each with different weapons, health and armor values, and play-styles. Some of these are hilariously, joyously overpowered, and some are not. Exploring all these vehicles and weapons is part of the game, and it's always fun to come across a mission that lets you use the gigantic pile of junked cars, for example, which lobs corrosive goo at enemies from far away and knocks out any survivors with a CIWS gun.

As far as the context for what's happening, that is all doled out in mission descriptions. When in a mission, you have your objectives and that's that. The overall lore explaining what you're doing in each mission is amusing in a mean-spirited kind of way. Solo Nobre is described as having undergone a socialist revolution to cast out the rule of corporate exploiters and mobsters (so, Cuba), and the player is employed by the "Solo Nobre Concern," which represents that aggrieved capital interest (so, a CIA cutout) and is tasked with "liberating" Solo Nobre by destroying military and civilian infrastructure across the whole city/country/planet. You gain money per each civilian killed, because these civilians are "Loyalists" - as in, loyal to the regime that replaced the corporate interest that now employs you. This does color the level of challenge posed by each mission. The mission is not to accomplish your objectives and NOT kill the civilian population; you won't be penalized if you need to blow up an apartment block in order to create a flanking route.  In fact you will be rewarded for doing so.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053049402', 'num_games_owned': 1623, 'num_reviews': 346, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 45, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1711191323}
review:
Бегай по картам, стреляй во всё что движется и не движется, без какого-либо смысла, ведь выбор разных персонажей и мехов не привносит ничего нового в какой-либо сюжет, который просто напросто отсутствует. Все молчат и это душит. Мол, зачем я всё это разрушаю, если в мехе сидит немой пилот, который даже не может сказать игроку, зачем всё это ему нужно. 
Глупый рогалик, не имеющий хоть какой-то смысл. Эта игра бы зашла, выйди она на кнопочных телефонах в далёком прошлом. Тогда бы никто не заморачивался и просто ловил бы кайф от происходящего.

Наскучило быстро, даже часа наиграть не смог.

Скорее я ждал больше, чем просто бродить и разрушать, когда покупал Brigador.
Кому-то эта игра конечно понравится. Скажет, что задолбали меня все эти ваши сюжеты, ролики и диалоги, хочу просто резни. И он её получит.
Мне больше зашла первая часть SYNTHETIK, тем более, в ней присутствует кооператив:
https://store.steampowered.com/app/528230/SYNTHETIK_Legion_Rising/

author: {'steamid': '76561198245858176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1664408081}
review:
Brigador: The Selected Works Quick Hits Review

Steam Curator group: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44858736/

A Caviar Game, wrought with artisanal skill for Discerning Gamers. A beautiful, brutal game, with a stunning soundtrack, and tons of great writing (that you do not have to engage with if you don't want to, by the way). One of the very, very, very few pieces of art with an original and intelligent take on cyberpunk/synthwave/etc. aesthetic, it makes other more popular interpretations of these tropes n' tools look like low hanging fruit gambits made by nostalgia-addled sadsacks with bags under their eyes.

A few heroes have stepped forward and tried to get this one the attention it deserves, but it still, sadly, has not gotten the attention it deserves. If you're here, you are a Chosen One. Buy Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109692569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1709473960}
review:
Вроде нормально, но есть серьёзные замечания (по поводу прицела)...

Плюсы:
- Красивая, сочная и красочная графика. Всё красиво взрывается и разлетается на куски.
- Хорошая отрисовка уровней в изометрии.
- Хорошее музыкальное сопровождение и звуки в игре.

Минусы:
- Разработчики сделали прицел так, что его еле видно. Это вообще ужас, в сильной заворушке его будет вообще не видно и ты мало будешь попадать по врагам. А там надо чаще целиться именно во врагов, иначе всё будет пролетать над ними.
Не могли что ли сделать прицел более заметнее и больше?
- На мехе нельзя менять оружие. Если хочешь круче пушку или скорострельнее то надо менять именно мега, который будет либо дохлый как ведро, либо неповоротливый.

author: {'steamid': '76561198856864081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1706996034}
review:
I don't leave reviews for stuff very often, but for this I'll absolutely make an exception. I've been playing Brigador since 2020 when a certain Youtuber made a video on this absolute gem & have been playing it ever since. Originally got it in GOG before recently buying it again on steam to help support the devs.

Brigador is a very special game to me. Everything from the gameplay, music, art style & setting just click. A deceivingly simple game with a ton of strategy & tactics where one bad decision can easily snowball & end your run. The game looks like it would be a simple arcadey twin stick shooter but its not, with the game requiring you to take very careful consideration of your environment, how to traverse it, and even the way your vehicle is positioned (the game features a directional damage system). Flanking is king and unless your driving a project mega death type vehicle, you should never engage most enemies head on. Especially large groups or swarms of enemies without some sort of cover or way to retreat from the situation.

The soundtrack is also simply a masterpiece. "Makeup and Vanity Set" created an incredible Synthwave soundtrack that can range from being either "Badass & Bombastic" to "Haunting & Atmospheric". Every track fits the games mood flawlessly whether your taking on a NEP garrison with a Touro, sneaking about in a MOG suit, or mopping up the remnants of your latest space genocide.

Art style lore wise Brigador also strikes a massive cord with me as I'm an absolute goober who's obsessed with retro future settings, the late Cold War era, and anything Military related. The vehicle designs are all fricking peak, the lore is way better than it has any right to be, and the city of Solo Nobre is crammed with so much love, attention to detail, and character that its almost a shame that its our job to destroy the damn place.

I won't say Brigador is the "best game ever made", but its personally one of my all time favorite video games. If you haven't played it yet & like vehicle combat games then do yourself a favor & pick this one up. 
Also the sequel "Brigador Killers", is still in active development so give the devs your money so we can finally play it!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198860756066', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2605, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 16, 'playtime_at_review': 2522, 'last_played': 1712124502}
review:
If you're interested in storming through cityscapes in a wide variety of different mechs to face off against an occupying force on an impressive scale, then buy it, hands down it delivers this in spades.
Its beautiful, strategically interesting, and really fun to grind through - which is 90% of what you will be doing with this game. Complete a contract, acquire new pilots (difficulties), harder mechs, and harder challenges, and go in again.

However, this game's lore broke me as a writer. I dipped my toes in the water with the excellent audio-book, read a lot of the in game lore, really intriguing stuff, excellent concept for a cyberpunk setting which really uplifts the game itself.
One of my favorite bits of lore is just the yellow raincoats. Really effective world building.
I ended up trying to dig deeper, which is when I found fucking MT Foxtrot from Cruelty Squad (an excellent game), very funny stuff. Then the blue skeleton, then fucking Johnny Five Aces, then the in universe TV series, and I found I couldn't make myself care more about the characters than the authors do, which turned out to be fairly little. Any character that seems interesting is just a difficulty tweak.
Early on, I was interested in seeing what fanfics sprung from this wealth of ideas, now I know why its all just jokes and porn.

I don't know if they can manage to resurrect my interest with Brigador Killers, but we'll see I suppose.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970598509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1703390304}
review:
The Ultimate in Post-Collapse Dystopian Voxel Mech Mercenary Action

Stellar Jockeys are some cool dudes and they made a fun game in the style of 'Jungle Strike' but with mechs, tanks, and a killer soundtrack by Makeup and Vanity Set (MAVS), which you should also buy and listen to on repeat for a year or two.

The game is an isometric shooter with an emphasis on destruction and ammo management (though, there is a "cheat" to enable unlimited ammo, if you're willing to give up achievements). Little foot soldiers can be obliterated by high rate-of-fire (ROF) machine guns, walked on, stomped on, or eviscerated in any other hilarious way you can imagine. There is some strategy to taking out objectives or larger tanks and enemy mechs, but it is mostly a game of "shoot everything until it blows up." You can try to kill the alarm-sounding enemies, or destroy the power grid to make things more stealthy, if that's your play style. But I can't emphasize enough that this isn't a "precision shooter" so much as it is a "destroy the entire world" shooter.

The weapon and vehicle variety is vast. There are some hilarious weapon and vehicle combos to unlock and play around with. One of my favorites is a corrosive gas canister launcher paired with a high ROF ballistic gun.

Stellar Jockeys did an awesome job building the world for such a simple concept. It feels right at home for someone who enjoyed the satirical, dystopian sci-fi films of Paul Verhoeven. Easily worth the asking price for the atmosphere and music, alone. It can be played with mouse and keyboard or with a controller, but I find that the aiming mechanics pretty much require a mouse and keyboard to be precise and effective, as you aim in an "arc" or sorts and have to mind your elevation when attacking the various enemy types (flying, ground, and medium/tall enemies).

My only real compliant about the software is that the game can't run native 4K and makes it annoying when I have to tab out to check something in Windows.

I think that this game would definitely be a bit more fun with co-op, some fast Japanese-style mech designs with melee capabilities, and some more in-depth mission mechanics. Either way, I'm looking forward to the sequel. Pick it up if you liked the older 16-bit generation isometric destruction shooters and are an enjoyer of synthesizer-based musics from a more civilized age.

review:
Brigador benefits from aggressive, fast-action gameplay, and many of the shield/ammo pickup mechanisms rely on proximity. Brigador breaks its own knees in the last third of the campaign by forcing an absurd amount of difficult scenarios, where the only effective strategy is to abuse the AI through a grind of pulling and kiting at maximum distance like it's a lazy MMO. Mission restarts are common and unpredictable - a single alarm from an off-screen flanking patrol often ends a 30 minute run.

Aggression still works through waiting for special ability cooldowns, and causing some missions to devolve into a mess of action-wait-action-wait. One misjudged use of the cooldown and it's another dozen enemies swarming your vehicle and another restart. So you're back to pulling and kiting - it's gruelling and unpredictable. Most of Brigador is brilliant, but I had a terrible time finishing the campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561198350412329', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1699396789}
review:
[h1]机甲的双腿不能平移或跨栏或爬高地，但可以蹲下当炮塔[/h1]
    总的来说是一个非常好玩的战犯（字面意思）游戏，战火肆虐的星际赛博朋克世界观在幽默的文笔加持下跃然屏上，挺有叙事潜力的。游玩方面它有自成体系的完善系统和高度开放（甚至像broforce一样允许地道战）的关卡设计，各种机体配装差异性极大，总之就是...极其舒适，玩家觉得能用的战术大概真能用，总能找到好玩的打法，有一种沉浸模拟系的感觉

    至于缺点...最大的应该就是瞄准，这俯视角游戏其实是有Z轴的，会影响瞄准、隐蔽、移动等重要要素，俯视角就是对Z轴不敏感，所以玩时经常会因此出一些岔子，再加上游戏里的枪大多都不是hitscan而且弹道还会被机甲的动量明显影响，高个子或高机动性的机体的瞄准体验真的很尴尬。
    作为俯视角游戏本作是有弹道线的，这是避免了很多*对自己的掩体输出*的大好事，但着弹点却没那么明显，如果开发者能看到我的话希望能改进这点

还有就是任务的形式很单一，虽然有着优秀系统和地图的加持也不至于打完第一关后“散了吧后面都是这个”。主要是自由契约模式根本不是什么肉鸽，因为没有必须的构筑角色玩法，机体装备都是在开局时选的，其实就是个地图随机生成而已，加上也没有故事可看，这个模式很容易腻

    再感叹一下这游戏的机甲真就是长了两条腿的巨型坦克而已，腿也不是合金装备里月光那样的美腿...有点失望

author: {'steamid': '76561199065003962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1704469283}
review:
If you look at the pics & watch the vids and think it looks like something you'd enjoy doing a bunch of times, then you'll probably like Brigador. The campaign missions are divided between tutorials, story-related incidents, and challenges. Beyond that, you unlock the dozens of variables (vehicles, pilots, weapons, missions) for additional freelance runs. That's the game.

Most complaints I've seen have to do with repetition (see above) and controls. You can customize controls somewhat, using different modes for different vehicle types. And, y'know, maybe people think the mechs should just be faster and more nimble. They can be sort of cumbersome, but not in a way that's incomprehensible. These are not Gundam. They don't move like people. Even the fast mechs have to be maneuvered with care. Some vehicles can plow through obstacles more quickly than others, though they are slower going down the street. Some weapons have long, slow arcs, and some shoot straight. Some weapons don't penetrate walls as well as others do. If you don't want to pay attention to (and experiment with) mechanical details such as these, this might not be the game for you. If forgetting that you can't survive blowing up a fuel depot while you're standing right in the middle of it makes you overly mad, this might not be the game for you.

As for me, I'm kind of annoyed I didn't play it sooner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180357867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5188, 'last_played': 1707811606}
review:
It's a top down mech/tank/floating thing game. The weapons are varied and plying around with them can let you discover some pretty useful combos, like a sledger with a ploughman chemical projector and a bonesaw machine gun. Or listen to the lore, the lockdown's description outlines that spacer kill squads are power suiits with lockdowns and black hands, so I outfitted a Juke like that and had loads of fun playing as a space hitman. For difficulty it's as easy or as hard as you make it, and the fully destructable environment gives you some neat tactical choices. Just pay attention to the penetration stats on your weapons and their arcs, there's nothing more embarrassing than firing off a shot that just alerts the enemies to your location, or worse, damages you because it hiit a building and exploded.

The Rounder will forever be my favourite tank, quick, well armoured, good shields, low profile, and good weapon selection. It got me through the Full linear Solo Nobre run and I'm going to use it for the closed casket special. Thunderclap, achie, and Zeus are all great picks for the main slot. For the turret, both the mortars are good, the mae dois is a bit underwhelming, the crambo is good but with limited range, and the confessor is good if you're good at aiming.

Experiment with the different vehicles, find out what you like using and what suits your playstyle, then dominate the military forces in Solo Nobre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977824972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 4198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4198, 'last_played': 1696990352}
review:
BRIGADOR IS GOOD. GET BRIGADOR.

Brigador is a game where you play a Brigador: an amoral lunatic who kills for money, hired by a corporation to go do various war crimes in an attempt to commit reverse Sim City.

HOW IT PLAYS.

Base gameplay of Brigador is you drive around a vehicle, like a tank, a car with jury rigged guns and anti-gravity pads, a mech, a mech made out of truck parts, a tractor with guns on it, a giant floating metal head that can scream at people ect, and you have a list of objectives to do. Blow up these buildings, kill these specific guys, decimate the garrison of the area you're in, stuff like that, and then you have to get out alive. 

The game controls from a top down perspective, and although its no longer the default with the Up-Armored edition, it's really meant to have tank controls. It really matters in gameplay, as there's directional damage stuff going on, and the new default controls make it really hard to back up while shooting, which is something you need to do when you've kicked the hornets nest by accident and thirty tanks and mechs are rushing you down.

There's an alert system, where some enemies, typically smaller faster machines, but sometimes super-heavies, upon seeing you for long enough, or getting shot at, will start to radio in your location. If they live long enough to scream for help, the entire map goes on full alert. Vehicles that were idling with their engines off will kick on, every single thing with shields will turn them on, and everything within a set radius will charge in your direction, not a death sentence, but certainly a problem to be avoided. This also causes emergency gates to pop up, blocking roads and neighborhoods off from you, depending on what weapons you're using this ranges from a nonissue to annoying, given that in most cases you can blow up the regular walls right next to them and just walk around through the rubble.

Besides the typical objectives, there's even more stuff to blow up on the map. There's your typical explosive barrels, in the form of gas storage silos, oil drills, and gas pipelines. You got radio towers that make radio calls take longer to go out if blown up, and transformer substations that cut the power to the entire map when smashed. Not just the emergency gates that pop up for alarms, ALL the power, from street lights to neon signs, which is a lot of extra lighting work needed, and I appreciate the effort.

HOW IT LOOKS.

COOL. Brigador has a lot of work put into it to make it look good, and this really shows in the vehicles. It makes sense these would look good given that these are what you're going to be looking at closely most of the time, either being what you drive or what you shoot at. From how I understand it, they made 3D models of everything, then took a lot of pictures of it from different angles, and then used those pictures to make sprites instead of rendering everything in full blown 3D, which still retains the small details of the model and also probably makes the game run better. Bullet tracers, lasers, missiles, and cannon fire all look great as well. Things that hurt look like they should.

There's also a bunch of effort that shows in the environment, all of the buildings both look good, and are very clear in what they're meant to be. That's a house, that's a casino, that's a tomb, that's a bar, that's a gas station, that's a gazebo, that's a strip club, that's a shanty shack, that's a warehouse, that's a combination casino/bar/strip club. Everything is very readable and that helps each map feel unique as you move though Solo Nobre blowing everything that moves to hell and back.

HOW IS SOUNDS

SICK. Brigador has a sick synthwave soundtrack by "Makeup and Vanity Set", would recommend a listen, absolutely fits with the tone of the game. Environmental stuff like the sound of tank engine, stomping mech footsteps and gunfire also have the level of punch you'd expect. Cannon fire has the omph behind it that you'd want, and there's a minigun that sounds like it came off an A-10.

BRIGADOR IS A GOOD GAME, GO PLAY IT, GO LISTEN TO THE SOUNDTRACK, GO CHECK OUT THE AUDIOBOOK.

I give it a "GREAT LEADER IS DEAD" out of "SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL" would gladly recommend.

WELCOME BRIGADOR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198827125132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 261, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1712119243}
review:
The controls take some getting used to, but once you got it down this is honestly one of the best indie action games there is!  The variety of vehicles and weapons is huge, the game play is intense and overwhelming, the levels are really detailed and fun, the art direction is a cool blend of cyberpunk and mech-warrior.  Also while not the most narrative focused game, the little bits of lore you get dropped are pretty interesting and does some original world building.

Def recommend if you want some well designed slice of mindless violence with a little narrative icing on top.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276634938', 'num_games_owned': 10153, 'num_reviews': 1500, 'playtime_forever': 3339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3339, 'last_played': 1702268345}
review:
[h1]
战 争 罪 模 拟 器
[/h1]

当初买这个游戏的理由很简单，看到推荐“解压游戏”“全地图破坏”等，存粹当作一个爽游来买的。
然而点开游戏之后没想到世界观设定竟然如此细致和周密，阵营之间的错综复杂的关系，玩家并非英雄，而错综复杂的政治局势让这个游戏根本没有“正义”的一方。
“独裁者”死了，然后呢？自由？解放？美好生活？事实告诉你这些都是放屁，政权瓦解带来的只有无尽的混乱，以及混乱中试图将自己的利益最大化的各个势力在互相斗争，无论是你是保皇派，无政府主义者还是大企业的雇员，这一切都已经毫无意义了，意识形态只告诉你该站在哪一边，把枪交到你的手上然后告诉你用子弹捍卫自己的理念，但是他们不会告诉你什么是“道德”和“正义”，在剧情任务中我一直避免去击杀那些穿黄色雨衣的平民，但是事实上在混乱的战局以及逐渐解锁的大规模杀伤性武器面前，这是毫无意义的。今天在我用305MM高爆攻城榴弹花费不到百分之一秒的时间就摧毁一个街区和其中的叛军时，跳出了一个成就“习惯化”，解锁条件是杀死1000个平民。我震惊了并且打算写下评论，是的，即使小心翼翼的去避免平民伤亡，在战争中杀死1000个平民也不过是一个很容易达到的“附带损失”，而且，玩家很容易就会把杀死那些黄色小人当作稀松平常的事情，一如那个成就“习惯化”的字面意思，何等的讽刺。
“在现代战争中，你会像条狗一样毫无意义的死去。——欧内斯特·海明威”，玩过这个游戏这句话就不难理解，而且不知为何我个人觉得这个世界观在某些部分可以和极乐迪斯科的世界观接轨。希望制作者能够继续带来这个世界观内的其他故事。

author: {'steamid': '76561198072169113', 'num_games_owned': 386, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2666, 'last_played': 1697910694}
review:
You're reading this because you want to know whether to buy this game or not.

I can tell you that there is no simple answer to that question. It depends heavily on your own personal tastes. But if you read the rest of this review, I will tell you what you need to like in order for this game to be worth buying.

Brigador is a cult-classic for a reason, the actual meat of the core gameplay loop is surprisingly small. The main campaign is a series of series of challenge maps with pre-determined loadouts, essentially difficulty settings (though I find the hardest are often more about being methodical and patient, not necessarily harder), which are tied together by a loose plot thread only really given in the mission description.

The actual feeling of playing the game is awesome, you can really feel the power of the vehicles you pilot, with entire city blocks coming down when you pull the trigger, and the yellow raincoat clad civilians giving the sense of scale of the violence, all to the tune of Makeup And Vanity Set's killer synthwave soundtrack. Undercutting it only slightly is the sound effects, which, in my opinion, don't quite match the devastation caused by the weapons. Take care with the controls; this game is not a twin-stick shooter, it defaults to those controls because everyone thought it would be from the trailer, and so the devs added it in. Tanks and Mechs play better with tank controls, and though it is somewhat more complex, it better sells the notion that you're piloting a 7-ton war machine. I'm no artist, but I find the visual style very pleasing, the colour composition appeals to me (lots of neon-signs in every hue) and the low-resolution sprites are both wonderfully made and tie into the established technology level of the setting (computers in Brigador are far less advanced than our own). It can get a little stale to look at after playing for too long.

The freelance mode, to me, is the actual intended way of playing the game. There, you get to pick your loadout; pilot, vehicle, weapons, special ability and the mission you want to run. And this is where the game hooked me, not because the gameplay was any more engaging, but because every one of those loadout options has a text entry describing it, written from the perspective of one of three characters in the game itself, often including details about the history of the world itself. And that world is fascinating to me. If you have the time to read, you'll find the world is positively dripping with character.

And therein lies the crux of my recommendation; would you buy a fun, well crafted, if repetitive game, just because the writing of the world-building is beyond amazing?
If yes, check out the audiobook too (there is a free excerpt available on youtube), it's astonishingly well written, providing even more insight into the world and the trials of the people who inhabit it, and it's narrated by Ryan Cooper, a man with a voice I can only describe as northern English butter.
If no, you probably won't get enough enjoyment out of it to get your money's worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076492050', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1695349212}
review:
Not enjoying it. Here's my rant.

Main issue is the crosshair. It's too small and even gets hidden by destructables(buildings, trees) because it's in game space. You easily lose track of it when there is a lot of enemies. A simple cross in screenspace with a configurable size and color would make a big difference. It's not rocket science, it's simple math. You just convert that aiming point to screenspace. Unless there was some kind of engine limitation ?
Apparently you can configure it through the debug menu, which I found a post about in the forums. Well, that debug menu made my game crash.
Anyway it should be in the options in the first place.

Even with the campaign, the game feels more like a sandbox. Just different missions to complete with different mechs. There are tons of unlockables, yet I don't feel compelled to unlock things.

The AI could be better. Early missions teach you about smoke bombs and also flanking, because armor strength is directional, so I thought that a certain level of stealth was possible. But in most missions, I quickly get spotted, enemies home in on you very fast, and then it's just chaos.

If you play with mouse and keyboard, you're better off using tank controls (called 'relative' in the options). 
'absolute' (the default) is better suited for a gamepad with an analog stick.

Good music, nice detailed graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027925074', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 292, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1695043491}
review:
[h1]Я БРИГАДИР, БРИГАДЮ, БРИГАЖУ[/h1]
Хорошая игра, позволяющая использовать разных "мехов"(в кавычках потому, что единицы ими не являются, а также  некоторые вообще собраны из хлама) и уничтожать целые толпы лоялистов на довольно обширных картах. Графика как для инди неплохая, звуковая составляющая доставляет. Геймплей прост и в то же время интересен, поскольку разные мехи дают абсолютно отличный друг от друга опыт пилотирования. Локализация полное дно, поэтому сюжет вы не поймете, да его тут практически и нет. Кое-какие части истории мира можно собрать, купив данные в магазине главного меню игры за внутриигровую валюту, которая копится за прохождение миссий и уничтожение ключевой инфраструктуры противника на карте (эдакие дополнительные задачи и не только).
В общем, на пару вечеров чтобы расслабится пойдет!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122389612', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 5211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5183, 'last_played': 1695189273}
review:
Top-Down Shooter в мире не самого светлого будущего.

Мы БРИГАДОР, наёмник КСН (Концерн Соло Нобре) иногда представитель одной из фракции Лоялисты/Корвиды/Спейсеры проживающих на Соло Нобре иногда хммм что-то совсем иное…

В нашем распоряжении техника 3х фракций Лоялистов/Корвидов/Спейсеров.
Техника подразделяется на основные виды Мехи/Танки/Антигравы, которые в свою очередь на лёгкие/тяжёлые/ультра.
Каждая единица техники имеет различные характеристики, влияющие на стиль боя.

2 режима игры:
"кампания" проходим задания с повышением сложности которых нам позволяют выбрать из 1-4 бригадоров, техника которых заранее предопределена и оружие с оборудованием предустановлены.
 
"фриланс"тут всё за деньги, около 50и пилотов и вся доступная техника в игре, задания те же что и в компании но доступ к ним ограничивается размером Вашего кошелька, тут мы уже можем разгуляться на полную, единственное ограничение связанно с вооружением которое подходит не на все виды креплений. Выбор пилота и техники кардинально изменяет стиль боя, вид врагов, количество денежных единиц. Например берем:
1.	пилот "Аудитор", машина "Материнская любовь" на задании нас встретят командиры передвигающиеся пешком и турели, даже если мы уничтожим все что можно уничтожить на карте мы по итогу получим 200000.
2.	пилот "Креститель Яков", машина "жулик" на задании нас встретят командиры передвигающиеся на тяжёлой и ультра техники, если поднимите тревогу через несколько секунд в зависимости от вероисповедания Вас поприветствуют в загробном мире, награда в случае выживания и успешного выполнения хотя бы одного задания 10000000.

Отдельное спасибо за аудио исполнение, чудные треки в сочетании с атмосферой игры убеждают мой мозг думать что где то в этом мире мрачного будущего солдат Тодд спасает мирное население Аркадии, офицер Кей киснет на лестнице, а слёзы лучшего из людей навсегда затеряются в дожде…

author: {'steamid': '76561197973866497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 834, 'last_played': 1710218787}
review:
"Brigador" is a game that I've long wanted to dig into but never quite made the time. After rectifying that mistake, I've learned that the world is lush, and the excellent audiobook, albums, visual design, and other trappings all serve to flesh it out well - with some caveats.

The story telling in-game is not voiced, and can lend itself to being dense at an average glance. Additionally, that engrossing lore is the thing keeping it all together, but it can seem daunting to break into from afar. Think less "Telltale games", and more original "Armored Core" in regards to narrative delivery.

One other complaint is that after the great 1st few missions things do "initially" slow down due to the types of weapons you're tasked with piloting. They do pick back up as the world begins to open up, but average players could be deterred by the slower mech piloting differences. It is certainly not a narrative choice I would have made, but overall "Brigador" keeps up with the best of 90's isometric gaming and easily surpasses them in other detail oriented ways.

If you let yourself sink into its grimy, morally dubious, steelpunk world, the lean campaign, diverse mechs, solid keyboard controls, and amazing world-building will reward you with an experience that is both classic, and comforting all the same time. 

Welcome to Solo Nobre, Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967387883', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 1228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1658326228}
review: Very fun game, has an official/legal built in "cheating" system by design where you can actually have unlimited ammo and do a bunch of other stuff to help you have a lesser challenging experience if you feel like it, which I actually loved and enjoyed, hence the reason I unlocked almost all the achievements in only 20 hours of play. All you have to do is press F1 in game and it should open the development console/menu where you can toggle godmode, invisibility, infinite ammo, change maps etc if I remember right, so the developer actually wanted people to have access to such abilities if they felt like it, and I liked it. The only downside is once you have access to all those options making your game much easier, you get bored really quick as you just run through it in no time and kind of don't want to go back to it, but I am totally fine with that as I almost never replay the same game twice anyway unless it's some sort of an RPG or what not, but ya, give this one a try.

review: Bought on heavy discount and finished the campaign at around 25 hours, playing V 1.63. Would've bought full price if I had known earlier. Absolute gem of a game. You get to the action quickly and there is 0 bullshit involved. The controls are a bit difficult to get used to (I use mouse and keyboard) but you learn to make your vehicle dance soon enough. I ended up preferring heavy mechs and agravs with one hard hitting weapon and one complimentary weapon, but I use power armour often too. Still have many many hours of content ahead of me. Love that the game rewards you for being prudent and thinking your moves, there's no timer or time bonus so take your time to maneuver to an ideal position. Hope the devs find a way to make the game suited to multiplayer because it isn't right now unless they made it just co-op. My only complaint would be that the menu music gets old after this many hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068977089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 5921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3251, 'last_played': 1695954162}
review:
Brigador is a game that feels like it was made for me. It has a dark science fiction universe that feels almost eerily grounded and realistic. It is a tank/mech/weapons platform lovers dream with unique designs and loads of lore to back it up. The gameplay seems simple on the surface but has just enough depth to spend 10s of hours improving and trying new play styles. 
The graphics are nothing to write home about but the design and look is interesting enough make you forget that. 
The campaign is great at introducing the mechanics and teaching you how to master them without saying much. 
The acqusitions tab provides a place to get lost in the story of the world, the pilots you play as, and even the background of how the vehicles and weapons came to be. The lore feels inspired by dune, battletech, cyberpunk, maschinsen krieger, and even the real life history of CIA intervention in south america.
The freelance mode provides almost endless replayability, allowing you to tinker with so many vehicles, weapons, and scenarios. 
I cannot recommend this game enough.

review:
勉强能玩但完全不有趣。
美术风格很好，音乐也还不错。操作手感也就到不难受这个等级。
客制化要素看起来很多，其实基本没有。而且剧情模式不能客制（剧情模式也没剧情就是了）
以双摇杆射击来说很罕见的采用了射程概念，弹药有限，敌人还有高度，不能朝着大概的方向而是要去瞄准。这点严重损害了爽快感。加上障碍物很多而机体很难撞穿导致的进展迟缓，文案中充斥的战争罪在画面和音效里没什么表现等等。感觉就是个为了刷而刷的游戏。

author: {'steamid': '76561198298031621', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1692235022}

author: {'steamid': '76561198279498123', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 1980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1980, 'last_played': 1692088211}
review:
30h全战役完成。

略有亮点的俯视角射击游戏。

你是跨星际企业的佣兵，力所能及地在索罗洛布列大开杀戒，所以你在游戏里的目标就只有一个：摧毁——要么任务是摧毁敌人首领，要么任务就是摧毁特定建筑物，任务大同小异，玩久了立马疲惫，此外，越到后面任务越阴间，经常是给个破烂机甲让你去面对七八十个敌人，最后一关敌人多到头皮发麻，没活了就硬堆怪。

剧情除了在档案选项里出现的文档、开头的两句话以及任务装备下的介绍，就没有了，除非自己闲的没事打开档案看个几十分钟，否则估计对于整体世界框架一无所知，剧情存在感太薄弱，任务后续同质化严重，除非很喜欢炸炸炸的感觉，这个游戏我觉没有什么可以吸引玩家继续玩下去。

除去以上的缺点之外，我觉得其他的都是优点，几十种载具可供选择，多种武器多种类别，不同的武器带来的穿透力与弹道是不一样的，武器的表现力与力量感非常好，88mm炮穿透贫民窟的铁皮房一炮击毁敌方载具的感觉与众不同，弹链炮如雨泼出，305mm迫击炮从空中给予毁灭，机甲的厚重、悬浮平台的灵巧、动力骨骼的敏捷、坦克的力量，竟被一个一G左右的游戏完美的体现了出来，坦克操控模式更是提升了一个档次的沉浸感，除去战役任务固定载具使用，你可以开随机合约，自由选择驾驶员，按照喜好挑选载具、配置武装，在随机地图上用弹坑肆意涂抹。

画面玩法宣传图所见即所得，这个游戏虽然后期无力，但是依然不错，值得一玩。

review: The smaller your mech is, the more money you get, which just completely destroys the entire 'im a big bad ass mech' fantasy that this game should invoke. If you think about other mech games like MechWarrior, then you're allowed to play a small/medium/large mech, but you're not limited on the payout based on what mech you choose, so you can choose fast+nimble which is difficult to hit, or large+armored which will get hit easily but can take a beating, and you receive the same payout on both... but in this game, the smaller and shizttier your mech is, the more payout you get, which is just stupid. The tutorial is also really bad and doesn't explain anything wrt. hardpoints or mech size or payout or pilot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965521837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 2709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2709, 'last_played': 1680400274}
review:
You play videogames to relieve stress, see shit from the outside what a studio thinks about a subject. Kojima thinks that nuclear weaponary is bad and with the power of stinger missiles, one well trained man can defeat a 45 billion dollar robot.

Brigador is about how it feels to be a part of sacking Rome. The northmen destroyed vital infrastructure, the reservoirs, cut off the city from outside contact, cornered & slowly killed defenders from a country eating itself with corruption.

It's an isometric Mech Game, with the artstyle of Mechwarrior Tactics with the graphics of today. Hop on a mech, (i recommend something Heavy starting out) Destroy vital infrastructure, engage in optional, but hard to avoid warcrimes and conquer this planet in the name of the Solo Nobre Concern.

Oh and buy the Audiobook, it's great. I bought the thing about a week before Stellar Jockeys decided to release Half of it for free on Youtube. Don't care, absolutely worth it.

Really good soundtrack from Makeup & Vanity Set too. Shoulda played this sooner for sure, Brigador Killers is next, and i can't wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967767593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1689195080}
review:
Je dois dire que d'habitude, ce genre de jeu me lasse assez rapidement. Et j'avoue que là...
...hé bien c'est aussi le cas :-P
Ceci étant dit, même si ce n'est pas mon type de jeu préféré, il faut reconnaître qu'il est tout de même bien réalisé.
Sans casser 3 pattes à un canard, il remplit sa fonction première, à savoir; un petit défouloir vaguement technique.

Pour résumer rapidement, voici ce qu'il propose:
On part en mission, qui deviennent plus ou moins difficile à mesure qu'on les débloque, et qui se décline en plusieurs étapes 3, 5, ...etc... 12, ou plus...
On gagne de l'argent, ce qui nous permet d'acheter les services des pilotes disponibles, lesquels sont plus ou moins bons selon les 5 ou 6 bonus que la fiche "pilote" propose.
Avec ce même argent, nous déloquerons aussi les véhicules, leur armes, ainsi que d'acheter/débloquer des missions plus avancées.

3 Type de véhicules: Mecha, tank, hovercraft. Tous aussi moches les uns que les autres.
Vous pouvez équiper les véhicules avec 2 armes, parmi un choix assez varié qui se décline comme arme:
Lourde, intermédiaire, légère, missile ou motier

Sur les cartes, les objectifs sont systématiquement les mêmes:
Entrer sur la carte

Péter des tours
Péter tours, mais d'un autre type
Péter des tours de ravitaillement
Péter un certain nombre de véhicules ennemis
Péter les "capitaines" qui sont des véhicules plus costaud
Sortir et passer soit à l'étape suivante, soit à la caisse, merci $$$

Puis on choisira une autre mission, et on recommence la même chose.

Difficile? Non!
Punitif? Oui! 

La difficulté principale réside en une seule situation. Se trouver à côté d'un élément explosif lorsqu'il pète à cause d'un tir perdu de l'AI. Sans cela, je n'ai jamais été inquiété.
Une citerne cachée? BOOM
Et là, si vous étiez sur une mission à 12 étapes, et que vous en étiez à la onzième - retour case départ...
Alors on se fera chi*r à refaire les 11 étapes soporifiques, soit répéter 11 fois les actions citées ci-dessus, pour pouvoir effectuer ces mêmes actions à la 12ème étape pour encaisser l'argent. Puis recommencer sur une nouvelle mission.

Voilà voilà...

Ah si, il faut aussi gérer vos munitions. Je n'en ai jamais manqué, et il y a des tours pour ravitailler au max une seule fois. Alors ça devrait passer sans problème si vous savez viser. Sinon tampis pour vous, il faudra finir au corps-à-corps.

Sinon bon, en utilisant le hovercraft, j'ai eu un vague souvenir plaisant de l'époque d'un certain jeu qui se jouait à bord d'un hélico,en vue de dessus il y a 25 ans+-...J'me rapelle plus le titre...dommage j'y rejouerais bien :-P

Les 2 musiques qui accompagnent le jeu sont sympa.
La traduction est correcte pour ceux qui ne parlent pas anglais, et combien même, même un anglais basique suffira, cela d'autant plus que les bonus et informations lisibles sont visuellement explicites.

Enfin pour conclure je dois voter en négatif et la raison en ai la suivante:
En aucune façon, le jeu ne peut justifier le prix de 22€
Toutes les cartes se ressemblent, la seule différence réside dans les unités que vous rencontrerez, et la dispositions des "tours à péter" sur les cartes.

Par conséquent, du contenu, il n'y en a PAS. Le développement se résume à pondre une boucle de jeu sur une carte, puis d'ajouter des étapes, sur ces mêmes cartes, pour justifier d'un niveau supérieur??? Ah non mes amis, ça ce n'est pas du contenu.
J'ai acheté le jeu à 8€, et j'ai tout de même hésiter à me faire rembourser, même comme j'ai apprécié de faire péter des bâtiments pendant un peu plus de 2 heures, ce n'était plus possible :-P

Edit: Desert Strike (1992) puis Jungle Strike 1993. Puis les suivants étaient moins bien.
Mais ils proposaient au moins aussi bien que Brigador, et plus de variété dans les objectifs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074788581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1689055715}
review: This is a tepid recommendation. It's a good game, but is extremely monotonous with some frustrating controls. Every mission is some variation on kill x number of loyalists or destroy x number of structures. Rinse and repeat for every single of this game's 37 missions. This is too many IMO for what's offered. There is little to no story in game. The audiobook is external media that must be purchased separately and therefore does not count. Instead of allowing you to pick whichever vehicle you want to take into the mission, you must select 1 of 4 options presented. This really sucks since you may not enjoy playing as any of the four you're provided. The final missions were especially frustrating due to me personally not liking any of the vehicles. Freelance mode remedies this by allowing you to pick whatever you want. Movement is awkward regardless of control scheme. Vehicles control somewhat realistically, so moving backwards is much slower than moving forward and in the heat of the moment, trying to avoid getting shot can be a hassle. Aiming is especially awkward since you only vaguely get an idea on where you're aiming. Weapons with an arc pattern are awful to aim with since the angle makes it hard to determine where your shot will land. The isometric perspective is more troublesome than helpful. 90% of my deaths came from me not realizing I was too close to some object and firing an explosive weapon killing myself or at least removing the majority of my health. The game doesn't try to show when your shot is being blocked. Dying due to some explosive structure going off next to you cause of an aggressive enemy spraying away is annoying especially with late game missions taking much longer and being more difficult. I enjoyed the tactical/stealth approach to the design. It's not just a straight up twin stick shooter. There's great enemy variety and the levels are dense with fully destructible buildings everywhere. The visuals are gorgeous. The lighting and color scheme give it a cyberpunk aesthetic I really dig. The spritework is incredibly detailed and well animated. Couple that with an excellent soundtrack from synthwave artist Vanity & Makeup Set and it's a feast for the ears and eyes. Weapons feel powerful and sound punchy. There's a huge number of playable characters each with their own vehicle that looks and handles differently. From quick glass cannon stealth mechs to slow towering tanks decimating everything in its path, there's something for everyone. Despite the overwhelmingly positive reviews here on Steam, most people haven't actually completed the campaign. My super rare trophy for completing some late game missions make that very apparent. That's understandable given the game's overall high difficulty. I do enjoy Brigador and recommend it, but it could've benefited with more mission variety, some boss fights and more in-game story for better context on what's happening. A better aiming scheme would've helped alleviate some frustration too. None of the playable characters have any actual "character" to them. It's a game that started strong, but lost its luster with me over time. Regardless, it's clearly a labor of love and brought back memories of playing Future Cop LAPD and MechCommander as a kid, and that's never a bad thing. (7/10)

review:
Wow. I came into this looking for an action packed top-down shooter and this game absolutely delivers on that itch... and way more. 

There are so many different vehicles and weapons that handle and play so differently. Some options are absolutely more powerful than others and that's honestly part of the fun. There were stealthy sniper builds, hit and run builds, run and gun builds, moving fortress builds, and every flavor in between. It scratched my itch for chaotic shooter action and for something far more tactical, and I think that the variety of different gameplay styles has kept my interest alive far longer than I was planning for. Some vehicles can feel clunky to control in exchange for speed or defense, but I really appreciated how each vehicle felt like it had a place it was best suited for. The controls will take some effort (and maybe an extra mouse button or two) to master, so just be aware not every vehicle can be operated without effort (but some definitely can).

Oh, and if you love the presentation and dystopian sci fi, this game nails it with some fascinating and meticulously written lore--but you can skip practically all of this if you don't want to do tons of reading.

One of my favorite games ever and totally unexpected. Can't wait for the next game in the series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024661985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1689409842}
review:
This game is so freaking fun that its mind boggling I just heard about it recently. Its very easy to get completely sucked into the game and lose track of the amount of time you have been playing. The campaign is pretty fun with the different scenarios it will throw you into, but it can get pretty hard if you are trying to rush through things without properly learning the mechanics of the different types of vehicles available to you. The "freelance" mode is the real meat and potatoes of the game and where you will likely spend the majority of your time. You can either go with a behemoth of a mech and absolutely obliterate everything with the most powerful weapons in the game, or you can set yourself up on a literal tuk-tuk truck with machine guns strapped to the side and zip through the map praying you make it out alive. 

Very fun game - would highly recommend to people who like fun games.

review:
Kann man sich mal anschauen und anspielen, es ist aber – abgesehen von den fantastischen Zerstörungsmöglichkeiten der Gebäude – nichts Besonderes.

Hübsch explodierende Pixeloptik auf die Augen gleicht den Rest nur bedingt aus, auf 100 % hatte ich dann keine Lust mehr, obwohl ich alles im Arsenal freigeschaltet habe. Die Geschichte wird dort beinahe komplett über recht eintönige Datenbank-Texteinträge erzählt, die meist Hintergrundinformationen enthalten. Immerhin macht die Musik gut Laune aufs Herumballern!

Am Ende wird es extrem schwer, was ich nicht wirklich gut fand. Denn die Entwickler haben sogar direkt in die normalen Spieleinstellungen mehrere Cheat-Möglichkeiten eingebaut, welche ich dann auch ausgiebig nutzen musste. Schade, dass man ein Spiel so gestalten muss.

Achievements: 90 %

review: This is a good pick if you're a fan of the Strike series (Desert Strike, Jungle Strike, Urban Strike, Nuclear Strike). Controls takes a while to get comfortable but still I find myself getting confused when the action is frantic. Plenty of options to get the experience you want including game speed.  Campaign mode is a series of loosely connected missions with preset pilot, vehicles, and weapons. The game is generous when it comes to earning in-game funds to unlock pilots, vehicles, and weapons for freelance mode. For me, the game comes together when I bust through a building and unload a 105mm shell nearly point blank into the side of a tank and stomp its dismounted infantry into red paste.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029894415', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 1424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1424, 'last_played': 1682896806}
review:
Mech games usually aren't on my radar, but a funny man wearing a metal helmet told me that this was a hidden gem, so I tried it. I had fun for the first 10-15 hours as I learned the mechanics and weapon setups, but after that my enjoyment fell off a cliff when I realized how completely wack the balance is, and how much of a grind the final achievements were. I had enough of a good time to give a soft recommendation, but I don't think this quite hits the "hidden masterpiece" criteria it was advertised as... and I can definitely see how initial sales could be poor, especially if earlier versions were even more unbalanced. 

The story in Brigador is top tier. After the death of an influential and (arguably) stabilizing leader, a megacorp mass-contracts the planet's local mercenary population to cause as much havoc as possible within a 24 hour window, and extract off-planet before local security forces can stabilize and mount a proper defense. Collateral damage and civilian casualties are not only tolerated, but actively encouraged. You're straight up being paid to be a war criminal and nobody cares; the megacorp doesn't care, the pilots don't care, the player doesn't care. The entire planet is your sandbox to smash around and get paid millions for, and I love it. 

The art style is a bit weird and uncanny, which is both good and bad. Environments look really good and virtually everything is destructible, but the maps can get cluttered fast, especially in dense urban environments where you're tripping over every single pebble just to move around. 

Getting into Brigador can seem daunting; there are 5 tiers of weapons classes (with 8 different weapon choices per tier), 4 active systems, 3 different factions each with 3 different mech types, and an enormous selection of mechs in between. The game throws a lot at you all at once, and while the tutorial helps a bit, it's very slow and has a bad habit of sticking you on mechs with terrible weapon loadouts... less so in the earlier missions, but definitely more so on the later ones I'm assuming were added in the Up-Armoured addition. So let me try to break it down:


Mechs - There are three types: walkers, tanks, and hovercraft. Walkers have the ability to crouch and lower their profile (I think this is also supposed to reduce damage, but I found that dodging hits is better than trying to tank them), and are most affected by terrain. Tanks tend to have lower profiles, and are still affected by terrain but usually have speed boosts to help them out. Hovercraft can ignore passive terrain but are still blocked by buildings & hard obstacles, which greatly diminishes their utility, as they tend to be squishier and have generally worse weapon options.

Mechs can range from giant death machines to tiny powersuits.  There's an enormous range of classes per mech & faction subtype, with the smaller ones generally being harder & with worse weapon loadouts, but give better post-mission payouts. Note that being in smaller mechs doesn't necessarily equate to them being faster than bigger ones.

As a point of personal preference, I find medium-heavy tanks to perform the best out of all available mech types. Walkers are fine but tend to be slow, more affected by terrain, and with a dubious active ability. Hovercraft tend to be too squishy and ignoring terrain isn't as handy an ability as one might hope. I found that the Brokenheart tank was the most efficient platform in the game; sports a heavy & main weapon slot, lower size profile, good speed, and very nice staying power for aggressive players, to the point where I could clear entire maps in hyper-aggressive brawls and come out victorious... albeit sometimes barely. Anything larger tends to be too slow, and anything smaller tends to be too squishy & with lesser weaponry. 


Weapons - Ranging from Heavy, Main, Auxiliary, Turret, and Small. Basically the smaller you go, the worse the weapons are, with very few exceptions. Smaller mechs tend to wield smaller weapons but again there are exceptions, for example the Sledge is a powersuit walker that's basically a heavy weapon on legs. These are further sub-divided into 4 weapon categories: cannons, ballistics, explosives, and lasers, with two options each per weapon type. These all vary greatly in what they do, but they tend to vary between a rapid-fire options and a slower use but more powerful option. 

I would say that weapon usability is the single greatest point of contention for this game. A bad mech can be made good with a proper weapon, but a good mech can be virtually worthless with bad ones. And there are a LOT of bad ones, personally I find anything below Main-class weapons to be not worth their time, especially when it comes to ballistic options. A lot of them tend to be too hyper-specific, like dealing purely with shields or armour. Anything regarding mortars is basically too slow to be used with reasonable consistently, and Auxiliary ballistics and below tend to not be worth their weight in salt. These problems tend to be compounded on storyline missions where you have no choice on what you can equip.

In my experience, it's usually best to have a powerful rapid-fire weapon, and a secondary that either helps deal with crowds or single-target damage. Thus, enter the Konig and the Zeus. The Konig is Brigador's perfect weapon; incredible damage against everything, huge range, handles both light & heavy targets, lots of dakka... frankly able to solo the entire game just by itself. It struggles to penetrate cover and quickly take down super-heavies, which is where the Zeus comes in: instant-hit railgun, penetrates every type of cover imaginable, excellent single-target damage with a bit of AOE. These two weapons form basically the perfect combination, and the Brokenheart can field both... you can see why it's my favourite mech of the game. Barring the Kraken, which has a bit less damage and anti-swarm damage than the Konig but WAY better cover penetration, the Konig sets the president for what a good weapon SHOULD be, and everything else tends to fall way flat. 


Special Abilities are unlimited-use special abilities with timed cooldowns:
-Smoke is the most useless s*** in existence, creating too small an AOE that dissipates too fast vs enemies that move far too quickly. No offensive utility. This really needed to be changed/improved, like allowing the player to hide in the smoke rather than only having it affect enemies.
-Active Camouflage doesn't really help unless you're in a very small mech, enemies tend to swarm you and know your exact location anyway.
-EMP has great crowd control but a punishingly long cooldown. The devs value this WAY too highly and virtually any story mech that has this on it is guaranteed to have inferior weaponry. 
-Audio-Kinetic Pulse does everything. It stuns, deals massive area damage instantly, levels buildings & terrain to dust (a lot of harder difficulty deaths come from getting stuck on terrain when facing swarming enemies), and has a reasonably short cooldown. There's really no reason to use anything else.


To conclude, Brigador is good, but gets worse over time when you realize how bad most of the weapons are, and how few ACTUAL choices you have for usable mech loadouts. For a game that's supposedly received so many updates since launch, I'm astonished that the weapon & ability balancing is still so off. It's by no means a masterpiece, and there's a MASSIVE jump in difficulty between the initial story missions and what was added in the Up-Armoured updates. But I did get pretty close to a 1-to-1, hours-to-dollars rate, and had a good time for the first 10 - 15 hours, so I'm happy enough to give it a soft recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055008956', 'num_games_owned': 1315, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1698381328}
review:
The difficulty spike in the campaign is insane. Played 25-30 missions no problem. I'm like 4-5 from the end and it's BRUTAL all of a sudden. You get one life, you can't heal your health, the mech choices are all garbage mechs, and there 100-150 enemies in a map the size of a football field, you can't it any easier, no check points. It just sucks. I'm probably gonna quit the game as a result of this. You have to crawl through maps to reach the end near the end and even then it's not a sure thing. Shoot one enemy and 35 of them rush you. There's no middle ground, I've either stomped through the levels with almost zero challenge, or 200 of them attack you in a closet.

STEAM still needs a middling review. The game plays fine, looks great, and has tons of mechs. It's just the difficulty balance is non existent. If you like the idea of banging your head against the wall for 1-2 hours to finish one level by grinding away it, by all means.
developer_response:
Apologies that you're having a hard time with it, but the E and F set missions were community made levels specifically designed as challenge maps for hardcore players. At the time we had players maxing everything out on Freelance mode and completing Closed Casket Specials, so we let the community build out a final level set for themselves.

 There's plenty of advice in the discussion forums on how to complete them, and if it's specifically an achievement thing then you can just turn on god mode in the settings menu—we don't deactivate cheevo logging from any of the in-game "exploits".

author: {'steamid': '76561197995244070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1708040455}
review:
Brigador is the game I never knew I wanted or needed. It wins on both the gameplay and presentation fronts: a combat vehicle pseudo-simulator in an isometric 2D world with gorgeous and detailed artwork, rippling firepower at your disposal and oodles of destruction to inflict while accompanied by a well-crafted synthwave soundtrack.

The campaign and the freelance mode both present a sort of destructible sandbox, one where you get leeway to experiment with your playstyle. A good run or mission will see you blasting your way through scores of enemies, smashing buildings as you go and using the inherent chaos of battle to your advantage--if you can play smart enough, that is. Mastering the quirks of your mech, tank, or a-grav craft is key to inflicting maximum destruction before you run out of ammo or get ground down to death.

The plot and lore are unobtrusive, but they're still there for those who are intrigued. The setting itself definitely makes me want to dive in deeper. I want to know more about this sci-fi pseudo-cyberpunk planetary war story the developer has crafted.

If you're a fan of BattleTech, Command & Conquer, Warhammer 40K, or any other strategic sci-fi thing, Brigador should be exactly your jam. If you still need convincing, just go watch MandaloreGaming's video. I know that sold me on playing through this, and I'm still not done with all the game's content.

review:
The game is great. The overall writing is good, but the campaign is really not coherent and there is no story, which is a shame because the game includes a ton of fluff and information. Hopefully it will be developed in a sequel.
A string of missions with some text do not make a coherent narrative, in that regard the game is similar to Syndicate, but Syndicate is a 30 years old game and we have come to expect something more when it comes to storytelling in video games.
Still, get this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197984568819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2364, 'last_played': 1679528154}
review:
I am deeply conflicted about Brigador.

Brigador is an excellently-made isometric sprite-graphic vehicular combat simulation. It oozes style and backs it up with substance. The controls are highly-responsive and, I think, quite good, considering the deliberate inclusion of tank controls for tank and legs units.

The lore poses questions about community prosperity versus individual escape from the grind, about whether it is better to live in an isolationist dictatorship or under the crushing weight of capitalism. It asks: would you ruin the lives of your community to escape? Would you make everything worse for everyone for freedom?

Two years ago from the time of writing, give or take, one of the authors of this work was discovered posting essentially every flavor of bigoted remark it was possible to make by posters on SomethingAwful, a dead comedy web forum, on a different, lesser-known forum.

The Monahan brother responsible apologized, and gave the usual boilerplate do-better nothing-apology and suspended his involvement with Stellar Jockeys.

Today, he is once again listed on staff and is regularly posting development updates for their next game, Brigador Killers.

I can't refund this game. I owned it long before that extremely unfortunate news came to light. Moreover, I LIKE Brigador, which is incredibly frustrating, as you might guess from the giant red thumbs-down at the top of this review.

Brigador is great! I can't recommend anyone purchase it. I love the characters! Every single one is now shadowed by the racist, sexist, anti-semitic, transphobic remarks of one of the pivotal members responsible for their creation.

Has Mr. Monahan grown in the two years since? I don't know. It's impossible for me to know. If he learned anything, I'm sure he learned to stop using the same username everywhere.

With that in mind, if you must try Brigador, I advise you to do so through methods that do not require you to pay for it, like library-sharing.As for me, maybe now that I've put all these thoughts down and added my drop to the bucket, I can finally run into exploding pipes with some measure of peace.

review:
É simples, muito simples: escolha seu veículo, suas armas, seu piloto, e então sente o dedo em todo mundo num cenário que se despedaça completamente.
E é divertido. Muito divertido!
Sua experiência de jogo é grandemente afetada por esses três fatores citados acima. Jogue do jeito que quiser. Não há certo ou errado aqui. Seja você um Rambo ou ninja, se divertirá causando o caos nas tropas inimigas.
E o jogo é isso, e cumpre muito bem seu papel. Surpreendentemente bem, eu diria.
Pra não dizer que é perfeito, só senti falta de uma maior variedade de missões. Não há escolta, perseguições ou resgate de reféns.
Meu sonho? Se ele tivesse o sistema de mecânicas e missões da série Strike (Desert Strike, Urban Strike, Jungle Strike, entre outros) eu juro: não ia mais conseguir sair do PC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180648210', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1681936596}
review:
优点是氛围渲染做的不错，但是实际体验实在是一言难尽
这个操作手感在使用厚重和炮台载具时还是不错的，但当使用灵活的浮游车和固定朝向载具简直是灾难，无论是坦克模式还是绝对模式都很难受，只有在敌人手里这些载具才能发挥出最大的功效。
而灵活敌人的存在更是加剧了瞄准线导致的偏差，很多时候感觉自己瞄准了实际上射空的情况数不胜数，这个精度要求对于一个45°视角的游戏实在是...有点太高了，并不是不能玩，只是在瞄了半天之后射空的感觉真的很不爽，这还是使用键鼠操作的时候，难以想象这游戏要怎么样用手柄玩...
对重装侦察兵有莫名其妙的执着，这个警报机制设计的完全不明所以，城市被炸了大半没人知道，超远程蹭一下重甲侦察兵就全图通报了，有一种在GTA5里潜入的美，只能说是恶心
忽略掉操作蹩脚... 瞄准难受...警报弱智...看整个城市陷入一片火海或者是用光学迷彩小车潜入点杀任务目标也是挺不错的，不过还是不推荐玩，买个地狱潜者不好吗？

review: This is an awesome mech game! Be sure to play through most of the campaign, it's necessary to learn the important mechanics of the game, allows to play some builds with a variety of play-styles, and gives you some money to unlock your favorite play-style first in freelance. Don't feel obligated to complete the whole campaign before messing around with freelance, and keep in mind that there are a lot of missions that were added post release. The last few missions in the campaign place you into a nearly impossible map only offer some very tricky builds to clear it. I haven't even been able to beat those missions without cheating, so be sure to dive into freelance once you feel like you're done with the campaign.

review:
This game is like a blend of Syndicate (the visual style, perspective and somewhat similar tactical shooter action), X-Com: Apocalypse (the huge city full of destructible environments that are technically 2D but so detailed it still looks like there's depth), a bit of Shogo: M.A.D. perhaps (the stompy blasty mechs, crazy weapons and panicking civilians)... and then the music and the wide variety of horns? Very, very nice.

The story is pretty dark and there isn't really a "nice person" way to play, but in the end, this is fictional violence. If it helps people blow off steam without harming any real people, all the better. You do get to blow stuff up and can destroy vast swathes of industry, mansions and whatnot as you see fit (or focus on the main targets), and there are loads of weapons and vehicles to try out. All good stuff.

There's also some interesting lore to unlock as you play, lots of options to customize your experience in the freelance mode after you play through the story missions (or you can skip or postpone those; whatever you prefer, really).

An awesome tactical action game for many reasons. Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198216532999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 891, 'last_played': 1708748620}
review:
用各种火力倾泻在敌人身上，从他们的尸体上补充护盾和弹药，并且无视掉被你波及化为残骸的街道。你正和你的座驾合为一体。
配合合成乐的回响（我确定你能在商店页面的预览视频里听到他们，真™棒），枪火轰鸣，你径直穿过一栋建筑任由它在身后支离破碎。你只想完成目标，对被破坏的城市与它粘在你装甲上的住客们漠不关心。
有点像是十几年前网络还不那么发达的时候，你翻找到的一部老科幻录像带。最好是赛璐璐的日本动画。它里面的想象瑰丽，霓虹闪烁，夜色昏暗，血肉模糊，满盈着硝烟与光污染。
不开灯，由着自己在昏暗的客厅里面对电视度过夜晚，面前也许有烟和酒，也许有点别的什么。你不在乎。
此刻的一切都让你感觉很享受。
对我来说叛击士就是这样的一种趣味。

author: {'steamid': '76561198089139880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1075, 'last_played': 1699901099}
review:
"War criminal - the game"

If you're into mechs and destructible environments, you're gonna love this game.

Once you've played a dozen missions and start caring about the lore, you're going to find out about the hidden depths of what is going on on Solo Novo.

The gameplay may seem at first like a generic twin-stick shooter, but that's far from how you play it, too.

The music and lighting are superb, each mech handles differently, the effects of gunfire and explosions are awesome, and you really have to play tactically, or you are going to get bumrushed by the enemy.
The Freelance mode is awesome, but finish the campaign first, so you can get a handle of each category of vehicle and weapons.

And if you're into the lore, get the accompanying audiobook, it's superb.

WELCOME, BRIGADOR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149259568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1710500625}
review:
Hissing pistons and the lowly thump of cannon fire hardly disturbed “8 Ball”, his unblinking eyes welded to the viewing scope. He had almost bitten the cigar planted firmly in his creased mouth a couple streets back, after a Corvid Rat King had slung two 140mm “Bishop” rounds as he rounded a corner.

The multi-storey apartment next to him had taken most of the brunt of the shot, the shields of 8 Balls Touro mech taking the remaining shrapnel with little trouble. The gaping hole left in the apartment next to him, had fared worse, the remains of the few families left living this side of town, decorating the demolished fragments of their home with blood and viscera. 

It wasn't the gore. Spending enough time pulverizing the local bandit populous through the scope of a 80 tonnes of hissing, pounding steel tended to dull the nauseating reaction of watching a human being turned inside out by a gamma ray.  8 Ball had plenty of that experience. No, this was seething hatred. Gritted teeth, white knuckle, hatred. 

8 Ball continued around the block, counting on the Corvids to set their guns south, from where was originally engaged, or west, the direction of the road he had headed when he was first engaged by the Corvid ultra mech. 

He weaved his controls around the rows of apartment flats and neon dive bars, his knee bouncing on his mechs trigger in anticipation. As he rounded the final corner, only a 4 storey office, no doubt filled with squatters, stood between him and the stench of Corvid mech. 

To the Corvids, the air had ignited as the building their Rat King was posted next to vaporized in a cloud of concrete dust and previous inhabitants. The sonic blast was followed by the visual of a Loyalist mech breaching the dust cloud, heavy gamma blasts making quick work of their cobbled together shields. The mech bore a large round black spot on its hull, a distinctive “8”, legible for a split second, before the heavy cannon fire breached the cockpit.

As the massive mech's legs gave out, the wave of Corvid crewmen scattered like roaches from its hull. 8 Ball powered through the tangled mess of car chassis and cannibalized mech systems, a firm foot of the Touro landing on the gunners section, sending a distinctive red splash up the side of its left leg. He quickly re-orientated the mech, finally biting the cigar in half as his foot planted on the trigger, the gamma ray vaporizing the fleeing crew. 

After hunting down and watching the final remnants of the crew invert their torsos, 8 Ball turned back south, and went hunting once again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025478065', 'num_games_owned': 736, 'num_reviews': 355, 'playtime_forever': 950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1682777075}
review:
[h1]L'un de mes coups de cœur de la décennie[/h1]

Attention aux impressions trompeuses, Brigador n'est pas un twin stick shooter. Les contrôles sont plus complexes que ça, notamment parce qu'il y a la distance à prendre en compte. 
N'essayez pas de jouer à la manette et mettez les contrôles en relatif (comme si pour une voiture téléguidée).

Pour simplifier, le but de Brigador est de tout faire péter, mais en finesse.
On a accès à trois familles de véhicules : mecha (idéal pour les embuscades), tank (lent, bourrin et robuste) et aéroglisseur (rapide mais fragile) et deux armes disponibles (utilisées par le clic gauche et le clic droit) parmi beaucoup : mitrailleuses, cannons, lasers, railguns, gaz corrosifs, shotguns, mortiers etc.
Notre véhicule a une armure (irréparable) et un bouclier (rechargeable et même surchargeable pour une durée limitée). Les ennemis abattus laissent tomber des recharges de munition et de bouclier qui disparaissent au bout de quelques secondes. Il faut donc prioriser selon la situation. Se dépêcher d'aller les récupérer au risque de s'exposer au feu ennemi ? Ou éliminer toute menace d'abord ?

L'action est incroyablement jouissive et la grande variété d'armes et de véhicules fait qu'on ne s'ennuie pas et nous force à changer de stratégie selon les situations. La plupart du temps l'action se déroule dans des environnements urbains et on peut se servir des bâtiments pour se cacher, se protéger ou carrément passer à travers pour surprendre l'ennemi.
Les graphismes sont plaisants, la musique (de la synthwave) est sublime et l'univers bien travaillé.
Le jeu comporte une grosse campagne avec une bonne variété de niveaux, avec des missions bonus (certaines sont assez frustrantes en étant trop longues et difficiles) et un mode freelance où on peut paramétrer son véhicule dans des missions customs.

Brigador est un jeu unique en son genre. En tout cas je n'ai jamais joué à un jeu similaire.
