author: {'steamid': '76561198019039303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1036, 'last_played': 1702861384}
review:
I enjoyed the time I had playing Brigador very much, and I hate to say it but I wish there was a mixed review option. 

Brigador is fun, full stop. From lumbering around in a walker and enacting war crimes that would see me hung if video game crimes were real, to accidentally blowing myself and my poor little tank into the next city block after incorrectly gauging the fire arc of my howitzer, this game is insanely fun. I would finish my daily run and let out a breath I didn't realize I was holding, relieved to be finshing one run and eager to go for another. 

The art direction is fantastic, portraying a sometimes gritty, sometimes glitzy, always eye-catching idea of an off-planet science fiction future hellscape. The music complements the action and gameplay in an excellent way; I am a player who usually listens to my own music while playing other video games, but I never felt the need to do that playing Brigador. 

If you are playing on Windows, I highly, highly recommend the game. If you find yourself in the unenviable position of playing it on MacOS, like I find myself, I would hold off. Currently there is a problem getting the game to launch, where reinstalling the game or rolling back to a previous version of the game does not solve this issue. I suspect it more has to do with a recent MacOS update, but I digress; if you are playing on a Mac, I would check to see if this issue is resolved before buying. Once that's resolved, OR you are playing on Windows, this is a hard, hard recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198919958366', 'num_games_owned': 86, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1260, 'last_played': 1675767838}
review:
游戏是好的
但是我在完成最后一关之前一不小心把存档和解锁的剧情设定删掉了
所以评论区有大佬有“无限金币”和“解锁全部关卡”的作弊码吗？孩子想要啊(Q_Q)
developer_response:
很抱歉，我们在这里只能使用机器翻译。 尝试按照这些说明进行操作。 赚大钱：

1.    When Brigador is running, press F1 on your keyboard to open the debug panel, and left click on the MONEY DEBUG tab.
2.    The money slider allows you to adjust the amount of money the player has in the bank. Normally, this slider will only have a range from zero to ten million. Press Ctrl + Left Click on the slider, and you will be able manually enter any value you require.
3.    Press F1 again to close the debug panel.

如果您想解锁游戏中的所有内容，请执行以下操作：

1.    If you wish to access all the game’s content, when Brigador is running, press F1 on your keyboard to open the debug panel and left click on the MAIN tab.
2.    Check the first box marked “devmode” and then press F1 again on your keyboard to close the debug panel.
3.    On the main menu of Brigador, click SETTINGS and scroll down to the bottom of GENERAL - you will see a new option marked UNLOCKS.
4.    Left click to set UNLOCKS to disabled. All content in the game is now accessible from the menus - this means you are free to try any campaign mission, read any lore entry and try any operation and loadout in FREELANCE mode.
5.    Disabled unlocks are only available when devmode is active. Turning off devmode will return the game to the state it was before you disabled UNLOCKS. You will not earn any achievements when devmode is active.

我们希望对您有所帮助

review: A casual mech power trip that gradually reveals depth with stealth focused strategy in later missions and higher difficulty. A decent variety of builds in freelance mission, with the campaign offering a fair few pre-sets to give an overview. I wasn't expecting much from the lore, but the mix of some decent dystopic world building with some sprinkled blackish comedy is a nice read through. Would also recommend the audio-book in the background during missions. The only issue is there are slightly too many tutorials and grind. But I'll give a tip for that last one. Get the Man from Volta or Pilar, get the Seeker vehicle, as it has the highest money multiplier with the best health and mobility. Equip the audio pulse and a short freelance mission. You might fail a  few times, but getting used to it will make you a billionaire fast.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983040117', 'num_games_owned': 1744, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1672379701}
review:
I adore this game. This is a fast-paced isometric game of armored warfare. It has a mix of mechs, tanks, and anti-grav hover units with a mix of heavy to light weaponry. Each craft gets 2 weapons and has varying strengths and weaknesses.

The game has a campaign which is a collection of loose missions acting as a bit of a learning ramp into the game. Maybe the better part of the game is the freelance mode where you choose what vehicle you want and a series of districts to take on. This operates a bit like a roguelike mode with a choose your own difficulty level component based on the vehicle you choose and the pilot (pilots govern how the difficulty ramps up over a set of districts).

In true roguelite manner, missions earn you cash which you can use to unlock more vehicles, districts, weapons, and pilots.

It's a lot of fun - particularly with some anti-frustration features such as unlimited ammo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074037408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1596, 'last_played': 1708289472}
review:
Most war video games either present a good vs evil narrative, a narrative that explores the war in an unbiased manner, or a narrative exploring the horrors it brings.

In Brigador, everyone is a piece of shit, and you play as one of the scum sucking war criminals/blackmail victims that make up the rag tag forces that an amoral megacorporation put together to fight jingoistic douchebags who want to preserve a brutal dictatorship, extremely violent far-left terrorists which are equally brutal and uncaring, and hedonistic space pirates that want to murder/violate/murderously violate everything in sight. And your employer's response to this is to pay you to commit apocalyptic amounts of property damage. That's right baby, you play as one of the bad guys.

Oh, also, music and art direction are gorgeous too, you are absolutely guaranteed to jam to synthwave tunes as you commit war crimes in a neon lit space banana republic.

9/10 would be sent to the Hague again

author: {'steamid': '76561199066359797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4884, 'last_played': 1696541670}
review:
There are few things in life more painful than fucking up a MAX™ difficulty Closed Casket run with your favorite spooky skeleton boi Precursor James after finishing all the Freelance levels. You've already played all the campaign levels multiple times before. You know what you're doing. You feel like a pro, like a god. Adrenaline is still pumping. You've most likely fought many hectic battles against hordes of enemies, coming close to death at least a few times more than you'd have liked to. And life punishes you for your arrogance by giving you brain lag for a few seconds so you die after running into two otomo lasers.

So yeah. This game gets very difficult towards the end (campaign and achievements). There will be a lot of high action moments where your reaction speed and situational awareness will be put to the test.

All the time you're playing this you will be listening to the great dark synthwave soundtrack by Makeup and Vanity Set (M.A.V.S.). That madlad has produced three EPs just for this game and overall makes great music. (I highly recommended that you check him out on Bandcamp)

I enjoyed my time with this game and struggling towards completing all achievements.
Theoretically it has a decent amount of replayability after you're done if you try out difficult and weird loadouts or install the community hardcore mod (sadly haven't tried the latter yet).

The only negatives I can list are unfulfilled dreams that would have pushed the game even further. Specifically I would've wished for more than the standard gamemode, an easier to use map editor and perhaps even multiplayer.

Great gameplay, great lore, great Discord community, great soundtrack, great price.
This is a textbook example indie passion project. I'm very excited for the sequel Brigador Killers even if it will still take some time to develop.

Well then - stop reading and go and play it already.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085352614', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1645393110}
review:
Brigador: Charge Not By The Hour, But By The Body Count

As an American who likes a comeback king story as much as I like high calorie count and cholesterol choked food, Brigador's tale warms my heart. It came out, it hit the floor like a fetus in the backseat of a Buick and no one cared. Every one gave it crap, didn't give it what it deserved and Stellar Jockeys didn't give up. They tightened their bootstraps, cracked their knuckles and took a mediocrely reviewed games into one of the most entertaining mech top down shooters in recent memory and made me actually stop and read the lore of it. I rarely do that for games. 

You are a Brigador, a hired mercenary brought in by interstellar corporation SNC to reclaim their former colony of Novo Solo which fell under the rule of "Great Leader", a totalitarian general who seized control in a coup and made Nobre independent from the SNC. Great Leader's greatness enforced by legions of combat mechs, populism and interstellar cannons keeping people out of his orbit. However, Great Leader gets shot, and like a good dictator his entire empire crumbles to squabbling factions and you exist to be the Goldman Sachs backed sledgehammer to return corpo control to Solo Nobre and wrestle it from the hands of the Leader Loyalists, the schizophrenic syndicalist Corvids or the juiced up yuppies of the Spacers. And you intend to do this with one thing.

As many mechs, agrav ships and literal Killdozer tanks as you can find alongside whatever chaotic firearms, lasers, cannons and forcefields can fit and be wired to your engine like some cyberpunk LS swap. The tagline isn't kidding, this game hands you as manymachines to fit your destruction as you can handle, with weapons that range from simple to hilarious. It's a game where a laser weapon is as effective as strapping an M2HB to a flying car and drifting around combat droids. All the while you're getting hit with the full magazine tube of Makeup And Vanity Set's utterly DIVINE soundtrack, done in the correct level of bass heavy synthwave to befit this 1980's cyberpunk cityscape. Which is good, you need that bass to be heard over the chaos you can cause.

Beyond basic mission objectives, how you approach any engagement with the enemy comes down to you and what you want to do and the environment allows you to pull off anything. Everything on a map can be destroyed with enough time and ordinance, allowing you total freedom to play this anyway you want. Go for direct engagements with overwhelming firepower, use your ship like a drift missile blowing up larger machines from behind, saturation bombardment from afar with a literal tower of power mech that's about four stories high and armed with building destroying gas grenades, the world is your oyster and you need to shuck it as fast as you can.

review:
MechWarrior's smart, tactical, deliberate vehicular combat, top-down, distilled down to its bare essentials, taken to its logical and aesthetic extremes, bottled up and served in a gritty and fully destructible environment.

This is one of the only games I've played where all of the achievements are worth getting. The simple build system and pre-made loadouts presented in the campaign hide a shocking amount of depth in choosing which weapons pair best with which vehicles and specials in which situations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079721978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1125, 'last_played': 1703655544}
review:
A delightfully cathartic tactical mech-shooter with quite a substantial amount of stuff to play for the price. In the tradition of old top-down shooters like Crusader: No Remorse, Brigador has very few competitors for just the sheer amount of glee I have tearing up levels and watching every one and thing exploding into a million pieces. It might be a bit awkward to get into and it can certainly have moments of frustration, but overall, this game is top of the line.

As soon as the game booted up, I was immediately drawn to it's presentation. The digitized 3D look of everything reminds me of that late 90s Command and Conquer era of graphics, heightened by a good amount of lighting effects that nailing the dystopic cyberpunkey look they're going for. The key piece to make the aesthetic really click though is that soundtrack. A perfect mix of electronic that compliments the game really well and gives the game so much of it's mood. The only gripe I have with the game on this front is that it seems like during particularly long missions, the music has a tendency of cutting off entirely, leaving me many times with dozens of minutes of nothing but the in-game sound effects. Fortunately, they are of equally high quality, as crunchy and satisfying as they need to be, so there is that.

As far as the gameplay goes, it's what you can expect. You are plonked onto the map, have to fight through the enemy hordes and take down key objectives like destroying certain buildings, kill a certain elite enemy or just clear out a majority of enemies off the map, after which you high-tail it out of there before the enemy can blow you up. It's here, where you'll come to one of the big deciding factors for the game, the controls. The game primarily uses tank-style movement, where you pivot the direction you are facing with A and D, while using W and S to move forward and backwards respectively. There is a more conventional movement control with the "Screen Absolute" option that it set as default after the Up-Armored update, but there are some tradeoffs you take with it. Your vehicles take damage depending on the direction you're facing and with Screen Absolute, it's easy to literally show your ass to the opponent and take increased damage completely by accident. Not to mention vehicles without 360 degree turrets, which can start swiveling out of control as the turret tries to orient itself. The game was clearly made with the tank-control scheme (called "Relative") in mind and how much you'll get out of the game will come down to how you can adapt to either control scheme.

The two major game modes are Campaign and Freelancer. In Campaign, you follow a set of missions with a selection of preset loadouts for each level, conveying the story through pre-mission text dumps. I know the lore is pretty expansive with audiobooks and whatnot, but the writing in the game itself is mostly just there to set the scene and give a bit of context to what you're doing. The campaign is a good place to get used to the game's controls, whether you opt for the psuedo-twinstick style or the more traditional tank controls and is overall a pretty good experience throughout. It gets a little ridiculous in difficulty by the very end, but you should be able to at least get to the end of the story just fine, with alot of the really wacky stuff coming from the post-game stuff, which just feels like a challenge set for experienced players.

Freelancer is a half-randomized mode, where you take on anywhere from singlular missions to multiple mission spanning marathons with some randomized elements from spawn points to the enemy you face. More importantly though, you get the freedom of fully customizing your loadouts, swapping between the many vehicles at your disposal and each have multiple options for weapons to equip from different weight-classes of weaponry. Vehicles with smaller gun platforms aren't to be dismissed though, as they will offer modifiers to end-mission rewards, encouraging players to challenge themselves with harder vehicles.

The customization aspect of Freelancer is where the real fun of the game shines brightest. It offers a variety in approaches that many current games try to implement, but never quite succeed. Specifically, the choice of stealth vs direct assault. Like in alot of newer games, you have a decision to either pack yourself with the heaviest calibers and mow down the opposition or you can take a more methodical approach as you destroy entire enemy formations before they've gotten to even fire. In alot of games, this ends up feeling quite shallow, as your player character is designed to be good at both at the same time, meaning either the choice to be stealthy feels arbitrary or the enemies are so over-tuned, that going for direct assault doesn't feel satisfying. Brigador splits it up well, where enemies that are unalerted can be more easily dealt with and the weapons that specialize in that tend to be inaccessible but to the smallest, most vulnerable vehicles. Meanwhile, you can take hulking big mechs with tanky health and big guns, but the game will adjust enemies accordingly, throwing in more and stronger enemies to compensate.

Not only that, but choosing between the direct or stealthy approach can also completely change how you approach levels and the unique challenges of both can feel like your playing a whole different game. When stealthing, a single scout that can alert enemies to your presence can be more scary than even the biggest, baddest elite enemy. You might not be as afraid of them if going in with heavy weaponry, but you might find yourself more on-alert for any suicide-bombers that could get mixed in with the carnage and completely ruin an otherwise flawless run. For me, there is nothing more satisfying than maximum stealth in the hardest conditions. Just take Precursor James, jump into the smallest mech you can find, slap on a Blackhand and spend up to 40 minutes on the most intense game of cat and mouse you'll ever play.

Due to it's unconventional control scheme, I am aware that this game might not appeal to everyone. However, to those that enjoy that type of game, those that are willing to give that style a shot or those who just don't care one way or the other, I cannot recommend this game enough. It is one of the best of it's kind that I've played in quite some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960581757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1667744107}
review:
Obviously, this game gets compared to the futuristic action/strategy classic Syndicate Wars (1996). Brigador very much tries to replicate that audiovisual presentation and atmosphere. Having actually played Syndicate Wars before Brigador, this results in constant comparisons for individual game elements. Although Brigador has a more modern game engine, it cannot replicate the most important atmospheric aspects that draw you into the whole dystopian setting and its lore. It also does not walk that fine line between action and strategy. It's all guns blazing with a constant struggle for ammunition, or overly strategic due to not being equipped for the job. Both playing methods quickly turn the gameplay loop into a drag. Completing missions feels like dragging yourself through the mud, instead of wanting to complete one more round and losing track of time in the process.

It feels like they replaced the top tier cast in a triple A science fiction movie, with B quality substitutes. Then slapping some alternative soundtrack on it and pretending to be edgy and cool. Syndicate Wars is a 25+ year old game, and still a playable classic for a reason. Brigador ultimately falls in the wannabe territory.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172392767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 4090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3972, 'last_played': 1667523068}
review:
The problem with Brigador ist that it's both too easy and too hard: It's too easy with the big vehicles and their big guns, where your main problem is not to run out of ammo (bigger guns = less ammo carried), and too hard with anything less lethal (the less lethal the harder it gets). The main issues in gameplay are the noise level and swarming enemies.

Weapons make noise, causing enemies to come over and inspect the place where that noise came from. The 3 issues with that are
1) that you get no indicator for the noise distance, so you can only guess, and 
2) that you can lure enemies 1 by 1, which you may have to do if you pilot any small vehicle, but which is also extremely boring and stupid (enemies will just turn around and try to get back to their previous spot if they find nothing, close by allies never join in for a search of the area, neither when the 1 enemy you got the attention from was alerted nor when it arrives at the location that it wants to check).
3) You can't spot & scan enemies, so you don't really know which weapons they've installed and what they're effective against or what their shield- and armor values look like - you'll learn that in the split second they're shooting at you and you're shooting at them.

Enemies can swarm the player for a variety of reasons:
-being spotted by multiple enemies
-noise alerting a lot of enemies (you using your loud weapons, enemies using their loud weapons, blowing something up that makes a lot of noise)
-an enemy finished its alarm, which alerted all other enemies to your presence
The issue with swarming is that it's very bad for any vehicle that's not durable and lethal.
For any durable and lethal vehicle it goes like this: Enemies swarm in, you destroy them, they drop ammo and shield pickups to regain what was lost in combat, you continue your rampage.
For any vehicle that's either not durable or not lethal it goes like this: You're getting swarmed. You're most likely getting overwhelmed and killed.
Normally there should be something available to your advantage for the disadvantage of not piloting a killing machine - but often there's nothing. While some vehicle are at least fast and small, which makes it hard to hit it with weapons that require some precision at least, that's not the case for all of them. Some vehicles are just death traps: Slow, weak in shields and armor, with only weak weapon systems as choice to install on them. The campaign, if you want the achievement, forces you to pilote some of these and sometimes sends you into a mission with weapons extremely unfitting for the level design and enemy types you encounter.

While there's some strategy you can play, like...
attacking enemies from the sides and back, where you can deal bonus damage to their armor, using the weapons you have right (some are more effective against armor, some against shields, some deal area damage, some damage in a line, some damage over time, some can shoot through or over objects, some have secondary effects), using cover (both against shots coming in and line of sight), luring enemies, using choke points, using explosive level objects to your advantage, paying attention to the noise levels, using your special system right, ramming / stomping enemies, making them blow up another with friendly fire
...there's still a large gap between what works and what doesn't work once you get into a very slow or very vulnerable vehicle, where you just hit a wall of try-until-the-odds-worked-for-you. And that's a design problem. Example: They give you a weak vehicle with low noise but also low range weapons and place enemies on the map that stand around in large groups of vehicles that can oneshot yours. Now it doesn't matter what special system you've installed on your vehicle: smoke launcher, EMP grenade, audio-kinetic pulse (blase wave in frontal cone that can level structures and destroy enemies) or invisibility. You're just not getting a kill, surviving that and have no chance of getting away once they're alerted to your presence.
It would really help if enemies had to lock on to you to keep firing at you and "know" where you are, allowing smaller and more vulnerable vehicles to more easily break this lock on by using obstacles or their special kit (as just mentioned), but there's no such mechanic. Additionally there's an issue with the weapon design: They're different degrees effective against shields and armor. Some enemies have lots of shields, some lots of armor, some lots of both. So IF you use any specialized weapon that's good only vs either shields or armor you immediately lose like 50% of your firepower, because first you've got to get through the shields, then through the armor, meaning that on each phase 1 of 2 weapons is almost useless. To solve this issue they could make the smaller weapons more lethal the closer they're to an enemy, but that's not a thing in the game.

They also don't take mobility into account for balancing, so that some vehicles that are weak and slow get the same equipment choices as such that are weak and fast, making the slow ones just worse without any upside that they get for having their disadvantage.

Now the only thing they're balancing in the game is: The worse the vehicle the more payment you get for completing the mission with one. But that's not enough, because in the campaign the money serves no value: You're not equipping your own vehicle, unlocking upgrades and features, but instead you get one handed with a specific setup that you can't change. Only the freelance mode (randomized missions) allows you to pick your own everything, and that's where you need the money to unlock that.

I kinda wish the game had more and better strategy but it's either mostly brawling with the vehicles that can handle that or lame careful gameplay with vehicles that can't because they're just worse and that's it. Imo skip the campaign and stick to freelance, you can make your money there too to unlock the other thins in freelance mode. The campaign was a mistake. There's some text story but nothing that sticks together as a whole. You can redefine the control mode for the different movement types (mech walker, hovercraft, tank), which is recommended.

The game is basically a gloryfied flash game and the good thing about it are the randomized maps with a good core pool of vehicles it's fun to play with. They could improve the gameplay by making sure it's not just taking weapon slots into account but how the unit performs as a whole to design some special mechanics for the units that'd otherwise be too bad to play with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004391786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1667166272}
review:
Was fun for the first bit, if you play this, you should just skip the "Campaign". It's repetitive missions that force you to select one tech out of a preset.

Play a few campaign missions, and then do freelance with the loadout you want. The game's mechanics are weirdly sluggish. It's difficult to plow through or over things, ammo drops from enemies can be blown up by you and enemies. This means if you have a loadout that overkills with AOE, then you're screwed.

There's a cap on how much the ammo depots give out. There aren't any combos, and the special abilities don't really add that much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045779347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1700247861}
review:
Honestly, the mech (+tank +vehicle +hover vehicle) game I didn't know I needed. Only found this thanks to Mandy (MandaloreGaming) on youtube.

It comes across as a Twin Stick but is more rewarding when you learn to play it with Tank Controls due to a directional damage system (Taking less damage from the front more from the back in example). Stealth and a Hit and Run style game-play works wonder as even at the height of combat enemies rely on sight to know precisely where you are. Big buildings and walls while so much fun to destroy (Literally everything is destructible) will hide you. Smaller vehicles trade HP for speed and are also easier to hide behind scenery. Different weapon types all feel different and are almost all warcrimes.

I'm not much of a critic so this "review" is mostly just some what enjoy but it's super worth checking out.

ALSO THE AUDIO-BOOK IS STELLAR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006244912', 'num_games_owned': 613, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 1520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1520, 'last_played': 1664542642}
review:
[b][i]“SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL”[/i][/b]

Как такового весомого основного сюжета в режиме [b]Кампании[/b] нет. Зато в самой игре есть куча информации и лора в описание большинства оружия, мехов и фракций. Я не знаю хорошо или плохо это дело прописано, потому как [b]“i ain’t reading all that”[/b]. Моей целью было делать [b]brrrrrrr[/b] по ходу игры, а не вникать в лор этого мира. Режим [b]Кампания[/b] же представляет собой набор последовательных миссий со своими целями и брифингами, в которых дается объяснение почему и зачем нужно устранить/уничтожить цели конкретно в этой миссии (к слову,это я читал). Помимо кампании в игре есть режим [b]Фриланса[/b], который по большей части предназначен для развлечения самого себя путем сбора различных билдов.
[b]Игровой процесс[/b] по своему динамичный и увлекательный. Его общая философия напоминает серию игр [b]Hotline Miami[/b], за исключением того что мех игрока не уничтожается противниками за один удар. По крайней мере, это правдиво в большинстве случаях. Сложность миссии как правило зависит от пилота, меха и его снаряжения. Если мех большой, толстый и имеет эффективные смертоносные пушки, то миссии проходятся довольно легко без каких либо замудренных стратегий. А ежели он маленький и хиленький то в такой ситуации приходится брать умением и стратегией, нанося внезапные удары и давая деру.
И говоря о [b]мехах[/b] - их тут много, также как и различного вооружения, снаряжения и пилотов. Всего представлено 3 вида мехов: [b]шагоходы[/b], [b]танки[/b] и [b]гравилеты[/b]. Как я говорил ранее, они могут быть любого размера и прочности. Их вооружение делится на 4 вида: [b]артиллерийское[/b], [b]лазерное[/b], [b]пулеметное[/b] и [b]снарядное[/b]. Каждый экземпляр оружия оружия варьируется внутри своего вида. На каждом мехе может стоять основное и дополнительное оружия любого доступного вида. На особенных мехах даже стоят автоматические турели! Также на каждом мехе может стоять одно из 4-рех видов снаряжение: [b]дымовые гранаты[/b], [b]эми-гранаты[/b], [b]стелс-поле[/b] и [b]разрушительная волновая установка[/b]. Открывается все это дело за [b]внутриигровые деньги[/b], зарабатываемые при успешном прохождении миссий [b]Кампании[/b] и [b]Фриланса[/b]. В каждой миссии нужно выполнить определенную цель, для открытия точек выхода, и по желанию выполнять однообразные для каждой миссии побочные цели. Множитель выплачиваемого гонорара зависит от того насколько сложно было проходить миссию. В [b]кампании[/b] это возможно понять только тогда, когда уже удалось пощупать один из доступных предварительных билдов (которых как правило представлено по 4 на большинство миссий). Во [b]фрилансе[/b] же можно настроить свой собственный билд, подобрав пилота, который напрямую влияет на сложность игры, а также меха, устанавливая на него любое доступное оружие и снаряжение.
[b]Багов[/b] и [b]вылетов[/b] за все время игры я не встретил. 
[b]Музыка[/b] в игре хорошая. Такой приятный синтвейв, задающий атмосферу мрачноватого гиперактивного будущего.

[b]Хорошая[/b] игра с в меру сложной кампанией (кроме уровней c F1 по F3, созданных какими-то лютыми трайхардами из сообщества), порой принуждающая к пересмотру стиля игры при игре за разные билды. А также позволяющая экспериментировать с различными билдами, значительно упрощая или усложняя прохождение миссий.
[b]Рекомендую.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198093518693', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2856, 'last_played': 1709775106}
review:
A game is good when you don't have to play it and just listen to the music.
A game is good when characters are well detailed and each have unique difficulty mechanics. 
My pilot can be a blue painted skeleton, a man with no eyes, a female ghoul from fallout 3 or NV, a paper-plate masked man.
The vehicles, my goodness the vehicles. I can pilot a huge military mech, a futuristic anti-grave tank, a rickshaw, a suit of power armor, or a bunch of cars stacked on top of each other.
Most vehicles have unique horns with the Party Van having a whole heavy metal guitar solo: S tier horn. 
I can exploit two missions for maximum payout to unlock both in game purchases and achievements. 
I can stomp on, run over, disintegrate, explode, shoot, or zap a civilian and get $50. 
Overall, not an easy game but adaptable. 
Buy this game but first watch Mandaloregaming's review to truly see if it is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998265076', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1235, 'last_played': 1661126817}
review:
It's not bad if you play in short sessions and get it on a sale. Otherwise, just pick something else.

While the pixel art is gorgeous and the heavier weaponry gives that feeling of power, the gameplay is quite repetitive and doesn't offer much variation. At best you can challenge yourself by picking a weaker or smaller mech/vehicle, but every mission plays the same.

The campaign isn't much of a campaign and instead it's more like a collection of loosely associated missions with limited loadouts and one or two unique challenges. The game makes little to no use of its setting despite making written lore an unlockable.

The game runs perfectly on Linux, so long as you use the Steam Linux Runtime as a compatibility tool since apparently it hasn't been updated for newer distros.

review:
Brigador is fun, it's pretty fast paced or slow if you want it to be. Ton of models, ton of guns, ton lot of fun tidbits and lore to read. You can ignore all that if you want though and just random and burst through entire cities in a rampage, destroying everything. review: With vehicles ranging from up-gunned infantry-sized powersuits and stealthy bikes to CQC hover-cars and towering mechs, all with their own high degree of challenge and advantages — Brigador is a deceptively tactical shooter that revels in the chaos of properly weighty and destructive vehicles supported by an elevated level of detail in its destructible retro-futuristic environments, readable lore, and one of the best soundscapes of any isometric shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056580277', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2257, 'last_played': 1689469046}
review: A fantastic game that you get as much out of it as you want. The gameplay has a lot of depth, the lore is extremely interesting and well written, the music rivals in quality some of the heaviest hitters in the indie genre,  and the amount of customization both in terms of settings and gameplay can really personalize the experience. However if you just want blow up intricate environments with a big cool mech this game is great for that too. I am sure the other reviews mention this too but this game doesn't really play like a twin stick shooter, and on the higher levels the game starts to pull away from being a power fantasy, but I think this game is at it's most fulfilling when you need to think and be tactical. Just don't expect this game to be frantic flash of colors and adrenaline. I really hope to see this game get the sequel it deserves. Consume Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061976957', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1674500926}
review:
Really good cyberpunk artwork and music along with reasonable price. Tons of blowing/smashing things up, chasing down civilians as they run from their homes, etc. Committing war crimes is encouraged, as one of your crazy pilots wears a paper plate for a mask to hide his identity from prosecution. But your trying to destroy a oppressive dictatorship regime, so your actually the 'good guy'. So go ahead - drive your tank through that multi-million dollar civilian home while honking your horn! Yes, every vehicle has a horn to help establish 'dominance'.

The tank controls are still kinda whacked, even in this updated edition where they were suppose to have improved that - both the mouse/keyboard and game controller are still very difficult to get used to. Also, the graphics/models are not really that retro, I thought, so they could have just made them much more detailed since the artwork and models are really cool.

But for the price, its a great game to release rage by causing lots of virtual destruction and mayhem, so it's lots of fun to play once you get used to the controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153632278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1695028798}

author: {'steamid': '76561198161887912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1530, 'last_played': 1700226483}
review:
世界観やメカデザインに刺激を受けるなら良い作品だと思う。
メカは発展と改良の開発史が見えたり、足回りを再利用して他の機体のコックピットやら廃材鋼材を無造作に組み合わせたあり合わせの機体があったりとかなり面白い。
断片的にちりばめられた情報は各勢力やこの世界の歴史の想像を誘う。

ただ、ゲームとしては単調さがぬぐえない。結局どのミッションも敵を排除しながら指定されたユニット・オービタルガン・弾薬庫・通信塔・変電所を破壊することは変わらず、マップや敵の配置のバリエーションは多いとはいえ飽きてくる。
連続でこなすミッションは1度でも失敗したらアウトで、リスタートも最初からやりなおし。2つ3つなら良いものの、後半は9とか18とか連続してやらされる。クリアまで1時間超えてくるのでやっていられない。
軽装高機動の機体の弱さもきつい。報酬にボーナスがあるとはいえ、弾速が全体的に速いので回避はできない。立ち回りとEMPか光学迷彩の活用をしても、そもそもの火力が低いので時間がかかる。ミスれば即死なので、連続したミッションでは使い物にならない。
結局重装甲重武装の機体でゴリ押しばかりで単調になる。

メカデザインや作品の雰囲気が好きそうだと思ったら買い。ゲームとしての面白さを求めているなら、10時間くらい遊べればいいなら買い、もっと長く遊ぶつもりならおすすめはしないです。

review:
Honestly I didn't think I would like this as much as I do.  I generally like more parts customization in my mechs, that said the sheer number of Mechs Tanks and Hovers means I can't complain about a lack of variety.  You slap a loadout of pilot, vehicle, two weapons and a utility mount.  

The number of unlocks will keep you playing for hours and the difference between loadouts is pretty interesting.   Grab the pilot The Auditor and you wont even have enemy spawns, making gameplay weirdly chill or frantic if you are time competing with yourself to hit targets as fast as possible.  Other pilots can raise or lower your difficulty along with a proportionate change in profit. 

Pick up the game it is well worth the price.  Have fun on the battlefield.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070907747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1682737865}
review:
Oh man, Brigador. I'm a big fan of twin-stick vehicle shooters and this one absolutely satisfies. The premise is really simple: It's the cyberpunk future (specifically Cassette Futurism flavor, go look it up) and humanity has spread across the stars. The authoritarian leader of Solo Nobre, an isolationist city on a backwater planet, has finally kicked the bucket. Your character is contacted by a mega-corp, SNC, to destroy as much as possible of the city's infrastructure (both military or otherwise), kill the high-ranking members of the 3 groups in the city that might pose a threat to their control, and then escape with a boatload of cash. In principle, this means being dropped into large levels with a general objective like "shoot the important guy in a tank" or "knock out the generators near this base so our ships can blast it from orbit". The magic of the game is the openness of each level. Do you pick a giant, armored mech and fight directly through legions of enemies to get to your objective? How about a small hover-tank to scoot around behind enemy defenses and blast them with poison gas launchers while their shields are down? No? How about a battle-suit with a cannon meant for artillery, active camo, and armor like paper plates with mad faces drawn on them? All are viable, if more or less difficult, tactics in this game.

In any vehicle shooter, the vehicles themselves are clearly the star. Brigador has 3 factions to pull from, all with varying types of colorful vehicles. The NEP are defectors from Solo Nobre's military, so they have lots of very minimalistic tanks or mechs with heavy armor and weapons. The Corvids are revolutionaries who have to make their vehicles from existing machines, bolting on engines and weapons and armor until they maaaaaybe will stand up in a fight; their vehicles tend to be of the glass cannon variety. Finally there's the Spacers, amoral raiders who usually live their entire lives in space (duh) and only come planet-side to steal resources or kill for fun. Their vehicles look like 60's moon buggies, almost-organic walkers, and weirder stuff. If you want to pilot a giant, floating face that shoots lasers from its eyes and projects weaponized sound waves from its mouth, these guys are for you.

In general, gameplay is a fun romp through a series of completely destrutable levels and huge armies. Challenging yourself to make more dangerous runs in less and less powerful vehicles is really the draw here. This, by the by, is encouraged by the game, as weaker vehicles and harder runs earn bigger payouts. In fact, if I could say anything bad about the game it's that once you complete the campaign, it feels kind of sandbox-y. You have to choose what runs to complete and with which vehicles, so if you get decision paralysis, this one is gonna get you. That said, get this little gem and enjoy the corporate-sanctioned war crimes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088377659', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1359, 'last_played': 1674896348}
review:
This game is absolutely amazing. The game has plenty of depth which will give you more than enough to play with and put tons of hours into the game.

The campaign is a useful tutorial to get you acclimated to different tactics and characteristics of some vehicles and different weaponry, but you'll spend most of your time in the Freelance mode. The Freelance mode is where you'll be able to set up your runs and make decisions that influence the play style needed to complete missions with your pilot setting the difficulty factor, payout bonus, and sometimes special rulesets such as fighting specific factions or alternate spawnlists.

Brigador has a lot of depth to its gameplay with how each build requires specific tactics. Make a glass cannon that requires playing games of cat and mouse. Build a heavy machine that is an outright brawler in the streets. Create something more rounded out - the choice is yours.

With all that said, welcome, Brigador. Your contract has been accepted.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993587710', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1678091244}
review:
Twin Stick Vehicular sandbox mayhem. Controls take a bit of getting used to and the UI isn't the best but give it an hour and you're running around the map stomping all over mech suits and blowing up tanks. 

Story/World/Atmosphere: If you want story/lore in your twin stick games this game has PLENTY, there's tons of pilots to unlock that are just a .jpg with text biographys for example on top of all the missions that have long descriptions. It's a dark bleak oppressive future and you're tasked with blowing shit up in it. The maps, lighting and sprites are all very gritty and paint a very good looking cyberpunk dystopia. The music is moody and that artist even went made songs for Stranger Things. The game is sprite based but this looks like the most crisp sharpest Starcraft-era game ever, you'll forget it's sprite based consistently. 

Gameplay: You get 3 types of vehicles. Mech, Tank, Anti-Grav vehicle(flying car basically). Each can be customized with different types of rockets, morters, chain guns, etc. They have different abilities, mobility, it's not super granular but its very accessible. You pick a map of which there are plenty, complete the objectives, get money, buy more weapons and vehicles and .jpgs to switch up your pilot. It's very arcade like where you just blow things up while trying to survive and your goal is *gasp* more to have fun than anything else.

When you're done with the campaign or you want to do something on your own, there's a free play mode where you can pick whatever mission you want with money(missions arent expensive and you get plenty of money) that have different objectives. Your pilot jpg gives you different payout amounts, as well as the type of vehicle you have. Squishier vehicles get more money compared to your beefcakes. 

Cons: Firing your weapons, unlike most twin sticks on pc or console where you either have a laser or a marker/cursor, this game is a hybrid. Theres a small triangle thats your cursor and there are 2 long arcs headlights that act as your laser sight. Losing sight of your cursor is constant as aiming far away your headlights will arc up to show how far they go, wether its enough to go over barricades or low enough to hit enemies mid range, the readability is not that good. You begin to learn everything by feel because the visual aid just isn't there, the arc lands at 5 meters, you know by feel the mortar will land at 7 meters and the rail gun will land at 4-5. It's not a huge problem but it leads to a learning curve that feels out of place because the game otherwise has an amazing tutorial and customizable UI to really ease you in. You can even slow the game down as much as you want with a setting. 

The objectives are these tiny TINY little icons that you cant make bigger(but i think you can change the colour) that are the edges of your screen and with how the artstyle is, it just gets lost or outright invisible and you have to move your camera around to find it. The maps aren't super big but I found myself constantly scanning the edge of my screen looking for this 1x1 pixel to tell me where the last cannon to blow up is. 

Final Thoughts: The artstyle, music and robot hotline miami gameplay gets a recommend from me. Whatever issues there are are pretty minor and theres mods you can screw around with to extend playtime. The sequel is in full development and looks to 'fix' everything about the 1st game while managing to look even better. The games 6 years old and got updates up until 2021 that added real content, REAL content. Not just skins or mutator updates like most developers do that try and tout they supported their game for years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033263509', 'num_games_owned': 2923, 'num_reviews': 569, 'playtime_forever': 1160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1660049584}
review:
Иногда  хочется  чего-то  простого  и  незамысловатого  –  сесть  за  штурвал  меха,  руль  антиграва  или  рычаги  какого-нибудь  танка-бульдозера  и  крушить,  крушить,  крушить.  «Brigador»  даёт  всем  желающим  подобную  возможность.

Для  разрушений  доступно  два  режима  игры  Кампания  на  пять  десятков  миссий  и  фриланс  состоящий  из  шести  десятков  операций,  в  каждой  из  которых  придётся  пройти  одну  или  несколько  карт.  Сюжета  как  такового  в  игре  нет,  да  он  и  не  нужен,  вся  суть  текстов  кампании  сводится  к  объяснению  как  играть  и  что  собой  представляют  бригадоры  –  наёмники  коим  поручают  грязную  работу  по  убийству  и  уничтожению.  Проходя  кампанию  и  операции,  мы  получаем  деньги,  для  того  чтобы  разблокировать  кучу  всего  –  порядка  60  пилотов,  около  90  мехов/танков/антигравов  трёх  враждующих  фракций,  50  с  мелочью  типов  основного,  башенного,  тяжёлого,  специального  вооружения,  да  и  сами  операции  и  кодекс  с  дополнительными  сведеньями  тоже  предстоит  покупать.

Ознакомившись  с  огромным  перечнем  наименований  для  материальных  вложений  игровых  миллионов  можно  отправляться  на  миссии  и  разносить  всё,  начиная  с  вражеской  техники,  заканчивая  строениями,  стенами,  деревьями  и  полями,  для  особых  ценителей  предусмотрена  возможность  давить  мельтешащих  людишек  –  чем  больше  будет  нанесён  урон  району  и  чем  больше  будет  жертв,  тем  больше  нам  заплатят!  Лично  для  меня  самой  большой  проблемой  стали  постоянно  заканчивающиеся  боеприпасы  –  да,  они  выпадают  из  поверженных  врагов,  их  можно  пополнить  на  складе,  но  в  игре  столько  всего  можно  разрушить  и  разнести,  что  палец  с  гашетки  убирать  просто  не  хочется!
 
Резюме:  когда  хочется  немного  хаоса  и  много  разрушений.

Yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048977206', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1252, 'last_played': 1658516275}
review:
The true appeal of Brigador shows itself once the player has completed the campaign. Through the use of money earned from missions, players can unlock new pilots, vehicles and weapons, which then can be used in freelance mode for any mission in whichever combination of arsenals they want with no restrictions.

The game is gorgeous - it reminds me of old, isometric games such as Alien Shooter but in a much more crisp, modern feel, and the music used further strengthens the overall cyberpunk feel of the game.

The game has its own faults though - campaign feels sluggish at best until late game, and even then it still feels very restrictive since you can only select from 4 predetermined loadouts given for the stage. Night time maps make it hard to navigate your shots on enemies, and when surrounded its difficult to identify any alarming enemies due to its use of the same color as your weapon reticule.

Once you get through all the faults however, the game with no restrictions become a true joy to play, with no bars held back to cause mayhem with your weapon and vehicles, crushing enemies after enemies with crumbled building and structures lying behind the chaos you created - Bliss.

Buy on sale, I definitely recommend this game

review:
Great gameplay. Combat is very satisfying and there is quite a lot of variety and tactics depending on which vehicle / weapons / abilities you use.

The aesthetics are fantastic IMO - fun and interesting vehicle designs and lovely, detailed and living maps. Now if the visual aesthetics are fantastic the music is even better.

Finally I have to say that I love all the lore and fluff they added for as the background and the story. It's a secondary consideration for a game like this, any you can completely ignore it, but it is really lovely work and excellent world-building.

Definitely recommended.

review:

If you're part of some sort of fandom that's into mechs, I swear you can use the audiobook as a recruiting tool in order to get more fans. author: {'steamid': '76561198084114266', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1657924541}
review:
Normally not my type of game but after a glowing review from Mandalore gaming I had to check this out.
Visually this game is amazing, it has a late 90s 2D/3D mixed look which looked great. The music is also top notch with a soundtrack from Makeup and Vanity Set though I do feel the tracks get a bit repetitive after a while and by the end I was mostly playing podcasts in the background. 

I started playing this game on the steam deck at first and was good, if a bit sluggish with a controller. However, near the end of the game there is a large difficulty spike which required me to use a mouse a keyboard. I really enjoyed my time with this game but the massive difficulty spike at the end really started to put me off. I was getting through levels in the beginning in only a few minutes and then I hit a wall and was replaying levels dozens of times barely scrapping by. If you're like me and don't usually enjoy this genre but want to try something new for a change, check this game even if it is just to marvel at the visuals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198810893972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1538, 'last_played': 1691365840}
review:
The game has a unique visual style which I adore. The half thrown together aesthetic of most vehicles and weapons really adds a grunge aspect to the style which I love. The music by Makeup and Vanity Set really does wonders for the atmosphere of blasting your way across Solo Nobre. And the story/lore of the game while hidden in the audiobook and lore entries are fantastic. And indeed the book by Brad Buckmaster has to be one of my new favourite books. 

If you like strategic mech combat with electro music and a grungy mech aesthetic than this is the game for you. 

Cannot wait for Brigador Killers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074309450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 2077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1393, 'last_played': 1699495473}
review:
Brigador is an old-school game. It is not the synthwave twin-stick shooters you're used to. It is an isometric vehicle combat game in the spirit of Desert Strike, Syndicate, and a little bit of Mechwarrior. You have to use cover and "mousehole" through terrain to outsmart the AI and avoid driving into a gas station and dying immediately. It's good.
     The graphics and music are pretty. My only nitpick is I think some terrain has inconsistent scaling. The lore is deep and riddled with war crimes and hyperviolence. But no story or character development is there to get in the way of your action. Enjoying Brigador requires a refined taste but gamers of culture will appreciate it as a blood diamond in the rough.

review:
The Good:
-Stylish Presentation
-Fun (Albeit repetitive*) gameplay with stellar feedback
-Impressively deep lore that is rather well written

The Bad:
-The storytelling outside of lore tidbits you can purchase with money from contracts is effectively non-existent
-The gameplay loop becomes immensely repetitive* after several hours of play

And finally, the biggest personal turn-off for me:
Jack Monahan, one of the primary devs of the game, was outed as a massive piece of shit a few years ago (racist, anti-semitic, homophobic/transphobic, etc.). Following the announcement, he issued the most basic "oopsie-daisy" 'apology' and left the dev team. 
Now, if this had been the end of it, I wouldn't be writing this review. Games are ultimately more than a one-man operation, and I would be content to let this lie had Stellar Jockeys not quietly brought him back aboard for the sequel. To this day, there has not been any formal acknowledgement on whether or not he has changed (quite frankly I doubt it), and it seems as if there never will be.

To conclude, I find the game fun, however that fun is somewhat hampered with this knowledge, and I can't in good faith recommend anyone purchase the game.

Too bad I didn't find out until after I passed the refund threshold.

review: While apparently simple, Brigador provides a rich gameplay experience that combines stealth, action, and strategy elements. Success requires a blend of careful planning, precise execution, and fast reflexes. The music is rich, and the visuals are simply stunning. Bridgador's art style employs an late twentieth century-tinged retrofuturism that will see you sneaking and blasting through cities, industrial complexes, farmlands, suburbs, and more, all with a slightly-too-organized look that perfectly fits the setting of a highly-developed sci-fi colony world.  There are times where you'll find yourself frustrated by certain scenarios, but that's because there is a lot of depth and challenge to be had here. If you're up for it, the experience will be rewarding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096663928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 426, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1654188936}
review:
Серия самых коротких рецензий:

Неплохая (6.5 из 10)

P.S.: Расшифровка:

Трэш — знакомиться с игрой рекомендуется исключительно тем, кто в диком восторге от описания, скриншотов и продолжительности. Остальным, из контакта с этой игрой, только тыкать палкой, как ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ку на дороге.

Так себе — в основном, эта игра предлагает меньше, чем вы увидите из описания и скриншотов. Рекомендуется только тем, кому вышеперечисленные критерии окажутся «зашибись».

Нормальная — неплохая игра своего жанра. Сами судите по описанию, скриншотам и продолжительности. Игра, примерно, соответствует своему наполнению.

Хорошая — весьма неплохой представитель своего жанра. Многие могут найти тут «свой шедевр». Зачастую, игра приятно соответствует своему описанию и скриншотам.

Отличная — эти игры, зачастую, превосходят свои первые впечатления, основанные на описании и скриншотах (в расчёт не берём репутацию, ибо «тот кто знает, тот поймёт»). Хорошие представители своего жанра

author: {'steamid': '76561198114108429', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 2556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1682996712}
review: An absolute delight in just about every way. A treat to look at, listen to, and interact with. The lore is a light touch and provides little more than the barest context, but the pilots themselves have enough character in their little profile pictures and mech loadouts that you kind of get everything you need even if you just play through as big monke. I'm never ever going to listen to the audiobook to find out exactly why I'm doing what I'm doing, but with gamefeel, visual and sound design, and a soundtrack of this immaculate quality, present me with an escalating series of mechs and a proportionally escalating series of cities to destroy and I'm a happy man.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976296109', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1654229195}
review:
Brigador is the sort of game that I could see myself buying in 1996, spending $49.99 at the store for a giant box with a CD and a huge manual full of lore. I mean this in the best way. This game is amazing. It looks amazing, some of the best and most detailed 2D artwork I have seen in a very long time. It sounds amazing, with crisp sound effects and some of the best synthwave/techno music out there. It plays amazing, with tons of variety and tons of content. It has a campaign that acts as a tutorial of sorts, ramping up over time, but the real meat of the game is a freeform mode that lets you tackle objectives with all sorts of weapons, modifiers, and maps. 

The most surprising thing when I sat down and played it is that it is far more tactical and strategic than it first appears. Going through each map presents different challenges and opportunities. Every vehicle plays differently and the game is flexible enough to allow for lots of strategies and tactics. There is just a ton to love here and it is just a brilliant PC exclusive. Get it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021980180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1595115391}
review:
Brigador is NOT a twin-stick shooter. It's important that you know that, because that's partially why the game flopped [at first]. It's a fantastic isometric mech-shooter, with possibly the most customisation I've seen in a game.

I'll start with.. the graphics, for once. As far as I can tell, the vehicles are 3D models that've been expertly converted into sprites, creating incredibly detailed models that don't look out-of-place in the art design of the surroundings. The lighting is really impressive too, considering how the game renders everything.

The gameplay is more strategic than it would appear. Every vehicle handles differently, and can be specced into different builds which ALSO affect how they handle. You'll generally find that your armour is thickest on the front, so being flanked is a real problem. Depending on whether your vehicle has legs, tracks or thrusters will affect how quickly you can rectify this, or whether you should have been more careful to begin with.

There is a frankly-ludicrous amount of weapons, vehicles and even pilots to play around with. Pilots have their own strengths and weaknesses to bear in mind, also.

The music in this game isn't necessarily my cup of tea, but I can acknowledge that it is VERY high quality. It's a strange mix of the electronic, synth-y music you might expect, and some more orchestral [though still very digital] influences, which will be more prominent in the quiet moments between shootouts.

Everything is destructible, and there are no "collateral damage" punishments to worry about, so the game is very liberating in that sense. It makes sense in the story, don't worry about it.

I can't recommend the game enough, it's very, very, very good.

I only have a few gripes, but they aren't necessarily the developer's fault. 
The default control scheme is 'screen-absolute' to satisfy those that bought the game, didn't look in the options, and refunded it, because they thought it was a twin-stick shooter. The intended control scheme is "Relative", which is more awkward at first, but more rewarding when you get good with it. As I mentioned before, the game has a directional damage system, so it's a very good idea to know where your rear is at all times, and tank controls gives you a higher degree of control over that.

I also find a lot of the "lore" for the pilots to be quite cringey. A bit "lol randum" and kinda preachy.

Aside from that, though? Best mech game I've played. Can't wait for the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103980772', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1664649199}
review:
There is something so refreshing about a game which tells you on the first minute, this is what I want to do and this is what you are going to get. 

Brigador is a cyberpunk mech shooter with tank controls, set in a grim dark future and remote world. Your choice of customisation is seemingly simple but actually really nuanced. You have a choice of hull (mech, tank, or agrav - a hovertank), and each controls in their own way. Each mech has two weapon mounts plus a special ability; however, and obviously, not every mech can mount every gun. The worldbuilding is also splendid. There are only three factions which all provide their own mechs, tanks, and agravs, but that is plenty enough - each of them ooze personality from not only the external looks, but also from the way these vehicles play. This means that one moment you could be playing as a tank towering over even the apartments - which, upon closer inspection is actually several vans stacked on top of each other firing several heavy cannons, only to in your next run switch to a pint-sized walker which on one hand is using that same heavy cannon, except moving at the pace of a snail.  


The sandbox is similarly amazing - although the maps admittedly blur together after a while, it never feels like you are doing the same mission twice. This is also not a simple power-fantasy where you get in your invincible metal box with huge cannons and steamroll everything - some level of strategy is needed. This is where the destruction of in-game terrain is seamlessly blended into the game. So often in sandbox games destruction is treated as a gimmick - not here.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010048406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1248, 'last_played': 1665254678}
review:
brigador is amazing in what it does, an arcade style shooter with its own distinct take on cyberpunk and showing art in destruction. The music and sound of the cannons, gatlings, lasers and blasters are perfect and get you in the mood for some colletoral damage. 

Having said all that there are two things I do find frustrating. Firstly, when you die in a run of missions, you have to redo them all. I get that is the difficulty but what if this was an option, I really don't feel like trying a 25 mission run when i know one slip up will mean all the time wasted.  Secondly; the campaign is great for teaching you the game which you then are supposed to take to the freelance game where you can mish and mash vehicles, two weapons and a special action with a pilot to take on a huge array of missions and maps. The problem is, it is so easy to make something that is barely winnable. Yes yes in theory you should be able to do anything with every combo but still to me I would have preffered that unlocking a pilot means unlocking a build, a vehicle  weapon combo. 

I am never really good at too many choices in games, especially from the go nuts variety like this. While I do now many people would find my critique weird, how can total freedom to mish and mash be bad, for me it is a bit too much and would have preferred a system where pilots come with a premade build. Regardless of that, i do find that the concept os pilots as difficulty tracker is good, but with the huge amount of pilots I don't see the incriments, what are the tiers of difficulty? I get that precusor james is the most difficult but what are the levels we go through here? 

if those two tings don't matter to you, don't let me hold you back; it is just that I see that I can"t fully appreciate the game in what it tries to do and that is a shame, but that is on me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000630500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1650119626}
review:
Mechs? Check!
More mechs? Check!
More weapons than mechs? Check, and check!
Brutal difficulty that will make you want to throw your computer out of the nearest available window? CHECK!

Initially, this game is a lot of fun. Instructions on how to play are provided in a hand-on manner, making it easy to jump right in and learn as you play. On the surface, the game is pretty simple: wander around the map, blow things up, leave. Underneath that, there's a bit more complexity, such as different arcs for different weapons, some of which are even affected by the momentum of your vehicle, so you can fire over walls and other low obstacles. You got lasers, machine guns, cannons, even chemical based weapons, and a sub-woofer that just DELETES anything immediately in front of you.

Sounds fun, right? Cos it is.

Until you get further into the game and realise the devs were sadistic @#!$s.

As you progress through the campaign, the difficulty of the missions increases. Dramatically. You'll soon find yourself piloting weak, paper thin vehicles with pop guns taped to the side while a literal ARMY of stronger, more powerful machines descend upon your position like a swarm of angry, killer bees that just got told you stood on their queen. One mission even has you start with NO ammunition in your weapons and forces you to run through a gauntlet of kamikaze trucks to get to the other side of the map, where you can restock you ammo, only to find your weapons are average strength at best.

Or, if story (or what passes for story, in this game) isn't what you're after, you can play single missions with random objectives, on random maps, with random enemies, and a loadout of your choice. Everything from weapons to lore can be bought with money, which can quite easily enough be obtained by doing missions, either Campaign or Freelance, and the difficulty of the missions can be set by what pilot you choose.

So, why am I down voting this, you might ask? Because, unless all you want from this game is a sandbox time killer, with mindless blowing up of random enemies (and outright mass murder of innocent civilians), you're probably going to go from "having a blast" to "beating your head against a brick wall" very quickly. As the Campaign progresses, fun turns to frustration. Not a challenge, not a chore, but cold, hard, unadulterated frustration at the absolute FY of the mission designs. This is a MECH game, not a game of chess, or ninja assassins. You don't "think your way through the problem" when you're in an armoured tank with cannons. You blow #!@$ up and move on. Occasionally you hide behind cover that's actually bigger than you, or go around the back of your enemy for more damage to their backside. You don't flee at the first sign of being sighted and play "cat and mouse" with the whole enemy armada.

If all you want is a 20-40 minute time killer, of mindless explosions and machinery, this game excels.
If you want to finish a story, and shoot for 100% completion, look somewhere else. Unless you're a masochist that likes getting their face shoved in the dirt over and over and over and over and over and over and over until you somehow fluke your way to completion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992400102', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2932, 'last_played': 1688357995}
review:
If you like mechs, morally dubious mercenary work and war crimes then this is the game for you. 

To summarize the setting and plot, Brigador takes place on the planet of Novo Solo, in the city of Solo Nobre. Great leader is dead, Solo Nobre must fall. You take the role of a mercenary known as a Brigador, who has either accepted a lucrative contract, been blackmailed, or given an offer you can't refuse from the SNC. They want their colony back no matter what. so you're free to do whatever you have to in order to complete your objectives, and the best part? You can't be tried for war crimes in SNC controlled colonies, so feel free to commit as many as needed to succeed. 

For example; need to level a city block with fuel-air cluster munitions to take out a Commander? Go for it! Need to get to that orbital gun a couple of seconds faster? Go ahead, level that hospital with an audio kinetic pulse, that'll make a nice pathway for you. Whoops! I accidentally missed my mark and launched chemical weapons into a neighborhood! Oh wait, I got paid for everything that got eaten away by this highly corrosive gas? cool beans.

You have three factions as well with their own visually distinct pilots, mechs and tanks too that add a ton of personality and flavor to the game. 

Loyalists tend to have well balanced vehicles that focus more on armor coverage. Be sure to give the leviathan a spin too, nothing like driving a tank the size of a building. 

Pretty sure the corvids spend most of their time high on gas fumes and their equipment reflects that. It all looks like a junkyard on legs/wheels/whatever those crazy fucks think up of. It's all built without pilot or crew safety in mind. 

Spacers are pretty weird hedonistic space pirates and all their stuff is extremely high tech. Not to mention a lovely shade of red. 

Visual appearances aside the vehicles associated each faction have a very unique feel compared to one another and are entirely modular in terms of armaments and special munitions/ordnance, so once you get to free play experiment and find a mix that works well for you. Since we're on the subject, despite weapons being broken down into hardpoint sizes and a few separate clases (cannons, machine guns, artillery and lasers,) they all feel really diverse and have their own niche and use.

Only thing I really wish is that pilots had unique modifiers and traits to really diversify each game play experience. 

Lastly, the soundtrack is fantastic, and fits incredibly well.

All in all, it's a fantastically fun game. Give it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995787580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4891, 'last_played': 1691127024}
review:
[h1] Mandalore Sent Me [/h1]]

[b] The Premise: [/b] pilot mechs, tanks, grav-vehicles, motorbikes, delivery trucks, and even a small touring van around a myriad of grungy sci-fi environments,  gunning for objectives in single or multi-mission runs. Earn cash from causing mayhem in a completely destructible world, while fighting hordes of foes.

[b] The Game Play: [/b] as difficult or relaxed as you adjust the settings and your loadout to be. For a casual day of fun: Ultra-class tanks that can crush city blocks with ease. For a challenge: a plucky suit of power armor against towering mechs will test your mettle and tactical creativity. 

The loop of playing through missions to unlock more missions and means to finish them is steadily rewarding, with a minimal amount of grind. Guides abound online about how to raise tons of money fast in-game -no guilt necessary; more options means more fun to be had. I knew the game had me when I was thinking of thematic pilot-vehicle-weapon combos, especially when they proved to be particularly challenging. Spend as little as five minutes or at most an hour or so on the shortest and longest mission runs respectively -its all fun.

[b] What I Liked Most [/b] the lore of the world embedded throughout the game. Only a few text scrawls provide a  minimum of background before and after a few of the campaign missions. The bulk of the world building is in the descriptions of the pilots, vehicles, and weapons. These are masterfully done, making excellent use of different, distinct voices. Notice the  coarse and self-deprecating humor of Marvin Beck, compared to the sneering judgments of Cephei Chattfield. I took to the company website after listening to the audio book included, still hungry for more of the setting and characters that had been developed. 

For $19.99, Brigador is an easily recommendable romp that equally rewards what is instantly accessible and enjoyably discovered through hours of play. 

Here's to the sequel, Brigador Killers, being all of this and more.

review: This game was amazing, though we've only seen about half of it. So missions where you have to use mechs or weapons your not used to can make you play in a whole new way and shake up combat!** __Indeed, a great game to play for many hours or as a pick up and put down game. We truly hope you can make the sequel but with how much has been added to this game we can only assume that one would end up as a monster with all new ways to kill your foes and reduce their cities to dust__

author: {'steamid': '76561198119842663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1665870650}
review:
Pros:

-Konig go BRRTTT 


Cons/My gripes with the game:

-In order to get the best experience, you need to either have a good bright monitor or play this in a pitch black room. Most of the maps are dark and/or at night, so it can be difficult to see enemies or environmental hazards if your playing conditions aren't great. A simple fix would be a general brightness setting or a way to make maps permanently day, but until that happens, get used to turning your monitor brightness up, shutting some shades, or running into fuel refineries.

-Their is no way to change the color of your firing arcs. Primary is blue, secondary is red, and your cursor is purple: that's the way it is. There are options to change the color of the primary and secondary ammo bars, but not the arcs. I had trouble seeing the blue primary firing arc due to how dark/blue some of the maps are (especially when you destroy the substations). However, I could have missed the option due to the next issue:

-In settings, you can change the color of the UI, but there is no option (at least at time of writing) to revert the colors back to default. I goofed up some of my UI colors when I was trying to figure out if I could change the color of the firing arcs, so just a heads up if you start tweaking some of the UI colors: write down what the original value is or only change what you need to. It's odd though because in the other settings tabs the option to restore to defaults is there, but not in the UI color tab. I know the UI settings were just added in the last update, so maybe it will get added in the next update.


The root cause of most my issues stem from how dark the game is, which can be easily remedied by turning up the monitor brightness or playing at night/in the dark. Not ideal, but the game makes up for it.

I know it looks like I have a lot of complaints, but it really is a fun game and I highly recommend it. Brigador has a great soundtrack, a surprisingly good story for a relatively straightforward game, and it doesn't get grindy. I was going to do more of a description of the game play here, but instead, if you are thinking of getting the game, get it and experience the game firsthand. 

One last thing: change the controls to one of the relative control schemes. It might take a while to get used to, but it will make the game easier in the long run due to directional damage.
