review:
GRANDE LIDER ESTA MORTO, LIBERE SOLO NOBRE POR QUALQUER MEIO NECESSARIO 

Brigador é um jogo de ação e tatico isometrico 2d, lembrando bastante os graficos de classicos como Fallout 1 e Command and Conquer Tiberium Sun,com cenarios totalmente destrutiveis e belos sprites. O jogo é simples de jogar mas dificil de pegar as manhas,pois apresenta uma variedade de veiculos e armas grandes. É lindo de ver,até mesmo a destruição e os destroços são maneiros de observar junto ao detalhe dos veiculos e o mundo ao redor.

O jogo tem um enredo,apesar de ser usado mais como pano de fundo,a Lore do jogo fica disponivel para leitura, alias até mesmo os pilotos, veiculos e até as armas tem algo para ler e contar mais sobre esse rico e vasto universo que Brigador tem a oferecer. É bem parecido com DOOM: ETERNAL,onde voce pode jogar e ligar o f**da-se pra historia e descer bala em tudo que se move,mas ela esta para aqueles que gostam de uma boa leitura. (Comentarei mais sobre o enredo no final da analise) 

A trilha sonora é otima e pega bastante as musicas eletronicas ou aquele clima de ação dos filmes dos anos 80/90, em um futuro sombrio onde voce não é o  mocinho  ou o  bandido da parada. 

O Gameplay é boa mas cada veiculo tem uma maneira certa de jogar,então é necessario ficar atento ou vai passar um tempo brigando com os controles....alguns Power-suits só podem virar até 180 graus,outros podem girar pelo eixo inteiro e assim por diante.  Os objetivos são variados mas o jogo te recompensa a fazer mais,como alem de cumprir os objetivos,causar o maximo de caos e destruição e dando a chance de ganhar uma grana a mais. 

O jogo pode se tornar dificil a medida que voce progride, sendo necessario um cuidado maior na hora de engajar os oponentes,inclusive tendo 3 tipos : Loyalist , Corvids e Spacers. 

- Os Loyalists são os militares fieis aos regime do Grande Lider, são profissionais e usam equipamentos tipicos de uma força militar bem equipada e organizada,indo desde infantaria a tanques, artilharias, Mechs e powersuits. Usam armamento tradicional com algumas armas a laser fruto de engenharia reversa da tecnologia dos Spacers. Eles tem como objetivo reagrupar e manter a ordem no planeta.

- Os Corvids são os rebeldes que lutam contra o regime,usam armas e veiculos improvisados/roubadas que em alguns casos até lembra veiculos de guerra improvisadas vistos em campos de batalha na Siria ou Ucrania, acoplando armamento em chassis de caminhões,tratores e criando mechs com partes soldadas,remendadas ou roubadas dos oponentes. 

- Os Spacers são humanos cuja a sociedade vive no espaço,seja em naves de guerra a estações espaciais e ODEIAM humanos que vivem em planetas,os chamando de "comedores de sujeira", são vistos como mercenarios ou psicoticos hedonistas com alta e avançada tecnologia aterrorizando o planeta e testando armas e equipamentos nos civis. Seus equipamentos lembram bastante veiculos de exploração espaciais a doideiras tiradas de alguma loucura scifi como o Zed Prime (KNEEL BEFORE ZED !!! ),fazem bastante uso de armas a Laser com raras excessões usando armamento balistico.

O jogo possui uma variedade de veiculos, desde os pequenos e ageis power-suits, motocicletas, blindados, Tanques, Veiculos flutuantes aos poderosos Mechs,cada um com suas vantagens e desvantagens,com cada facção tendo um estilo proprio para cada tipo de veiculo.

O jogo tambem apresenta o modo mercenario,onde podera escolher os pilotos,veiculos,armas e as missões que deseja executar. Cada piloto tem seu modificador e nivel de dificuldade,quanto mais dificil maior a recompensa, alem de fatores unicos....alguns pilotos apenas encaras Corvids,outros apenas inimigos surpresa e assim por diante. 

Antes de comentar sobre o enredo,o jogo de fato usa termos e girias da lingua portuguesa,seja a origem de portugal ou brasileira,então não estranhe se ver alguma coisa em PTBR ou PT-PT em meio ao texto em ingles. 

**ALERTA DE SPOILER ABAIXO** 

A muitos anos, no planeta chamado Novo Solo, era controlada por uma megacorporação de nome desconhecido,uma coloca de exploração onde os colonos eram tratados como escravos e explorados ao maximo,um certo dia,uma revolução explode e é liderada pelo NEP (Novo Exercito do Povo), expulsando a megacorporação e tomando o poder. 

O novo governo instaura um regime militar e controla com mãos de ferro as estações espaciais e o comercio/navegação para dentro ou fora do planeta,criando uma robusta rede de defesas orbitais e tambem reconstruindo o planeta apos a guerra civil para expulsar a megacorporação. O planeta apesar de ser controlado pelo seu libertador conhecido apenas como GRANDE LIDER (sem nome), é autoritario mas cuida de seu povo,fazendo que o planeta prospere e aos poucos constroi uma vida digna aos seus cidadãos, no entanto nem todos gostam do modo que a NEP controla tuda e assim surge um grupo anarco-sindicalista,conhecidos como Corvids (Ou corvinios,se for jogar em PTBR), um grupo rebelde que usa taticas de guerrilha para libertar o planeta em um futuro proximo...

20 apos o planeta ser libertado, em uma noite sombria na capital Solo Nobre, o Grande Lider morreu, ninguem sabe como ou quem matou, mas é nessa noite que a Megacorporação retorna usando uma empresa-fantoche conhecida como SNC (Solo Nobre Concern), contratando proxies e pilotos dentro do planeta para sabotar a infraestrutura e as defesas planetarias....é ai que voce entra. 

Voce é um traidor da causa (caso seja um Loyalist ou Corvid) ou um Spacer mercenario a serviço da SNC, alguns dos pilotos foram recrutados por serem a escoria,outros por terem sido traidos dentro de suas organizações e outros por pura ganancia ou foram chantageados a agir em nome da SNC...não importa o motivo, o jogador devera trair seu planeta natal e sabotar as facções locais para facilitar a invasão planetaria que a Mega Corporação em breve lançara, resgatando voce no processo e de quebra receber um pagamento o suficiente para viver confortavel na sede da mega corporação.

O jogo tera uma continuação chamada BRIGADOR KILLERS onde vamos nos vingar dos pilotos que trairam Solo Nobre mas no momento sem data de lançamento. 

Resumo : Vale super a pena comprar essa obra de arte, a OST,os graficos...tudo nesse jogo é agradavel. Se voce gosta da lore pode ate comprar o AudioBook vendido por aqui na Steam, acompanhando a saga de um dos pilotos jogaveis na campanha. 

Nota : 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198090542544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 812, 'last_played': 1704495206}
review:
BLUF; If you find yourself wondering, " should I but this game?" Do it. Bought this game after coming across it during a sale quite some time ago. The environment in this game is incredible and the action will keep you on the edge of your seat. Tactical mistakes will cost you dearly and you will find yourself doing everything you can to regain some for of initiative in combat. The campaign missions are challenging and will test your abilities.  I have found myself to be partial towards mechs and powersuits. Infinite replay value with the random missions. I see a lot of complaints about the aiming system, I find it to be appropriate given the platforms the weapons are mounted on. And for those who have not been able to experience the book... do so.. one of the better SciFI novels I have ever listened too. I have listened to it probably four or five times now, excellent story. I wish they offered a campaign along the lines of the story.  
Detailed and captivating environment, gripping combat, awesome soundtrack and replay value will have this game  frequently played in your collection. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994925709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1642917084}
review:
The tank controls + cursor aiming system doesn't feel good, the cursor is tiny and feels off (you have to aim at the tile the enemy is situated on specifically rather than the enemy), menus/mission selection/briefing screens are bad, no voice acting or character development so nothing feels at stake.  The music is good, though (I was already a fan of MAVS).  I played the A/B missions and started on the C when I realized I had not yet had any fun and didn't care about anything that was happening.

If this game had more time put into its intro, had mission briefings with recurring characters/voice acting, and had characters appearing in-game during missions (whether as units or just radio contacts), it would feel like you are part of a bigger story instead of just randomly shooting things to tick off mission objectives.  Having lore be exclusively purchasable vs. something at least partially revealed through gameplay was a mistake.

Just don't misconstrue this game as being some lightning fast twin-stick shooter. It's a slow and deliberate tactical combat game in stompy mechs, tanks and hovercraft. Play the campaign until the tutorials are done and then jump into Freelance. Also, use tank controls. Seriously, use them.

review: tiny super fast hovercars, chainbikes, a bus with tracks, BIG hovercars, big mechs, small mechs, powersuits, MASSIVE tanks explosions, lasers, massive weapons, a massive variety of pilots to play with, proceduraly generated themed maps, tons and tons of loadout combinations.... you got the point. buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031988409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1359, 'last_played': 1642793865}
review:
It took me a while to get into it, but once I was hooked I was really hooked. From its Synth music and top-down perspective you might be tricked into thinking that this is a mech version of Hotline Miami but dig deeper and you'll find a fiendishly complex tactical mech game which perfectly combines tense positioning and frantic firefights. Brigador is packed with content, lore, weapons and vehicles. It's honestly a steal at its current price and on sale its even more worth it. 

At the very least its worth giving it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074085762', 'num_games_owned': 1145, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1636149660}
review:
[h1] Muy buen juego en su terreno. [/h1]

Variedad de modos de juego, de mapas y de vehículos.
Controlas un vehículo, ya sea un mecha, un tanque, una nave... y tu objetivo es destruir X cosas dentro de una ciudad.

Puedes abordar la situación de varias maneras, ya sea con sigilo, a distancia, destrozándolo todo...
Como tu quieras, lo importante es acabar con los objetivos y no morir en el intento.

Todos los decorados y objetos son destruibles, lo que aporta mucho juego a la hora de abordar el objetivo, además de una gran satisfacción a la hora de desatar todo el armamento que lleves equipado.

Tiene dos "modos" un modo historia y otro libre.
En el modo historia te dan ellos el vehículo junto al mapa y en el libre eliges tú.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989212961', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1688242499}
review:
Bought this game as it reminded me of a game called bedlam (isometric game with a hover mech from the dos era) I played long ago that had a similar setting.

So what does this game entail, it is a action packed vehicle versus ai enemies on a map with total destruction of the environment possibilities, but it is not mindless, one needs tactics and carefully poking and luring the enemies to clear the objectives.

When stuff goes wrong it quickly turns into a mad scramble to try and get into the most optimal spot still available and move around the enemies so one can focus fire them down while not letting most of the enemies return fire on you. If all goes according to plan one lures the enemies on ones own terms into ambushes and clears them out peacemeal. 

So far love the setting, the controls are nice and responsive, the game runs like a charm and is fun. The isometric perspective kinda gives me the vibe of the old syndicate game but now using a vehicle.

The campaign showcases both the mechanics of the game and the lore behind it, the freelance mode allows infinite generation of maps and adversaries to take down. The game also has a massive amount of things one can unlock from pilots to vehicles to weapon systems to levels and so one can tool each freelance run to ones own preference and challenge level.

The modkit is also available for the game and via the discord of the game one can find quite some mods one can patch in to extend the amount of options and levels.

Please note however the game is single player so far and should it ever get a 2 player co-op mode with friendly fire on it would imho improve it even further.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969025704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1708029341}
review:
I feel like Brigador is *THIS* close to being perfect. The art style, the music, the design of the mechs, the frantic mania of combat, all of these are really solid and on-point for this game. 

I think Brigador drops the ball hard in two spots that make its more frustrating than it should be though. Number 1 are the movement and aiming mechanics. The game looks a lot like a twin stick shooter, but it's most definitely not. Bullets and projectiles arc slightly in a height dimension that isn't obvious at the start and only gets more important as the game goes on. Once you master the concept of lobbing block-destroying energy orbs over huge security fences it starts to make sense and you can see why the designers made it that way, but it gets in the way of fun more often than its generated. The movement mechanics are somewhat easy to deal with via options settings, but still somewhat confusing and not really what you would expect from some vehicles.

Number 2 is the story mode. I think the over-arching story in the game is super interesting and the factions and personalities behind them are very well written, I just wish it was tied together better. Every mission feels disconnected to the previous one and there doesn't feel like any continuity or progression. The freelance mission mode is much better, but you still have to unlock them one at a time, which can be a frustrating bar to overcome, but I think suits the design of what they were going for better. It's certainly more fun to just hit the random button, load up a mission and smash stuff for 10 minutes.

It sounds like this is a negative review, but I do really think this is a fun experience, provided you know those two points going in. I'd love to see a Brigador 2, but troubled development at the studio doesn't leave me optimistic any time soon. If a sequel could bend more towards a twin-stick approach, make the missions be a little more story-driven, and keep everything else as-is, then it would be an instant classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029936404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5546, 'last_played': 1656371453}
review:
As someone who 100%'d the content as of writing this, I have to say that Brigador is a great game to play casually or find a way to provide a challenging grind that feels rewarding. The game is about taking a mech or vehicle and destroy enemies or objectives with side-objectives that reward a player more cash to buy more vehicles, pilots, and weapons.

The game offers a campaign mode where you should play if you're starting this game, and it provides both a good experience when starting out and gives fair challenge throughout.

It is worth the full price because in freelance mode there are 126 vehicles, 40 unique weapons, 4 special vehicle abilities, 53 pilots, and 18 freelance missions. Also, you can in freelance mode play the 38 main campaign missions in any loadout of your choosing. And in doing the math, there is 1,169,344,512 possible gameplay choices a player can make. Of course, not all choices are equal and some are better than others, but the fun in the game is finding that stuff out for yourself.

So go on ahead and buy the game since it offers amazing value, challenging gameplay, and allows you to live your city-destroying mech dreams.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995722872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1655490094}
review:
I got this on a lark when it was on sale. Turns out this is worth the price of admission just for the soundtrack. The Deluxe edition is worth it just for the audiobook and bonus tracks. Then the game itself is absolutely worth the price.

1. This is more of a tank sim than twin-stick shooter and I am here for it
2. I don't actually dig the fake-retro art style generally, but they make it work and I admit that this looks like the best possible Tiberian Sun.
3. Gameplay is solid, very arcade-action without too much time required per-sitting
4. The universe and storyline is actually pretty great. I am a sucker for scifi, though.

In short, I don't know how this game got made (how does an action-arcade game have such solid writing? How does a game where you only ever have 2 guns feel so deep? How can casual genocide for bonus cash feel so relaxing?), but good lord I am glad it did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971042404', 'num_games_owned': 574, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1676180593}
review:
Great game, wish I'd have given it a try sooner. The progression is unique in that the strongest stuff is the cheapest; you aren't saving up to buy better equipment, you're saving up to play against a harder challenge. It's really satisfying to increase the difficulty, take longer missions, use smaller vehicles, and still succeed.

Also, the war crimes are truly horrific and haunting. It's a very dark setting.

review: When I went into this, I was just hoping for a simple arcade shooter, something similar to what you'd see in flash games but with more content. But the entire game falls apart once you have to deal with the controls. I don't know why this is a PC game. So far I've been unable to adjust to the stiff controls and the settings don't change anything. But even if I get used to them, there are other problems. The destructive terrain seems like a big selling point, but all it does is add to performance issues. Its not really a mech game, because there is very little depth put into the mechanic. It could be just a robot running around shooting things rather than a piloted mech. And I have no clue whats up with the presentation, like the level difficulty. No explanation as to why I can give up on a mission and no easy way to reset things. This ones a doosey but I'll still give it a try again sometime later. Not worth the trouble of buying

review:
I like this game for the visceral sense of reward when you win. The variety of the campaign mode is very refreshing, and playing with loadouts I would not have otherwise chosen gets me outside of my comfort zone. The art is delightfully synth-punk sci-fi grunge, and the soundtrack slaps.

The only complaint I had wasn't with the gameplay at all, but with an infuriating bug that required consultation from the Internet. Upon launch, the screen would flicker and the game would crash, logging around 2 seconds of playtime on Steam for the 'amount of time played' stat. After that was solved (I apologize for not linking the solution, nearly bedtime when I wrote this), the rest has scratched an itch I've had for a long time!

Edit: I must have a few of these models in WH40K scale, and would be thrilled to take any part in making that happen to the benefit of the devs!

review:
I have funni number of hours so I figure I can finally review. It's a kind of game to boot up for an hour or two after some bad shit happened or after a tiresome day at work to unwind. I can't play this for a long time, only in bursts, but they do help and brigador is cheaper than therapy.

I love this game, I love the unadulterated rage, I love the killing music, I love the symphony of destruction. The game is fantastic. I also dig the story, so far I listened to the audio book for three times and unlocked every entry to read in the aquisitions. I don't remember another game where I would be so immersed into lore. Perhaps it's because I grew up in eastern europe. 

I hope  the devs can get their shit together and finish the sequel

author: {'steamid': '76561197972658645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 6267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5757, 'last_played': 1679275379}
review:
Curiously enough, I had bought this game before the Mandalore review. Played it a good while, got impressed with the music and lore, but then life took me through other paths. Never thought of it as a great game, but I distinctly recall having enjoyed myself with it.

Of course, the Mandalore review came in, and so I installed it again. To my surprise, the game was now the Up-Armored edition. To my even bigger, very pleasant surprise, the game had been updated constantly ever since release, adding several new missions, a level editor, better graphics, and so on. So, I installed it and fired it up.

I became obsessed with it. I devoured the book, the soundtrack is now one of my most listened albums on Spotify, and didn't stop playing it until I 100% it. 

The game is not for everyone, that's for sure. While the game can certainly be frantic at times, this isn't an arcade game. Think of it as the isometric Mechwarrior game we all deserved. Mech and tank combat is reasonably realistic, with turning speeds, limited turret angles and locational armor. There is trajectory, penetration and projectile speed to consider for each shot, and ammo is limited, as well as your hitpoints. So, it's a really tactical game. Taking it slow is worth it, fleeing is valid, and hiding perfectly possible. All this, of course, while being drenched on an incredibly well-built world, which, regrettably, is pretty much another book inside the game. I say regrettably because I know most people won't have the patience to read through it, or perhaps won't savor it as much. Me, I'm a lore-head, so everything I read immersed me even more in the nocturnal, chaotic, and solitary world of Solo Nobre. 

An impressive game for a niche audience, with an incredible world behind it, and a really lasting impression. Very recommended, if only to support the devs :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198001253264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1628357953}
review:
Music is good. Visuals are rad. 

Gameplay is... hit-or-miss. 

Structure and progress of the game was what made me bail. The repetition and the nonsensical back and forth between factions, along with the fact that you can only pick certain vehicles for the mission didn't help. It made it feel like you were just playing a string of randomly generated missions, instead of actually going through to some end goal... even if that end goal was simply getting to the end of the story. 

Such a shame. I had been waiting for years to get this at a price that I thought was reasonable for this type of game (even bought the novella, which is an interesting read), but it just didn't click.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985982321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 4529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 688, 'last_played': 1672346395}
review:
This game delivers everything it promises. It's like synthwave reverse sim city where you smash entire city blocks to rubble with various mechs and vehicles. 

The graphics are pleasing. As someone who has made a lot of isometric-style sprites, the decision to go with an inbetween amount of angles (24? 32?) and the render size make these sprites absolutely amazing. The sounds, the particle effects, the debris and different levels of destruction.. the people walking around being stomped or run over... It's a 90's style PC game at heart but with sophistication and satisfying interactivity.

It's Mechwarrior 3050 reimagined lovingly for the modern era. What more can I say?

author: {'steamid': '76561198151689142', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1701866182}
review:
貴方は何らかの理由で弊社こと「SNC」と独立契約しています。貴方は弊社と関連している事が第三者に発覚した場合殺害、口頭での注意、または契約破棄される傭兵であり、「Bridgator」と呼ばれています。

貴方、あるいは貴女は多様な背景を持っており、全員が優秀なオペレーターではありません。大抵の場合、身の程知らずだったりして作戦開始前からソロ、リブレの警戒態勢が高くなります。

もちろん、身の程をわきまえたパイロットであったり、破壊工作専門のパイロットであれば、ソロ、リブレで兵力の薄い地点を攻撃する選択肢もあります。

弊社から提示する契約は多くは無いですが、大抵の場合は3つの契約のうち2つを達成して頂ければ契約が完了したと認識し、ソロ、リブレから帰還して頂ければ指定の口座に振り込まれます。

弊社は困難な作戦を達成した場合、提示していた報酬の何倍もお支払いしたします。逆に、想定より単純な作戦になった場合、報酬は何倍も減額します。

「特に問題なく作戦をこなせる能力を持つ傭兵」と「一般的に広く普及している機体」の場合、弊社は作戦目標を達成した通り、提示した通りの額をお支払いいたします。

「生活苦での焦りのある傭兵」と「パワードスーツ程度のサイズの一人用戦車」で作戦目標を達成し、帰還した際は、提示していた額の12倍お支払いいたします。

弊社としては提示した契約を達成して頂き、契約書条項※別途金額を必要としたします※を参照して頂ければ作戦目標を誰が、何で、どうやって達成したのかは一任します。


以降何か必要な情報等あれば、私の後任者、または前任者のレビューを参考にしていただければ幸いです。

author: {'steamid': '76561198049840197', 'num_games_owned': 484, 'num_reviews': 383, 'playtime_forever': 4164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 24, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1711741657}
review:
I think a lot of people misunderstand what Brigador is.
And the game does not help that at all.

Brigador looks and sounds a lot like Hotline Miami. It's all neon pixels and thumping synthwave music.
With the opening statement of "Great Leader is dead. Solo Nobre must fall" as you stomp a few hundred civilians into thin red paste you'd think you're set for a face paced action shooter experience.

Lol no.
Brigador could more accurately be described as a Maneuver/Urban Warfare simulator.  

I won't waste time talking about the campaign. Frankly I got bored of it pretty fast and since your pigeonholed into certain loadouts it kinda sucks. Sure the loadouts change with each mission but I rarely liked any of them. They just don't fit my style. 

Freelance is where its at, hundreds of unlockable pilots who all have their own modifiers. Changing your starting difficulty, your reward bonuses, which enemy factions and what units you will face. Loads of vehicles too Mechs, tanks and "agravs" all with their own quirks and hardpoints. All set loose on very open ended semi-random missions to cause chaos.

What you'll notice right away is the loadouts with the highest rewards have the least armour and the smallest guns. Which is why I call Brigador a maneuver warfare sim. 
Once you realise the game doesn't want you to destroy every single building in sight and do all the possible objectives the game becomes a lot faster and a lot easier. Even in an Ultra class mech with the biggest guns available fully clearing a mission is hard and very time consuming. 
The game wants you to play fast and aggressive but not stupid, you're supposed to move through a level with deliberate targets in mind. Strike from the flanks, engage quick and disengage faster. Always be moving. Never let the enemy see your backside. 

Instead of conveying this rather essential core concept of manuvere warfare the game will instead spend the first 10 missions beating you over the head with insultingly simple tutorials. Avoid scouts, things that explode will hurt you, break walls, blah blah blah. 
The game has such a focus on letting you destroy everything in sight that its very understandable how an average player would assume that mass destruction is the goal of the game.
Rather than a bonus or something to be done tactically. 
Something that I really could have used a tutorial on is that firing a mortar is loud, but the impact of your shells are a helluva lot louder. 

Also Brigador devs we need to talk.
Why are your default controls so lame? 
For whatever reason the default control scheme does not allow you to rotate your turret & legs/treads separate from each other. Instead you move "screen absolute" with a fixed facing like a twin stick shooter. 

Also also. Brigador devs, again.
Why in the Sam Hill are your weapon stats so useless?
Don't tell me a gun is "loud" tell me from E X A C T L Y how far away my shots can be heard.
Don't tell me its got 5 stars of damage. Tell me E X A C T L Y how much damage I'll do per shot. If it fires more than one shot per salvo tell me how much damage each pellet will do and how many pellets there will be.
ESPECIALLY if you're going to give me EXACT stats for how much armor and shield my enemies have. 

The first issue I admit is minor, you can just change the controls after all.
But the stats are exceedingly frustrating. If I want to make a build I want to be absolutely sure of what my ranges, rate of fire, and expected damage out put will be. I don't know why video games keep withholding information about weapon stats or using nonsense arbitrary systems to describe their stats.
Games have been assigning exact numerical values to items since fucking CHESS. It should not be some cosmic mystery that giving players detailed information leads to a better experience. 

Ultimately, I really like whats here. Anyone whose seen me play Mechwarrior knows how much I love games that focus on movement and positioning. 
I just feel Brigador's design is very misguided and will probably lead to a lot of players assuming the game is something its not. I know a lot of people haven't finished most of the campaign, probably because the game is very different than what they expect.
When someone like Mandalore says "the game hard, and has lots of action" they probably expect another Hotline Miami. Not something as geniunely unique and thoughtful as Brigador.

review:
Hace mucho que buscabaa un juego como Brigador.
Me gustan las diferentes unidades y armas. Esta variedad genera distintos modos de juego.
Esta es la parte que creo que los desarrolladores hicieron muy bien.
Para mí, el juego en sí, el gameplay, el game loop, me queda debiendo.
Yo esperaaba un juego más orientado a la acción, pero está mas bien orientado al stealth, al sigilo.
Hay que ir cuidadosamente por los niveles. Poco a poco. Lentamente.
Ese es el desafío de los niveles. Buscar la mejor ruta para cumplir el objetivo (llegar al final, destruir edificios o unidades). Lo cual no se puede hacer rápidamente, o sin cuidado, pues atraes a todas las unidades del nivel.

Recomendado si buscas dominar los diferentes tipos de vehículos, cumpliendo las distintas misiones de manera sigilosa.

Yo hubiera preferido un enfoque más hacia la acción y mucho menos enfocado en el sigilo.

review: Good mech games are really hard to come by and this one is a gem. As you get deeper into the campaign you can't just run and gun as you did in the beginning, you have to apply some strategy to your runs. Take out the comms towers to slow down alerts, blow up substations to prevent panic walls from raising. You will find yourself trying out different vehicles and strategies to get through some of the tougher missions. All of this fun is enhanced with a phenomenal soundtrack, you can pick it and the audiobook (which is also great) in the add-ons. If you like big machine combat, retro shooters, and cyberpunk aesthetics, then this is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048244150', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 726, 'last_played': 1661685852}
review:
The core gameplay is really good, took me a while to get to grips and start playing well, but that's exactly what I was looking for.

I do, however, think this game is lacking in a few quality of life and progression based areas. 

The random choice for freelance mode is a great idea, but without the ability to blacklist certain vehicles or missions you might find yourself pressing it a couple times to get what you want. Even without a blacklist, at least a choice between a couple random mechs would be more interesting.

The view distance was also something I struggled with. I would have gladly taken a suboptimal mech if it allowed me to see further. For a loud approach this isn't an issue, but for stealth I was always wishing to see just a little bit further into the distance.

The thing that bothered me most though was the progression. You just earn money too fast, especially if you can sneak around in a tuk tuk. That's not to say that I ran out of things to buy, just that I got all the stuff I wanted really fast, and was left buying the other stuff because I could. I never felt the need to play higher difficulties or longer missions, which was a little disappointing. 

Personally speaking I would have loved to see some sort of permadeath mode, where you lose your purchases and have to make do with other stuff, maybe multi zone missions where you pick up new gear as you complete missions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986527965', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 415, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1634395412}
review:
Brigador is pretty much what it looks like. Pilot some sort of mech through a level while destroying $hit.

Brigador is divided into 3 main sections: Campaign, Freelance, and Acquisitions. The campaign features 51 levels. The early part of the campaign is a tutorial with your mech selected for you. Later, you get a choice of 4 different vehicles for each mission. You get money for each mission you finish based on the vehicle you selected. Choose lemony vehicles for larger monetary rewards. Acquisitions allows you to spend money buying mech types, weapons, freelance maps, lore, etc. The mechs, weapons, etc are for freelance play. Freelance lets you load into a map with a personally customizable mech from mechs/weapons that you've unlocked. Levels typically require you to destroy a certain percentage of enemies or destroy specific enemies/buildings and then you're free to go to the level exit. If you die, you get very little money and are then free to retry or resign and try out a different vehicle.

Brigador starts off well enough but has too many issues.

This is extremely repetitive. Despite the huge variety of mechs and slight change in mission types/locations/etc, every mission feels pretty much the same and plays out pretty much the same. There are a few enemy types that stand out and you'll learn, but despite there being 3 factions and multiple types of each vehicle for each faction, they all pretty much blend together. Blow up the same looking/acting vehicles and buildings on every level. The campaign is 51 levels long. The story descriptions for each level are mostly pointless. I was already tired of the campaign by halfway through it but finished it for the sake of finishing it. It felt like a chore.

Some of the mechs are incredibly cumbersome and annoying to use as they don't automatically turn their bodies to line up with where you're aiming. You have to manually do this.

Then there's the aiming. Each mech has a blue line and a pink line extending out from it showing your primary/secondary aiming points. These don't line up so you can be hitting something with your primary but missing with your secondary and vice versa. Sometimes you'll be aimed perfectly on enemies and still be missing them somehow. Especially annoying are hover vehicles which you don't aim directly at to hit them, but aim at the shadows well below them to hit.

Killing enemies sometimes results in shields/ammo popping out. These vanish after a little bit if you don't pick them up. Sometimes they stick around for 5-10 seconds max, other times they'll be there 30-60 seconds after you killed whatever it was. I have absolutely no idea what causes the huge disparity between whether shield/ammo pickups stick around for a large amount of time or seemingly disappear seconds after they showed up. That said, it's extremely annoying when they disappear right in front of you as you're going to get them.

The majority of deaths, if not the vast majority of them will come from insta or near insta deaths. Some buildings explode when shot or walked into causing a huge amount of damage or outright killing you if you're next to them. There are plenty of nondescript buildings that explode. Even after the 51 campaign levels, there were still things I weren't sure if they were going to explode or not. So you have to spend  time avoiding this nonsense, shooting them to test it out, or just going by them and hoping something doesn't cause one to explode. I'm not a game designer, but objects that explode, especially if they're essentially a game over, should stand out and be obvious to your player.

Aside from exploding buildings, the other main way you'll die is from the occasional level with large mortar enemies who can shoot them from a mile off and they come down in a small area in clusters of 10-15. If you happen to be in that area, you're pretty much fucked.

The last 10-15 levels of the campaign are mostly about zerg swarms coming at you. Occasionally these will kill you, especially since it's incredibly easy to lose sight of your aiming points as they blend in with the swarm/background. Also notable is that I don't believe weapons have a maximum range. If you're shooting at zerg swarms, your rounds can go to the whole other side of the level and aggro enemies on the other side of the map, further adding to the swarm.

Ooooo, I almost forget my favorite part of this. Do you love getting stuck on random $hit while playing games? Then you're going to love this game. Every enemy you kill leaves behind an incredibly hard to see husk that takes your mech forever to get through and fully destroy. So when swarms of enemies come at you and you're blowing them up around you and trying to dodge, you will repeatedly get stuck on $hit. Then add in the plethora of buildings/walls that all blend together and if the smallest pixel of them is touching the smallest pixel of your mech causes you to get stuck on them as well. It's incredibly aggravating.

It's obvious that a lot of love went into Brigador going through the massive amount of intel, lore, etc in the game. Unfortunately love doesn't equal quality. Brigador is mostly a mindless mediocre mech shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198398867000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2095, 'last_played': 1707052826}
review:
是个值得一玩的好游戏！
大量种类的机甲，坦克，可以搭配各种武器，特殊装备（技能），可全部破坏的复杂地图和各种各样且数量庞大的敌人，可以装上各种大威力，大范围的爆炸性武器一次毁掉一整片街区，或者装上高射速的大机枪看满屏弹幕乱飞。
这个游戏不是单纯的射爆游戏，游戏有潜伏玩法，喜欢挑战的玩家也可以选择使用轻型的机体/坦克，装备小噪音大威力的火炮，谨慎地选择路线直接摧毁目标并避免交火，全身而退。
除了自由的打法外，游戏有很多的阅读内容，文字量相当于一本科幻小说，有很多有意思的小故事，每个角色，武器，装备，区域，都有自己背后的故事。
游戏也有一些问题，虽然关卡打法很多，但是关卡内容比较单调。另外还有些武器并不能玩家自己操作比较可惜，但是最可惜的是！最可惜的是！！！最可惜的是！！！！！没法多人联机啊啊啊啊啊！！！！！！！！！
这游戏要是能联机得好玩50倍！
总之是个很推荐的游戏~喜欢机甲，赛博朋克，科幻的朋友值得一试~！

review:
[h1]재미있는 로봇액션게임. 단 매크워리어나 아머드코어라고 생각하면 안된다.[/h1]

조종할 수 있는 장비 숫자가 많다. 매크나 자동차, 탱크, 심지어 소형로봇과 민간인까지 가능하다.
조종사도 바꿀 수 있다. 조종사에 따라 게임의 난이도와 보너스 기타 추가적인 특징들이 바뀐다.
반면에 커스터마이징 할 수 있는게 무기랑 보조옵션뿐으로 이거때문에 호불호가 갈릴 수 있다.

나는 이 게임을 메크워리어로 보고 구입했기때문에 썩 마음에 들지는 않더라.
매크들이 멋있지 않고 건물이나 지형지물은 그게 그거고 탑다운 슈터형식에 커스터마이징 할 수 있는게 별로 없었기때문에 초반에는 재미없다고 생각하고 플레이 했다. 내가 좋아할 이유가 별로 없거든...

하지만! 그럼에도 불구하고 내가 거의 5시간 넘게 플레이했다. 다른 게임 하다가 잠깐잠깐씩 이걸 플레이 한걸 생각하면 아주 많이 플레이한거다. 재미있었다. 내가 좋아할 이유가 별로 없는데 이정도로 플레이 할 정도로 재미 있었다.

그러기에 추천한다. 물론 이걸 메크워리어나 아머드코어로 보고 사겠다면 말려야겠지만.
할인도 자주 하기 때문에 할인할때를 노려서 구매하라.
[h1]잘 만든 게임. 돈값은 확실히 한다.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197972599329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1684615030}
review:
Unlike so many games where the prerogative is to be careful and avoid collateral damage, this game revels in pure carnage.  Pilot around 100 different vehicles from Mega-hover-fortress to a tuktuk truck and arm yourself with conventional stuff like machineguns, lasers, cannons, mortars or ever a rail gun if you are fancy. However for the warcriminal inside you there stuff like cancer ray, toxic waste barrel launcher, ultra sound pulse and many more. 

Ingenious approach to difficulty. You pilot and vehicle combo act as a  difficulty meter. Some pilots spawn entire armadas because they are a known war criminal while others fight against infantry and few dirt bikes.
The more powerful your vehicle the less payout you have in the end. So playing with dinky tuk-tuk truck while facing entire map swarm of enemies is quite a ride. 

Also rip-snorting sound track. If you love hotline miami you will love this. 
Also also dangerous based devs 
10/10 would buy again on gog

review: Have you ever played SimCity 4 and thought "I really want to drive down the streets of my bustling metropolis in the Apollo Program's lunar rover, armed with both a sentient GAU-8 Avenger and a DIY Soviet BS-3 anti-tank gun"? Yeah me too. ACQUIRE PAPER PLATE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081201242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2992, 'last_played': 1710789044}
review:
This is one of my favorite games of all time now. I do say this lightly. Brigador itself is such a well crafted and thought out experience of a game, every aspect I enjoyed. 

The lore of this game is what kept me hooked. The setting, which has also earned a spot in my top favorite sci fi settings, is very very unique yet digestible in it's own right. It's visible instantly with the stunning mech design and aesthetics of this world. I became obsessed with it, each pilot and intel section a reason to push forward. As I began to reach the endgame, I picked up the audiobook, which is also A VERY good companion to the game itself.

Even without the setting (which to my personal taste is what draws me into games first) the gameplay is absolutely solid. It's real time strategy, and action wrapped into one. The vehicles and pilots you choose determine your style of play, and all are fun. Some are more harder than others, but you never have to be locked into one way of handling a situation outside of the tutorial. Though you'd be doing yourself a disservice if you never try to take a weak vehicle into combat, something that's nimble but dies faster so you have to learn enemy patrols and strategize hitting your targets and picking fights.

Most of the games end goal revolves around unlocking a variety of weapons, mechs, and pilots for freelance mode, on top of lore tidbits and operations. I thought that wouldn't be for me, in most games with similar concepts I just think "is there a money glitch" or "Why can't I just have it now?" - not with brigador. For some reason, maybe just in me, something clicked. I reveled in the challenge of using faster, weaker mechs and insane pilots for higher payouts. It activated a completionist instinct which has yet to cull on the harder achievements.

This game in particular absolutely deserves your patronage. It is excellent, and even now criminally underrated. I look forward to Brigador Killers, and it's companion book with GREAT anticipation. Aquire Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025732064', 'num_games_owned': 1251, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1631206884}
review:
[h1]Alpha Version[/h1]

[b]Brigador[/b] is an old-school isometric [b]Jungle Strike[/b]-style mech-combat-simulation arcade with decent 2D artwork and appealing retrowave OST.

But at its core, it is still an early-access game that strives to achieve excellency but fails miserably at every possible step.

There is no variety to the missions whatsoever - every single operation goes like this: get in the mech, explore the map (randomly generated in the freelance mode, uninspiringly slapped together in the campaign mode), destroy [i]N[/i] something (enemy officers, buildings, etc.). 
The shooting gets stale pretty quick, especially considering the horrible control scheme with the body rotation being nigh impossible when operating wheels-based vehicles (also, there is no gamepad support), unreliable aiming (e.g. long-range laser weapons), and an ultimately flawed difficulty curve - at later stages of the campaign ([i]D[/i]-levels onward, to be meticulous) the combat intensity increases: not thanks to the introduction of new advanced enemies but rather via taking away all the good mechs at your disposal - the ones you are getting after that stage are absolute jalopies (save for the [spoiler]Zed Prime[/spoiler] model). 
The increased difficulty curve leaves the player only one option to beat the longer maps - the tedious hit-and-run approach.

The story fluff is presented via graphomaniac mission briefings that became a chore to read after around an hour.

The final mission is bizarrely anticlimactic.

The freelance mode brings nothing to the table - all same weapons, all same mechs, the same repetitive 9-to-5-grind-style gameplay.

Verdict: a bad game with shallow mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077113116', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1637522122}
review:
Brigador is a blast. 

 I really like how versatile your tactics can be. Want to play a light hover bike with an indirect mortar and a gauss rifle with active camo for a stealthy and indirect combat style? No problem. How about a tank the size of an apartment block bristling with weapons? No problem. You can play as an infantryman if you like, or jump in a tuk-tuk. There are loads of options, and very nearly all of them are viable.

 There are lots of pilots to choose from but they only really affect rewards and difficulty. The bios for the characters are generally well written but they are probably the weakest part of the background info. The lore in this game was a real surprise. Well written, well thought out, consistently bouncing between dark humour and the tragedy of war. After the weapons I unlocked this just for the pleasure of reading it.

 I have to mention the sound too. The music is fantastic, great for setting the pace. The sound effects of your mech stomping about a city, the gunfire sounds, the way that the AI reacts to the noise you make make this a very immersive experience.

 I bought this on sale but knowing what I do now I would happily pay full price for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989677083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1629930169}
review:
If you treat Brigador like a simulator instead of a twin stick shooter, you'll find a surprising amount of rewarding depth and variety on offer.

The sheer variety of vehicle/weapon combinations on offer is impressive, given that they all have their own quirks and there seems to be very little "repetition" that I can see between their designs.

The game rewards and encourages the "exploitation" of the AI behaviour, and things like cover and range. Find that special, unique, way that you want to cheese, and you'll find that there's a high probability that it will be effective in a wide variety of the mission settings.

It has everything covered; from a gigantic, heavily armoured tower made of heavy guns, all the way down to a tiny one man army, sneaking around corners to pop tanks in their rear, before running away. The game also rewards you for taking a more difficult path by adding difficulty multipliers based on the combination of pilot and vehicle you choose.

Very much recommended.

review:
Briefly, it's a highly replayable mech strategic game. Fast paced and difficult to play well but when you get the hang of it and start nailing some difficult scenarios it's amazing. It starts off slow enough to learn the basics and the freelance mode is killer. Overall it's a wonderful game with good sounds, graphics, and story. Though the story is mostly hidden in the book (audio book included) and the unlockable lore.

I had some fun with it, didn't think it was all that special. But then I listened to the book, read some lore, and watched a great youtube video reviewing it. Once I got a few of the nuances and had some story to back up the gameplay I've played it every time I had a few minutes to spare (not many of those recently). There is just so much more than first meets the eye.

Check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986409130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 6624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6624, 'last_played': 1628788201}
review:
Запускай, уничтожай, отступай. Повторить.
Геймплей игры прост и даже отупляющ. Несмотря на большой арсенал мехов и вооружения, миссии кампании и свободной игры сводятся к дави-стреляй. И как это? Очень даже хорошо. Процесс и оформление выполнены просто прекрасно – все работает на то, чтобы тебе не захотелось останавливаться, от бытия машиной уничтожения. Звуки музыка, антураж и сеттинг – садись в мех и воюй. Однако, для меня у игры есть слабости. Малая – мусорный дизайн техники. Это не плохо, это просто своеобразно, когда несмотря на разные фракции, вся техника выглядит собранной на помойке. Да, это обусловлено, но глазу от этого не легче. Более серьезным минусом я считаю жуткое однообразие миссий – геймдизайн в кампанию просто не завезли. И самая главное – просто преступление в таком сеттинге и с такой проработкой лора, вообще забить на какой-либо связный сюжет.
Не шедевр, но окунуться и насладиться однозначно стоит.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026717018', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3125, 'last_played': 1628923523}
review:
Difficult, but mostly in all the right ways. Some mechs/tanks just plow through enemies, persisting through salvos of incoming fire while raining down death with artillery, lasers, cannons, or missiles. Other vehicles need to dart in and out of combat, using stealth, cover, and guile to outwit enemies or suffer a quick and explosive death from a single shot or suicide bomber. Still more vehicles have even more specific strategies that become clear by using their unique preset loadouts in the Campaign mode, which opens up your mind when you start making your own builds in Freelance missions. 

The missions vary from complete stomps to really tough and exasperating slogs, but none of them have felt impossible so far. Just very, very tough. But if you're looking for a difficult game that doesn't pull punches but also doesn't waste your time artificially, this is probably for you.

Great art style reminiscent of older games. I am reminded by the art in the original Fallout games from the pilot portraits and isometric view. The particles and weapon effects are satisfying and punchy, the music is great and fitting, and the destruction of the environments is perfect.

A good game with steep but satisfying difficulty, that definitely scratches the "mech game" itch I was having when i bought it.

review:
"I was walking to Ed's the other night when it happened. Chilled me to the bone man, felt like some sort of holy reckoning was happening. Lord knows how many horns those scrapper Corvids hooked up to one button, but all hell broke loose as soon as it was sounded. I started to rush on inside as it opened fire, steel rain slicing through whoever was there. A couple to my right got shredded, but I kept runnin'. A squad of Mogs, those wimpy lil' things always keepin' the peace came stompin' through a wall to fight whatever that Corvid junkyard was. A couple laser blasts blew threw their shields and a whole lotta bullets made the pilots connoisseurs of swiss cheese. I got inside, slid under a desk, and watched with my heart poundin' in my chest. Across the street, a couple big walkers, Touros or whatever the regime calls 'em, crashed through a building. They could've given the Corvids a run for their money with their cannons, or at least cause it to run away; but the mobile heap of trash had other ideas. A couple shells battered against the shields, it's shrapnel hitting the nearby building and whatever civilians lookin' on in awe. Didn't matter though, as the top turret, forged out a couple cars and a big ol' generator swiveled towards those two mechs. In a blink of an eye, those walkers and whatever buildings were behind them were flattened. An overwhelmin' sounds echoed throughout the street, blowing me away mentally and giving me tinnitus for weeks. I survived that helluva fight, but I've always kept an eye above the rooftops ever since." - John Poltop, on his night out at Lannois.

     Brigador is a top down tactical mech game, which basically means that you pilot a mech (or a tank, or an anti-gravity speeder) and blow up certain objectives. It takes place in Solo Nobre, a colony that was founded by the SNC to be a space banana republic. As all banana republics do, it got overthrown by a mysterious Great Leader and his regime. However, now that Great Leader just died, the SNC is enacting its great plan: to hire mercs, called Brigadors, to strike at ammo depots, orbital guns preventing shuttle landings, comms stations, power generators, and the garrison of whatever faction controlling the district, all over the course of a night.
     Gameplay wise, you spawn, destroy, and leave. Make sure to enable tank controls, since that's the original way the game is meant to be played, and directional damage bonuses can screw you over when you're fighting the controls. Brigador's missions, while almost always the same, are always fun, due to the nature of it. Sneaking up behind an enemy to blast them from the rear, dodging between buildings being shredded by enemy fire (everything in this game is destructible, it's a wonderful canvas of carnage), trying to eliminate your foes as efficiently as possible and picking up the ammo dropped to do it again. My only criticism is that the downtime between one fight and the next can be a bit long, but there's usually a couple goons that you can tango with while walking (or driving, or floating).
     An average freelance mission goes as follows. First, select a pilot, who have different difficulties, and sometimes extra quirks attached to them. Next your ride. There's a wide variety of mechs, tanks, and speeders, all with their own stats, designs, and difficulties. Notable favorites are the van on treads, the massive looming citadel of doom, the giant floating head, and the lovable Touro (it's the one on the cover of the game). Then select your weapons, of which there are a couple different types, but are all glorious. Whether it be artillery, ballistic, lasers, or whatever else, there's a combination for any idea. Finally your special weapon, like smoke grenades or an audio-kinetic pulse that is canonically a warcrime. After that quick process is over you select your mission, which can range from one simple district (level) to the entirety of the game. Do the objectives, blow up buildings (and civilians) to get extra money, and cash out. The best part is that depending on what you choose, you get higher and higher payouts to spend to unlock lore, vehicles, pilots, weapons, special weapons, intel, and missions to play. Controlling a dinky van that dies in a stiff breeze during the longest mission of the game piloted by a max difficulty pilot is hard, sure. But when you do complete it, that payout you receive is divine.
     The graphics are fantastic, with the terrain as all pixel art and the vehicles given the DKC treatment. The landscapes are varied, from cyberpunk cities, to backwoods slums, to gated communities, to necropolises filled with graves, to a mix or something else entirely. The music is also very good. Composed by Makeup and Vanity Set, it makes Brigador feel as if you're playing an electronic-synthwave-retro-whatever album; not unlike how Doom feels.
     The lore is also great. You piece together the wonderfully-detailed world of Solo Nobre through descriptions of everything you unlock, and it's all written from the perspective of characters in the world. There are three main factions you face. The NEP/loyalists are the remnants of Great Leader's regime, practical, efficient, and militaristic. Then you have the rebel anarcho-syndicalist Corvids, whose vehicles can best be described as "transformer Detroit." Finally the Spacers, rich raiders whose vehicles are aerodynamic, fast, and weird looking.
     To sum it all up, Brigador is wonderfully fun to play, and near-perfect in its execution. If I were to have any complaints, it would be to ask for more pilots to have weird quirks (i.e. a pilot who reverses faster because they're cowardly or something), and for there to be a bit less downtime between fights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067944758', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1067, 'last_played': 1703856698}
review:
Got the recommend from the Mandalore video and haven't regretted the purchase. All vehicles control nicely (AGRAV on screen absolute) and all the small caveats of movement and shooting are taught while playing the campaign, after which the difficulty ramps up in a fair way. The fact that all campaign levels can be played with a multitude of loadouts makes it so you have different options to approach the level.

Graphically not a game that stretches the limits of current gen tech, but does very well in it's own way. Destruction has a good impact that is properly conveyed in both sound and visual design. 

Fantastic all around package for a mech/tank game, highly recommend at full price. Replayability is great with customisable loadouts and even if you only plan on playing it for a few hours you'll get your money well worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041930065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 983, 'last_played': 1673945007}
review:
有什么能像变成大怪兽然后摧毁大都市一样爽的？驾驶巨大的载具粉碎敌人和城市 :)
优点：
画面精良，细节很丰富
音乐和音效都很有沉浸感，甚至不同机甲踩踏都会有不一样的音效。
不同的武器有不同的弹道，打击感也不一样。
几乎全部可以破坏的场景。
极为丰富的可选配置（包括众多驾驶员）！
缺点（存在主观判断）：
可能存在优化问题，大地图在移动过程中会出现明显卡顿，可能需要转入SSD硬盘，但是作为一个非超高分辨率的2D游戏似乎有点没必要？
没有导弹？有机炮、火箭、火炮、激光甚至电磁炮，却没有导弹？？？（是因为会“影响平衡”？）
各种武器的弹药效果过于单一，火炮就是一个红球，最多能分裂出更多红球，机炮无论大小型号，都像是……连射的激光。

author: {'steamid': '76561198298995238', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1623855499}
review:
Frankly, I was biased towards the game at first. The reason is that I always thought that these kinds of games would be boring after a point. But I can say that I was wrong in this game. Music and graphics are sweet, gameplay is good. It is nice to change the vehicles used as the level progresses, which are constantly challenging and intriguing for other chapters. .a game far from monotony. You can get it especially if you like demolishing buildings or something. But if you have doubts, wait for the discount like me.

率直に言って、私は最初はゲームに偏っていました。 その理由は、こういうゲームはある時点でつまらないといつも思っていたからです。 しかし、私はこのゲームで私が間違っていたと言うことができます。 音楽とグラフィックは甘く、ゲームプレイは良いです。 レベルが進むにつれて使用される車両を変更するのは素晴らしいことです。これは、他の章にとって常に挑戦的で興味をそそるものです。 単調さからは程遠いゲーム。 あなたが建物か何かを破壊するのが好きであるならば、あなたは特にそれを得ることができます。 しかし、疑問がある場合は、私のような割引を待ってください。

author: {'steamid': '76561198005503227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1696, 'last_played': 1645234740}
review: Why don't more games release Audiobooks? Especially ones that tie to the game? The Brigador Audiobook is something that can change this game from simple fun destruction to a realized world that gives you sensible background to what you're destroying. Highly recommend.
developer_response:
It probably has something to do with the fact that making an audiobook is itself almost as much work as making a game. The very short version is it involved six people (author, voice artist, director, audio engineer and two of the devs for feedback and cover art) working on close to 200 audio files (that were combined to form the 18 chapters plus the epilogue) across multiple countries (US, UK, Russia) over the course of a few months in 2016. In 2019 we remastered the original files so it could then also be put out on Audible.

It wasn't a simple process but we're proud of what we accomplished and we're glad you like it enough to leave a review about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018729371', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1627349598}
review:
So... I've refunded Brigador - I so wanted to love this game, such a fantastic aesthetic (audio and visual) that reminds me of classic games like Tib Sun - but the story didn't pop out enough for me. 

Destroying things as mechs is cool and all, but there's no reason beyond 'destructive environments' and 'cool game engine'. The only thing I believe it's missing is a more guided story that entices me into the game! Freelance mode can provide the bulk of the enjoyment for those that don't like more story-based games, but for me - I don't always want to 'make' my own fun.. if that makes sense? 

If Brigador 2 has a more guided story experience - then I'd buy it in a heartbeat! Brigador 1 is just not enjoyable enough for me on a lack of story guidance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993396516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2341, 'last_played': 1680286719}
review:
Do you like the idea of walking tanks? Do you enjoy nihilistic isometric shooters like Syndicate, Crusader: No Remorse, Project:Overkill? Are you interested in military history, weapons and so forth? If any of the aforementioned conditions apply to you, this game might be for you!

A twin-stick shooter at heart (all right, KB+M) Brigador is surprisingly deep in its mechanics, yet remains delightfully arcade. Tons of stuff and lore to unlock if you're into collecting stuff and unlocking things, but playing through the campaign should net you enough cash to start getting into freelance mode.

The initial learning curve may be a bit steep for some, but stick with it, and the finer aspects of the game begin to open up. Throw a couple of mods at it and you'll be happy blasting away for quite some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975408856', 'num_games_owned': 1446, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1638566062}
review:
Brigador is an amazing game. Game-play, graphics, sounds, its all just fantastic. Lets start with the game-play.

You pilot a mech around, although there are also plenty of tanks and anti-gravity vehicles as well, usually with two weapons + an equipment, such as camouflage or smoke screens. In campaign this is preset, usually giving you 4 pilots with their preset vehicles to choose from, and this lets you get a good feel for vehicles and weapons you enjoy, and let you be more direct for choosing what to unlock in free-play. The campaign is interesting and while you don't need to read every single line of text or dialogue, the lore behind the world is interesting. Lore entries are also written by characters in game, pilots you can unlock in free-play, and gives you insights from certain points of view on the story if that's your thing. The scapes of Solo Nobre all look great, from the city centers to the more rural areas, and the art style is consistent through everywhere. Nothing looks out of place, and it really helps to build a cohesive world. The vehicles all look great as well, with 3 factions to choose from, Loyalists, Corvids, and Spacers. Spacers are personally my favorite, but they all look great, and the weapons sound great too. My favorite combo so far is the Broodmare Spacer Mech equipped with the Thunderclap and Zeus laser weapons. Even though they are lasers, they still sound really satisfying to use, as do many weapons.

Speaking of sound, the music in this game is just amazing, so much so it's one of the few games I bought the soundtrack for. While there are some songs I prefer more than others, I definitely wouldn't say any of them are bad. My only real complaint audio wise is sometimes the game will transition from a really upbeat track during your rampage to a more low key, foreboding track, which while the track isn't bad, it does feel slightly out of place given the track that played before it. As I mentioned earlier as well, the weapons sound just excellent and crisp, even the lasers sound like they have some punch to them. The heavier railguns that just demolish everything you point at are a joy to use, and it's only some of the smaller caliber weapons that sound dinky, which does make sense given the magnitude of physical size difference some of these weapons share.

This game is a real joy and I hope Brigador Killers does come out. I only have about 12 hours at time of writing but I do plan to play and stream this game a lot more. It's just so good, and for $19.99 it's honestly worth the price. Check it out, and leave a review if you do. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198260527422', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 208, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1626403176}
review:
叛擊士是一款賽博龐克風格的俯視視角機甲遊戲，遊戲中共有三種類型的載具可以挑選，機甲、坦克和浮空載具，除了有各自的特性外，每種載具還會有不同型號，各型號能搭載的武器款式有所不同。在戰役模式中必須使用系統預先設計好的載具武裝與駕駛員來遊玩，在自由委託中則可以自行設計載具並安排武裝及駕駛員，並透過賺取到的金錢來解鎖更多載具、武裝或劇情檔案。

遊戲過程的節奏很快速，且敵人多樣，從小小的步兵到敵對載具坦克、偵察機等等，各自有不同的行為和攻擊模式，擊毀敵人會產生能量球，收集可以回復護盾值，或從唄擊毀的載具中獲得彈藥。在後期敵人的數量會很大量，有時還不容易打中，因此合理分配主副武器的彈藥和特殊技能，互相搭配來完成任務並存活很考驗技巧。任務目標通常是摧毀特定目標，並有額外目標達成可賺取額外的金錢，完成目標後還要活著抵達撤離地點才算成功。

author: {'steamid': '76561198132792733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1624172526}
review:
游戏还行，就是关卡千篇一律。乐趣在于DIY机甲。

这里针对评论区的玩家《exciting膜法技术宅》的类似言论回复一下，经常在steam看到一些ZZ评论，就像这位玩家说的“高喊着民主自由的家伙，你们以为一场武装暴动人民就会自由民主幸福生活了？别逗了，你只会带来死亡和恐慌！”，滑天下之大稽，你以为现在的政体当年是和平上位的？历史怎么学的？呵呵呵。

“像极了现实中某些国家”，最像的应该是您自己的吧，内战都打死多少人了，打完了又大饥荒，又和爸爸国闹翻脸差点挨慈父的打。纯粹运气好生在了一个现代化、整体进步的大时代背景里，要早三四十年生在的蛮荒发展时代也是被推翻的份，不被推翻也是给慈父吞并，建议多用脑多读书，少拍脑袋。

以上，共勉，呵呵。

review:
This looks like a twin stick action shooter at first glance, but it's a more slow-paced strategic/tactical affair. 

If you play this like a twin stick shooter, you won't have fun, I know that's why I didn't enjoy it at first. However, if you slow down, evaluate your current vehicles strengths and weaknesses, and play accordingly, you will have a good time. 

Visuals and sound are unique and high quality. Once you take the time to understand the game, consider flanking and your vehicle's orientation (getting hit in the sides and back is a good way to die quick).

author: {'steamid': '76561198315716873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 5496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 331, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1711880354}
review:
动力装甲兵的妈生了个什么玩意？连横着走都不会了？为了刷全成就被恶心到了，战役还给你出一堆阴间载具配阴间武器，这么喜欢阴间怎么不去阴间找你木琴？
这款游戏就是做给国内某些人看的，那些高喊着民主自由的家伙，你们以为一场武装暴动人民就会自由民主幸福生活了？别逗了，你只会带来死亡和恐慌！
说回我自己吧，我为什么会这样说，因为我当初也是这样的。
这款游戏里面最有趣的地方就是那三个击杀平民才能得到的成就“黄色雨衣”，“习惯化”，“只是数字”，还有政府让人们穿上黄色雨衣，以表示自己是非战斗人员，以及公司的漫画书里面穿着黄色雨衣的恶鬼。
这不叫“解放”或者“救助”这就是赤裸裸的侵略！这个雇佣玩家的“企业集团”像极了现实中某些国家。

此外小贴士：按H键可以让你的载具鸣笛，从而驱散平民，减少伤亡。

最后是推荐武备：
阿尔齐88炮，高射速AOE，近距离最强武器
大友聚焦激光炮，能散射能聚焦，除了射程和弹药没有缺点
酋长脉冲激光炮，弹药巨多，DPS也不错，万金油武器
黑手+封绝+光学迷彩，潜行必备
报丧女妖14mm无壳弹机枪，远近通吃的万金油
公爵夫人40mm自动炮，同上
收割者305集束攻城炮，专门对付集群敌人，反一切炮
铁嘴鸡电磁炮，以小博大必备良品
载具推荐反重力坦克，无视地形，并且没有阴间的转向机制
及其不推荐动力装甲，最阴间的玩意没有之一，建议多吃点螃蟹，学学它们

author: {'steamid': '76561197972632989', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 1756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1683831799}
review:
There's good and bad. The good is there's a lot of variety, a lot of potential replayability, a lot of creativity. Lots of weapon types, mechs, even movement types. 

The problems with this game are it's core gameplay.
 * The dev's specifically made weapons difficult to aim, in a 3d way, in a 2d viewing plane, which makes shooting often ambiguous. I say this having completed the campaign as every offered mech except on 3 of the final missions.

* Compounding that is that a weapon may impact a building unexpectedly, or your mech may tangle its footing up on concrete or debris that looks similar to the rest of the ground. 

 * The game is designed around using your understanding of line-of-sight, weapon noise, and destructible terrain to bend battles towards your favor; but the harder missions make this nigh impossible; in part because the setups they allow you to use are loud, clunky, and often slow.

 * The pacing of the game, where secondary objectives often require you to backtrack back and forth over a map with a slow vehicle is obnoxious.

In the end, the designer put a lot of work into building some systems that are simply unenjoyable.

review: Love tat the game throws you into the world with no introduction, and finding out more about the world comes through unlocking new vehicles, weapons, and pilots. Every unlockable item come with an in-character description coming from one of the pilots, which gives more insight to the setting as well as to the item. Through this, the game incentivizes you to buy new things indescriminantly and try new things that you hadn't previously considered, instead of just buying the *one* vehicle you *think* is the best and then saving up money for no reason like we all love to do.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198201426702', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1702610808}
review:
Been awhile since I could get mad at a game and still thoroughly enjoy it. Brigador is a load of mechs and vehicles and missions. You can play the campaign which is fun, but mediocre, the real game is in freelance. Choose your pilot, choose your vehicle/mech, choose your weapon loadouts, cause mayhem. Buy newpilots,  mechs and vehicles, new weapons, make new loadouts, Rinse and repeat. Missions are quick making Brigador a great game to play at really any time. Jump in when you want, jump out when you need to. I bought this on sale but it def deserves the full asking price.

The Mongoose is prob the most frustrating mech to pilot, but It's still one of my favs.

Brigador is a game about being a walking war-crime, or if you're crazy enough, being a small scooter armed with a machine gun taking on an entire city's worth of armoured mechs, tanks and crazy floating anti-grav vehicles.

Don't play with anything other than the Tank Controls for the best experience, this is worth it despite the harsh learning curve, as you can properly face your vehicle when facing off against those that want to stop your war-crime in action.

review:

you may be wondering why an auto rickshaw is an option and the answer is it has a payout multiplier of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033801280', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3652, 'last_played': 1680461361}
review:
Most underrated mech game of all time, and mechs are only one third of the vehicles you can play. Add fantastic lore, and atmosphere-rich world, and tons of weapons to mix and match, and you have yourself a good fucking game.

Biggest issue with the game is that it can get a bit repetitive. Most missions feel pretty similar, so its usually not something to play more than a few hours of in one sitting, but that's fine honestly. Not every game needs to be something you spend all day doing, and after a little break, I always get the itch to come back.

Also, the devs have continued to update and support this game despite the low initial sales, which is commendable, and they just released an update that mixes up enemy spawns and increases gameplay variety, which helps a great deal to alleviate the issue of missions feeling repetitive.

In short, buy this game. Its well worth the asking price. Oh, and turn tank controls to relative. Its more fun that way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998205567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1696896988}
review:
So this is an edit to my original review that was harsh on the game due to crash related issues and not being able to play the game even.

I later found out after running a DDU and reinstalling fresh drivers for my GPU that this was entirely on AMD's fault and had nothing to do with Brigador.

I got a lot of help on the discord by passionate fans and modders, and any game dev that fosters such a helpful and passionate fanbase means they are clearly doing things right.

Not to mention Boss Tweed comment on this review trying to help me fix an issue when i barely provided any info shows how much the devs clearly care about their community and players.

So yea, i will update this review once i am able to find some time to play it now that i can, for now i recommend the developers (and probably game too as for what i've seen its great).


Original post
Crash the moment you try to start a mission, Tried updating drivers and doing a bunch of things recommended by other users on the community forums.

It worked once and i've tried about 60 times to get it to work with different combinations of compatibility and launch parameters.

It sad because the game seems fun and i've heard well about it. But atleast on a AMD GPU stay clear of this game as its barely functioning.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989204592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7250, 'last_played': 1685164024}
review:
I put off buying this for so long and man have I been missing out. Everything in this game is incredible. The art and sound are amazing and the game oozes character with all its lore, but the gameplay is really where it shines. So many different loadouts and tactical options. The Campaign supplies you with a variety of loadouts and situations, encouraging you to try different playstyles (some of them quite challenging), and the "freelance" mode lets you try whatever loadouts and levels you want (after you purchase them with in game earned $$)

This game has stealth, facing, armor and weapon types, alarms, objectives, height based los/cover, destructible cover, and frantic run and gun moments. It also has utility items that vastly change the way you can play it. Smoke grenades let you sneak around, make an escape, or just establish a fire line from which to shoot from behind (and the ai is smart enough to shoot at your last known location, but you can take advantage of this too). Emp grenades give you a nice panic button or a way to set ambushes. stealth field lets you turn invisible for a brief period of time allowing you to sneak past someone, sneak behind someone (more damage from behind), or make a quick escape. Or just get akp and blast holes through walls or decimate entire squads with a single close range blast.

Stop wasting time and get this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965443782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3895, 'last_played': 1694237010}
review:
A bit quirky. Surprisingly deep. Great range of difficulties and tools to play with.

Definitely a game first, not an 'experience'. Narrative is minimal and character interactions are nonexistant. Lore is captivating, but inherently supplementary. Play the campaign to learn the mechanics, try various loadouts, and challenge your completionism. Play freelance mode to tackle semi-random missions and unlock the game's full loadout options.

Playstyle (and difficulty) dramatically varies by vehicle and loadout. Play a heavily-shielded two-story junkyard to turn entire neighborhoods into parking lots. Play an armed forklift to strike from the shadows and run from anything resembling a fair fight. Play an invisible UFO that destroys all vital infrastructure and runs. Play a bulldozer whose strongest weapon is ramming things. Play the smallest possible thing that can level a neighborhood in one shot. The worse your vehicle is, the more you get paid for using it.

Recommend using relative controls ("tank controls") for mechs/tanks and screen absolute controls ("hold left to go left") for agravs. Neither mechs nor tanks are designed for screen absolute, and you don't want to accidentally expose a tank's rear armor under fire.

[b]GRIND RATING:[/b]
Lots to unlock for little grind each. Your biggest problem will not be saving up for what you want, but figuring out what you want in the first place. The campaign helps with this by giving you sample loadouts to try out while giving you money to spend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158453165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1951, 'last_played': 1666499750}
review:
One of the best "arcade" type games available atm imo. An already extensive loadout of weapons and vehicles, further expanded by its most recent update (06/21). Play as a hovercraft, automobile, tank or a mech and use a wide variety of guns, lasers and explosives to take out objectives or just wreck as much collateral damage as you can, and get paid more the more you destroy. 

The worldbuilding is wonderful too; you take control of various expendable mercenaries at the behest of a corpo-state who were kicked off the planet "Solo Nobre" in a military coup/revolution. Now that the general, referred to as Great Leader, has died, they want you to cause as much chaos as possible so that they can step back in and reassert control. You'll be fighting the old guard who use standard (futuristic) military equipment, the vaguely anarchistic populous who use whatever they can get their hands on, up to and including a WW2 esque bomber welded to a pair of mech legs, and viking raiders funded by Musk/Bezos types who live on ark ships and raid planets for resources to sustain themselves. All in all its a wild world and im 100% here for it.

There are campaign missions where you must select from predetermined loadouts, and a more freeform arcade mode where you can go hogwild with what you bring to the field.

There is already a sequel in development, and by what is exhibited here, one can only hope it is as wonderful as its predecessor
