author: {'steamid': '76561198079323277', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 1352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1352, 'last_played': 1623787653}
review:
I like the game. You go through several smaller independent missions, so it is well playable even if you have only 30 min at a time to play. In later levels it does require some skill to succeed, so it is not a casual game in the classical sense.

There is a lot of variety in the gameplay, because the different vehicles and vehicle classes (mechs, tanks, anti-gravs) you control play very differently, especially given the many different weapon types (machine guns, cannons, lasers, artillery, chemical launchers, ..). 

This allows for many different approaches to a level, from the Rambo approach (gatling guns blazing), the Bond approach (go in with stealth), the race car approach (speed by enemies to take out strategic targets) or the sniper approach (artillery, long range lasers). 

Needless to say, you should go for the Rambo approach whenever possible.

Even different machine guns feel differently, e.g., due to higher calibre or higher rate of fire. It is just awesome to rip apart hordes of smaller enemies with two large gatling guns. The physics look cool when the bullets pepper the environment behind the ashes of your former enemies.

The soundtrack and look is great. Love 80s synth stuff.

I think the only downside in the campaign was that in the later levels, the available vehicles are somewhat limited. They all have some long range AOE weapon, which does not really allow for the Rambo approach.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078923958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 4916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1697318306}
review:
Пока будет немного, дальше видимо больше.
Игру купил под впечатлением отличного обзора, не буду пиарить человека. И покупкой на данный момент доволен.
Из того что игра напоминает, в первую очередь Mechwarrior(s?) c Сеги, с хорошим обзором, более простым управлением, большим кол-вом пилотов(с биографией в духе Джаги)) вместо ноунейма, и годным выбором оружия. Присутствует хороший выбор техники, необязательная кампания(для ачивок и мб сюжета), и свободный режим с кучей карт.

Из того чего к сожалению нет, нет озвучки. Ну и недостатков явных не нашел, кроме того что игра глаза утомляет(устал за два часа, что довольно странно) Музыка весьма так себе, скорее бы подошла игре вроде Neon Drive.

Если кто хочет вспомнить старых злых Мехварриоров на приставке, добро пожаловать.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149544499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1083, 'last_played': 1652533257}
review:
This game is great. Stomp around in a stonking great big mech, fly around strafing fools in an agrav (anti-gravity vehicle, by which I do not mean helicopters), just roll out and break things in a tank, or go full Rambo and kill from the shadows of metal giants in a powersuit, this game will have something you'd like.

For gameplay, it's responsive, tactical vehicular combat, rewarding you for smart placement of shots while at the lower difficulties - which are, unusually for this sort of thing, decided by which character you play as - being forgiving enough that a few minor mistakes won't completely mess up your run, and if you do screw up badly enough to die, the game's coded well enough that you don't even need to wait 2 seconds for it to load and you can just get back in there instead of ruminating. And I mean it when I say this game is well coded - it has started chugging on me, but only once or twice for about a second a time, and runs as smooth as a baby's bottom otherwise, which is phenomenally good for the mediocre laptop I own.

Buy this game. You will not regret it. (And buy the soundtrack too, it's phenomenal.)

EDIT: I forgot to mention, after buying this game (which you should) open the settings menu and change the controls from "screen absolute" to "relative". It'll make the tutorial levels easier to understand. Others have mentioned this elsewhere, I just want to make sure no-one misses the memo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198869270189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1648727358}

The challenge comes from mastering controls.

These settings are comfortable for me:
Tank & Mech: RELATIVE
AGRAV: SCREEN ABSOLUTE

There is much to tweak, tho it is easy to find the optimal settings for how you like to play.

Many fun hours ahead after you do this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027992381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1670681629}
review:
Very entertaining game.
 - The gameplay is simple, yet allows for a variety of tactics. And that's even before you factor in all the ways you can customize your vehicle (and thereby your playstyle). Go stealth, obliterate entire city blocks, or anything in between.
 - You can pci kyour levels, depending on whether you want a quick bit of 10 minute action or spend an hour or two on the game.
 - Graphics are simple, but charming, and perfectly capture the atmosphere. The tone reminds me a bit of the old Syndicate. Though here you're going solo and mechanized.
 - Sound effects are good. The music fits the setting, though could be a bit lees background-y, if that makes any sense.
 - They even introduced in-game cheats with a recent update, just in case one of these levels proves too hard, or you just want to let off steam by taking on an entire army with invincibility and unlimited ammo.

If the idea of an isometric cyperpunk-style mercenary vehicle shooter appeals to you, I can only recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987658658', 'num_games_owned': 1431, 'num_reviews': 341, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1623509345}
review:
[Code] Retrouvez mes avis par tonne ici : https://steamcommunity.com/groups/LEDODO/curation 
mettez un "utile" ou "rigolo" svp ou une petite récompense?[/code] 

Brigador est un vieux jeu mais comme il m'éclate et que les développeurs continuent à le mettre à jour, je me suis dis que j'allais écrire un petit avis vite fait.

Jeu de...heu, ha, oui, jeu de destruction d'environnements dans lequel vous conduisez une machine (mecha, tank ou hover-car) qui, sous contrat, doit remplir  certains objectifs, principalement de la destruction d'assets stratégiques: tour de communications, dépôts,générateurs,...

Le plus du jeu étant que vous avez à votre disposition tout un arsenal violent, allant de la mitrailleuse, aux missiles téléguidés, combinés à des skills, telles que : mur de fumée, EMP, lance-flames, …  y a vraiment de quoi s'amuser pendant des heures, d'autant que le jeu n'est pas facile, il faut souvent jouer de discretion (oui oui), pour se mettre dans une position favorable avant de balancer la sauce. Un jeu plus tactique qu'il n'y parait.

Si pour la plupart, la campagne ne présente pas grand intérêt, je ne suis pas d'accord, les missions sont progressives en terme de difficulté et expliquent relativement correctement les différents concepts du jeu (et il y en a une tonne) : les contrôles, les skills, le blindage, les alertes, la destruction, les différents types de munitions,… le jeu n'est pas une simulation pour autant mais est riche de plein de choses qui donnent envie de les découvrir. 40 missions sont disponibles. Avec une histoire brièvement expliquée mais relativement intéressante.

L'argent gagné en fin de mission sert à débloquer de nouveaux pilotes, de nouvelles missions, des nouveaux jouets, du lore, tout est déblocable et vous en avez pour un petit moment si vous voulez tout débloquer.

Le coeur du jeu étant les contrats en freelance: des cartes aléatoires, énormes, avec une bonne quantité d'ennemis pour bien vous mettre la pression. Jeu difficile mais qui pousse à tester différentes combinaisons pour découvrir laquelle correspond le mieux à la mission que vous souhaitez accomplir, c'est vraiment fun. Ajoutez à cela une bande-son du tonnerre, quoiqu'un poil répétitive (electro-synthwave), un style graphique relativement simple mais coloré et vous avez un jeu dans lequel j'apprécie de rester.

Puis, je l'ai pas dis mais la grande force du jeu reste sa destruction : tout est destructible, tuable et rayable. C'est simple, satisfaisant et dangereux ( piétiner une station essence et vous le regretterez) . Une couverture? l'ennemi la détruit en 10 secondes. Vous voulez faire le tour? Foncez simplement dans le tas, ça fonctionne aussi. C'est moins rapide et plutôt dangereux mais quelle satisfaction.

L'interface, et certains détails montrent un manque de moyens, les contrôles font débat mais on s'y fait, passez bien par le tuto et ça devrait rouler tout seul.

Puis je salue la dévotion des développeurs envers leur produit, mis à jour il y a quelques jours à peine, nous seulement le jeu est rempli de contenu mais en plus, vous pouvez faire vos propres cartes ou télécharger celles des autres. 
Je vous devais bien un petit texte que personne ne lira.

author: {'steamid': '76561198311132563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1672738681}
review:
当初买这个游戏的理由很简单，看到推荐“解压游戏”“全地图破坏”等，存粹当作一个爽游来买的。
然而点开游戏之后没想到世界观设定竟然如此细致和周密，阵营之间的错综复杂的关系，玩家并非英雄，而错综复杂的政治局势让这个游戏根本没有“正义”的一方。
[spoiler] “独裁者”死了，然后呢？自由？解放？美好生活？事实告诉你这些都是放屁，政权瓦解带来的只有无尽的混乱，以及混乱中试图将自己的利益最大化的各个势力在互相斗争，无论是你是保皇派，无政府主义者还是大企业的雇员，这一切都已经毫无意义了，意识形态只告诉你该站在哪一边，把枪交到你的手上然后告诉你用子弹捍卫自己的理念，但是他们不会告诉你什么是“道德”和“正义”，在剧情任务中我一直避免去击杀那些穿黄色雨衣的平民，但是事实上在混乱的战局以及逐渐解锁的大规模杀伤性武器面前，这是毫无意义的。今天在我用305MM高爆攻城榴弹花费不到百分之一秒的时间就摧毁一个街区和其中的叛军时，跳出了一个成就“习惯化”，解锁条件是杀死1000个平民。我震惊了并且打算写下评论，是的，即使小心翼翼的去避免平民伤亡，在战争中杀死1000个平民也不过是一个很容易达到的“附带损失”，而且，玩家很容易就会把杀死那些黄色小人当作稀松平常的事情，一如那个成就“习惯化”的字面意思，何等的讽刺。 [/spoiler]
“在现代战争中，你会像条狗一样毫无意义的死去。——欧内斯特·海明威”，玩过这个游戏这句话就不难理解，而且不知为何我个人觉得这个世界观在某些部分可以和极乐迪斯科的世界观接轨。希望制作者能够继续带来这个世界观内的其他故事。

author: {'steamid': '76561198006330944', 'num_games_owned': 848, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 1206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1206, 'last_played': 1623471565}
review:
Excelente jogo de ação com câmera isométrica,
Clima do jogo altamente atmosférico graças à excelente direção de arte, belos gráficos, lore excepcional e absurda trilha sonora: synthwave brabíssimo.

O jogo pode ser jogado em modo "twin-stick shooter" ou com "tank controls". Apesar de parecer estranho, recomendo fortemente que se acostume a jogar com controles de tanque, o jogo foi feito pensando nisso!

A campanha dura bastante, tem uma boa quantidade de missões e há bastante variedade nos pilotos, veículos e armas que irá usar ao decorrer delas.
Além disso, existe um modo Freelance, no qual você utiliza o seu dinheiro para contratar pilotos, comprar veículos e armas e completar séries de missões levemente randomizadas. Há muita coisa para desbloquear, o conteúdo desse jogo é gigante. Também há um mod kit e editor de missões.

Vale cada centavo.

5643 Civis aniquilados.
1432 Residências pisoteadas.
348 Capitães NEP mortos.
2478 Veículos destroçados
138 Crimes de guerra cometidos.
$248.000.000 embolsados.

Cidade-estado Solo Nobre recapturada.

Jogo recomendado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103697379', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1699115466}
review:
tl;dr It's fantastic. Use relative controls, for everything. The soundtrack is also *chef's kiss* perfect.

Your main objective as a brigador is to cause as much mayhem and destruction (to strategic and civilian targets alike) so your employers can invade and retake their former colony on the planet of Solo Novo. You operate as an inhabitant of Solo Nobre, its capital city.

In the campaign, each mission gives you a small selection of pilots and their vehicles to play with to help you get used to the controls and weapons of each vehicle. There are mechs, tanks and anti-gravity vehicles, each class ranging from small powersuits to hulking battlemechs, tuk-tuks to gargantuan tanks and hoverbikes to hovertanks. You have hull/armour and shields for defence (shields can be replenished on killing enemies - armour cannot). Furthermore, each vehicle has a 'special' ability and a defensive ability- mechs stomp, tanks boost, a-gravs ground pound. Depending on the vehicle and pilot, you can also use smoke grenades, emp grenades or a sonic boom to defend yourself if you start feeling vulnerable. The tutorial is great too, drip feeding you mechanics to get you used to it, no information overload like other games sometimes do.

Each comes with equally diverse armament, including lasers, cannons, railguns, high caliber machine guns, grenade launchers... the list goes on. Each weapon will be effective against armour or shields, some weapons penetrate through buildings, etc... You can refill your ammo from a limited supply at depots in each district. Also, every building is destructible.

The campaign is an appetiser though - freelance operations are your main course. They are like campaign missions with multiple stages, and you must complete your objectives and make it to the end without dying. Can get quite challenging.

With the money you earn in the campaign, you can unlock various vehicles, weapons and pilots (as well as snippets of lore and information about vehicles and locations, and the culture of Solo Nobre if you're into that sort of thing).

Don't be fooled, however. This game is definitely a power fantasy, but it's not easy - some missions are very straightforward, others will test you, and you'll have to adapt your stragegy depending on the enemies present, your vehicle and its loadout. I have zero complaints about this game, it's obscenely good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991828645', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1624586023}
review:
Is it on sale?  Buy it.   It has a very weak narrative and is more a sandbox game.  Its hotline miami meets sci fi mechs, tanks, and hover tanks, but no real campaign.  The campaign itself is a long tutorial leading into some hand crafted maps with lore tagged onto them.  Same with a lot of the hand crafted mission maps.  It's just about the gameplay, spectacle,  trying combinations and... fun.  And it has those things in a very satisfying retro feeling package.  

Playing as a little mech in a daunting map feeling like a sneaky peaky death dealer.  Playing as a juggernaught and laying waste to city blocks.  It's a really neat little game to visit.  The endless mode it resembles is great, but a stronger narrative and progression pacing would be welcome.  The way the rewards pivot on the pilot in freelance feels odd, and there are glaring imbalances in rewards schemes.  ( I feel like there's a certain pilot for easy unlocking).  

I paid 7 bucks for the game , all things considered: two thumbs up.

review:
The game itself is very fun and well designed. We can argue that after unlocking everything it kinda loses itself, but that is not the reason why I cannot recommend this game.

The reason is quite frankly that Jack "Gausswerks" Monahan, who is together with his brother Stellar Jockeys (even if his name is seperated for PR issues we will talk about now on the steampage), is a neonazi, holocaust-denier and a trans-/homophobe.

While they said they saw the light and suspended themselves from all operations in June 2020 it was just a week after another transphobic post on a forum, so this seems to be little more than lipservice. His brother meanwhile confirmed Jack's return to the studio earlier this week, seemingly only waiting for all of this to blow over.

If supporting such a person doesn't bother you, go ahead and buy it, it is an enjoyable game, but if you don't want to support such people you might want to look somewhere else.

review:
I only bought this game to support Jack Monahan (dev of this game) as he apparently is a based transphobe and I wish to support him for daring to speak truth in this PC clown world.
I think the game kinda sucks though. I would prefer it if it was more streamlined and had a more clear design as to what I'm supposed to do with the money I get and what to spend it on. It's too confusing and I can't be bothered to fuck around with it. The game gives me too much freedom with too little explanation and I get choice-paralysis.

You should make the campaign missions start automatically and in between them give us a reason to buy an upgrade so we get used to the system and how it works. Choosing a new mission from the list in campaign after every mission just seems so... aimless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198420926116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1623177198}
review: Everything about this game looked good. The reviews were encouraging. This review will not be. I pulled the trigger on this one fast because it looked like everything I would like. Classic graphics and cool little mechs running around blowing stuff up. Also there are a whole bunch of mechs and upgrades to choose from. Movement from one area to another is clunky and slow with obstacles that impede you constantly. The first time you think cool, I get to blow stuff up and crush this obstacle. Now multiply that by 15 more times in the same mission and you swear if you run into one more barricade you are gonna go out to the garage and drink anti-freeze. Their is garbage everywhere that slows the whole pace of the game down and makes you feel like your are trudging through 3 feet of snow in every mission. Next it was the controls. This was special. They actually vary the movement controls from tank to tank so that some tanks move like you would expect and other tanks you will spend a long time driving into walls zigzagging all over the map like a drunken fool while people shoot missiles at you the entire mission. Not having standardized movement controls is a deal breaker. Another problem is that you actually have to hold down a button from time to time to orient the legs of your mech to the direction you are pointing and walking so that you can walk faster... or I guess you can call it normally. Why would they design it so your mech doesnt orient to the direction you are walking and pointing your mouse automatically? You are gonna be fiddling with player orientation, barricades and trash, and random screwed up controls all day on this one. Uninstalled and refund requested. A game interface overhaul that doesnt have big rectangular buttons and an overly dark appearance lacking color variation could help here too. There is some potential buried deep under the surface here, but there is too many things wrong here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964777799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1623620707}
review:
A very beautiful 2d isometric shooter game with a Mechwarrior/Gundamesque spin on the usual hightech dystopia setting. I have to say the artwork is what really lets me get absorbed into this game. On a large monitor the amount of destruction created by the fight between myself and the legions of scrapheaps being pitted against me is something to behold. For only $20.00 you get a bunch of campaign missions, a lot of unlockable content to earn by completing the missions, and a freelance mode for missions outside of the campaign. 

Previously I was mentioning that the game offers no official mod support, but according to the dev response while there is not workshop support at the moment they do host modders and resources on their discord.
developer_response:
We're glad you're enjoying the game! Wanted to clarify that while we do not have Steam Workshop support, we do indeed support modding this game. In fact, "modding" isn't quite accurate, as we give full access to the suite of tools we used to build the game.
 Search "Brigador Modkit" on Steam for the free DLC, or inside the game click on the Discord link (labeled "FEEDBACK") in the main menu and our community of modders will be happy to help show you how to begin your first weapon or vehicle mod, or your first map. Thanks for playing Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169001650', 'num_games_owned': 77, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 897, 'last_played': 1696084533}
review:
Bought it arround June 2020 when Mandalore realease "Brigador-Review", so I never know this hidden gem exist before that. If you like isometric games, bright neon colours, diverse weapons, driving a vehicles that consist of Mechs ; Tanks etc. This game is for you.

Some of the early mission in "Campaign" is a tutorial, making you ease up on driving various vehicles, make sure to check "controls" on those vehicles and find the one that you find enjoyable. The heart of this game lies in "Freelance", you can choose any vehicles and any weapons you like for a "Mission/Contract". Said vehicles and weapons are unlocked when you bought them, finishing any "Mission/Contract" on either "Campaign" and "Freelance" always give you money so don't worry about money, but if you still got overwhelmed by how many things to unlock, just go to YouTube and search "Brigador fast money".

Welcome Brigador

author: {'steamid': '76561198060684733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1664506968}
review:
An excellent Arcade style mecha game of tactics and destruction. 
What you start with is already a decent mech and equipment loadout, and from there anything you unlock is more of a side grade that transforms your experience as the potential difficulty of your missions increases.
You can fight stealthily, up close and personal, safely behind buildings with artillery, or from a medium distance with an assortment of weaponry... but only if you have the skill to use your mech and weaponry properly.
The lore paints an interesting dystopian mecha based future, but does not require you dive into it; it just sits there on the side, waiting for you to unlock or read it.
This is not a long story based game, it is a classic arcade time killer and it knows how to make the most of that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044113235', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 1291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1688314993}
review:
[code]"Patriotism is the virtue of the vicious" - Oscar Wilde[/code]

[i]Brigador[/i] is an isometric mech shooter with an emphasis on picking your fights and environmental destruction. Following the collapse of Solo Nombre's dictatorship, three factions emerge and you assume the role of a pilot contracted to overwhelm garrisons of troops to hit each of them where it hurts.

Not in the scope of a review, but multiplayer coop or versus would be KILLER.

[h1]The Pros[/h1]
+ The [b]gameplay[/b] is pretty simple and addictive as something that you can quickly pick up and play.
+ [b]Destruction[/b] of enemies and the environment can only be described as delicious. With level design as varied and beautiful as this, war crimes never felt so good.
+ [b]Sound effects[/b] are good, they give the weapons a lot of weight.  Combine that with some great asthetics, and there's plenty of immersive carnage to be had.
+ The [b]tutorial[/b] is solid and introduces pretty much everything you need while seemlessly transitioning into the campaign.
+ [b]Freelancing[/b] is loads of fun because though there's not an insane variety, there's an abundance of combinations to try out. The campaign does a good job of introducing these, and freelance missions are a great way to make cash and unlock new toys.
+ The [b]weapons and vehicles[/b] are oozing with quality. A Zöllig bipedal mech rocking twin Banshee machine guns and an audio-kinetic pulse piloted by the Man From Volta is something to behold.
+ It runs well and it's less than a gig on my hard drive. I can afford to keep this one installed.

[h1]The Cons[/h1]
- Ok, I'm gonna go against the grain here. To me, the [b]score[/b] was forgettable and it only felt at home in the menus. If you read the lore, this world seems rather cutthroat and hopeless. Some of the pilots have nothing to live for and are hired because they'd take a cheap insurance package. The gameplay breathes fumes of intensity and the excellent sound effects can't accomplish it alone. However, the soundtrack is pretty par for synthwave and only portrays mild sentiments of intrigue and maybe some melancholy. Games like [i]Hotline Miami, Hyper Light Drifter, and Party Hard[/i] all have more meaningful synth soundtracks and as such are much more memorable. The score is fine by itself, but it doesn't have the tempo to keep up with the gameplay. It doesn't compliment it.
- I frequently found myself wrestling with the [b]vehicle controls[/b] (particularly for tanks), regardless of my scheme. Apparently this was a big deal back when on release and is partially responsible for why [i]Brigador[/i] didn't sell super well at launch, but it's a minor inconvenience that I was able to tolerate for the entire campaign. Targeting hovercrafts and operating mortars can also be tricky when you factor rotation speeds on your vehicles and the isometric layering of yourself in the environment. To that end, there's only a handful of the warehouse of mechs, tanks, and anti-gravs that I liked enough to use consistently.
- The [b]campaign[/b] itself isn't very special from a narrative perspective. It's laid out like [i]The Phantom Menace[/i] - it exists to justify a "plot" or build a world and doesn't really have any characters or interactivity.
- Though fun to destroy, the levels are often extremely [b]congested[/b], and the vehicles which cope best with maneuvering the clutter are unfortunately the worst at destroying things. When you first start, it won't be clear what explodes and what doesn't until you've killed yourself a few times.
- This is just a nitpick, but I wish [b]map markers[/b] would stay on the borders until I could actually see the thing I was tasked with blowing up. It's easy to lose track of objectives when they are neither sprites nor markers on your screen.

[h1]The Indecisive[/h1]
• [b]Combat[/b] in and of itself is pretty smart, but I found that it divided up into 3 general categories. Guns blazing, hit and run, and retreating. Each is viable if you position yourself well and know your weapons - especially at lower difficulties - but later in the campaign you'll find that some are like a peanut butter and lime sandwich for that scenario. In a way, defeat feels worse here than in other rogue-lites.
• The [b]lore[/b] is pretty cool and I enjoyed reading about it. However, you have to go out of your way to purchase and read it since it's super easy to skip over the text in the campaign. It's completely optional but if you put some time in to buy all the lore, you'll get what you paid for.
• [b]Difficulty[/b] is established by how long a mission is, the type of vehicle you use, and the pilot. However, some pilots are game-changing and if you randomize a freelance mission, you might need to manually switch off of them because they can be detrimental. Otherwise, the difficulty in freelance is very balanced and I tended to know when I'd be in over my head (even if that meant restarting with a slightly different loadout).
• [b]Level objectives[/b] almost exclusively involve blowing up something that can't move. Captains are an exception, but there's very little variety in level navigation and the core gameplay loop is essentially just blast your way from one corner of the map to the other unless you can pull off stealth. Fortunately, blowing stuff up is satisfying and stealth is simple enough to find a groove.
• This game brings out the worst of me and I love it.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
[i]Brigador[/i] is competent in what it does. The world doesn't care about brigadors - it doesn't care about you. For that reason, you shouldn't care about it. So brand, squelch, and maim everything that gets in the way of you and getting paid. Great Leader is dead. Solo Nombre must fall.

[b]8.25 / 10[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198083026474', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1686851785}
review:
I know I haven't played much, the record says so, but I have to say, the feels in this game are amazing. You are a mercenary in the hands of a powerfull organiaztion bent on eradicating the remains of a now-dead brutal dictator. 

Your gear varies by mission and you can pretty much replay all the missions available in different wargear and different tactics, so the replayability is certainly there. I can say with confidence that you can sink in a minimum of 10 hours for the first run, and pretty much as much as you feel like it on Freelance. 

One more thing: BUY THE AUDIOBOOK. In fact, if you buy the game without it, you will be missing out on a substantial amount of the lore available along with the game. If you're into military futuristic dystopian stories, this game is for you and so is the audiobook. 

I cannot recommend this game enough. BUY IT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043985291', 'num_games_owned': 1514, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1623799351}
review:
Finally a sequel to Future Cop LAPD!...but as someone else said its mixed with Hotline Miami & man can it get difficult.

First off, you should play this game for the pure A E S T H E T I C alone. The visuals, music, ambience & just everything about the presentation oozes a brilliant aesthetic you just don't find in modern games.  Even if you just dabble in the game for a few hours it’s worth the experience just to support bringing this style back. Watch any trailer & you will immediately know what I mean.

Another thing that impressed me is how tight the Mech controls are. I genuinely forgot over the years what a Mech should feel like. & despite being an indie top down shooter the Mechs in this game have the best Mech gamefeel I have felt probably since the 90s.

The only issue I can take with the game is frustration. This really only affects the Campaign because if you play the expansive Freelance mode (which I think most consider the heart of the game) beating a level isn't as big of a deal. The issue with the campaign difficulty is you are forced into a selection of 4 pre set Mechs & if you don't like any of their loadouts you are out of luck. This became especially frustrating for me on the last 3 missions of the game...not only were they by far the hardest missions, but they were that much more maddening for me because I simply didn’t mesh with any of the Mechs I was allowed to use. 

Another big point of frustration you may find for yourself in the campaign is the slowness in beating a level. This game plays like Hotline Miami as I mentioned earlier. You get a map, an objective & you have to navigate through the difficult mission without dying despite your enemies being often overwhelming. Many enemies can kill in one hit & there is a tenseness when you begin to get surrounded. You made it near the end of a mission & got one shotted? Too bad you start all the way at the beginning of the level. While I enjoyed this in Hotline, in Brigador the frustration comes from how slow you are forced to play to get through a tough mission. You need to pick your shots carefully & move very slowly through the mission to avoid getting overwhelmed. On the last missions I found myself repeatedly getting frustrated over getting so close to the end & having to restart due to a bullshit death. When I hit the restart button, because of the frustration I would move fast & almost assuredly lose on the next attempt. You simply cannot power your way through the missions no matter how good of a shot you are or how much adrenaline you have. You have to take a breath & give yourself a moment before trying, the final missions each take about 20 minutes each & that is with the user carefully crawling through, sometimes painfully slowly. Playing with incredible patience will guarantee a better time with Brigador.

TL;DR Brigador is a return to the old in a wonderful way. Music, aesthetics, visuals & Mechfeel are all top notch. It’s something you won’t realize how much it was missed until you experience it for yourself again. If you get yourself addicted to its feeling the Freelance mode can provide you countless hours of fun allowing the user to combine unique pilots, Mechs, objectives, maps, everything. Just be ready to face some frustration when plowing through that campaign.

Update: Holy shit. As of writing this the Beat The Campaign achievement has a rarity of 2.6%. In my opinion that is insanely low for such a standard achievement, guess I am not alone in thinking those levels get brutally difficult.

author: {'steamid': '76561198392965743', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2674, 'last_played': 1651115149}
review: Going into this game expecting a fast-paced twin-stick power fantasy shooter is setting yourself up to be disappointed. While you can play it like that in freelance if you wish, the true fun of the game comes from turning on tank controls and playing it slower and more methodical. Setting up traps, waiting for enemies to cluster into chokepoints, and then blowing them away with chemical weapons banned by multiple worlds is certainly more rewarding. However, I do have a problem with the end campaign levels. The normal campaign and levels are fine, and ramp up the difficulty at a reasonable pace. That is, until the end levels. These levels were added later on in the games lifecycle, and "Are deliberately intended to be a test of everything you have learned up to that point." These maps and mech loadouts are incredibly hard, and are a great test of skill. However, the F series maps and mechs have crossed the border from fun to incredibly frustrating. in a normal playthrough, this wont be a problem. Just completing the main "Story" and screwing around in the freelance missions is fun enough on its own. For full completion, completing all levels with all mechs, it would have been nice to have "all levels" been the levels in the game on release, with the additional ones added on as a challenge for the most determined BRIGADORS. All in all, this is an excellent game with a lot of replayability, and I would highly recommend it.

review:
This is my favourite war crimes simulator on Steam. 

Morality is a bump on the road to a very, very fat bonus.

Picture this: it's a lovely sunny summer afternoon, and you're cruising through a nice upscale neighbourhood in your little tuk-tuk... wind through your hair, music blaring, content in the knowledge that your bank balance will be tens of millions of dollars fatter after nothing but a quick sortie with enough chemical artillery to make historians blanch. The gentle "THWOP" of the canisters launching, the locals running for their lives, the complete and utter collapse of local infrastructure... Ahh it's so nice to relax at the weekend.

Though you might want to make sure that you're up to date on your life insur-- wait, what do you mean "non-citizen"? "RTFM"?

Oh... [i]OH...[/i] ♭

8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198048008412', 'num_games_owned': 489, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 4408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3500, 'last_played': 1644644802}
review:
Thank Mandalore for turning me onto this game: from the trailer I thought it was just another twin stick shooter, but in reality it's actually a delightful isometric tactical mech (and tank an hovercraft) fighting/demolishing/war crimes game. Run around learning the game and experiencing a variety of pre-crafted loadouts in the "campaign" mode, or make your own horrendous war crime machines as a Freelancer! The game has a large variety of player-drivable vehicles and numerous weapons to kit out your death machines, and despite the isometric artstyle the weapons work in 3D, so a towering mech that can shoot over many buildings and a tuk-tuk from hell that can hide behind even the lowest barriers will play differently even with the exact same weapons.

Not everything is perfect though. Most immediately, the game defaults to "screen absolute" controls so you can play it like a twin stick shooter: IMMEDIATELY change the settings so that mechs/tanks use relative controls for a much more engaging experience (no one will blame you for using absolute controls on Agravs though). The fact that weapons shoot in 3D can sometimes make figuring out where exactly your bullets are going to hit is difficult, sometimes the difference between "behind" and "actually hits" is difficult, and good luck having any idea where an artillery weapon is going to hit if you're firing it signifigantly towards the top or bottom of the screen. Finally, the F levels of the campaigns and the "no stone" and "statistik" achievements are downright aggravating compared to everything else in the game.

Overall, the cons, though annoying, are heavily outweighed by the pros. They are but mere blips on the otherwise greatly fun experience, I highly recommend trying out Brigador if you're into isometric shooters, tactical moment-to-moment experiences, choosing your dream death machine, or flattening entire city blocks at once.

review:
Je suis tombé amoureux de ce jeu. Il est exactement ce qu'il donne l'impression d'être lorsqu'on regarde les screens sur la page du magasin. C'est comme jouer une sorte de mix entre Future Cop et un Hotline Miami plus posé, c'est comme prendre le contrôle d'une unité dans un vieux STR isométrique au décor savoureux à la Tiberium Sun. On fait ce qu'on peut pour venir à bout de la map avec les outils et les faiblesses inhérentes à la machine utilisée. Et ces derniers  paramètres ne sont pas les seuls à prendre en compte... 
Entre autres: perforation, vélocité des armes, exposition de l'armure, pénétration du véhicule dans le décor, tant de paramètres contribuant à renforcer la dimension tactique du jeu. 10/10 bordel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058243825', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1703898108}
review:
There is a brief moment in each district, as you walk towards the exit, surrounded by the smoking ruin of what was once a bustling suburban community, or industrial park, or relay station, that the gravity of your actions sink in. Even if it's just a little bit. The civilians you stepped on haphazardly, or were caught in the collateral damage of your guns. The scores of people you have gunned down. The years of development that have been reduced to rubble by you, without so much of a thought. It's a horrifying realisation, really, and the moment is perfectly accentuated by the relatively quiet tones of the music that plays between levels.

The moment is made worse by your destructive trek through each district. As you rampage through people's homes, their place of work, their farms, their food, their parks, their monuments. As your shells reduce everything, everywhere, to smoke and ash. People lived here once, worked here once. They made memories here. Perhaps it means something to them.

But then the lights turn back on. You're in another district with new objectives. The wanton devastation you left behind you is no longer at the forefront of your mind. Already, your thoughts turn away from the people you've killed and from the places you've razed. You now think about how many shells remain in your ammunition stores, how much hull you have left.

It isn't about the people anymore. Great leader is dead. And Solo Nobre must fall.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993190984', 'num_games_owned': 800, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1967, 'last_played': 1614249777}
review:
The game is exceptionally fun. You jump in a mech, tank, or hovercraft and roam about the city, blowing everything in sight up. Visuals great. Sound great. Soundtrack, simply the best. Gameplay awesome.

The only thing I would say is that the game quickly gets repetitive. Every game is a sandbox where you choose the pilot, the vehicle, the weapons, and the maps. While that leads to a lot of combinations they are kinda much of a much-ness.

The game would really benefit from a progression system or an "Open Contracts" type system to keep the replayability up. Difficulties, levels, enemies, and modifiers should unlock with playtime/score. contracts could be offered to encourage players to play with vehicles and weapons they have not tried/ wouldn't play with otherwise.

While the current system is good in the sense that you can literally play anything you like right from the get-go, provided you have enough credits - I feel as though that completely guts out the replayability factor which is sad for a game that is otherwise so excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263554071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1839, 'last_played': 1689009269}
review: I often find that an hour isn't enough time to start playing a game and don't want to bother committing myself if I know I will have to stop soon after starting, usually resulting in wasting time mindlessly browsing the internet. Brigador is excellent for those short spans of time that you don't know what to do with. Everything in the game can be bite sized, the campaign missions often capable of being completed in under 15 minutes, while the freelance missions can be tailored for length and difficulty. Every time you pick Brigador up there are a great variety of options to try out and each session feels both familiar and fresh. That the game can be short is but one positive feature, though. Run a gauntlet of increasingly difficult missions, each completed section growing your bank account, the promise of a jackpot at the end for completing the entirety holding a command over you to think "just one more run." At these times you feel invincible and want to keep pushing further, only to get steam rolled by your hubris losing all that hard earned cash. First you're angry, but then you want to try again because you know you can pull it off. It's awesome, I love the feeling of pushing your abilities and luck at every moment and want to keep going long after that hour I had is over. Others have noted how beautiful this game is, the delightful design of each vehicle, weapon, and loadout, the remarkable score by Makeup and Vanity, and I feel I cannot add to what they have said without reiterating their points. What I can add is that this is the perfect game for immediately gratifying enjoyment, easy to pick up and play at any moment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022275842', 'num_games_owned': 3263, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1614849500}
review:
Remember Future Cop L.A.P.D. and Nuclear Strike? Well, Brigador is their glorious and magnificent spiritual successor. This game doesn't need many words to describe how good it is. Amazing gameplay, beautiful art, perfectly suitable effects and music. Worth every dollar I spent on it. My only regret that I started playing game this late. So, just buy it and enjoy. 

Developers, please create Brigador 2, but with kind of open world strategic map (not just mission list) and ability to shop (and upgrade) for mechs, armors, shield generators, reactors and weapons like it was in good old classic game such as Tyrian. Also, please allow to have more than 2 weapon hardpoints on the mech and allow free hotkey assignment for every hardpoint. Stat-wise upgrades are enough (as it was done in Tyrian), no need to give unique texture for every upgrade - even though it is cool, it is extremely time consuming.

Actually, proper mech equipment screen with multiple weapons, shields, armors, reactors, engines and special modules (with assignable hotkeys as well) will be even better. You also can even add some kind of base building, where player can establish the base, develop over time and raid enemy for resources via strategic map. Enemy should respond in kind forcing player to defend base personally or with help of autonomous defenses, turrets and units.

EDIT: I've discovered that it has proper modding toolkit. Seems like I will be modding it future (maybe) and adding some really insane things (Holy Hand Grenades Launcher anyone?).

author: {'steamid': '76561198037289619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 6232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5738, 'last_played': 1697700941}
review:
This game is horrible. 

Not in terms of gameplay, mind, the gameplay is fantastic once you get used to the quirks of steering the individual vehicles. 
The spritework is gorgeous, it runs smoothly, the sound design is wonderful, the vehicles handle nicely and the basic gameplay premise, while simple, is extremely fun - get plonked down in an area with the objective to destroy certain objectives, including the means of communication, enormous anti-air cannons and power supplies, and how you achieve these goals is up to you. Achieving them by whatever means necessary awards you credits, which you can spend to customize your chosen approach.

Sure, you could roll out in a functional tank, with a howitzer to take care of your objectives - the buildings - and a machine gun to take care of small fry that try in vain to scratch your shields, let alone dent your armor, with a stealth field generator to ensure smooth progression of hit and run guerilla tactics to avoid collateral damage as well as a safety net for when things go south.

Alternatively, though, you could also come floating up in a modified limousine, blasting sick guitar riffs to draw as many eyes on you as possible before firing cannisters of corrosive gas into a nearby strip club before levelling an entire apartment complex with an audio-kinetic shockwave. Or you take a stroll in a weaponized tuk tuk that will explode if looked at funny, but it's still an entirely viable means of playing. 

It's a game that lets you have fun. There is a broad selection of vehicles - between the three archtypes of mechs, tanks and anti-grav (basically aircraft) pertaining to the three enemy factions (the militaristic loyalists, the advanced spacers, and the corvid, who continuously baffle their competition by fielding vehicles that seem held together by the faith of the crew and the superglue they huffed while 'designing' their vehicular abomination), there's already lot to choose from. Each vehicle feels unique in the way they play, the way they maneuver, the way they turn and behave; and of course, what weapons they let you fit to them. Two mechs may look identical in terms of design on first glance, but upon playing you may find far preferable to the other - be it for faster acceleration, because you find a given weapon class one mech has hardpoints for boring, or because one of the two may not be able to rotate it's upper body 360 degrees around itself, meaning you can't shoot behind yourself as you leg it away from the enemy. 
There's a lot of experimentation to do and a lot of weapons to purchase; with machine guns ranging from those specialized in shredding shields to gatling guns so powerful dual-mounting them on a heavy-class tank can see it propelled backwards through recoil alone, howitzers with flat or high arcs, shotguns, laser weaponry and weaponized warcrimes in the form of super-corrosive gasses and mining beams that vaporize someone's entire skeletal structure, there are plenty of combinations to work with. It's all rounded out with extra equipment in the form of recharging smoke bombs to impair enemy vision, a cloaking device, an EMP grenade that neutralizes enemies within a radius, and an audio-kinetic pulse that flattens everything in a large radius.

They also come with juicy, juicy lore; each vehicle, each pilot, each weapon has its own little story and flavor text, all of which are very well-written and genuinely fun to read. 

However it also proves I am capable of great evil if given the tools to experiment and a lack of consequences for collateral damage, as I once again find myself slamming my hovercar down onto a group of civilians for no reason other than that they exist, only to then vaporize a group of soldiers with a gamma ray emitter.

So [i]morally[/i] speaking, yes. The game is horrible.

But Great Leader is dead.


And Solo Nobre [b]must[/b] fall.


[spoiler] plus in this economy, i cant pass up on the hundred bucks i get for each splattered red mark i leave on the sidewalk. gotta get that bread, man. [/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198121337925', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1339, 'last_played': 1682557092}
review:
Brigador is a master class in entertainment. I have not found a game I find myself enjoying as much as it in a very long time, and for good reason.

Brigador was met with little fanfare upon its release; as an Indy game, this is unsurprising I suppose. It received lukewarm reviews, a combination of unintelligent and unscrupulous gaming journalists and players without time or desire to learn the nuances of a game with slightly more complex anatomy than their baseline. I would be untruthful if I said that I was a fan of this game that whole time; like most people I presume, I learned of this game through a certain schizoaffective YouTuber and his Doctor Jeckle African warlord alter ego. However, that doesn't change my actual, genuine love for this game.

Brigador is not a wordy commentary on war. It is not a master work of world building through intricate gameplay and hidden lore. It does not tell a cohesive overworld narrative though in-depth dialogue and personal stories. Brigador instead tells it's lore through dialogue boxes, acquired after purchasing implements of destruction. These tools are to be used in it's top-down romp through the ruins-in-being of Solo Nobre, the capital of Novo Solo, a corporate war colony liberated from its chains by the enigmatic Great Leader. On the twilight of his passing, the corporate liaison, who I can only assume glows in the dark, offers war contractors to "Brigadors", guns and vehicles for hire. The war economy is booming, and anything that can mount anything more powerful than an 8mm Machine Gun is invited to the party; Have Gun, Will Travel.

Stardust on your boots and your Blood Group on your mechanist fatigues, you, your machine, and your weapons are free to romp through the world, destroying orbital guns, communications arrays, electrical infrastructure, and the defenders of the city at your whim. This game has that buzzword that seemed to be all the rage at the time of it's release, "fully destructible environments''; except they mean it. You can destroy everything you see except only the map border walls. Every. Single. Thing. Every building, rail track, and road sign. Every gas station, civilian dwelling, or shop. Every square meter of crop and every tree. Everything. It's amazing. It reminds me of my first time playing Battlefield Bad Company in its own way, the absolute elation of taking your 200 tonne mech and walking through a retaining wall like it's paper, the joy of collapsing an apartment dwelling on top of your super-heavy tank and rolling through like it's rain. It's a joy im not legally allowed to obtain in the real world, and makes for a pleasant surrogate.

Brigador allows you to become an Avatar of death almost immediately. It costs less than $12 million in game (a typical mission will give you no less than $1.5m in the early game) to unlock the games most powerful weapons spread. That is not the end game, however. Oh yes, it's fun to roll around in the games most preposterous wonder weapon, mounting a GAU-8 and a 140mm smoothbore gun or becoming a wandering war crime by mounting an audiokenetic pulse device, a gas lauchner and a LASER that deep fries anything it touches, allowing you to turn anything into slag, a puddle, or a pink mist at your leisure. But the REAL fun comes in the form of getting their lesser comrades. That 200 tonne mech is well and good, but try destroying 4 orbital guns and 70% of the local garrison with a pickup truck mounting an MG-42 and a Carl Gustav m/48E5 with only AP rounds. NOW were talking. 

All of this is set to the background of a driving combination of synths and 808s. What DOOM is to metal music, Brigadors sound track is to Synth. Hotline Miamis sound track remains one of the best of all time, but Brigadors music firmly sits in the category of "Music To Commit Genocide To", and you will. Mick Gordon may have let his players know that The Only Thing They Fear is You, but Makeup and Vanity Set provide you with an assurance that there is No Way Out, except to go through the denizens of Solo Nobre. The sound design in game, besides the music, is lovingly crafted with so many mechanical sounds and thunderous impacts, that even if the music isn't your taste, the soundscape certainly can be enjoyed on its own.

9/10. Any problem I have with this game is insignificant. Acquire Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030217555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1612238837}
review:
GREAT LEADER IS DEAD, WELCOME BRIGADOR

This is the best off-brand Mechwarrior game you didn't know you needed. Stomp, explode, and laser everything in your way in a variety of vehicles through the middle of a revolutionary colony in order to bring it back into the fold of Evil Inc. Your character is one of 50~ potential mercenaries that are trying to profit or die trying. 

This game's hard in a fun way. There are very clear rules to how the game world operates, your relationship to the game world is very nuanced. For one, you can ram through almost anything without taking damage. In one of the earlier levels, the tutorial actively smack talks you into bravely kool-aid manning through the game world. If you don't look before you ram, you might hit something explosive and die almost instantly. Explosive hazards are predictable and always spawn in the same spots. Secondly, every weapon has innate strengths and weaknesses. The chaingun melts everything, but is an ammunition hog. Explosives are powerful, but have long reloading periods. etc. Oh, and many bullets are tracked and WILL zoom past the small hitboxes of the various go-karts the revolutionaries drive. It's never as easy as "Hold mouse buttons to win" in this game, you have to keep a lot of variables in your head as you rampage around. 

Not only can you drive most of the mechs in the game but you can also drive various tanks, flying cars, power armors, and even a meter maid cart. In fact, the game actively rewards you for playing with the harder vehicles in the game. So yes, the tempation to just drive the super tanks is there but you also progress faster if you survive destroying the planet in a little power suit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11196, 'playtime_forever': 3835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3835, 'last_played': 1612021943}
review:
This is a 2D/ISO top down twin stick style shooter where you control a tank-like battlemech and destroy terrain, enemy vehicles and people in a style reminscient of Syndicate. 

There's a lot of depth in the vehicle selection and customisation which is a plus.  The game concept is brilliant.  Unfortunately the technical implementation is lacking.  Graphics appear very retro/pixelly despite the game being released in 2016.  Overscan/DPI issues cause the game to render only 1/4 of the screen, so you need to jump through compatibility hoops to make this 2016 game run on any high end PC from 2016 or later (so they didn't do enough testing, either).   Once you do get it to work, there's no display scaling so text can be difficult to read, another technical gaffe. 

Despite the technical faults, there's a massive $20 USD price tag plus a slew of $5 DLCs, which is much too pricey considering the drawbacks here.   It's a good concept that deserves better treatment, so I'm hoping this 4 year old game gets a remaster or a sequel with updated graphics, bugfixes and so on.   Until then, this is a game that came close to being great but is let down by implementation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127981358', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4287, 'last_played': 1703709769}
review:
This game kept me engaged for well over 100 hours (started on the GOG version) with absolutely no padding whatsoever. No level grinding, no redundant or repetitive missions, nothing to artificially lengthen the game like slow traversal or unforeseeable deaths. Just wall to wall skill and wall to wall strategy. 

The weapon and vehicle variety is incredible and so long as you keep switching up your loadout every run feels unique. Even if you avoid the sandboxy Freelance Mode entirely there's enough meat in the Campaign Mode to keep you playing for a very long time. 

I have a hard time explaining the gameplay of Brigador as it's unlike anything else I've played. Much more strategically nuanced than a twin stick shooter, much more intensely visceral than a strategy game. It's sort of a stealth game but one in which you're mean to cause as much destruction as possible. Worms meets Thief. Like I say it's unique. 

The devs are very active in the forums and will go to great lengths to help you out. They personally respond to most threads, even for minor stuff like offering tips to help you beat a particularly hard mission. 

If you do take the plunge I strongly recommend setting the controls to Relative instead of Screen Absolute as this was how the game was originally designed and IMO it feels much more natural. I also recommend using a mouse and keyboard as, again, this is the intended way to play and the default Gamepad controls feel a little janky. Having said that, I ended up playing most of the game using custom gyro controls on a Switch Pro Controller (there's a post in the forum about it for those interested).

author: {'steamid': '76561198075507228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 2428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2159, 'last_played': 1679954465}
review:
Absolutely, positively one of the greatest games ever made. You wouldn't think a top down isometric mech game could feel so immersive, but man...you really weigh what you need to do next. The tank controls make everything so contemplative and it makes you WANT to strategise by getting you into your pilots head.  You're like "Do I have enough ammo? Can I make it back to the depot before the scouts catch up to me after I made that big explosion?"

 It helps that cover actually works in this game and the AI is pretty competent. You won't find yourself struggling to outsmart it, and once you're in a firefight it does just come right after you, but the search patterns and  patrols will keep you on your toes until then. 

It's gorgeous too. Sprite work this good is almost never seen anymore. It's unique in that regard, and would stand above its peers if it actually had any. 

How many videogame soundtracks can say that they got you into the band that made them? I put on Makeup and Vanity set when I need to study or read, and I only know of them because they scored this game. 

Get this game. Don't wait for a sale.

review:
Excellent destruction and combat game that allows you to fine-tune your experience in so many important ways.  Set up something easy breezy to do while you're watching videos or buckle up for a hell ride suicide mission.  This sort of built-in difficulty adjustment is something I wish more games did.  Soundtrack is amazing, visuals range from great to downright gorgeous, especially during night missions when neon lights and weapon tracers light up the scenery and debris.  

Don't let the playtime on this review fool you.  I'm 30+ hours in on the GoG version and I'm still going.  Welcome, Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962044609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1627462818}
review: Unassuming at first glance but it's a very enjoyable and in-depth vehicular combat game. The excellent visuals and sound design gives the feeling of watching live footage of a city getting blown to pieces during a war, the vehicles have different handling and loadouts, and the weapons all have distinct roles and uses. Tread carefully and snipe mechs in the back with high-risk high-reward man sized power armor or go nuts with a tank made of 7 minivans welded together that shoots flesh eating acid canisters. The fluff writing is well done and fun to read, giving a lot of context and tone for the overall mayhem. You can rest easy knowing that your bass cannon soundwave has shattered the eardrums of every civilian in a five block radius or that your radiation gun gives everyone in the area terminal cancer if they don't get flash-liquified first.

review:
看介紹好像很有趣，但實際上玩了之後，會明顯有一種感覺，大概前5分鐘有新鮮感，

但5分鐘後就覺得這遊戲可玩度很低，畢竟都是在做一樣的事情，

必須老實說，因為現在這個年代的遊戲越來越追求精緻及多功能，

早期較單調的設定，除非是本身真的是單調卻非常有趣，不然大多數仍會面臨時代去淘汰早期的遊戲設定相關遊戲，

而該款明顯的就是無法抵擋時代的潮流的狀況，所以個人已經被很多款多功能的遊戲給薰陶下，無法接受該款太過於"精緻"的內容，

因此給予負評。

review: An underappreciated gem. Evoking old-school 1990's isometric shooters like Crusader and the Strike series, the variety of weapons, vehicles, and sheer unrestrained fun of demolishing city blocks for profit is something that very few games do as well as Brigador. A short and underwhelming campaign is more than made up for by Freelance mode, which is where the real meat of the game lies. A great synthwave soundtrack and well-written (often darkly hilarious) lore are extra bonuses.

review: I passed this over years ago since I wasn't paying attention at the time. Now I see brigador as the highly flexible, engrossing experience it is. Want a quick 5 minutes as a death machine? You got it. Want to torture yourself with a rickshaw, a skeleton and several WMDs? Why not. The lore was a present surprise and I love the whole "lore from an in-universe perspective" thing. It tells you even more about world just by what people say about it. I won't talk about the music since you can go listen for yourself and enjoy it there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030705469', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3366, 'last_played': 1682923433}
review: Remember that it's not a twin-stick shooter but a real-time mech tactics game – and you'll be fine. It's a wonderful game once you pass the initial learning curve and testing new vehicles and weapons keeps the game interesting. The skill ceiling here is pretty high but the game is still fairly balanced according to the difficulty levels and your playstyle approach. It also has a fairly deep and fascinating cyberpunk lore along with the audiobook that is a blast to listen to. The only potential con this game has is the fact that you have to enable the tank controls for your vehicles for the most optimised experience: the way it's meant to be played; but truth be told, it's just a matter of going to options and enabling a couple of switches, and it does not detract from the overall experience. It's not a fast-paced game by any means, so please keep that in mind. Honestly, I can't recommend it enough. It scratches a very specific itch that you just can't find in any other game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043676284', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1576051304}
review:
It's okay. Just okay.

I wanted to love this game. I got hooked on the world, the book tie-in is actually one of my favorite books (seriously check out the audiobook version it's a great experience) and the aesthetic design of the world of Brigador is beautiful. The music is some of the best I've heard in a game in a long time, it regularly ends up in my spotify mix because of that.

Despite that, though, the game just isn't good and didn't hook me. I don't know if it's how some missions are far too short and others tediously long, how combat often feels like it either has no stakes at all because of how trivial it is or just that the controls in almost any configuration are just unpleasant to use when combined w/ the specific point of view the game has. I wish I knew, because it's something I could suggest to the devs to fix, but I think that it's something inherent to the game which is disappointing because it does everything else so well.

I don't recommend that anyone actually play the game, unless it is heavily discounted. You'd be better off picking up the audiobook and delving straight into the good parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057918945', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3652, 'last_played': 1625270982}
review:
Brigador is a top-down vehicular combat game developed by Stellar Jockeys. It was originally released back in 2015 on early access & left it in 2016. The Up-Armored Edition was released in 2017. Players assume role of a Brigador; A mercenary working for a faction called Solo Nobre Concern.

Pros:
+Plenty of drivable vehicles from mechs to agravs, tanks or even a weaponized rickshaw.
+Great art design. Everything fits together and no asset feels out-of-place.
+Fantastic soundtrack.
+Good amount of content (Took myself 59 hours to 100% the game).
+Rich lore.
+Mod support.
+Both vehicles & weapons feel beefy and good to use.

Cons:
-Controls can feel a bit janky at first.
-Not One Stone achievement.

If you've ever played Future Cop: LAPD or Battletech or just happen to enjoy vehicular combat then this game is definitely a must-have for you.  It's worth the full price and delivers everything it promises to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058851171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1681704192}
review:
Giant robots big guns, and game design that snaps together like a perfectly machined puzzle of steel. 

Brigador is a fantastic game where the only wrong way to play is to die. Every shot fired has worth as your paid almost as much for breaking the buildings as you are the machines you're fighting. A top down view gives a wide and extensive view of a finely detailed, fully destructible, battlefield of your making, and allows for quick reconnaissance to make a plan for your next attack. Just be sure to swap the controls because this isn't a twin stick shooter, and where you're facing will affect how you receive damage. Learn the controls and you'll be easily soaking rounds to pump out death in return.

You can play this entire game without reading a word if you so desired as the gameplay stands just fine on its own, and would almost relish the fact that the "why" doesn't matter, if you were to ascribe sentience upon it. That said there's a full on audio book and droves of lore if your willing to read. Brigador is now one of my favorite science fiction stories.

The music in this game is all synthwave and damnit if every single piece isn't perfectly placed. Rock out with your mech out, as you kick ass and chew bubble gum.

The only downside is that the skewed view, and aiming system make it a REAL pain to hit agrav units, but that's my only legitimate gripe about this otherwise wonderful game.

review: A hidden gem of a game I wish I had seen earlier but better late then never. The game has a campaign that doubles as a tutorial and a challenging set of missions to burn through with premade builds to try out. Brigador has a massive amount of customization available between the different vehicles, weapons, and equipment to choose as well as pilots to determine the difficulty of a run. Another hidden gem INSIDE a hidden gem is a surprisingly well written and engrossing story as told in mission briefings and equipment/vehicle/pilot descriptions written from an in character perspective. This is an easy recommend for anyone who likes tactical combat and rampant property damage, or just good games. Probably that last one more.

review:
brigador up-armored édition ou un des seuls jeu de combat de mécha sur Steam qui a compris le concept de mécha !
brigador est une jeu de niche avec un semblant de rogue-like et une putain de quantité de lore !
Le jeu réussis parfaitement malgré sont aspect 2D à vous faire ressentir toute la puissance des machines que vous contrôlé grâce en premier lieu à sont pixel-art très beau et sont sound design au petit oignions !
Bien-sur le jeu n'est pas pour tout le monde celui-ci n'est pas si facile même après avoir fait les 30-40 mission de tuto (un poil overkill le tuto) au contraire une fois la campagne finie ses là que votre véritable aventure va commencer,
car ses à ce moment là que vous pourrez participer à des contrats de très haute dangerosité avec un semblant d'aspect rogue-like et une customisation de vos véhicule complétement absurde on parle de plus de 100 type de véhicule plus ou moins grand.... mécha ou tank ou antigrav et tous possédant au minimum une dizaine voir une vingtaine d'arme chacun !
Pour sont pris et si vous aimez le fait de rentré dans un énorme robot et de casser absolument tous sur votre chemin entre vous et l'objectif ou de vous la jouez tank ninja alors ce jeu sera probablement un coup de cœur et pour sont prix vous en tirerez largement plus de 50-100h !

review:

Controls are mildly confusing especially because it feels like every other vehicle uses their own set of controls. Some of the guns I had no idea how they worked and was never explained ingame apart from telling you the name of the gun which is frustrating when you (me) are shit at remembering names. Many guns/cannons also feel as if they are just baiting you to use them because they are so garbage, anything with that fucking rainbow colored ray never worked well for me. author: {'steamid': '76561198152503886', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1640043618}
review: Most war games try to sell you on the writing detailing the dangers and horrors of war for the soldiers and civilians involved, or try to speak to the corruption and evil of governments and/or human nature. Brigador throws you into the setting of Space Brazil shortly after the death of it's dictator and tells you to make the chaos caused by the ensuing power vacuum escalate even further by causing the most damage and casualties possible. You're given a massive mech, an antitank cannon and then told to go ham on the nearby city and we'll give you a $50 bill for every civilian you step on while you do so it's fun chaotic goodness and the isometric sprites are absolutely beautiful and the music is stellar the entire thing is just a grand time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963155484', 'num_games_owned': 430, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1607945808}
review:
Most of the parts of the game are pretty great. The graphics, sound and music are more than up to par. However, aiming in this game feels extremely off. I get that the developers wanted to make the height of your own vehicle and those of enemies matter but it does not pay of for me. Hitting anything in an isometric perspective is already difficult but with the larger vehicles you have to almost point the cursor at the position of your enemy. It's not just the angle but the distance as well. That makes the screen move a lot because it is not centered on you but factors in where you are. There is an option to center the screen on yourself but then you give away a lot of "operating range".
And while you could micro manage switching the view and all that it simply is not fun for me.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197961408419', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1656788291}
review:
[b]The best SNES game that never was.[/b]

I wish I could port this game to Super Nintendo and send it back in time to myself when I was 12 and I had all day to sit around and play video games, lol. Seriously though, what a fantastic product; and an exceptional value for it's price. I just noticed I haven't reviewed it and I want to fix that, this game deserves every bit of praise it gets. The graphics, the sound, the lore, the music, the design, the game itself..where do I even start, or end for that matter? I could write a book on everything this game does right. At 35 years old, I've been playing video games since I was 4, from Atari on a black and white TV, through all the consoles, all the way to a high end gaming PC today. I'm an avid gamer, usually averaging at least 4-6 hours a day and I've played literally thousands of games in the last 30 years. Brigador is a highlight of that experience, it stands out, head and shoulders above the crowd and that's saying something; especially for a small indie game.

I'm going to be mostly, completely honest here. I had access to this game through a copy I didn't personally own, I won't go into more details, but I'm sure you can fill in the blanks. I've played this game to death, prolly hundreds of hours. Beaten it multiple times, unlocked all the lore, and all that jazz during a time in my life when I did not have the means to buy a copy for myself. I did play it though, and I did love it. This one vacation with my gf's family years ago, I brought my old laptop and had Brigador loaded on to it, and spent most of the week just playing it and unlocking all the extras for like the 3rd time. However, like all good things; it did eventually come to an end, and I felt that I was satisfied and "done" with the game. Time quietly moved on.

Then one day, later on in life.. I saw it on sale, and I thought to myself "Even though I've played it to death, it'd be nice to have in my library" but I hesitated over the purchase button. I thought of all the time I had spent playing it, how I had gotten so much enjoyment out of the game, and fell in love with it so hard; it felt wrong to buy it for anything less than full price. So, I waited until the sale was over and bought it then. It feels good to be in a place in my life where I can afford to finally give the dev's the money they so rightfully deserve.

Now, I just need to work on unlocking all my extras again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197969847656', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 8061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5988, 'last_played': 1700597203}
review:
One of the most under-rated indie games on the market. I don't have time for a detailed review, but it also comes with a phenomenal audio book, I would highly recommend that you purchase that as well.

Set in Solo Nombre, the largest settlement on the outer colony planet of Solo Novo, Brigador is set in a dystopian future setting where the local dictator, Great Leader, has just died, and the powder-keg planet explodes in war.

You play as a "Brigador", an on-world soldier (can be from one of various factions, loyalists, rebels, spacers) that accept bribes from an off-world corporation (trying to take control of the planet in the power vacuum) to betray your own forces, and take your mech against both them and the surrounding civilians. You are NOT the good guy here... You get paid for destroying military targets, you get paid for collateral damage, you get paid for killing civilians. It is a bit... dark, and I love it. The more you destroy, the more money you get when you leave the planet in your escape craft.

If one phrase could describe this game, it is "attention to detail". It runs on a home-grown engine, and renders the vehicles, buildings, and explosions in stunning detail. You can shoot anybody and blow anything up, every wall, street light, home, business, person, and oil pipeline is fair game (definitely target the pipelines, watch the entire block explode!). Seriously, the artwork alone is extremely impressive. Even outside of the audio book, there is a plethora of in-game lore (that you purchase with in-game credits) that I found to be well worth my time.

The only "con" I can give this game is that the audio book is not available in a printed form, that said, the voice acting is top-notch (simply have a personal preference for physically printed books).

author: {'steamid': '76561198004854110', 'num_games_owned': 376, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8598, 'last_played': 1651835972}
review:
I thought about why I love Brigador for a long time.  I wondered if it was because I already had a weak spot for the kind of setting and military fetishism in full effect here.  I mean, it's true: Brigador scratches a million itches for me.  But, while thinking about this, I realized that the they're all things found in every aspect of the game, not just the setting, awesome and fleshed-out though it is.  The gameplay is exciting and nothing if not varied: it has the kind of mix of lethality and creativity I love about games like Hotline Miami.  I'm sure other people have made the HM connection because of the synth soundtrack and neon skyline, but despite this having a pace more befitting of its scale, it retains the thrill of a lot of HM gameplay.  That's pretty amazing.

I could have written a lot more, but if you want needlessly detailed reviews, I've seen them out there.  Watch Mandalore's video, for that matter.  It's vastly more informed than a professional reviewer's would have been, because it's a fan's perspective and therefore, he knows more about the game than he needs to - in a good way.

This is just one of my absolute favourite games ever for a combination of personal interests and reasons.  I think it might become yours too, if you give it a shot.  That's my review.
