author: {'steamid': '76561198186511753', 'num_games_owned': 104, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 431, 'last_played': 1691515629}
review:
Fantastic game that has had a lot of love put into it. Gorgeous 2D art and an incredible soundtrack. Also boasts  over 60 playable vehicles, 50 pilots, tons of weapons, and over 70 freelance missions in addition to a 50 mission campaign. 

The campaign missions act as a tutorial that then scales up to more challenging scenarios. Freelance plays similar to a rouge-like. allowing you to chose a pilot, vehicle, and weapons before entering into a somewhat randomized set of maps. The vehicles are varied and all feel great to play, from mechs and grav tanks, to motorcycles and rickshaws. 

Overall a great tactical 2D mech game with a lot of depth and replayability. Worth picking up if you enjoy games like this.

review: I was originally fooled by the negative reviews for this game and skipped it over. I have since come to understand that truly great games can be ruined by poor marketing and explanation over what the game actually is. This is not a twin stick shooter, this is a tactical vehicular combat game. It's also a damn good one. It's not perfect, I think the freelance mode lacks enough variety to keep you invested for more than 10 hours (still a good number to be fair, just not nearly enough to purchase every unlockable). In addition to the freelance mode, the game also includes a loose campaign mode with a choice in most missions between several premade vehicles allowing you to try out several builds you normally might nor. Some weapons are better than others, some vehicles too, some maps are just easier than others, but none of the balancing issues are bad enough to detract really. All in all the game isn't perfect, but still gets a solid 8.5/10 and a firm recommendation from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962005988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1623526031}
review:
I first discovered Brigadore quite long ago but never got around to picking up. After watching MandaloreGaming's review, however, I was sold.

In short, it's a game about heavy vehicles (mechs, tanks and antigravity hovercraft) blowing stuff up. We're talking about mechs stomping through urban centers, plowing through buildings and chewing through enemy vehicles with a hugely satisfying armory full of fun toys. What else do you need?

The game has a campaign in which most missions can be completed using different predetermined loadouts (vehicle, weapons and special abilities) allowing for a surprisingly large variety of playstyles and challenge levels. After that are the Freelance missions in which you can freely design your experience by creating a loadout from scratch by choosing your pilot (which determines the difficulty level), vehicle, your two weapons and your vehicle's special ability. The harder you make things for yourself the bigger the cash payout you will get.

And what do you use the cash for? Unlocking more pilots, vehicles, weapons and special abilities for the Freelance mode. And you also use the money to unlock lore.

And for a game about big machines blowing stuff up the lore is both surprisingly interesting and well-written. The world-building in Brigador is excellent and the lore is well worth purchasing.

What else is there to say? You've got big mechs, explosions, surprisingly interesting lore and explosions. Did I mention the explosions? Right, there's the soundtrack as well, which is a collection of absolute synthwave bangers that perfectly fit the game's action and aesthetic.

If anything above interests you at all then I highly recommend picking up Brigador.

Do be aware, though, that the game uses directional damage: vehicle's have less armour in the rear. The default control scheme moves your vehicle relative to the screen, which could result in you moving with your rear towards the enemy. As highly as I recommend the game I also recommend switching the controls to being relative to your vehicle (tank controls).

review:
Great game for such a low price. Efficient top down shooter with tons of content to unlock, from enormous mechs to tiny tanks and everything in between, along with a healthy arsenal of weapons. The art style is great, the soundtrack is awesome, the feeling of power one gets from stomping over building blocks and blasting waves of enemies is very satisfying. 

The campaign mode isn't very interesting and doesn't add anything to the game past the few tutorial missions (I would advise to focus on the freelance mode instead)  and I've had a few performance issues on some levels (which is odd given the pixel-art nature of the game) but aside from that I recommend Brigador to anyone looking for a fun, action packed game that can be played in quick sessions.

review:
The guys at Stellar Jockeys are so impossibly dedicated to producing the best possible mech/vehicular mayhem simulator ever devised, its practically a crime that this game doesn't get more of the attention it so rightly deserves. 

I considered for a moment the dream game that could be if these guys were given some big name IP like Battletech to work with...and then I remember that on their own without any lore to borrow from, they built their own awesome world for this game to exist in...and I think its better(Now I'm committing a crime).

If you like mechs, stomping on things, blowing things up, being tactical, keeping all the money, immersing yourself in being a sci-fi mercenary ready to tear down the old regime for enough cash to retire offworld, play this game, you won't regret it.

And if you like it leave a positive review, these devs need to know that this kind of dedication should be rewarded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066223884', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 607, 'last_played': 1657679599}
review:
Brigador is awesome. The gameplay has surprising depth with a ton of different vehicles each with unique stats that can utilize a ton of weapons that range from a machine gun to a laser shotgun to a cannon that fires canisters of corrosive gas. Destructive terrain, great music, and lots of style make it a very enjoyable game.

The three different factions, Loyalist, Spacer, and Corvid, each have a unique style to their vehicles. Spacers are made from construction equipment, Loyalists have a more standard, modern military look, and the Corvid rebels have vehicles made from scrap metal and old cars. Past the factions, there are three types of vehicles: walkers, tanks, and aggravs. Walkers have the benefit of being able to stomp, tanks can rush through enemies and terrain, while aggravs have a stomp like walkers but also have much higher mobility (they can strafe).

The different combos of Faction, vehicle type, and weapons make for a ton of interesting playstyles. Whether you want a ton of armor or mobility or range, it's all there somewhere. Enemies can be ruthless on higher difficulties so it's very important to play smart and use all game systems.

Also check out the Mandalore video for a better review than I could ever make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048150603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1637711064}
review:
Brigador? 20 Dollars, the feeling of walking over a traffic jam with a mech dual wielding 30 mm ap gatling guns? Priceless.
Jokes aside this is a game I've genuinely enjoyed from start to finish although I haven't even gotten close to finishing. Plenty of stuff to unlock, an campaign which explains the controls, and introduces you to a variety of vehicle loadouts in order to ease you into the "real" game. Sparse on the lore when it needs to be, but if you're interested there's a lovingly crafted and interesting world behind it. Despite everything being 2d the game is absolutely gorgeous. I'm kind of a nitpicky asshole but holy shit I literally can't find anything to complain about here. I wanted to say at one point "there's not enough stuff to unlock" but... there honestly is, and freelance mode can potentially offer you many hours of entertainment.

I suppose the one bad thing about this game, is the control scheme shenanigans. The game comes preset with "Screen Absolute" which you can change to "Relative" which I absolutely suggest. Screen Absolute plays more like a twin stick shooter, but this is definitely not a twin stick shooter, as you can take more damage from the sides and back. Relative will feel wonky at first since wasd movement becomes relative to your vehicles direction, but I feel like it's absolutely better in every way. If you find Screen Absolute preferable on agravs, and Relative preferable on mechs and tanks you can set it to where agravs use Screen Absolute, and the later use Relative.
Genuinely good game however, would actually recommend.

review:
Okay for something a little different from the positive review bombs, a few stray thoughts:

-Controls are a little weird, but you'll get the hang of them with an hour or two of play.

-Gameplay loop is pretty simple, you'll be doing the same things over and over again but the higher difficulties become devilishly hard in a fun way. Mixing and matching vehicle loadouts is a great way to spice the somewhat repetitive gameplay up

-Game sort of takes a Metroid Prime style approach with it's lore, surface level you just shoot shit but if you enjoy reading the little bits and blurbs about the people, technology, and setting there's a lot here to unlock, read and enjoy

-Visuals look great for what they are, audio is great, soundtrack is top notch. Go for the deluxe edition for the OST's and the audiobook that fleshes out the world of Brigador even more

-Remember to use the horn to establish dominance. Especially when piloting the Treehouse.

For the price it's money well spent and a lot of fun to just play around with. Would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297289856', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 10865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6629, 'last_played': 1707381645}
review:
I fought the law as a skeletal tank crewman driving a tuk-tuk armed with a gamma radiation blaster, and surprisingly I won.

Brigador is a LOT of fun, and initially plays as a dystopian/cyberpunk-y vehicle rampage simulator. There's a lot more depth to it than you first expect, and a wealth of well-written lore if you take the time to read it. Overall your job as a mercenary pilot (or Brigador) is to tear down the current dictatorship by any means necessary, and that generally includes a ton of property damage; everything can be destroyed except for the district walls. You won't be penalised if a railgun slug completely misses the target and flattens several houses instead, or if you sit back and carpet-bomb a whole base with howitzer rounds. Far from it! The more you blow up, the more you get paid.

You can choose from a sizeable roster of pilots (who function as difficulty modifiers) and pick from around +60 unique vehicles, like the aforementioned tuk-tuk (the most fragile vehicle possible) to towering military battle mechs or a "tank" that is literally a pile of scrapped cars that features the best horn in the game. You can then load up with a variety of weapons that go from the Bonesaw 8mm MG to the Harvester 300mm fuel-air siege howitzer. The arsenal is extensive and includes everything from simple machine guns to laser cannons, chemical gas munitions and railguns to the "Audio-Kinetic Pulse" projector that literally disintegrates everything in a 90 degree firing arc.   

Combat is challenging, fun, and allows a lot of freedom for different tactics; a stealthy approach with a suit of power armour and a silent radiation blaster may make things easier, but if you want to take a super-heavy tank armed with city-levelling, war-crime enabling weapons it's all fair game. It's worth noting that Brigador also uses a directional damage system, with vehicles having thicker armour at the front and weaker to the sides and rear, so you always need to be aware of where your enemies are! It really helps to change the control scheme immediately to Resolute too, as it makes handling of most vehicles much easier.

I'm really excited to see what the upcoming sequel Brigador Killers holds, as Brigador Up-Armoured Edition utterly blew me away.

GREAT LEADER IS DEAD. SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144619290', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1760, 'last_played': 1710853106}
review:
This is a long overdue review despite me having played the game and joined the community for roughly over a year, so here it goes.

[h1]In short, 100% recommended.[/h1]

To simply put, everything is superb. The core gameplay loop never fails to get old: Brigador is one of those games that you create your own fun from the combinations of vehicles and weapons, going anywhere from 'just f*ck my sh*t up fam' in ultra-heavies with city killer cannons to playing Metal Gear Solid/Armour Hunter Mellowlink in fragile but effective power armour suits. The music I actually initially felt rather lukewarm towards but have grown into it: I think the game can work with a more.. intense soundtrack, and funnily enough the preview tracks for Brigador Killers totally satisfy that requirement for me. 
But the thing that really sealed the deal for me was the lore. Everything has its own entry and written in-universe in a very grounded way that can immerse you wholly into the world, if you let it work its magic. Even the drier, more technical (and not entirely technobabble!) entries you'd expect elsewhere (Efi) even has its own little quirks that makes them a joy to read. So much so that I have gotten into writing fan-lore myself, though whether if it's any good.. I'll let fellow community members to decide. You can read all of them in the fanmade brigador(dot)wikia(dot)com if you want to check them out yourself.

On top of all this, the game has mod support, though no Workshop support: you can find user made vehicles (all enemy vehicles previously unplayable are playable now thanks to our own modders! And then some OCs too), user made maps, an outrageously difficult difficulty upgrade mod named Hard Times, and so much more. Most of it are in the Modkit DLC but if you want them more up-to-date, the Discord server is the place to be.   
And of course Stellar Jockeys is one of the best communities I have been to. It's.. hard to describe but you can just join us and see for yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062202441', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6015, 'last_played': 1702708838}
review:
This game is badass. It has a lot of depth, a cool artstyle and cyberpunk setting, and awesome music from Makeup And Vanity Set. It can also be brutal at times, both in its difficulty and in the ethical dilemmas it puts you in, as you'll find yourself leveling apartment complexes to get a better shot or gunning down crowds of people because there may be suicide bombers hiding out.

It might just look like a twin stick shooter, but this game is mechanically complex. Where your vehicle is facing affects how much damage you take, the speed and direction you're moving at affects accuracy and range, the loudness of your guns affects how far you can be before being noticed, your vehicles profile affects how easily noticed it is from a distance, and your movement type affects what speed and terrain you can traverse.

All of these variables, plus thoughtful map design make the game play like a real time tactical action game. Whether you're a huge mech or a tiny powersuit, if you charge in guns blazing, it's going to end badly. You have to have a plan of attack and think ahead in order to be successful. If you get caught out of position by destroying too many buildings or carelessly run out of ammo, or overextend, it can make for some desperate and intense firefights and some ridiculous moments like luring out and stomping a tank from behind with a powersuit because you ran out of ammo.

There's a lot of freedom in the maps and loadouts. A powersuit plays completely differently than a giant mech, but the weapons themselves can also drastically affect gameplay. You can play it stealthy with a powersuit and sneak up on enemies, or you can play it safe from a distance with smoke bombs + sniper rifles, or say fuck it and go with a multi chamber seige howitzer.

The campaign is very challenging and forces you to try out new loadouts with totally different playstyles. Freelance mode is a blast too since it gives you more replayability, a place to test out new loadouts, and its just fun to chill out and play a few freelance missions.

If you're looking for a hardcore stealth/strategy/action game, and are willing to learn the tank controls, Brigador is worth picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995402481', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 4242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1036, 'last_played': 1652635262}
review:
Есть одна тема. До тебя ведь доходили слухи о Соло-Нобре? Мол, ихний великий вождь двинул кони?
Так вот, это правда. Хунта в панике, все понимают – диктатуре кирдык. Вопрос теперь только в том, кто урвет себе кусочек послаще. Тут-то в дело и вступаем мы. 
Я стакнулся с одной корпорацией, очень серьезные ребята. Они планируют взять город. Но сначала кто-то должен расчистить путь для вторжения. Главные цели – орбитальные зенитки, офицеры, подстанции, склады боеприпасов.
Им нужны хорошие пилоты, спецы по городскому бою. Драться придется в меньшинстве, так что диверсии и засады – наше все. Впрочем, что я тебе объясняю? Ты в этом деле дока.
Конечно, дельце рисковое, но хорошо оплачиваемое. Гонорары будут миллионные. Такой шанс выпадает раз в жизни, без шуток. Ты подумай, что лучше – тянуть лямку за гроши до пенсии или пошабашить одну ночь, и потом до конца жизни не работать?
Погоди, это еще не все. Я читал твое дело, и понял, что у тебя к работе… творческий подход. Как там написано? «Моральный релятивизм, граничащий с социопатией». Искусство требует жертв, так? А теперь представь Соло-Нобре. Никакой отчетности за пределами основного задания. Корпорации нужна земля, а не домишки и людишки. Если случайно развалишь пару кварталов или там прибьешь десяток пешеходов, никто не заплачет. Даже, наверное, выплатят бонус: с чувством юмора у этих ребят все в порядке.
Как и со снабжением. Я мельком пробежался по списку доступных машин. У них есть плюс-минус все – меки любых моделей, танки, башни на колесах, антигравы, экзоскелеты, даже пара доисторических мопедов завалялась для искушенных мсье.
Да погоди ты, я как раз собирался про арсенал рассказать! Какой художник без кистей? У них на складах горы классики типа мортир и гаубиц, но по случаю подвезли немало добра, запрещенного во внешних колониях. Какое именно? Да всякое – газометы, бомбы объемного взрыва, гамма-излучатели…  
Ага, сразу глазенки загорелись! Чувствую, сработаемся. Значит, буду на тебя рассчитывать, бригадор. Корпорация даст отмашку со дня на день, так что приготовься. Вечером вышлю тебе твой контракт. 
Пока не забыл. Будь внимателен: роспись надо черкнуть на трех страницах – первой, пятой и семнадцатой. Аванс не дают, питание не оплачивается. Зато похороны за счет компании.

review:
Of course I found this game due to Mandalore Gaming. Bought it and no regrets yet! I have just shy of 4 hours in the game currently and I can say, the controls are easy, you make money pretty quickly regardless of your skill level with the game, though the better you are the fast you'll progress.
The tutorial is easy, but a little lengthy in my opinion. Everything has lore and a fair description, however I wish the weapons had a better account describing what they are. 
Tons of mechs, tanks and hover tanks, weapons, pilots and freelance missions to choose from!
Over all if you enjoy a good twin stick shooter thats all about chaos and destruction, this is your game!
Great music and amazing artwork in this retros styled game.
I'd honestly give it a 9 outta 10!

review:
Плюсов в игре много, вам стоит в неё поиграть однозначно. Минусы не так значительны, их почти не имеется.
Лучше напишу о других минусах, а точнее, пожеланиях. Всё то, что могло бы сделать игру ещё лучше.

#Мультиплеер. В такой шикарной игре он просто обязан быть, но его нет.
(Вместо этого пилят точно такую же игру, особых отличий я пока в ней не вижу.)

#Контент. С ним проблем нет. Кроме одного но. Маловато разных объектов на карте. Со временем они быстро приедаются. Для такой простенькой в плане геймплея игры это простительно, но немного жаль...

#Режимы Игры. Я бы не прочь увидеть в такой игре всякие арены-дезматчи, захваты точек и захват флага,  удержание территорий и прочее-прочее-прочее.

#Открытый Мир. Такие крутые мегаполисы, и нет открытого мира, одни малюсенькие локации, айайай. Столько потенциала шикарной игры пропадает впустую. Хотелось бы не просто районы, с трэшаковым убей всех и забрось, это можно было бы превратить в полноценный MMORPG, на подобие Fallout в мире мехов. (Да, я знаю, такого не будет).

#Масштабирование. В такой крутой игре такая крутая фишка просто обязана быть. Не брать же с собою лупу, что бы рассмотреть всё великолепие игры, разработчики оплошали.

#Карта. В такой цветастой игре определять направление по меткам, которые ещё и вечно мельтешат на экране, по моему не очень удобно. Да и знать что где по карте намного удобнее.

#ИЗ ЭТОЙ ИГРЫ УЖЕ МОЖНО СТРАТЕГИЮ ДЕЛАТЬ! Куча разных юнитов и вооружения, разрушаемость зданий, ах и ох, как тут не хватает стратегии.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995741939', 'num_games_owned': 549, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1594939532}
review:
I am not quite sure whether to recommend this or not, but the reason why is - I haven't quite figured the game "out".
Its a twin stick shooter alright, with a lot of tactical/strategic fluff around it. It looks *gorgeous*! Soundtrack is awesome.

However, after 5 hours in, about half the campaign and few freelance missions, some equipment unlocks & all - I am still not quite sure whether I like this game or not.

I miss a sense of progression, I think. Pilots, vehicles and weapons, they all cost about the same, and with one mission you'll be able to unlock few... so I figure, once you find a working combo, you'll likely stick with it and just wreak havoc. But - at least in my playtime - I haven't really gotten the feeling of having to work the contracts to get the money, to unlock real showstoppers. I can pretty much unlock everything I want, which makes me wonder why should I even bother unlocking it. There's no increasing sums of money you need to pay for better weapons - there aren't "better" weapons to begin with, its all about how you want to configure it. There's no gating mechanism except money, but as I said - you earn a lot and you can easily unlock enough gear after a single mission.

This is the most confusing part of the game, for me.

The action itself is really awesome, and its not just mindless pounding. Directions matter, armour matters, visibility matters, your specials matter. Heck, your outfit will determine whether you die in seconds or just blast through with your mind half on autopilot.

Its a weird title. I bought it, refunded it, bought it again. I really wish I love it more, and I wonder if I will if I play it longer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071757298', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 829, 'last_played': 1623109939}
review:
Brigador is a great isometric mech/tank/whatever game with an insane amount of customization and a surprisingly good story if you're willing to dig a little. 

It's definitely the sort of game you'll know if you'll like just by looking at it - you control various big war machines and you stomp around destructible environments, shredding through hordes of enemies with an entertaining array of sci-fi weaponry. The destruction is suitably chunky, all the vehicles feel exactly like they should, and the map, enemy and weapon variety keeps it fresh for quite a while. 

The biggest flaw with the game is the lack of specialized objectives.  You'll essentially always be destroying one of three or four structures, killing a certain number of enemies or killing special marked targets. I would have loved to see some levels that more directly encourage stealth, overzealous aggression or the unusual use of certain vehicles/weapons. 

This isn't that big of a deal though, because the main dish is still the combat - and it's always great. Brigador has two key components that keep the combat engaging for longer than expected. First - aiming has a height element, so you can overshoot shorter units if your guns are too tall, which forces you to pay a lot more attention to where your cursor is rather than just fire-and-forget. Second, enemy units drop shield and ammunition on death, but the former decays after a short time and the latter can be destroyed. Combine this with the enormous range of specialized units, height-based cover & environmental hazards and you get a fairly elaborate dance of balancing target priority, extreme aggression and careful decision-making. Brigador rewards the player that goes in deeper than they should, but only if they know what they're getting into. Knowing who to kill first and how long that takes is key to surviving, and if you play your cards right you will survive, even in the most absurdly lopsided encounters. 

There's also always the stealth option, even if the game never directly forces you to do it. Enemies seem to have both a sightline and hearing - so picking the shortest mech with the quietest weapon gives you the best shot at avoiding them. There's an active equipment that can make you invisible for a short time to further encourage this style of play. Each faction also has several spotter units, some of which are tall enough to see over cover. If the alarm is raised, huge walls will appear all over the map, and a large group of enemy units will converge on your last known position. Unfortunately, not all maps are suited to this playstyle, but there are enough that allow it. 

The only other thing I want to complain about is the new-ish F-series campaign missions, because holy SHIT do they ramp up the difficulty. There's one for each enemy faction, and the unit options in conjunction with the fact that each of them has about five trillion enemy units makes them an actual headache to beat. They aren't bad per-se, but they're way, way harder than anything else up until that point. 

In terms of variety, the game has 46 missions in the main campaign of varying difficulty - each will give you a selection of between 1 and 4 vehicles with set loadouts. Usually, the first vehicle is the most powerful, with the alternate options encouraging increasingly careful or stealthy approaches to objectives. This is already enough, but Brigador also has freelance mode, which is a pseudo-roguelike with insane customization. There's 35 pilots, 68 vehicles and 44 weapons. Everything needs to be unlocked with money, but it's really easy to make it fast - pilots & vehicles have income modifiers, which can allow you to make >100mil in a single mission pretty easily. Freelance missions are grouped into "operations" with several new maps not seen in the campaign. Their difficulty is based on the pilot you choose at the start. 

As for the misc stuff - sound and visual design are top notch. The vehicles are loud and threatening (and they all have horns, too!), the guns rattle, the lasers pulse, etc... Everything sounds great. The music is a fantastic cyberpunk-synthwave mishmash that's a lot more upbeat than I expected it to be. It generally seems to react to your play as well, which endears me to it even more. The visuals are honestly incredible - there's so much minute detail in every tile that I couldn't tell if they were repeating assets, even by the end of the campaign. 

The story is kind-of pushed to the wayside, but if you read the logs it really is quite interesting. Regime changes in the face of a large power vacuum & a curious exploration of the "lesser of two evils" wherein every single option is probably a bad choice. Basically - moral ambiguity: the game. Considering you'll spend most of your time with Brigador stomping civilians into paste, this isn't much of a surprise. 

tl;dr - Brigador is a good mech game with a shit-ton of variety. Get it if you like big robots, big guns, loud noises and war crimes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028214959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 4515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1626198595}
review:
Brigador's all about piloting powerful sci-fi war vehicles in gorgeous 2D isometric fully-destructible environments and committing war crimes for fun and profit. This game is a total blast - while there's not too much variety in what you do in this game, there's plenty of variety in the way you go about it, with a bunch of vehicles and devastating weapons to unlock. You can opt for a brutal all-out assault with a heavy mech loaded up with destructive artillery to lay waste to everything in your way, or you can opt for a smaller, faster vehicle and use hit-and-run tactics to accomplish the mission objectives while evading enemy patrols, or anything in between those two extremes. If you opt to take the challenge of taking on missions with smaller, weaker vehicles the game will award you extra for it if you succeed, meaning that challenge runs that test your abilities are encouraged. The environment is a big part of your strategy no matter what - everything is destructible but not to the same extent, and part of the challenge is finding the spots in the landscape and enemy fortifications that your vehicle can easily barge through or blast through with its weapons without getting bogged down long enough for you to get swarmed by enemies.

The visuals in this are really impressive, with some of the most detailed 2D spritework that you're ever likely to see, complete with really detailed lighting. I'm not sure how they managed to get it to work the way they did but the effect is stunning. It only makes the total destructibility of the map even more impressive - even the rubble that gets left in the wake of your rampage is absurdly detailed. The various vehicles you can use mostly have some really unique designs, divided between three factions that each have their own design philosophies, and the weapons can get seriously visually impressive when you're blasting away with full firepower. Overall it's an insanely good looking game, whose cyberpunk-esque visuals enhanced by a fitting musical score that's equally as impressive.

The game's not heavy on story - you take up the role of various mercenaries being paid by a corporation to assist their regime change efforts on a colony planet called Solo Nobre in some place in the distant future, and there really isn't any more plot to it than that. The game is however quite heavy on lore that you can unlock as you play, and it's really well-written and fun to read, with entries dripping with dark humour. That's the tone of the whole game really, there are no good guys in the world, especially not you, the player. You actually get paid extra for collateral damage, even if that's running over a civilian in a tank or flattening an apartment block. I guess this game might not be for you if that sounds like it'd trouble you, but it's fine so long as you don't take the game too seriously, it clearly wasn't meant to be read that way.

Overall this a great game to just pick up and blow off some steam, you can finish most maps within a few minutes. There are campaign missions with set choices of vehicles to use that are good for learning how to play, but the main mode is the Freelance mode which lets you freely choose a combination of sequences of maps to play on and the vehicle loadout you'll challenge them with, with an additional choice of picking a pilot which adds some additional modifiers to your run. Apart from buying lore entries, you spend the money that you earn while playing to unlock more stuff for this mode, and there's quite a lot to get, although the game's generous enough with cash that it doesn't feel like a chore. At the end of the day this is an easy sell, it's easy to pick up and get into and accomplishes pretty much everything it set out to do without any major flaws to point out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986391796', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1594268992}
review:
It's...OK. The main thing I got from the $9 and 7 hours I spent trying to like this game was bored. Whether in the campaign or freelance mode, the gameplay was most often either far too easy or too hard; it's very difficult to find an appropriate challenge. That wouldn't be so bad if the combat itself were a lot of fun—but even when the challenge felt right, I didn't ever find it particularly engaging, and on top of all of that I spent more time wandering across the map tracking down objectives to blow up after defeating almost all the enemies on the map in the first minute or two. Overall this game was just very disappointing, and I spent too long trying to give it the credit it ultimately never earned to be able to refund my purchase.

If you're thinking about buying this game, consider just picking up the fantastic soundtrack albums by Makeup and Vanity Set, and listen to that while you play Synthetik: Legion Rising instead. That ought to scratch the itch this game wants to.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257119429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 5222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1657124307}
review:
20/11/27編集。
今の今になってようやく慣れてきました。
それでも低難易度キャラ（大体５まで）ぐらいでしかまともにクリアできませんが…

外周の壁以外の建物すべて破壊し尽せるゲーム。かと言って最強ロボットに乗り込んで破壊の限りを尽くす事ができるかと言えば別にそういう訳ではない。調子乗ってるとボコられるので注意。
二脚型・戦車型・ホバークラフト型の三つの種類から豊富なユニットを選び、二つの装備と一つのアビリティを組み合わせれるのだが、一部の武器の癖が強過ぎて慣れるのに一苦労。しかし使いこなせれればかなり便利な兵器になるのは間違いない。自分にとってこれが一番使いやすい！という武器を探し当てよう。

キャンペーンは機体も武器も固定で割とさっくり遊べる。
本番はフリーランス。フリーランスの出撃で稼いだ金で様々なキャラ、ユニット、武器、情報、ステージをアンロックしてまた出撃しての繰り返し。
キャラ（パイロット）は難易度と報酬に影響する。最初は難易度低いが徐々に高くなり、最初の難易度・上がる難易度が高い程高報酬が基本形だが、
最初から一定の難易度で固定するキャラも居れば、逆に最大難易度から始まって徐々に下がるキャラ、難易度最低どころか敵対ユニットが全くでないデストロイモードだけど報酬は１０％しかもらえないキャラ等、顔面含め個性溢れるキャラばかり。
お気に入りを見つけておけばモチベーションも上がるというもの。

外周以外すべて破壊できるものの、アビリティで破壊音波を選ばない限り、全部破壊は難しい。爆発する建物は近接攻撃で破壊すると自機に致命傷レベルのダメージを喰らう。目標建物だけでなく、ガソリンスタンド等の小物も爆発する事もある。戦車型だと移動＝近接攻撃になってるので迂闊に移動すると大惨事になる。
またＭＡＰが広く、チマチマ破壊してると単純に時間がかかる。
近接攻撃が強く重武装が出来るユニットは足が遅く、足が速いユニットは重武装を持てず近接攻撃も弱い。
どこを妥協するかによってプレイスタイルもある程度変えれる。建物破壊特化にしても良いしユニット撃破特化にしても良い。
低難易度はそこまで強いユニットがでないので建物破壊にある程度特化するとストレス発散になるよ！

爆発するとそこに敵が集まったり、レーダーユニットに捕捉されてサイレン鳴らされるとＭＡＰ中の敵が全員群がったりと、ステルスゲーム要素の側面も持つ。ご丁寧に武器の発射音の大きさも設定されてるので、難しいがステルスプレイも可能と言えば可能。

フリーランスで気軽に出撃できる為、結構長く遊べるタイプのゲーム。
設定もかなり凝っており、そういうのを調べるのだけでも結構楽しい。
興味がない人でもストレス発散用に如何でしょうか。

author: {'steamid': '76561198006990315', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3986, 'last_played': 1687586607}
review:
I like many people here bought this after mandalor's review.
And what can I say, its fucking awesome as hell.

I've been addicted to this game since i started playing it, I'm 200 mil from 100% this game and i've enjoyed every minute of it (well except when it crashed once during the closed casket special 3 hours in, but it only kept me away for a bit before I came back)

It was well worth the price of admission, the graphics are amazing and there's something very cathartic about destroying the entire map leaving nothing but rubble behind you and the carcasses of the enemy just to storm into the next township to do it all again.

I think about the only thing I would like to see added for the sequel would be a 2 player CO-OP function. Not a deal breaker here nor for the future release should it come out, but I can just see the carnage of two pilots going full erecto-destruction on an emplacement being the cherry on top of this remarkably fun excursion.

Two big thumbs up for me, was exactly what I needed and i can't wait to see what the developers have coming down the pipe next.

review:
Brigador is a special game. You can truly tell the developers love this project, and took the time too flesh out the universe and lore. I can't wrap my head around the visuals. These are by far the most stunning 2D graphics I've ever seen in a game. The lighting looks like it's in a real 3D environment, I just don't get how it works but the artist(s) for Brigador is a fucking savant. Gameplay is good, solid isometric tank-control action, although controls are completely customizable. 
My only knocks against it are I wish the roster of vehicles and weapons was bigger and the missions are, let's be honest, all the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970387591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1108, 'last_played': 1676306719}
review:
What a lovely little game this is. At first glance it's a Mech Rogue-like with a campaign, plenty of unlockable pilots, vehicles, weapons and missions, linked up with the endless replayability of the Freelance mode that allows you to set up short bursts of mayhem in single missions or campaign marathons. All this is true, but that doesn't do the game justice: There's interest in the background lore and the incidental text that wouldn't look out of place in a genuine MechWarrior title and there's a real sophistication to the combat, allowing for equally valid approaches if you prefer a stealthy, commando-like hit & run style, or whether you prefer to bludgeon your way through levels with overwhelming firepower. 

It's not the biggest or cleverest game you'll play in your life. It's not here to be thought-provoking. It's here to be fun, and my goodness... what a great job it does, too.

review:
This game is actually pretty great.

When I first booted it up I figured it was a standard top-down mech game. Just shoot everything and blow everything up. And it is that game but what I didn't count on was the sheer variety of playstyles it would support.

Be a tiny battlesuit, be a towering tower of cannons, be a floating tank. They all play different and they're all supported by the game. Throw in a great soundtrack, surprisingly in-depth world-building (if you want it) and fully destructible terrain and this is a really fun game.

review:
The isometric perspective combined with the control scheme and the fact that the levels constantly block and hinder your movement makes for a terrible experience. On top of that the targeting system is no help at all, being imprecise and further hindered by the perspective. Then there was that campaign mission where you are immediately beset by suicide units oneshotting you. Getting stuck with your mech, oneshot and then having to sit through the loading screen, that takes longer than the attempt, is not fun at all.
Enemy AI is dumb as a brick, the spotting mechanic feels inconsistent. 

All in all thumbs down.

review: VERY cool. If you like widespread destruction, you'll like this game. It also has an interesting, morally ambiguous story to dive into if you choose. I think it's a great speculative piece on the potential future of the "War Industrial Complex" and you may feel a little guilty about how much fun you're having. Even in a small isometric perspective this game does NOT shy away from depicting the terrible tragedies of war. I'll admit my heart sank a little when I realised I was driving a Tank through a suburb, and all the little people swarming on the street were actually terrified evacuees. The game is loads of fun and non-stop chaos, but if the player looks close enough, they can actually see the horror they have wrought...and I think that's just brilliant.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977901020', 'num_games_owned': 506, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1566, 'last_played': 1671159773}
review:
I enjoy this game a lot. Combat in general has a lot of "weight" to it.

 The visuals and lighting are amazing. They paint a wonderful scene when there's rounds flying through the air, citizens disintegrating into giblets, lasers crackling across the street, treadbikes whirring by under a hail of cannon fire, buildings being shattered into a million little pieces, and a horde of war machines closing in on you. 

In the quieter moments, it's easier to appreciate just how detailed everything is, and how the "theme" of each area is carried across. In the denser urban areas, you have tons of buildings crammed together with gas stations and convenience stores around every corner. The "upper crust" areas by contrast are dominated by wide-open spaces, strangely pervasive golf courses, and single mansions that are as big as, if not bigger than, the apartment blocks you blow apart in other areas. There's also a bunch of more industrial areas, and even some maps that have you running around out in the boonies stomping through shanty towns. The difference in architecture, layout, and terrain in these areas is complimented by different colors and intensities of lighting in each area as well, dependent upon what kind of lighting you'd normally expect to see in such a place. The densely crowded urban areas, for example, have street lamps everywhere.

The visual effects of firing the weapons also have an impressive amount of detail put into them as well. Weapons of similar class and size will still have different "projectiles" on screen. The best demonstration of this would be the laser weapons. Just look at the Black Hand compared to any of the other laser weapons. 

The vehicle designs deserve their own review entirely. I'll keep it short and just say that the three different factions each have a unique and well-realized style. And the detail with which they're represented makes all of them feel very real.  This takes on a whole other dimension if you read the novel tied into this game, which I would recommend if you're into any kind of military sci-fi.

The music in this game is good enough to justify the vinyl release of the soundtrack by Makeup and Vanity Set. It fits the atmosphere of the cityscapes and in an odd way, the cold brutality of the gameplay perfectly.

I'd be silly not to mention that the weapons by and large have a good, satisfying report when fired. Again, there's been enough attention paid to keep them detailed and distinct from each other. And the sounds do a wonderful job of suggesting the relevant level of carnage caused by each weapon all on their own. Just fire the Banshee with your eyes closed and try to imagine anything else but the complete obliteration that follows it.

Finally, most importantly, the gameplay. It's good. It can be repetitive, if you let it, but Brigador's biggest strength is probably in experimentation. I've spent much more time in freelance than in the campaign (which I have yet to finish). With the freelance mode, you control the difficulty, your loadout, and the locales. There's such a wide variety in the first two options that you can end up playing a very different game from one run to the next. Play a low or medium difficulty with an ultra class vehicle outfitted with some heavy ordinance, and you'll have an autopilot power-trip of sheer destruction. Play on a higher difficulty in a mog (powersuit), and it's suddenly a stealth game. A stealth game that benefits heavily from the destructible terrain, allowing you to ambush one group of enemies from behind, before they've had a chance to raise their shields, then carve a path through a block of office buildings to get away before their friends arrive to investigate the noise. 

In the right circumstances, all of these elements can synchronize to achieve something in Brigador that generally is only achieved by sim games. It can give you some of that "weightiness" of actually trying to pilot one of these vehicles. It makes it feel about as real as what an honestly, fairly arcadey game can.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982576274', 'num_games_owned': 1302, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1618617476}
review:
So, much like everyone else, thanks to Mandalore to point me to this game.
It's great fun. Being a walking, shooting mobile war-crime machine is a really good stress reliever, and the game can be pretty much as hard as you want it to be - You can have a nice, easy ride, at the helm of a treehouse on threads that fire enough corrosive grenades in one shot to melt, almost literally, an entire street in 2 seconds flat, piloted by a nobody with some talent and nothing to lose, oooor you can go with a small but fragile machine favoring stealth and guerilla tactics, manned by a mercenary so dreaded the sheer [i]possibility[/i] that he might be coming to the district is enough to send an entire platoon on high alert. It's all highly customizable. Of course, the more difficult you make it out, the more cash you earn in the end.

Basically, the campaign is an introduction to the game and gives you some predetermined loadouts, as well as a big wad of money, to play with in preparation for the Freelancer mode. I'm still going through it right now, I'll be honest.

There's a lot to like here. The lore is very extensive, with even an audiobook on separated purchase. The music, by Make-up and Vanity Set, is phenomenal. The visuals are really nice too. While the controls - in Relative mode at least - are taking some time to get used to, once you DO get used to it, it's very fun.

And there is also this nice, cozy satisfaction to urge every once in a while in wanton destruction of everyone and everything in sight. It IS a Cyberpunk universe after all. You're not playing as the good guys here, just another mercenary contracted to wreck stuff up. Embrace it, and go ham.

If you want a more in-depth review, check out Mandaloregaming's video on the game. I bought it because of him and it was money very well spent.

THE GREAT LEADER IS DEAD.
SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL.
WELCOME, BRIGADOR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092438906', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1472, 'last_played': 1696188227}
review:
TLDR: A fantastic tactical game with overwhelming amounts of content for its price.

My first review on Brigador was a part of the Mandalore review boom and didn't have a loot to say on the actual game, except for the sheer amazement I have felt when playing this game ffor the first time. 
Hower, not that the novelty has worn off, I would still recommend it to both anyone interested in a stress-relief piece of entartainment and someone who enjoys a game with a lot of depth besides the surprisingly decent combat system. 

--------- The Combat ----------
I think that this is the first and most impportant subject to touch when speaking about Brigador. The thing is that, despite playing a lot like a top-down shooter, the game feels a lot like a CRPG in real time with a single powerful unit as a fine substitute for a whole team. This is first and foremost a mech game and even though some targets will definitely test your aiming skills (Smaller enemy Agravs require precise aiming to bring down, while moving the fastest and most of your weaponry being projectiles), the most powerful threats are actually really hard to miss. 
Therefore most of fights, while being quick and unforgiving, are mostly decided by your usage of the many different options your warmachine possesses. Moving or hunkering down as a mech, manipulating your surroundings through the sheer destructive power of a stomp or a ram of tanks, the versatile movement options of agravs, and those are just the basics they teach you first in the tutorial mission. In Brigador the battlefield is up for you to change, carefully managing time in a fight or sound outside of it. 
Everything besices the map bondaries is there for either cover or destruction and combat changes drastically between open areas and city streets. 

--------- The Variety ----------
There are a lot of enemy types and a lot of ways to make them go away. In Brigador you have two weapon mounts on a big roaster of different machines and certain weapon classes, ranging from SML as the smallest to HVY as the biggest. There are a lot of quirky ones in all the classes and even some of the most standard have enough flavor for you to unerstand the enemy arsenal in a chaotic fight. Your layout of weapons, the powerful additional equipment,  the class of the machine, the surroundings and the specific enemies you face all force you into building strategies and making quick tactical choices. 
The enemies cannot be described solely based on their faction as all of them have their own flawor of weaponry and machines, however in broad strokes the Loyalists are sporting the best long range weaponry, the Corvids are the quickest and the Spacers will force you to move out of your cover with devastating close raange capabilities and artillery. Specifically the Harvester cluster shells, which are absolutely terrifying (you can equip one, btw). Yet, all of them have units that can do other things but the faction-specific stuff. Like the Ratking of Corvids is slow and fires twin autocannons with a cyclic rate of GAU-8 (basically, clouds of big fucking shells) or railgun tanks of Spacers that have one of the rare long range hitscan weapons. 
To finish up this point, I'm sure that there is more than enough content to keep you going. 

---------- The Lore ------------
I was amazed at the amount of lore this game has and I still am. A half of the game's Aquisitions section is just lore, a lot of flavor and some pretty meaningful stuff. And most of it is just 100k ingame dollars, which is seriously not even a price in Brigador.
More than that, in Steam you can get yourself both the soundtrack (it's seriously good, RUINER tier good) and a Brigador Audiobook. Surprisingly, the book is fucking amazing and really makes you a fan of this brutal universe if you were not already. It's a deep story about struggling to follow ideologies in the face of overwhelming violence, the primal lust for power and even sporting some serious fear of the unknown (not fear per se, but an uncanny feeling of someone else, someone powerful and incomprehensable coming to your home to burn it to the ground). 
It kinda elevates Brigador above most of the other mech games for me. 

----------- The Conclusion ------------
The game had a bad launch but its a hidden gem. A polished, shining but hidden among countless other games that might appear simular but could never compare to Brigador. And at least here in Russia it has a really modest price for hours and hours of content you'll be getting. 
This quickly became one of my favourite games and it is simply awesome.

review:
[h1]Brigador | Reject Interplanetary Geneva Convention™️ | Embrace SNC Backed Regime Change™️[/h1]

Hey hey people, Eugenius here.

Today we're gonna be reviewing Brigador — a cult classic released [strike]by Westwood studios in 1996. I once enjoyed it as a child, and now i return to it as a machild[/strike] wrong script, it was released by Stellar Jockeys four years ago actually. Anyway,

[b]STORY:[/b]
The game takes place on Solo Nobre — a mining colony on a remote planet of Novo Solo. Many years ago local [i]ancien regime[/i] of trans-planetary corporations was overthrown in violent [i]coup d'etat[/i] by the Great Leader. Following these events, a global state planned economy was established in a Great Leader's effort to build well-defended socialism on single planet. His iron fisted rule, however, was not exactly well received by large swaths of population, leading society to split in two factions immediately after his death. These are:
— Loyalists – devouted stalinists belonging to NEP party and striving to maintain political legacy of Great Leader, and
— Corvids – followers of Mikhail Bakunin, who despise state, vanguardism, proletarian dictatorship and central banks

Their internal struggle is quickly joined by SNC — [i]independent[/i] think-tank promoting neoclassic economic thought and return of rightful corporate overlords on Novo Solo. And SNC wants you to perform dirty work for them, offering you brigador contract. This is not a joke by the way, they wrote an actual corporate document that can be accessed in-game. Take a look at this excerpt:

[i]...
ARTICLE 5: OBLIGATIONS OF COMPANY
5.01. Company agrees to assume no liability for any Contractor actions, damages inflicted by Contractor, or damages inflicted upon Contractor (both physical and emotional) in pursuing the Agreement.
5.02. Company will comply with all reasonable requests of Contractor necessary to the performance of Contractor's duties under this Agreement levied prior to Contractor deployment.
5.03. Company agrees to sever all contact with and deny all knowledge of Contractor pursuant Contractor engaging in actions identifiable in any way as being in connection with the Company.
...[/i]

Under its terms SNC promises to deliver vehicles, weapons and other equipment, as well as shield you from any legal liability, while asking you to return "Asset" (with "Asset" being "entire Novo Solo planet") back to their hands by launching several military operations against local groups. With that you begin.

[b]GAMEPLAY:[/b]
It is very good. The game drops you to the battlefield, giving objective to destroy certain targets. It will take you a minute or less, however, to realise that every single thing you see is destructible. And in corporate world destruction of hostile means of production somehow means profit coming your way. A lot of profit. And you will spend every dollar to unlock new equipment. Which is great by the way — every single vehicle comes with three slots allowing you to install various weapons ranging from machineguns... that can't even hit a target at close range... to absolutely disgusting cluster bombs. Vehicle roster gives you a wide selection of:
— Walkers – slow, easy to hit, tanky, and
— Anything else... I... haven't actually played game for this long, i think you would have to check it yourself.

These can be used not only by you, but also by numerous opponents, who will try to find and swarm you from several directions using some sick squad AI. While easy to [i]debate[/i] with at first glance, they will get bigger [i]arguments[/i] on later levels, allowing them to DESTROY your position and thus undermine civil discourse on Novo Solo even further. That is unless you are prepared to stay out of their line of sight, launch surprise attacks and use smoke grenades to hide your presence.

And if vehicles are [b]somehow[/b] not enough for your taste, you get pilots. Just take a good look at them... Yes, they look exactly like they just came out from serving prison sentence for aggravated crimes against humanity.

Flexible controls (which you should immediately change to "Relative") allow you to easily maneuver through the battlefield. With some easy-to-do micro you can even dodge hostile shots. Shooting, however, requires high precision — while it's not obvious upon first sight, the space you are playing in is 3D, and projectiles are launched [b]exactly[/b] from the point of the gun, giving you [i]fun[/i] ability to miss the target you were specifically aiming at due to your weapon being offset from central axis of your turret, and then to die to utter nonsense. 

[b]GRAPHICS:[/b]
To put it simply, it's great. That's it. What else do you expect, it's not a script of an actual merchant video review. You have trailer above, you saw it right? If you want more, go to Youtube. I believe one popular channel had a good review on it. Its name was something related to star wars. Maybe GunganGaming, if i recall correctly.

[b]SCORE:[/b]
Despite barely playing it, I give this game a final objective score of
[b]Precursor James' acquisition cost out of Bonesaw's chance to hit infantry[/b]

Thoroughly recommended. Go play it. I certainly will.

This review [b]was not[/b] bankrolled by Brigador Promotion Guild. While most unfortunate, it means, however, that its objectivity and total lack of bias are guaranteed. More content to come, so stay tuned. You're all truly wonderful. Have a good one!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001322825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1705332908}
review:
Put some hours in and I'm pretty smitten at this point. The vehicles just feel amazing. The mobility is responsive & agile.  I'd strongly recommend switching the default Absolute settings to Relative as it grants far more fidelity in control. Took me a good hour to wrap my head around, but it was worth it once it clicked.

Environmental destructiblity is super-impressive. Last time I remember having this much fun just leveling everything was years and years ago in Red Faction: Guerilla. It's super satisfying and also nets you bonus cash on Mission Debrief.

Music is pretty glorious if you have an appreciation for thick, heavy synth. Varies in tone from background to pumping and I'm really glad I got the soundtrack edition. Catchy stuff. Lore is pretty dense too. Mostly comes in the form of a Codex that you pay to unlock piecemeal. Strange but the prices are fair and I'd venture that it obliges the player to invest in reading the material as you're paying for it with the money you earn. Very well written.

But that seems like how the game's economy works on a broader scale. You pay to unlock pilots, vehicles, Freelance missions, etc. Seems intelligently integrated as a system overall in that it always keeps bread-crumbing you along with fresh new unlocks.

So all in all it feels like a really comprehensive package that's put together with care. Gameplay feels great with an awesome audio/visual suite and all the trimmings feel smartly integrated. Big ups.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094707710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1593946492}
review:
Against the backdrop of neon lights and purple skies,
you stumble out of the flash from the pilot requisition
which brings you to a tron-like loading area with other
pilots waiting. Three classes of vehicles to select are
in front of you, the gigantic bipedal machine has its pilot 
hatch open, beckoning you to a revolutionary war of
mechs, ladies, and 1980s.

[b] BRIGADOR - UP-ARMORED EDITION.[/b]

Synth background music pulses quietly at first, tracking
with your every move as you navigate the loadouts
and equip your war machine- be it towering mech, a
no-nonsense battletank or a hastily-converted civilian
hovercar which prioritizes speed over armor- with the
top-off-the-shelf weaponry of this near-future city. 

Where it may be taking place is irrelevant- know that
[b]Great Leader[/b] is dead, and [b]Solo Nobre[/b] must fall. You are
welcomed as a [b]Brigador[/b], a tireless warrior who will help
ignite the spark of revolution in this merciless city of the
future, gripped in tyranny by the would-be heirs of the
Great Leader.

So you tighten the controls after you've come from the
travels that have brought you here to Solo Nobre. As
the machine marches to life and engages enemy forces
in battle, you are encouraged to level anything and
everything in your path- buildings, scaffolding, trees
and replenishing ammo depots are not safe from your
rampage in the name of revolution. 

The retro-inspired pixel tapestry of the city blurs
as you escalate after switching out pilots and weapon
loadouts to better suit your mission of righteous civil 
disobedience. You hope that all this will come to an end, 
but you know the soundtrack only stops when either the 
opposing force or you are dead, where until then, Miami 
and instrumental power ballads will carry you to the very
gates of bullet-riddled Valhalla to see her. 

The woman you loved solar systems away, whom you 
failed to protect. You've been a spacer and gone to 
worlds beyond imagining, beyond death, and now you 
fight a war you cannot hope to win as odds stack higher,
the credits payout too impossible to ignore. The risk of
death grows with each mission, and the thrill of falling,
of forgetting your failure that led you to Solo Nobre is
too good of a kick the war machine cannot even buck.

The levels grind and churn you through a gauntlet of
ruthless metal and blood. It is a hermit-kingdom city,
this Solo Nobre; where a man's life is worth 50 credits
but a flower bed's destruction is worth twice as much.
With every instance of mayhem, you are a step closer
to fulfilling your respective contracts for benefactors
which reward you with varying payouts, perpetuating
the seemingly endless cycle of money, weapons, the
need to upgrade and the endless head-bopping action
of the retro synth music of the 1980s.

Your hands shudder as they struggle to let go of the
pilot controls, but the [b]Precursor James[/b] - a mythical 
figure who is rumored to be an undead pilot, beckons
you to battle again. The revolution requires a rallying
point, the tip of the spear, the spark of sacrifice.

[i]"On this day, we need you, Brigador."[/i]

You grit your teeth and fight the pain of emptiness
away, trying to block out futile memories of her
love never meant to be. [i]"Summer. Samara-"[/i] You
begin, but the pilots call out over comms chatter
before static cuts in, and Precursor James removes
his mask and says the words that signal your return
to the fight. As you hear these familiar words that
has become the unspoken mantra, you know the
spaceport and that ticket offworld can wait.

[i]"Great Leader is dead. 

Solo Nobre must fall.

Welcome, Brigador."[/i]

[b]BRIGADOR - UP-ARMORED EDITION.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198000326220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 1353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 949, 'last_played': 1593898168}
review:
A rich game about poor mercs, eager to share its wealth of variety and vision to anyone willing to take the contract.

PROS:
- Tons of meaningful customization. Pick vehicle, weapons, tac gear, difficulty, operation length.
- Exceptional creativity with loadouts. Mix of conventional and unique weapon systems.
- Tons of gameplay options. Loud/Quiet. Fast/Heavy. Long/Short, Low/High Risk, etc.
- Gorgeous level design and layouts.
- Deep, well written lore.
- Thumping, yet somber electronic soundtrack sets tone beautifully.
- Little touches breathe life into setting (Unique vehicle horns. Vehicle facing affects shield efficiency. High RoF weapons can slow your vehicle down while firing, etc).

ONLY CON:
- Can't save operation progress. For long ops, if you don't have the time, can't commit war crimes.

NITPICKs:
- AI fairly basic. Missed opportunity to have them approach situations tactically.
- Campaign little more than tutorial. Could have drip fed more lore.
- Default control scheme works against you, but can easily be switched (facing matters).

Recommend To:
- Fans of mech games.
- Fans of isometric action games.
- Fans of gritty war fiction.
- Anyone looking for an immersive, tactical experience that requires planning, adaptation, and the willingness to leave a Steam game running in the background when life calls.

review:
This game is a hell of a good time. It scratches the itch for slaughtering underlings with massive cannons in just about all of the right places, those being the vulnerable rear-ends of Tanks.

It's got a pretty good campaign, but what really stood out to me about this game is just how much Content it has. It's got so many Lore/Intel pages it's insane, and the sheer quantity of equipment and Stuff To Buy gives this game a spark it probably wouldn't have otherwise. It also has great sound quality, though some of the tunes get repetitive rather quickly.

So yeah, great buy, and it feels like how some of the Mechwarrior game should have felt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046056498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1681951507}
review:
Do you like violence? Of course you do. If you didn't, you wouldn't be here. It's a part of you. You, like me, crave the sweet smell of gunpowder and the thunder of distant explosions. Brigador delivers. 

The core mechanics are simple. You move with WASD, you left or right click to kill things. Easy. However, despite there only ever being two weapon slots, there are over a hundred combinations of weapons before even getting into the dozens of mechs, anti-grav vehicles, and tanks. 

The soundtrack is good. The graphics are good. Killing is good. In other games, when you 'accidentally' kill a civilian, you lose cash, reputation, or game over. Not so in Brigador. Civilians, like everything else inside the district walls of Nova Sobre, are fair game. Everything is destructable, and on Nova Solo, destruction pays.

This game delivers the perfect blend of simplicity, customization, and replayability. 

So, Brigador. Great Leader has died. Nova Sobre must fall. Time to earn your pay - or die trying.

review:
A beautiful and atmospheric game with great music. Also it's actually a good GAME, so the gameplay is fun and tactical, while the progression is really good. The campaign is pretty fun but it's more of a large tutorial so you can figure out what vehicles, weapons, and characters you like. Also, try out the siege mortar for the tank or mech vehicles. I don't ever want to let go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006832794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1595699677}
review:
If you love mechs and mayhem, this game is for you. Being able to fire a laser chain gun from a van strapped to the top of a tank is pretty enjoyable. Or maybe you want to drive a power lifter with chainguns to take down mechs five stories tall? You can do that. The game has a decent campaign mode to get you comfortable, but it really shines in freelance mode where you get to use a custom loadout to play through several maps.

You also get a pretty cool hard sci fi story in the deluxe edition.

The devs poured a ton of love into this game, and it's well worth the price of admission!

author: {'steamid': '76561198136419945', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2099, 'last_played': 1710275169}
review:
While Brigador has a campaign, its main game mode is Freelance - a roguelike-style set of randomized missions that allow you to create your own loadouts.

That customization gives the game its replayability; massive tanks like the Treehouse let you play more directly, crushing houses and unloading tremendous weapons. In contrast, smaller, faster vehicles like the Rope Kid are less destructive, meaning the maps start to become more hazardous - walls matter a lot more when you can't drive through them.

While the game always has slight stealth mechanics (lookout enemies that trigger alarms, increased damage to the back of enemies), these can be made much more vital with some loadouts, like slow, fragile powersuits. These runs reward subtlety and sudden, incapacitating strikes, with the destruction system used more as a way to create escape routes than as a way to cause damage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015039238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1602561378}
review:
I'll start this review off a bit different. Note: As I wrote this review, I couldn't help but hear the words coming out of my brain onto the keyboard with the voice of 21Kilotons minus his colorful expletive prowess for obvious -want to make sure this review gets post- reasons. If the flow seems a bit weird, I recommend you apply his voice to this review in parts, especially towards the end.

Don't Buy If:[list]You're looking for an uninspired rehash twin stick shooter, it is not. Nor was it officially advertised as such IIRC.[*]You are looking for a MechWarrior clone.[*]If you're looking for a Binding of Isaac clone *gag*.[*]If originality is a hobgoblin to your mind.[*]If you don't want an excellent game that's got complex, but natural controls that have a learning curve.[/list]

Do Buy If: [list][*]You want a destroy everything but don't be reckless or you're dead simulator.[*]You understand that this isn't a twin stick shooter despite the devs having to tweak the settings to allow it to play a bit like one to appease those who automatically assumed it'd be another twin stick shooter skin.[*]You want to play a game that's very unforgiving, but is an excellent challenge and feels very rewarding.[*]You want an original game that's difficult to draw comparisons to as it's just that... ORIGINAL.[*]If you like real time tactics and can appreciate the achieved technical ingenuity behind the game's many excellent mechanics. Want to go into a mission shooting everything in sight? Be prepared to alert every enemy in a wide area to your location and expect to have according difficulties with a relentless AI that can hear your shots, can competently track you once spotted, and invariably cause your demise as, in this game, even tanks can be lethal (as they should be). [/list]

TBH, there's a bit of sarcasm & :steamsalty: above, not because of the game itself, but because of how it bombed on launch due to no actual issue of its own. A lot of people bought it thinking "Oh! Another twinstick shooter in a market over-saturated with twinstick shooters!" and bought the game. Tried playing it and then realized it wasn't only to refund the game due to "horrible controls". If by horrible controls one says so because the original defaults were meant to play like the original game it is and NOT a twinstick shooter, well, that's not the games fault. This isn't to say that the controls don't need getting used to, they do, however, that's a part of the game itself, anyone who has play a MechWarrior game might understand how much precision can be gained by incorporating controls that allow torso swivel on mech and, though as stated previously, this isn't a MechWarrior clone, someone who comes from that franchise might find it easier to adapt to this game a bit easier. That said. I feel bad for the devs whose labor of passion bombed due to misconstrued assumptions that were opposite to the concept they crafted. It's a damn good game and you can tell that once you boot it up.

There are, I think, about 60 different vessels of destruction you can play with in the game. Though the game is isometric 2D, the models are beautiful and have extremely fluid animations no matter which way you turn. Everything yells from the mountains in a thunderous voice "This was hand crafted and not an asset flip!". The use of lighting is phenomenal, and I think it's the most beautiful in darker missions where you can really respect the detail of neon signs making an area glow, the dark corners where it's difficult to see lest you've a light of some sort on the rig you're running. I don't believe that level of detail I've seen elsewhere except maybe ShadowRun? Yet, that's separate game completely. Aesthetically everything just Todd Howards (read: Just works). I've encountered no glitches and even though it's 2D iso, I've quickly found myself immersed in this universe. I've heard comparisons to Hotlline Miami. I personally fail to see the comparisons, in fact, having play both, I see the only commonality between the two is in terms of you're rewarded to kill everything on your screen. Run over a civilian? Here's $50, level a housing district? Here's $2k. Unlike Hotline Miami, you're rewarded most, by finishing objectives and, if you're dead set on destroying everything, it's best to wait until you snipe everything on the map that could harm you because, trust you, YOU DON'T WANT all the units on the board swarming you. Okay, maybe there is another parallel to Hotline Miami, in the way that everyone has that 3rd cousin who hits the bottle, parties, soils their pants and drools there way through the first year of college only to drop out and work at burger king because the other cook is their dealer and it's more convenient to buy your drugs there since you can blow your paycheck on the spot conveniently so you can go get your fix right away. I'd warrant everyone also has that one cousin that saw the drooler and realized that's something they DIDN'T want to be, so they buckled down, got 3 Associates 1 Bachelors degrees. Realized those degrees are now worth toilet paper, so they took a job they didn't like whilst working on their passion project and released it only to see the friends of the drooler buy copies of their passion only to use it for toilet paper, so, like they're degree, that educated cousin realized, they'd have to clean the turds the droolers left on their project and work harder to further refine their formula despite it being perfect regardless the human excrement removed.

I understand that such a review as above is very terse :steamsalt:, however, I feel it necessary to sort of indicate the difference between the drooler (Hotline) & the educated cousin (Brigador). Don't like my comparison? Me neither, however, if you're so inclined to directly compare both the games, there's your analogy. If you like Hotline Miami. Buy Hotline Miami. If you want a hotline Miami-esque game, consider one of the true gems that ara 10tons ltd twin stick shooters that are, imo, superior in every way. Want a game that's good, has excellent gameplay, graphics and an amazing cyberpunk aesthetic & soundtrack? Give Brigador a go. I fail to see how you'd be disappointed. Me? I love the game and am glad I took the time to get used to the controls, which, after doing so, I realized how the game NEEDED the tank controls and how SEAMLESS it is once you get used to them. 

10/10 Too broke to buy it again, but would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066507844', 'num_games_owned': 644, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1594731569}
review:
First things first:

[h1]Set your movement as Reverse Inverted Relative. Makes the mech drive like a car, much better[/h1]

So, yeah, I'm here as a part of Mandalore's boost, but this game is absolutely amazing, and seeing the love the developers put into it already at first glance, I can tell i'll have a lot of fun with this one.

Besides, I'm brazilian, and seeing that one of the Pilot's name was "Clotilde" acctually made me laugh out loud. I kept imagining the Witch of the 71st apt. driving a mech. Hail to you if you know Chaves (Chavo del Ocho). Seeing spanish-portuguese terms being thrown around correctly made me feel really f*cking good.

This review will be updated upon further gameplay, but for now, just know this game left an amazing first impression on me.

review:
A mix of Nuclear Strike, Geometry Wars and Commandos with mechs and tanks, an incredible soundtrack and 80s neon lighting that reminds me of Tiberian Sun.
Play as a towering war machine destroying whole city blocks with a single shot or as a sneaky suit of power armor carefully picking your targets and retreating into cover after a successful attack or anything in between.
I needed a little bit of time to get used to the controls and the different playstyles, weapons and tactics. 
But after figuring this out Brigador offers some surprising depth and great replayability.
If you like mechs, tactical gameplay, explosions and games that punish your mistakes Brigador will not disappoint.

review:
Brigador is a fun action game with big robots. 

It has massive amounts of customisability when it comes to weapons so you can suit your playstyle. If you don't like mechs, how about tanks? Feel like they're too slow? Grab an anti-grav vehicle and zoom around the map circle strafing to your heart's content.

If you like fun, and you like action games that also make you think about tactics and the environment, don't go past this one.

Here is your contract, Brigador...

author: {'steamid': '76561197971954092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1593492932}
review:
Not an action game, a stealth game. You trudge around in a giant robot mostly concerned with alarm bots spotting you because you die super quick. You use active camo and smoke screens to slink away and opportunistically take pot shots at tanks far larger then yours. You can buy tanks and guns and pilots and can't use them in the campaign. Several missions start you with zero ammunition and force you to sneak past robots (as a giant robot so large you are able to knock over buildings by walking into them, yet you need to SNEAK and only a few mechs actually make noise somehow!) until you finally find ammo, then turn around and slowly snipe your way back to where you came from. The game has no time limit, so you just wait and wait for good times to engage or creep away. 

When I think of giant tanks I don't think of sneaking missions or procuring supplies on site, but here we are, and that's what you do in this game.
