author: {'steamid': '76561198034026335', 'num_games_owned': 953, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 5077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1693409958}
review:
[h1] Great Leader is dead [/h1]
[h1] Solo Nobre must fall [/h1]

[b] Brigador [/b] is an isometric tactical mech game - many people assumed from the trailer that it was a twin stick shooter, and the standard controls reflects this, but that's simply not how it's designed and balanced. I would recommend you go into the settings and switch the control scheme to Relative, for the proper tank controls the game was made for. Movement [i] will [/i] take time to get used to, but once you've tuned your brain to the right frequency it controls like an absolute dream.

In [b] Brigador [/b], you are a pilot of a mech, tank, or anti-gravity vehicle. In each mission you are deployed to a district of the city of Solo Nobre with the goal of destroying anti-orbital cannons, killing enemies, and wreaking general havoc. It's a great stress relief game, since the variety of vehicles, pilots, weapons, and missions allow you to fine tune the difficulty to your liking, anywhere from "Uncontested destruction of a gated community" to "All out assault on a fully manned military base".

With every mission you gain money, which you can use to unlock more of the aforementioned vehicles, pilots, weapons, and missions, as well as lore and intel on enemies. I know it may sound like a horrible grind, but I promise it's not - the balance is very well done to keep you feeling like you're constantly making progress.

[b] Brigador [/b] flopped [i] hard [/i] on release, but it's a genuinely fantastic game that's had years of post-release love and support poured into it, and a sequel is in production. If you have any interest at all, please purchase this game to support its future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068370015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1653516386}
review:
Isometric blast-a-thon set to synthwave. Pilot mechs, tanks, and flying vehicles and care not a bit for collateral damage. In fact, your Brigadors get paid to trash the place; you're definitely not the good guy here.

The gameplay is simple at its foundation but solid and with lots of content layered on top of it. The campaign is fully fledged, but you'll find yourself hopping over to the freelance mode with your earnings to experience the crazy freedom it allows you. A campaign mission generally gives you a set choice of a few mechs, which offer different strategies for passing that particular mission. A freelance mission lets you mix and match whatever combination of pilot, mech, guns and systems you want. You can be a towering colossus of mechanoid death dealing or a pickup truck with a gun bolted on the back and face the same mission in totally different ways.  You're rewarded for making the mission more difficult with higher payouts, which can be used to unlock even more options for future missions. 

This game is worth the dirt cheap asking price, and if you're the sort of person that appreciates a pick up and play sort of game, this will be one you come back to over and over to kill twenty minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063202514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1687740770}
review:
Brigardor is probably one of the best audio-visual experiences I've ever had. The art is beautiful, the animations are amazingly smooth, and it has maybe the best sprite work I've ever seen in a game. And the music, by god the music. If you have any interest in electronic music do yourself a favor and spend extra for the soundtrack, you really wont regret it. Tying this all together is an extremely fun and "edge of your seat" mech game that's equal parts pants shitting and rewarding.

This game not blowing up may have been the biggest sham of 2016, which is really saying something for the year that it came out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992162983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1636572330}
review:
The game finally got what it deserved - overwhelmingly positive reviews!

And yes - it is totally worth it. The game is a rare gem, everything it is made with love and dedication. 

You are a brigador. Basically a mercenary. You have your job, a ton of vehicles at your disposal, a ton of different (and i really mean it - different) pilots, weapons, a mission goal. Wonderful hand-crafted graphics, fully destructible everything, mind-bending new-retro-wave 80's vibe soundtrack, crazily well-thought throug lore bits... Whate the hell else do you need? Go blasting!

This is not an arcade shooter though, even if it looks like one on screenshots. Well, with some loadouts it can almost be played like one, but there is so much tactical depth in the game it is incredible. Takes some time to master but all in all it is incredibly fun.

And it brings some nostalgia about anciend Strike series on Sega too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034218094', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1593419692}

review:
It is 12:15 AM. I felt like playing a few missions after work, and now it's 12:15 am, and I've gotta say... Well worth it. The game is fun; good combination of tank and mouse controls adds a nice weight to the mechs and tanks, while the antigrav vehicles glide smoothly and cleanly. Weapons are satisfying, tho accuracy takes a bit to get used to, as while the game is isometric there is a level of height to be aware of while rampaging. Apart from that tho, I've really been enjoying this game, and I hope I can wrack up some more hours soon. 

Seriously, this seems like a good one for relaxing after an 8 hour shift. Very cathartic destruction, excellent visuals, stunning electronic soundtrack. 9/10 easy.

review: A criminally underrated 2-D tactical shooter in the vein of the Strike games from the SNES and Genesis era. review:
This game is sick. Its an isometric tactical shooter with a ton of vehicles and weapons. There's so many options, it would be hard to imagine somebody not finding several builds they liked. This game was tragically overlooked by so many people, including myself. Great game to drop in and blow some stuff up to blow off some steam or kill some time. 
The companion audiobook is great too. It gives you even more of the already great lore they have here.

review:
I feel like an asshole, but this reviw is here for people who search for problems with games.

Context: A YouTuber had this upvote bombed while describing it as a near perfect game. My assessment is more 'meh'; regardless there are criticisms that should be brought up.

This game goes HARD on the simulation. Powered down units blend into the background. Enemy soldiers are hard to make out on a glance. Determining weapon range is difficult on the fly. There is also terrain height which can result in a grenade blowing up in your face. Not to mention the controls; these vehicles have handling relative to their type.

The takeaway; this is not the flashy twin stick it appears to be. This is a tactics simulation. Almost a Mech Commander game without the controls or UI. I want to tell you it's good, but the truth is it's niche.

review:
I'm part of the Mandalore wave who saw his video and came over to try it.

The game is good at what it is, a tactical real-time mech shooter. If you've played a Mechwarrior game you'll probably like this as the way you control your mech (at least using the real control option) is similar: forward moves you in the direction your legs are facing, your upper body rotates freely for shooting and flanking has big advantages.

There is a good choice of weapons to use and try out. Every mech/tank/hover tank has 2 weapon and the different combinations do change things up. Making a walking war-crime machine is super fun :D

After playing a couple of hours you will see pretty much all the main elements to the game, but that's ok, cause those elements work really well. Variety comes in the freelance missions with trying out all the different possible combinations of mechs/tanks/hover tanks and weapons and you can honestly spend a long time playing it over and over with different setups.

There's a story here you can ignore, but if you want to get into it there is a huge amount of lore and intel you can unlock in the game. Pretty good job at world build for a small team.

Music is godly. You can just put this game on in the background and chill.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025738669', 'num_games_owned': 719, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1666633914}
review:
[b]A good review can sell a game.[/b] I mean, after I saw Mandalore's video on Brigador, I immediately bought the game on Steam. I very rarely do such things, but I don't regret my decision.

As Mandalore said, this game resembles Red Alert 2 (in terms of graphics and SFX). I always liked the missions where you must control a small number of units, and Brigador kind of reminds me of those missions.

[b]Main pros:[/b]

- Excellent sprites. A lot of variation and details on the maps. 
- Everything is destructible.
- A lot of weird mechas, antigravs, tanks, you name it. A lot of stuff to drive and to destroy.
- In campaign you can choose between various types of vehicles. This can alter your playstyle. E.g. if you pick a sturdy tank, you can just go on a destruction derby without ever holding back. And if you pick a small mech with camouflage, but very little HP and shields, you can basically play a stealth mission, trying to avoid the spotters and baiting the enemies in small quantities.
- Pretty neat soundtrack.
- Replayability. You can complete campaign missions with every type of transport + there is a freelance mode with tons of maps and customisation. It's somewhat like skirmishes in RA2.

The only "con" for me is that it takes some time to get used to the controls (there are alternative modes for them in the options menu, so be sure to check them out).

Other than that, it's a pretty solid game. Mindless fun or somewhat tactical approach - you decide. Really nice piece of nostalgia, but at the same time it doesn't feel ancient.

P.S. Played with keyboard+mouse.

review: Brigador has everything you could possibly want from a mech game of its type: cathartic gameplay, a great soundtrack, and an enticing story. My only complaint is that there isn't more. Stellar Jockeys' Hugh Monahan mentioned in his talk at GDC 2017 how they designed the game around a kitbash style, and that's clearly evident. The mechanical designs alone look like what happens when you put Weta Workshop and Maschinen Krieger through a blender. That is to say, this game was destined to be niche even without its doomed launch. It has the makings of a cult classic, and I'll gladly help it along.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004409964', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1627349313}
review:
Big thanks to Mandalore/Sseth for recommending and double endorsing this game.

Honestly I'm not sure what I can add that wasn't already covered in Mandalore Gaming's review (so definitely go watch that instead). Regardless, this game is great. I'm not a huge fan of twin stick shooters, they're OK but I could really take them or leave them. Brigador is a solid twin stick shooter but it brings a lot more to the table. It has a great deal of variety in vehicles and weapons loadouts that allow for some downright insane weapon and vehicle combinations. The story and lore that's in this game is unexpectedly excellent and fun to read; normally I just skim over flavor text but what's in this game adds so much grit and atmosphere to the game. It's written in a more conversational, casual tone that gives the game so much more personality than most other games that divulge lore and backstory in a dry style that tend to read like wikipedia articles. Possibly one of the best aspects of this game though is the sound design and especially the music. Even if you just get the base game I'd still recommend buying the soundtrack if you're a fan of electronica/synth-core. To top it all off the game has some gorgeous sprite work and environments. 

Definitely pick this game up if you enjoy committing war-crimes, wanton destruction of property or just general virtual debauchery.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049333445', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1593450013}
review:
Brigador is a game about commiting warcrimes with style. The gameplay is fun and the different vehicles and weapon types really make the game shine, once you get used to the controls. The soundtrack is great and the the towns look amazing - in tact as well as destroyed. To me half the fun of the game isn't just the combat itself, but also just admiring the sheer destruction the poor saps are experiencing. Yes it is fun to fight of a horde of enemies, navigate around a neighbourhood, make way through a golf course only to appear behind them and blowing them up, giving them super cancer or using bass boosted weapons (literally crushing entire neighbourhoods with sound), but the detailed city scapes and the relentless, merciless destruction thereof are a big part of the enjoyment to me. 

Now, all the praise isn't worth much if I don't also point out the flaws or weak points. You play the game for the great, diversive combat, listening to great tracks and reveling in the destruction of property (and lives). There is a story, but it is dismissable and not too memorable. So if you go into this expecting a story driven campaign, facing big boss fights and drama or anything like that, you would be disappointed. The world building is neat and the story itself is an interesting read through, but not much more than that. Another thing to be wary about are the controls. It takes some time to get used to it - tbh when the speed picks up I'm still not entirely used to it either - but tank controls make sense in the long run, as well as help immerse yourself in the positon of a walking warcrime machine. 

TL;DR:
Great game, lots of variety and fun with great combat, music and it looks amazing too. Don't expect a story driven campaign à la Doom and expect to fight with the controls at first, though it is well worth it all. Highly recommandable, expecially considering the price.

review:
Super cool futuristic mech combat / destruction game. Stomp cities, crush fleeing people underfoot and wreck stuff. The mech designs are cool, the visuals are great, the weapons are all really fun to use. The soundtrack is a fantastic synth score which fits the futuristic setting perfectly.
 
A word of advice however, set your controls for the mech and Agrav vehicles to "absolute". The vehicles have their strongest armour on the front and you'll want to use this to tank hits. The default "relative" controls make it very hard to put your frontal armour towards the enemy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960399151', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2017, 'last_played': 1593341662}
review:
Excellent game for anyone who likes bombastic sci-fi action games with a hint of tactical thinking mixed in. Fantastic graphical and sound design with a soundtrack that's great to listen to even outside of the game. Controls are very responsive, but take some getting used to, especially when "relative" controls are used, which you really should do! The campaign offers fun for a few hours, but it's really rather a glorified tutorial, whereas the Freelance mode is the real meat of the game and offers the most variety.

Brigador can get a bit repetitive, especially as objectives aren't changed up a lot, so the real fun comes from experimenting with the (vastly) different loadout possibilities on different levels and campaigns. Also, the story is only presented through in-game text. Although, even if story presentation should not be your focus, the lore is surprisingly deep, and if you like that the accompanying audiobook is highly recommended.

Overall highly recommended!

review: I remember seeing this game's trailer a few years ago and being very excited for it. It wasn't until Mandalore came out with his review of the game that I remembered its existence. The game's shining feature is its the ability to lay wastes to entire cities with a wide variety of weapons. and WOW does it do it very well! Its very therapeutic. I'm about halfway through the short story as of writing this review and the game has been very generous with the amount of money it rewards you. I imagine by the time I finish the campaign it will have given me enough cash to purchase nearly everything the game has to offer. 10/10 would recommend especially with the sale going on. The music is a BANGER and well worth the extra $4 to own it yourself

review:
Addictive, engrossing gameplay with memorable music. I'd never played a game like this but I'm glad I discovered this one.

Some levels showed more polish than others, and the difficulty was not uniform depending on your choice of mech. But I was always excited to see what puzzle and scenery was on offer in the next area.

You may consider changing the control scheme for different mech types, which was the hardest thing to adjust to as a new player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021988534', 'num_games_owned': 153, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1594404240}
review:
I was going to make this review yesterday but I wanted to play more of the game. And Brigador is an amazing ode to 80s cyberpunk movies. You drop in with your chosen tool of destruction be it a tank, anti-grav vehicle or mech, and rain death upon one of the three factions warring for the planet. 

The music is the best part of the game by far, with the electornica blasting in your ear as you  tear down the impressively destructible environments. This game is a gem at it's current price, so stop reading this and go pick it up nao.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048503358', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1591552859}
review:
Not gonna lie - totally writing this after I saw Mandalore review it recently, which I was pleasantly surprised about. I generally don't write many reviews, but his video helped convince me to finally put one out, even if it's not super long.

Brigador is an awesome little gem with gorgeous 2D art, great sound and music design (I have a soft spot for synth and have multiple game tracks on my phone), and a mix of easy-to-learn, harder-to-master type gameplay that you can easily sink into and not realize it's been hours already. Vehicle and weapon combinations feel noticeably different, and unless you like dying a lot, you'll often need to change up your play-style/ tactics between them. If you like the sound of beautiful 2D graphics, synth tracks that get stuck in your head, and badass mech/ scifi vehicle warfare, you'll love Brigador - and right now it's a steal. 

Getting more money for leveling a residential block full of panicking civilians after you've reduced their military protectors to smoking wrecks: good stuff. Geneva Convention? More like Geneva Suggestion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198968605032', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1707879081}
review:
Greetings, fellow brigadors! 

Behold, as way of a review, my humble Universal Problem-Solver configuration for any and all your needs while tearing across Solo Nobre:

Step One: Acquire the Loyalist Heavy Mech known as the "Swede".

Step Two: Equip its Heavy Hardpoint with the 305mm Fuel-Air Siege Howitzer, or "Harvester".

Step Three: Equip its Main Hardpoint with the 88mm Airburst Cannon, or "Archie", and make sure to bring along smoke rounds for covering your advance. 

Step Four: Align the Harvester with the city block containing your objective. Fire.

Step Five: If anything challenges you following the utter ruin of what used to be a fully functional Orbital Gun, Comm Tower, Substation, or Ammo Depot, respond to their complaints via further Harvesting. Should any foe decide to get in close to protest your actions, introduce them to Archie.

Step Six: Enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997421195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1594123176}
review:
I slept on this game for so long and I'm so sorry for it. On the surface, Brigador appears to be an arcadey twin-stick shooter with cool mechs and really good art direction. It is so, so much more than that.

While you can play Brigador as a mindless twinstick shmup, loading some ultra-heavy mech with twin autocannons and sending more tracers than you can count down range at every enemy you see, the game encourages you to play a lot more thoughtfully, and that's FAR more engaging to me. For example- in my last time booting up the game, I ran a mongoose (a powersuit, think battlearmor from battletech/mechwarrior) with a bonesaw (which is just a fuckin MG42 as far as I can tell) and a mortar, with smoke grenade launchers as my special equipment. This loadout is really good at chewing through light armor, and the mortar gives it a good anti-structure punch (which is important- you're not just here to kill stuff, you have a job to do, and that job is usually to destroy specific infrastructure targets), but against tanks and mechs I had to fight a lot smarter. And so, of course, I start getting rushed by tanks and mechs when I fail to kill a sentry enemy fast enough for it not to alert the whole area to my presence. I retreat to a natural chokepoint in the map, pop smoke and fire a few bursts into the crowd, then bug out and run down a side alley while the enemy pushes up on my old location. Once they get there and start to disperse to search for me, I lob a mortar shell or three in the area to kill or severely damage all the clustered up vehicles, then mop up with my bonesaw.

Is it a milsim? No. There are shield pickups on the ground, big bright ammo resupply points, and your vehicle is always significantly tankier than an enemy piloting the same thing. But it's also not just some mindless arcade game- there's nothing wrong with those of course, and it can sort of be played like that, but there's a lot here to sink your teeth into. 

Ty mandalore for showing me the light

author: {'steamid': '76561198021660951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2229, 'last_played': 1627870349}
review:
I been on this train ever since the Up Armored Edition graced my feed with a simple question: Do you like warcrimes? 
The answer is overwhelmingly yes and I can't believe I never thought to leave a glowing review until Mandy asked me to.

This game has gotten me through some hard times. I keep coming back like its comfort food. And why wouldn't I? 

Everything about Brigador works in tandem to deliver a cohesive experience. The music, aesthetics, and lore are all pillars the gameplay uses to its advantage in a big way. The core loop of the game encourages you to purchase components for experimentation, tactical advantage, or just reading for your enjoyment. With customization being crucial to the experience I feel like this is truly a game anyone can play. 

Welcome Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017696516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4912, 'last_played': 1642838687}
review:
There are games that I buy and never get around to playing. There are games that I play, love and never touch again. There are games that become constant companions, that I keep returning to and loving - and then there is Brigador.

This game is an absolute masterpiece. A brilliant combination of striking presentation, engaging lore and blood pumping gameplay. Every element shines with quality, competence and passion. You will learn to love your vehicles, the city you fight in, your pilots you play as and the enemies that you fight. This is the joy of the classic Desert Strike pumped up to not just 11 but 110. Top down, tactical, 2D heavy armour combat in a cyberpunk, dystopian future setting.

The systems, environment and enemy behaviour interact in layers of complexity to produce a highly satisfying playing experience. You sneak up to the rear armour of a powerful enemy and deliver a killing blow through a residential building block using the absurd penetrative power of your Zeus railgun. You attract a hoard of enemies by blowing up a gas station, then obliterate them with waves of Scimitar artillery strikes. you crush an enemy scout bike underfoot while simultaneously engaging in a laser duel with the powerful tank rolling down the street. The real joy in the game lies in trying and mastering the dizzying array of vehicle combinations and playstyles.

If any of this sounds even vaguely interesting, then try it, chances are you will love it - and then go buy the audiobook too. I hope that these devs pull through the tough launch and succeed, because it would be a travesty if this game is the end of the line.

author: {'steamid': '76561198347503398', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 30775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1674489782}
review:
Brigador is a fun, simple rampage-simulator, where you must assist a mysterious corporation in regime change by destroying everything in a building-sized walking death machine. 

Brigador's charm comes from it's vehicle customisation - you're given a selection of over 50+ vehicles and 40 weapons spread across 5 hardpoint types. Brigador's "risk = reward" gameplay means that making life harder for yourself will net you more profits, so picking a dinky little tuk-tuk and the most difficult pilot will get you hundreds of millions in cash, while a massive mountain-on-treads will only get you a tenth of that. In addition, destructible terrain allows for dynamic battles where the battlefield can be shaped to your liking, should you be equipped to do so. Brigador's presentation is stunning, pairing detailed spritework with a banging synth soundtrack. You even get paid to stomp on civvies - what's not to love?

However, the game's simplistic nature means that the game may get repetitive, especially after the campaign is completed - this can be remedied with mods (of which there are many, uploaded by the community to the developers' discord), however. The only issue I really had with gameplay outside of repetitiveness however is the aiming system, which can make placing precise shots difficult. The game has lore, told through weapon, vehicle and pilot descriptions. Though the game's lore is very intriguing, it isn't really integrated into a story-driven campaign, which is disappointing given the fascinating universe of Brigador.

On another note, Stellar Jockeys (the developers) are incredible. They are still dedicated to Brigador, updating their game 5 years later even after a failed launch. They've fostered a small, but active community that I am proud to call myself a part of. 

I would happily call Brigador my favourite game, and would absolutely recommend it. Watch MandaloreGaming's review of it if you need more convincing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010930580', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1593263558}
review:
Despite Lord Mandalores glowing review, I can't for the life agree with him.

The controls are absolute dogshit in any mode, whether relative or absolute. They both come with their ups and downs. A lot of times you find yourself stuck or unaware of your hulls position to where you're aiming. If you press E, the hull aligns where you're aiming... so why can't that be a control scheme?

This is why Gravlev/Hover vehicles handle like absolute trash too. Either control scheme is absolutely terrible for them.

The straw that broke the camels back for me is that the game doesn't tell you the exact stats, ammo, rof, firing mode etc when you want to unlock them. For vehicles and pilots, you get at least what guns they can carry (heavy, aux, etc) and for pilots you get some vague stats too. From the few vehicles I unlocked and played, they all share the specialty: tanks have a slight speed boost, mechs slam and hover cars go... uhhh... I dunno, like they just slam onto the ground.

Mandalore also praised the music a lot and I agree. It's definitely nice and all... but more often than not in the actual gameplay, it often times cuts out or gets overwhelmed by some of the sound effects. So you never really get to hear it in its glory.

The only redeeming quality I can say is that graphically it looks amazing. But if you've been kneecapped by the controls and shot in the head by the lack of information, the visuals should at least be appealing.

review:
Mr Mandalore.. Review me a game.

Something to add outside of his review, this feels alot like my childhood favorite game Future Cop: LYPD could have been if made with modern technology. And then they added tanks. And then they added hovercraft. And then multiplied the weapon selection by like 30.

If you have relative controls turned on, it really feels like piloting a mech rather than playing with video game controls. I cant even get myself to turn off relative controls for hovercraft because it ruins the feel and starts to feel like a video game rather than the feel the game is going for.

It's alot of fun. I find myself amazed at some of the beauty of the levels slowing down to take it all in. I find myself doing stealthy approaches, juking hordes that are after me around buildings and hitting them from behind, breaking holes through the level and assassinating marked targets. So much fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025707720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1228, 'last_played': 1690901412}
review:
This game, is pretty good.
-Well-realized setting and background
-Excellent music and sound
-Gorgeous sprites to exult in the ecstasy of destruction

In it you take your giant war mech, or hovertank, or auto-rickshaw on a variety of missions to cause wanton destruction and chaos in a former bannana republic space colony that the United Fruit Company really wants to get back into control of. If that's morally uncomfortable to you, congratulations! You get 50$ per civilian killed. Welcome, Brigador.

The game is about mission after mission of this, all taking place in these massively destructible environments. The sandbox mode is the real draw here, and the game's stealth mechanics are refined enough to allow for a lot of variety in playstyle. Sure, you could go out as a towering warmech with long-range artillery, but if you strap a gun on your Toyota land Cruiser  and still complete the mission, the sheer chutzpah will get you a huge bonus payout. Which lets you buy more things to play with.

Apparently this game was actually a commercial failure on launch, which is a damn shame. It's worth its full price, and it's even on discount right now.

review:
Came here from Mandalore, and do not regret my purchase in the slightest. The game runs great even on my crappy laptop, the soundtrack slaps hard, and the combat is so satisfying.

The weapon sounds are punchy and you can tell what they're supposed to be by audio alone, which makes firing the guns feel great. The controls for the vehicles are a bit weird at first but if you've ever played a game like War Thunder it's not that bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001450871', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1496843219}
review:
I'm leaving this review to counteract the positive review bomb and bring some clarity to the question of the game being worth the purchase.

The issue I have with this game is its gameplay.
First, lets get the campaign mode out of the way - it's dull or at the very least nothing to write home about. It's basically a tutorial/challenge mode that forces you to play exclusive or freemode shared stages with custom presets (enemy/key object placement and player vehicle loadouts). I guess the core of the campaign lies in the contextual lore setup that frames the entire experience, but at facevalue it feels like an arcade gamemode that is supposed to be packaged in addition to the main game. In a bit I will elaborate on why it's not even a good standalone arcade mode, but first I need to describe what many people regard as the main mode of the game.
Second, the freemode. In freemode you assemble a custom vehicle to take on contracts that lead you through a set of districts with a requirement of completing one of the key objectives to advance through a stage. Mainframe of the vehicle and a pilot will define the difficulty and reward modifiers (where money is used to unlock said mainframes, pilots, equipment and "contracts"). I'll use a bulletpoint list (within a bulletpoint list review) to describe each particular aspect is inherently flawed and fails to contribute towards making the game enjoyable. So in no particular order:
-Contracts. Different sets usually feature the exact same stages that you will end up playing over and over, with no way of circumventing or avoiding that issue.
-Objectives. There are 3 main objectives shared between all stages (even campaign ones with a little caveat of you usually not being able to pick which one to complete): destroying all key structures, assassinating the captains and defeating a percentage of enemy forces. The latter one is entirely redundant due to how the ability to pursue it, implies your capability of dealing with the other two and the other two can essentially be summarized as "Destroy all of the key entities". Thus, due to how the game doesn't feature any additional scripting for events and conditions (outside of a few minor environmental ones) the immidiate goals the game sets for you to pursue are at their core extremely basic and dull.
-Currency and reward system. The problem is, its not elaborate enough to support a middleground. One either plays at their leasure and earns barely any money or is stealth rush farming the first contract. There is no point on taking on longer and thus harder contracts, since at max/static modifiers the change in payout is linear. There is no point messing only with either pilot or vehicle mainframe alone, due to how said change would again would only be linear. And when one is combining reasonably difficult pilot with moderately challenging mainframe they will most likely find themselves either extremely stressed (and not in a fun way of that) or bored due to how said mainframes either have no durability to the point where making singular mistakes becomes deadly or them having only peashooter slots, making progression through stages twice if not thrice as slow.

So lets say, that this game is supposed to be that basic, since it is in a sense an arcade twin stick shooter. And here comes my final point, the games scoring system is garbage. There is no combo system, no time scaling there isn't even a leaderboard, it's just destruction score x total "difficulty" modifier, making it entirely pointless. It's just a signifier of how much time one is willing to spend on a stage which tells nothing about the quality of the performance.

Thus in conclusion, the campaign mode is too minimalist to be good enough, and due to how freedom mode and mutual core gameplay systems are even less sophisticated, the overall game feels extremely dull and majorly lacking in essential aspects that are inherent to the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040126845', 'num_games_owned': 1007, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1638044071}
review:
Steam keeps ordering me to rereview a game every november. And I won't get tired of it until BRIGADOR wins Labor of Love that it deserves.

These guys kept working on the game for years, no paid DLCs (not that I'd mind, this game is good enough), nuthin. And the updates aren't just bugfixes - there were multiple major updates for years.

According to the Steam Awards rules, a game can't be nominated for Labor of Love if it won that award in a previous year. Apparently the damn GTA 5 is on that list, which is a travesty, with all the greedy monetisation, the grind and not caring for their player base.

BRIGADOR is not on that list. That is a mistake.

Oh yeah, this is supposed to be a review. Just buy the game, it's hella good, and if it's not your style, you'll figure that out way before 2 hours pass (unlike some games that loooove stretching their meaningless openings).

author: {'steamid': '76561198065770729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1652549686}
review:
Been playing Brigador off and on since 2016; and I always enjoy it. Its well worth the 20$; on sale, it's a steal! 

The relative tank controls can be disorienting, but if you enjoy games like SYNTHETIK, you can enjoy Brigador. Once you get used to the controls, it becomes second nature. The interface is a bit clumsy, if not confusing... and the story is buried in pieces of briefings (or intel that you have to unlock), but you can feel theirs more lore there under the surface. The gameplay is very satisfying - especially when in the campaign you're forced to try a totally different vehicle/load that you end up enjoying; going from one mission sending penetrating sabot rounds in a hover tank through a inflammable tank farm, to the following mission, lobbing out canisters of chemical weapons into a playground from a minivan on top of a mechanical tower tank.

Giggling like a manic... Or perhaps something might just be wrong with me? ;D

Anyway, I'm greatly looking forward to the sequel - but if you havent tried Brigador, its best you just try it for yourself!

review: Gritty cyberpunk dystopia torn apart by war with you at the helm in this frantic action shooter. Thin storyline, the real fun lay in unlocking more pilots and vehicles.. whether it be in a massive goliath with railguns and mortars, or living fast in a slick hovercraft and mowing enemies down with lethal microwave beams and scatter lasers. I personally love the 2D isometric look achieved in game, with bouts of neon light offsetting the drab ruins and broken down infrastructure of Solo Nobre. The soundtrack is fantastic, just feels like a whole collection of influences coalescing together created this gem.

review: This game is extremely polished with fantastic visuals and sounds. Want to feel like a tiny little robot with a couple of machine guns sneaking around blowing up buildings, its got that for you. Maybe you would want to have guns that (as some people would say) commit war crimes while striding the now war torn districts in a massive mech, cause that is how you feel with the bigger vehicles. There are a lot of combinations of guns/vehicles and a lot of different play styles because of it, so you will have an easy time having fun with this game. I have also found that this game is pretty good if you dont have a lot of time since you can just play a short freelance mission or do some of the story, and if you have a lot of time you can do one of the pretty long freelance missions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023504044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 28805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13250, 'last_played': 1710774961}
review:
Some weapons are better against shields, some against the hull, but every Brigador knows the 140mm HE shell just doesn't give a shit. 

Brigador is not a game. Brigador is a way of life. 
There are tanks, and mechs, and weird trucks on legs, and mobile junkyards! Oh man I’m getting ahead of myself. 

Let’s start with the basics. Here you are, piloting your touro for the first time and, wait is my target a civie? Why yes, yes it is. Ladies and Gentlemen, it’s war crime o’clock. Open up that 
.50 and watch the fun. 

I love Brigador with a passion I rarely reserve for video games. I love creeping down a city street in a Rounder, pumping 105 shells at range through smoke. Or Smashing through a building with the biggest boom (audio kinetic pulse) all the while blazing rock from the party van. There are just so many options to approach the situation from. And all are excellent.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998217262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1606211744}
review:
I bought this game as soon as I saw Mandalore's review of it. I'm a big fan of mecha and I really like isometric-style games too, so I'm surprised this one flew under the radar. It's a shame this game bombed at launch all over a simple control scheme misunderstanding. I feel bad for buying the game on sale, I would have rather paid full price but I was really itching to play it. This game is a great distraction if you're looking to kill an hour or two. There's tons of weapons, loads of mechs and tanks, and a bunch of different pilots and scenarios to add a lot of variety and replayability to the game. 

Everything from the artstyle to the sound design is amazing. You can tell they put a lot of work into crafting the world too, there's a ton of lore to read into if that's your kind of thing and even extra chunks of lore you can buy. It's obvious that the developers really wanted to create something new and unique and I think they've more than achieved that. 

10/10, I can see this game being like another FTL or Into The Breach. FTL has been around for years but I still always find myself diving into it time and time again, still having just as much fun as the first time I played through it. I easily see this as a game that can keep my attention for years to come.

review:
First I want to thank MandaloreGaming for reccomending me this game, its been on my wishlist for quite some now and with the steam summer sale it gave me all the reason to go and buy it.

Brigador is an isometric shooter game in which you pilot heavy machines and destroy anything and everything that lay between you and victory. The music is spectacular, the lore is fascinating to read and the atmosphere the game creates is truly unique. You may not expect much of a story at first but I must say that what is there is surprisingly entertaining to discover and overall from the gameplay and sound design to the visceral feeling of armoured combat, the game is a one of a kind wreckfest. I reccomend this to anyone especially while its on sale, its got a little something for everyone ;)

review:
So I always assumed I had written a review for this game before, because why wouldn't I? But here I am late to the party.

Alright, in case you don't want to read my entire badly written review, here's the long and short of it:
Brigador is just about the most complete, solid, and fun game you can get for 20 bucks.
If you like mechs, and/or destruction you have to try this game.

Honestly I don't even know what to say. The gameplay is really fun. It feels kinda like playing an old Rampage game but with better gameplay mechanics and actual enemy threats.
The audio is stunning. The weapons and clanks of the machines sound... "heavy", is the word I'd use.
Also the soundtrack is awesome. Just buy the deluxe edition, it's worth it. God is it worth it.
The developers are a great group of people. They've continued to update this game for years for free, despite low amounts of sales.
Honestly I can't even do this game justice.

Just, go watch Mandaloregaming's review for this game. Hell, watch all his reviews, his work is absolute quality.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977296190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1654017954}
review:
It feels fairly hard for me to succinctly put into words why I like Brigador. If I tried this review would probably be a long winded text filled with ramblings about minute details and my own (poorly) reasoned analysis.
So, let's try to be succinct:
In short, Brigador is a very fun tactical top-down mech/tank/agrav game. It's got good controls, a fantastic aesthetic and great game feel (???). If you like mech-games and/or cyberpunk: Buy it, play it. As an added bonus, the lore and audiobook are top shelf.
In slightly longer "short": 
Brigador is a strange thing. A game that is slightly less than the sum of its part, but still is a great game. The above statement is less of a damnation of the entirety of the game, rather a celebration of the games wonderfully realized individual pieces. But what does that mean anyways?
Well, as mentioned previously, the aesthetic (audio-visual) is great, the lore is fantastic, the game feel is good. What's the problem then? Well... as great as the individual pieces are, the game lacks some connecting tissue. For example: There is a campaign, but the missions rarely "flow" into each other. Each mission is an isolated instance of the conflict of Novo Solo. Each mission has you controlling different Brigadors, each with their own load-out. While this idea is commendable, seeing as it gives the player different challenges to overcome and adapt to, it fails to tell a story with a clear "red thread". While not a deal breaker, it is kind of a shame, seeing as the lore and intel you can read between missions, and the accompanying audio-book, are great. Seems like a missed opportunity. Furthermore, the interesting story and lore is somewhat buried in menus that while being aesthetically in unity with the overall design, could either do with being a bit easier to access and digest.
So, "what am I trying to say here?" I am thinking to myself. Well, let's put it like this: Brigador is great, no doubt about that. But don't expect to come in an be welcomed with open arms. It's up to you to find the interesting lore buried within the game, it’s up to you to master the games fun but challenging game-play, it’s up to you to create your own favourite combination of pilot, vehicle, weapons and support equipment and it’s up to you to read, digest and sometimes interpret the story and lore.
Also, hey hey people, Mandalore is a cool dude.

review: Great real time tactical mech game. The different guns and mechs all feel and sound great and there are lots of unique options that invite playing things over and over again to try out different combinations. The aesthetics and audio work really well together and are really good individually. Some of the most difficult missions that are available after beating the main missions are perhaps too difficult to be fun but there is no need to play them. A lot of the fun is playing custom missions where you select the difficulty, stages, and your mech and its loadout so you can customize everything to your liking. The controls might feel awkward at first I'd recommend trying out tank controls in the settings for the mechs and tanks, youll get used to them quickly. Unlocks also come really fast so there is pretty much no grinding involved in getting to try out new stuff.

review:
There's a very interesting story happening somewhere on Solo Nobre, but you're usually showing up after the fact and shooting anybody still standing. Gameplay changes wildly with your loadout; depending on the size of your vehicle, this could be a stealth action game, a shooting gallery, or a bullet hell. Keywords: Big stompy mechs, war crimes, balut. Looking forward to the sequel [strike]and sseth's review of it[/strike].

author: {'steamid': '76561198024439400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3995, 'last_played': 1677127945}
review:
Man Where do I even begin?
The gameplay is great. mechs, tanks, or agravs, all of them are fun. The maps are all completely destructable and there is enough variation of the weapons and vehicles to always mix things up. The three factions are completely unique and you always know what to expect when fighting one over the other. The soundtrack is kickass and I'll listen to it on my drive to work occasionally. The tutorial is usefull and the campaign really helps ease you into the game while at times also being difficult. I encourage you to read mission flavor text but you don't have to.
The Lore is probably one of the strongest aspects of the game. They got a PMC mercenary as a reference to help write a lot of the lore and make the game world feel crazy alive for what appears to be a small indie retro style twinstick. (which of course, it's not.) The lore is so great I've actually been planning on using the setting for a pen and paper RPG with some friends, the audio book certainly adds in much more content when the game already has loads.

Speaking of the audiobook, I would be remiss if I didn't mention it since it's also like the game in the sense it's surprisingly fantastic. If you are interested at all in sci-fi or maybe if you had read warhammer40k novels before than this is up your alley. when it was over I found myself wanting more and the narration was very on point. It didn't have any pacing problems and kept the action and drama going without overdoing anything and it was actually really refreshing. The words "Kinny screamed" is burned into my memory as are so many other lines. It's a really great read and if you're picking up the game I actually strongly encourage you to check out the audiobook as well. I admit I put it off for about a year before actually coming around to it.

The only downside I have for this game is the lack of co-op, which i know is asking for a lot, so I can't completely count it against the game, but still, the amount of times me and my friends have wished to play this game together is countless. It would be nice to experience the destruction and mayhem with a partner. Here's hoping we'll be able to in the next game, if it ever happens.

review: How do you even make a game this good? Seriously, what game *starts* with the volume at 50% so you can actually wear headphones the first time you play it? Everything in this game serves to make it more enjoyable. Even the tank controls are fun to glide around in, and you can really play however you want. Rushing headfirst and trying to rush tight movements in close quarters combat is thrilling, using support options to flank the enemy and find sniping spots is all rewarding, sending the enemy into explosion traps is excellent, and even ignoring the mission to destroy the environment will never not be fun. This a true pick up and play a mission or spend a day working through the near endless repertoire of extra missions and challenge loadouts kind of game. Pure video game crack in its distilled form. The only thing I hate about this game is that I didn't hear about it sooner. This is something everyone will enjoy and needs to forego your wishlist completely and make it straight to your games library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079666743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1574, 'last_played': 1643788398}
review:
In a world devoid of good mech games, Brigador fills the gap perfectly. Though I call it a mech game, tanks and hover vehicles of all shapes and sizes are also at your disposal. The love that went into this game is wholly apparent throughout the entirety of it. From in-depth lore, to music, and the unique feel of each vehicle, the passion for creating a fantastic game shows through.

With the buzzwords out of the way, Brigador lets you experience what it's like to be a bull in a china shop, to use few words. You can tear down the entire city block you're operating in, and get paid to do it. the SNC only cares about taking Solo Nobre back, and they're willing to pay you big money to help them do it, by any means necessary.

Of course, you only get paid if you survive. The campaign follows a loose story, but the freelance ops are where the bread and butter is at. With varying difficulty and payout depending on the pilot and vehicle, the game can be played however you like. There's enough weapons to choose from that you can easily find a new way to spice it up, or just make yourself suffer for the sake of it. 

All in all, Brigador oozes quality from a tiny indie dev, and doesn't ask for more than a twenty at most. They deserve it, to say the least.

review:
It's not a game for everybody, but it also didn't deserve the anonymity it got. What it is, is a destruction simulator extraordinaire. If you ever wanted to strap yourself in a enormous tower of cars and blast your horns so loud that the nearby neighborhood collapses into rubble on the ground, this is your game.

The creators of the game put so much care and attention into this game. So much value and love that it hurts whenever you realize nobody cared for the longest time. Audio books. Lore about everything in the game. Music that is straight boppin'. 

My only hope is that Mandalore and Sseth recommending the game will pull in the love and respect it deserved from the beginning. It's not a game for everyone. But if you like the game, you will love the game, and to find out is worth the price of admission.

review:
It's a unique game that doesn't quite know what it is? 
-It's a tactical mech game
-It's got lots of lore
-It controls like a twin stick shooter (but it's not)
-It has rougelite elements
-It has great music
-It can be very difficult but also satisfying.
-The only big drawback there is to the game is that there isn't that much vareity
to the missions. It's usually kill X number of enemies and buildings but the sheer
variety of mechs and weapons more than makes up for it.

Insanely fun. The only game where you can use a sawed off orbital cannon strapped to a junkyard on treads to level a few city blocks, and get paid for it. In order to sum up how fun the weapons and equipment in this game are, I'm going to summarize a few of the more interesting ones.
Pitbull (main) - anime rocket pod
Konig (heavy) - Brrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrt
Donkey (small) - gun melee
Ploughman (heavy) - Agent orange Pt. II
Crambo (turret) - human rights violation
Black hand (small) - SUPER human rights violation

review:
I'm still super early in this one, but WOW what an atmosphere this game sets. Hostile, grimy, CRUEL. This game's art and music are just sublime for setting a scene. Top marks.

Plays real good, too! It's amazing how a game can communicate this much of a power fantasy while still forcing the player to be intelligent and deliberate. This game slaps.

review:
I had this game for awhile and enjoyed it in low-spec offline play, I never expected it to get the attention it deserved and it went completely under my radar that the devs were working on a sequel.

If you enjoy mech games (like me) you should get it.
If you enjoy tactical games (like me) you should get it.
If you enjoy electronic synth music (like me) you should look into the soundtrack.
If you play this game, please for the love of all that is good change the controls from absolute to relative and git gud with them.

If you're on the fence about buying it, the tutorial is comprehensive and under 2 hours, so if you don't like it or feel mislead you can safely refund it.

review:
Come for the big stompy mechs, stay for the weaponized auto rickshaw. And remember, lay on the horn to assert dominance.

To be honest, despite a relatively low playtime, this game is fantastic, the visuals are great, the soundtrack is fantastic, its just an all around awesome time. What other game can you play as a mech pilot working for a company trying to forcibly overthrow a space banana republic after the death of the local dictator, and get paid $50 for each of the squishy meatbags you are now using to grease the servos of your mech's foot actuator? If it looks at all like a game you'd enjoy, pick it up, its worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027904750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 925, 'last_played': 1641886602}
review:
In short: This game is amazing, buy it at once. 
Actual review follows below.

This game has exceptional atmosphere, giving you the feeling of being a militant space-corporate terrorist attacking an oppressive totalitarian state on an alien planet. Read the stories in the optional text and fall in love with this world. After playing this game and winning the campaign, I bought the audiobook, and I already owned the novel. Hell, even if you don't buy the game, buy the soundtrack, because it truly is one of the crown jewels in an already amazing game.  It's absolutely criminal that something so hand-craftedly excellent has been ignored by the wider market.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960868862', 'num_games_owned': 869, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1623383401}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003866474', 'num_games_owned': 544, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1491613632}
review:
I've played many more hours of this that Steam is just unaware of.
It's incredible that a game this tightly designed exists. There's no real blemishes on it, just pure mech action gameplay. It's got a lot of variety in vehicles, weapons and characters with a huge amount of side missions that weave into the campaign. This is all on top of a stylish, well thought out world and mood that is sure to satisfy any cyberpunk fans out there.
Buy it, you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042254541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1994, 'last_played': 1606594615}
review:
I'm sorry to hear this game has struggled to find a large audience. It is effectively a "perfect" game. Of course, in our world it is hard to imagine something being truly perfect. What I mean is this is an artistic achievement, and that any criticism is likely so personal and subjective it's essentially invalid. This game has a level of vision and refinement that any changes to it could threaten to upset that order. Yes, I am saying a game whose central themes are entropy, destruction and decay is great in a rare, clean, and precise way. 

I have 160+ games and only considered getting all the achievements in a game once before. Currently I have 82% of the hardest ones (I highly recommend putting together ALL of the equipment combinations presented in a block of the achievements you’ll find, it’s obviously a nudge in the right direction from the developers, many are extremely fun and different than my preferred rig: Fork with Mae Dois and Gutterball)

I recommend you purchase this at whatever price it's offered. Don't let my meager 33 hrs fool you. This game will never leave my favorites list. I will seek out anything this studio produces.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987066959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5885, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4952, 'last_played': 1624633550}
review:
I am not very good at reviewing things. However, I really ended up liking Brigador. It reminds me a ton of the old strike series of games mixed with a modern polish. It has a ton of fun weapons, Intresting missions, a large freelance map/mission pool, and quite a bit of backround lore. 

The game has a unique art style. I like the shading of the colors along with all the small details that go into the city its self. It even looks good when its destroyed. 

Gameplay is for the most part, very tight. That is if your using tank controls. Brigador was not meant to be controled like a twin stick shooter. Despite that being the default option, you get a ton of things to play around with. The highlights are a chemical projector, a heavy rail gun that goes through most targets, a semi auto rocket launcher, and the 88mm shotgun. Most weapons fit some sort of build with a extra feature. For example, the 15mm lockdown is completely silent and is really good against armor, or the chemical projector that does damage to enemy's over time and acts mostly like a cluster launcher. Each character and vehicle can change things like the payout or the difficulty of a contract. Some of the higher difficultys/ rising difficultys can spawn alarm treehouses which are terrifying. Mostly due to the fact if you dont have heavy weapons, they tend to get their alarms off due to being damage resistant. Stuff like that makes chosing a character and vehicle more exciting.

Overall its a really tight game and was one of the highlights of 2016 for me.

review:
I kept meaning to write a review for Brigador because it's a great game that deserves far more praise and, let's be real, sales. 
i'm still amazed at how a game so simple in it's control scheme can bring out a ridiculous amount of way to play it be it in command of a gigantic mech or driving a laughably small and under-gunned anti-grav. There's nothing quite like it, and despite it's very arcade gameplay and presentation the writing and the lore are very unique and entertaining to read despite being mostly walled-off from the gameplay and the campaign itself. 
Also I must commend stellar jockey for suporting the game through and through despite it's difficult lauch and poor sales: the game still receives patches, translations and recently got a modkit and a map editor for free. 
If you like to blow stuff up, just go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980267638', 'num_games_owned': 1977, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1691063642}
review:
First thing first, this game is NOT a twin-stick shooter. It's a mech game. Think MechWarrior 2/3/4/, but in 2D, or MechCommander but you are a pilot controlling a single mech (or a tank, or a anti-gravity vehicle) instead of a commander commanding a lance.

With that said, this is a great mech game, with frantic action, beautiful 2D graphic where everything is destructible and a funky electro soundtrack. 

In addition, the game has tons of mechs and vehicles to choose from, along with tons of weapons and support equipment. All of these, combined, offer a surprising amount of depth.

You will find yourself pausing and surveying the enemy's position, planning your attack, where to place that EMP blast to disable enemies, or plotting alternative routes to flank their position and attack them from behind, where their armor is weaker, creating a constant tempo of frantic actions and brief lull where you plan your next move.

All in all, a one of a kind game, where I'd love to see more of. Also, the dev has (had?) been supporting this game after it launched for 4 years, so even though they are now moving on the their next game (which hopefully is the sequel to this game) there is plenty of contents to play around with.

Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102139684', 'num_games_owned': 1253, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1591431922}
review:
Brigador: Up-Armored Edition is an isometric action game where you pilot various destructive vehicles (from lightweight-bikes all the way to mobile-towers) equipped with a variety of weaponry. Leaving apart the game-play aside, the soundtrack is incredible and provides an awesome cyberpunk feel.


First a Pros and Cons list:-


[u]Pros:-[/u]

-Incredible Atmosphere (soundtrack especially)
-Simple but rewarding game-play depending on the vehicles you choose and mission parameters you set.
-Surprisingly large amount of lore.
-Very easy to pick & play (each level is just a few minutes long)
-Apart from the campaign, you also have a random-map generator with variable parameters for replay-ability.

[u]Cons:-[/u]

-Short (Campaign takes about 12 hours)


[u]Overall rating: 9/10[/u]

As mentioned, you pilot various destructive vehicles and each vehicle/weapon has a noise component that determines how far across the map you are heard ie the stronger weapons/vehicles attract more enemies. You have a horizontal and vertical axis to traverse through for aiming making a simple action game, surprisingly deep and fun.

The game has a campaign that teaches you the ropes and lets you play around with a variety of pre-equipped vehicles. The overall campaign is short but the game has replay-ability through the Freelance mode where you can customize your vehicle/pilot/weaponry to suit your tastes. There is also quite a lot of lore to be unlocked. 

The soundtrack and artwork laydown a perfect cyberpunk universe where brutality is awarded above all. There is a sequel in the works.


[u]TLDR: Brigador is an isometric stealth-action game with an amazing cyberpunk feel and fun game-play.[/u]

review:
Main Campaign Beaten - Around 14 hours
(There are several free post campaign DLC packs put into newer versions )
- Lots to still unlock/do

An AMAZING isometric vehicle based game that is basically a twin stick (ish) blade runner meets mad max.

1. Take a mission
2. Choose a pilot (each have stats)
3. Choose a vehicle
4. Choose weapons
5. Pick a mission 
6. Kill everything and hope you dont die
7. Make it to the exit

Pros:
- Some of the best art / art direction I have seen in a video game. Seriously. The level of detail is incredible
- An amazing soundtrack
- Endless replayabilty
- A TON of unlocks. Just an absurd amount. Can keep you busy for a very long time
- Freelance mode (just non campaign missions)

Cons:
- Getting used to the controls will take some time. It is sort of a twin stick shooter, but with some major differences. WASD to control direction of vehicle. Mouse to control where you are looking (think Mechwarrior).  On top of the, each weapon has a line of attack coming from the vehicle. The thing is, you dont just shoot in the direction. You also have to aim the DISTANCE.  This takes a LOT of getting used to. Each weapon has different archs to the fire, so it is complicated.
- Can be incredibly difficult, especially at first. 

Overall, an easy recommendation. Also the soundtrack is for sale and it is just the best.

review:
Lots of fun guns and destruction. You can get one of the superheavies, put two Konigs on it and vaporise everything with glorious BRRRRRRRT. There are lots of other fun weapons, chain guns, lasers mortars and so on but the Konig is the best.

You can get a little power-armour mech and put little guns on it, though I don't know why you'd bother. (EDIT: There's an absolute tonne of fun to be had with the little a-gravs, try Scimitar and Donkey for some machine-gun mortar + jousting action)

Lore is decent too. Refreshingly, every single faction is evil in one way or another, as are all the characters. No cringey campaign where you 'liberate' people by killing them, your sole responsibility is achieving your objectives, getting your pay and continuing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054429431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1588537464}
review:
[i] "If you are going through hell, keep going." -Winston Churchill [/i]

Like a single miniature human being encased in a hulking piece of war machinery, humming into the staccato of heavy turret fire, Brigador makes you feel big and small, mighty and fragile just seconds apart. One moment you’re frenetically dancing in the fray, trying to steer your sleek hovercraft clear of enemy barrage, the next you’re ramming into their flank with a bulldozer, or bombard them from afar with long-range lasers and howitzers. The only constant is that you are alone, pitched against overwhelming odds. The game bolsters its intense isometric combat with a strong tactical layer and sets it all against the bleak background of a totalitarian state spiraling into a gory civil war, presented in between missions through anecdotal lore.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965119525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1571, 'last_played': 1709583433}
review:
Excellent mech (and tank) arcade game similar to twin stick shooters of the past.  Easy to hop into and a blast to play, with lots of variety in vehicles and weapon choices.  Handles great, never manages to feel like movement or shooting is contrived or awkward.

You take on the role of "Brigador," a hired gun for the Solo Nobre Corporation attempting to liberate from a rebel regime that overthrew them in the past.  Despite almost no direct exposition within missions, the game manages to strike the mood and setting perfectly, with background lore being presented in the way of technical briefings on the various weapons, vehicles, locales, and colorful cast of characters.  The details are often reflected in maps, enemy force compositions, and tactics, giving weight to what's written beyond simple writing.

Recommended for anyone who enjoys quick arcade action or enjoys similar settings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984685730', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1652804791}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016603957', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1588493227}
review:
No... Just no.
It's not a fun as it looks.  Aiming is all f'd up on several of the vehicles.  Some taller vehicles *refuse* to shoot where your mouse is.  You have to aim over an inch away to get it to hit your target.

Even when you have a mech/vehicle that aims well, the came simply isn't any fun... not even the tiniest bit.  

Several of the 'campaign'  (Their word, not mine... as it's most *definitely* not a campaign) missions are just flat out stupid.  Start out inches away from suicide bombers than one shot you... with no ammo. Start another one where the entire enemy force is right on top of you from the beginning.  I got it at a deep discount and still not worth it.  Not worth it even free.

review:
awesome, classic, fun. this is the first mech game ive played since G-Nome or maybe Gundam on PS2. the first few missions are great but what i quickly found out is that every pilot/mech/weapon combo require very different approaches to any given mission. the goal is to ultimately unlock everything in "acquisitions" and little to no story beyond that. however, its perfect. its an arcade/retro style mech game that was developed in a way that you can have a different experience every time you launch it. 

this title is a fantastic step away from the over-polished/underdeveloped, over-saturated, AAA wanna be market that seems to have consumed the gaming industry. what youre looking at here is something youll always be glad you have in your library and well worth $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168968716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 270, 'playtime_forever': 2811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1599350478}
review:
[i]「オレたち傭兵の仕事は、ソロ・ノブリ中に設置されている対航空艦隊用のオービタル・ガンを潰すことだ。新人民軍、あー、連中はロイヤリストとか名乗ってんだっけ？そいつらを排除し、都市の再開発を行うには、それが不可欠だからな。速やかに標的を破壊して脱出する、それがプロの仕事ってもんだ。まぁ…作戦行動中に流れ弾が関係ない建物や一般人に命中することもあるが。仕方ないだろ？オレのメックは繊細な動きをするようにできてない、二次被害なんかを一々気にしてたら、こっちがやられちまうよ。イカレてる？いいかおい、ブリゲイダーはな、作戦中の死亡は契約の不履行と見做されるんだよ。遺族への補償金すら支払われない。イカレてなきゃ、こんな仕事はできねぇのさ」[/i]

スペースコロニー時代…現体制派の指導者の死亡とともに泥沼の紛争地帯と化した入植惑星ノヴォ・ソロの首都ソロ・ノブリにて、SNCに雇われた傭兵"ブリゲイダー"となって数々の作戦を遂行するアイソメトリック・アクション・シューティング。
おそらくは3Dモデルをスプライトに落とし込んだのであろうグラフィックの描き込みが尋常ではなく、膨大な量のオブジェクト、破壊された建物の断面、8方向どころか33方向対応のメックのアニメーションパターン、搭載火器によるグラフィックの変更など、2Dゲームの一つの極北とも言える仕上がりとなっている（信じられないかもしれないが、本作では3Dモデルは一切使っていないのだ！）。
またリフレクションマップやグロウマップといった3Dのテクスチャマッピングと同等の処理を施しているため、リアルなライティング表現を可能としている。ぶっちゃけ3Dモデルを使っても労力的には大差ないというか、むしろメックに至っては3Dモデルを使ったほうが簡単だったはずだが、あえてオール2Dでの表現に拘った開発者の心意義に敬意を表したい。
物理判定はZ軸を含む3D処理を行い、精緻な弾道計算をしている反面、照準ガイドが最終的な着弾地点の予測をしない簡易的なものでしかないため、狙った場所に弾を当てるにはいささかの操作の習熟を必要とする。
選択可能なパイロットは難易度の補正と報酬の倍率にかかり、ユニットの性能に影響を及ぼすことはない。また操作ユニットも性能強化といったRPG的なカスタマイズ要素は存在しないため、金を稼いで自機を強化してヌルゲー化、というバランスのゲームではない。それぞれ背中合わせの利点と欠点を持つユニークな機体の特徴を把握して使いこなす必要がある。
ステージ中に存在するオブジェクトはすべて破壊可能で、逃げ惑う一般市民も殺害可能。GTAなら"犯罪者の凶行"、Postalなら"キチガイの所業"となるが、Brigadorの場合は"軍事作戦中の二次被害"でしかない。そのことに、かえって居心地の悪さを覚えるのは自分だけだろうか…？
正義なき戦争に凝った背景をスパイスに加え、設定厨も楽しめる本作は「ゲーム好きなら買って損はない」と言い切れるくらいオススメの作品です。

[i]「サンドクリークを憶えてるか？ニスール広場は？あんたがモニターの中で笑いながらやってることは、今日も世界のどこかで誰かが実際にやってることかもしれないぜ」　──SNC傭兵"デュアルバンシー"[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198000057269', 'num_games_owned': 2502, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1363, 'last_played': 1586668543}
review:
Brigador is flawless and you should play it.

It's an isometric shooter where do you do various mercenary contracts in a futuristic dystopia. The gameplay is fantastic, and the loadout combinations are endless. You can zip around in a hovercraft with a shotgun, lob artillery past the edge of your screen with a tank, or rock dual chainguns as a mech. The environment is fully destructible, the maps are massive and hand-crafted, and there are several dozen enemy unit types and it never gets boring or samey. 

Also, the developers clearly loved and put their soul into this game. You can check out the lore shop and find pages upon pages of background and world-building, all narrated brilliantly from the perspective of in-game characters. 

Brigador is a gem, trust me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965768250', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1709404606}
review:
Absolute gem of a game, I haven't been transported back to my childhood 90s games in forever. I had this wishlisted for a long time and wish I had taken the plunge earlier. Just understand going in this isn't a standard twin-stick shooter roguelike but more of a tactical mech/tank game where positioning and facing matter and using the terrain is key. The world is rich and vibrant and interesting. You can basically set your own difficulty depending on the pilot you choose.

To highlight some of the nostalgic feelings this game brought back for me:
- Battletech (tabletop game) for how unique and quirky and well described each vehicle design is. They really have their own character and feel
- Mech Commander but if you played that on real time mode
- Cyberstorm for the custom pilots and some of the weapons, plus a bit of Earthsiege
- Syndicate for the goddamn BEAUTIFUL graphics (the screenshots don't even remotely do it justice - the level of detail and care that went into each model is insane)
- Raptor for reveling in destruction and getting more money the more you blow up
- Ring Runner (more modern but still) for the complete customization and how the devs love of their game spills through in every way

The controls take some getting used to, but they have half a dozen different settings so you're bound to find one you like (from absolute controls, to offset absolute, to relative, to inverted relative). Plenty of nice quality of life features. Banging soundtrack. Bit sad this game didn't take off like it should have, but it seems like a dedicated core group of fans understood how lucky they were to find it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156867388', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1872, 'last_played': 1635487892}
review:
Brigador is criminally underrated - a hidden gem that is largely unknown only because it struggled to generate publicity upon release. I personally had won a key in a giveaway years ago and completely slept on it until sometime in 2019.

The amount of mechanical nuance and playstyle variety in gameplay, the astounding yet subtle quality of the writing/flavour text that creates a world to immerse you into, the phenomenal dystopian synth soundtrack, the unique aesthetic, and the constant rush in a world where almost anything and everything can be destroyed or killed. It all comes together to create a truly wonderful experience. Sadly singleplayer only, but incredibly enjoyable. All done on an in-house engine that took years for the developers to create.

If the pricetag is a bit tough to stomach, wait for a sale. You won't regret it.

A sequel is also in the works too, and I'm excited to see how that turns out.

review:
Game of the decade!

But you'll have to understand it's not a brainless dual stick shooter. Instead, it's closer to a tactical mech simulator.

Weapons are diverse, some will shoot over buildings, some will be blocked, some will pass through, and others will destroy everything along the path, but nearly all take some careful aiming, since you're not just picking a direction, but also have elevation to take into account.

You'll have to dance with the enemy, being careful enough not to draw too many aggro, yet agressive enough to grab the shields and ammo they drop before it vanish.

review:
Met the devs and tried this game out at PAX West last year.  Can't express enough how nice they are and how much they clearly care about this game!  They were very patient with how bad I was at it, lol.  The game itself has beautiful environment design and lighting and the maps for each level are extremely varied (and much larger than you'd expect).
-
Only complaint is that it takes a while to traverse the map from one end to the other if you missed an objective, and there are a finite amount of enemies in each area, so you'll likely end up walking for a while if you're not strategic in the order you complete your objectives.
-
Overall this game is absolutely worth your time and money and you should absolutely give it a shot.  It's clearly a labor of love :)
