author: {'steamid': '76561198071357475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 393, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1580518600}
review:
Este es un juego espectacular pero que al final termine odiandolo.  Y ahora contare porque.

Este juego trata sobre un planeta colonizado por humanos en el cual ocurre un levantamiento y eligen a un lider revolusionario supremo como gobernante. Pero como es un gobierno de mano dura. Debido a los intereses de cierta cormporacion aeroespacial, deciden enviar a mercenarios entrenados con sus letales veiculos para enfrentar a las fuerzas enemigas y "derrorcar" el regimen. (algo muy parecido a lo que masa con estados unidos y medio oriente por cierto)

La jugabilidad es elegir un veiculo con armas y habilidades que te interesen mas, pero la pega es que todos tienen desventajas. Ya sea en maniobravilidad y armamento. Ademas en necesario aclarar para que no les pase como a mi, que no es un simple juego de accion isometrica como lo es el postal 1 (que por desgracias hubiese sido la hostia) sino que es un juego que se necesita muchisima estrategia minuciosa para ganar los niveles. Ya que tenes que matar unidades que llaman a otras, tenes que usar gadges para que no te descubran, y matar con discrecion. Tenes que ir de a poco avanzando y tener 800 ojos para ver que no te disparen por todos lados, porque solo podes regenerar el escudo. La barra de vida no. Y si se te acaba, sonaste.  

Asi que si juegan a este juego, presten atencion a la etiqueta "pequeño picaro", que tiene que ver con el genero rouge-like que si la hubiese visto antes me humiese ahorrado el actual disgusto de haberlo comprado y llegado muy lejos. Porque en lo personal los niveles mas avanzados son terriblemente engorrosos y frustrantes, hasta no ser divertido.

Aun asi le pongo calificacion buena porque esta espectacular lo bien hecho que esta la destruccion y el diseño de veiculos.

Si lo que buscas en un juego con un muy buen desafio y muchisima destruccion esta es tu cita obligada. Ahora si lo que buscas es postal 1 version cyberpunk este juego no es para vos.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964171905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1702194299}
review:
Easy recommendation if you want something quick and satisfying. 
I really, really wish there was more to this game. I flew threw the campaign so fast that when the final screen opened announcing I had escaped the planet, or whatever it was, it came so suddenly and unexpectedly that I almost didn't believe it. 
Freelance mode is interesting, but I don't know how many times I can destroy four structures and the garrison. 

I would pay another $20 or $30 for an engrossing, rich campaign with evolving, interesting objectives and challenges, and a rich story line. The brief, vague bits of lore available on the side with each mission didn't cut it.

Overall, Brigador feels like 90% style and 10% substance. This world is very cool, very well crafted, and a pure delight to stomp around in. Every weapon system and vehicle feels unique and engaging enough that I instantly started dreaming up combinations and play-styles. But that's about it. 

Brigador: Neon popcorn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036186446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2708, 'last_played': 1635671218}
review:
Bring on the NEON! 

Brigador boasts a good amount of Story and really cool flavourful worldbuilding that oozes out of every Item description. But that is not why you start up Brigador. You do so because it's fun to walz around a ... Tiberian sun esqe Cityscape in a gaint mech with funky weaponry Blasting other mechs, tanks, Hover thingies aswell as hapless Plebeans(some armed some not). 
It's about destruction, when you flatten a block and mow down the survivors with Machine guns.
It's about the thrill of the hunt when you hide your Gangly mech or shifty a-grav behind a Drugstore to get that perfect hit on the back of that mound of scrap cars bolted to Railguns.
It's about being silly, when you honk at the previously oblivious Squad of tanks with your "up armed" Tuk Tuk.

This is not normally my genre but I still really enjoy this one immensely. 

Also the soundtrack is top notch

PS:
I got this game in a humble monthly and was about to give it away, but I decided to give the DRM-free version a go. Which is where most of my hours are. I only later activated the Steam version, and got the Soundtrack etc. to show some support. So I practically got the game for free, but technically not and I surely did not get it as a "Please write positive reviews"-gift.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965960078', 'num_games_owned': 1231, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1583598524}
review:
I love the feel of stomping around in a giant mech. I also appreciate the throwback to the old Syndicate games with how the maps are laid out.

The campaign structure is a (long) series of missions and I would have liked a more linear and cohesive experience. In fact you don't really ever have to read the briefings or debriefings between missions. 

Controls could do with a bit of tweaking as well, the game picked up my x-box one controller just fine and will roll with it, but having to control both distance and direction with the right stick makes for an unpleasant experience. I would have liked for the game to turn on autoaim for distance, and had the crosshairs locked at a specific distance when using a controller instead.

Using the mouse for aiming works perfectly, but movement with the keyboard can get tedious, as you often have to walk diagonally.

Thankfully, almost all of these issues can to a certain extent be fixed in the settings. If aiming with a controller is hard, you can either alter the sensitivity, or lower the game's speed to give you more time. 

If having to press W and D at the same time to move diagonally gets tedious for you, change the settings so that W moves you diagonally (either left OR right).

So the solutions are all there if you have the time and inclination to experiment until you find what fits you like a glove.

In short: I really recommend it!

Watch full review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8b_NZFcdXRU

author: {'steamid': '76561197999546614', 'num_games_owned': 653, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1579583991}
review:
This game has a lot of good going for it. The controls are unique, and mostly pretty good. They vary per type of vehicle, and all the vehicles feel like they look. The gunplay has enough skill to it to be interesting for the most part. There are a lot of unlocks to get, and some are even decent. The aesthetic is interesting, and works well for this game.

But overall there is practically no story here, the "campaign" is just disconnected missions. Freelance mode is even less connected. Buy some unlocks, stomp on some captains, shoot some buildings, rinse and repeat.

This game is 95% gameplay loop, and that loop is not compelling enough to play more than a couple hours. Missions are too stale after that much gameplay, and the unlocks just don't do enough to make me want to stick it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013025716', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1706873817}
review:
Syndicate meets Desert/Jungle/Urban Strike with some N64 Blast Corps thrown in. The engine these guys built from scratch is really impressive and the amount of destruction one can cause adds to the fun and the interactivity of the levels. The pacing can get a little off since each vehicle doesn't have a boost, but you won't feel slow for long.

Don't let the controls fool you-- if you don't like them, you can change them in settings.

I wouldn't plan on using a controller, tho. This seems to be a mouse/KB affair through and through.

Great action game. Use the campaign to warm up for the freelance mode, which seems to be the core of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039019831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1898, 'last_played': 1698571890}
review:
Since you probably already have a rough idea of what the game is like, I'll just list some notable good points:

-Excellent vehicle combat, every map is a sandbox, everything is destructible, the basic gameplay loop is satisfying
-Incredible amount of play styles, if you think up a certain type of tank/mech/hover tank, odds are it can be made into a loadout
-The game has been painstakingly polished over the course of multiple years, many indie games leave something to be desired, here the devs did not stop until their vision was realized in all its glory
-Lore wise, the world feels original, interesting and believable. Better than 90% of sci-fi oriented game worlds
-If you're obsessed with all sorts of military equipment like I am, then the weapon/pilot/vehicle descriptions are a treasure trove, every entry is entertaining
-The game is full of weapons you will not see anywhere else, inspiration for most of these exists in the real world, but other games simply do not bother
-Enemies are the correct mix of capable and believable, any sandbox where I can break line of sight and not have them know my position gets a huge plus from me
-The game rewards mastery, unlike many AAA titles where your hand is held no matter what

The game is not without flaws, but you can read up on those elsewhere, I only have one suggestion:
-When you have so many vehicles and weapons, more than 4 special weapon types seems like an easy way to boost replay value

author: {'steamid': '76561198094585670', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4135, 'last_played': 1670036439}
review:
Apparently it’s been exactly a year since I started playing Brigador, so it’s about time I write a review:

On the surface, Brigador may look like a simple twin stick shooter, but this is far from the truth. Brigador is a detailed isometric shooter that has a surprising amount of depth to it. Vehicles have their own weight and height values, affecting movement and their ability to shoot over cover, respectively. Height is an interesting aspect of the game that isn’t seen in many other shooters – piloting a hulking Citadel ultra-class tank will let you shoot over cover (even entire buildings) without a problem, but this comes at the downside of allowing enemies to see you from much further away. Alternatively, using a tiny Mongoose powersuit will let you stealthily sneak around without alerting anyone. Sound also plays a major role in stealth. Firing a Harvester MIRV can usually flatten just about everything on screen, at the cost of every enemy within district walls being instantly alerted to your presence. Alternatively, the Black Hand irradiator is nearly silent, allowing you to quickly and quietly melt enemy vehicles.

Brigador’s main gameplay involves completing objectives which consist of destroying marked enemies, buildings, or X% of enemies in the map. While this might seem like it could get stale over time, there are simply so many ways to accomplish these objectives that it never does. If you get tired of instantly alerting enemies by using a large vehicle with heavy weapons, you can always try out using small vehicles with lighter weapons and try to be stealthy, etc. Of course, there’s nothing stopping you from trying to be stealthy in a heavy vehicle (you can’t get spotted if all the spotters are dead :^] ), or going guns blazing in a small vehicle, etc. 

Brigador’s gameplay mostly consists of destroying things, and this is done extremely well. Every weapon feels fairly unique, has distinct audio, and some weapons have unique graphical effects. Laser weapons leave behind afterimages that slowly fade away, while machine guns spew out shell casings that remain in the level until you leave. Damaging buildings will leave behind fragments of the building, depending on where you hit it, and whether or not it is completed destroyed. Basically, every action you make will change how the area looks until you’ve exited the level.

Overall, Brigador is an absolutely fantastic game. Although I’ve only mentioned the basic gameplay, there is much more to Brigador than that. The soundtrack by Makeup and Vanity Set is great and fits the mood of the game perfectly. If you think you’ve done it all and have unlocked all of the vehicles, you can use the developer console to create your own vehicle using existing vehicles as a base – ie: putting a tank turret on a pair of mech legs, etc. Editing existing vehicles (both player and enemy variants) is possible as well, and is pretty easy to do. If you’ve completed the campaign and finished all of the freelance runs there is an active modding community if you want to find new levels, or even learn to create your own level. Both the developers and the community are extremely active; the Brigador/Stellar Jockeys Discord server is 100% worth joining, and it’s easily worth getting a Discord account for if you don’t already have an account. All in all, Brigador is much more than just another isometric shooter and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone.

Tl;dr: Brigador is arguably the best cyberpunk-based warcrime simulator on the PC and Mac, at least until Brigador Killers comes out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228941028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 822, 'last_played': 1578672791}
review:
The game to me is a mixed bag. I bought it since it seemed like a fun shooting game to play with controller. However it felt "not quite there" with respect to controls. It gets more annoying at some levels where slight mistake can result in quick death due to enemy type and placement (e.g. "Joy Bus / Hell Ride" and "Always Forever Now"). Overall, the campaign missions feels disjointed (with player having to switch between different sets of vehicles and loadouts regularly), while the "freelance" (i.e. skirmish) option feels repetitive after a while.

Having said that, the game does have good music and art style, and doesn't have high system requirement. It also seems to be stable. But ultimately while the game has its merits, I can't recommend it at full price.

review:
[h1]评分：8/10[/h1]

+ 第三人称视角
+ 可以给机甲换武器

+ 激情的音乐 [spoiler]听久了不舒服? 关音乐换ASMR[/spoiler]

- 任务种类略微单一
- 机甲的转向方式/移动方式
- xbox手柄表示摇杆有很奇怪的问题，好在这个游戏不太需要手柄也能玩

疑惑点：
? 更换装备后没有一个可以测试的地方，用错了装备有时很难受
? 不知道会不会有创意工坊？
? 会不会有多人联机？
? 希望在一些细节的地方添加一部分说明（比如更换了机甲之后，两个武器类型可能会变，希望在页面上有提示）
? 更换购买按键的位置
[strike]? 地图编辑器，允许玩家自制地图？[/strike]

推荐购买？推荐
比起之前观望的时候算是更加完善了，虽然汉化的一些地方略微有些模糊，但是不影响阅读（除非你是个外国人）
没事刷刷刷，搓搓[strike]可爱的[/strike]敌人(?)
不过希望加入联机模式啊，多人双人对抗模式，玩家与AI的对抗模式（或者AI队友，如果这个做出来了的话，甚至可以有额外的剧情？类似于护卫任务？）这样的。

机甲的设计非常有趣，如果你觉得你需要一点点发泄的话，趁打折入了是很划算的。
如果你对斜四十五度第三人称视角不感兴趣，那还是免了。

author: {'steamid': '76561198257219615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1578218403}
review:
[h1]😣 TRY IT FIRST ON SOMEONE'S PC, BEFORE BUYING 😣[/h1]
Game developer replied my review. The followings are updated after their reply.
[b]I experience with The Brigador is, it is annoying and unpleasant to play.
It is hard to recommend it to everyone.
My advice is to play it on someone's PC (for like 2-4 hours), then decide whether it is suitable for you.
I gave up on 5th hour. 6th hour is to test game developer's feedback.[/b]
👍🏻 Appreciate game developers' effort.
[table] [tr] [td]
👎 Game level design which promotes stealthy approach, or else all the nearby (including outside of screen) enemies will storm your location.
But, you pilot a combat vehicle with big+loud cannons+missiles & machine gun turrets.
And, your target are (Michael Bay's) high-explosive buildings and enemies' explosive-packed vehicles.
[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]
👎 The weapon [b][u]DOES[/u][/b] shoot at exactly where the laser sight points to. 
[b][u]BUT[/u][/b], some enemies are so small / short or hover in mid-air, the projectiles does not hit them, and need to be re-adjusted.
[spoiler]Annoyingly wasting machine gun turrets bullets on foot soldiers who are storming slowly towards you, but you still can't hit most of them, while you point your laser sight on top of those foot soldiers.[/spoiler]
However, at the heat of the battle (where enemies swamp at you from all directions), to align the shot at 1 specific enemy is a luxury one cannot afford. 
[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]
👍🏽 Developer's recommended guide: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=535841178][u]Brigador - The Solo Nobre Murder Spree Handbook[/u][/url]
Most of the tips are similar to those from in-game tutorial missions. No too useful.
Also, strategic planning is hardly a thing in this game, because player can't see where most enemies are. There is no map.
[i][u]Example[/u]:
I saw 1 lonely enemy from the far edge of the screen, and thinking I should take it out before it alerts others.
After 1 shot, the horde of enemies just behind that lone enemy (outside of screen) swamp my location.
Other hordes from other directions are also alerted, and ambushing me.[/i]
[b]Without more useful information (e.g. map / overview of the field, no. of enemies, enemy type, etc.), planning an attack is equally suicidal as running in guns blazing Rambo style.[/b]
[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]
😞 (Not game developer's fault, but......) 😞
[u]NVidia Graphic Card[/u] player might need to manually tweaked settings to get smooth game-play experience (i.e. stable FPS).
(See: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/274500/discussions/1/1640917625019290891/][u]Attention Nvidia Laptop owners! increase FPS![/u][/url])
I got stable 50FPS (after changing settings).[spoiler]
Intel i7-7700HQ + 8GB RAM + GTX1050Ti computer
[strike]Game runs mostly at 30FPS on high graphic quality.
Only when shadow and aliasing graphic settings are tuned down to bare minimum or OFF, then the game can run mainly 60FPS.
It still dips down to 40FPS from time to time.[/strike][/spoiler]
[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]
👎 FPS affects game response.
At lower FPS, both player's and enemies' movement becomes slower.
The changes between 30FPS and 60FPS is very noticeable when playing.
[spoiler][strike]Most enemies still move at normal speed.
Making the enemies storming your location much more deadly.[/strike][/spoiler]
[/td] [/tr] [/table]
You, the 1-man army, going against the whole fleet (or, most) of enemies from all directions, and a single shot is enough to alert all of them to your location.
[spoiler][strike]Why waste time fighting a lost war? Go play other games.[/strike][/spoiler]
I can see the potential of this game, but the combat mechanics and game level design are contradicting themselves. 
[h1]Feedback to Game Developer :[/h1]
If someone's guide is better than your tutorial / tooltips, you might want to include/update your game with those information. 
(e.g. picture of the laser pointer and projectile path)
(e.g. explosive pipeline is not explained in tutorial)
✨ Best wishes to the game developers. ✨
✨ Hope you guys would continue the effort developing good games in future ✨
But I still can't recommend Brigador.
developer_response:
While a more strategic style of gameplay is favored, it's certainly possible to successfully play Brigador with a full Rambo style. Regarding your other points however, there's some things to be cleared up.

Regarding performance, those specs should run the game fine so make sure your drivers are up to date and that your computer is using the graphic card not the integrated chip -- see this post: https://steamcommunity.com/app/274500/discussions/1/1640917625019290891/

Regarding FPS dips, when the framerate drops below 60 fps the entire game will slow down because otherwise physics and projectile errors will be produced. *Everything* in the game slows down though, so you're incorrect in saying it's only the player unit. You can manually test this yourself by adjusting the default game speed in the settings menu.

Regarding aiming, the issue you're having is due to the 3D nature of the game. One of our community members has put together a comprehensive guide that includes diagrams that show how aiming works and why you're missing shots you think should hit: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=535841178

I hope this clears some things up for you and enables you to better enjoy the game. If not, we understand and hope you enjoy our future titles better.

review:
Excellent game, every run ends up in massive amounts of property damage, you could have hundreds of tracers flying and buildings blowing up all over the screen and the framerate remains like silk. The mechs are awesome, the backstory is gritty and cool, and the entirely difficulty curve revolves around challenging yourself with ever more brazen pilots and unconventional loadouts.

Also runs like a dream on linux, there's only a single loading screen right at the start that's over in three seconds even without an SSD. Huge respect for the devs going against current trends and putting in the work to make their own engine, the game is objectively better for it. Totally stoked for the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198392593013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 6436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 171, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1711887246}
review:
良質なサウンドトラックが情緒豊かな、どこか懐かしい粗いグラフィックのクォータービュー(俯瞰視点)の全方位シューティングゲーム。比較的高難易度で、ユニットおよび武装の特性をつかむまでは所謂"死にゲー"になりがちだが、道を逃げ惑う無抵抗の市民に腐食性ガスグレネードを打ち込んだり、ネオン煌めく歓楽街を極大口径迫撃砲弾の砲爆撃で廃墟に作り替えたりすることに興味があるなら"間違いなく"買いである。
　機体の武装構成により、純粋な破壊力で押し切る"ゴリ押し"タイプの機体から、特殊な兵装を組み合わせて適切なタイミングで効果的に使用することで敵をすり潰す"コンボ"タイプの機体まで、プレイヤーの求めるあらゆるスタイルでの戦闘を実現する非常に自由度が高いゲームとなっている。

　ゲームモードは"キャンペーン"と"フリーランス"の二種類。
・キャンペーンモードはステージ毎に固定のユニット/武装でクリアを目指す"チャレンジモード"的ゲームモード
・フリーランスはプレイヤーがユニットおよびその武装構成を選択しステージをクリアするゲームモード
　キャンペーンモードは所謂"ストーリーモード"であり、各時系列で3人から4人のキャラクターと彼らが駆る戦闘機械でステージを攻略していく。装備変更等はできず、限定された機体構成でどのようにしてクリアするのかに挑戦するパズル的な側面が強い。
　一方のフリーランスは選択したステージを自由な構成のユニットで攻略でき、ユニット構成には搭乗者の選択も含まれ、選択した搭乗者でゲームの難易度、クリアした際の報酬(ポイント)が微調整される。選択できるステージにはキャンペーンモードのステージも含まれ、より自由にゲームを楽しみつくすことができるゲームモードである。
　フリーランスで使用可能なユニットはステージクリア時に獲得できるポイントでアンロックしていく形式なので、まずは武装やユニット特性を把握し操作に習熟するためにもキャンペーンモードを面倒臭がらずに攻略していくことをお勧めする。

～以下蛇足～
　地球を遠く離れた植民地惑星"ノヴォ=ソロ"、その首都"ソロ・ノブリ"。かつて宇宙開発企業SNC(ソロ・ノブリ・コンサーン: "ソロ・ノブリ開発事業"といった意味か)により搾取されていた人民は"偉大なる指導者"に導かれて"新人民軍"を組織・決起しソロ・ノブリの自由を勝ち取った。しかし時を経て今"偉大なる指導者"は斃れ、ソロ・ノブリはかつてない混乱を迎えようとしている。
　プレイヤーはSNCと契約し"ブリゲイダー"と呼ばれる傭兵となってソロ・ノブリの覇権を握らんとす三勢力を排除し、当初の開発事業を再開せんとすSNCのソロ・ノブリ再占領のために戦場へと赴くことになる。
　SNCおよびその契約下にあるブリゲイダーたちが排除すべき敵対勢力は、"偉大なる指導者"亡き後の混乱を抑え支配の安定を取り戻そうとする"新人民軍"、"偉大なる指導者"の圧政に異を唱え黄緑に塗られたジャンク兵器で命をものともしないゲリラ攻撃を得意とする"コーヴィッド"、地上(惑星上)に居住する人類全てを下等な生物と断じその抹殺を最終目標とする超科学の宇宙居住者"スペーサー"。
　"偉大なる指導者"の圧政はSNC統治時代に勝るとも劣らない過酷さであったようで、プレイヤーの分身たるブリゲイダーたちは誰もが様々な所属と出自を持つ一癖ある人物たちばかりである。どのキャラクターにも魅力的なバックグラウンドが設定されており、あるものは生きるために戦い、あるものは夢の実現のために、そしてあるものは快楽を追い求めて果てしない破壊と殺戮に身を投じる。
　ブリゲイダーたちが搭乗する戦闘機械もユニークで、ガラクタの寄せ集めから地上居住者の技術では解析不能なオーバーテクノロジーめいた先端科学の結晶まで、反重力バイクに始まりパワードスーツ、二足歩行メック(戦闘ロボット)、果てには超重量級タワービルの如し怪物戦車に至るまで多種多様、様々な戦闘機械を操縦できるのは爽快の極みである。無論、これらの戦闘機械、その搭載兵器に至るまで詳細な設定が存在し、SF好きであればこれら資料に目を通すだけでも楽しめることは請け合いである。
　全てのゲーム内のテキストは丁寧に日本語化されており、日本語話者のプレイヤーであれば言語面での心配は一切無い。ここまで至れり尽くせりの環境で日本語圏における知名度が低いことに疑問を感じずにはいられない。情緒あふれるサウンドトラックも相まって、是非ともおすすめしたい一作。

author: {'steamid': '76561198067849193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 5506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5334, 'last_played': 1626344301}
review:
Fantastically good 'hidden gem' game. A methodical top-down shooter featuring mechs, tanks, hovertanks, and tuktuks. Planning and applying tactics are rewarded with survival, haste and sloppy decisions generally result in death. Everything within each level's border is destructible, buildings can be used for cover or smashed to the ground to create an escape route. Campaign has a series of scenarios ranging from easy to challenging, Freelance lets you mix and match your vehicle, weapons, level set, and pilot however you want.

Back to the destructible buildings- this is the best. Walking a mech over a bunch of abandoned cars, driving a tank through the side of an apartment block, or launching an airburst shell at a row of suburban cookie-cutter homes. It feels great, arguably more fun than blowing up the enemy vehicles. This is the most fun I've [i]ever[/i] had committing war crimes against my home planet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051415780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1682961235}
review:
It's wreck or get wrecked. Normally I refrain from writing reviews so soon, but Brigador is a blast. Basically, the trailers are accurate.

[b]Getting into the game[/b] is made easy with pre-fabricated loadouts including strategy tips. Early campaign missions show contrasting playstyles and let players choose their preferred one, while late campaign missions put them to the test and show the weaknesses of each playstyle.

[b]The story[/b] and worldbuilding is raw, concentrated dystopian New Wave. However, there is a big con: Most LORE costs extra. You have to expend effortously earned mission rewards if you want to know what the "yellow raincoats" are about, for example. It's worth the cost, but upsetting nevertheless.

Shoutout to the art, gfx, music and soundwork. They blend well with the game, and swing the mood back and forth between energetic upbeat and grim premonition. It is usually busy, so you can't help but feel suspicious when there's not much going on.

review: This game is great, a mech game with many playstyle options. Do you want to facetank everything? You can. Wanna play as a guy in a powerloader, using hit and run tactics and camouflage to get out of a sticky situation? You can do that too. Very fun, very difficult. My only complaint is the fact the game's single player only, i feel this game would be perfect for co-op play, and co-op allows much more replayability even if single player starts to get boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008120595', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1225, 'last_played': 1590121641}
review: This game is absolutely amazing. Your a Piece of Crap Merc undermining a less than stellar workers Republic predicated on a cult of personality. Dear Leader is dead and you are part of the cause. A smorgasborg of freeform destructible maps where you cause wonton destruction for some reason or other but you just here for a paycheck and to see crap go BOOM.  And Boom do they go.  Shoutout to the Dev's for the fully destructable environments.   Something special about watching countless debris splinters fly through the air while not thinking about all the innocent civilians you are carelessly smashing beneath your mechs feets and endless weapon loadouts.  This is a game of action and it delivers

author: {'steamid': '76561197960342473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 2645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1084, 'last_played': 1670254241}
review:
Destroy stuff with a mech!

And get paid. Then buy more mechs or guns. Repeat.

Theres also a story mode which gives some reasons (not badly written actually and theres alot of lore) why you destroy stuff with a mech but thats basically it.

Theres mechs, tanks and hovercraft in big, average, small and joke/challenge variations which each play differently and can fit (two) different type guns and (one) special weapons.

Theres alot of guns like cannons, howitzers, lasers, machineguns etc which also handle differently.

Beyond pure reflexes theres also an amount of tactics involved altho that mainly boils down to how much attention you want by noisily blowing up big targets.

Difficulty/Rewards are handled in a somewhat unique way. Each vehicle has a reward modifier - for example playing with a big killer mech will net fewer rewards as driving around in a trashcan with a nerf gun. Difficulty is customizable via Pilots and scenarios. Scenarios define what type of maps and how many in sequence youll play and if you can cash out before playing all of em. Pilots define the starting difficulty and difficulty jumps between maps. So for the big bucks you might wanna play a 10 map scenario with said trashcan and a high risk pilot - if you can survive.

Unfortunately theres no parts customization beyond vehicle and weapon choices, altho there are quite a few of em. The gameplay might get repetitive after a while.

The neony graphics and music are quite good, reminded me abit of Hotline Miami.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972146100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 202, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1571005865}
review:
Fun top-down shooter when you just want to watch the world burn. Pilot a mech, hover-tank, or battlesuit (numerous models for each class), and about 8 variety of weapons and 5 or so variants of each. There's a lot of versatility in gameplay - you can build a stealth/sniper mech, or just a powerhouse guns blazing kind of mech, and everything in between. Each vehicle has its own advantages and disadvantages. There's a variety of levels and opponents, and the environments are completely destructable. The game starts off silly slow with about 16 levels of tutorials, then the difficulty quickly picks up, and you unlock the "freelance mode," which is the real meat of the game with a variety of difficulty settings. Great atmosphere, great music, and fun gameplay make Brigador worthwhile.

+Lots of play styles
+Variety of difficulty settings
+Completely destructable environments
+Great soundtrack
+Classic sci-fi setting
-lengthy tutorial

author: {'steamid': '76561198043388752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1665817226}
review:
Somehow the gfx remind me of C&C Red Alert, a game I used to love playing as a kid on the PSX. I like it.
The music is awesome, it's the music from the trailer that will accompany you while you rampage through urban districts.
The lore and background story is quite intriguing, I like how you can spend the gold you earn from missions to unlock more intel about the world.

I'm currently still doing missions, they are supposed to familiarize players with the game. When I complete all the missions and start Freelance, the real meat and potatoes of the game, I will probably update this review. From what I've seen there's a lot of weapons, mods and mechs to buy and customize. You can then use those to go on Freelance missions to earn more gold  to buy more stuff to do harder missions. Looks promising!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006535445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1569680316}
review: So way back when, in the days of Sega Genesis, there was a series of games that were all called "____ Strike" and were isometric helicopter games of you rescuing civilians, blowing up enemy infrastructure, and shooting at enemy forces.  This is that game's great grandson two generations removed: the pixel art is all hyper detailed, EVERYTHING is destructible, the vehicles all handle with a weight and speed that makes them comfortable, the lore is worth reading, and it's fun in a way that not a lot of other games have been in a long time.  The music and graphics are amazing and the beats in particular will get stuck in your head.   I had a blast with this - worth the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034630828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1689462793}
review:
Reminiscence of the old classics like the Strike games (Dessert, Urban, Nuclear etc.), or Future Cop LAPD, etc.

Fortunately its even more complex as the old games. You can choose between many vehicles, which not only have different health and speed, but also distinguishes in movement, and the way they control. Weapons also have a "ballistic arc", so you have to aim for the right hight of the enemie, or otherwise you over/undershoot.
Overall the controls and aiming in this game are done very well.
It packs also great soundtrack, which suits the scenario extremly well.
Fun fact: It may sound like a dream, but you can destroy EVERYTHING!

In short, kick ass game, with bad ass soundtrack, and great art style.

Thank you devs!

author: {'steamid': '76561198873179219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8963, 'last_played': 1629327003}
review:
it's a very if-you-like it-you-like-it kind of game, but nothing else really does it like Brigador. It's neither the stick-shooter nor the mecha power fantasy you expect going in, which may be a disappointment if that's what you wanted. If you stick with it, though, you'll find something much more interesting than either of those, and it won't release its hooks until you've experienced everything it has to offer. The gameplay is deep enough to provide a broad variety of viable tactical approaches, while being intuitive enough to ensure you can explore any of them without feeling like you're doing it wrong. It's one of those games that makes you crave higher and higher difficulty as you play and your understanding deepens.
Make sure to change the default scheme to tank controls, though, as the game is designed with that in mind. It's strange that it's not the default.

The lore is also noteworthy, as it's surprisingly great. For a game from a small, lesser-known studio with a story mode that could only loosely be referred to as such, the worldbuilding is shockingly excellent. It feels like this is some IP that has existed for decades already, and that had a host of different writers fleshing everything out and justifying every aspect of it. This is the only game where I have considered unlocking a new lore entry over a new piece of equipment. It's just that good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977128616', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 664, 'last_played': 1625665660}
review:
DESTROY. EVERYTHING.

If you've ever played MechWarrior 3050 for the SNES or BattleTech for the Sega Genesis (they're the same game), it plays fairly closely to that game. I rather liked that game growing up so this was a pretty easy game for me to get into. And it's 1,000x better.
Weapon selections only look limited on paper until you see what the amount of combinations you can make just on one unit; a Touro mech fitted with the free gear (an HE cannon and a light machine gun with smoke canisters) will make for a great, tough line fighter, while simply changing the weapons to an "Archer" cannon and ... a class of laser I've forgotten... can turn the Touro into a shock trooper.
And there's roughly 100 units to pick from, from mechs to anti-gravity hulls ("agravs") and actual light and heavy tanks, with varying speeds, armor and shield levels, and two different sized hardpoints on each unit. Lighter units likely have smaller hardpoints... but not always.
Once you're on the field, it's about completing objectives however you need to. Sneak in and dart in and out of trouble to complete your objectives like a scalpel? Roll in and stand up to whatever garrison is thrown at you, overcoming all who stand before you? Or lure your enemies into ambushes and cause maximum shock and awe before they know what hit them?

It also helps that everything -- and I mean *everything* -- is destructible within the district bounds. Causing maximum property damage has never been so much fun.

The neon aesthetic and accompanying music by Makeup and Vanity Set just seals the deal for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035392672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1485, 'last_played': 1704480845}
review:
I don't always get time to play video games, but when I do, Brigador is usually my go to.

It's an incredible experience. The art work, the ambiance, the soundtrack and the sheer combination of equipment through which you can decimate your enemies - really just all around a great game! I've got about 25hrs and counting on it so far, and am looking forward to logging much more. I learn something new every time I play and I'm constantly working to improve my abilities as a fearsome warrior!

10/10 would recommend. If you love sci-fi Indie games with a retro feel like Neon Chrome or Hotline Miami, then this game is for you. Easily ranks within my top 5!

review:
Ok, so I gave it a try.

Unfortunately didn't score for me. I was expecting a classical desert/urban strike / battletech inspired gameplay.
It feels like a prove of concept and game engine. I wish there would be better though-throw game design, a storyline and more consistent visual art. 

You have a hundred of repetitive missions, generic briefing (don't expect any storyline or characters to connect to). You don't have a chance to customize, upgrade or select mechs/weapons. There is zero lore.  Fullscreen mode is bugged and stays either under big screen mode or over all other windows without  possibility to switch to any other apps.
Objects are being destroyed by tiles (which makes no sense with buildings and looks weird).

Couldn't run with either 360 or steam controller on MAC.

Overall: 4.5/10

Concept: 5
Story: 3
Gameplay: 5
Design: 4
Art: 4

author: {'steamid': '76561198004297047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1639, 'last_played': 1690926898}
review:
A Planet gripped in the tyranny of a spaceage Banana republic, under siege by ruthless corperations and Playground of cruel Aristocratic spaceborn Mercenaries garanteed to stab you in the back. The setting and Lore of Brigador is one of the Most interesting I have ever Encountered. Sadly the Game itself has little to no narrative making use of it, and we learn of it only in unlockable Lore texts.

The gameplay is similarly excellent. you control a customizable vehicle as you navigate through various fully destructible maps, dodge and fight three different factions. the selection of vehicles is vast, all with different stats and Brigador sports a broad weapon selection. the Game is challenging and takes time to master the controls. Some options however are more painful than others, as I found that the slow and heavy tanks make a map drag on and on compared to speedier A-gravs. but that comes down to playstyle. 

Overall an excellent game, the only things missing is a story, and sadly there is no mission diversity whatsoever. I know however that the Devs worked their asses off to get this released, and that it didnt sell too well. I hope and am Looking forward to a Brigador 2 nontheless because I can see the potential waiting to unfold here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033602078', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1564847071}
review:
I love the aesthetics of the game, it reminds me of Tiberian Sun and if I were to only rate that part I would have given it a 10/10. What brings this game down is the lack of a proper campaign, story and good progression. There is something called a campaign in the game, but it is just a series of disconnected missions and some fluff text that doesn't really tell you anything interesting or important. The missions always have the same goal: kill X amount of enemies or kill X specific buildings. It just feels like a normal skirmish except that the map is premade/fixed.

There is also no progression in the campaign. Instead you get to select from 3-4 characters with preset loadout. There's no difference on who you pick, the only thing that changes is what you're driving and what weapons you have. The character himself is basically just a picture, because there are no character interactions or dialog. Besides, the characters you can select from changes from time to time so it really feels like you are picking from random characters that has no impact on the nonexistant story.

A more accurate name for the "campaign" would be "Tutorial & Challenges". Because that's ultimately what it is.

There's also a freelance mode where you can select whatever you want as long as you have unlocked it. The problem here is they the progression. You can easily buy the biggest and baddest vehicles & weapons very early. So you have to deliberately select crap things and make it harder on yourself unless you want to play the same thing over and over. I really dislike games that does this rather than make you start weak and then you get gradually stronger and stronger while the challenge increases.

Finally, there's a lore section where you can unlock lore in the game. I must say I'm very impressed by this, because there is so much text while at the same time it barely tell you anything important/interesting. Just like the text for the "campaign missions".

So I'm sad to say I can't recommend this, because I really love the aesthetics, but it is not enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179342283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1577743227}
review:
One of these games that are designed to make you feel PAIN!
Controls are bad. Your hand start to hurt, because you mech moving so slow, so terribly SLOW! Even if you hit turbo it's still too slow and it stops after a quarter of your screen while the level is twenty or thirty times bigger than that. Story consists of disconnected senseless pieces of ideas. You can't choose mechas you want, you can't choose weapons you want. Aiming is a pain in the ASS: shots are displaced from where you point to. Your mechas become weaker the more you precede while enemy becomes stronger. You try to dodge, because your weapons are weak, your fingers hurt, you screem in agony! Jesus Christ, there is a place in hell for this kind of games!

PS: Graphics are nice and music is surprisingly good, to be fair.

PPS: Review is related to the campain, not the additional missions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028046072', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1565417386}
review:
Um game que segue a linha de jogos de ação 'shoot 'em up' dos anos 80 e 90 como Desert Strike e Jungle Strike. Vc controla mechs assassinos por contrato e a temática é cyberpunk.
Muito bem produzido, polido e acabado. A trilha sonora é synthwave para melhorar ainda mais a situação.
No jogo vc pode fazer missões de campanha e ganhar credits ou ir em missões paralelas com equipamentos comprados.
Muitos e muitos itens para desbloquear além de pilotos, veiculos, equipamentos, etc.
É um ótimo game. É leve. É barato. 
Acho que só é um pouco dificil de pegar o jeito dos controles, mas depois de se acostumar isso deixa de ser um problema.
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198029715995', 'num_games_owned': 809, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1564936429}
review:
Когда я обнаружил игру, где можно пилотировать меху, я очень обрадовался. А зря.

Игра представляет собой отдельные миссии с максимально хилыми врагами. Ладно бы они отличались хоть каким-то разнообразием, но нет - это монотонное повторение одних и тех же действий из миссии в миссию. По сути, это одно большое обучение, не более. Заработай деньги, открой пилота, меху, задание и т.д. Вот только мотивации открывать следующие задания нет совсем, так же как и пилотов, а точнее клоунов именно так они и выглядят.

Из всего этого месива выделяются только саундтрек, годный ретровейв, дизайн техники и полная разрушаемость окружения. 
И это все, больше в игре нет ничего, просто красивый и пустой фантик, без наполнения.

Не понимаю, откуда столько хвалебных отзывов у игры, которая сделана на отвяжись?

author: {'steamid': '76561197960398267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1630853681}
review:
-크림슨랜드나 에일리언 스웜 등의 탑뷰 슈터게임을 좋아한다면 강력하게 추천합니다

-조작감은 대체로 훌륭한 편이지만 이족 보행 메카의 조작체계가 좀 어색합니다 포탑의 발사각이 정면 180도 정도로 정해져 있
고 이동방향에 맞춰서 무기의 방향이 움직이는 방식이라 키보드의 WASD 조작체계에서는 헷갈릴 수 있습니다

-게임의 난이도는 파일럿을 골라서 결정하는 방식이라 유동적입니다 쉽다면 매우 쉽게 할 수도 있고 터무니없이 어렵게 할 수도 있는 방식

-음악이 매우 훌륭합니다 Up-Armored 판을 사면 같이 제공되거나 따로 구매할 수 있는데 사운드트랙만으로도 돈값을 충분히 합니다

-모든 사물이 파괴됩니다 게임내 맵의 경계선을 지정하는 끝자락 벽을 제외하고는 모두 파괴됩니다

-한국어가 지원되어서 영어를 잘 몰라도 게임을 할 수 있습니다 번역도 정성스럽게 잘 해놓아서 일부 오역,오타를 제외하고는 전혀 문제없습니다

-게임내내 탄약이 부족하게 디자인 되었는데 적을 파괴하면 나오는 탄약아이템을 잘 먹거나 무기의 종류에 맞는 탄약 보급소를 이용하면 됩니다 혹은 F1 키로 개발자 메뉴를 열어 무한탄약을 키면 됩니다

-개발사에서 직접적으로 게임의 모드를 지원합니다 모딩용 툴도 무료 DLC 로 포함되어 있습니다

author: {'steamid': '76561198014461505', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1581109971}
review:
Absolutely love this game.

Best proper Indie title I've played for god knows how long.

+Beautiful destructible Cyberpunk environments.
+Massive amount of content (put in about 4 hours but I reckon there's a good 70\80 in here)
+Sophisticated and difficult  battle system.
+Deep and fascinating Lore
+Dark story with no simple "good guys and bad guys"
+Ludicrous amount of vehicles which all run and play completely differently.
+The Music.It's got me excited for cyberpunk 2077.
+Runs like Usain Bolt on steroids with a hurricane to his back.
+A sequel is coming out where you play the side you are massacring. (shows the grey, cyberpunk, no good guys story) 

-Control system takes some time to get used to.
-No voice acting.
-It's a difficult game. Read this. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=535841178


Buy it. This is what games should be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986717975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1617, 'last_played': 1648182194}
review:
Best way I would describe this game is Hotline-Miami-esq but the context is you're space Blackwater PMC clearing out those pesky local armies for glorious capitalism and committing warcrimes and atrocities while doing so. You're a one vehicle army vs up to hundreds of opponents in a city, your upgraded whip and your isometric perspective been your only advantages. 

This game is as hard as you want it to be, you choosing from a wide range of vehicles from impossibly superheavy tanks to tuk-tuks with some machine guns on them and your pilot tweaking how dangerous the opposition is and how big the payout is. Ever seen some fancy weapon such as the 20mm M61 Vulcan BBBBBRRRTTTTT it's way through a column of armoured vehicles and turn them to scrap in weapons test footage? Now you can stick 2 of them on 15 m high Mech and turn a whole favela into mulch.

If you love games with deeplore, this game brings it in spades. You've got 4 factions with distinct histories and aesthetics, an expanded context that goes beyond the game, a lore audiobook for those who purchase the DLC and an active discord with the devs communicating to the public. The overall mood of the game is pretty dark and cynical, but that comes with the territory.

Has good options for both lengthy play sessions and short ones. Well worth a short if you enjoyed Hotline Miami or other challenging Action or Arcade games.

-玩了一阵子，没有遇到有头有脸的敌方ACE，机器人对轰关键元素-1

续作已经有steam商店页面了，预计2020年上，买呐！

author: {'steamid': '76561198337338668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1565649560}
review:
[b]I really dislike the control scheme of this game. Don't use a controller, it's too frustrating when adjusting firing arcs of the turret. You can change the Absolute/Relative control scheme (I refer to it as TPV/FPV) but it doesn't help with firing arcs. [u]The game itself is really great.[/u] [/b]

In regards for controllers, it essentially makes the control of the mech very un-intuitive depending on the perspective you are working on. 

Say you are playing the game from a FPV perspective in relation to the pilot in the mech, you move your right stick towards the left and you would expect the turret to rotate counter-clockwise. To the right, clockwise. To the upward or downward orientation, an adjustment of how close or far you want to aim your weapons (firing arcs). 

The game however takes on the TPV (Third-Person View) in that if you push your right stick to the left it will point to the left of the screen and if you continue holding it in that direction, you will essentially be telling your mech you want to aim your weapons further and further away. 

This has the effect of making it incredibly difficult to maintain your crosshairs at a fixed distance. Say if you wanted to run a circle around a static turret, you would have to constantly make sure you aren't accidentally changing the angle of your firing arcs as you run the circle. 

This becomes unbearable when you are using high-arc indirect fire like mortars since almost any change in the firing arc greatly affects the location and time it takes for it to come down on a moving target. 

The left stick also operates on this TPV, but since it's controlling the legs of the mech it isn't that bad and is appropriate as a twin-stick shooter game. 

My (separate) complaint for keyboard is that you can only really move in the eight directions of your WASD keys can take you. So if you wanted to really control the angle of your approach, it isn't appropriate. 

---

You could say, "just get used to it nub" and you would be right. It just saps the fun out of an otherwise extremely fun game when you have to wrestle with the controls to make it do what you want. [b] So I am going to be refunding this game, as I just can't enjoy it.[/b]

Obviously, many people like the game, even I really like it. I just hope that they put in an option eventually that lets you change how you would like to control the mech. 

So really, this is a peeve of my own when it comes to games. If you can get over it, buy the game, it's pretty great.


EDIT/REPLY: In response to comments on the control schemes in the game. (max 1000 characters for comments)

Repurchased but the relative controls don't actually fix my primary concern. 

To clarify, keyboard and mouse movement wasn't really a bother to me in the first place, merely the lack of granular adjustment that is inherent when using absolute. (Which for the most part is a near non-issue for me.)

The main concern stems from when I want to use a gamepad to play. 

The left stick is equivalent to WASD and the right stick does what the mouse would do in aiming. Even under relative controls, the right stick is still pushing the firing arc far out into the distance. 

It is difficult to describe; but say you are trying to rotate your turret from North (12 o'clock) to South (6 o'clock)  while maintaining a constant firing arc of 50 meters (arbitrary). To accomplish this in [b]both the relative and absolute control schemes[/b] you have to move the right stick from North to South. What ends up happening is as the turret rotates (at around the East 3 o'clock position), the firing arc changes at an increasing (near exponential) rate the closer it gets to the South (6 o'clock position).  

When you finally reach the South (6 o'clock position) your firing arc is no longer at the 50 meter mark but much [b]MUCH[/b] further than where you intended it to be. I am not even sure you will be able to maintain it at the 50 meter mark while in the rotation using a controller (I haven't been able to pull it off), and it often times necessitates a separate step where I have to essentially pull the right stick [b]BACK[/b] into the North (12 o'clock) position to correct the firing arc while [i]simultaneously[/i] preventing the entire turret from turning again back to the North (12 o'clock) position. 

That is really a major issue with high arc weapons and a slight/non-issue with flat arc weapons. 

I suppose I can still enjoy the game with KB/Mouse but I was really looking to getting the nostalgia from when I played these types of mech games on the venerable Sega Genesis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004010996', 'num_games_owned': 793, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1328, 'last_played': 1599589811}
review:
This was a game that I was never too sure if I was going to like it, even after it maintained a mostly positive rating and watching gameplay. But during the summer sale, I picked it up and I've been kicking myself ever since I started playing it.

Brigador is that game that seems like just another indie twin stick shooter but it feels like so much more than that to me. Probably biased as I'm still starved for mech games, getting my hands on a game that not only feels good to play,  challenging, and is well polished, but this is easily one of, if not the best indie title I've bought in a long, loooong time. This game feels like its got a lot of heart. From its design, to the controls, to the soundtrack, to all the lore entries.

The concept is simple, Great leader of a place died, and there is a company with a lot of money wants control of said place. So they're paying out to to do their dirty work. And to do so, available to you is a variety of tanks, mechs, and weaponry to get it done, and there is just so many different combinations to screw around with. And its rather straightforward, destroy objectives by any means and get out. So don't feel bad about leveling a city block, or a stray artillery shell landing on a pack of civilians, its covered in the contract.

I'm one of those people that generally never make reviews, but I felt like I really had to do it for this one here. If you get it, I hope you enjoy it.

EDIT: THEY ADDED A MAP EDITOR? NO ONE TOLD ME! Make your own districts and level them for your stompy shooty pleasure!

review:
Flat out the best indie I've ever purchased. Far....VERY far after release and the dev keep pushing golden updates and free content updates. The game was already greatly playable and holding itself up and still there are new things every now and then.

I feel actual guilt from buying just once.

If you like those top down isometric shooter games from SNES this is by far the best love letter.... better yet... above just a love letter, a proper iteration of the isometric shooter.

Pros:

+Mechs.

+Infinite gameplay value.

+Campaign mode in parallel with a freelance mode.

+Aesthetic are blasting 80s in the most groovy way possible

++The soundtrack is a masterpiece. I've put it in my daily work playlist at spotify as well as a purchase from the steam store. They deserve every penny.

+proper... I mean PROPER sprite graphics and gorgeous interaction with the environment including lighting. These are the best sprites I have ever seen.

+Tough if you want, easy if you want. VERY VERY tough if you want too.

+Interesting lore

+++Graphics

+Fun

++++Environmental destruction. You can just flatten out a suburb if you want. Every.Object...

Cons:

- Can be confusing at times if the action get too hectic.(very minor)


Underrated af game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079215654', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1686662061}
review:
昔PS1にあった「Future Cop: LAPD」という洋ロボゲーを思い出す、由緒正しい見下ろしタイプの洋ロボゲー
自機は二脚メックや小型のパワードスーツ、普通の戦車や高速ホバー、装甲皆無の武装3輪バイクからスクラップを組み合わせたトーテムポールみたいな重武装のタワー型タンクと何タイプかあり、武装もマシンガンや滑腔砲、曲射砲や腐食性ガス弾、レーザーやレールガン、建物や機体を貫通して敵パイロットに直接ダメージを与えるガンマ線放射機、振動波で建物を砂糖菓子のように粉砕してついでに人体の骨も粉末状にするらしく市民を打ったら赤い塵になっちゃう武器まであって豊富
ステージ内の建造物はほぼ全てか破壊可能でガソリンスタンドを誘爆させて敵を一網打尽にしたりできる。ちょこまか逃げ回ってる黄色いレインコートの市民も撃ったり踏んだりヤりたい放題

高火力高HPの鈍足機で蹂躙すると爽快な反面単調になってしまうが、それでも敵に囲まれると容赦なくゴリゴリ削られるのでそこそこスリリング。また敵にも視界があるためビルや森林の影に隠れたり煙幕でやり過ごすなど、防御力の低い小型ユニットだとステルス戦の立ち回りを要求される場面があってシンプルながら奥深い
とくにパワードスーツは集中砲火を食らうと瞬殺されるものの小さいので遮蔽物を盾にしやすく、正面対決だと撃ち勝てないタワー型タンクに対しては建物越しに曲射砲やガンマ線放射機で攻撃するなど戦術性が高くて楽しい

トランス系のBGMがクールで日本語ローカライズの質も高く、資金でアンロックできる設定や解説もエクセントリックで初代アーマードコアっぽいダークな世界観が垣間見えるのも○。とくに兵器や武器の設定は諧謔み旺盛なので読んでから遊ぶと愛着がわく

ただオートセーブはステージをクリアor失敗した時っぽく、トップメニューで終了を押してもただゲームが落ちるだけ。なので大量にアンロックをした後は一度出撃し、ローカルファイルにある「profile.json」というセーブデータファイルが更新されてるか確認してもいいかも

author: {'steamid': '76561198061679114', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1461, 'last_played': 1707347373}
review:
Isometric cyberpunk mech combat that's simple enough to dip into for 30 minutes at a time but also offers a good range of play styles and loadout options.

First of all, it's very stylishly presented. The pumping, synth-heavy soundtrack by Makeup and Vanity Set absolutely slaps and fits the purple and red, neon-soaked art style. The different factions and their vehicles all have very distinct looks, and the environments look surprisingly good for sprite work (I'm pretty sure this game uses sprites). The lore of Solo Nobre is rather well written and deep, considering it's almost entirely delivered through written data entries purchased from Acquisitions. The locations, factions, vehicles, weapons, and pilots all have their own entries which allow you to piece together the history of this city that you're fighting to liberate.

Some people seem to have gripes with the tank-style controls (i.e. A and D rotate your hull while W and S simply move you forward and backwards), but I enjoy them. It does feel weird at first given the isometric perspective (and the fact that the 'Agrav' vehicles move rather differently) but eventually you'll come to appreciate the added control it gives you over movement, not to mention it seems to add more tangible weight to your mech's ponderous footsteps. If it turns out these controls aren't for you, there is an option to switch them for more traditional controls.

Of course, it is the mechs, tanks and Agrav speeders that make this game so good. They all have their particular play style and personality, ranging from the humble Touro mech to the towering Treehouse (basically a stack of scrapped cars on tank treads) and everything in between. Complementing this formidable garage is an equally impressive arsenal. There are large howitzers and 30mm rotating auto-cannons for those who dismiss subtlety, short-range energy weapons for sneaky take-downs, or a railgun that can penetrate almost any cover for the snipers amongst you. I mentioned sneaking because there is something approaching stealth in this mech game, funnily enough. One piece of equipment allows you to cloak for a short period of time, allowing you to avoid raising the alarm to assassinate important targets or bypass large patrols.

Now, the drawbacks (at least for me) are few. One used to be that the levels got a bit repetitive after doing enough freelance contracts as they aren't randomly generated, although this is probably for the best. However, the developers just added a free level editor add-on, which I'm sure will alleviate this issue. 

My other main niggle is that all the weapon models of each class are the same. Although you can't see them that clearly on your mech because of the distance from the camera, it would have been nice if the more outlandish weapons had appropriately ridiculous designs, but this is only a small personal nit-pick. 

All in all, well worth the £14.99 price tag, pretty much that of your average niche indie title. Even more so on sale. Your contract is waiting, Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043637358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1563660904}
review:
With this new release an already great game (that was sadly overlooked) becomes even better. 

Brigador is a top down tactical shooter in which you select your own mech or tank loadout to then destroy certain objectives. Stealth, speed, precision shooting or just brute strength are all viable options here and there are many combinations of vehicles and weapons to choose from.
Besides the "Freeplay" mode there is a campaign mode available as well that teaches many of the basics and lets you get acustomed with predefined loadouts.
The graphics are reminescend of games like syndicate or c&c and beautiful to look at, the soundtrack is absolutely stellar.
To popular demand the developer patched in different control options but i would say that the "relative" tank controls are the way to go. The option is there for people who want it.

I liked this game back then in its original state and now that it has become even more accessible and bigger i pretty much adore it. Easy recommendation to anyone who is into mechs or shooters with slight tactical elements. Give this developer the sales they clearly deserve. Brigador is unique and awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080573793', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1616657283}
review:
I can't get enough of this game. I have adored isometric games since Crusader: No Remorse, Syndicate, Diablo, etc. Brigador combines that throwback isometric feel with a grittier MechWarrior where the battlefield is denser, more frantic, and filled with soft, squishy, civilian bodies. There is a huge variety of mechs, powersuits, tanks, anti-grav units, etc., each with diverse loadouts that can be further customized in Freelance. The loadouts can range from massive deathdealers that make you feel like a lumbering, nearly invulnerable god of war to tiny and fragile but agile and punchy bikes and powersuits that require careful strategy, judicious use of defense skills, well-planned ambushes, and white-knuckled, high-mobility strikes. Gameplay, on the surface, is relatively simple, but there is a deceptive amount of nuance. It's not too hard to drop in, but it can take several hours to really master. Fortunately, there are virtually no load times (although I'm on a 9th generation Intel with an NVMe drive), so you don't feel punished for failing a mission and jumping back in to nail it. Definitely try the campaign missions on all the different loadouts, as each presents unique challenges and gameplay styles for the same scenario.

The graphics are tiny, detailed, well-animated sprites that are punched up by surprisingly excellent lighting effects. Maps are varied and detailed as well, ranging from sprawling estates to residential strongholds and densely populated urban environments. However, the palette is dark and ruddy which looks great IMO but some friends have found it a little tiring and occasionally makes it hard to pick details out. The soundtrack is incredible. If you like synthwave or 80s/early 90s horror/action-inspired soundtracks (think: John Carpenter), I'd be surprised if you didn't find yourself popping on the soundtrack when chilling out.

The lore is dense, blood soaked, and morally ambiguous, but presented in a way that you can largely ignore it and just jump into the game if you don't care. I think of the violent socio-eco-political churning from MechWarrior, Syndicate, Eve Online, etc. It's very satisfying. Be sure to pick up the associated novel if you are a space opera or military sci-fi fan.

Now for the cons:

- Controls can have a surprisingly high learning curve, even if you're relatively experienced with isometric games. The reality is you'll deal with vehicles where the movement is separate from the turret/torso, and you can find yourself tangled up in the environment quickly when the fight gets heated particularly when dealing with multiple close-in threats. Definitely experiment with the plethora of orientation schemes, using a gamepad, or even slowing down the gameplay (there's a slider for that) before you give up, and also try to remember that after a little time you'll likely get a feel for it.
- Aiming arc. Weapons have different ranges, arcs, and you're dealing with targets of different heights (some aren't even attached to the ground ala anti-grav units). Even after playing it for a while, experimenting, reading the manual, the aiming system can still be frustrating. Again, this can be exacerbated by close-in swarms and anti-grav units. Perhaps a mild autoaim/targeting feature that you can toggle on might help for some players.
- Isometric perspective has some drawbacks for fast-paced gameplay. Sometimes you're trying to do a fast strike on a target and get away behind buildings, only to be caught on something on the backside of a building that you can't really "see". 
- Sound effects aren't bad, but they don't seem textured or particularly deep. Some individual effects can be a little underwhelming.
- Mouse-holing, stomping, ramming environmental structures to gain a tactical advantage can get a little tedious, especially if you're in a small and fragile unit.


A final thought: I would LOVE to see co-op in the follow-up, but I'll take it either way.

review:
This is one of my favorite games:

Never before have I seen an indie with so much love and care put single handedly into the logistics of committing war crimes. There is a huge range of mechs and weaponry you can choose from, dozens of levels and difficulty levels, and more lore then you know what to do with. In fact, the game itself is alright, but I think the lore behind this game is some of the best I've seen in any video game, indie or otherwise. Highly recommended, please do buy it.

review:
Awesome game! One of my new favorites.

Nice visuals. Great sounds and great soundtrack! The audiobook is a great compliment to the game and fits nicely while playing.

The story is simple on the surface, you blow stuff up for money, but is full of flavor for those that are willing to uncover it.

My only real complaints is that it feels like its missing some simple options that would make the game even better. Had to look up how to manually add a deadzone for Xbone controller, that was fairly annoying but pretty simple fix and is just a silly problem that for some reason was never fixed. You also have to dig into the game files to find the soundtrack and audiobook dlc, kinda odd they wouldn't make those more accessible.

Great game to pick up on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056277244', 'num_games_owned': 782, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 5139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1837, 'last_played': 1682872492}
review:
I'm not that great at going into detail, so I'll just say these few things:

There's a wide variety of weapons, vehicles, enemies, maps, pilots, and sequences of maps (for Freelance mode). These all help keep the game fresh and ensure there's always something new to try out.

The story of the game is quite in-depth and well-written. Yes, it's only in text boxes in the Intel and Briefing screens. I still recommend you read them.

The gameplay itself can be a bit hard to grasp - tank controls are in full effect and agravs follow the mouse - but once you get the hang of it, you'll be blowing up yellow-raincoated civvies in no time at all!

EDIT: One thing I want to bring up is how the gameplay really makes you behave in-character for someone who may have betrayed their own people for cash and a ticket off this soon-to-be-obliterated rock.

There are lots of enemies and only one of you, so managing how many enemies are attacking you at once is vital to survival.

Use special abilities to even the odds, whether that's by blocking the vision of foes, stunning them, becoming invisible, or even immediately hitting them for a large chunk of damage.

Rain down death upon the heads of your foes, or obliterate them by punching through walls before they know you're even there.

Ultimately, I highly recommend this game.

Also, this game has a deluxe edition that gets you the game's soundtrack and an audiobook - both of which I'd also highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979307063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3143, 'last_played': 1677405103}
review:
A fun little isometric shoot-'em-up game with a large variety of vehicles, weapons, and pilots stomping through finely detailed, fully destructible maps. Although there isn't any objective type other than kill it/blow it up, the game requires the player to use tactics, stealth, and understanding the strengths and weaknesses of your vehicle and weapons to get through missions in one piece.

There is also a lot of well thought out lore and additional information on literally every part of the game world, from the development of each weapon and vehicle through to the factions, pilot's backgrounds, and the world where the game takes place. There are no cutscenes or characters talking to each other during missions so all of the story takes place in the mission descriptions, pilot biographies and lore directories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026969135', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3150, 'last_played': 1670788144}
review:
The enviroment not only has breathtaking aesthetics, but also becomes part of the gameplay: being totally desctructible, you can develop a huge quantity of different tactics to exploit it. Keeping in mind strengths and weaknesses of the loadout you are piloting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990574800', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 7537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4017, 'last_played': 1665869852}
review:
[h1]"War crimes are all good fun, until they make you inhale"[/h1]
- a snip from description of "Ploughman" chemical mortar, which covers the area of impact in corrosive gas that rapidly melts anything within AoE.



Have you ever played Future Cop L.A.P.D. on your PS1? This is basically its spiritual successor.

BRIGADOR is an isometric vehicular combat simulator where you take control of one of Brigadors - mercenary contractors hired by "The Company" to sabotage the infrastructure and military cohesion of Solo Nobre independant colony, to make it easier for The Company to move in and secure the planet for whatever it is they want to do with it.

You get to play one of ~90 (!) unique vehicles ranging from small exosuits and treadbikes to large heavy tanks and mechs, armed with variety of weapons - conventional or otherwise - and you have only one objective: destroy marked targets and get out.

"Or just flatten the whole sector if you feel like it, we don't care LMAO" - The Company, probably.

You'll be deployed in a closed off sector with hostile forces present and given some key targets to destroy. You can go about it any way you want - you can either go surgical and only destroy what needs to be destroyed... Or you can take on the entire hostile regiment in the sector and kill absolutely everyone, civilians included. Company doesn't care, so you don't have to either.



The game is made mostly as a sandbox to have some casual carnage fun.

[b]CAMPAIGN[/b] mode is called so very loosely. There's no dialogue, no story, no anything. It's more like sets of challenges where you pick one of predetermined loadouts and must finish the map with what you've been given.

The money you earn are then spent in [b]ACQUISITONS[/b] menu where you unlock vehicles, weapons and pilots to play in sandbox FREELANCE mode where the real game lies.

In [b]FREELANCE[/b] mode you get to completely customise your experience:
Pilots determine enemy strength and composition (as well as paycheck), while your Loadout acts as extra difficulty modifier and determines your plastyle.
Larger heavy vehicles act as easy mode and rely on raw strength, while to smaller vehicles a single mistake can cost them their life and so they rely on stealthy hit'n'run tactics instead.

Then you pick which sets of maps you want to beat and out you go.
You can go for a casual single map run, or you can go for all 39 sectors in a row, where any damage taken to the hull is permanent so any scratch you suffered in sector 1 will still be with you in sector 39.



The gameplay of combat itself is simultanously simple and deep.
While your vehicle is slightly stronger than NPC counterparts - you are still not exactly invincible, so you need to pick your fights carefully.
Shots from behind deal extra damage.
Different weapons deal different amounts of damage to Shields, Hull or Environment.
You are always outnumbered and enemy patrols will check out any noise made.

Oh, did you just accidentally hit an oil pipeline, resulting in a chain reaction that blew up local oil refinery? Congratulations, half the sector heard that and now every hostile within a couple kilometers is converging on your position. Have fun!



Unfortunately no multiplayer or coop. Netcoding is hard i suppose.

review:
You've got giant mechs to pilot that flatten a building with a single stomp of their foot and fire weapons capable of committing at least ten warcrimes a minute. Little powersuits that slink through alleys, blasting off a salvo and disappearing into gaps in the walls. Tanks that plow their way through every wall, building, and civilian in their path with simple brutish horsepower. Hovering agravs that evade the enemy by flying where their grounded pursuit cannot follow.

Weaponry includes autocannons, lasers, artillery, rockets, shotguns, laser shotguns, sound cannons, camouflage, radiation emitters that melt metal and bone.

Level fields of brutalist office buildings, gaudy strip clubs, dilapidated slums, forested fields of sewage runoff, and highly explosive fuel depots.

Cyberpunk as fk, from the incredible synthwave music, to the corporation hiring you while charging you for the privilege, to the fluorescent lights glittering in the dark (until you crush them underfoot and blow up the power substation).

Watch out for the tuk tuks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993149333', 'num_games_owned': 557, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1990, 'last_played': 1703902398}
review:
This game is a wonderful and very pretty isometric vehicle combat game. There's actually a fair amount of depth to the game, as there's a stealth system of sorts and the variety of ways to customize the difficulty of the game makes replayability wonderful! Also, I'm a huge fan of the setting, and there's a TON of lore to unlock and read through. I'm pretty sure there's enough lore in the game to be a small book. Things from weapons and vehicles all the way up to factions have a lore entry, which really helps flesh out the world Brigador takes place in. Brigador is really a game I come back to time after time!

The only con this game has is that the game can kinda feel repetitive at times, as you're always doing the same few objectives regardless of map and loadout, and it can be a bit of a chore cleaning up a map, completing the last few things you need to do if you want to do all the objectives while all the enemies are dead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025438671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6975, 'last_played': 1687407523}
review:
Drenched in explosive mechanized violence, pulsating synth, and beautifully-established atmosphere, follow the path of a group of mercenaries dedicated toward cutting a swath of criminal destruction through the city of Solo Nobre.

Level city blocks with a single mortar, fire shark gas that melts concrete and metal, or use a humble gamma emitter to decimate the forces that dare to stand before your lucrative rampage.

Spend your hard-earned money on intricately written lore about your setting, from why the humble civilian dons a raincoat to massive artillery platforms from a spaceborne culture of hedonists. 

Great Leader has fallen.
