review:
What makes the Grass Grow??

BLOOD BLOOD BLOOD

Had bad day?  Play this game.  Your boss get in your face over something ridiculous?  Play this game.  Your S.O. driving you up the wall about this that and the other?  Play this game.  Go ahead and work out those frustrations by tearing ass through town destroying everything you see.  Become the Righteous Hand of God for a little bit while you play this.  Get it out of your system so you don't go and do something stupid.  


Seriously, though this game is very very good.  What hooked me is the lore and the way it is presented.  Fans of World Building will enjoy this.  if you are looking for a challenge look no further.  Choose from Mechs, Tanks, and Hovercraft as you blow up entire city blocks to take down your targets, get paid, and get the hell off world.  

Do you wear a yellow Poncho?

author: {'steamid': '76561198031452320', 'num_games_owned': 700, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1560375649}
review: This game is every mech lovers dream. You can ram, stomp, blast, gas, zap and emp your way to victory. You can chose slow, heavy mechs with a lot of firepower and go all rambo or you can chose fast, agile mechs with low armor and ambush your enemies. The mech designs are extremely cool and every inch of the world is crafted with extreme detail and love. The controls are admittedly hard (tanks are almost impossible to control) but they really don't keep you from getting into the game. This game is worth every penny, I suggest you give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198124014248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 2303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1122, 'last_played': 1637261486}
review:
Brigador is an isometric shooter which boasts an impressive selection of bipedal mechs, tanks and anti-gravity vehicles which can be outfitted with an equally impressive lineup of weapons which range from antitank guns and machine guns to more exotic choices such as lasers and corrosive gas.
It's important to note that this isn't a twin stick shooter, it can be controlled like one, but it's not recommendable. Tank controls are superior for more advanced play because vehicles tend to be vulnerable from the back and mounted weapons usually can't rotate 360°. This probably contributed to the game's lukewarm initial reception, but it adds much needed depth to the combat.
The bulk of the game's content are freelance missions which consist on procedural generated mercenary contracts of different length that usually involve the destruction of something as the main objective. The environments in Brigador are completely destructible and collateral damage is rewarded, it also facilitates certain tactics such as blowing up an apartment building to create a nice choke point. There's also a risk-reward system with harder difficulty pilots and crappier vehicles awarding more money at the end of a mission. 
Finally, I would be amiss if I didn't mention the soundtrack. It's one of the greatest synth soundtracks in gaming and fits the game very well. 
To conclude, Brigador is great and you should play it. I would recommend it to everyone who can stomach the controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037960452', 'num_games_owned': 3958, 'num_reviews': 423, 'playtime_forever': 1960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1908, 'last_played': 1624194586}

review:
Amazing game-feel, like Hotline Miami with explosions. The stealth mechanics are intuitive, and it's combined with the directional armour is great to cause a big explosion, hide around a corner, let a big mean tank roll past and then whip behind it and shoot out its undefended rear.

This review's posted when I'm about halfway through the campaign but the variety in vehicle controls, weapons and specials means a multitude of tactical ways to play each one.

The art style is beautiful and pain-stakingly detailed, with tons of little details that are easy to lose in the chaos, but weave together into a fabric that's greater than the sum of the strands. The soundtrack and writing are also great, and everything comes down to a game that just feels excellent to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971907582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 4410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1937, 'last_played': 1652586569}
review:
Brigador is a fast-paced isometric action game that delivers on its premise and then some.  The central conceit is that you play as a collection of mercenaries piloting a wide variety of mechs, tanks, or hovercraft (with an even greater variety of weapons) in a civil war raging on the planet-colony of Novo Solo.  The story is not terribly important (or really explained during gameplay at all), but the important thing to know is that the dictator who has been governing the planet for the last several decades has died, leaving turmoil and strife in his wake.  The lack of importance of the story, however, is fitting for your role: you do not care for the ideals or reasons of any side in the conflict.  You are there to earn a living in the destruction.  This is not Star Wars, where idealistic heroes fight nobly for the future of the galaxy.  This is the Spanish Civil War in space.

None of that really matters, though, because what really matters is the central gameplay loop of taking your chosen vehicle/weapons into an inhabited area and absolutely devastating it in whatever way the mission requires.  The main campaign provides a good series of introductions to game mechanics, different possible playstyles, weapon loadouts, etc, but really serves as an introduction to the main attraction of the game: the Freelance mode.

Freelance mode allows you to choose any vehicle and weapon loadout you want and take it for a spin in a level (or series of levels).  The variety of vehicles and weapons is very large, ranging from heavy, towering mechs to low-profile tanks, to zooming hoverbikes, and each one has its own mass profile, armor, shielding, speed, turning rate, and weapon mounts.  There is an even more impressive variety of weapons that you can mount on your vehicles: various mortars, lasers, machine guns, and heavy ordinance are complemented by quiet gamma ray emitters, EMP disabling devices, stealth camouflage, and more.  Naturally, each weapon functions differently and has different synergies with vehicle chassis and other weapons for you to unlock/discover.  I can't stress enough how satisfying the central gameplay loop is and how I keep coming back to experiment with different weapon/vehicle combinations.  The levels are also fully destructible, so you will get to see the scars that your brawls with enemies will leave on the streets, fields, and neighborhoods of Solo Nobre in your wake.   

What elevates Brigador above even its central gameplay, though, is the atmosphere.  The art direction, sound/music, and level design are gritty and thematic.  Every part of the design makes the setting and conflict feel authentic, and if you take the time to read the lore and written snippets surrounding the vehicles and weapons you are in for some of the best writing I've seen in a game.  The writing takes what could have been a generic (though very entertaining) isometric shooter and elevates it beyond the sum of its gameplay parts.  When you read the text describing the bureaucratic trevails of the military's engineers, the cultural significance of different areas in the city, or the smattering of the planet/city's history that is provided, all sprinkled with snippets of the futuristic evolution of Portuguese that the locals speak in the colony, it almost makes you feel bad when you level another apartment building with your cluster-bomb howitzer.  Almost.

review:
自己看看我的遊玩時數吧。這是一個自由度非常高的遊戲，各種載具與武器的配搭千變萬代，你可以駕駛像攻城塔一樣的坦克把一切移平；想乘坐靈巧的浮行車對敵將進行精準格殺？又可以；甚至你喜歡自我挑戰的話，選擇摩托車或是動力服看看著重遊擊、隱密的戰術行不行吧。

遊戲場景全都是人手打造的，然後他們卻容許你全面摧毀它們。一邊聽著頂級的Synthwave音樂，一邊在霓虹燈光照射下的賽博龐克都市環境中任意放肆，可說是下班後最佳的發洩方法。

別忘了閱讀一下那些引人入勝的故事背景文章，你會更能享受這個精心打造出來的科幻世界的。

author: {'steamid': '76561198062435291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 1051, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1623134687}
review: Одна из лучших мех игр за последнее время, она касается классической линии геймплея мехварриора. Рассчитана на небольшие забеги по 20-50 минут в день чисто для фана. Вся сложность в скорости игры она регулируется. Если ты слоупок как я ставь помедленннее если же нет - добавь... Обещаю будет пекло) Она из тех игр которые играются под настроение. Все в игре можно приобритать получая различные бонусы или информацию  для игры изначально игра непонятна так как разработчик придумал вселенную похожую на постсоветский мотив, но при этом грамотно вписал концепцию, единственный минус игрок не понимает кто он и зачем он это делает в кампании. и даже сама классификация отрядов открывается за игровую валюту, с *оплаты миссий*. Поэтому вникнуть достаточно сложно. Эх ей бы мультиплеер по аналогии с одной известной игрой с сега где робот полицейский трансформировался в ховер и обратно в робота. геймплей очень похож на помесь этой игры и классического батлтеча с сеги. Но при этом у него свой стиль улучшенный по сравнению с батлтечь - он даже больше напоминает книги этой серии нежели игровую версию, однако дело происходит немного в другой вселенной. Как минимум советую ознакомится с игрой вместе с длц. Тем более что игру перевели с помощью фанатов и студий ( а это уже о многом говорит) в правильном переводе по сравнению с оригинальным начальным авторским транслитом ) Но автор игры - чувак ты крут) Спасибо

author: {'steamid': '76561198212690213', 'num_games_owned': 1099, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1555943372}
review:
Game seems interesting and unique on the surface but playing it quickly reveals its downfalls. 

If you want to relive the nostalgia of old school 90s shooters with the same era art style and great music or want to play as a mech and blow up buildings and tanks this would be for you....though not at the £23 price tag.

Comparing it to this era though its offers nothing new, interesting or engaging at all:

-"Campaign" is a huge tutorial that repeats itself constantly on what all the controls are and uses immersion breaking scenarios to drill them home (units put in places outside the map just for you to fire at and being told "let the enemy spot  you just this once to see what happens"). It doesn't offer anything interesting and your reward for completing a mission is another mission. 

-Very weak yet wordy "story" that you have to buy units to read up more of the lore. No interesting characters or personalities that keeps it entertaining just blocks of long texts that tell you to shoot things.

-Boring repetitive gameplay with no interesting mechanics just shoot at units from behind or over walls. Stealth builds are useless thanks to spotters that quickly alert everyone to you so its always shoot then hide then shoot etc. Easy to play easy to master. No variety in the missions just blow stuff up. How about a stealth mission? or escort a convoy? Or how cool would defending a base with ally soldiers from a massive enemy force be? But no just shoot and run away. How about some environmental factors? Like sandstorms, earthquakes or lava, or maybe wildlife to watch out for?

-Artwork is great but every bland. All units look the same on all factions and the world looks very dark, grey and boring for a cyberpunk colony. I missed several buildings to blow up because They looked just like the regular ones.

-no bosses, loadouts are very similar, weapons are boring and very few "specials" so making your own mech gets dull quickly with no real purpose.

summery: a simple WASD shooter with old style 90s graphics and good music. In today's era there are loads more better indie games for a fraction of the price, don't get this if you want a 'armored core' style game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023138912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1586648729}
review:
Great Leader is dead. Solo Nobre must fall.

Equal parts a celebration of heavy 80's synths and gratuitous gore and action, and brilliantly written lore in a horrific and nihilistic dystopic sifi world.

If you like mechs, explosions, great world building, or all of the above, Brigador is a must buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970739339', 'num_games_owned': 676, 'num_reviews': 564, 'playtime_forever': 1294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1294, 'last_played': 1555126464}
review:
Do you like top-down or isometric shooters? Do you like used future settings with lots of different vehicles and weapons? Do you like blowing things up? Do you you like synthwave music? ... Do you like relentlessly bleak settings with no good guys, war crimes and nigh-unavoidable civilian casualties? If you answered yes to some of these things, you might like Brigador. If you answered yes to the last thing, you should probably get some help. Who hurt you anyway?

Brigador is set on the distant colony world of Nova Solo, specifically a single, violent night in its capital city of Solo Nobre. Until recently ruled by the dictator "Great Leader", its former corporate overlords, known to us only as the "Solo Nobre Concern", are offering a high-paying contract to anyone on the planet who can destroy the city's orbital defense cannons and open the way for their invasion. As the titular mercenaries, you will wreak unholy havoc across the city with an array of vehicles, weapons and special abilities against the numerically superior forces of the city's Loyalist military, rag-tag Corvid rebels, and mysterious Spacers.

Though I had heard of the game before, I was introduced to Brigador properly by some of its developers in person at PAX East, and they were quite nice to speak with. I came away with the game and some goodies and was glad to help them out after I'd learned about the game's troubled history. Purely on the basis of it's gameplay, Brigador is unique and engaging. I can recommend it to fans of isometric shooters, with some stipulations: It's a good deal more challenging the most games of it's type, as well as more tactically complex. You have available to you mechs, tanks and hover-tanks, and each can be configured to move arcade-fashion, where directional controls move you relative to the screen, or a more simulator-style setup where up and down move you forward or backward relative to the direction of your vehicle's base, while left and right steer. Directional damage is a factor: Mechs take less damage when their upper body is facing the enemy, while the other vehicles take less when their body is oriented thus. Mechs can stomp enemies or crouch to reduce incoming damage, tanks can use a boost function, and hover tanks can perform a Unreal Tournament 2004-esque ground slam maneuver. Weapons have limited ammunition and firing arcs, and projectile weapon arcs take into account the movement of the vehicle, and have different degrees of effectiveness versus armor, shields or structures, and even different penetration values. Enemies occasionally drop ammo and shield pickups, however these ammo pickups can be destroyed so watch your fire. 

Aside from the campaign mode with its fixed selection of characters and setups, there is also a Freelance mode where you may use any unlocked stuff you wish, including a lot that isn't usable in the campaign. Based on your performance in a level, you earn money that can be used in the "Acquisitions" menu to get new pilots, vehicles, weapons, freelance missions and bits of lore. This lore is extensive, especially for the genre: every pilot, vehicle and weapon has some story behind it, and with the additional lore entries concerning the planet, its government, history and individual districts of the city, it all paints a surprisingly detailed picture. There's even a novel and audiobook.

Unfortunately, the more one learns of Brigador's setting, the worse it gets. A culmination of the bleak military fiction of years past seen in settings like Battletech or Warhammer, Brigador somehow manages to be even darker, and lacks the latter's overt parody. It appears to be a setting with no moral justice, no humanity and no hope. The player characters are at best ruthless mercenaries who have turned on their brothers and countrymen for the promise of a corporate paycheck and possible "future opportunities" with said corporation. Some are fighting for their families or fleeing past mistakes, but others are vicious sociopathic monsters. The money doesn't even go to their next of kin if they get killed on the job. There are achievements for killing civilians. And what information comes through about the bizarre Spacer faction is more gruesome still. 

Some might ask the question of why any of that matters in a game like Brigador. I had a friend who refused to read the codex in Mass Effect, seeing it as a waste of time. I say that if a developer adds lore entries to a game, they intended for them to be read as part of the complete experience. A game with a story often has some kind of message, even if unintentionally. A lot of games I've played and enjoyed had a positive message, or at least one worth hearing. Take CrossCode or Wolfenstein for example. What then is Brigador's message?

A solid action title with great music but an alienating premise, Brigador stands, I think, as an example of why we need the "hopepunk" genre to gain more prominence in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019241778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 902, 'last_played': 1708281958}
review: Love this game. Hadn't played it in a while as I'd gotten stuck on a mission but I've come back to it and I'm falling in love all over again. Finding the right vehicle/weapon combo to match your preferences in Freelance mode is a blast and the game has this interesting approach to difficulty where the most powerful vehicles and the easiest pilots are the first to unlock and as you get better at the game you can unlock more challenging vehicles and pilots to ramp up the difficulty. Or just stick to the more powerful vehicles for less of a challenge but plenty of fun. Great way to blow off steam and relax as you run and gun your way through Solo Nobre, your own personal playground of destruction. Absolutely recommend. Good luck, brigador!

review: I do enjoy this game and the number of possible vehicles/mechs, primary, secondary, special and class skills make so many possibilities that can fit everyone's playstyle. I like to lob "nukes" on guys from far away while predicting their movements. Makes its so enjoyable when you get those really long shots especially when on the move. Then my second is a shotgun or smg like weapon. Enemies are also not the only thing you need worry about... So many times I've been duking it out with enemies only to blow myself up. Enviromentals are unforgivable in this game for sure as it is rare not to die from it in a med or smaller vehicle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002630530', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1554038355}
review: Terrific Game with a responsive dev!
developer_response:
Hello, glad you've enjoyed the game. Yes, you are correct that the lighting is a series of configuration files and could be used to overwrite the newer lighting revision. We haven't offered this in any substantial way in short because we are over capacity in trying to support this game and develop a new one at the same time.

What would be involved is getting the pack file from the desired version, dumping it (adding a shortcut in your brigador dir, and then appending \brigador.exe" -dumppack to the execution line). once you've dumped the pack, you'll need to overwrite the "weather" files that contain the lighting, then delete the existing pack, and then rebuild it from the loose files. This will revert the lighting. 

 You'll need the modding material linked here: https://www.reddit.com/r/BrigadorModding/comments/8v6h64/tools_brigador_modkit/

Part of the reason we haven't pursued this widely, not only because it is not particularly user friendly, but because you'd need to do this again every time the game updated, and we've got another update in the works.

Anyway, that's how you do it. Thank you for playing Brigador!

review:
Really cool game. Shaping up to be one of the better indie games that I have played on Steam.

I had been looking for a mech-type game, and I am really enjoying this one, in the short time that I have played. This game knows how much fun it is blowing up buildings with a mounted cannon - or blazing hot lead into an enemy through a flimsy wall. I watched some gameplay videos before purchasing, and my experiences matched what I saw pretty well. It can feel a bit repetitive after a while, though.

Also has a lot of interesting artwork and lore buried within the game: some is in the mission briefings and much more is unlocked with in-game credits.

This game uses some sort of java engine, with a 900 MB install size. I enjoyed this game on an ubuntu linux quad-core desktop with 8GB of memory. The levels loaded extremely fast, and I generally had no technical issues. However, the game prefers your use of a keyboard and mouse, and in fact, my xbox-type controller requires a configuration file fix, before it will work. Good music here, too, and you might consider getting the DLC soundtrack, since they are not available in the local files.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002873214', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1554548188}
review:
An excellent top down shooter where you get to stomp/drive around/through fully destructible environments in your chosen vehicle, which mostly fall into the categories of small/medium/large tanks, hovercrafts and mechs. 

The music is a selection of banging synthwave tracks that accompany your rampage, along with the suitably loud and satisfying crunches of rubble and explosions.

The setting and lore is interesting and well realised once you delve into the "acquisitions" section where you can unlock new pilots, vehicles, weapons, and missions, as well as lore and descriptions for all the aforementioned, giving insight on why the people and vehicles of the setting look the way they do, what motivates each pilot and faction generally, etc.

After thinking about it for a while I realise that this game actually reminds me somewhat of a top down version of the old n64 game Battletanx, but that's just a random insight from yours truly.

Also change the game speed to 100% and change movement to relative to experience the game how it was originally intended, except agravs if you're like me (I am too stupid to use agravs with relative movement).

author: {'steamid': '76561198041108401', 'num_games_owned': 1219, 'num_reviews': 496, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1551804806}
review:
[u]Conclusion[/u]
I am disappointed. The trailers showed so much action, so I expected that, but it turns out this is rather about stealthy tactics taking it slow and sneaky. You can play it fast-paced, but even with the fastest vehicles (5 diamonds), 8 enemies chasing me, pilot difficulty 10 and alarm ringing the combat doesn't get intense enough to bring me into trouble (provided I use my preferred loadout). I can always pick up enough shield items, dropped by the enemies, so they never deplete my green health bar. It's not challenging enough for me. I feel bad for giving this a thumbs down. It's a really good game! But I want to warn and say that it's not for everyone. Whoever is with me here should try PION for an intense twin stick challenge.

[u]What I like[/u]
+ unlike most twin stick shooters your weapons here need time to turn to the position of your mouse cursor. Hey realism!
+ your two weapons have different turning speeds. Therefore you have two indicating projectile lines which you need to distinguish. There's a red and a bl...ah no, sorry, we have 80's style and this is Neon Magenta and Dark Sapphire. 
+ more unlike most twin stick shooters your projectile suffers gravity! Hey realism again! The height of each projectile is simulated. Your shooting angle in height is determined by how far your mouse is away of your vehicle. Therefore the right direction is not enough to hit your target, also the height angle must fit. But guess what, all targets have a height too! Most targets are big and easy to hit, except these tiny humans scurrying about the place.
+ projectile path is also dependant on your vehicle speed. They get a bit of your vehicle momentum of the moment when you shoot. Hell, this realism, omg!
+ the camera follows your mouse cursor / crosshair, but keeps your vehicle in the screen at all times. This way you can look ahead, but only where your mouse cursor is. Just like spying glasses. God damn realism again!
+ the direction of your weapons mounted to the cockpit and the direction of your drive below are independant of each other (for the default Mech vehicle and others too, but not all). Your movement depends on which direction your drive faces at the moment. Woah, so much realism! A yellow arrow indicates your drive direction. Also your vehicle has a turning angle. Often drive and cockpit have opposite directions. That makes the movement sometimes a bit off but you get used to it quickly.
+ everything is destroyable. From every building over each tree and bush to even the tiniest blade of grass can be erased with your firepower.
+ Instant loading! Progressing to a new map or loading new parts of the map does not take any time. At least it did for me. Instantly there, no waiting, wow.
+ Instant window change! Even when playing in fullscreen (not full windowed) it takes no time to switch between game and desktop. For me this is the first game which does that so wonderful. *applause*
+ tons of loadout possibilities (pilot, vehicle, primary weapon, secondary weapon, special gadget) lets you adapt the game to your playstyle. Go fast-paced with a small vehicle, tank-like with a big vehicle, stealth-like with camouflage featured vehicles or go random and play different each run.
+ pumping 80's Synthwave beats. Not as pumping as Carpenter Brut, more relaxed, but still very nice!
+ pixel-y and Sim City-ish / Command and Conquer 2-ish art style
+ This game is intended to be played with mouse and keyboard (The game says so). Controller is possible but not recommended. Controls are fine for me!

[u]What I dislike[/u]
- the game is called Brigador and the tutorial explains, that you don't go on the intended way, because you're a Brigador and push your way through. The game invites and even tells you to smash buildings to get through, but often punishes you for doing that really hard. Often you smash a wall or building and nearby buildings explode and do massive damage, often killing you and killing your whole long played run! Game Over only because of that one mistake. Doesn't seem so inviting for me to act like a Brigador!
- fast AGRAV vehicle "Buckler" with double Auxiliary "Broilers" is overpowered. Everything is too easy with this. These double equipped hit scan weapon makes ballistic projectile movement redundant and has also still a long reach.
- It seems this game wants you to play it safe and sneaky. I hate stealth games, sneaking around avoiding the fights. I want the fights! I want action! I thought this to be more intense, but it's rather tedious :-(
- Boring walking through already cleared areas. On most maps you won't find the best way to clear all targets within one straight path, but you need to go back or search for your target. Then you have to walk through some places again. This is enough to get me out of action and a bit impatient.
- There are many loadout options to be unlocked which set you in a really weak situation being vulnerable, but gives you extra reward for it e.g. "Varlet" the most expensive vehicle in the game costing 20 millions, but doing almost no damage and being very low on health/shield, slow and offering only weak weapons. There are more options like that. I like a risk/reward system to adapt the difficulty to your skill, but I want to make the enemies stronger, the environment more hazardous, not myself slower with only few options. This leads to stealth gameplay.
- If I was in charge of a corporation to buy military equipment intended to kill, I would not spend 2,000,000$ without any description of what I get. The description of your unlockables are only displayed after you purchased them and there is no refunding! I bought the mortar weapons and hate them, because they are in the air for AGES before coming down and doing damage. I guess this is only for siege or something like that. However, I wish I would get to know what I was buying before actually buying it!
- music is often not beating in action enough. Often chill, often even only ambiant sounds, that's too slack for my taste. 

[u]What I suggest[/u]
The campaign is basically a very long tutorial. Complete the first 5 campaign levels until you feel you know enough to begin and then hop into Freelance mode. This is the real game. DON'T make the same mistake as I by picking the cool looking pilot "The Auditor", this will remove all enemies off every level and make it a boring walking simulator. This pilot is only for map knowledge purposes and is NOT fun. Take the ugly looking one "Norman Osberger" instead, this will get you into the real gameplay. Also, don't take the default mech, it is slow as hell. Take one of fast anti-gravity "AGRAV" vehicles e.g. "Buckler" with higher speed rating, so that you can finish a level MUCH faster. With the Auxiliary weapon "Broiler" double-equipped things get easy. Buy the special gadget "Audio-Kinetic Pulse" as soon as you can. This destroys whole buildings and several enemies with only one shot! (Also OP) This will spare you much time and ammo (this has infinite ammo) which you need to destroy the target buildings. You could smash them with your slam attack (Space) but you risk blowing up with the whole building explosion ending your run. Don't do that.

[strike]I don't understand. Weren't there supposed to be enemies in this game?
I spent 50 minutes in Freelance mode without spotting any enemy!
I was NOT attacked by anyone! That was like a walking simulator, walking from target to target...reaaallly slooooooww...with oooobstacleeeees to smash before i can walk oooooon... *urgh* that was really boring. 

I thought this game was supposed to be fast-paced with intense fire fights!?!? I'm really surprised within almost 1 hour it didn't deliver ANYTHING (☉_☉)
You know, I don't have so much spare time to wait hours before a game begins. If I have time I want action, and this here is the very opposite. Or did I miss something?

I really dig the Sim City pixel-y art style and game mechanics, though.[/strike]
developer_response:
The 1st available pilot in Freelance mode is 'The Auditor' which removes all hostile spawns—the idea being to give players a stress free way to explore maps and test weapons/vehicles.

Start with the pilot 'Norman Osberger' and as you get tougher pilots I promise you the action will ramp up. If you want really fast paced action stick to smaller vehicles with higher move speeds or if you want everyone to come to you go with big vehicles and get the loudest weaponry possible; you'll aggro half the map when shooting but can wipe the whole screen in a few seconds.

If you haven't played through the campaign yet it will work you through the basics until the higher tier missions which can get really challenging especially in smaller vehicles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998404426', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1731, 'last_played': 1623729149}
review:
BRIGADOR: UP-ARMORED EDITION - 9/10

Basic Info
-----------
Genre(s): Twin Stick Shooter
Game Length: 5~ hours
100%: Length: 20+ hours
Achievement Difficulty: 6/10
Missable Achievements: Yes (One of them, detailed in review)

Brief Synopsis
--------------
The Great Leader is dead and it's your job as a Brigador to finally liberate the city he held such immense control over: the dreary, cyberpunk wasteland that is Solo Nobre.

Pros/Cons
---------
+ Addictive gameplay
+ Enormous customization
+ Fantastic soundtrack
+ Huge amount of content
+ Great setting
+ Interesting, diverse achievements

- Several minor issues (detailed in review)

Details
-------
There is just so much to say about Brigador that I can't sum it up in bullet points so i'm going back to my old style just for little bit with an in-depth review.

Brigador is an isometric twin stick shooter. It's not exactly top down like most others but rather a top and side view. In Brigador, you spend 95% of your time blowing things up, fighting multiple armies, destroying cities and ultimately liberating the game world. I honestly don't even know where to start reviewing this but I guess i'll review it in the order I experienced it.

The first option you get is a Campaign mode. The Campaign mode contains around 10~ish tutorial missions, 18 standard missions and around 10 more extra, more difficult missions. Upon completing the tutorial missions where you're assigned one specific machine, the later campaign missions allow you to choose from 3 then eventually 4 different machines each with their own strengths and weakness and i'll be talking about this a bit later. The campaign missions are almost all the same, generally having you destroying some building(s) or killing certain units. It's pretty repetitive but the setting and the soundtrack as well as the sheer addictiveness of the gameplay is easily enough to keep you going.

Speak of the soundtrack, it's full of amazing retro/synthwave/cyberpunk beats and the soundtrack alone is worth buying if you're into that sort of music. It's high octane and pumps you up, is super catchy and is always a blast to listen too.

Upon completing (or even failing) any mission you'll be given a bunch of money, which can be spent in the "Acquisitions" menu on all different kinds of things including different vehicles, primary and secondary weapons, different pilots, freelance missions and even game lore.

So now, what makes the game so interesting? Using your hard earned money allows you to open up more options in the Freelance mode where you can buy different missions (including the 18 standard campaign missions) and use your own custom machine in order to tackle it and this is where the game TRULY shines. No matter what machine you make with what weapons, it will always be REALLY good at something but also, REALLY bad. Some machines are far more difficult to pilot than others but the reward for using them is super high.

Do you want to pilot a literal siege tower of death that obliterates anything even resembling an enemy? Sure, but you're be moving no faster than a parked car. What about an assassin style of invisibility using deadly, one shot one kill hit and run tactics with a high speed machine? Of course, just don't expect to survive multiple hits from even the weakest machine. Do you want to drive a tank with nigh impenetrable armour that can literally roll over even the toughest enemies? You go for it but don't expect to be able to move in any other direction than straight towards the enemy. What about a small, 3 wheeled jalopy with no redeeming qualities other than the fact that if you manage to kill someone with it, you've shamed their family for generations to come? You go girl. The vehicle customization is ENORMOUS and the campaign gives you a taste of the different playstyles but the freelance mode is where the game truly shines. The list of weapons is endless, from straight up machine guns to bombs that rain death from above, to sweeping lasers, penetrating ballistic missiles and even poison over time that can travel through buildings.

Apart from the actual playable vehicles, you can also purchase "lore", which tell you more about the game world and story. EVERYTHING you buy including all weapons and machines has a piece of story information attached to it. Nothing is just "there", everything is a part of this large, expansive world. You can also purchase Pilots which act as the difficulty for your freelance missions. Since all freelance missions have the same objective, if you want a harder challenge you'll need to buy a new pilot. The default pilot makes it so not a single enemy even spawns in a freelance mission, but the more expensive pilots you buy, the harder the missions become but the better the payout is. The payout can then be used to buy more pilots, or vehicles, or missions in an almost endless cycle.

It's not so much the game play itself that is addicting but rather your own creation that makes the missions interesting. Sure, blowing up hordes of civilians and decimating entire cityblocks never stops being fun, but doing it in your own creation is pure joy.

Achievement wise, the game has such a diverse achievement list ranging from super easy to very difficult (including a 39 missions mission freelance run where death means you start again), with achievements for playing with certain machines with certain loadouts so you can examine different playstyles, to purchasing everything, beating the campaign with ALL machines (which is really quite difficult). It's an amazing list and I haven't seen one this good since I played RUINER (which is actually a very similar game to this).

On TOP of all this, Brigador gives you FULL access to it's developer console and game editor with the tap of a button allowing you to create new weapons and edit stats on the fly (although it does require some practice). With this, the customization literally becomes limitless.

So what about the problems? The controls aren't the best. There are 4 control options with none of them ever feeling "good" to use. The default controls means pressing W moves you to the top of the screen whereas using the old "tank" controls means pressing W moves you in the direction your vehicle is facing. Because the loadouts can be radically different (from tanks to hovercrafts to walking bipeds where the top and bottom control separately) you just have to end up accepting the control scheme you pick will have some serious flaws. The game can also be quite frustrating especially if you plan on going for all the achievements, with some of the campaign missions feelings almost impossible with some of the vehicles you need, but it does feel good when you finish. There's a missable achievement, missable as in you have to do it during a freelance mission but it's almost impossible to get and may be bugged so I suggest using the console to grant it.

All in all Brigador is one of those games where you'll play for a bit, get frustrated, then turn it on again 15 mins later just do get one more mission done and the next thing you know you've 100%ed the game and haven't even realised how much fun you had until it's over.

Buy it.

review:
Not in any way shape or form a roguelike, which is what it is advertised as.

The game as is is ok, I guess, but it's not what it says it is and it's not what I wanted.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997175557', 'num_games_owned': 735, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 11345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4639, 'last_played': 1635664933}
review:
このゲームは2足歩行メックや戦車、反重力ホバー戦車にのってソロ・ノブリで戦うゲームです。

あなたが選べる機体には多種多様なものがあり、巨大な戦車、小さな戦車、武装バン、バイク、大きなメック、パワードスーツ、ホバー戦車、ホバー車などがあり、搭載できる武器のサイズや移動速度、防御力が異なります。
武器もマシンガンから榴弾砲、レーザー砲、レイルガン、ショットガン、レーザーショットガン、化学物質ランチャー、壁を突き抜けるガンマ線放射器など様々なものがあります。もちろんわたしはガンマ線放射器が好きです、この武器は持っているだけで戦争犯罪に問われてしまうそうです。

ソロ・ノブリには敵や建物、そして民間人がいますが、こういったものを壊したり殺すことでボーナス金が得られるので殺しましょう。　

このゲームは基本的に1対多の戦いとなり、たくさんの2足歩行メックや戦車、反重力ホバー戦車があなたを襲ってきます。　敵を殺すことでシールドを回復できるので、ダメージをあまり受けずに殺していくのが大事です。
市民が住んでいるビル群や家にむかってクラスター爆弾迫撃砲を撃つと、大量の瓦礫とともに跡形もなく粉々になるのでおもしろいです。　ブリゲイダーからは低所得層が住んでいるあばら屋も特権階級が住んでいる豪邸も耐久力が違うだけで、だいたい同じなのです。
民間人に向かってマシンガンやロケット砲やガンマ線を撃つと死んでしまいますが、$50を得られるので殺しましょう。　わたしはホーンを鳴らして市民を警戒させて一箇所に集めたあと、爆発系の武器で一度に虐殺するのが大好きです。

ゲーム内でアンロックできる世界観テキストはかなりの量がありますが、質のよい日本語化がされているので安心です。　このゲームに出てくる派閥はプレイヤーの所属するSNCも含めて4つありますが、どれもろくな奴らではないというのがテキストを読むとわかります。


私は昔から、クールな戦車や二足歩行メックにのって戦争犯罪的な破壊と虐殺がしたいと思っていたので、このゲームは大当たりでした。　みなさんもこのゲームを買って破壊と戦争犯罪にまみれた生活を始めましょう！

author: {'steamid': '76561197962502316', 'num_games_owned': 2676, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1658096302}
review:
GREAT LEADER HAS DIED. SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL.

Neon lights, an authority violently overthrown, and buildings that crumble like they’re made out of ash under your mech’s stomping feet, all to a synth soundtrack. Brigador knows exactly what it wants to be. The good news is that it mostly achieves its vision, with a couple hiccups.

You play as a mercenary collecting a paycheck by completing missions in support of the Solo Nobre Concern. They’re offering a ticket offworld if you can help them overthrow the factions controlling the city of Solo Nobre. You’ll do this in an isometric action game from a variety of mechs, tanks, and anti-grav vehicles with dozens of weapons.

At first look, Brigador might remind you of the classic Strike series (Jungle Strike, Desert Strike, Nuclear Strike, etc) of helicopter action games, due to the vehicle selection and third-person isometric perspective. That’s not a terrible comparison, but Brigador offers a lot more. Not only is there more vehicles, weapons, and pilots, but more depth to the combat.

You’re armed with two weapons, and an auxiliary ability. Each weapon has its own fire rates, and their own behaviors. There are the standard machine guns and cannons, but also mortars, lasers, and shotgun-type weapons. Your mouse controls not only set the direction of fire, but also the range of fire, so you can launch mortars over walls, spray smoke canisters in semi-circles or lines, and shoot over or past enemies. This is cool in a lot of ways for the level of control it gives you over the destruction you’re going to rain down, but it complicates what is otherwise a fairly simple action game. Instead of just pointing in the direction of the bad guys and firing away, you’ve got to actually consider their distance and aim so that you’re not shooting in front of or over them. If you can’t get this and just treat it like any twin-stick shooter, you’re going to have limited, frustrating success.

The campaign mode offers a couple dozen missions with premade pilot/vehicle/weapon combinations that are fun, but it’s kind of training wheels for the operations mode, which is much more freeform. Operations mode lets you select any pilot, vehicle, weapon you desire, and go on a multi-map romp with an open set of objectives and building difficulty. Early options and low level pilots offer easy difficulty and a couple maps to stomp through, but unlocking high level pilots will greatly increase the resistance and later operations become endurance runs to see if you can manage to keep up your health and ammo count across several sprawling maps.

The music of Brigador is also notable for perfectly pairing this dystopian mech action with Vanity and Makeup Sets synth sounds. It’s a beautifully drawn game with a moody soundtrack that comes together very well. However, some of the weapon sounds could use some work. In particular, big cannons don’t really sound like the size they are. They nail the whirring sound of very large machine guns though, which is great.

Brigador is a great action game after you’ve figured out its quirks. It’ll frequently overwhelm and stomp on you, but rarely to the point of frustration. Your implements of carnage come in a large variety, so there’s a ton of action to be had. It’s only slightly marred by disadvantaged by doing more than action games of this nature normally do when it comes to weapon control, but that’s a gift once you’ve got the hang of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045005161', 'num_games_owned': 1913, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1529919910}
review:
Be Godzilla... but in a Mech with guns. 10/10

Am I drunk or just a bad driver? These controls are pretty difficult to get used to on a keyboard. I'm guessing it is probably more logical on a controller with a twin stick. That said, this game is a lot of fun to play! 

You have to destroy everything. The sounds and overall atmosphere make it a lot of fun to do. Very satisfying explosions and overall mayhem! 

You can drive various Mechs and each has a big arsenal of guns. Get destructo happy and just wreck the whole neighborhood, the buildings, the trees and the little guys that are frantically running around... oh and let’s not forget the actual enemies. You'd almost forget about them, since destroying everything else is already so much fun. I'd sometimes forget the main missions and just run around crushing everything. 

There are multiple possible strategies per scenario. Mine was simply to destroy everything you encounter. Perhaps you are more of the sneaky, stealthy type. 

The graphics style is really enjoyable, crispy clear sprite design with a splash of neon, along with a great 80's Stranger Things type soundtrack. All these elements give Brigador the final finishing touch. 

I am oversimplifying the game with this review, since there is a lot more to discover. Campaigns, the story, freelance mode, customization, multiple strategies and more.

If you enjoy loads of missions, strategy and destroying stuff Godzilla style, this one is definitely for you!

The Good:
+ Destroy everything 
+ 56 Mechs and customization
+ Many scenarios 
+ Graphics, sounds and just amazing detail
+ Good backstory and lore
+ Many hours of game time

The Bad:
- Difficult controls you need to get the hang of

How long to beat Brigador: Up-Armored Edition?
The main game story can be completed in about 8 hours, the main game + the extra's a total of 30+ hours of gaming fun. For completionists a whopping total of 230 hours. That is a lot of game time for your money.   

15 minutes of no commentary gameplay so you get a good impression of the game:
https://youtu.be/rqVC5u4lbfg

author: {'steamid': '76561198012187596', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 6678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3901, 'last_played': 1680592059}
review:
A state of the art war crime simulator. Because sometimes, you just need to take a giant mech into a city center and blow everything up. And I mean everything.

In all seriousness, Brigador is a rather enjoyable isometric vehicle shooter game. There's plenty of bang for your buck.

GAMEPLAY
As stated above, it's an isometric vehicle shooter. You have 3 broad classes of vehicles to work with: tanks, mechs and anti-grav units. Each has their quirks in how they handle, but they all draw from the same pool of weapons and special abilities.
+ Basic gameplay is just...fun
+ Large number of weapons to play around with
+ Vehicle types offer just enough variation in gameplay
+ Freelance mode allows for near endless numbers of challenging scenarios
- Not much depth or variety to the missions/gameplay (spoilers: blow _everything_ up)
- Default controls are rather iffy
- Can be a pain in the ass finding stragglers
Look, the gist of Brigador is to blow everything up. If it moves, blow it up. If it doesn't move but stands higher than a few centimeters off the ground, blow it up. If you're in doubt, the answer in Brigador is yes, to blow it up.

How you go about this varies. In the campaign, you'll be choosing from a few preset loadouts for each set of missions. In Freelance mode, you can choose your own loadout, appropriate to the chassis you're using. Each weapon has something going for it- rate of fire, raw damage, AOE, DOT, efficiency vs shields, range, ammo supply are among the factors taken into consideration.

There's a lot of fun to be had here, and it can be pretty challenging, too. Choosing when to go loud on a mission, the effective use of terrain, understanding how to best use your loadout all factor into success.

But if you're sort that wants to clear all objectives on a mission, be prepared for some frustration, though. Not all enemies get drawn into the initial fracas you create- each faction has units that are especially irritating to find. Tiny infantry units with one; stealth drones with another; another with vehicles that resemble some props on the maps.

You may also find yourself asking...."but is there more?" And the answer is no. It's not a meme. The only mission types are to blow stuff up. If you can't find ways to challenge yourself, this game will probably have rather limited replayability for you.

GRAPHICS
Clean and crisp visuals. A distinct retro feeling that makes me think back to the glory days of Red Alert 2 and TS. I'm sure there are better lookng 2.5D games, but this one is no slouch.
+ Vibrant and detailed environments
+ Excellent lighting effects
- Many tanks, mechs share common chassis'
- Maps have no height variations
I'll be honest, when I first started playing, it didn't even realize the vehicles weren't sprites or voxels until I noticed the way they interacted with the various light sources on the maps. And I love it. Maps are surprisingly detailed: city maps in particular caught me by surprise, with how densely packed they are. And the level of destruction possible makes playing around in them all the more enjoyable.

AUDIO
+ THE MUSIC
- the music eventually ends if you stick around too long on one map
Welcome to synthwave heaven. Brigador has an absolutely amazing soundtrack. It's perfect for the havoc you'll be causing. Sound effects are pretty much average, though.

OTHER
The game also has a rather extensive lore section. You can read about each pilot, vehicle, weapon, faction, location, so on so forth, as you see fit. While the game is hardly story driven, many of the blurbs are quite entertaining to read.

review:
While I acquired the game for free in a giveaway, I still feel it is well worth buying. It has a deliciously immersive lore to go with -everything-, which adds an extra layer of fun to the destruction. The twin stick nature is a little rough to get used to at first if you're a KB&M player like myself, but you quickly get used to it and can lay down all the fire and fury you vehicle has in its loadout. 

The soundtrack is also very amazing, the cyberpunk/synthwave tracks make your relentless onslaught all the more fun as you destroy the environment simply because you can. Some missions you can do multiple times with other vehicles, for those who are completionist players like myself. 

TL;DR of it, great game, great music, lots of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198309345115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 6433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2208, 'last_played': 1695344700}
review:
Okay, I can't quite recall when I saw this game but the title art definitely caught my eye. It didn't take long for me to establish that I wanted this game, especially when I started watching the vids and reading the reviews. It sounded really cool, and I certainly don't regret going and buying it. Not one bit.

I absolutely love the gameplay of Brigador, and the music that goes along with it just makes it that much better--plus I get to listen to the latter whenever, wherever, which is totally radical. Perhaps my favorite thing about this game is that it brings me back to my childhood, playing good ol' MechWarrior 3050 on my SNES, a game I still enjoy to this day. Of course, it's not the same game--not in the slightest--and it's not the same universe, either.
Indeed, Brigador is set in its own world, and it's absolutely full of lore and little details that just make you wonder how much thought went into creating it. My hat--if I had one--would be tipped far too much to remain on my head, this game's just that awe-inspiring to me.
Brigador also fixes a problem that other game had for me, which was the length of the campaign and the level of customization afforded to the player. Brigador's vehicles all have different capabilities, some to make things easier for you, others to make things harder, but they all have their place if used correctly (yes, even the Varlet). It's glorious how much freedom you have in flattening the environments (and the civilians) of Solo Nobre.
-As a side note, the Auditor pilot available in Freelance mode allows you to experience the game without enemy spawns, which is very useful for learning how to work these things if you need some time to adjust to a new loadout without worry of getting shot up.

Overall, I'd play this game a whole heck of a lot more if I had more hours (and energy) in a day. I love it too much for my own good, but I just don't have the time lol
10/10, would totally recommend to anyone else who loves blowing stuff up with wild abandon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198330016095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1544500762}
review:
Наглядное пособие, как нужно взять хорошую задумку и убить её. В этой игре собрали почти все, что нужно для хорошей меха-игры: мощные стволы с проработанным ощущением стрельбы, зрелищную разрушаемость, бодрый саундтрек, симпатичную и хорошо прорисованную графику, кучу интересной и неплохо прописанной информации о персонажах. 
И совершенно забыли о каком либо сюжете и разнообразии. Да что там сюжет, даже набор каких либо разнообразных миссий спас бы ситуацию. Кампания? Кампания это один большой и растянутый туториал, проиграть в котором не сможет даже ваша бабушка.

Вот и получаем в итоге то, что получаем:  набор отдельных "миссий", игрок запускается в песочницу с некоторым количеством беспомощных мобов, на половине карты у него кончаются боеприпасы(включая запас на складе), и дальше приходится либо долго, нудно и уныло давить домики ногой за 100 денег каждый, либо идти к выходу и закругляться.
И да, все миссии представляют из себя одно и то же. Весь смысл игры, в итоге, сводится к тому, чтобы заработать еще денег, чтобы открыть нового пилота, почитать его забавное досье и вновь играть в "день сурка".

А теперь спросите себя, готовы ли вы отдавать довольно таки немалую сумму за фантик от конфеты(даже если он действительно красивый) без наличия самой конфеты?

(А ведь некоторые даже сравнивали ЭТО с Future Cop LAPD...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198049768171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1574966448}
review:
Broken by design but really enjoyable. 
What Brigador does well is pay homage to and emulate old isometric shooters. I love the aesthetics of this game, the soundtrack and gameplay feel is OK. It's fun to rampage around and destroy things. There is an attention to detail which can be admired. Brigador is a good effort, but falls flat in the packaging as well as the tactical aspects of it. 

Broken in many aspects of it's design and all of it reeks of post-completion crunch to pad the game time up:
-Campaign default difficulty seems to be set to as low as possible, which is a bit off-putting considering it's the first thing people would try and as it stays pretty much the same through out , it makes the campaign seem less exciting in it's length
-Then there's the AI which does fight back but many a times forgets that the reason we have such a selection of mech is that they are supposed to play differently, and running the lightest units at my heavy mech barrel line will get them dead.
 
- BUT THATS NOT THE GAME, no no no! The idea is that you get to see different loadouts and vehicles in campaign before you buy them to be available for Freelance missions, along the pilots which act as difficulty and payout level modifiers, that's the actual intended game, despite the campaign being on top of the list. I'll presume this might do something for the AI as well but I haven't unlocked highest difficulty pilots and missions yet to tell.

- All this is poorly conveyed, as well as everything else being bit of a padding with you having to unlock well written but quite pointless info about the items and story to know it. Which is all pretty much optional, granted, but then you have your actual factions backstories locked down and that's really counter-intuitive, like, why do I have to fight you to get that story? Isn't knowing that sort of prequisite of wanting to know more of this setting?

Overall , I still enjoy my time with it when I get to play. For a HumbleBundle tie-in it's great value, and I'd hope to see sequel with a bit more polish and variety on the campaign missions, standard difficulty slider for campaign so you'd have that option for getting challenged right from the start, better sneakier AI, maybe picking and swapping to enemies dropped weapons would be a cool addition, sneak escape missions etc etc. This has potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012311486', 'num_games_owned': 2782, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1675258328}
review:
「でかいマシンに乗っていると、人間なんざちっぽけな肉塊なんだなって思うワケだ。」――『鋼の足、肉の腕、機械の脳』～[アルゼンチン・1971年]

偉大なる指導者は死んだ――君は巨大企業SNCの傭兵として、惑星ノヴォ＝ソロで破壊活動にいそしむのだ。
バカでかい高火力ブリゲイダーで敵と街をまとめて吹き飛ばすのもよし、小回りの利く軽量機でゲリラめいた遊撃戦を展開するもよし、トップスピードに命をかけて街をぶっちぎるもよい。あらゆる障害を打ち倒し、大金を抱えて(電子キャッシュだからこの表現は適切ではない)次の戦いに備え給え。

斜め上視点で敵とか街とかいろいろなぎ倒すアクションゲーム。目標を堅実に狙ったり、いろいろぶっこわして金を稼いだりしよう。
本作は(今のところ)宇宙で最強の兵器、ブリゲイダーに搭乗して気に食わない奴らを吹っ飛ばすわけだけど、機体のバリエーションがやたら豊富で、武装とかスキルもいっぱいある。組み合わせがすごいことになるから相乗効果でものすごい破壊を生み出します。すごい！
機体の特性を理解するまで死ぬことはよくあるけど、この手のゲームの常でリトライは容易。安心して暴れまわろう。

世界観がやたら重厚で原文の時点でむせ返りそうになるのに、訳文でも油臭いアレが遺憾なく反映されててむせる。雑魚敵にもしっかり背景が用意され、強いこだわりを感じる。みんなも感じなさい。

デカいロボットで暴れまわるのが好きな人は買い。物を壊して金をもらおう。

author: {'steamid': '76561198035644453', 'num_games_owned': 1096, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 338, 'last_played': 1637570590}
review:
Highly aesthetic vehicle combat game where you play as a variety of mercenary pilots (Brigadors) in a variety of vehicles including house sized tanks, lumbering walkers & spritely anti-grav platforms. Controls are suitably clunky or responsive depending on your vehicle, weapons & performance depends on loadout & vehicle model as well.

Containing a fair lineup of story missions & a freelance campaign mode that allows the player to choose their pilot, vehicle & equipment loadout; the game provides a variety of challenges all set against a backdrop of interplanetary corp-politics, fascism, oppression & technological stagnation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044467913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1577, 'last_played': 1699313077}
review:
Brigador is a cool game. It starts off feeling maybe a little shallow. Not too terribly daunting once you get past the long list of vehicles you can pilot, or the almost excessive amount of pilots you can choose from. You might play it for an hour or two, have a bit of fun, and maybe put it down after a while in favor of other things. But, slowly, it'll start to sneak back into your thoughts. It could be the bumping soundtrack, it could be the long list of loadout options, it could even be the unique world that they've created. Because, at its core, Brigador has many quirks of its own.

Let's start with my personal favorite: The equipment. Brigador features a whole slew of vehicles, divided into catagories based on locomotion, then on faction. While not explicitly seperated in the list, these vehicles are all roughly sorted from high durability to low. In the case of Mechs, which are my personal favorite, you first are presented with giant, plodding, walking apocalypses, with progressively smaller and more mundane options opening up as you move down the list. Starting with the super heavy stuff may seem really backwards at first, since they certianly can trivialize some things. But, as you play, maybe trying out some of the "weaker" vehicles, you'll notice that what they lack in outright heft, they make up for with more options, both in armaments as well as engagement opportunities. For example, where a heavy mech would look down over all but the highest cover, certain small mechs have the ability to either stay hidden behind most cover or extend its legs for a quite shot at an enemy on the other side. It's differences in engagement that present a huge amount of choices. Do you pick a large, easy to see mech and hope you can wipe enemies out before you're swarmed, or will you opt for a more subtle, hit and run playstyle with the faster options the game provides?

On the topic of the vehicles, they aren't just a list of stats and a model. Each vehicle has a short bit of lore atteched to it that gives a look into either the history of the vehicle itself, or a glimpse of the world of Solo Novo. Furthermore, a considerable amount of attention was put into the design of the vehicles. Loyalist vehicles, being the most "normal" of all, sport simple, clean designs that prefer function over form. Corvid vehicles, which are used to fuel their revolution, are almost all either thrown together messes of car bodies and tank treads, or repurposed parts of other vehicles that were captured. Finally, Spacer vehicles, being an odd sort of "wealthy elite private army" group, all tend to feature unique, kind of strange designs. These all come together to create both an interesting combination of vehicles to pilot, as well as a long long list of enemies to take on. 

As for the presentation, that's one thing I just adore. Every single unlock has a piece of lore of varying complexity, ranging from a brutal look at the warfare employed on Solo Novo, to a look at the design processes of each faction, to "It's a laser shotgun." There's even a very interesting entry about the civilians, detailing the reason behind their strange look as well as the cultural value of their outfit.

All in all, Brigador was a sleeper hit for me. I went in expecting a plain twin stick shooter, and ended up with a deceptively deep game that has me hooked to the point that I'm eyeing the achievement list, a feat that only the dark souls series has accomplished before now. The game is worth it at full price, so if you think it might be your cup of tea, do yourself a favor and give it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961283256', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1543775497}
review:
O jogo é uma obra de arte. Nostálgico não só nos gráficos, mas um tributo a um tempo de onde tirou as melhores qualidades. Pacing bem cadênciado, jogo de proposta simples, menu objetivo e direto ao ponto. A direção de arte é incrível e conversa com a proposta nostálgica do jogo que tem como direção um pixelart muito original por ir além do visual 8 bits, simulando algo entre 24~32bits combinado a um 3D real time ao invés de shaders.

A música e os mapas são mais que incríveis e dão um toque especial ao universo do jogo.

Pontos que poderiam ser melhorados são detalhes da HUD no gameplay: algumas das poucas entidades do HUD (como pequenas setas) são skeuomórficos e similares em volume e cores a elementos do mapa, podendo ser confuso em alguns momentos. Poluição visual dificulta um pouco saber onde estão, quem são e de onde estão vindo os inimigos.

Jogo 8/10 (e isso é muito bom).

author: {'steamid': '76561198045969594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 8477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6262, 'last_played': 1660525589}
review:
Brigador is, on the surface, an isometric twin stick shooter where you choose a difficulty, vehicle, two weapons, a special ability, and a pack of levels to fight through.  But what makes it so much more than just that is the flavortext.  No, that's not a joke.  Every single map, Pilot, weapon, lore concept, and vehicle, including the non playable ones have a full paragraph or more written about its special quirks, how it came into service, crew oppinion, and other such things.

The setting is a genuinely interesting one.  Yes the 80s synthwave meme is a bit overplayed these days, but it works out in a way that doesn't feel forced in brigador.  Cassette tapes and CRT moniters work along side crainial jacks in this dystopian North Korea meets Rio Brazil in an An-Cap universe and it just kinda works.

I tried to explain the background of the game but I found that I ran out of space to write about actual game play.  So you should just read the in game lore and listen to the audio book.  Its excellently written and narrated.

So the game puts you in control of one of these brigadors who will risk everything to get rich and escape Solo Nobre alive.  In order to do that you have 68 playable vehicles that fall into five, technically six types, each with unique abilities and traits.

Powersuits: These are the smallest and weakest engines of destruction in Solo Nobre.  Their biggest attribute is their small size.  They excell at stealth.  Sneaking around large enemy formations and destroying objectives without getting caught.  They take a lot of skill to master at higher difficulties, but a job carried out in a power suit nets a hefty score multiplyer. Their melee attack is a stomp.  Useful for dealing with infantry and light vehicles like tread bikes.  Their special move is to extend their legs.  This allows them to shoot over lower objects and duck back down before the return fire comes in.  A useful tool for ambushes.

Mechs: Exactly what it sounds like.  A towering bi-pedal war machine.  These come in three subclasses of light, heavy, and ultra.  Ultra class vehicles get a damage reduction bonus due to their thick armor whereas some particualry light vehicles are open topped and get more recieved damage.  Mechs come in all shapes and sizes with some varients playing differently than others.  So I will leave it simple.  They have a stomp attack which can range from a slight upgrade of what a power suit can do, to one that will level city blocks and punch right through the top of a tank.  The mech's special move is crouch.  They tuck their legs in and get low to the ground, netting them a defense buff and allowing them to take cover behind lower obstacles.

Tread bikes: Because you gotta have a panzercycle in your cyberpunk game.  These are the powersuits of the tank tab.  Lightly armored, lightly armed, and only good if you absolutely know what it is you are doing.  These things are fast, but they can't crush obstacles all that well and are in general difficult to control.  Use them for stealth, hit and run tactics on objectives and try not to get tied up or cornered by a large battlegroup.  Their special ability and melee attack is the bull rush.  They zoom across the screen at breakneck speeds and gain a buff to ramming damage.  This might be enough to plow under other bikes and powersuits that try to stop you, but don't count on driving through a tank.  If you try ramming a mech, it will just step on you, killing you instantly.

Tanks: It seems self explanitory, but this also includes ramshankle technicals and gun trucks.  Some are fast, some are slow, some are well armored and some arent.  Their special ability varies between bull rush and downshift.  Bull rush is a charging attack that grants you a burst of speed and ramming damage, whearas downshift is the austin powers steamroller.gif attack which allows you to crush basically everything in your path at a leasurely rate.

Agravs: This is the most confusing class to play.  Agravs themselves are self explanitory.  Hover bikes/tanks.  They are usually agile and lightly armored, although some are rather sturdy and slow.  Their control sceme has them follow the mouse with W while A and D strafe around it.  Their special ability is to lock their orientation in one direction.  Useful for ones with turrets to facilitate drive by attacks and quick side strafing dodges.  Their melee attack is a belly slam which drops the vehicle ontop of anything it was hovering over.  Bikes will only be able to stomp out infantry and other bikes, whereas the larger ones can hit almost as hard as a mech.

TukTuk: A joke vehicle.  A simple three wheel delivery rickshaw with some light weapon hardpoints welded to it.  Good luck.

So how does the game play?  Its simple enough to learn, so simple that the tutorial is a bit insulting and drags on for far too long in fact.  But once you finish it, you are open to go way in over your head and get yourself killed.  There are a lot of things you will need to learn.  Wall penetration with different weapons, what explodes when shot, how difficult it is to crush a type of building to pass over it, But the most basic of aiming skills is the most important one of them.  You see, while the game is isometric, there is still height.  You need to aim directly at enemies in order to hit them.  If you try playing it as a normal twin stick shooter you will shoot over the target.  This can get very frustraiting at first, but I would advise you to git gud.

Your health is made up of hard shield and armor bars.  Hard shields can be regenerated and overcharged for a short period of time by picking up energy dropped by destroyed enemies.  Armor is your last line of defense and will not regenerate.  Enemies also have shields and armor, though they cannot recharge their shields.  Some weapons do devistating damage to shields, while barely chipping armor and vise versa.  So its a good idea to get a weapon that will fill in the gaps of the other.

If an enemy sees you, they will begin to power on their shield (if they have one) and try to kill you.  Unless its a spotter.  Spotters will report your location to all the enemies in the map which will have them all power on their shields and zero in on you.  This also raises walls that will box you in and severly hamper your movement.  Allowing them to sound the alarm is a good way to get killed quickly, so be mindful of that.

Unless you are playing the campaign, you have a choice on how to complete a level.  Destroy the orbital guns, kill all enemy commanders, or wipe out 70% of all enemies on the map.  Some vehicles are better suited to some tasks than others.  But its all up to you.  Do bear in mind that if you are a completionist and want to do all tasks, you can.  But expect runs to go into the hours.  It can be a quick game if you make it one.  But it can also be a very long one.  If you mess up and get yourself killed far into a full campaign run or similar, you will probably turn off the game in frustration and not come back to it.  For a few hours.  Then you will be right back into it trying again.  Its alluring that way.  The sound track isn't half bad if you like synthwave too.

The world building and vehicles are straight up inspired.  Many of the weapons are real world hardware that you can pick up on if you look at their discription and calliber close enough.  If you really like military hardware and reading, this game is practically worth it on that alone.  If you want a challanging twin stick experience like gungeon but more built on tactical planning than raw skill, this is a perfect choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050350698', 'num_games_owned': 584, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3477, 'last_played': 1709623683}
review:
Brigador is an isometric vehicular combat game reminiscent of classic isometric action titles such as Mechwarrior for the SNES, Bedlam for the PC and Desert Strike for the Sega Genesis.

The game allows you to customize a huge variety of tanks, mechs, hovercraft and some other more unusual combat vehicles - including but not limited to a tank-treaded motorcycle, a bulldozer and a tuktuk - with an equally lavish armory that ranges from high-caliber machine guns and mortars all the way up to fully automatic laser beams and battleship cannons.

Brigador also features a remarkable wealth of background lore with regards to the weapons and vehicles you can acquire, with each and every item of the hundreds of pieces of equipment coming with a dossier that provides interesting tidbits regarding how that particular item fits into the world, as well as an extensive collection of general Lore entries that relate to the setting as a whole and the events that have lead up to this point.
The strong lore, in conjunction with the moody aesthetics and soundtrack, give Brigador a wonderfully dark atmosphere and an immersive quality that is perhaps unexpected in an isometric game.

Brigador is a game that offers enormous amounts of tactical depth in terms of the vehicle you choose, which weapons you decide to put on it and the pilot you select, with the pilot essentially acting as a Difficulty setting. This fine-tuning allows for a highly granular level of challenge; if the player desires a gentler experience they may select a tough vehicle that can mount powerful weapons, alongside a pilot that prevents enemies from scaling up between consecutive missions, while a player seeking a greater challenge might select a more delicate vehicle, or weapons with more specialized uses, or a pilot that causes enemies to scale more drastically.

Brigador offers a highly-configurable experience that can be a relaxing and cathartic explosion fest or a tense and challenging gauntlet requiring stealth and patience, and so I can comfortably recommend it to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004668614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2128, 'last_played': 1695491214}
review:
In many respects, this game gives you what you'd expect from a twin-stick shooter: solid controls, a variety of vehicles and weapons, and plenty of levels in which to blow things up. If it was just that, it wouldn't stand out from others that well. 

Where Brigador makes things interesting is the story. It's pretty straightforward: you're a mercenary taking work on a world whose ultra-oppressive, centralized government is crumbling and the various factions present are each eager to strike out now that the chance to do so is present. The more missions you do, the more money you earn, and the more information you unlock about the world. It's a journey of discovery, told through blood and explosions.

The levels and art design is where this game really shines. Everything can be destroyed or blown up, meaning you can play missions as fast or slow as you want, and different vehicles and weapon systems change up how difficult a mission can be. The game also challenges you to beat missions with specific loadouts or vehicles, with some loadouts offering high payouts because just coming back alive from using them is tough. 

However, this also means the game is a bit grindy. While the variety of levels, vehicles and weapons will let you play the game a variety of ways, after a while it becomes a title you'll play every once in a while when you feel the urge. Thankfully, it's a game that delivers well in that respect.

If this game has one big problem, its a lack of multiplayer options. The game is easily too overwhelming for local co-op, but an option for online co-op would have been great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052298931', 'num_games_owned': 1254, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1146, 'last_played': 1673092376}
review:
In Brigador, you play as a double-crossing mech/tank/hovercraft pilot fighting through hostile sectors to secure a fat paycheck and a ticket offworld. Gameplay is very straightforward, as you have a primary, secondary, and utility mounted on your mech (operated by lmb, rmb, and mmb respectively). Most goals are a simple "kill them" or "demolish these", but the variety of loadouts, enemies, and maps keeps everything feeling very fresh. The Loyalists, Spacers, and Corvids each have their own roster of vehicles, weapons, and pilots that are unlockable through gameplay, and the pilot/vehicle/weapon descriptions are displayed as information collected by the Solo Nobre Concern (the people paying you to shoot your friends in the back). There's plenty of fluff/lore to read through, and none of it gets in the way of simply playing the game. There's also an audio book for anyone who wants to take a further dive into the setting of Brigador. All-in-all, I'd absolutely recommend this game for anyone who's into run and gun arcade action.

review:
魔改造トゥクトゥクからSF感バッチリの巨大ホバリング戦車のようなものまで、多彩な機体/武装で好きなだけ街を蹂躙しよう！

ごちゃごちゃした街中で建物を盾に攻防したり、引っかかって蜂の巣にされたり
なんとなく一般市民をミンチにしたり
可燃物満載の施設を壊して大爆発！を囮に背後から奇襲したり…
超小型/紙装甲だけど近距離火力ピカイチな機体でゲリラ戦法もよし
鈍重で見つかりやすいが圧倒的な装甲/火力で整地するもよし

派手な戦闘はお好みではない？
それも大丈夫。
このゲームにおいて背面は装甲が薄く、戦闘状態に入っていない敵はシールドを起動していないため非常に脆い。
光学迷彩でこっそりと敵の背後へ回ったり、視界外の遠距離から一撃で仕留めるもよし
建築物へのダメージが低いエネルギー兵器で壁抜きして一方的に撃つもよし

キャンペーンモードではステージごとに用意された機体しか選べませんが、フリーランスモードでは好きな構成で破壊の限りを楽しめます。
私のオススメは爆撃機の胴体に脚を付けた"ラットキング"に、貫通力の高い大型散弾と曲射クラスター弾を装備した「移動経路が更地になる」スタイルです。

ですがこのゲームの魅力は破壊衝動を満たせることだけではありません。
機体や武装、組織やパイロットなどなど…ゲーム内の様々な要素を解説するテキストが豊富で読み物としても楽しめます。
群衆整理のために開発された殺傷力を持たないショットガンが、ゴム弾から金属弾へ変更され、さらにはフレシェット弾に対応する"改良型"になるまでの経緯が読めたりします。

貫通力が高い兵器でビル３つ４つブチ抜いて敵破壊したり、強力な直射砲の爆発と衝撃で広範囲まとめて吹き飛ばしたり、大型のクラスター弾2門で市街地まるっと整地したり、タンク型の突進攻撃で建物も敵も一般人も全部潰してくのも楽しい…

author: {'steamid': '76561198037069940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 948, 'last_played': 1613872717}
review:
BRIGADOR is an isometric action game featuring your choice of towering mechs, tread-borne vehicles and anti-grav craft.
In it, you play AS john brigador, bringing peace and prosperity to novo solo by murdering everyone and everything that looks at you funny.
Jokes aside, BRIGADOR is a good game to pick up and putter around in. The campaign is a little bare-bones, but that's only because the real meat of the game is in the operations menu, where you can purchase rights to run certain sets of missions that give you more money to buy more stuff to get more money. Pilot selection does more than change the face on the top left - each pilot has different modifiers to difficulty (and payout) that are both immediate and long-term, and choosing a pilot that you can handle is just as important as choosing what weapons to bring. However, higher difficulties bring bigger rewards, which can be spent on all sorts of things. Between new pilots, weapons, chassis and the mass of lore you can requisition you'll have plenty to spend your dollars on - assuming you manage to get off the planet in one piece.
