author: {'steamid': '76561198033719090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 3418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2896, 'last_played': 1561766263}
review:
I'm reminded of the old Desert/Jungle/Urban Strike games for the SNES and Future Cop: LAPD for the PS1 whenever I play Brigador, and with good reason.  It's a isometric sci-fi vehicular combat game that gives you a single well-armed vehicle and a set of missions to complete (similar to the Strike games), and has you navigating a futuristic cyberpunk city rife with corruption and chaos (similar to Future Cop: LAPD).

You can choose from a large variety of vehicles from the game's three factions, and select two weapons based upon the available hardpoints and one special ability.   While the campaign missions restrict you into using specific loadouts, the real fun comes when you begin to experiment with various vehicle and weapon setups in the Freelance mode, and see just how far your design can make it before succumbing to the enemy hordes.

Choosing which pilot to play with is arguably the most confusing part: they don't impact your vehicle performance in any way, but instead govern the difficulty and payouts given at the end of each operation.  For example, the starter pilots will start off at the lowest difficulty levels, nor will the diffculty rise when progressing through the districts.  But in exchange, their payouts and bonus multipliers are far less rewarding.  In contrast, the most expensive pilots will likely start at or near the highest difficulty, but in exchange receive generous bonuses upon completion of an operation.  Oh, and a few of the vehicles themselves serve as difficulty gauges in obvious ways.  For example, piloting a heavily armored mech with dual 30mm gauss cannons is going to be a cakewalk, where in contrast driving around in a small, paper-thin Tuk-Tuk with only small hardpoints is going to SUCK if you selected one of the higher difficulty pilots.

And when they say you can destroy everything in the environment, they do mean EVERYTHING.  The only indestructible objects in the game are the large concrete wall barriers at the edge of the level, and the occasional alarm barrier that is raised under certain circumstances.  And at no point are you ever penalized for being destructive as possible: you're given payment for every single bit of property destruction you cause, ranging from knocking down trees to demolishing city blocks.

The only flaw (if you can even call it that) is that there is no co-op multiplayer.  I suppose it would've been only a whimsical addition and would've made many of the levels far too easy, but the idea of playing through one of the longer Freelance Ops with a friend would've been a blast.  Again, I don't really hold this against the game - its just an addition I wish could've been made.

In conclusion, if you like retro vehicular combat games and causing wanton destruction, go ahead and buy Brigador, you'll absolutely love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992570638', 'num_games_owned': 1437, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1932, 'last_played': 1543088884}
review:
Great, atmospheric mech game with fine, responsive controls and fine-tuned, superb gameplay.

Brigador is an isometric game with masterfully crafted bitmapped tiles for the map. Think something akin to the original Syndicate with very high-quality graphics. The vehicles seem to be fully 3D animated, and the looks and lighting work very well together. 

It's quite rare to find a game that is retro but doesn't need to be low-resolution pixel art. The games of old were not low-res for aesthetic reasons, but because of hardware limitations. Brigador goes the extra mile and satisfying the craving for retro sensibilities while not sacrificing graphical quality. 

It's quite clear this game had a long, healthy development cycle as the gameplay is balanced and the controls are quite responsive. 

There are a campaign mode and freelance missions, but they play relatively the same. There are no RPG elements, you play as a series of different pilots, and not as a single individual. The main difference is that the campaign is linear and has a series of preset Brigadors with loadouts and pilots. 

It's not quite accurate to call it a mech game, as you can fly a plethora of vehicles, varying from towering mechs to tanks, a-gravs hovercrafts and other types of vehicles, from power armors to even motorcycles.

The three main factions are a bit stereotypical in a good way: the Loyalists are the standard military-militia type, which favors bulky military gear, the Corvids are bandits out of Mad Max or Fallout, using improvised, irresponsible equipment made from leftover cars and random parts, and the Spacers are high tech offworlders who favor energy weapons. Each faction has a very distinct personality, look and feel to their vehicles and weapons.

While in the campaigns each Brigador usually has a faction-appropriate pilot and loadout, you can really mix it up on the freelance mode with varied, wild setups that can be quite rewarding.

The difficulty is fair and, for the most part, adjustable through a clever risk/reward mechanic: the pilots and vehicles have multipliers, so the bulky mechs with easy pilots offer a light challenge for a modest financial reward, while nimbler, lighter vehicles with hard pilots provide the best reward.

There's a lot of story and worldbuilding, provided by optional, non-intrusive texts, which you may dive into our skip at your leisure. 

The music is quite good and adds a lot to the overall atmosphere, being a superb complement to the visuals.

A solid recommendation for anyone who likes mech games.

review:
Эта игра имеет сильный ностальгический эффект, есть в ней что-то SEGA'вское.
Я думаю, её главные плюсы заключаются в следующем:
Очень крутой саунддизайн.
Визуальное оформление с хорошо выдержанной общей стилистикой, мне пришлось по душе.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071227805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1643263773}
review:
This is a game that I feel is going to slip under the radar for most people which is a shame because it's brilliant. The best description I can give for the gameplay is Hotline Miami or Syndicate with mechs, tanks and hovercraft. Where HLM is a bit more frantic and twitchy, rewarding mayhem more than anything else, Brigador is far more tactical.

The isometric view and destructible environments of varying durability and height create meaningful choices in how to approach a fight. Do you blast the enemy through a thin fence, lure them into a narrow passage where their numbers don't count or blast them sky high with a conveniently placed ammunition depot or fuel station? The approach to difficulty is also unique. Instead of placing more enemies in a level or boosting their health, you instead pick from vehicles that are more or less difficult to use. Using hover tank with a cannon that can level a city block doesn't earn you as much money as a small mech that relies on a cloaking device and subterfuge to complete the mission.

With what depth is here, I could write pages about what this game has going for it. I think you're probably in or out by now so If you're interested then maybe check out Youtube videos or ask me to broadcast for you (if you're on my friends list).

review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Brigador: Up-Armored Edition is a game developed by Stellar Jockeys and Gausswerks and published by Stellar Jockeys

The game offers some pleasant graphics and really vibrant colours, although some ugly glitches here and there, it is pleasant all the same, the game's graphics reminds me of the classic SimCity games with it's 2.5D perspective, the game does suffer with some really confusing and awkward gameplay mechanics

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game and the controls both on keyboard and on a controller is absolutely annoying and a chore to do but a fun game nontheless

Brigador: Up-Armored Edition overall, however, is a fun game to play in short bursts!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198101654148', 'num_games_owned': 1044, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1546476696}
review:
[h1]Destruição em paisagens urbanas, caos sem limites, mechas customizáveis, tanques flutuantes e uma maravilhosa trilha sonora neo-80s. Este é Brigador: Up-Armored Edition[/h1]

Brigador trata-se de um shooter twin-stick com bons controles de mouse e teclado, embora tenha a complicação extra do movimento alternando entre girar e bombardear, que dependerá da máquina que você estiver pilotando, sendo um mech ou um tanque. 

No game há uma forte necessidade de tática, particularmente em termos de munição e gerenciamento de saúde, física de armas, controle de multidões e particularmente visando inimigos específicos antes que soem o alarme. Brigador é glorioso de se contemplar - paisagens urbanas abrangentes e detalhadas, cobertas pela noite salpicadas de neon, tranquilas e pacíficas ao iniciar o nível, mas ficará destruída por completo no final do nível.

Por um lado, o jogo parece com um Lo-fi, mas em contrapartida a maré de destruição e as unidades intrincadas, me fazem sentir como se eu estivesse jogando um jogo de tabuleiro em uma vida explosiva e bem iluminada.

Um explosivo cuidadosamente implantado pode criar uma grande reação em edifícios, porém só basta um piscar de olhos bem cronometrados e poderá ser despachado uma horda de inimigos simultaneamente. Tudo em Brigador é uma experiencia única, recriado com escalas e efeitos impecáveis, sobrepondo muitos do seu mesmo gênero. Espero que o fã teimoso do Mechwarrior entenda, pois, a categoria de mech lovers ficará satisfeito com o Brigador.

Particularmente, eu gostei de tudo o que Brigador faz, porém ainda não achei suficiente, apesar de seus maravilhosos brinquedos robóticos, carnificina em escala industrial e estética impecável, às vezes ele pode ser frustrante. O game não é difícil, mas a apresentação da interface torna a vida do jogador mais difícil do que se imagina.

Eu tive um problema com a distância dos medidores de saúde, escudos, munição, que ficam posicionados no canto superior esquerdo e os são da ação, que se espalha amplamente na área central da tela.

O jogo faz parte do gênero do roguelike, ou seja, a morte neste jogo custa todo o progresso em mapas que geralmente são grandes e desafiadores. Alguns dos níveis da campanha também são desavergonhadamente brutais – conceder um mech extremamente forte, como uma fortaleza móvel do tamanho de uma torre e com apenas uma mão aniquilar uma onda incansável de unidades velozes que lutará para te destruir.

A boa notícia é que ficar preso ou desanimado em algum nível não será um obstáculo, pois pode ser usado o pular missões freelance, que apresentam mapas menores, diferentes desafios e o mais importante, a opção de configurar as compras de mechas, pilotos, armas e habilidades. Ao invés de ficar apenas com as opções pré-fabricadas oferecidas na campanha. 

No entanto, este não é um game que você está jogando somente pela história, mas sim para fazer grandes destruições nas cidades e esmagar soldados. Por isso, é importante ter opções de lugares diferentes para ir e experimentar, em vez de ficar preso somente em algum modo. Brigador possui também uma impressionante variedade de veículos no jogo, como por exemplo: o abrigo rápido que pode ficar invisível.

O dinheiro poderá ser ganhado em qualquer modo, seja ele o da campanha ou do freelance, e podem ser gastos em atualizações e desbloqueios incluído de novos mapas. Então, caso você esteja repetindo várias vezes a mesma missão, só basta comprar uma nova.

A escolha do armamento está bem diversificada, desde metralhadoras simples até o lento recarregamento de railguns, bombas tipo daisy cutter, variados canhões e foguetes. Existe muitas armas que tem os nomes parecidos, para descobrir e muito menos lembrar o que exatamente faz leva um certo tempo. A metade da diversão de Brigador está em apenas descobrir o que seu novo investimento é realmente capaz de realizar no meio da cidade, ou melhor, a zona industrial que em breve se tornará um campo flamejante, fumegante e cheio de cascalho.

Contudo, Brigador: Up-Armored Edition é um título interessante – monte o seu mech ou death tank dos seus sonhos, faça um giro em Blade Runner Ville, acabe com tudo em sua volta e tenha uma ótima luta.

[h1]Prós:[/h1]
• Divertido e desafiador;
• Gráficos detalhados, coloridos e bem-feitos;
• Dispõe o idioma PT/BR;
• Compatível com o controle;
• Trilha sonora impecável, sendo um dos maiores pontos positivos do jogo.

[h1]Contras:[/h1]
• Dificuldade desequilibrada em certos níveis;
• História clichê;
• A HUD está mal posicionada.

Review para Curadoria [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6874381]Jogos Grátis Brasil.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993475888', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1550867814}
review:
[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
“Brigador” is an old school retro-style top down tactical shooter, where you play as one of severalhigh-skilled mercenary pilots, driving various types of vehicles and taking part in fights for a colony located on a distant planet. As you can see from the videos and screenshots, the game’s main feature is ability to destroy literally anything within map limits. It’s rather clear that Brigador uses BattleTech (later known as Mech Warrior) as a source of inspiration. But let’s take a deeper look at the game:

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
The story is supposed to be unlocked and guessed by players on their own, as it comes with short pieces, part of which can be unlocked for cash. Main flow goes this way: There used to be a cruel leader on one distant colony planet. Duo to his poor leadership, the colony had fallen from prosperity to the dark ages. However the Great Leader had died and soon after his death, multiple factions started fighting to gain power and control over the planet. One of such factions decided to bribe most skilled pilots on the planet and hire them for the dirty work. Obviously, you represent these pilots and deliver devastating strikes on the targeted areas. 

With all that being said, though, it’s worth mentioning that storyline isn’t quite most important thing in the game.

[h1]The atmosphere:[/h1]
Everything Brigador is saturated with nostalgia: Dark red colors, main menu looks, vehicle and buildings style, the music, all of that reminds you of some dark sci-fi, or apocalypse movies from back ‘80s.

Maps are quite variative aswell: Industrial areas, with all those dumps of broken and abandoned vehicles; green parks and cementries, filled with many tiny details; cyberpunk themed downtowns, or living quarters with huge amount of parked cars and traffic jams – each region has own looks and story behind it.

As it was mentioned above, the sound also contributes for the nostalgia feeling and remotely reminds of most famous melodies of sci-fi movies of said era. It sounds both stylish and old. The only real issue with music is that there’s short amount of tracks available in game , so you’ll have to listen to the same melody over and over again during battles.

 [h1]Gameplay analysis:[/h1]
Game menu meets you with multiple points. Let’s cover three most important of them: Freelance, Campaign and Acquisitions: 
“Freelance” is a game mode which lets you choose your favorite vehicle, equip it with weaponry and special ability on your choice and proceed to an operation selected by yourself. Basically, it’s sort of skirmish with a  set of rules you make for yourself. It’s necessary to mention, though, that the variety of vehicles and equipment is pretty high, so even one mission can be played in a multiple ways, depending on the vehicle and equipment you choose.

“Campaign” tells you the story of the planet and gives missions with pre-set pilots and equipment. You can consider it as some sort of challenge mode. You earn cash for each completed mission. The more destruction you delivered and more goals you completed, the more cash you have earned. 

“Acquisition” is not quite a gamemode, but rather is a place where you spend your money on purchasing equipment for “Freelance” mode and unlocking more info about game world, in case you’re actually interested in storyline.

As for actual gameplay, it feels quite old school and reminds 16-bit BattleTech game from 1994, yet with refreshed graphics and a bit more abilities. It’s not an insult though, as game feels similarly good and intense when you need to maneuver between several large groups of enemies confronting you from multiple sides, trying to avoid massive damage and charge up shields by walking over dead enemies. 

Usually during each shootout some random shot accidentally hits fuel station or highly explosive pipeline and whole region turns into a huge messed up pile of burning wrecks, sometimes capable of destroying most of your enemies, or even your vehicle as well. Now repeat that situation about ten times and you’ll have your average Brigador match. So yeah, if you like huge explosions and collapsing buildings, you’ll sure love the gameplay. High destructibility, however, actually plays an important role from the perspective of tactics, but I’ll leave that for you, the player, to discover…

[h1]Making up conclusions:[/h1] 
So as we’ve covered most important parts of the game, it’s time to sum everything up and have some final words…

[b]What’s good:[/b][list]
[*][i]Retro futuristic atmosphere style[/i]
That has already been covered, but game really gives you that cool nostalgia feeling.
[*][i]Total destructibility[/i]
Anything can be destroyed. The only thing which prevents you from destroying all the objects on the map is amount of ammunition your vehicle carries, but apart from that, there are no limits really.
[*][i]Large variety of equipment and pilots to choose from[/i]
That, combined with previous point, gives game quite deep tactical aspect. It’s only up to a player if it’s worth using artillery fire, or hiding between tall buildings, or blow up something highly explosive… You are the one to choose own playstyle.[/list]

[b]Not-so-good:[/b][list]
[*][i]Repetitive mission tasks[/i]
Unfortunately most missions feel the same way, despite maps being diverse: You always have to destroy some units, some orbital guns and supply stations. There’s no advanced and more dynamic missions, like defensive objectives , or some evacuation missions whatsoever. Perhaps devs could have a look at some RTS games as a source of inspiration?
[*][i]Lack of Coop or at least some allied units[/i]
A game like Brigador, which is filled with nostalgia for old games not having at least some 2-player mode makes me personally really sad. Truth to be said, netcode is hard to write, but devs could’ve done at least some missions where pilots are supposed to cooperate with friendly AI in solo mode. PvP in such game would be even better addition but I’m going way too far now.
[*][i]Limited amount of equipment you can use on vehicle[/i]
Despite large variety of weapons, player is able to only choose two of them and one special ability, which significally cuts down the tactical aspect.[/list]

[h1]The conclusion:[/h1]
Brigador is a nice game which can surely bring you some fun and help you with spending some boring evenings. It does, however, have some issues, biggest of which is repeatability, but other than that game is alright. After all, there aren’t many games where you can stomp down whole city and leave it in ruins after mission is completed.

You play as various mercenaries in decked out mechs and super tanks destroying everything in your path, and I mean everything. Big stompy mechs, lasers, railguns, KILLDOZER, thermobaric cluster mortar, WAR CRIMES, fully destructible environments, political intrigue, WAR CRIMES, awesome and diverse pilots, big crushing tanks, great environmental and indirect storytelling, amazing lighting, WAR CRIMES, fantastic synthwave soundtrack, dual 30MM autocanons for overwhelming BRRRRT,  WAR CRIMES.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196958822', 'num_games_owned': 529, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2932, 'last_played': 1539370699}
review:
Do you remember the days of Desert Strike on MS-DOS? For a short review, this game is its dystopic cyberpunk grandson that pulled off everything perfectly.

For the long review; here it comes.

Brigador gives you three types of vehicles, the most dystopic setting and lore possible with the best synthwave soundtrack to go along with it. So, you may say, what does it warrant for me to buy it? What happens after finishing the campaign with only a single choice of 4 given vehicles in any scenario? Why should I even "freelance"?

Same thoughts went along my mind. Although i loved it, for years i only played it 30-min mark most, with one or two campaign maps cleared at most. It's like the sublimest of drugs, for it hits you when you are determined to finish it once and for all. Gotta get all these campaign maps cleared with each one at least in such an enjoyable game, right?

That's when it hit me specifically, trying to finish Wait For The Blackout with the mech Fence.

It was more or less of a breeze up to that point. Try a feew different tactics and that was it. But at that level, at my 7th try I finally understood the mindset of people that created this game and it was truly a piece of art. 

That explosive next to that building? That unit spawn next to the ammo building? That vehicle not having an Aux Secondary but a Turret? All of that is PLANNED. All of it is INTENDED. 

Level names are strange, right? No, they are much, much more than that, they are song names. Just youtube them.

Most mechs have nearly same parts, right? Yes, of course because that would actually be instead of BattleTech's ingenius and hopelessly flawed designs. Why create huge chests and arms for a f--kn mech??? 

And with all these details, the game has a placeholder as a piece of art. Because every detail is handcrafted, everything has a reason and the lore is a masterpiece of real world where sh-t would hit the fan just as it would. And it grows on you. You suddenly begin to talk about the mechs and vehicles in "turret turn speed" and "forward acceleration" terms.

And in variation? Here we have the open topped light support mechs, treadbikes, treadbikes with side wheels, hovering construction vehicles turned artillery platforms, flying limos with guns on both sides, an aeroplane that lost its wings because it no longer needs it because it just got upgraded with an anti grav engine, the only Tank Police style ball-wheeled tanks in any game, more mech variations that satisft even the pickiest Gundam fan, guns, futuristic guns, guns that spew silent radiation, railguns, a damn Mk12, a mining laser, an EMP rocket, a shortbarreled anti-tank rifle, even the old Carl Gustav himself.

Just go ahead and buy it even if you are slightly interested. Sooner than you know, you will crash apartments with your futuristic tank just to flank some idiots who have no idea, you will emerge from the low wall you have been hiding your powersuit to snipe some huge mech that would have no problem stomping you, you will strafe among the blackened future city streets running and gunning after blowing up the power infastructure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982200745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 11106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5024, 'last_played': 1635573910}
review:
The good: Great sound design, killer music, cool setting, unique art style, fun gameplay. Lots of replay value, with countless crazy vehicle and weapon combinations to explore.

The bad: It starts off slow. Really slow. Literally, the game is set to like 50% speed by default, you have to open the options menu when you first load it and set it to 100. Then you begin with a stream of tutorials, plodding around and learning the game's controls and features one by one. Then you get several missions which are complete pushovers in slow vehicles with boring loadouts. Then things finally start to get interesting, as each mission presents a tactical challenge that can be solved a different way by the four equipment sets on offer.

The game's free play mode is where the real magic happens, where you can mix and match combinations of vehicles, weapons and maps to your heart's desire. Unfortunately, all of the above has to be unlocked, meaning that the most fun part of the game is gated at the start. It's also poorly explained - if I hadn't hit up the wiki beforehand, I would have had no idea how the freelance meta works: that the pilots act as your difficulty selector, determining how much opposition you face and how much money you earn. It so happens that this also determines how much fun you have - once you master the controls, you'll find that the lower tier pilots are total walkovers. You'll push yourself to the bottom of the list, running the weakest vehicles at the highest difficulty for the biggest rewards.

If you've got the patience to push through the bad first impression it makes, Brigador is a great video game that I heartily recommend.

(If you do purchase it, I recommend the deluxe version of the game. The Audiobook is decent but the OST is required listening)

author: {'steamid': '76561198322080930', 'num_games_owned': 64, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1536543656}
review:
The review in brief: BRIGADOR is a competent old-school isometric shooter experience with a lovely retro aesthetic, synthesized score, and Cold War era feel that'll bring you right back to the 1980s.

If you enjoyed playing the old BattleTech/MechWarrior game on SEGA Genesis or SNES, or if you were a fan of Jungle Strike and Desert Strike, you'll feel right at home in the cockpit of one of BRIGADOR's huge roster of vehicles, including stompy battlemechs, tanks that can roll through anything, and nimble hovercraft that fit right in with the retro-cyberpunk atmosphere. The game also gave me strong flashbacks to the isometric tactical simulation MechCommander--though a different genre, BRIGADOR is a lot like what MechCommander would be if you only commanded one mech.

You'll be fighting a somewhat clandestine war to destabilize the despotic government of a planet called Solo Nobre. The locale will make you think of a Portuguese version of Blade Runner's future Los Angeles. It's dark, moody, and suffuse with neon lights. You can also immerse yourself in the character biographies and lore notes about all of the game's vehicles and weapon systems--this intel goes a long way to making you feel like you're actually in the setting.

Controlling your mech or fighting vehicle of choice feels smooth and polished. Lots of different enemies and approaches keep missions from becoming repetitive. Best of all, while some obstacles can stop bullets temporarily, everything in BRIGADOR is destructible. Your mech can bust down walls to get the jump on enemies who realistically have weaker armor on the rear than they do on the front. Hostile AI is also surprisingly effective. They can be alerted by sound alone, and some enemies will actually bother to alert their allies. Many of the missions can offer a real challenge as a result.

BRIGADOR is not likely to be a game that you will sink hundreds of hours into, or replay half a dozen times. It's not going to offer you a compelling story or meaningful decisions. It's more of a fun, fast action experience you can jump into at a moment's notice to sink an hour or two, and will wow you with its atmosphere as much as its gameplay. I think it's worth the buy to support an indie development house that put real time and effort into making a great product, and continuing to provide free updates to that product. Hopefully, with our support, Stellar Jockeys will have great things ahead of them in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971626164', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 22336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3221, 'last_played': 1692668282}
review:
Brigador started out as a slow burn for me. I really had an initial attraction to the game for purely aesthetic reasons - the soundtrack was by favorite artist; Makeup and Vanity Set. The gritty, retro-but-sophisticated, ultra-greebled cyberpunk art and setting appealed as I was riding a heady wave of William Gibson, Synthwave, and anticipation of Blade Runner's sequel and Cyberpunk 2077. It has customizable mechs, which pretty much grabs my inner child by the lapels and drags them in front of the part of my brain that controls the paypal account. The witty and cynical flavor texts which abounded throughout the game, telling the story of Solo Nobre and Novo Solo via blurbs under each gun, mech, pilot, and mission, gave me something for my mind to chew on, creating the world in which I could imagine my actions and their consequences as part of a larger story; the brutal, often short lives of my pilots merely corporate subscripts of a savage struggle for power in the wake of Great Leader's death.

But at first, especially before they revamped the control options menu in a later update, I was really not sure whether all of this artistic achievement was attached to gameplay that was actually GOOD. I was frustrated:

- the levels are flat
- the levels are sometimes brutally hard, sometimes stupidly easy
- the game often doesn't give you enough information to make good purchasing decisions
- levels get rehashed across different freelance campaigns
- weapon balance is nonexistent; some are absolutely terrifying, others are nigh useless - some can defeat all opponents, others are good specifically only at defeating some
- the game is way too damn dark
- no multiplayer/coop
- a game which cried out for cutscenes, voiceovers, and randomized levels/freelance campaigns had none
- the game conflates points with money and then makes it super-easy to earn a ton of both by destroying the level (you get money for destroying pretty much anything), but the levels are huge and fundamentally this means the game is asking you to trade your time for achievement (a lame grind to do better than other players/advance through the game).

Gradually, though, as I came back to this game over and over again (thanks in large part to the fact it could be played on any of my computers since it supported Linux), I came to realize most of the above criticisms had valid answers, or were the result of looking at the game wrong:

- flat levels are intricately populated with a 2D urban jungle of structures, flora, and vehicles which provide a diverse array of tactical options
- the hard levels you have to prepare and conserve for; the easy levels exist for that purpose; they vary the gameplay so that it's not always so tense, but always important.
- while it's not necessarily a great dev decision, omitting info prior to purchase forces players to make do with what they end up buying, pushing players to innovate tactics and loadouts. Almost every level (with notable exceptions) is so open-ended that it is impossible to find yourself without a means of accomplishing through subterfuge what brute force could not - and that is immensely satisfying.
- level rehash becomes more understandable once your realize how ridiculously intricate and large these levels are, and how they were constructed to push players to use all the tools available to them - who would have guessed that if you know you'll be fighting in a cemetery, it makes more sense to use a grav than a tank or mech, for instance?
- weapon balance actually ends up being a problem - not that it's not fun to use immensely powerful weapons when feeling lazy, or super crappy ones when feeling up to a challenge - but more because the devs unknowingly removed one of the more interesting dynamics present in some other mech games - the need to balance guns which damage shields and those which focus on armor/hull damage. It's still here, but it's just not as important as in other games if you don't want it to be, and the game loses some sophistication because it leaves that wrinkle behind.
- the game actually looks fine if you brighten your monitor up or get one that can display blacks nicely.
- the AI in the game ends up being sufficient, but future multiplayer in a sequel game is undeniably desirable
- cutscenes, voiceovers, and randomization would also all be great; no denying it.
- I'm still kind of interested in the problem presented by giving payers almost unlimited points opportunities in each level, but only if they grind... but honestly it doesn't bother me as much as it used to. The game is just fun to play through without worrying about the points, and if you do, you'll always have plenty of cash to play with as you expand your arsenal. This will only matter for people trying to achieve top scores.

So at the end, you get a game that's a good game in the tradition of something like Dynasty Warriors, but with a truly excellent presentation. It may not bring anything "new" to the table, but that which it does bring, it brings with truly unbeatable style and quality. Definitely buy and hope Stellar Jockeys makes more of this franchise in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974341875', 'num_games_owned': 1385, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1611812240}
review:
I still haven't finished this, but I'm loving it so far! Great combat mechanics, satisfying heft, challenging scenarios yet still clear rules because of its simplicity.

[h1]LONG RAMBLING BELOW, NOT A REVIEW OF THE GAME IN ANY WAY[/h1]

This game reminds me a bit of an isometric shooter from the '90s, Crusader: No Remorse. I'm not sure if this comparison will be completely fair, but I'm going to give it a try.

Brigador has by far easier controls. Crusader was very flexible but too ambitious to the point of being daunting. I would love to re-play it using Brigador's "isometric tank" controls, I can see it working very well.

Playstyle wise, they're also very similar. Both of these games pit you in maps with a relatively destructible environment (Brigador more so, being a mech/tank game) which you can use to distract and destroy your enemies. Both of these games have a focus on traps and stealth (going head-on without some plan to control crowds, manage aggro and flank can result in your death real fast).

Style-wise, they also feel rather similar: retro-industrial tech aesthetics, isometric view, focus on destruction. Let me elaborate on this.

While both games feature lots of destruction, I think they handle it differently because of their scale. In Crusader, you control a single super-soldier infiltrating and attacking the outposts of an evil mega-corporation. You use a varied arsenal of both realistic and sci-fi weapons, plus a very destructible and hazardous environment to get rid of enemies (or yourself). Death in this game is gruesome and horribly detailed: shoot someone with an RPG, they will go up in flames and run while screaming in pain. Microwave guns melt the flesh off their skeletons. A broken teleporter will disintegrate its unlucky user into a pile of red goop. You can use all these against enemy guards, as well as unlucky workers or scientists. It's up to you to decide if that's OK. The game grosses you out by sparing no detail.

Let's contrast that to Brigador: while this game also has a huge arsenal, the effects of the weapons don't seem to be so varied. Shoot a building and it will crumble. Shoot an enemy and it will explode. Shoot a fleeing civilian and it will splat. So there's not much variety there. The difference is just how easy it is to even accidentally destroy the environment while you walk through it, and it's pretty much inevitable you will kill civilians. The other difference is morality: while Crusader used the "evil mega-corp" to mitigate the guilt a bit, Brigador doesn't hold those pretenses. You're leveling whole cities, from favelas to mansions in the suburbs, while the residents flee. All sides of the conflict do this, without penalties. Some missions happen in cemeteries, so even the dead don't get to rest.

Once I realized this, I felt a little sick and it made me re-evaluate how I was playing. This game grossed me out not because of the detailed description of death, but because of the scale of the destruction and its implications. I've heard the (audio?)book is great too, I need to read (hear?) it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001507954', 'num_games_owned': 3199, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1705531582}
review:
[h1]Brigador[/h1]

In the densely retro neon cityscape of Solo Nobre, disorder and disorganization is felt through the streets as three dangerous factions vie for control. Capitalizing on the turmoil in the streets is a band of ruthless and skilled mercenary pilots with a fleet of extraordinary and unique vehicles of destruction at their disposal. [b]This playground of fully destructible dystopian environment is yours for the taking and yours for the plundering[/b], as you smash through 37 intense missions with the [b]56 death-dealing mech toys available to play with[/b].

[b]Destruction[/b]. [b]Satisfaction[/b]. That is the modus operandi here in [i]Brigador[/i].

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The trajectory aiming and angled shelling of baddies from your lurching mech behemoth feels realistic and wholly impactful, leaving a lot of room for strategy and tactics in how you dispatch your enemies in their various environmental placements. Defensive stances can be taken and your sights can be unlocked to fully scope out your opposition and plan out tactical approaches to handling them with little mess. [b]Or you could just go full Rambo[/b] and mow everything down in sight civilians, buildings and all.

There's a gritty band of pilots to choose from each with their own mechs or tanks to pilot that are proficient in their own areas. Just to name a couple; You have Singh and his behemoth Kilgore tank with its [b]ram-capable sturdiness[/b], and the punk-y Snell with her mobile Canavan and its [b]quick hover strafing and maneuvering mechanics[/b] with a whole lot more quirky and uniquely playable personalities to meet along the way. The choice is yours to go about things in a steady and strategic way planning your attack from afar or to just take your behemoth deathmachine and sledgehammer through your adversaries with reckless abandon. Either way, [b]you're gonna have a lot of fun[/b].

From the nostalgic joys of [i]Blast Corps[/i]. and its [b]reward-by-destruction[/b] formula, [i]Brigador[/i] brings that same [b]anarchistic and anti-authoritarian feeling of city-wide rebellion and chaos[/b]. As your arsenal ramps up so does the banquet of blood and explosions surrounding you, with a satisfying and rewarding scene of shock and awe in the wake of every leveled and destroyed cityscape.

[h1]Visuals/Sound[/h1]

If you've heard of [i]Brigador[/i], there's a pretty good chance you've already heard about its stellar soundtrack. Heavy and entrancing synthwave by way of synthwave electronic pioneers [url=https://makeupandvanityset.bandcamp.com/]Makeup and Vanity Set[/url] clocking in at 2 hours of head-pulsing and nostalgic synth tones and retrofuture beats set the neon 80's vibe here.

There's a whole heap of isometric eye candy to go along with it from its atmospheric retrofuture urban landscapes with the oppressive overtones of authoritarian cyberpunk dystopia. A vision best seen in arthouse masterpieces of the late 80's and early 90's like Gilliam's [i]Brazil[/i] or Otomo's [i]Akira[/i]. The beautiful chaos of destruction on full display as buildings crumble to your firepower and insignificant little humans crush beneath your metal feet like bugs.

[h1]Final Thought[/h1]

If you're one of the poor, unfortunate souls who hasn't been bestowed with exposure to [i]Brigador[/i]'s cyberpunk greatness just as I was until recently, this is the perfect chance to remedy that mistake. Two years down the road and I'm still not sure if [i]Brigador[/i] ever got the exposure it deserved, but what I do know is that it has a very dedicated and deserved fanbase of diehard enthusiasts who delve into every facet of its lore and world.

One thing's for sure; the brothers at Stellar Jockey know what the hell they're doing, and I certainly hope they continue on with their heavy and gritty take on cyberpunk authoritarian dystopias.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031675374', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1625244757}
review:
Considering that this was originally intended as a turn-based game and just kinda became a twin-stick shooter later, the result is stupidly good.

The aesthetics are on point, the performance is expectedly rock solid for a mostly 2D game, soundtrack is great.
Gameplay itself is just what you'd expect from this sort of a game and it's interesting how it has elements of stealth to it that can be utilized to great extent in smaller vehicles. [spoiler]Good luck doing Hell in a Two-Stroke achievement the intended way instead of cheesing it[/spoiler]
Worth noting that this game has an unexpected amount of very nicely written flavor text to it that uncovers quite a bit of history behind the events as well as providing general idea on how certain vehicles and armaments are best used. Whoever wrote the weapon descriptions specifically deserves a personal espresso machine.

Overall, it's probably the best top-down shooter you can get right now, especially for the price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992100266', 'num_games_owned': 5293, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1532369185}
review:
坐在机甲上，把面前的一切都扫成碎片，我就是——捣乱者！！！！
虽然官译名字很奇怪，但这是一款画面华丽，手感奇佳的45度俯视角双摇杆机甲射击游戏。
—————————————————————————
虽然不知道作者用的什么引擎，看起来是仿古2D点阵画面,但是渲染出的光影效果别有一番华丽的韵味。优点不少：
1.机甲动作流畅，射击时子弹夹杂着烟尘，在抖动的枪口中喷薄而出，伴随着激荡的音乐，敌方机甲一个个倒下爆炸时的感觉简直不能再赞。
2.各种爆炸效果的使用。游戏物理模拟比较真实，不同威力的武器打在同样物体上，效果绝无雷同。
3.各种场景描绘的细致生动，而且百分百可破坏。看着各种建筑碎片横飞，烟雾弥漫的倒下成为废墟蛮爽快，喜欢拆迁的可以大展身手了（笑）
4.游戏中的不同机甲效果多样，配合副武器系统（EMP，烟雾弹，隐形迷彩），后期横扫一切可以体会到唯我独尊的感觉
—————————————————————————
至于缺点也有一些：
1.中文机翻，虽然大概能看出啥意思来。（标题捣乱者什么鬼23333）再有就是地图如果再多些就好了。
2.系统还是比较单薄，机甲不能定制有点伤，作为一辆机甲，武器没有导弹类和激光类有点不合格（笑）
—————————————————————————
特别提示：要特别注意地图上的爆炸物！！！！这玩意威力大不管炸到谁都有奇效（笑）
—————————————————————————

review: This is a great game. I think it's the most dark synthwave thing ever created and that alone makes it a timeless gem. As someone who listens to wave music I could have bought this for the music, never mind the incredibly fun game play. The only thing this game is missing is coop/multiplayer but that doesn't detract from the experience. Given this game is a couple years old now I can only hope the devs read this review and realize they could bolt a community map generator, coop, and multiplayer modes onto it and resell it to critical acclaim. Shit, I can only imagine how fun this game would be as a multiplayer game with team-PvP mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096342667', 'num_games_owned': 3294, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1531670174}
review:
声明

游戏来源于STCN：https://steamcn.com/
STCN鉴赏家：http://store.steampowered.com/curator/255962/
完整图文评测：https://steamcn.com/t406599-1-1

       虽有古文云“乃知兵者是凶器，圣人不得已而用之。”，但其实，很多男生心中都或多或少埋藏着一颗叛逆的种子，当这颗种子接触到一种名为新鲜感的养分后，便会花开遍野。犹记得，在《GTA》横空出世时，这些充满诱惑力的叛逆可能给世人展现出其妖艳到极致的游戏性，更是让很多玩家感受到了不为规则所束缚的快感。这种快感是一种天性使然。几乎每一个男孩子，都有过一段喜欢打打杀杀搞破坏的日子，进入了规则引领的秩序世界后，我们把这种爱好埋藏进内心深处，直到第九艺术给我们机会以极低的代价体验一个个鲜活而又一定程度上可被破坏的世界之时，很多人终于能填上心中缺失的那一个窟窿。

       《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》也是这样的一个填窟作品。在这款游戏中，我们将扮演一个个个性诡异的机甲战士，踏上故土极尽破坏之能事。最初，《Brigador》场景破坏的核心设计意图是为了弥补一款著名战争游戏的破坏活动的不足。《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》的主创人员Hugh Monahan曾经说过，他虽然很喜欢《战地：叛逆连队2》，但是其关键道具被固定地放置了，加之很多场景无法充分破坏，因此玩家的自由度受到了限制，因此他希望在《Brigador》中做出他希望的更丰满的那种破坏层次。

       尝试更丰满的破坏层次，也许就意味着做一些别的开发者没做过的事。正如《黑道圣徒》的开发团队Volitions曾赋予《红色派系：游击战》的那种极具真实感的物理引擎那样，《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》的开发者Stellar Jockeys也将面临这样的挑战。区别是，Volitions是一个技术实力强劲的成熟开发团队，其在THQ破产之后，仍以22.3亿美元的价值卖身成功，而Stellar Jockeys则只是一个一开始仅由三人组成的制作团队，资金来源存疑。在这种情况下，Stellar Jockeys仍然毅然决然地决定开发一套游戏引擎来制作《Brigador》，这不得不令人心起尊敬。

       21世纪的游戏市场，虽然涌入了诸多独立游戏，但更多决定其销量的仍是市场推广与游戏本身的硬实力。看过《独立游戏大电影》的人都知道，哪怕如《FEZ》那样素质如此过硬的独立游戏，其开发团队仍然面临着生理和心理的双重巨大压力。而更多的独立游戏开发者，包括Stellar Jockeys，将长期面临着投入与产出的严重不均衡。事实上，投入了5年研发时间的《Brigador》正是那一颗投入这一片红海市场中的一颗常见的小石子，虽以90%以上的好评率掀起了一些涟漪，但也终究沉入了大海。直到Humble的2017年月包将其捆绑给订阅玩家之前，《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》一直都在叫好不叫座的尴尬境地之中徘徊。

       忽略掉这些外部因素和Stellar Jockeys在市场营销上的失败决策，让我们平心气和地探究一下《Brigador》的游戏本身到底出了什么差错。初次体验过《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》之后，我深深感受到这款游戏的用心之处，多样化的机甲和武器搭配，几乎完全可破坏的场景，出色的战斗光影效果等种种深度要素似乎阐述了其为何能获得94%好评的原因。但尽管《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》在游戏的机甲武器等内容上做了非常多的内容填充，却在玩法上设计的非常单薄——任务几乎只有破坏和杀敌，没有解谜，剧情薄弱而不连贯，rpg元素的缺失，联机要素的缺乏……这就使得很多玩家在给这款游戏打上好评之后，还是依然向他们的好友推荐诸如《Rim world》、《看火人》、《星露谷物语》、《盐和避难所》、《缺氧》等等更具话题性或互动性的游戏作品。毕竟2016年的优秀独立游戏如此之多，这一片名为独立游戏的战场，早就已经成为了一片名副其实的尸横遍野的红海市场。

       仅就其展现出的游戏内容来看，虽然《Brigador: Up-Armored Edition》衍生出的变化不多，但其表现却也对得起其好评如潮的评价。也许是限于现实生活的压力和研发决策失误，这款作品并没有在那些易于产生话题性的元素上做进一步拓展，也是令人可惜之处了。

review:
Incredible soundtrack.

Game istelf is a lot of fun, can be difficult at times however.  But its very easy to jump from one mission to another without much in the way of downtime, so retrying missions isn't an issue.  There isn't so much of a campaign since its mostly tutorials, but the game has a Freelance mode that is strictly gameplay specific without handholding.

In a lot of ways too, Brigador reminds me of Future Cop LAPD, another fun game.  Either way, Brigador is sweet.  Give a whirl sometime.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987156904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 1205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1533688012}
review:
My time with Brigador was fun, but there are a few design flaws that stop the experience from being truly great. 

Brigador's isometric mech combat is satisfying and more than adequately varied. Similarly, the environments are exquisitely detailed and varied. Neither the combat mechanics nor the environments ever feel stale throughout the campaign. 

What holds this game back is the low difficulty level of the campaign. The game has a great engine, but the campaign missions can be thoughtlessly steamrolled by any reasonably competent player. It rarely feels like it is necessary to use tactical subtlety and problem solving over brute force. This means the game's mechanics are not fully expressed, leaving the game feeling flatter than it could have been. While the game does have a longer form 'freelance' mode that bears some similarity to roguelikes, if you are like myself, you enjoy a more curated experience. Thus, I am forced to file Brigador away into the "could have been a lot better" category.

Some people have also commented on the highly interesting world building that seems inadequately explored due to the way the story is told. I agree, but I think this is more a matter of writing quality than of delivery method. I noticed numerous spelling errors, grammatical artifacts, and tangled wording that left me having to re-read passages numerous times. Additionally, the sequence of lore that is titrated to you over the campaign often feels disordered. However, some of the writing is decent, which leads me to believe that they didn't have a competent editor on hand to help achieve consistency.

This problem of great engine building with sloppy design seems to be endemic among smaller developers. I hope the devs will not make these mistakes in their next game. 

Criticisms aside, I would like to close by complimenting the game on its theme. 

The world of Brigador is cold and brutal, being driven by the self interest of the four factions. Although Solo Nobre is a place of high technology, it feels like wilderness of metal. All of the factions are reprehensible by our standards. Their conflict is akin to predators fighting over territory and resources with the total amorality that follows one animal sustaining its life at the cost of another. 

We live in a time of relative stability. Arguably, this stability is enabled not by the exceptional goodness of modern man, but by novel power dynamics which render predatorial conflicts too costly. We often forget the animalistic forces which drove the conflcts of the past, and which pulse throughout the undercurrents of our world in the form of geopolitical standoffs and corporate machinations. Brigador has explored what a world of intelligent animals looks like when armed conflict is highly profitable. I have not seen this theme expressed in such a distilled manner, and for that reason, I feel that Brigador has accomplished something truly interesting.

review:
Remember the factory shootout scene from Robocop? There's a badass mech with a badass gun, lots of violence, and a gritty, 80's VHS feel to everything? Well that's kinda what this game feels like, once you get the hang of it. It's good.

In less poetic terms, it's an isometric mech sim. It's got a ton of cool mechs, tanks and grav bikes to pilot, and lots of satisfyingly shooty guns to bolt on these machines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105326036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1555268580}
review:
Really having a blast with this game.

Lots of depth. In campaign mode you can tailor each mission's difficulty by picking stronger or weaker vehicles. But there's also a puzzle aspect of it as some missions can't be beaten just with brute force, you gotta play stealthy.

You can completely tailor to your playstyle. Every mech and vehicle plays differently, and when you begin freelance mode and customize them all with weapons and pilots, you can tailor difficulty, create your own unique challenges. I've never played anything quite like this.

You can take a casual approach to the game and play the stronger mechs with more firepower or you can go with the tiny guys with pea shooters and get extra rewards for taking on the extra challenge. There's even an unlockable freelance campaign with 39 sequential levels and no save points for the ultra hardcore. Get it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971536555', 'num_games_owned': 1667, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1529260885}
review: I'm rather disappointed with this game. I played for about 30 missions and didn't feel challenged even once. I expected a game with complex mechanics, and found that they can be ignored, and shooting willy-nilly is enough to solve most situations.
developer_response:
We're sorry to hear that you didn't find the game challenging. For most of the game's life, we've had the opposite problem, which is why the game was relaunched with such a long and gently sloped tutorial section, because the vast majority of the players were not understanding how to play the game, quitting out and refunding. The trouble with addressing those concerns means that we've generally gotten fewer refunds, we have the opposite problem: any players that don't need that long of a ramp-up get bored.

If you still own the game, we recommend a few key enhancements: make sure the game is played at 100% speed (not the default 80%, which is tweaked for controllers and also easier difficulty overall) and use relative (tank) controls with m+kb, and go straight into Freelance mode, rather than work your way through the campaign first, which has a long introductory portion, only becoming challenging much later (if ever, for some). Though you will still need to modulate your own difficulty to some degree in Freelance by picking tougher pilots, there is much more definite challenge played that way. Thanks for playing the game.

review:
GREAT LEADER IS DEAD
SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL

Welcome, Brigador.

Fan of mechs? top down shooters? highly customizeable vehicles? varying playstyles ranging from mouse with a laser pointer to a fuckhuge mech that would make an ork shed a tear of joy? This game has all of that in such a beautiful looking, beautiful sounding package in such an interesting setting and also thankfully with enough lore to put AAA rpg games to shame.

Amazingly replayable with tight gameplay. You are doing a disservice to yourself by not giving this game a try if you're into these types of games.

review:
Brigador is somewhere between a strategy game and a shmup. Once you take the time to learn the vehicle controls, learn the to use the aiming reticle, and being to understand the properties of weapons, then you can really dig into the game.  The game play is diverse and can range from stealthy, mobile mechs armed with silent chemical weapons and lasers creeping through a residential subdivision to high speed hit and run attacks in the cyberpunk streets, to all out warfare in a massive machine decimating waves of attacking troops. This isn't a game that is won by reflexes, this is a game that is won by tactical thinking: bait those goons into a chokepoint and hammer them with the big guns.

Highly recommended. Brigador is everything a computer game should be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004208837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1565764046}
review:
This game is awesome!

They tagged it as an 'isometric intense tactical combat game' and it is very much that. As a badass mercenary from the future (yep it's science fiction), you will pilot various war vehicles from tanks, to hovercraft, to mechs that carry some truly destructive weaponry. Your goal: kick the ass of various military factions & escape from Solo Nobre. Ha! That should ring a bell for the likes of 'Escape from New York' or 'Escape from Los Angeles' by John Carpenter. Call me 'Snake in a Tank'!

The best part: Almost everything you see around you on the map can be (and probably will be) destroyed as soon as you (and the bad guys) pull the trigger. It looks beautiful, it's fun, oh and it has a neat synthwave soundtrack!

Some tips that will help you early on:

[h1]Campaign vs Freelance[/h1]
Brigador has two main game modes. Campaign and Freelance. Campaign teaches you the game, starts with tutorial missions that will help you through the basics, but then towards the middle and especially at the end missions you will be tested. I recommend that newcomers do the Campaign first. Freelance is a bit more complex... it's a sort of sandbox mode that is likely aimed towards advanced pilots. In the Campaign you can choose only from a few vehicles that will come with predefined weapons and abilities usually fitting the sort of mission that you need to accomplish. In Freelance you can bring whatever vehicle and weapons you want as long as you have it unlocked. Doing the Campaign will earn you tons of money, so then you can go Freelance with kickass weapons. Neat!

[h1]Tactics & Resources[/h1]
This game as mentioned above is a tactical game! If you try to just walk in and engage the enemy forces head on... you will almost certainly lose every time. For a single vehicle to defeat hundreds... you will need to choose your battles, refill your shields, manage your ammo and prioritize targets the correct way. Each vehicle will come with a special ability like Cloaking, Smoke Screen, EMP or a devastating Shockwave. These specials have unlimited charges except for their cooldown and their correct utilization is key to success. Lure in enemies, flank, use melee to conserve ammo, pick up all ammo and shield drops. You will get the hang of this, no worries!

[h1]Friendly Fire / Self Fire?[/h1]
Your weapons (and your vehicles themselves) are super deadly, so you will need to learn not to kill yourself. This is one of the main challenges, and actually surprisingly tricky at first. When your massive gun blows up like a 100 meter radius crater per round, it is not smart to fire at point blank. Easier said, then done when you are in intense combat, firing and navigating the environment at high velocity. Give it time, and experiment with the various weapons.

[h1]Explosive Buildings[/h1]
Fuel stations, orbital guns and fuel lines explode when rammed (sometimes a simple contact will trigger) or if fired into. These can change the tide of combat favorably or end your life in an instant. Always scan your surrounding for such explosives and take it into account before you engage. Do NOT go near them or you will learn the hard way. The tutorial missions will showcase this to you, but you truly need to pay attention.

[h1]Suicide Enemies - Red Beam[/h1]
Another deadly threat are the suicide enemies. They will ram you and explode for massive damage, unless you identify them by their glowing red beam and take them out first. Once they are somewhat close, they should be your number one priority target.

[h1]Facing and Rear Damage[/h1]
Never turn your back to the enemy! Sounds simple, but cannot be emphasised enough. The body of your vehicle can face a different dirrection then your turret. You control the turret with the mouse, and the vehicle's body with the keyboard. Your vehicle facing is indicated via a small yellow arrow and it should always look towards the enemy when you expect to be hit. Your rear armor is weak and will result in major damage if not instant death if a strong weapon hits you there.

[h1]Spotter Enemies - Blue Eye[/h1]
These enemies will raise the alarm, and bring tons of reinforcements and all kinds of nastiness on you. Take them out before the time runs out!

[h1]Strong Starter Mech for Freelance[/h1]
You can buy 50+ vehicles and they are all quite cool and powerful, but which one to get first?
I advise you to get the [b]Aetós[/b] which is a Spacer Mech that can carry the heaviest weapons in the game, has extremely powerful melee and full 360° turret movement. I use mine with [b]'König'[/b] Primary (massive gatling gun) and [b]'Ploughman'[/b] Secondary (large area bio-weapon). Another combo that works well is [b]'König'[/b] and [b]'Chieftain'[/b]. From specials, I recommend the [b]Cloaking[/b] technology, as it's very versatile and easy to use.

[h1]Pilots in Freelance[/h1]
This is a tricky thing as well. Pilots in Freelance mode have to be unlocked and will determine critical factors such as difficulty and money earned. Choose your pilot with care and review the values, so you know what you are singing up for.

Happy hunting!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001370961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2538, 'last_played': 1530363008}
review:
Brigador is an action-packed indie game that deserves more recognition (RPS has done a nice job covering it and singing its praises).

The gameplay is chaotic and intense. The flow of Brigador’s gameplay feels similar to the Desert and Nuclear Strike games, Crusader: No Remorse and even some ARPGs.

The isometric graphics & lighting are colorful and interesting. The soundtrack is gripping synthwave.

The developers are active and friendly on social media and the Steam forums.

My favorite parts of Brigador are the art direction and the lore. The mechs, tanks, and hovercraft are strange, beautiful war machines on the grungy sci-fi planet. I have probably spent just as much time reading the colorful in-game lore about the vehicles, weapons, and pilots as I have blasting through missions.

The universe and writing are great (the fiction e-book is a fun read too) and the developers have mentioned they are at work on a new game in the same universe. My hope is that they use the same beautiful engine and create a turn-based, squad-level strategy game with a story-driven campaign. I would love to take command of multiple squads of Spacer walkers, tanks, and agravs against some hardnose Loyalist fortifications in a story-driven campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983469595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2925, 'last_played': 1593449323}
review:
Great art design, soundtrack and gameplay. 

The campaign has over 25 missions which are generally fairly short but feature 3-4 different loadouts for each one and the playstyle is very different depending on which one you choose. Beating the campaign with all 4 loadouts on every mission has taken me around 20 hours. 

In tandem is the freelance mode which allows you to select which mission or sequence of maps to play. This is where you get to customize basically every aspect of the game, ranging from your vehicle, your 2 weapons, special ability and your pilot. The amount of enemies and their difficulty is based on which pilot you choose. There is also a randomize button and the possibility to change just 1 of the variables if you are satisfied with your loadout before starting your run. This is where the rogue-lite side of the game takes place. 

The controls are very customizable, you can also use a slider to determine the speed of the game. I recommend setting it to 100% unless you use a controller. 

The gameplay is deeper than it might seem at first glance with a few different systems going on, I recommend reading a few guides on steam. 

The story is presented more in a "world-building" way and the game is filled with great writing. The story and background to this interesting universe is mostly through the vehicle, weapon and mission descriptions.  I think it's worth taking the time to read it all as it really fleshes out the game world and the story isn't really presented upfront. 

Most of the big reviewers reviewed this game when it first launched in 2015 and were giving it favorable scores. The game has since then improved a lot from what I'm seeing, withmajor patches still happening as of june 2018. 

I personally picked up the deluxe edition which includes over 40 tracks in total and an audiobook (haven't listened to the book yet though) and I think the soundtrack alone is easily worth the extra $5.

Overall I really recommend this game, I can see myself playing for many more hours. It might not be for everybody, but if you enjoy synthwave, outrun, cyberpunk themes etc and a retro feel to your games this will definitely hit the spot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001845435', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1692763787}
review:
There is so, [i]so[/i] much to love about this game.

I, like all of the other people I've talked to about it, had no idea how I hadn't heard of it before. Even after putting it on my wishlist, it skipped my mind repeatedly until it came up in this year's Summer Sale. And now that I have it, I am honestly regretful that I didn't pay full price for it, as it is unquestionably worth it. It's as deep as you want it to be — you can decide so much of your experience, from mission length in freelance mode, to the type and weaponry of your playable mech. 'Mech' being a catchall term here: There are several visibly and mechanically distinct forms of playable war machine, each individual unit carrying its own unique combination of the game's weapon systems. You can choose to breeze through a two-zone mission with a badass god-machine that crushes through structures and enemies alike, or put yourself in a light mech to run-and-gun your way through an entire mini-campaign.

And of course you'll be rewarded accordingly. Something this game does extremely well (at least in my experience) is keep you teetering on the edge of your comfort zone. Sure, you can do that mission you've gotten down pat with the pilot you like and a mech you know can handle it, but the payout would be so much [i]better[/i] if you brought that little fast powersuit that can only mount two small weapons... Stuff like that. It's very rewarding to lean toward the outer edge of your ability. Sure, there's a risk of you dying and losing the reward entirely, but if you manage to pull through, it is more than worth that chance. Money buys everything from new mechs and weapons, to pilots themselves, and even bits of lore and intelligence on in-game factions and elements.

Speaking of the lore, the setting is beautifully hazy and believable. Residing somewhere on the quasi-cyberpunk spectrum, with a grim devaluation of individual lives, and set after the normalization of space travel. It's well thought out, with elements that made me laugh and others that made me grimace from the too-real aspect of it. The backdrop and scenery as you stomp around and blow shit up slowly comes to make more and more sense as you play, even if you don't go out of your way to read the lore entries or do the campaign missions. Despite the characters being little more than portraits and stat sheets for your mech, they have their own summary articles that give them depth, and I would almost guarantee you'll quickly find one that you like for reasons other than just their completion bonuses.

I've run a bit longer than I intended here, but I really do want to drive home that this game deserves much more attention and praise than it's gotten. I've only started scratching the surface of it, but I can tell it's going to be a mainstay in my library for quite a while.

review:
打穿了评测一下：
1.官方机翻中文（在后续更新中已经换成正经中文了）
2.虽然乍看上去是驾驶机甲的游戏，其实双足机甲、车、悬浮飞行器各占三分之一左右的比重
3.武器和载具种类很多，各有特色。但强的很强，弱的很弱
4.关卡类型和任务目标比较单一。任务模式打穿一次只需要几小时
5.Rogue要素只体现在随机选地图随机选角色之类的方面
6.战斗非常爽快，真100%可破坏场景。不同武器的破坏力差异也很明显

总的来说这游戏底子很好，但玩起来有点单薄。如果游戏内容尤其关卡和任务设计方面能再加强一些的话就好了

author: {'steamid': '76561198025122777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1535761547}
review:
i could barely believe the unison joy in the reviews for this one, so i bought it to see for myself. i am no fan of nostalgia gaming, meaning the likes of syndicate and others would not be the reason i bought this. 
this game tho, took me a bit by surprise, cos it starts you off kind of easily, but all of a sudden you find yourself punished. the total destruction of maps feels nice on my insides, and makes me a bit warm too! yes, and the weapons are quite capable and very satisfying to fire, but that's where your first punishment comes. out of ammo. the second is when you're gung-hoing the map, you find yourself suddenly shot to bits, cos it was all weapons and no tactics. one example: out of ammo, and the last objective i had was to take out an ammo depot. i stand next to it and mechstomp and end up blowing myself up. i have to restart.
it might not be punishing enough for the hardcores, but i find it quite right. 

8/8, recommended! 
- casual

author: {'steamid': '76561198026360511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1529595213}
review:
"You got your war crimes in my roguelike!"
"Oh yeah? Well, you got your deep and disturbing lore into my distopian social commentary?"
"Fellas, fellas, why argue when there are so many civillian buildings undestroyed out there?"

Brigador is the most criminally unheralded game I've ever seen. It does not reinvent the wheel, but takes unique elements from so many disparate inspirations- mech games, roguelites, isometric city builders, synthwave, Latin literarature- and puts them together into an incredibly complex, cohesive, replayable, and above all, polished whole. I have never seen such a true "indie" game with such a cohesive identity formed right off of the bat. 

The story is intruiging, the gameplay is accessible yet super fun and deep, and the second worst thing you can do today is NOT buy Brigador. 

(The first worst thing is all the war crimes in Brigador).

review: This game was a surprise hit for me. I had never heard of it before I received it from a Humble Monthly Bundle, but after having played it I can say it is worth the full price. It has both a beautiful soundtrack and gorgeous graphics. The gameplay is fun and the mechs all feel very responsive. There are extensive customizations options for mechs in game, and each new configuration drastically changes how you approach missions and combat, and keeps the game feeling fresh. The one weak point is the story. While there is extensive lore in-game in the form of a kind of encyclopedia entry that can be unlocked by earning credits and purchasing the information, most of it is not told more naturally through the game's story. That being said, all of the positive aspects of the game heavily outweigh that.

review:

Brigador这个名字显然是从Brigadier-陆军的旅长，准将来的，那brigador肯定有相似性，更具体的一点看看Urban Dictionary: Stemming from brigadoon (a place that is idyllic, unaffected by time, or remote from reality) and Brigadier (a rank of officer above colonel and below major general.) , this term describes an officer of unknown and surreal landscapes that need the firm palm of law to guide its wildlands.
捣蛋者这个名字既不准确，也不酷，也不符合游戏剧情，想个更好的很容易啊，叫“机甲叛将”不好吗？？？

author: {'steamid': '76561198010545488', 'num_games_owned': 3539, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1501, 'last_played': 1564816435}
review:
惊闻这游戏更新中文了，那我来写一下……

前略，致天国的钢铁咆哮：
虽然这游戏是开机甲，但总体来说，游戏的整体套路明显更接近钢铁咆哮而不是mechwarrior，防2D的斜45度手绘画面，机甲武器自由拼装，驾驶员自由更换（虽然只影响难度），打起来画面乒乒乓乓非常热闹，这些都会让人有玩钢铁咆哮的错觉……

能做到这种程度就足以说明这游戏是个还不错的小游戏了，熟悉套路之后打起来会很顺畅，而且套路武器有很多种，可以刚可以苟，不想手抽筋可以整个肥宅机甲，想拿高分可以上小麻雀，成就感还是挺好。

但是说到底这也就是个4399，没有僚机，武器只能带两把，武器和机体虽然有很多选择但总体来说数量仍显不足，而且……别看他介绍是ROGUELIKE啊，地图都是固定的！只是出生点和敌人配置会有变化，而且后期为了打高分需要连肝很多场，万一中途一下手残直接几个小时白干，当然如果觉得自由模式太累专心研究剧情固定配置过关倒是也可以，但是这样内容就显得更不足了……

最后，请远离地图上的一切爆炸物。

哎啥时候KOEI才能把钢铁咆哮2EX和3挪上STEAM惹…………

author: {'steamid': '76561198037169608', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1529339568}
review:
Attirato dalle recensioni "ESTREMAMENTE POSITIVE" sul titolo (acquistato da terze parti) eccolo nella mia libreria pronto a sfornarvi e condividere con voi, il mio ennesimo parere.
Brigador: Up-Armored Edition è un grido di gloria nefasto e distruttivo in onore di tutti quei giochi di stampo retrò che tentano, ricalcando vecchie glorie, di farsi valere ancora oggi nel mercato dei videogamers.

Nei panni di un mercenario alla guida di uno dei 56 robottoni, carri armati, furgoni, astronavi ed assudità varie disponibili, non importa quale sia il vostro obiettivo.. l'importante è raggiungerlo e percorrere la strada fino ad esso nel modo più distruttivo possibile! Questo è lo scopo.. questo è il fine.. questo è il senso! 
Uno sparatutto isometrico, che vi regalerà qualche ora di spensierato svago.. a me sinceramente rilassa molto distruggere le cose e bhe, Brigador: Up-Armored Edition, ha mappe dettagliatissime e totalmente distruttibili in ogni singolo pixel! 
Insomma, che male c'è ad avere ogni tanto qualche delirio di onnipotenza e seminare distruzione e panico??

State attenti però.. Brigador: Up-Armored Edition, secondo me, come detto precedentemente, [b]NON E' UN GIOCO[/b] ma un semplice [b]PASSATEMPO[/b]. Una spensierata postilla quando magari sono le 20:00, avete un appuntamento alle 20:30 e siete già pronti  ma, la vostra consorte vi dice che ancora deve truccarsi e quindi vi posticipa minimo di mezz'ora.. Oppure, quando siete totalmente scazzati che vi fa schifo alzarvi anche per andare a pisciare! Che si fa in questi casi??

 [h1]>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> BRIGATOR: UP-ARMORED EDITION!<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<[/h1]

SI, ha una trama (banale e del tutto secondaria) ma, fondamentalmente non la cagherete di striscio. Quello che conta è la distruzione totale.. distruzione che dopo un paio di ore vi avrà già annoiato perchè, parliamoci chiaramente.. è uno sparatutto isometrico vecchio stampo. Siamo nel 2018 e c'è sicuramente di mooooolto meglio praticamente allo stesso prezzo. Cazz 19,99 euro, è come se vi proponessero se foste favorevoli a subire una rapina a mano armata seguita da stupro! 
Cioè dai.. vi scrivo questa recensione mentre su Steam, in questo preciso momento, offrono a 14 euro The Witcher 3. Dunque, a buon intenditore.....

Concludendo,  Brigador: Up-Armored Edition è un titolo carino, spensierato, divertente che consiglio perchè ,nel suo genere, è realizzato molto bene ma da comprare solo quando non superà le 3 euro SE SIETE PROPRIO FAN degli sparatutto isometrici vecchio stampo o cercate semplicemente un modo carino di coprire qualche vostro "buco" nella routine giornaliera.

[b]PRO:[/b]
- adrenalinico sparatutto isometrico SBOOOMMM!!!! RATATATATATAT!!! PFIUUUUUUUU!!! ZAAAAAAAAAEEEON! (onomatopee assortite di missili, esplosioni, laser ecc ecc)
- mappe dettagliatissime e totalmente distruttibili
- gira anche su una caffettiera
- validissimo e spensierato passatempo che svolge egregiamente il suo scopo di intrattenervi..

[b]CONTRO:[/b]
- ...quando non c'avete un c...o da fare!
- alla lunga annoia..
- destinato principalmente ad una specifica fetta di videogiocatori.
- controllare certi mezzi è così macchinoso che vi potrebbe far venire l'ulcera perforante.
- non c'è l'ITALIANO tra le lingue disponibili ma non so se, in questa tipologia di giochi, sia un vero e proprio difetto.
- 19,99 euro.. WUUUAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA! 

[b]VOTO COME "PASSATEMPO":
6/10[/b]
