author: {'steamid': '76561198019182562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4549, 'last_played': 1710249033}
review:
TL;DR: I love this game. This game is not going to be to everyone's taste.

Brigador is a bizarre beast. If you watch some gameplay footage, you'll see it's a game about someone in some sort of armored vehicle, speeding around, and leaving in a trail of destruction.

You can't really miss that much. But the game is a damn iceberg and that stuff is the tip.

I didn't expect depth from a game like this. Or a surprising amount of nostalgia too. This game plays as much like the Desert Strike series on the Megadrive/Genesis and SNES (mercifully without any fuel demands) as it does any twitchy twin stick shooter - and that isn't so obvious from the gameplay footage.

For one level, the game Brigador most felt like to me was Hitman: Codename 47 (the very first game, before the series truly found its feet). I'd clear targets, little chance of surviving a straight up fight, not even speed to just hit-and-run them all, and needed to think of the level as a puzzle and a search for a path of least resistance. When I finished that level (with the ridiculous amount of flowers) I felt a kind of satisfaction I hadn't since the day I texted 'LEE HONG IS DEAD' to a friend with no other context. We both knew exactly what that meant. We'd both been there.

The setting for this game has executed lore in a way that puts RPGs to shame. There's a monopoly on that information. Held by people of ill repute. You pay significant costs for it, up front. No refunds. That money you're paying feels HARD earned. There are no freebies or audiologs falling out of the pockets of your foes here. Not one voice acted pilot will verbally barf exposition or their life story at you. These people are the same ones that throw on contrived fees for every failed mission so on death you get a pittance. 

You grow to hate them. You should.
Oh. And these are your business partners and your only way out of escaping a planet ran by a dictator. These are as close as you'll get to people who aren't your fellow idiomatic crabs in the barrel.

You're in this position because you're in no position to bargain. EVERYTHING you earn feels you got gipped (massive transaction fees hinting at corruption, or a budget for Brigador payments that reflected you beat the odds and survived when they calculated you were as good as dead the minute you accepted the contract). It feels like a one player version of shady EVE intrigue. There's an angle being worked by big players. You're just a detail here. A replaceable part. And both everything you learn and everything you do to learn more about it reinforces you're not a big deal here. There's some astronomical gap in power here between a player and the powers that be in this game. The kind of gap that normally only appears in horror like Lovecraft's or a setting like Shadowrun where no matter how big you are, you're no match for the smallest of dragons.

You get told what you need to (if even that much...) and then lead on your way to blow it up. Don't expect pluck, or tones of anime shonen heroism in mechas. There are no genki girls and any 'I believe in you' best friends are filling the collosal numbers of graves that appear in some levels. The level design in what is shown in abundance and what is shown barely both hint of a planet that is closer to warhammer 40,000. Not all the way grimdark, but even the vice and black market seem like they were being rationed out by Great Leader.

Until mission 1 began the's signs there was barely law here. Before mission 1 ends you feel what a Brigador must feel. You started pumped up, over-equipped and under informed.  Then confusion over the importance of what to do and what to absolutely not to do. Then frustration. Then a decision. Then you realise you're not going to be proud of what you're doing today. Then you do it. Then you get paid far too little and feel a mix of self loathing and ripped off. And that feeling of being ripped off makes it clear - now there is no law here.

This all happens with no cut scenes and less than 12 words of dialog. You're also given a choice that isn't immediately obvious. Looking at the statistics a lot of people either don't ever realise it is there or act in a way that makes the planet wide space dystopia that much more believable (look at rate of globally unlocked achievements closely). It's the best kind of morality system - mechanically none at all, and only the painful hindsight that many people could have been a better person. But they didn't. And here we all are now.

So yeah, it's clear I like the feel and the setting. Now, is there enough GAME to be worth the money?

Oh yeah. A ridiculous looking Scrapheap Challenge weldjob on meth (called a Treehouse) firing gas canisters like artillery, that melt anyone or thing like they're xenomorph blood has to be seen to be believed.

A nippy little high speed atrocity platform that feels like it was used by the Cylons with about as much regard for human life, that (on middle click) can make whatever is in front of it die in a war crime every is something that takes LOTS of practice to get the hang of. Especially when you're firing it every 7 seconds.

A Mantis with a twin pair of Belters feels like a scaled up ED209 with less subtly (somehow). And you're in it a planet with no stairs you can't flatten, no Robocop you can't stomp, no executives alive to react to Mr. Kinney's glitch induced high caliber acupuncture.

Killdozer? Killdozer.

Whatever you pick, it's not just about thoroughly doing the job. It's about getting to the shuttle alive to collect payment in full. And everything on the way feeling like it is trying to kill you. Even if some of those people are fleeing for their lives. And your mind is not on where you step anymore.

Soundtrack: One of my all time favs. One more reason I love this game. Check out Makeup & Vanity Set on Bandcamp to listen to it.

UPDATE:
Bought the audiobook DLC.
Money well spent.

review:
19,99€ for this? I expected at least something similar to Alien/Zombie Shooter, which are at least half as cheap and tons more fun then this. No, I honestly don't understand what they call a campaign, all I've seen was endless tutorials! Where's the gameplay, where's the meat grinder? 

Game: You know, you can break walls!
Me: Okay, thank you for the advice.
Game: Do you know how to walk? (Second mission)
Me: Facepalm, I already know it, I managed to complete the first mission.
Game: Did you know that your bullets are damaging the enemies?
Me: Oh I didn't know that, I've only killed couple of them before...
Game: Do you know how to shoot your weapons? It's Mouse 1 and 2 (third/forth mission).
Me: Facepalm, I shot them before! I know that...
Me: Quitting the campaign, trying to play free mode... what is that? What the F*** is that?
Me: Alright, I had enough. Quitting the game, asking Steam for refund...

People say, the first impression counts, well, my impression was ruined after a couple of unskipable missions with dumb advices instead of action...

review: One of the few games that actually makes me want to try harder when I lose. The games got too much going for it to cost 20 dollars. You got so many cars, so many guns, and so many guys to put in those cars to shoot those guns, and every guy gun and car has atleast a paragraph of writing grounding it in the games world. If you see something, with enough firepower strapped to your car you can destroy it. Walls, buildings, yourself even if you aren't careful. Came out a little over 2 years ago and still has dev support. The only game in my library I can honestly say i have zero regrets purchasing. Only real complaints I can field is that the enemy is sometimes too good at shooting you with hitscans as opposed to all other gun varieties, and that if you fight a bunch of dudes with AOE weapons it can suck to try to dodge shit. This can be seen as cheap, or a ever present threat to play around. However, you can always pick up the same railgun or howitzer the enemy just recked you with, and dunk them just as hard. I've never felt like a death was out of my control up until the moment I started panicking. If you like things that are good, you will like this. 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198078053406', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 15644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13955, 'last_played': 1693202270}
review:
Третьего дня, по совету проверенных камрадов, приобрёл новый мегадевайс — Brigador: Up-Armored Edition. Сразу же, задыхаясь от жадности, установил игру цепкими лапами и заюзал контракт. Размер, моё почтение. Настоящей глыбой был Precursor James. Даже моя, привыкшая к суровым NEPовским будням, жепа, отказывалась принимать с первого захода. Совместными с Kick Dickem усилиями забороли проблему. Ощущения — АТАС. С Mech Merc Company не идёт ни в какое сравнение. Кроме того, Black Hand приятно щекочет щиты. Проиграл так весь день. Решительно готов к совершению новых war crimes.
Многие spacers увидят тут проявления гомосексуализма. Тупым детям невдомёк, что NEP и corvids — это разные вещи.
Игра отличная, всем рекомендую к приобретению.
Всё это, как водится, реклама.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021618539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 2827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1445, 'last_played': 1686610374}
review:
[h1]무한 스코어링[/h1]


스코어=돈($)인 게임
놀랍게도 무기, 파일럿, 메카, 맵, 심지어 라이브러리까지 전부 게임 한 판 깰때마다 모이는 돈으로 직접 뚫어야 됨ㅎㅎ;
근데 어차피 처음엔 제일 쉬운것밖에 못 해서 상관 없음 자금이 의외로 빨리 모이기도 하고. 제일 쉬운 미션 한 바퀴 돌아도 아무거 하나 뚫을 돈은 모이는 정도라
그래서 해금하자고 굳이 뺑이를 쳐야 하나 부담을 가질 필요는 거의 없음 그냥 하다 보면 알아서 돈이 모임

파일럿, 메카별로 스코어 보너스( 보상금 )랑 난이도( 적들의 스펙 ) 가중치가 제각각인데 메카는 보통 왜소하고 약할수록 보정이 높고, 파일럿은 일단은 뒤죽박죽이지만 목록 아래쪽의 비싼 파일럿일수록 편성이 빡센 편. 대충 상위난이도 뚫는 거라고 생각하면 됨



탄약에 제한이 있긴 한데 적 메카 부술때마다 가끔 탄약 떨궈주는거도 있고 맵마다 보급소가 종류별로 있어서(없는 맵도 가끔 있음) 허공에 탄을 흩뿌려댔거나 탄창이 원래 작았던 무기가 아닌 이상 탄약 바닥나는 꼴은 잘 안 봄 그러니 싸울땐 화끈하게 싸워서 빨리 끝장내주자

아무튼 그렇게 무기 2종, 특수장비 1개를 장착한 작을 수도, 클 수도 있는 사랑스러운 애마를 이끌고 목표물을 죄다 부수든, 다음 지역 개방되는 커트라인까지만 부수고 바로 빤스런을 하든 어떻게든 마지막 지역까지 한 몸 보전해 무사히 살아남는게 매 판의 목표


목표래봤자 정해진 타겟 쏴부수는 거 딱 하나임 그냥 쏘고 존나 강하게 쏘고 다니면 모든 대화가 해결됨. 킬링타임용으론 그만
[b]나쁘게 말하면 깊이가 겁나게 얄팍하고 좋게 말하면 군더더기 없이 깔끔한 슈팅게임[/b]



※ 조준이 비직관적이고 불편함
※ 원가 주고 사긴 좀 아까울 수 있으니 세일을 노리자

author: {'steamid': '76561198105549932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1511, 'last_played': 1631084330}
review:
Welcome Citizen!

TL;DR: Good Game, lots to do.

+Gameplay allows for taking the objective from any angle you see fit: Tanky power trip, Hit and Run Weasle, Sneaky Snake in the grass, and Troublemaking Tactician. Run it your way.
+Fantastic Sythwave Soundtrack!
+Loads of vehicles, weapons, abilities, and pilots; each plays different with each mixup of any.
+Damn good Isometric graphics, if Factorio or Original Starcraft was your jam, you're in for a treat.
+Very in-depth customizeable controls, allows for lots of rebinding, and mechanical switchups.
+Controls pretty well with keyboard and mouse, feels nice and tight for the most part, a little floaty in tanks and mechs, but it honestly just adds to the experience.
+Freelance mode!: Allows you to aquire and customize your own build and pit it agianst the AI in the various (purchaseable with in-game currency)scenarios, vehicles, weapons, pilots, and abilities; Good way to find the playstyle that suits you best.
+The Lore.: It's extremely deep, you can get a real feel for the really dark and gritty sci-fi industiralized setting through a lot of just the item/character descriptions alone. each character has their own ambitions, problems, in couple of cases some serious ambiguity, and some of them are just outright obscure references.
+Horns.
+Horns.
+Horns.

~Tactical and slow combat in regards to campaign, sometimes they'll give you a behemoth pile of armor to work with but for the most part, if you're not careful and tactful with how you run the mission, you'll be up shit creek without a paddle, and the time you spent getting that progress will be for nothing. Not everyone's thing but I surely enjoyed planning out what to do and executing it.

-Not much in the ways of display options, but it's really not that much of a qualm.
-Poor Controller Binds, very slow response and is definitely going to be a pain in the ass if you decide to roll with it; that being said, the devs do recommend that you slow the game speed down if you do, which makes the pacing rather drab quickly.

Well worth your money, but the real question is: 

Do you accept the terms of service?

author: {'steamid': '76561197971040548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3151, 'last_played': 1623410630}
review:
Brigador

I was gifted this game from a friend and I have to stay that I haven't had fun from a game like this for a long while now. The intense fast paced combat is very challenging, but not challenging just to pi*ss you off. If you end up getting killed on a level, high chances are it is because you made a mistake and got cocky/arrogant and ended up getting squashed. You really have to plan/strategize in order to suceed. When you succeed you really do have that feeling you have accomplished something.

Brigador kind of has a story/campaign but not in the traditional sense. The campaign portion of the game consists of a series of levels that you complete with different pilots and earn cash and you unlock more stiff as you go along. What Brigador does have is a ton of highly detailed and well thought out background lore. I mean a lot of it. If you take the time to unlock all the lore goodies you can see they put a lot of creativity and time into it and it is very enjoyable to read.

The real bread and butter of the game is the freelance portion. As you play operations and earn that cash, you can unlock more pilots that have increased difficulty but also offer higher rewards if you complete the operation.  All the pilots have unique stories and you can get some enjoyment out of reading them. You can also unlock more operations that increase in difficulty, as well as unlocking different weapons, mechs, tanks, agravs, etc. It is really fun to play around with various weapon types, special abilities, and pilots you want to try out on a level and see how you fair.

I am really having a lot of fun with this game and even the achievements are a fun challenge to try. My only real critique is that I wish that they would have had a more fleshed out story mode since they have so much lore that you can create a very fun and unique campaign mode. The combat is obviously the game's strong point and it kicks a*ss, but I do hope in the future whether in a patch or in the next game (Brigador 2?) they also offer some other types of game modes and maybe even a two person coop would be fantastic.

I highly recommend picking this game up if you are into games such as this and want to support these developers. Especially if it goes on sale, pick the game up and have at it!

EDIT#1: Oh man how could I have forgotten. The game also has a KILLER  soundtrack!

EDIT#2: They dropped another nice update to the game and made it even better, great developers.

EDIT#3: They added some more pilots, operations, and mechs to add more fun to the game. Seriously can't wait for Brigador 2, might be a while but can always come back to this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960703529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 989, 'last_played': 1707506790}
review:
Possibly the best 2.5D isometric thinking-shooter I've played.  Brigador has every bit of the soul of MechWarrior 3050 and Jungle Strike, and an amazingly rich background world for you to explore in lore text and subtle visual hints in-game.  That's before we even get to the raw distilled 80's awesome of its synthwave musical score.

The game has a variety of mission sets with individual map missions and sequential map runs.  Difficulty is highly customizable with a combination of pilot choice, vehicle choice, and map(s) choice - there are so many possible permutations, it's probably in the hundreds of thousands.  Some lean towards a firey lead-spitting rampage, some require an assassin's subtle touch.  Something for everyone.

Wholeheartedly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989955269', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 14830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9768, 'last_played': 1684351989}
review:
My first impression of Brigador was "Hotline Miami meets Red Alert 2". It took a little getting used to the game's dry, formless presentation, but my opinion hasn't changed - and I love both of those games.

Brigador tosses the player into the controls of a walker, tank, or hovertank and gives them a very simple goal; kill [i]everything[/i]. There is no failure state in the game short of death. There is nothing in the game that is indestructible short of level boundaries. There is no penalty for leaving every building on the map as a smoking pile of steamrolled rubble - Hell, that's what you're being paid to do.

Brigador's selling point is its dedication to giving the player freedom to fight however they please. Take a heavy tank for a spin, load it out with a 90mm shotgun, and run over everyone stupid enough to stand in front of you. Grab a hovertank with double chainguns and hose down the whole map in a fight that never ends. Get freaky, pick up a walker with a radiation gun, EMP rockets, and active camo - win or lose, the game'll pat you on the back for trying.

It's hard to put it into perspective just how good a job Brigador does at setting up its gameplay. Even after you've settled on a loadout, the freedom doesn't end. The game oozes with simple strategy and straightforward stealth. Want to get things done quick and easy? Knock out the orbital defense guns and run for the exit. Want to go for the full measure? The game'll pay you more for it. Want to keep things quiet? Bring quiet guns, knock out the comms tower, and check your sightlines before you move.

Pile all this on top of the game's dynamic, destructible environments and you've got one of the most open-ended shooters out there. Add in Brigador's fast, frantic gameplay and hard tactical edge, you've got one of the most exciting challenges in the genre. Tamp it all down with Brigador's focus on keeping things simple and intuitive and you've got a game that's easy to get into.

Brigador's visuals are a bit of an odd topic. On the one hand, there's no denying it's got the look of a very old game shored up with modern trimmings. On the other hand, its visuals are dripping with style, quality, and consistency. Sounds and audio are limited mostly to gunfire and engine noise, but they're all pleasing to the ear. The music in the game is absolutely incredible - that the game doesn't have a proper dynamic music system just kills me inside. The soundtrack was worth every penny.

The story in Brigador suffers a bit from its sandbox disposition. The campaign isn't much of a plot; you're thrown into random missions with a bit of story text and not much more. There's no voice acting, no cinematics, little much plot involvement in mission objectives, and zero scripted encounters. Whether this is all for better or worse is down to the end user. That said, the writing in the game is masterful. It's flooded with lore and flavor text that all complement Brigador's atmosphere perfectly.

I've not once had a bug in Brigador. At times, the flawless stability has almost been a bit disappointing - [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1112125453]take a look at my screenshot library and you'll see why.[/url] The game runs well, loads quick, shuts down on a dime, and has never once crashed on me. Modding, on the other hand, is close to non-existent. At most, you can fiddle with a debug menu to do basic tweaks, but advanced modding and mapping are out of the picture.

[quote][b]Edit[/b] [i](6/21/2018)[/i][b]:[/b]
It's not often that I have to update a review for something good. The previous paragraph is now half incorrect; modding and mapping were introduced in a recent update. With them came a lighting overhaul, new pilots, new vehicles, and a string of campaign maps ported to the game's freelance mode. All things considered, it's now very hard for me to find a single flaw with this game that's even worth mentioning.[/quote]


In all, I'm very happy with Brigador. It came out of the blue as a gift from a friend and wound up as my favorite of the following months. It's given me a lot of personal inspiration and a lot of fun. It's tickled my nostalgia bone with its classic isometric perspective. It's simple, open, and does what it does very well. It's a great game that I can't recommend enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072325646', 'num_games_owned': 11297, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1525568247}
review:
[h1]Cyberpunk + Mechs + Top-Down Shooter = Brigador[/h1]

A história que me fez descobrir este jogo é curiosa... quem me conhece sabe que desde sempre fui fascinado por este subgênero de ficção científica repleto de seres marginalizados e bizarrices cibernéticas, o Cyberpunk. Frequentando os fóruns de um RPG de mesa dos anos 80 chamado Cyberpunk 2020 foi onde tive a ideia de criar uma playlist de músicas dos gêneros Synthwave, Retrowave e qualquer outra porcaria que se remetia a este subgênero, foi em uma recomendação vazia de cowboy encontrei uma música chamada [url=https://open.spotify.com/track/1XKkdhQ4vIp22c4ScOHZW9]Solo Nobre Must Fall[/url], música tema deste maravilhoso jogo. Enfim, escutei tanto a música que tive curiosidade pesquisar sobre sua origem, ainda bem que fiz isso, ainda bem...

Logo após completar o primeiro cenário o jogo lhe apresenta ao enredo... 

''Há muitos anos, o grupo paramilitar NEP (Novo Exército do Povo) tomou o poder de Solo Nobre, a capital de Novo Solo. As negociações de paz com o líder do NEP, o tirano conhecido como Grande Líder, falharam. Depois que o Grande Líder fechou os espaçoportos, os cidadãos de Solo Nobre foram forçados a aguentar anos de políticas econômicas regressivas e isolacionismo.''

O enredo que é mostrado ao longo dos cenários é, digamos, ''modesto'' e provavelmente não vai te cativar, bom, pelo menos comigo foi assim. Em jogos com temática cyberpunk eu sempre busco enredos profundos, mais complexos e ricos em detalhes, mas nem sempre é o caso.

Existem vários cenários para se jogar, cenários que equivalem a uma campanha, entretanto, a maioria desses cenários são muito simples de se completar e não exigem habilidade do jogador, eles funcionam como um grande tutorial que servem para introduzir o jogador as mecânicas dos mechs e do jogo em geral. O jogo brilha mesmo é no modo ''mercenário'', lá nós podemos comprar missões, mechs e pilotos com a grana que juntamos ao jogar a campanha, os cenários e as missões.

A jogabilidade é padrão [url=https://store.steampowered.com/tags/en/Twin+Stick+Shooter]Twin Stick Shooter[/url] / [url=https://store.steampowered.com/tags/en/Top-Down%20Shooter/]Top-Down Shooter[/url] e lembra bastante alguns jogos como SYNTHETIK e Nex Machina, mas um pouco menos  Rogue-lite. Geralmente esses jogos funcionam melhor com um controle ou joystick, mas neste game eu diria que minha experiência com o teclado e mouse foi mais do que satisfatória, então não se preocupe caso não tenha um controle à disposição.

Ultimamente ando me interessando bastante por estes gêneros de jogos, principalmente pelo algo nível de dificuldade que eles geralmente apresentam... Aqui a dificuldade é um fator relativo, pois ela é determinada de acordo com suas escolhas para cada missão, o piloto, o mech, as armas, etc. 

Os visuais e gráficos não são nada que além do convencional, mas a maioria das artes do jogo são muito bem feitas e acabam se destacando... imagine as [url=https://www.artstation.com/artwork/brxvo]ilustrações de Josan Gonzalez[/url], mas sem aquele estilo pitoresco da paleta de cores que ele costuma usar.

Como eu disse no início da análise, conheci o game a partir de sua maravilhosa trilha sonora, então não poderia deixar de mencioná-la. Pra mim é o ponto mais positivo do jogo e foi o que realmente me fez continuar a jogar, ela combina muito com os visuais e com o tema geral do jogo, com o tempo esses jogos mostraram que destruir quase tudo no seu caminho ao som de uma boa música pode ser extremamente divertido.

O preço original de Brigador era uma piada, R$55,99 se não me engano, e os R$36,99 cobrados hoje em dia ainda são um valor um pouco alto para o que é oferecido, mas tudo depende do jogador. Na minha opinião um valor justo seria algo em torno de 20-25 reais.

Durante as horas que passei em Novo Solo não presenciei nenhum problema técnico no game, houve apenas uma situação em que o jogo ''crashou'' (fechou sozinho), mas foi só isso, um único crash. Brigador também possui suporte completo para monitores ultrawide (21:9) e conta com tradução completa para Português do Brasil, a tradução é boa, só encontrei alguns errinhos e infelizmente algumas coisas que não foram traduzidas, como por exemplo o nome das missões.

[b]Conclusão:[/b] Brigador: Up-Armored Edition infelizmente é um jogo para poucos e pode até mesmo não agradar fãs mais ''hardcore'' (assíduos) de Top-Down Shooters, mas pra mim foi uma experiência bastante satisfatória e sinceramente não vejo motivos para não recomendá-lo. Entretanto, é importante levar em consideração o preço a se pagar pelo que ele é capaz de te entregar.

Críticas e sugestões são sempre bem-vindas, só peço que, por favor, seja educado(a) nos comentários e não poste spoilers sem usar a [url=https://steamcommunity.com/comment/Announcement/formattinghelp]tagspoiler[/url].

[h1]Análise fortalecida através do Curador do grupo [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/magnaway]Magnaway.[/url][/h1]
[h1]Apoie-nos seguindo nosso [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/26745635/]Curador[/url] para futuras análises.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197967817775', 'num_games_owned': 2072, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 4083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1688598376}
review:
When I first fired this up, I was immediately put off by the (seemingly) awkward controls, but thanks to some very smart on-boarding with the campaign I quickly came to love being able to torso twist and blast one enemy while stomping another into a fine red paste. Give it twenty minutes and I have a feeling you'll be hooked. I also really dug the huge selection of vehicles and weapons, it really gave a lot of variety to the gameplay and kept things from degenerating into simple spray and pray. Usually I tend to stick to a single method of play, but here I found myself constantly alternating between stealth, speed and straight-up through the wall siege tanking. As a final cherry on-top, the in-universe fiction, while entirely text-based, is a great mix of Battletech and some subtle black humor. You know a  writer's earning his pay when you spend 30 minutes just reading all the weapon and vehicle descriptions. Can't recommend this game enough!

EDIT: Just wanted to add, it's 2021 and this bad boy is still getting awesome updates even with the sequel looming on the horizon. Gotta love it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197977140424', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1524632306}
review:
It has a great art style. The atmosphere has a juxtaposition of steam-punk, sci-fi neon lights and it felt like classic red alert 2 in live action. 

However, very bad design mechanics forbid from enjoying such a nice graphic design. 

Text based narratives do not work anymore in 21st century. This is just my personal preference, so you can ignore it, but because the presentation of its narrative is not so appealing that I don't even bother to understand any context of the story if there is one at all. Look at what happened to JRPGs.

Limitation of choosing character / vehicles. 
Just Why? 
Why don't I get a freedom of choosing my own vehicle for any mission at all?
Having a specific vehicle should have been for a challenge or some extra mission not for a normal cmapaign progress. 

Sure you get to try new vehicles, but you don't get to know their functions and stats because they are all written in a very bad manner style in the description box. Only the health, shield and number / type of rounds the vehicle have. We would not know what kind of weapon each vehicle has at all until you try and figure out certain vehicle is not suitable. 
There was even one description of a vehicle saying it has a bad formula of weapons or something like that. Again. 
Why? Why would any one use a badly designed vehicle in the first place? I am no English teacher, but I gotta say the writings are pretty bad.

It should have its own customization. There seems to be some kind of market system with the money you earn from each mission, but most are restricted for whatever reason and I couldn't figure out how it works. There seemed to be unnecessarily amount of tutorial on how to use few different types of vehicle, but why not how the market works?
It has such a great potential of having a warehouse to build your own unit / vehicle, buying new weapons / kits to try them in a new combinations and / or upgrade your gears etc. 
Instead, you get a series of different vehicles with very uninspiring characters with another limitation of 2~4 choices from every single missions. 

UI design. 
The obstacles are too dark that sometimes when you think you have enough space to move around while in combat, you end up stuck in a corner, because you haven't 'completely' destroyed the obstacles. 
The color variation of objective markers are too similar to the whole map that you often have to look closely to see where the markers are at. They should have some glowing marker or should have used some opposite color to these whole dark-neon themed environment. 

Aim system.
I tend to use flying vehicles often, but it will get very frustrating when it comes to fast moving enemies who tend to shove their face against yours. Once enemies are literally in front of you, good luck aiming at them. 
The aim system here is just terrible. you have to have a mouse cursor over ground or small units or else you may shoot over them. It tends not to work well when they are very close to you. You better have some AOE weapons to clear out close quarter combat situations. 

It has a potential, but expecting to choose my own character - anticipated to have their own set of skills or different stats - and to create my own vehicle seemed to be too much of expectation.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993365782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4739, 'last_played': 1672107616}
review:
It's a bit difficult at first, but once you get over the fact that it's not a typical twin-stick shooter, it's amazing.

Brigador has a high skill ceiling, and it encourages you to inch yourself up the skill ladder with better payouts for higher difficulting pilots and vehicles.  It's easy to stomp through a mission in one of the heavilty armored vehicles, but if you want the real payout, you'll do it in the one that's basically a tricycle with a couple of tiny guns mounted it to it.

The art is also super detailed, and the dynamic lighting looks fantastic.

Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052733586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1524364052}
review:
[b] Stealing an idea I saw done here to help me get through my huge backlog of games on Steam. It is what I like to call my "1 Hour Playtime Reviews Because My Steam Library Has Gotten Stupid Big and I Don't Want to Regret How I Spend My Money Challenge." [/b] 

Ever wanted to be a mass murdering fu**-head invading a country to destroy as many buildings and civilians as possible to earn money? Then Brigador is for you! There is a story that explains why you are demolishing neighborhoods with unarmed people in it, but didn't want to read all the mission objectives due to my deep enjoyment of all the complete annihilation I was doing. 

You do have enemy units to deal with that are doing their darndest to stop you from murdering unarmed people, but with a certain level of skill, they too shall be dust under your mech, hovercar, or tank. Brigador was starting to get challenging by the end of the hour, and I can say I am in interested in diving back in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995257664', 'num_games_owned': 1358, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1524200060}
review:
The Good: 
Art is beautiful, with the flashing of lasers and explosions at night
Lots of vehicles
Lots of weapons
Fully destructible environment
Shooting gameplay is fun

The Bad:
All vehicles handle somewhat strangely, with how holding down a key does not mean your 'front' is always facing  the way you're walking. This can be used tactically to have your 'front' face enemies as you move backwards, but it's still awkward.
Tanks have terrible controls
Missions are repetitive, and are either: shoot everything that movies, OR shoot everything that doesn't move
Obstacles feel like they take forever to destroy when you move into them. In actuality it doesn't take very long to blow them up, but it feels painful when having to go through several walls as certain vehicles who can't ground pound
The plot is incomprehensible. It appears there's a world with back story, but the campaign missions do nothing to explore it. For some reason I'm fighting loyalists, spacers and corvids? Who are these corvids and spacers? All I'm told is that the great leader is dead. I guess that means it's time to shoot up and place and massacre everyone?

Verdict: 7/10. I hesitantly recommend Brigador. Beautiful art with lots of vehicle and weapon variety can offer a lot of content if you enjoy a 'shoot everything' game, however strange movement controls and bad story hold it back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013781501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 993, 'last_played': 1709840734}
review:
Brigador is probably one of the best written games made in the last ten years. The world built by Stellar Jockeys is unique, complex, evocative, strange and familiar. Despite being set far in the future, it holds some palpable realness that so many other games set in that time period fail to muster. 

The first game that comes to mind when I play this, is, oddly enough, F.E.A.R. I liked F.E.A.R. enough to play it and its expansion packs ( but not the sequels) several times over, and I firmly believe that if you liked F.E.A.R., you'll like Brigador as well. This is both an endorsement and a subtle warning: while I love both games to pieces, they are both unquestionably rather repetitive,  

You pick a loadout, arrive in the district, and utterly lay waste to it. Then you do it again, and then more times. The reason why this is fun is that there is a staggeringly large variety of loadouts, and each one presents its own challenges: with three very different types of vehicle (tank, mecha, and agrav, which are essentially Floating Gun Platforms) control in a different fashion, and each have their own quirks: tanks are typically slow and strong, but can ram things with explosive resuts, mecha are easy targets but quite straightforward to use, and agravs can float over certain obstacles. Add to this the four different weapon types, bullets, artillery, cannon and laser;  four different "special weapons"-- EMPs, smoke grenades, camo, and the audio-kinetic pulse (this is essentially a cone of noise that can level a building-- or foe), and you have a lot of choices. 

Fortunately, in Brigador, the act of murder feels sublime.  Stellar Jockeys have perfectly calibrated the interface between sound design, animation and damage level, so that landing damage typically feels amazing. If you are a fan of gargantuan tanks being worn down in a series of ambushes, before near-erotically exploding, this will be something you are going to devote a couple dozen hours to. 

Speaking of sound design, while the 80s soundtrack is no Hotline Miami, it is certainly contains an earworm or two, and feels grimly suitable for what you're actually doing.

The "problem" with the narrative is a Marmite one: there's a lot of lore, and all the weapons, vehicles, and pilots have bios, but it's all sequestered away. If you demand your narrative and your gameplay synthesized, then you're probably going to be pissed off by this game, or at least disappointed. Which is a huge shame, because it's all really good, and I read all of it. In addition, none of the factions are shallow: each of the three are visually and thematically distinct, in refreshing ways. You'd think that a faction called "Loyalsits" would be boring but they aren't! 

In short, for a first game by an indie dev, who clearly have put a lot of effort into making a memorable experience, it's pretty great, and at least worth a spin if you need to scratch that "stylish murder" itch.  If you're looking for AAA fidelity, shiny graphics (in an isometric game lmao) or anything fancy, look elsewhere or be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961907194', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2214, 'last_played': 1672688272}
review:
This game rocks and it's a shame it sold so poorly. It looks and sounds beautiful, the shimmering synthesizers of the soundtrack a polished accompaniment to the rough mechanical noise of combat. The Freelance mode offers a nigh-endless variety of mechs and weaponry with which to experiment. The setting is well written: What little you learn of the place invites you to imagine the rest. 

It's rare to see a game lean as hard as this one does into the idea that the player character and their associates are evil, which might not be to everyone's taste, but in the tradition of good science fiction, it's in the service of satirizing the present day.

But despite the seriousness of the plot, it's also the kind of game that features Johnny Fiveaces from The Zybourne Clock as a joke character. It's fun, fast-paced, but strategic. I highly recommend it.

review:
For the most part, everything this game sets out and tries to do, it does perfectly; satisfying gunplay, huge arsenal of weapons and vehicles, all in a fleshed-out and brutal cyberpunk setting.

Take all of that, bundle it with a solid and crisp isometric artstyle, and top it off with a soundtrack that I haven't grooved so hard to since Hotline Miami. There's a huge amount of ways to play this game, and everything surrounding that gameplay makes it all better. They nailed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024735043', 'num_games_owned': 1655, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 5896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1706407951}
review:
I would have paid for this but lucked out & got it for free through chrono.gg coins.  Thanks guys!  I LOVE THIS GAME!

I'm not sure I've ever played a mech game before with fully destructible environments, such a vast range of possible loadouts and variety in tactical maneuvers.  You can level the entire map.  You've got the option of hitting targets by shooting over or through obstacles depending on the height of your mech, ballistic arc, and the penetration rating of your guns.  Enemies will react to loud explosions alarms or catching you in line of sight.  You've got smoke screens, EMP blasts, active camouflage, etc.  There's so much deliciousness in this game I don't even know how to cram it all into this review.

There's a 'campaign' mode that's more like a tutorial and a 'freelance' mode that's more like the main game.  In tutorial you're locked into one of 4 mech types each with a single loadout.  In freelance mode you get access to the whole salad bar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054666239', 'num_games_owned': 3252, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1558899476}
review:
Brigador was a pleasant surprise for me. I usually do not like top down action games like shoot 'em ups. Though Brigador is definitely a more 'tactical' breed, it still features shooting in the forefront. However you have to use a more indirect approach most of the time. Vehicles, weapons and specials make every setup different enough to warrant a slightly different approach. Top that with varying missions with different goals, enemy placement and variation.

Visually the game is quite unique and overall looks really good. This is the high resolution 90s Syndicate/cyberpunk aesthetic that you were looking for. While being tile-based it is really stunning how nicely the various pre-rendered assets come together. One of the main tropes is the destructibility of basically everything, be it buildings, trees, walls, towers, etc., you can destroy anything that is inside the map boundaries resulting in huge eye-pleasing explosions. My only concern here is while these unique well-done visuals are one the strongest lures for the game it obstructs the gameplay a wee-bit every now and then. Specifically when a map starts at dawn and everything is darker and there are more shadows that is an objectively worse situation to play in because of worse visibility. And as far as I know it is randomized, so it is not mission related.

The lore included in the game is rather vast. While I would not say that it has too many totally unique ideas, the dystopian cyberpunk futurescape is engaging enough as a backdrop. There are tons of pilots to unlock with different backgrounds and portraits. Even vehicles and various gears have their own little description which gives them a unique stamp. Campaign missions also have a briefing that adds up to a decent story over time. You will eventually get to know your own employers and the strict nature they operate in. This is definitely not a future anyone is hoping for. As for mission design they are well-made and usually distinct enough. The layout being tile-based it eventually becomes rather samey, but it takes some time before you start to see the same building too often. On the other hand that is one of the points of the game, you have to be able to identify hazardous structures, so it becomes second nature to avoid or destroy them from a distance.

Brigador's main gameflow is a slower paced search and destroy oriented top down shooter. You choose your equipment then head on to complete your objectives which start with simple tasks like destroy every opposition in the area then pretty much goes into various combinations where structures and troops are targeted as well. Hazardous objects and less generic enemy units start to appear which will lead you into more difficult situations. Knowing the map is an important thing and proceeding in a way to avoid choke points, flanking enemies and destroying useful building as soon as possible is an important thing in later missions. The equipment you get is also quite varied. There are simple machine turrets, long range mortars, plasma cannons plus the ever-needed special equipment. In campaign mode you have a predetermined set of setups but in freelance mode you can choose any combination that you have already unlocked. Unlocks can be earned via money that are constantly gained through completing campaign missions and freelance assignments. Overall, Brigador offers a surprising amount of tactical options. You can drive three main types of vehicles: mechs, tanks and hovertanks/cars. They all have distinct features like the first two has an orientation that has to be controlled in order to move optimally during fights. There are objectively weaker sets which yield bonus money for completing missions. Overall, this is a diverse system with many options. Unfortunately, things can become extremely chaotic and you can find yourself in a bullet hell game with a slow moving, clunky vehicle. As I mentioned earlier visuals do not help the situation either. If you played games from the 80s this might not frustrate you and you will likely find quite a lot of fun hours with Brigador. I would add though that there are settings to customize the controls' behaviour and also a game speed changer which starts at 80% when you first launch the game and maxes out at 100% which kinda says something about the difficulty. Despite the cons Brigador still plays nicely and if anything the occasional problems might even add to the throwback charm.

Sound-wise the game does a decent job. Weapons and explosions sound great while feeling filtered which adds to the style. There are no voiced lines unfortunately, it would have added to the atmosphere for sure. Musically however Brigador stands above the rest. I might not being totally objective here as I am a big fan of the new outrun/synthwave scene, but Makeup and Vanity Set's tracks specially written to accompany the game are just amazing. Even though you hear the main menu theme a thousand times, it always gives a great feel right at the first moment, that you are in a different period, at the time of conflict. During missions the variation is better, though mixing is a rather simple, it is still hard to not appreciate the great musical score. Moreover, you can get the multiple albums via the deluxe edition. They are great to listen to outside of the game, what more you want from a soundtrack?

As for content I already wrote about the many options available for the player. The campaign is quite lengthy and was already extended by updates but for anyone who fells in love with the gameplay and finds joy for hundreds of hours there is depth to be found here.

In the end, Brigador remains a surprise hit for me that I come back every now and then. Originally wanted to take a look after having it for some time to check out the visuals and more importantly the music, the gameplay and the world created pulled me in. Despite the shortcomings mostly related to gameplay Brigador still is a genuinely great game.

[u]MY OPINION: 8.0/10 (GREAT)[/u]
Graphics: 8/10
World Design: 8/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Sound: 8/10
Replay Value: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198040892359', 'num_games_owned': 3008, 'num_reviews': 369, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1558922552}
review:
I like this game quite a bit, and would certainly recommend it, albeit with a few caveats.

So, when I bought this, it was early into it's early access period and I didn't care for it. Playing it again over the last few days I found it has come a long way. 

In case you don't know what Brigador is, it's like the old Mechwarrior game on Genesis... although I honestly feel it's closer to the Strike games (Desert/Jungle/Urban/Soviet/Nuclear), which I love. You have multiple vehicle options/types to go on a mission that includes a fully destructable environment. That type of sandbox presented in this game is perfect.

Buuuut... the main thing I hate about this game are the controls. I'm constantly pausing to switch control options, and often times none really feel "right" and usable to me. That was one of the main reasons I quit playing it while it was in EA, and that hasn't gotten much better. Maybe it's just me, but yeah...

The other thing I don't like is the campaign has you first doing the mech, then the tank, then the grav car thing. So you're stuck four missons at a time using not just one vehicle, but one type of that vehicle. Later in the campaign you can switch between three or four vehicle options, but the limited vehicle selection makes the campaign kind of repetitive.

Freelance mode is much more fun, as there you can use any combination of everything you've purchased. But as the game has a campaign mode, I obviously want to finish it, although it's tough to stay interested enough when you've got the much superior Freelance mode.

In the end, if you like mechs or the Strike series, definitely pick this up. Be aware that there's a chance the controls may be frustrating though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988903500', 'num_games_owned': 2136, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 4321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2548, 'last_played': 1624856232}
review:
This is "Yes you can": The Game

Its a mech game right? But maybe your more into tanks than mechs or something? You can play as a Tank, hell there are a ton of them, want to play a hover tank maybe? Think treads are too old school? There are hover tanks and tons of hover vehicles to choose from. Maybe your a power armor sort of guy? Even there they have you fucking covered. Want to ride around in a glorified fucking golf cart? BAM! There it is. 

When it comes to completing objectives and missions you can approach them in any way you wish. Maybe you don't want to take the hugest mech and go in guns blazing, maybe you want to be a sneaky boy sneaking around and precisely ambushing targets or picking off stragglers before cloaking and running away? Yeah, you can do that. Maybe you want to go break neck fast to the point where enemy's cant keep up with you and cant hit you, running up behind enemies and blowing them up driving by them too fast for their buddys to react in time? Yes, You can. Maybe you want to hang back and pick off groups of enemies with artillary and precise firepower before they can possibly get to you. You totally can. Literally just approach your work as you see fit. 

Its such a great game dude. And the more you play the more the possibilities open up before you like a fucking wide horizon filled with shit blowing up. Any kind of mission or difficulty you want to play is covered. Like maybe you want your levels to be full of nothing but civvies that you run over and gun down? Yeah you can totally do that. Do you want the difficulty to gradually increase over time or even gradually decrease over time? Its all doable. Also the lore is pretty cool too, to the point where I genuinely recommend you check out the novel, Underneath the game is some cool fucking sci-fi.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999282226', 'num_games_owned': 972, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1519374888}
review:
An isometric shooter, sci-fi, cyberpunk, synth slamming, Mechwarrior, no-hold-barred destructathon, a district at a time. Brigador challenges you to select one of a massive array of vehicles (tanks, hoverbikes, anti-gravity platforms, small powersuits, massive mechs, and everything in between) a loadout of two weapons (selected from the likes of laser shotguns, corrosive gas grenades, flamethrowers, machine guns, mortars, rockets, short rnage sledges) and a defensive mechanism (smoke bombs, EMPs, active camo, and more), and then go mano-a-armyo against a massive array of procedurally generated foes, taking out strategic objectives in setpiece afte setpiece, where every single thing is destructible, and you absolutely get paid to blow it all up.

Brigador is set up in a sci-fi setting TEEMING with extra goodies to learn and read about in an extensive encyclopedia of entries to unlock about literally everything in the game, from the civilians you step on, the pilots you unlock, the weapons you fire, the vehicles you drive, the nature of the civil war than rages, and everything else (The way the game's lore and history handles FTL travel is decidedly horrific.) Attention to detail comes to this game in spades, and it oozes neon colored theme from every pore.

The game sports a campaign mode to ease you through learning the games mechanics, and then runs you through some challenging missions all about restricting those mechanics once it teaches you about them. This all culminates in you learning everything you need to take on the meat of the game's procedurally generated Freelance Modes, which are the bulk of the game. You can buy campaigns of varying length and difficulty, from short 2 map campaigns for quick plays, to massive, 39 mission long grindhouses that require you to go through 15 odd random maps as well as about 20 of the campaigns most difficult missions - all without ever taking a single loss and all using the same vehicle the entire time. Not for the faint of heart by any means. Freelance allows you to completely customize every vehicle you make, from pilots, which determine difficulty and money modifiers, to the weapons and defense systems. Campaign mode, in contrast provides three to four set specific pilot and vehicle combos, each one providing a different way of tackling the same mission, from a massive tank designed to be able to brawl its way through, to a small powersuit designed to sneak around, strategically grab objectives, mousehole through walls, and then deftly escape.

You quickly discover that every ounce of power you can throw at your foes cna be tossed right back at you in kind, meaning waltzing into an army can be a dangerous prospect. You learn to use sound distractions, blowing up buildings t lure enemies around corners, or using smoke to confuse, and creating holes in terrain to make artifical chokepoints that last barely as long as the battles that you made them for. Each map generally challenges you to take out some assortment of building, or to defeat specific enemies, or a general number of nonspecific enemies. Maps will generally reward you for completing multiple objectives as well as side objectives as well, so you need to rate your risk/reward - can you finish clearing the entire map, or are you getting low on ammo and health and need to move on, hoping to replenish?

The game's visual presentation is cohesive and pulls everything together, combining laser shotguns, explosions, mortars, headlights showing which way enemies are focused (stay out of sight!), even down to tiny things like crowds with swaying flashlights around their neck. Neon metropolises are your playground, set to a pulsing background of heavy beats and electronic music.

STRONG recommendation for anyone who likes mecha games, top down shooters, and is looking for a game that they can play in small bite or large chunks, with tons and tons of unlockable content to keep things new and fresh. The game is fun, and although you can get yourself into some incredibly sticky situations, the game never feels unfun - just difficult at times, hectic, chaotic, and hoping you can dash away from the missiles and rockets to kill a shiled generator for some extra life.

Fantastic!

review:
A glorious orgy of mechanised carnage!

It scratches an itch that I didn't realise I had, and keeps me coming back again and again.

Awesome diversity in vehicles, loadouts and playstyles.

The retro art style is complemented by the great syth soundtrack. The developers' passion and eye for detail results in the best visuals I've seen in an isometric action game.

The depth of the lore isn't obvious at first, but if and when you decide to look for it, it will grab hold and have you digging for more.

Also really enjoyed the audiobook. Well written sci-fi war novel with accurate military jargon and believable characters. Reader has real voice talent, and really drives the story home.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006507699', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1554873566}
review:
Got this almost a year ago through a Humble monthly bundle and totally forgot about it. Today I gave it a try...

It's a classic isometric/top-down Shooter. There's not much to describe... one glance at the screenshots should be sufficient to get the gist.

It's a simple principle, but the game is actually quite difficult. Good graphics, nice dystopian/cyberpunk environments that are fully destructible, a thunderstorm of effects and on top of that a disgustingly good Retrowave Soundtrack! It's as if Walker and Syndicate had a love child. Really fun to go on a rampage! It fully captures what made gaming so good back then.

That being said, it's certainly not for everyone. Maybe you have to be an old fart like me to fully appreciate this type of game and its style.

Quote from another review:

"I'm not objective about neo-retro ... i was a kid in the 80's early 90's, and back then, the future was awesome. The Lamborghini Countach, Tron, Snake Plissken, Red Neons, Atari, Terminator, Syndicate, Cyborgs, Akira, Pink Neons, Japanese Mechas, Electronic warfare, HAL, GUNMN, Purple Neons, Time travelling DeLorean, PowerGlove, Ninjas, Reebok Pumps ...

Well, we all know what became of this vision. It became nostalgia, buried under gray-ish ikea furnitures and white-ish Apple products. [...]

It brings back the dream of a more dark, but also a much more awesome future."

author: {'steamid': '76561198011595325', 'num_games_owned': 2476, 'num_reviews': 929, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1519078673}
review:
Sendo franco, Brigador não fez mais sucesso porque é um jogo de nicho, embora possua seus defeitos (repetitivo e difícil de entender e controlar no começo) possui muitas mais qualidades: trilha sonora boa e efeitos de som de qualidade, variedade grande de pilotos, mechas e armas, cenário totalmente destrutivo e varias dificuldades diferentes.
As dificuldades são definidas pelo piloto que você escolher, o mecha, as armas e por ultimo, o levels. O jogo tem uma campanha grande que funciona mais como um extenso tutorial, lá você também junta dinheiro. O foco do jogo é o modo freelance, lá você tem que pagar pelas missões, equipamentos e pilotos, é ai que o jogo fica repetitivo. Pra mim foi um bom jogo pra passar o tempo jogando seções curtas, pra outras pessoas (que já entram no nicho do jogo) é muito divertido jogar as fases e liberar tudo que o jogo tem bloqueado. 
Dito isso tudo, não encontrei bugs e acho o preço justo, então vou recomendar positivamente esse game, mesmo assim recomendo qualquer possível comprador procurar por vídeos e ver o que está realmente comprando.
---------------------------------
Being frank, Brigador has not made more success because it is a niche game, although it has its defects (repetitive and difficult to understand and control in the beginning) has many more qualities: good soundtrack and quality sound effects, large variety of pilots, mechs and weapons, totally destructive scenario and several different difficulties.
The difficulties are defined by the pilot you choose, the mech, the weapons and lastly, the levels. The game has a great campaign that works more like an extensive tutorial, there you also put some money together. The focus of the game is the freelance mode, there you have to pay for the missions, equipment and pilots, that's where the game gets repetitive. For me it was a good game to spend time playing short sections, for other people (who already in the niche of the game) is very fun to play the levels and release everything that the game has blocked.
That said, I did not find bugs and I think the price is fair, so I will recommend this game positively, but I still recommend any possible buyer to look for videos and see what they are really buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970585182', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1145, 'last_played': 1625718160}
review:
As an isometric mech combat game with a retro feel, this is the best ever made. You will truly be amazed as you play the first 4 hours. The details in the levels, the tactics, the AI, it's all really good. But after about 4 hours you start to realize that's all there is. There's no story, the campaign is just the same missions in about 5 different map types. There's some progression as you use your money to buy new equipment in the sandbox mode. But the campaign is really just giving you a different vehicle in the same arenas. Again and again until it's over. 

THIS GAME NEEDS A STORY CAMPAIGN! That's all it needs. Just like Crusader: No Remorse / No Regret. That's what this game is the most like, believe it or not. And those games, although somewhat cheezy, had 100x more going for them because they had a story based campaign. 

Such potential lost. Still, this is a great game despite the gaping hole I mentioned, so I do recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998537520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1575742176}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013216453', 'num_games_owned': 783, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1695700333}
review:
Featuring the graphics of a violent Roller Coaster Tycoon, the gameplay of games like Desert/Jungle/Urban Strike/Future Cop LAPD, and the vibes of games like Crusader: No Remorse/Regret and Syndicate, Brigador is a love letter to all these old school games. 

Pros: 
-Fun, explosive gameplay
-A variety of vehicles and weapons to choose from
-A beautiful atmosphere on a space colony
-A Rich backstory behind the world of Solo Nobre
-Synthwave Soundtrack, need I say more?

Cons: 
-Gameplay while fun, can get repetitive
-Slightly steep learning curve (Which was fixed)
-No Workshop support. The Steam Workshop can really make great games greater, thanks to the communities dedicated to their respective games. 

Overall: 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198137183142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1515128039}
review:
Basics review: This was a literal blast to play. Every explosion and weapon felt satisfying and it was not difficult at all to grasp the controls for. The music and artwork for the game were also quite awesome. The diverse cast of characters and vehicles also gave quite a bit of variety. You can find my completed Let’s Play campaign [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLL6mgIhiVyYRVHB3tFqOAU_SUKeL4y6PG] here  [/url] on YouTube

More in depth review! Does this game appeal to me as a “Dad who Dads?” Yes. While it must be played with two hands, and while there is no in-mission save function, the missions are short and don’t require too much of a time investment. If you have to leave the computer, it won’t take you forever to get back to where you were. There’s also quite a lot of replayability to the campaign and a whole section for Skirmishes!

I also like that this game does not try to spread itself too thin in terms of things to do. You are there to lay waste to a map full of pixelated enemies and you have a broad selection of machinery to use. I am really glad that this game does not have any “Escort Missions.” There’s also a hefty section of lore for you to unlock and read through. I skipped through this on my let’s play, but it is pretty interesting stuff; a lot of thought and depth went into it.

I had a little bit of a struggle using a controller, but there are mechanics to adjust that experience. I confess I am not the tinkering type, but I found keyboard and mouse to be just as fun to play with. Some missions can be quite difficult, but they aren’t prohibitively so. If you practice a few times you’ll get the hang of it.

I would have liked to see adding in allies or a bit of a strategy element to this. An old-old-old game I used to play (LAPD Future Cop) had a RTS versus mode that was pretty fun. I completely understand why something like this wasn’t put in, but it is on my wishlist from the devs! The campaign is a bit short, but it has much more flexibility and diversity of engagements in the Skirmish mode.

Anyway to sum up from my perspective: Great game, solid investment. Very easy to pick up and play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011398065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1316, 'last_played': 1689623773}
review:
Plays like a more sophisticated Desert Strike, but with your choice of a Mech, Tank, or Antigrav.  Allows a range of playstyle, from grinding slow behemoth that can quickly level blocks to small powersuits that can hide and go stealth.  Noteworthy that I feel like I could beat nearly any mission with nearly any loadout if I am willing to figure out how.  Some loadouts are more challenging, but would be hard to make a real fail loadout. 

Vehicle options - The difference in control/gameplay of the different chassis provides a lot of variability and the vehicle multiplers make it rewarding to challenge yourself or try random rigs. 
 Overall they look fantastic and provide plenty of variety.  I do wish there were mech chassis with more than two legs, but not a big deal. 9/10

Weapons/Specials - The weapons overall are fun and have sufficient variety.  The powerful weapons actually feel powerful, which is a big compliment. My only complaint in the weapon department are the lack of missiles, but it's certainly no deal breaker with the options provided and considering the extra ui/control that would be needed for missiles.  The Specials available are great, but I wish there were more.  Spicing the specials up some alone would improve thinges greatly.  It would have been nice if there were some Specials for mobility too. 8/10

Graphics - Overall visual aesthetics are fantastic.  From the UI and pilot portraits to the in-game palette, great!  The lighting in particular, and the debris, are excellent.  I wish all missions were at night just because the lighting is so gorgeous.  The game doesn't support 4k, which is a big bummer though, and some of the laser weapons have no visible beam which I find disappointing. 8/10

Sound - Good, but more mixed bag here.  Music is great, no complaints here!  Some of the weapon's volumes are way low or just not impressive.  The Audio Kinetic special should sound impressive instead of being barely noticeable and some of the rail guns are virtually silent.  I also wish the narrator voice on the first campaign mission stuck around for other missions, sounded cool! GREAT LEADER IS DEAD 7/10

Missions - This is the weak spot in the game.  While the mechanics of the AI and how the various targets (Comms, Substations) interact with them are good, the fact that the only mission objectives are to destroy the buildings and perhaps some captains is lacking.  Would have been nice to see some other objectives in at least the freelance missions like assassination, extraction, protection for a convoy, etc.  There is really only one mission in this game, only the scenery changes. Easy implementations that would really stretch the game's value. 6/10

Lore/Fluff/Story - I dig the fluff but don't agree with having to use in-game $ to purchase it bit by bit.  Fluff should be there to immerse me, not act as a carrot on a stick for grinding.  IMO it should be unlocked with campaign progression or purchase of the equipment in question.  All the current design effectively does is incentivize people to not look into the lore until after they've filled out their garage. 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197982837520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 1706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1557, 'last_played': 1659737865}
review:
Brigador: Up-Armored Edition

Is a game that isn't hard to learn, not too hard to master, but keeps you interested for a pretty long time.
The game is basically a mix between Syndicate & Mechwarrior 3050.

The graphics and atmosphere are very Syndicate like when it comes down to this Blade Runner like feeling and the music does a good job to support this setting also.

The Mechwarrior part is where it comes down to what combat vehicle and weaponry to choose for the next mission.

Although the missions are basically all the same, (Kill and or destroy X units of type Y) it doesn't get boring and it does fit the lore. Which is a very important part of this game.
As a matter of fact, it's just a lot of fun to test your configurations, tactics, doing combat and exploring the various maps, reading the lore, etc.
It's a game that packs a lot of universe behind the scene and it shows in the small details; which is a great thing.

Is there something I would like to see in the game?
Hmm, maybe a sort of endless battlefield mode. (Random map, endless waves of enemies and see how long you can last. Just for the fun of it.)
But, something tells me that this wouldn't really fit in this particular game universe/setting. Although it could be lots of fun, I think.

The DLC is also worth every penny. If not just for the cool audiobook that comes with it. (If you like such things)

Fun games don't have to be triple A studio productions.
Brigador is proof of that.

review:
ゴチャゴチャした未来の街で機動兵器を乗り回して破壊の限りを尽くすゲームです。プレイした感覚としてはPS時代のアーマードコアに近い感じで、二足歩行・タンク・ホバーの三系統に癖の強い武器を組み合わせて戦います。弾数制限があり、キャノンはACよろしく十数発しか打てませんし、チェインガンは千数百発を絶え間なく撃てたりします。回避重視の戦闘もよし、ガチタンでなぎ倒すもよし。動画では難しそうに見えますが、チュートリアル的なキャンペーンがあるのでSTG初めての方でも楽しくプレイできると思います。

ゲーム内の設定集は非常に濃くて面白く、ゲーム付き設定集として楽しんでしまえる程です。薄い本でオリジナルSF設定集を買いあさっている私としては、設定だけで値段以上に楽しめています。

アーマードコアやフロントミッション2nd、アインハンダーが好きな人は気に入ると思います。

追記：
機動兵器に乗って風俗街で暴れまわれるゲームは他に見たことが無い。看板の文字が日本語なので「間違えた日本」ファンにもオススメ。

review: Very charming isometric mech game with a wooping 56 different vehicles to choose from including mechs, tanks and anti-gravity fliers. Weapon options are equally diverse and range from machine guns, auto-cannons, howitzers, unguided rockets and grenade launchers over to lasers. The fully destructable environment adds a large part of the immersion and fun - there's nothing quite like firing a 140mm smoothbore SABOT round through 2 office buildings and obliterating the mech behind them. Missions feel a bit repetitive and could need a bit of diversifying. It's also sorely missing a coop mode. Definitely recommend this when on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962245625', 'num_games_owned': 837, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1513648895}
review:
This love letter to the 80's not only has a bombastic synthwave soundtrack, it lives and breathes it: dark humor sci-fi that laughs at the absolute carnage that a mechanized war machine can wreak upon densely populated urban areas. Story is lacking, but this game makes up for it in style and gameplay. 

While the campaign at first shoehorns you into only one loadout per mission, it branches out about 40% of the way through to allow you 3-4 different loadouts per level, each one changing the way you play drastically, from taking and dishing out massive ordnances, to hit-and-run tactics.

The game is best in the former as you're likely to get swarmed by large numbers of enemies. It never gets tiring firing a 140mm cannon into a large group of enemies. The visual feedback in this game is phenomenal. 

As to what I didn't enjoy, the isometric angle also makes it difficult to tell exactly where your shot will land, leading to plenty of missed shots. 

The limited ammo system can be hit-or-miss. It adds a lot of tension as you often have to pick your shots instead of simply spraying everywhere, which is a plus. However, if there are no enemy ammo drops to be had, your only recourse is to reload at ammo dumps. 

This is no fun at all given that it has to be the RIGHT type of ammo dump, often ALL the way on the other side of the map AND it is easily blown up AND it has limited ammo. Even less fun if you have a slow, lumbering vehicle and there are a million obstacles in the way. Running out of ammo happened more often that I would have liked, and I feel I was already playing conservatively when possible. 

Thankfully, there is a built-in infinite ammo cheat easily accessible through the developer console via F1. So these negatives are moot depending on how you want to play this game (namely if you just want to blow stuff up). Even then, these negatives largely don't get in the way of the mountain of fun to be had.

review:
My face went cold as the blood rushed out and the fear rushed in.  I just caught myself exasperatedly laying into the horn at a crowd of yellow jackets.  Road-rage on any other day;  an involuntary act.  A lingering reverberation of humanity.

A reflex can save a life, or in this case, make you pound yourself in the forehead for being so fucking stupid.  It all depends what day it is.  Tuesday.  Under contract and legally owned by a corporation till death or 70% objectives razed.  Every one of these yellow Loyalists is worth a few scrip in the bottom line of a contract, and any one of them could be clad in high explosives, seething inside and primed for heroics.  For fuck sakes.  Today is a good day for indifference, not veiled courteousy.

I watched them -- self-loathing and clinching my teeth -- I listened to them.  Cries of crowd and city began piercing through the long echo of a waning horn; a blaring embarassment that won't go away.  I held an unfocused stare through the HUD.  Blurry green metrics of the display refracted in rain drops streaming down the canopy.  That stare lasted until the green blur turned to red.  Something big and metal heard us and wants to investigate.  I backed up into a corridor, crouched, and opened the radiators to cool off.  Stealth is out the fucking window, and now a small signature radius is "pertinent".  I checked munition count, tightened my harness, and forgot all about how much I hated myself.  I hate this job even more, and this one will end it all, one way or another.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972280108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1513427108}
review:
I'm about two or three hours into the game now so I can safely recommend it. It's ridculously fun, a little challenging (once you start to get to the missions where it gives you a lot of playstyle choice) and very very cool. You select from a series of hella cool mechs in order to complete various general tasks in big open maps that can (and most assuredly will) be reduced to rubble. The firefights here are intense and frantic, with shells, bullets and explosives flying back and forth with satisfying whooshes and thumps. Many isometric or top down shooting games can feel a little flat or limited, but thanks to the destruction and carnage this manages to feel meaty and deep enough to warrant a few replays. Whereas with one tank you might just run in and blow everything away with twin cannons, another might require you to make small rabbit holes in the terrain in order to smash and run on large groups of enemies and defensive positions. Sometimes the missions feel a little unfair for a chosen character, one springs to mind where you must avoid numerous suicide bombers with no ammo until you reach the depot beyond - with the slow moving tank it's nigh on impossible to even get out of the first area.

This aside, the challenge is there if you want it. I haven't dived in to the freelancer mode yet, but it appears that you can fully customise your mech loadout for maximum badass.
