author: {'steamid': '76561198048555360', 'num_games_owned': 844, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3581, 'last_played': 1671085811}
review:
If John Carpenter had ever made a film about mechs on an off-world colony, this would be the accompanying video game for that film. 

Extremely detailed visuals that don't waste any of the pixels on your screen. The accompanying soundtrack fits perfectly and is good enough to stand on its own as well. For those few times when you do turn down the music, you'll be able to hear the whine of servos, hum of a particle beam, and the jarring crackle of high caliber munitions.

The story won't be fed to you during your missions, but if you're interested there is a 'lore' section accessible in the main menu (if those reams of text aren't enough to flesh out the world, there's also an audiobook/e-book available that gives more hints about the nature of Novo Solo and the city of Solo Nobre).

At first I found the controls to be awkward, but ultimately they do grant a very high level of control over each vehicle. You might be tempted to play this like a twinstick, but it is far from that. While some encounters can be won by brute force and reflex, most will require a few moments of planning to survive. 

Brigador is brutal, deep, and unflinching. However, it can also feel clunky and unfair too. Trying to master the game in spite of those challenges has provided an extremely rewarding video game experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 10453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5643, 'last_played': 1512400743}
review:
Brigador is the epitome of the 90's having come back with a blast from the past.

If you ever wanted to commandeer a rocket shooting flying Cadillac and lay waste to entire city blocks, this game is for you.  If you ever wanted to steer a bipedal mech armed to the teeth with gatling guns right through a building instead of around it, this game is for you. If you ever wanted to be so engrossed in the flow of battle that you start feeling invincible, just to be blown to bits by having made one single mistake, this game is for you.

The amount of content is massive and there are nigh endless possible combinations of weapons, all featuring a different playstyle.

Brigador is a trip down memory lane and it doesn't end in a musty smelly back-alley. Instead it just spirals out of control, wider wider wider, causing quite a fervent flow of its own.

I absolutely loved every single second I spent in this absolute gem of a twin stick shooter-derivate. Absolutely recommended to anyone even remotely interested in these kinds of games. Beware though, the difficulty curve is actually quite high.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025612048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1512502285}
review:
Do you like late '80s/early '90s cyberpunk art style with a big John Carpenter vibe?

Do you like synth-y musical goodness?

Do you like driving around a mech, laying waste to soldiers, tanks, bases, abandoned cars, and every other structure in sight?

Do you want to stomp on your enemies with your big robo-legs?

Do you want to blast your silly horn on your war mech as you march into battle, announcing your presence and the imminent doom of your enemies?

If you answered yes to any of these questions and like to play video games, this game is probably a game you will definitely pick up during a Steam Sale and then forget you have because you're too busy playing Skyrim for the billionth time. Instead of playing a game that you've bought multiple times on several platforms over the past 6 years, try playing this one. The missions aren't lengthy but there are a lot of them, you can run around guns blazing or sneak through checkpoints to flank your enemies and take out your target, and the game isn't super demanding while still looking super pretty. Nazeem will not ask you if you've been to the Cloud District and then mock you in this game. Why? Because this game is a badass and Nazeem is a milk-drinker.

It's an explosive good time! Hell, buy it at full price. It's worth the $20! (The dev keeps adding extra content for free too!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197969843705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 34296, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16904, 'last_played': 1635466657}
review:
In short Brigador is a fantastic game that's niche enough that it isn't for everyone.  If you're interested in driving stompy robots buy Bragador.  If you like isometric shooters buy Bragador. If you like challenging yourself buy Bragador.   If none of those things are true or you want something casual to spend your time on there are better choices.  

Now for the long version.  Brigador is an isometric vehicle shooter with both a campaign and freelance mode.  Either pays out money on successful mission completion which you use to unlock vehicles, weapons, special abilities, freelance missions, and lore.  The learning curve is relatively steep but managable, the tutorial missions at the start of the campaign are decent enough to learn the ropes.  The game can be quite difficult but that difficulty is always fair.  

Campaign mode have fixed enemy spawns and a selection of 4 loadouts to bring to that mission.  Difficulty of campaign missions mostly ramps up with earlier missions being much easier and later missions being harder.  There is one curveball mission in the middle which probably rage inducing for some. The loadouts for each campaign mission tend to have a mix of reasonable and challenge loadouts.  

Freelance mode is the meat of the game.  In it you choose a pilot which replaces the difficulty slider found in most games.  From there you select a vehicle, 2 weapons, special ability, and mission.  Freelance missions range from 2 maps to 30+ maps.  Individual maps have fixed layouts and psuedorandom enemy spawns.  Depending on the pilot, vehicle, and mission choices difficulty can range from cakewalk to 'I'm a skeleton in a golf cart, today the enemies will probably be exploding me for a change.' 

Weapons range from a lowly peashooter machine gun to city block leveling artillery with a huge range of weapons in between.  Almost every weapon has a niche that needs to be considered when choosing your loadout.  

Vehicles range from heavily armed nigh invincible supertanks to fast and agile but fragile agravs.   And a golf cart.  

All of the choices available for for freelance give a ton of replayability.  Different vehicles give a ton of variety, a Lowmill plays nothing like a Hoker.  Even within a vehicle different loadouts can play very differently, a Raider with Kraken, Pinch, and smoke, plays very differently from a Raider with Harvester, Donkey, and camo. 

Lorewise the game is set on a dystopian colony world far distant from earth.  The lore entries, pilot descriptions, and weapon descriptions are all written from the perspective of characters in the universe.  Each has their biases and knowledge gaps.  Personally I've found the writing to be uniformly excellent.  It's one of the better crafted worlds I've come across in a game, to the extent that when a new patch comes out the first thing I check is to see if there are new lore entries to unlock.  

If the above sounds interesting buy Brigador it will be worth every penny once you have an idea what you're doing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040635142', 'num_games_owned': 795, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1557, 'last_played': 1671155596}
review:
Brigador feels like a game that I missed in... 1995. A game where deaths feel like a collection of mistakes I can remember, not a game mechanic working against me. The music is great. The aestetic and graphics are great. The gameplay is great.


Brigador is a game that has been lovingly crafted, and I do mean that. Looking at the game while it's running (in a high resolution anyway) may not key you in on how it's doing what it does, but the game is entirely 2D. Even with the massive amount of rendering space on screen at once on my 1920x1200 monitor, the game still runs over 200FPS, and never drops. It's not an unoptimized mess, and it still manages to have a lot of pretty features for those who want the most to look at out of their game (The aiming path is rendered to make the 2D look 3D, and there is a lot of dynamic lighting to do the same).

With Brigador's Campaign mode you'll have most of the game's learning curve explained to get you on to a plain where you may start to use any of the vehicles, weapons and defences you purchase effectively. The first 12 missions aid you in controlling a Mech, a Tank and an Agrav (Anti-Gravity, or [i]hovertank[/i], if you will). Controls are currently available to split between Agravs between Mechs and Tanks, and while some people want a unique control preset between Mechs and Tanks, if you aren't bothered by the same control scheme on both, you won't need to change it every time you want to use one or the other. Controls are available between forward being [b]Tile Absolute:[/b] north on the map (North being selectable as top left or top right), [b]Screen Absolute:[/b] north on the screen (always up, you control 45 degrees against the map's grid), and [b]Relative:[/b] forward is forward to the vehicle's heading (allowing you to hold W and D to walk in circles). Agrav controls are mostly the same except for [b]Relative[/b], where W will move the vehicle towards the cursor. Pressing A and D will still strafe relative to the vehicle's heading. This occurs mainly because a mech has heading of the legs, and the turret. The legs move, the turret does not. A tank has the heading of the treads and the turret. The treads move, the turret does not. An Agrav has the heading of a turret. The turret moves. If you've played Hotline Miami or are used to the way it handles movement, an Agrav might not feel too far off when played in [b]Screen Absolute[/b] mode. There are a few options for control toggles: mech crouching, orientation lock, and Agrav low-fly height. Players may also change gamespeed (the default is 80, and the slider goes up to 100, or down to 50); the ingame loadingscreen hints recommend changing it down "if you use a controller or like seeing stuff explode in slow motion." I personally have left it at 80, but allowing people to change it is definitely a plus. Too bad you can't set it to 150% and play [i][b]Super Brigador Up-Armoured Turbo: Hyper Armored Combat[/b][/i].

The music is quite enjoyable, and I'd recommend the Deluxe edition from the start to save you a dollar (or two, depending on your currency) to get it's soundtrack (The Deluxe edition comes with an audio book and the soundtrack in MP3.) So far, my only complaint with the entire game is that the soundtrack isn't administered in FLAC. That's pretty impressive when you consider that I have no other problems.

[b]Edit:[/b] Makeup and Vanity Set has a bandicamp, which contains all four albums currently included in Brigador's Soundtrack on Steam; Bandicamp supports FLAC downloads, however: [i]Up-Armored[/i] will cost you at least [b]$7 USD[/b], [i]Uplink[/i] is [b]Free[/b], [i]Volume I[/i] costs [b]$10 USD[/b], and [i]Volume II[/i] costs [b]$15 USD[/b], which is a little upsetting to say the least, if you want FLAC quality [i]and[/i] the audiobook. [b]End Edit[/b]

Do I think Brigador is worth your time? Absolutely. Brigador's gameplay allows you to jump in at just about any time after you've made some bank to choose what pilot, vehicle, weapons and defences you want and then a set of zones to just play whenever. Pilots dictate the game's difficulty and additional victory cash rewards, with some pilots ranging from easier difficulties, to a pilot who's difficulty is at max on the first map you will load on (each pilot has a Bio, and visible stats for difficulty and payout bonuses, regardless of wether you've bought them using ingame currency. There are no loot boxes, and no way to use real world money to get anything in this game).


[b]tl;dr:[/b] Brigador, post Up-Armored relaunch, is quite possibly the second best game of 2016 to me, second only to Titanfall 2. It is well worth your time and money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037875553', 'num_games_owned': 2066, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1671259423}
review:
TL;DR - Game is great, well worth the money.  Highly recommended.


-Pasted from a comment I made somewhere-

Awesome graphics, if you're a fan of the sprite style.  Everything is so detailed, all the buildings, mechs, enemies, piles of rubble you leave behind and even the little civvies running around.  The lighting is great too.  The flash from the various guns and lasers, all the neon lighting around, and the frantic little flashlights that kick in when you scare the civilians.  It also interacts with the environment really well, the shadows from your vehicles lights look awesome on the rubble and grass and stuff.

Sound and music are great.  Guns, vehicles and explosions sound very powerful and punchy, the audio helps everything feel like it has weight to it.

Everything is destructible.  For me this is more about seeing shit blow up in a battle than necessarily pathing through structures, which is slow and loud (but still fun)



The vehicles have 3 types, mechs, tanks, and anti-grav vehicles.  Within those three categories, there are a variety of sizes, with differing stats, weapon mount types and difficulty multipliers (more on that in a bit)

There are 3 factions that each have vehicles in those three styles.
Each faction has visual differences and, if I remember right, faction specific stat tweaks.  Nothing game-changing, but one faction may favor shields over hull strength for instance.

Each vehicle has a certain amount of hull strength, shields, and overcharge shield capacity.  Hull strength is just your hitpoints, can't remember if there's any way to replenish it (I don't think so).  Shields can be replenished, though they won't do it passively over time, but from pickups from destroyed enemies.  And overcharge is bonus shield capacity that deteriorates over time.

Each vehicle has two weapon mounts, from types like auxiliary, main, heavy, small (and a few others I think), that determines what guns you get to pick from for your loadout.



For weapons there are ballistic weapons, lasers and mortars/artillery.  Ballistic and lasers have a few variations like cannon, chaingun, machine gun, shotgun etc., and artillery has varying sizes/ranges.

Individual weapons have different stats for things like shield damage, hull damage, fire rate, reload speed, structure damage, penetration, magazine size and total ammo pool.  Penetration is pretty neat, some of the big cannons can fire right through multiple structures.  Nothing like rear-shotting an enemy tank through a city block.

You also get to pick one of four or five special abilites, like smoke screen, cloaking, emp charge.  They have a cooldown, but unlimited use.



I Haven't really played campaign at all, below mission info is about freelance/sandbox mode.

You start by picking an operation from the list.  Any op will always have the same maps and the same number of them.  So "Operation Whatever" will always take place on the drainage map, the slums and the canal for example, but the placement of objectives and enemies will be randomized.

Aside from taking place on different maps, each mission plays out the same.  You unlock the exit by doing at least one of the main objectives - kill a % of all enemies, kill all the commanders, or blow up all of the big artillery structures.  There are also a few side missions that are the same each time.  The more you do, the more money you earn for unlocking stuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992104223', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16365, 'last_played': 1634428425}
review:
Every time I try to write a review of this game it starts turning into a book, not sure if that's on me or if it says something about the game. There is a suprising amount of depth to the game, and once you start going into one part of the game mechanics you end up having to cover all of it in detail and it just grows from there. Anyway, if you like gritty old-school cyberpunk with great worldbuilding and moral ambiguity, if you like the idea of an isometric shooter with a hefty graft of simulation and highly tactical gameplay, give Brigador a go.

It does have a fairly steep learning curve (probably not so bad since the Up-Armoured Edition added new tutorials and lower default speed, I started on the original release) but it's really worth it, and there's lots of replayability with the variety of loadouts and difficulty levels. Everything from huge mechs and tanks with heavy artillery which can level a whole block with one shot to tiny powersuits with gamma lasers which can cook the enemy through walls and nippy agravs which can flit through enemy fire and circle around to attack their weaker rear armour, you can find a build for pretty much any playstyle you want. At higher difficulties with the smaller, more vulnerable units you really need to think ahead and take full advantage of your environment and equipment to survive.

The devs have done a fantastic job of supporting and extending the game despite it sadly not being a huge financial success for them, adding new levels and units and improving the graphics, with more to come in future updates. Linux and OSX are both fully supported, I spend most of my time on Linux so I appreciate that.

A lengthy campaign, an even lengthier Freelance mode, where you buy mini cmapaigns, vehicles, pilots and weapons and pick and choose loadouts to tackle them with, beautiful isometric visuals and a great synthwave soundtrack make Brigador a great choice for anyone looking for some fun gunplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045695345', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 6486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6457, 'last_played': 1705217613}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197984291881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1659069050}
review:
Definitely one of the most enjoyable and unique games I've played to date. The developers are extremely talented and wonderful people.

The visuals perfectly recreate that 90's aesthetic so many great PC games had. Such a wonderful futuristic dystopia full of mechs and other massive weapons in a completely unique setting. I've been waiting for years for a game to have a theme like this and Brigador definitely delivers.

The gameplay is definitely not dated however. Controls are tight and responsive and the variety of mechs/vehicles, weapons, pilots, and missions is staggering to say the least. Many of the options feel very different from one another adding so much to the depth of the game. You'll definitely keep coming back to try new things for a long time.

Finally I can't leave a review without mentioning the story. While many games in the past similar to this would have a barebones story that a lot of times were either down right boring or in some cases never even finished Brigador sets itself FAR apart. While it's not always forthright this game is filled to the brim with lore and quite an interesting story. I won't spoil anything but I definitely hope we see more of Brigador. I'm aware there is an e-book and audiobook though I have not checked them out but I certainly will soon!

If the game wasn't great enough as it was the developers released an updated version free of charge a while back and are still updating with new content! Definitely show these guys some love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970648480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3450, 'last_played': 1694059286}

author: {'steamid': '76561197985900913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 11544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4808, 'last_played': 1669327567}
review:
On the surface Brigador is a 2D isometric tank shooter.  Underneath there is a lot of customisation and a wide array of tactics you'll use to avoid an untimely demise.

The campaign mode has loads of missions, most with a choice of four loadouts.  These allow you to try to have a go at each scenario in very different ways.  Freelance mode allows you to set up your own vehilce and choose a set of missions.  There are three vehilce classes (tank, walker, agrav) which all handle in different ways and have significant pros and cons.  In each class there is a spectrum of sizes and the three factions each have their own strengths and weaknesses.

The difficulty in Freelance mode is entirely up to you, there are no easy/medium/hard settings.  Each pilot has a difficulty rating and many get harder as you progress through missions.  Certain vehicles and classes lend themselves to particular weaponry and each weapon has pros and cons.  Some maps are wide and open with lots of room to move but nowhere to hide, others are perfect for sneaking and setting up bottle-neck ambushes but with no room to turn and run.

Its easy to learn in a big heavy tank, able to take a beating and dish out huge damage but you cant run or hide.  In some more difficult missions run and hide is the only thing which can keep you alive.  Projectiles take your vehilces momentum, making fast agravs exceptionally good artillery platorms.

The central theme of Brigador experimentation.  It's easy to find a loadout you like and use it to learn the basics, then start swapping parts and branch out.  Soon you'll find something completely different which works just as well but in a totally different way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067570891', 'num_games_owned': 503, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1696051470}
review:
Pros:
Tons of variety and choices in your loadouts. Whether you like being fast and nimble, a brawler, a sniper, the ol' bait-and-switch, or even stealth (yes, that's possible in a two story walking tank) there's a way to get what you want out of this game. Tons of chassis, tons of weapons, and 4 different special abilities that you can mix and match to make what you want.

Campaign does a good job of teaching the basics and how the different vehicle types work, and then starts to ramp up the difficulty over time until by the end you feel like you got gud. There are also some interesting wrenches in the works here and there (Joy Bus/Hell Ride anyone?). It's nice that you can select from 4 premade loadouts; doesn't break the balance of the missions while giving you choices to suit your playstyle and also introducing a new player to the concept of building a loadout. (NOTE: I haven't played the new E-series so I can't vouch for that.)

Very well done freelance mode lets you take things as slow and gentle as you want...or if you'd rather bend over and take it like a man, that's an option too. Build a loadout freely by picking a vehicle along with two weapons and a special ability and a pilot to go along with it. Then pick how many levels you want to run. The game determines how the difficulty scales based on which pilot you choose, as well as the payout, with the vehicle you choosing also providing bonus cash if you make it out. Precursor James Double Donkey runs are rumored to be the hot new thing but I haven't saved up the 100 million yet so don't ask me.

More subjective portion: I love this game's style and worldbuilding. Shots of all kind are distinct, the whole place has a sort of downtrodden industrial look to it and the color palette and art reflects that without compromising the gameplay (too much at least, see cons.) The backstory is great as well and the Lore section allowing you to read up on the game's world as told by its inhabitants is awesome.

When you actually get into the game, the environment doesn't feel limiting or like a playing field, more so a tool you can use if you're clever enough. Pretty much all 4 special abilities tie into it at least indirectly and all vehicle classes have one way or another of smashing through groves of trees or apartment blocks. No need to walk down the street into a tank platoon, bust out from behind them two blocks down and hit them where it hurts most. Kool-Aid Man Simulator 2016.

Cons:

Sometimes I find it hard to tell whether a particular piece of scenery is explosive or not. Dunno if that's just me or what.

Can be a little hard to see the red glow emitted by an enemy behind a wall sometimes.

Freelance mode is slow to start since you have to unlock the different equipment and pilots which can take a bit of doing. (Thankfully you can pick what to spend your blood money on rather than there being a linear unlock system.)

Some enemies have rather unexpected loadouts and can catch you way off guard, other enemies are quite hard to deal with based on what you brought to the fight. Some loadouts just don't have a good way of dealing with those red-headlight suicide bomber enemies.

The aiming system is a little weird at first, especially when fighting agravs.

Overall:

Not a perfect game but definitely a very competent example of a roguelite that will definitely scratch that big stompy robot itch. Solid gameplay mechanics but unless you find fun within said mechanics themselves it may get old fast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044763969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1092, 'last_played': 1698634150}
review:
Brigador is a game with a strong sense of identity. That identity is neon-soaked, synth-scored, vehicular mayhem. There's a ton of unlockables along with a good amount of lore if you care to read it, much of tinged with a dark sense of humor. But the real meat of the game is the all-single-player rampages you get sent on with your tank/mech/hovercraft across the cyberpunk planet of Solo Nobre.

Although there are some light stealth elements and discretion is important at times, overall this is a game that wants you to fully enjoy making damn near everything in sight asplode with the incredible firepower at your disposal. Even just fighting off enemies will often result in extensive collateral damage to the environment. Which is fine, because this game basically tracks "collateral damage" as "bonus points".

Beyond that, the "Freelance" mode offers quite a lot of customization, allowing you to combine whatever weapons with your chassis of choice before setting off for a string of missions. If you want a tiny, tracked motorcycle or battlesuit equipped with grenade launchers? No problem. A massive superheavy tank or hovercraft with a cloaking device? Done! It's all in there, waiting to be unlocked.

One last note: while some objections could still be made about the HUD, I think, (the icons are often rather small and hard to make out) the controls offer a satisfying amount of customization. If you're worried that you'll be stuck with a scheme you hate...don't sweat it too much. As long as twin-stick shooters in general are fun for you, you can likely find a setup that works for you in the options screen here.

If you're looking for something quiet, introspective, or with multiplayer then this isn't the game you want. But if your main objection to Mechwarrior and World of Tanks is that they don't let you demolish enough stuff with your war machines? This is one contract you'll want to accept, Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058943508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1295, 'last_played': 1659326040}
review:
This game snuck up on me. I got it in the humble bundle probably a year ago, and I'd never heard of it. I mostly ignored it in favour of playing the other games I got in that bundle and eventually completely forgot about it. Then, as I was digging through my library on a friday night, this game caught my eye and figured I might waste an hour or two on it, just have some mindless fun. An entire weekend later, I went back into society and told everyone I knew about this game; I had just spent the entire weekend playing it pretty much non-stop.


This game somehow manages to combine twitch reactions with deep strategy that encourages players to observe the environment and use to their advantage. Combine that with the satisfaction of modular loadout building, and the PURE JOY of some of the most satisfying weapons I've played with, and it's easy to see how you can get lost in it for hours at a time. Oh, and it also has some really interesting and in-depth lore on everything from the places you visit to the weapons you fire. It's worth a read.

review:
Highly recommend this game. Works beautifully on Linux.

It's a hidden slow-paced, tactical mech combat game hiding behind a bullet hell-esque design. The gameplay is smooth and engaging. It's very tactical in that you have to constantly be three steps ahead or you will be overwhelmed by the enemy and killed. The freelance mode is an excellent roguelike.

Most impressive about this game is the lore and world. The devs have spent a ton of time developing the world for the players to destroy, unlocking lore and intel took priority as the world feels real. I keep wanting to find out more and more about it.

Devs also get a +2 for being fans of trainspotters, taking inspiration from Asimov and including a playable Sikh character! The latter actually made me double take because it's just that rare to see a Sikh in games. 

Keep up the good work!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026485607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1512763693}
review:
SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL. WELCOME, BRIGADOR. Back in the days we had these shooters Jungle Strike and Desert Strike with (nearly) completely destructible terrain. Then came Syndicate and Syndicate 2, both upping the ante with even more full blown orgy of destruction and endorsing the player to do massive collateral damage on one's wake. Then, on the whole different perspective we had wonderful Mech games in the forms of Mech Warrior series (well, about half of 'em were wonderful, at least) and Mech Commander. From this background comes Brigador, cherry-picks the best parts from its role models and brings us the terrible, beautiful wanton of destruction.

Only after few hours under my belt I already love it. It is both a tactical shooter and nearly limitless sandbox of destruction - like playing with a huge Lego set without assembly instructions and a ton of explosives. Brigador's slightly pixelish, neon light drenched and shadow blotted landscapes get constantly pulverized  under heavy mortar strikes, rip-roaring chainguns, rampaging tanks, stomping mechs, even hover-like flying platforms - and they all are designed in a delightfully wonky way that is completely implausible and yet very delightful, like something out of any 2000AD comic strip pages. 

The game has a quite lengthy campaign dealing with procedurally 'liberating' the colony planet as a group of mercenaries doing it all for money (handsomely paid by a shady megacorporation). You use the cash to buy more drivers, vehicles, weapons, missions and (also very delightful) intel and lore for the mission mode, which I think is the real beef of the game. (Although I have enjoyed the campaign so far, too.) 

You set up your death machine by selecting a hull from towering huge mechs or 'tanks' (more like an apartment block with guns on treads) or flying behemoths to relatively tiny ACPA suits, IFVs or flying platforms, and bolting on them your favored methods of destruction, and off you go. This gives lots of variety into how you plan to pull your job through - level everything with massive firepower, screw dodging and try to just soak the incoming damage with you shields and armour, or be the nimble little bastard that nobody can hit into and surgically strike your targets and dance away from the blasts before the enemy gets their cumbersome big hiney on the spot. Your imagination is the limit. 

Brigador hits my nerve perfectly with its payload of insane scale destruction, frantic shooty-action, tactical aspects and lovely old-skool visuals, not to mention the groovy retro-drenched Synthwave soundtrack pounding on the background. Cherry on the top, the lore is fun to read and gives names and faces on the odd looking things you're either driving yourself or blasting away with glee. Easy to get a grip on, simple enough to learn and time consuming to master with every aspect, Brigador reminds me of good old times - and that we have way too few good Mech games around. Luckily we have this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995069973', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2225, 'last_played': 1693914017}
review:
Brigador is easily one of the best games on Steam.

The frantic combat is tough-but-fair. High replayability with things kept interesting by a huge number of choices in vehicle type, each with pros / cons, and a large array of different kinds of weapons. Stealth mechanics are not particularly deep, but their simplicity lends itself well to the game's general sense of urgency. Fast-paced action and precision is balanced well with tactical maneuvering and thinking on your feet. Find your niche in personal style and thrive.

Like any proper retro-inspired action game, the story does not get in the way of the game. There are no cutscenes, or even screens that force you to read about what's going on. If you so choose, however, the game's grimdark setting shines through narrative in the form of technical and personal descriptions displayed as notes written by characters in game, complete with a touch of dark humor that never feels out of place.

I did not expect a game primarily about piloting mechs and blowing things up to have an incredibly rich, dark aesthetic. While not cyberpunk, it grips tightly to the same tone of a cold, cynical dystopia lit frequently by neon. The gritty style of the game's graphics is used to grand effect with cool-looking weapon effects and explosions. While it carries a certain oldschool feel, being set on an isometric plane, Brigador does not look or feel dated, partially due to its clever use of shaders.

The music, composed by Makeup and Vanity Set (MAVS), could singlehandedly give any best-of playlist put together by New Retrowave a run for its money. This reason alone should justify a purchase if you enjoy music like Perturbator, Carpenter Brut, Mega Drive, or Power Glove.

This game is good. It is quite possibly the peak of indie gaming. I cannot recommend it enough. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011190521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1685741060}
review:
Pretty fun game that doesn't seem to get the exposure it deserves. Amazing synth soundtrack, beautiful isometric artstyle, and surprisingly deep and well written lore. However, I felt a bit mislead with the trailer. I expected a more visceral, lots of action and shooting all the time gameplay. Instead it's actually a very tactical and sometimes stealth driven which can actually be frustrating if you went in expecting otherwise. There's also a rather annoying gimmick level that raises a sudden roadblock while you're playing the campaign. Controls can feel a bit clunky too, tank controls just don't work well in a 2d isometric when you're trying to concentrate on so many little things on the screen. And they really don't give much ammo in some parts which ties into that tactical aspect they push. Often I found myself holding back and playing slow, which just became tedious rather than fun. Also you'll find the levels mostly boil down to the same thing, blow the things up and exit. Very 90s I guess, but repetitive. Repetition can be fun when it's mindless, but becomes a chore when having to be very careful about movement and ammo consumption, etc.

Overall it's an alright game, not given enough recognition, but also overrated by some fans. It's worth the money though, especially for the OST.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015840044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1623113066}
review:
I'm a simple man.
I see a mech game, I investigate.

I was not disappointed.

Brigador is a fantastic little game that has a surprisingly large amount of world building for the universe that it has you playing around in. At its core, it’s a simple sandbox game that has you ploughing through sectors and wasting enemies while completing objectives. The main campaign serves to get you comfortable to the various vehicular control schemes (mechs, tanks, and hovercrafts) and weapon types while sprinkling some lore in short text briefings before each mission. Once you finish that though (roughly 20+ levels), the real fun begins. The meat and potatoes of this game are in its FREELANCE mode, where you can totally customize your player before you go play a series of “see how far you can go” type missions. Choose your pilot, vehicle, weapon loadout, and mission environment. Every run earns you cash to spend on other variations of the elements I just mentioned. Experimentation is greatly encouraged, as you can try different loadouts/vehicle combinations to suit your (any) playstyle.

The music is fantastic as well (80s synthpop/wave), thumping away as you blast away at baddies.

There is also an audiobook that’s included with the deluxe package (game+music+audiobook), as of this review I have not read it yet.

Overall: Fantastic game that gets even more entertaining once you finish the main campaign. Once you warm up to the control schemes (of which there are many options) and shooting mechanics, the game truly becomes a real fun experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000083712', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3474, 'last_played': 1708236207}
review:
Brigador is a game that I wish I had supported earlier in its development and even after dumping 50+ hours into it return every so often for a good hour or so of unbridled destructions and frantic top down mech/tank shooter action. In a nutshell the game takes place in a late 1980’s early 90s esc cyber punk dystopian future where humanity has spread colonies amongst the stars. The game takes place in the city of Solo Nobre, a former corporate mega city turned Cuban esc regime by the efforts of Great Leader and his army the NEP. You as the player take the role of a “Brigador” essentially a mercenary hired by the corporations to accomplish various goals and wreaking as much havoc as possible within Solo Nobre during the chaos brought by great leader’s assassination in exchange for cold hard cash.

	In terms of gameplay brigador plays very much like the old SNES BattleTech top down mech shooter, albeit with a greater degree of polish. The player takes control of one of the various war machines in the game to accomplish their assigned goals and has a wide assortment of weaponry to do so. By completing missions and successfully extracting you earn cash which can be used to unlock various items in the game such as new pilots, vehicles, weapons, and lore documents. Brigador’s gameplay is divided into two major parts the first being the campaign/story mode, in this mode the player must accomplish a series of missions using premade vehicle loadouts. Campaign missions can have a wide assortment of objectives but most boil down to eliminate the target then get out of the district. The second mode is free lance where players can select a pilot (difficulty level and payout multipliers), vehicle and its weapons, as well as what operation (series of levels) they wish to play. Every level will pit you against one of three factions, the NEP, the Corvids, and the Spacers. Each faction has their own vehicle sets (many of which you the player can actually use your self) and have different strengths and weaknesses though these are hardly noticeable when you start deploying with weapons that destroy entire city blocks in a single shot.

	In terms of sound design and eye candy brigador achieves what its going for. The sprawling neon lit city scapes are fully realized in an isometric style reminiscent of command and conquer tiberian sun and dripping with just as much atmosphere. The game’s soundtrack by Makeup and vanity set is simply fantastic and matches the visuals to the letter; I must point out however that the sound design for individual weapons and vehicles tends to rely on reusing sound assets though this is hardly noticeable in the grand scheme of things.

Brigador’s story and world building is perhaps the aspect I love the most about this game, every piece of equipment, vehicle, and pilot has back story detailed in various logs that take on different perspectives some of which going so far as to bring a bit of humor to what would otherwise be a bland lore document. The writing behind some of these logs is pretty clever and though not award winning materiel it certainly does add a bit of depth to what is otherwise just a top down shooter. 

I do thoroughly enjoy this game and would highly recommend it, but I can’t help to see a few problems with it. The most glaring issue I see with the game is how repetitive it can get after a while, once you've completed every campaign mission you turn to freelance, but then it doesn't take long before you're running through the same city districts over and over again; the only real diversity coming from the vehicle and weapon set up your using as well as the possibility that you might be fighting a different faction this time around. A lack of any kind of multiplayer also kinda limits the game’s replayability and effectively makes this a game I play when I have no one else to play with. One last gripe I have is that though all three opposing factions are well fleshed out in terms of design, back story, and visible arsenals they tend to function all the same and lack any kind of behavioral differences.

If I could make suggestions for updates, or changes to be made in any prospective sequel it would be the following.

The inclusion of some kind of coop option for Freelance mode, or any kind of multiplayer really as this gives me incentive to actually recommend the game to friends and increases replayability. 

Diversifying AI behavior between the various factions, everyone in sight rushing at you makes sense for the rag tag corvids or glory seeking spacers, but not so much for the supposedly disciplined NEP.

Perhaps more districts or variations of the various districts so players are not stomping down the same streets over and over in free lance.

The inclusion of further customisation options for the player vehicle, perhaps color tweaks of some kind or vehicles with more than just two weapons slots.

review:
[h1][b]「ソロ・ノブリへようこそ。ブリゲイダー」[/b][/h1]

緻密に描かれたジオラマ風未来都市をメックにて蹂躙するサイバーパンク風STG。

プレイヤーは架空の未来都市ソロ・ノブリに放たれた傭兵として、メックやガンタンク、ホバーカー、果ては機動要塞まで駆使して眼前の敵ロボットや建造物、逃げまどうソロ・ノブリ市民を跡形も無く破壊することがゲームの目的である。

主なゲーム進行としては、与えられたミッションをこなしていく「キャンペーン」と、キャンペーン完遂後に支給されるリソースを使ってアンロックしたロボや兵器を実戦投入する「フリーランス」の2通りに分かれている。
キャンペーン自体はユニットや建造物の破壊といった単調なものが多いが、上記のフリーランスにおけるアンロックについては、膨大な攻撃兵器から未来世界ソロ・ノブリへの没入を深めるための情報まで多岐にわたり、全てをアンロックするには膨大な戦闘をこなす必要があるだろう。

サイバーパンクな世界に地表を闊歩するメックと、誰もが考えそうで考えなかった本作。
そういう意味では非常に意義深い作品だと思う。

author: {'steamid': '76561198019654408', 'num_games_owned': 1805, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1534536536}
review:
I've read articles like "we made a good game but indiepocalypse and noone is playing it" and "making a good game isn't enough to sell it nowadays" and so decided to give it a fair chance.

So I bought it and played it. I don't know, maybe there's a deep and interesting game that comes out after hours of gameplay, with all the pilot and mech choices, but it very quickly started feeling like drudgery for me.

Combat became monotonous after tutorial missions, hunting down objectives in a slow moving mech is about as engaging as watching paint dry. Every combat encounter I had so far was resolved by holding down left and right mouse while pointing vaguely in the direction of the enemy.

I'll probably give it another go since the devs seem to really care about their game, but I don't think honking will suddenly make the game interesting.

review:
A classic style isometric shooter featuring some fantastic art, music and retro sensibilities. The basic premise of every level is to blow up some stuff and leave before your vehicle blows up.

Soundtrack is great, all the levels are packed with detail and completely destroyable. Campaign mode is fairly simple but sets you up nicely for the main feature of Freelance mode, which lets you pick your pilot (difficulty curve), vehicle, weapons, special equipment and operation (list of levels). 

Playing in a big heavy vehicle is a constant battle with enemy forces, while smaller vehicles have to carefully engage to ensure an advantageous fight. 

If the screenshots and trailer look good to you, it's worth a go.

review:
Admittedly I was almost ready to refund this game because it took me a while to get it to work (due to Microsoft C++ runtimes) and I'm glad I didn't as it is shaping up to be a great game. 

The different units, abilities, controls, sound and visuals all combine to make a fun mech game which has short (yet action packed) missions that allows a very casual play through. 

The environments are very reminiscent of mechcommander and running around smashing buildings, walls and squishing people hasn't gotten old yet :) 

Apart from not working straight out of the box my only other criticism are the menus / interface & mission briefings, very underwhelming! so while everything else in the game is up near perfect this is a big letdown.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1672140835}
review:
Tags: Topdown Shooter

TLDR: MechMercenary Tycoon. Destructible urban instances in a well presented real time tactical topdown shooter with permanent unlockables. Audiovisually decent.

Campaign that doubles as a tutorial. In-game currency rewards towards an hybrid sim-mercenary menu minigame where you loadout your freelancers. Check out the acquisitions menu and get lore, contracts, items for squads and hire members. Destruction oriented rewards with kaiju style protagonist that towers over urban landscapes. Topdown shooter instances. 

Note: I hat to rebind mouse middle button to mouse scroll down for the powerup to activate otherwise no complaints.

Game requires use of crouching, the use of extended vision aiming to pan screen, as well as some use of positionning and ammo conservation.

Good PC resolutions support. Xbox360 pad working out of box. Game is being inserted at the outskirt of urban areas and being given objectives that must be accomplished. Ammo is a concern. You get paid for everything you destroy which is a nice touch. Difficulty seemed fairly easy. Low ammo means you often have to rely on brute force to make some money without expending ressources. 

Thankfully many tanks seem to feature ways to leverage the physics as a weapon. Additionally this enforces a more tactical oriented approach rather than holding fire and kiting which is a welcome change of pace.

The audiovisuals seem like they might disappoint at first but the fluid animation work and the physics gives everything a weight and an importance. The sound of the barrels of gatling spinning by in the headphones was subtle and psychologically satisfying. The gameplay loop is definitely there with a decent hook and the progression through the menus seem to have a lot to offer and be thematic.

Seems like the game would play better on wider resolutions as otherwise screen panning is introduced which adds additional keys and renders the action flow clunkier. I am not sure if this is a feature to accomodate for lower resolutions or if this scales with higher monitors and I would have to edit this after I tested. Especially since the aiming does not have a custom animation like the crouch and as such feels floatier and finnaggly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997555711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 9052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1697, 'last_played': 1705565669}
review:
[b]"Welcome, Brigador. Here is your contract."[/b]

Brigador is an isometric action game set in a 80's science fiction universe full of neon lights, hovertanks, and mechs.

The campaign lets you play through missions with set loadouts. It lasts about 9 hours and is pretty fun.

The "arcade" mode, Freelance, lets you choose one of several dozen vehicles including hardsuits, mechs of varying sizes, hovercraft, and tanks. You can then equip it with any two weapons that can fit in the vehicles mountings, as well as taking a unique power such as laucnhing smoke grenades or firing a massively powerful audio pulse.

Freelance will be the reason you come back to Brigador again and again. The different combinations you can create with each vehicle, pilot, weapon, and equipment make the game filled with potential. The small dev team also promises updates in the near future, but unfortunately, it's in Valve time.

I'd recommend this game for sure. I also recommend getting either the Deluxe Edition or just the Deluxe DLC Upgrade so you can get a really good soundtrack, and also a very well-written audiobook, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143223512', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1508075332}
review:
Brigador: Up-Armored Edition

Resumo:

Um título de muitas qualidades. Excelente arte, apresentação viva, cheia de cores e cercada de qualificada sonorização. Interessante mecânica de combate, talvez lenta demais para o gosto de alguns, mas bem implementada. Alguns problemas parecem ter restringido um tanto o público. Brigador é um jogo que não se compromete com narrativa, mas com a satisfação de um combate difícil em uma apresentação retrô. Mas não é um jogo para público diversificado e possui alguns problemas, além de um preço um tanto acima do que deveria ser.

Recomendo com desconto a partir de 50%.

-----------

Brigador é um ótimo jogo em diversos aspectos. Música é excelente, sonorização é muito boa. As cores vivas e o detalhamento do cenário em perspectiva isométrica dão ao jogo um visual retrô e tornam a ação bastante peculiar.

Há um modo história com uma grande quantidade de missões para as quais você tem entre 1 e 3 veículos disponíveis para fechar o cenário. Cada cenário demanda, basicamente, que o jogador destrua uma determinada quantidade de alvos específicos e depois saia do cenário.

Há uma boa variedade de Mechs, veículos e também pilotos (que possuem seus próprios atributos), ao lado de uma variedade de armas. Tudo pode ser destravado com pontos obtidos em modos arcade e campanha (uma espécie de tutorial). Cada veículo e arma funcionam bastante diferente uns dos outros, dando incrível relevância mecânica às escolhas do jogador.

O jogo possui uma tradução razoavelmente bem revisada para Português Brasileiro, mas não há muito para ser lido na parte da narrativa. Não que não haja texto, mas o texto é (também em versão original) desinteressante e pouco brilhante em relação ao visual.

Praticamente TUDO no cenário é destrutível, há boa quantidade de tipos diferentes de inimigos, mas nada que funcione como um BOSS ou chefão. Dificuldade está relacionada aos tipos de táticas que o jogador deve adotar para cada tipo de inimigo e de acordo com a quantidade e inimigos acumulados ao redor.

Você vai lembrar de todo e qualquer jogo do passado envolvendo mechs, veículos armados e filmes de ação dos anos 90. E isso é bastante para me deixar interessado, mas não é o suficiente para fazer uma recomendação a preço total.

Brigador não é bem um jogo para diversos públicos. Não é rápido nem simples o suficiente para quem gosta de twin stick shooters. O visual é cheio demais de detalhes que prejudicam a percepção visual necessária para um jogo de ação tática (especialmente quando você acumula inimigos e precisa ajustar distância de disparo). 

Você pode imaginar que sistema ideal para controle é um gamepad, mas o jogo parece ter sido feito principalmente com teclado e mouse em mente. O controle de distância da mira com uso dos sticks é ineficiente. É possível jogar com gamepad, mas melhor desempenho é obtido com teclado e mouse.

Uma excelente apresentação, mas com uma execução muito restritiva. O jogo pode não prender você depois da terceira hora. Você sentirá vontade de voltar a ele de vez em quando, mas não apenas a mecânica cansativa, como também o visual cheio parecem não ser apropriados para longas sessões.

Um bonito e interessante jogo. Mas que eu não posso recomendar a preço total... recomendo com desconto de 50% ou mais.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982745233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1510798068}
review:
Really great game.  Lots of customization and replayability.  There is a surprisingly lot of lore to the game.  But the real catch for the gameplay is the destructible environments and totally satisfying gun mechanics.  The game really makes you feel like an invincible towering tank able to mow down city blocks.  You can absolutely do this, but you will get swarmed and die so you need to approach each fight strategically so choosing the right gun to use and avenue of attack is very important to surviving on this hostile planet.  Each fight can last about 5-10 minutes so the game is great for broken up into sessions.  

Definitely recommend this game, it is really a hidden gem and works great with Linux and with my aging hardware.

Но как оказалось - это простенькая аркада с жалким подобием мехов, включаю нечто собранное из мусора. Никакой тактики, никаких мехов, никакой прокачки, бестолковый сюжет, деньги, на которые можно в энциклопедии игры купить описание техники - в общем жесть. )))

review:

3. 武器平衡性有问题。lowmill坦克加上两门konig机炮横扫一切，而那些大威力低射速武器面对蜂拥的快速小目标就没办法了。

review:
Retro 90's feeling done right. Also a fantastic mech game. Isometric. Works very well on linux. The only thing missing being a map-editor.

At first I felt it was a bit fast paced but I soon realized that the pacing is kind of set by the player. In other words, I got carried away... Stomping through buildings and turning enemy tanks, houses and civilians into ash and dust.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995129699', 'num_games_owned': 496, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1697282613}
review:
This is a game you just have to play. You feel like a kid in a sandbox with an overpowered multiple ton machine, yet if you are not carefull you will get your ass handed to you.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics with a completely destructable map.

- Sound is amazing, you can almost feel the strong weapons and their kick when you fire. The soundtrack is great.

- You can customize your mech/vehicle/hovercraft, and the options are good in freelance missions (I wish you could do 
   the same for campaign).

- The atmosphere is really good, the feeling of strength of the weapons is conveyed really well, all in all you feel like you 
   are operating  a huge mech or a vehicle. There is no loss of that feeling by it being an isometric shooter.

- Good controller support.

Cons:
- The campaign is not long but it was fun. There is lore but the story is practically non existent. Still fun.

- Weird cheap looking menus.

And that's about it. I am no writter or a good reviewer, so I tried to convey my thoughts about this game as best I can.
I can safely say that to me, this is one of the best indies I ever played, period. I hope for more support, content or a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256633547', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2051, 'last_played': 1690126007}
review: 美术风格很棒，从武器机甲驾驶员的注解也能看出来设定的用心，武器瞄准需要考虑高低差虽然有时候比较蛋疼，但总体上射击手感还是非常爽快的，这个游戏的真正乐趣其实得在解锁难度等级较高的驾驶员以后才能得到展现，虽然游戏机制很简单，一开始的低难度也很容易让人麻痹大意，但在高难度下的后期关卡，即使使用带重火力的大型机甲，不略微谨慎一点落命也就是一瞬间的事情，得像迈阿密热线般breach&clear，尤其是地图多的马拉松关卡更要考虑见好就收，想清楚脱离战场的路线和时机，使用高速脆皮机甲带上光学迷彩和迫击炮玩hit&run也是很刺激的一种玩法，简单的怪咖游戏能玩出魂味想想也很有意思

author: {'steamid': '76561198076689222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1575674454}
review:
This is a solid game to play while listening to podcasts. The difficulty ramp feels right. Grind on this game for awhile, and before you know it, you're playing it like a bullet-hell game, weaving in and out from behind buildings and anticipating bullet trajectories.

The music is great, too, and when I notice it I love it. Like I said though, it's a good podcast game, so I turn the music down low most the time.

You unlock new missions, equipment, and pilots; these unlocks give you a little bit of context as to the world. It's perfect, and I love it. It's akin to D&D style adventure hooks. They're just enough to get your creative juices flowing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015796854', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1505484323}
review:
The Up-Armored update brought this game to an excellent, enjoyable, and very playable state, fixing a ton of launch issues like the controls and camera. Yes there's some appeal to the tank controls for the mechs, but boy was that unfun. The campaign was short but sweet, and scratched that itch of destruction and open-ended gameplay to tackle the mission objectives.

My only gripe was that I wish I could take certain vehicles to certain missions, but otherwise it was fun experimenting and playing without having to think about loadouts and instead focusing on the mission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002148461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1681, 'last_played': 1527447674}
review:
This is a big stompy robot game in the structure of Desert Strike (go into a large level filled to the brim with destructible scenery, enemies, and objectives and then go buckwild) with masterwork visual chops and a great soundtrack that stands on its own.

The game has a campaign, replayable with different loadouts, and a free-play mode with unlimited loadouts. There is a short progression system in this game where you unlock pilots, vehicles, and weapons, which is a good diversion, but the main fun in the gameplay. Picking a vehicle, smashing and blowing up buildings, and ambushing enemies is a ton of fun.

My favourite part will still be the game's style. The art style and choice of music is well-defined, and so is the lore that goes with it: grim and cyberpunk.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992432685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3079, 'last_played': 1693767891}
review:
It's a fantastic game. It's got inexplicably great lore for a mech action game, and it's got a very tight action packed gameplay loop where there's a bunch of different and fun options. Just because there's a lot of different options doesn't mean that they're necessarily easy though. There's a lot of different and interesting ways to play to a wide variety of strengths.

Also it's stompy mechs and shooty tanks breaking absolutely everything in an adrenaline filled neon hellscape with a perfect accompaniment from a great soundtrack. If you want to engage with it in a technical sense or a sheer adrenaline junkie sense, there's a great way to play it for you. And yes, this does cover the intersection of the two. Just remember to pick your fights well if you like to wade in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086010113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 7054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2310, 'last_played': 1665362820}
review:
[b]“Hey, you there!”[/b]

[i]A man in a striped suit stands there pointing, motioning to you.[/i]

[b]“Yes, you! Who else would I be talking to?”[/b]

[i]Oh god in heaven, I think he’s a salesman…[/i]

[b]“Are you a public commuter; and more importantly, are you tired of waiting in traffic? I know right! The traffic is just absolutely abysmal this time of year. You can’t go half a city block without encountering those gnarly pileups and security checkpoints. I mean, you can't see past the cars anywhere in Solo Nobre.”[/b]

[i]This man’s grin seems a bit off.[/i]

[b]“You needn't say a word friend! I’ve got your rootin'-tootin' one-stop, traffic solution!”[/b]

[i]What the hell…[/i]

[b]“This model is affectionately known as the Canmore! Annnd it certainly can-do-more! Ever wanted to just ride over all that backup during traffic jams? Well now you can, with this one hundred fifty ton tank! It’ll flatten anything from telephone poles to ten story buildings!”[/b]

[i]...[/i]

[b]“Hey, and if that’s a bit too sizey, we can drop down to the compact models! The good ol’ Rounder here weighs in at just over 95 tons, but don’t let the size fool you. It’s main gun is a twentyfive millimeter Zeus railgun. The Big Z, as I like to call it, can put a sedan sized hole in quadruple reinforced concrete at around five kilometers - and if that’s not enough bang for your buck - the coaxial thirtyseven here can ground and pound anything that gives you a dirty look beyond 800!”[/b]

[i]I… I… uhhh…[/i]

[b]“Uhhhh... are you alright?”[/b]

[i]"I’ll take it! You’ve got a deal! That tank looks fuckin’ awesome! Where do I sign?!"[/i]

[b]“Right here, friend. And remember Brigador..." 

[h1]Great Leader is dead. Solo Nobre must fall.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197971785163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1576630342}
review:
I love games with character customization, and like a lot veichle battles. You can imagine how high were my expectations for this game.

However, here I am. 

The problems with Brigador are the following
1. Slow paced
2. Too easy
3. Designed as a vehicle-stealth game (I have proof below), plays as a steamroll the city game.
All of them lead to Boredom

The campaign is not a campaign, is a huge tutorial. Skipt it and head to the core of the game:

FREELANCE MISSIONS:
The game felt too slow at maximum game speed, but even with the lighter vehicles it failed to deliver any kind of thrill, even in the middle of a battle. Why?
Because all you have to do is destroy 1 target by 1, therefore leeching on their shields, and you can keep soaking damage even with a light vehicle.
Therefore the game is too easy and you can steamroll the enemy.

Therefore all the mechanics about using flanking, EMP granades, smoke screens, cover mechanics and such are mostly garbage.

It's supposed to be as a stealth game because the objectives spread across a huge map (that is also boring to cross to gather them all).
Why would have that in a battle game? You could just steamroll the enemy and then gather the objectives in the (now) ghost city. There would be no reason to spread them! But you're supposed to sneak past their formations or at least try to flank them. But you won't. You'll just steamroll them and then spend 10 minutes to cross the entire city and gather them.

It is a stealth game because of the above: the campaign clearly hints on how you're supposed to "Swat the enemy": you're supposed to flank their formation, toss in a EMP granade, dinamic entry by diving trough a building with your fullspeed tank, and wipe out the enemy squad.
Problem is, nothing of that is necessary (and the tanks are either too slow or too light to pierce themselves trough buildings...)

If it was not so easy, so dammn easy, all of it could make some sense.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002567771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1527273665}
review:
It took me a long time to think about what I'd say about Brigador, as I usually list a negative first and I'm very judgemental when it comes to games. Brigador only had very mild negatives, along with some very strong positives that makes it difficult for me to say anything bad about it

From an excellent soundtrack to the incredible gameplay, to the lore and graphics design, everything about Brigador appears to have been well made and shows great attention to detail. A gentle learning curve and a campaign that will teach you and then present you with ever increasing challenges followed with free play contracts that will let you go at the speed and difficulty you prefer means that you will always be able to customize your experience to tailor it to what you like and what you can handle. 
The maps are designed well and pretty to look at, with everything inside except for the map boundaries being fully destructible. You are even encouraged to do so, and destroying things gives you a bonus. 

A large selection of vehicles, weaponry and enemies ensures that there is a lot for you to choose from, with every piece of gear you pick having its use and using your gear well is usually the key to success. But with all that gear, you can pick and choose how you want to play. Stealth, guns blazing, or a mix is all possible with none of the weapons seeming overpowered or underpowered. And everything you see ingame is a thing you can take and use.

The only negative I've found was the control scheme, which doesn't always work well with every vehicle. But it is barely a negative as you can change your control scheme as needed. Out of all the things in game, everything works together amazingly well and handles great, both in the missions and with the overarching theme.

Brigador is one of those rare games where you do not regret any moment of your time playing it. Everything can be made to be the way you enjoy it the best while at the same time offering you challenges exactly the way you want them. It seems to do everything right and has no real negatives to it that I could find. Brigador tells you to enjoy yourself, and it gives you all the tools you need to do so.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359498', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1503035709}
review:
When I caught wind of Brigador being similar to one of my favorite classic games, Urban Strike (part of a great series of Strike games), I was immediately determined to pick it up.  Those games and their gameplay were some of my favorite on my Sega Genesis as a kid.  While Brigador isn’t exactly like those games, it gave me just enough of a nostalgia trip to really get in to it and enjoy it's hearty gameplay.

[h1]Who is your Brigador and what does he do?[/h1]

Brigador: Up-Armored Edition is an updated version of the original game released in June of 2016 after eight months in Early Access.  The re-released update dropped in June of 2017 and added some missions to the campaign, updated the graphics, and did some rebalancing.  I had the pleasure of playing both since I got the game just before this update.  I can say that it is more appealing now than it was before, though even with the balance changes there can be some rough difficulty spikes that you will come across.  The core of the gameplay in the campaign is relatively simple.  You’ll grab one of the next missions in the group you’ve unlocked (usually three or four at a time), perhaps read the gist of what you’ll be doing and why, select one of the four pre-established vehicles, and head in to blow up nearly everything in sight.  The vehicles come in a large variety.  There are tanks and wheeled vehicles, hovertanks, and bipedal mechs, all of which range in size from tiny you lose them on screen to fairly larger and slow to maneuver.  These are each outfitted with a unique loadout of weapons and abilities that can be better or worse suited for the type of missions you encounter.  However, the campaign is designed to have you replay missions as many times as you want and receive marks for beating it in each provided vehicle.  Going through it the first time I gravitated toward the larger and more heavily armed and armored vehicles in most situations because that’s the playstyle I like, however I could see how the faster and more stealthy vehicles could work very well too if you practiced with them.

Once in the mission, you’ll have a list of your objectives in the top corner and little else guiding you through except some icons along the edges of you screen indicating the direction of the objectives.  You can move through at your own pace on your own path, or just carve it out of the destructible level.  Vehicles and buildings will crumble and explode at the whim of your mouse clicks.  Enemies vary just as much as your choice in vehicles from small and super-fast to much larger than anything you can pilot and equally slow.  Their firepower can be just as diverse.  Dispatching them may take a sweep of your machine gun or have you running around dodging their shots as you pick them apart.  Objectives are simple at best, usually requiring you to either blow up certain buildings or special vehicles, or just wiping out 70% of the enemies on the map (and sometimes both).  However, the unique design of each map makes it much less repetitive than such a limited set of objectives would indicate.  Plus, the real challenge comes to the surface when you have to manage both the health of your vehicle along with its  ammo that runs out several times a mission, requiring you to salvage ammo pickups from not-completely-destroyed enemies or finding the handful of ammo depots with limited supply.  The raw carnage and combination of action and tactical efforts from the player really define the beginning and end of what makes Brigador so fun.

[h1]What else is going on?[/h1]

Well, there’s a metric ton of story lore in the game.  There’s a tiny bit presented in the campaign, but the majority is unlocked via the money that you earn for each mission.  This money has no effect on the campaign itself as far as I can tell, but you earn a great deal going through the missions.  You can spend it on unlocking tons of in-game content including vehicle and enemy descriptions, story elements of all sorts including information about the factions involved, freelance mission items that include vehicles, vehicle pilots with varying mission modifiers, and equipment for those vehicles.  This leaves a pretty robust amount of gameplay even after you finish the campaign that, if you wanted to complete fully with all vehicles would take many hours beyond the four-plus I used to run through it once each.  The lore and descriptions you can unlock weave a giant web of story content that is entirely optional to the player, but it seems to be something the developers put a lot of effort in to.  There’s even an audio book included with the Deluxe edition, which I think I received just for having the game before it re-released.  Also included in that Deluxe edition is a great soundtrack of perfectly crafted synthwave music that meshes with the explosive gameplay surprisingly well.  It’s very prominent, so if it’s not a type of music you’re in to, you’re going to have to turn it off entirely.  However, for me it was great and I left its pumping beats and 80s aesthetic going strong the whole way through.

[h1]So did anything suck?[/h1]

There were a few smaller issues and some larger ones that really had me drinking the rageahol.  The health system in Brigador has you maintaining both your standard health and a shield that can be recharged by enemy drops.  However, your normal health can’t be fixed by anything in a mission.  This isn’t a problem in most missions that are relatively short an simple, but some missions are a bit longer and any encounter with a lot of enemies can wear your non-reparable health down, making a small mistake force you to restart.  On top of that, shield drops disappear after a period.  This means that if you’re working with long range weapons or slow moving vehicles, a large firefight may have you missing out on the lifeblood you need to keep going.  Another small issue is that you have to learn about the environments in a bit of a trial by fire.  Some buildings will explode killing you instantly if you run into them or destroy them from too close.  It can be difficult to distinguish these and result in an unexpected and frustrating death.  They could easily be marked in an more obvious way, but they often blend in too well.  The most annoying thing I encountered was the difficulty spikes.  Some missions would be many times harder than missions before or after.  I played through one probably 15 or 20 times as it had you starting with no ammo and dodging insta-kill suicide enemies to get to the ammo depots.  In addition, the final optional campaign mission is significantly longer than previous ones and trying to maintain health during it is nearly impossible with what vehicles are supplied.  If this is the rebalanced version, I’d hate to have seen what some of these later missions were like before that.

[h1]Recommendation?[/h1]

This really is a good game and I would suggest getting it for $10 or less as it has been (and currently is on GOG) under that price.  While it may lack some of the things that I really enjoyed about those old Strike games, it does have some solid mechanics that the player can improve and master throughout the tons of replayability provided.  Fans of the whole ‘you against the world’ concept in games, where you’re mowing down enemies like a badass, will definitely find this appealing.

If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/EndyoGaming#curation

author: {'steamid': '76561198387405677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2444, 'last_played': 1502144513}
review:
[h1] Summary	[/h1]

Brigador is a game where you pilot variest styles of tanks, hovercrafts. Blow up buildings, crush units, meaninglessly kill everything with a pulse and get rewarded for doing it.

[h1] Positive [/h1]

Serves as an excelent "I need to kill 10 minutes" kind of game.

Very simple to understand, brings a new meaning to pick up and play.

Surprisingly addictive.

Freelance mode is by far more enjoyable than the campaign mode

[h1] Negative [/h1]

UI is a "bit" of an eye-sore to look at and navigate.

Campaign missions get rather repetative and feels like you're doing the same thing over and over again (because you are doing the same thing over and over again)

Even Freelance mode gets rather repetative, this is a game best played in short spurts rather than long marathon sessions.

Not exactly visually pleasing.

[h1] TLDR [/h1]

Game is moderatly enjoyable however the UI is awful to navigate, the missions are boring and repetative and there isn't really much drawing me back into replaying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007813436', 'num_games_owned': 1276, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 463, 'last_played': 1693230329}
review:
Brilliant game. 

If the price of the game is under 15$, I'd personally say it's worth it.
This is an isometric, tiled game which only has the destruction part of Blast Corps(n64).
(You are a mech in the middle of a city, killing and crushing people and destroying their homes and power plants)
So it has an old style to it, which seems to be appreciated by most.

The campaign has a nice, not annoying tutorial, which not only teaches you the dirty way but you get to keep all your earnings and spend it in freelance mode. I believe if you play the entire campaign, you can get enough dough to buy some of the best available. 

In freelance, you can buy a pilot, a vehicle, weapons and missions (and lore; intel but w/e)
Here's one of the brilliant part of the game.. The biggest, baddest vehicles are worth the least and the smallest, weakest vehicles are worth the most. Why? Because each vehicle has a payout modifier, wanna make it hard on yourself but earn three times more than anyone else? Use the tiniest vehicle. Wanna wreck havoc or get through a long and hard series of missions? Use a big bad vehicle and tear the place apart.

Pilots also get to have such modifiers but I first need to explain missions (Operations as they are called in-game).
Operations are basically a series of missions, smallest being a series of 2 but can get up to a whopping 39!
You have to be careful though, as your vehicle does not repair itself nor rearm itself between missions.
During each missions, you have a set of main objectives and a set of optional objectives (They're all about killing and destruction). You can end the current mission after completing at least one main objective, or you can stay and complete the level to gain more money. As you finish the entire operation, the money you've earned will be multiplied by some factors, such as the type of vehicle and pilot you've used.

And that brings us to the pilots. 
Here's what the pilot named "Phil Bromlin" has for stats:

[table]
[tr]
[th]Stat[/th]
[th]Value[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Start Difficulty[/td]
[td]1[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Max Difficulty[/td]
[td]7[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Increase per Level[/td]
[td]0.50[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Victory Bonus[/td]
[td]$25'000[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Min Payout Multiplier[/td]
[td]1.0[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Max Payout Multiplier[/td]
[td]2.6[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

Let's say you're playing an operation that has 5 districts(missions).
The difficulty and the payout multiplier will grow by 0.50 per district.
Meaning by the fifth mission, you'll be at 3 difficulty level and 2.6 of payout (since it's the max).

So you really want to buy better pilots and better operations, so you can make more money and eventually try to beat the hardest missions the game can throw at you.
There's 38 pilots to hire, 63 vehicles and 44 weapons to purchase.
The vehicles are divided by 3 factions (Loyalist, Corvid, Spacer) and 3 vehicle types (Mech, Tank, Agrav(floating vehicles)).
Beyond that, you'll have to see for yourself.
