review:
Brigador has a very unique style and has a retro-like feel. It was a fun game to play for a lazy weekend. 

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
[list]
[*]Unique, but pretty good looking
[*]Really manages to set a cool, futuristic and rebellious ambience
[*]Each machine plays vastly different and there is a big arsenal of weapons
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Controls take some getting used to
[*]I'm missing voice acting and/or video's to further pull me into the story. It's a lot of reading now
[*]The story is a bit confusing in the beginning
[*]It becomes a little dull after a while. "Drive into base, destroy target, get out".
[/list]

I would recommend it when it's on sale or something. Not the best game ever but fun to play nonetheless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064997740', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 19, 'playtime_at_review': 1594, 'last_played': 1712178297}
review:
Amazing. Simply Amazing.

This is a stunning and immersive experience. The atmosphere and the music and the lighting bury you in the Brigador universe and keep you thinking about this game and the world it lives in when you're not playing it. The story and lore are surprisingly deep and interesting, game play is a blast, the soundtrack is powerful and moving, great replayability, great devs still adding new content. I've had this game for quite a while and seen it go through some changes and they've just been improvement after improvement. Worth every penny even when not on sale. The controls can be a bit wonky at first but by the end of the campaign (which isnt much compared to freelance mode) I was a master of movement with all the vehicle types. It reminds me most of a cross between command and conquer and mechwarrior, two of my favorite games as a child consequently. ( might not be the msot accurate comparison but it's what comes to mind forme. I love this game and can notsay enough good about it or the devs. Also highly recommend the book. (Ebook or audiobook) I keep going back to listen to it evey few months.

Long story short: Buy this game, you will not regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126033857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1284, 'last_played': 1703631257}
review:
If you think you'd enjoy strapping a gatling mortar and a dumbfire rocket pod to a flying Camaro, turning a 10-story tall robot invisible, or leveling a city blocks with canisters of corrosive gas, BUY THIS GAME. 

Seriously, though, it's a well-made top-down shooter with an incredible degree of loadout customization, an interesting approach to difficulty (the toughness of a level is dependent on the notoriety of the pilot you play as), and an acquisitions database which tells the game's story by talking about the events surrounding the creation and deployment of various weapons and vehicles. There's strategy, there's action, there's some awesome music, and the audiobook ain't half-bad, either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094792832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1674945359}
review:
Un très bon jeu habillé "à l'ancienne" mais avec les avantages de la modernité.

La maniabilité est très bonne : différents modèles de contrôles sont possibles types char-mech-aeroglisseur (il possible de mettre un controle "type char" pour tout les véhicules, donc une fois votre type préféré trouvé c'est parfait), les touches sont paramètrables sans problèmes.

Sur l'aspect artistique c'est très tranché et jusqu'au boutiste dans l'ambiance néon-rétro 90's, faut aimer.

Le tuto est assez bien fait et donne les bases. 

La campagne semble assez longue et la difficulté bien dosée.

Bonne diversité d'armes et de véhicules disponibles pour les escarmouches, chacun devrait y trouver son compte.

En résumé si vous aimez les méchas et les chars, la musique electro rétro, les années 90 ET tout exploser sur votre passage vous devriez passer un bon moment !

review: Great game. The controls are smooth, the oldstyle 2D visuals are gorgeously drawn and animated, and the music sets the mood perfectly for this dystopian retro scifi masterpiece. The best thing about this game, and the aspect that gives it so much replayability, is the great variety of suits and weapons to choose from. You can pilot anything from a several stories tall walking extermination machine with dual 30mm Gatling cannons to a literal fucking autorickshaw that blows up in one hit. My favorite though is the flying cholo mobile. The weapons are off the chain, too. The Ploughman, for instance, would surely be banned by the Geneva convention. It fires a salvo of rockets loaded with toxic chemicals that generates a death cloud that destroys nearly anything within seconds. Oh yeah, and EVERYTHING is destructible. Buy it, destroy, have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006563527', 'num_games_owned': 3471, 'num_reviews': 909, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1561060019}
review:
Brigador ist ein 2D (isometrische Ansicht) Actionspiel mit "Mechs". Brigador versucht sich im rauhen Alltag des Söldner-"Mechpiloten", wobei es auch eine ganze Reihe anderer Fahrzeugtypen gibt. Trotzdem erinnert das Spiel an die Söldnermissionen der frühen Battletechspiele. Im Katalog wählen wir aus, schalten frei, kaufen. Im Freelancemodus spielen wir dann die Missionen. Die Kampagne erscheint mir nur Beiwerk. In einiger Hinsicht zeigt das Spiel in meinen Augen gewisse Story/Atmosphäre-Schwächen: Es fehlt mir an Story, an Zwischensequenzen, an "lebendiger" Hintergrundwelt. Es spielt sich meiner Ansicht nach daher etwas "blutleer" bzw. "trocken". Auf der anderen Seite haben wir im Freelance-Modus schöne große Level in denen wir alles zu Klump und Asche ballern und stampfen können. Das macht Laune. Die Effekte sehen anständig aus, die Level mit den Gebäuden, Fahrzeugen und Zivilisten erinnern vage an den Klassiker Syndicate. Einige Punkte in dem Spiel finde ich übertrieben bzw. sinnlos wie die Auswertung mit der Zerstörung und den Opferzahlen. Die Standard-Steuerung mit Maus und Tastatur ist etwas krampfig, gerade bei Kettenfahrzeugen. Alles in allem ist Brigador ein ganz anständiges Geballer für Zwischendurch, das mir aber zu oberflächlich und zu schwach überzeugend in der Atmosphäre wirkt um über längeren Zeitraum viel Spass am Spiel zu haben. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TkreWLAiYIk

author: {'steamid': '76561198027446195', 'num_games_owned': 1779, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 3557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1709072991}
review:
[h1]Welcome, Brigador[/h1]

Do you miss the good old days of Mechwarrior: Mercenaries where you can just dive in and wreck things, and generally cause all sorts of mayhem in all kinds of machines? Well, this is that kind of game. And with the lovely isometric art style and retrowave tunes to blow crap up to. But if Retrowave isn't your style, then you can always turn down the music and listen to classical music in a different music player otherwise. Whatever works for you.

Much like in MW: Mercs, Instant Action, or Freelancer Mode in this case, is probably gonna get the most attention from you. Campaign is nice and all, but if you want to flatten cities, ground spaceports, and make necropolii deader than dead, then be a Freelancer, choose your pilot, your vehichle (from titanic mechs, tanks, and floating cars, to battle suits and a dinky little moped or 3-wheeler (for 10x the pay, and with good reason too; probably some of the most fun, and definitely worth the 10M to unlock.), how you want to be armed (relative to what the vehicle is limited to carrying), and a special ability to further aid you, and choose your mission, and go nuts. The greater the challenge, the greater the profits.

The world is your sandbox, and you're armed with all kinds of fireworks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961161813', 'num_games_owned': 640, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1513487565}
review:
Brigador brings out the best pixel destruction I think I've seen. The game is all about blowing everything the hecks up and it's a total great time doing it. 

Each vehicle type offers a unique gameplay style, and I found the hulking mechs and the smaller "speeder hover craft" type vehicles my personal favorite.

Objectives are pretty straight forward, and how much stuff you blow up to accomplish them are totally up to you. There's loads of side objectives, always involving blowing more stuff up.

Honestly the only weakness I could find was that the games UI for purchasing new items, tanks, etc. is very rigid and a bit confusing when you first start out.

Also, the game name doesn't befit the amount of destruction involved here. The game should really be called "Destruction McDestructo BlowingUp Desctructionator" (or something along those lines).

Great fun, easy to play - Totally recommend for a light weight arcade game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966287779', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1500774238}
review:
As a piece of art, as an exhibition of neon-techno-giant-mech-destroying-buildings aesthetic, Brigador is pretty fabulous. There's no denying the sound, art, writing come together as a cohesive whole. But as a piece of design, as a game meant to be played, it leaves a lot to be desired.

I played long enough to beat the campaign and to give the more open-ended Freelance mode a couple whirls, and I kept waiting for the game to hook me. I tried playing with the biggest mechs with the best weapons and destroying everything in sight. I tried playing with the smaller vehicles, ones that required more strategy and were more difficult. I tried completing every side objective on a map. I tried speed-running through them instead. Didn't matter. The game never felt compelling. It never felt more than a superficial, mildly entertaining romp through rectangular districts that mostly look the same.

There's a lot of design approaches a game can take to hook the player and while Brigador dabbles in some of them, none of them were implemented well enough to draw me in:

-A game can hook by providing interesting characters with character arcs (like the Telltale Games). There are no characters in Brigador and certainly no character arcs.

-A game can hook by providing an interesting plot / environment with mysteries to uncover (like Bioshock). The plot here is paper-thin. You get summaries before each mission, but they're only providing an explanation of the objectives. Basically you're a mercenary who blows stuff up because some text told you to. There's no sense of progress, no meaningful advancement of story.

-A game can hook by providing a meaningful challenge (like Dark Souls). Difficulty in Brigador is problematic, as it primarily comes from willfully choosing poor tools for the job. For example, in a given campaign map, you can choose a massive mech with double lasers that can take a lot of punishment or you can choose a tiny sniper mech that is easily destroyed. Some people enjoy this - and I think these people may appreciate the options Brigador provides. I do not. I love difficulty - but I love difficulty that the game provides, not that I must generate by willfully making poor choices or placing arbitrary restrictions on myself.

-A game can hook by providing stat / gear / unlock progression (like Diablo 3). Brigador's open-ended Freelance method provides an extensive list of things to unlock, including new weapons, mechs, & pilots. While the pilots represent difficulty options and don't otherwise affect gameplay, the weapons all felt unique and interesting, an excellent feat given how many there are. Unfortunately, the campaign has NO progression. For each map, you're provided a couple pre-made loadouts and that's that.

-A game can hook by providing exploratory elements, such as new environments, hidden collectibles, bigger and scarier opponents, etc. There is some variety in the level design - rural vs. junk city vs. regular city - but none of it ever really *pops.* Same with unit design. You do eventually encounter some larger mechs but it's genuinely kind of hard to tell the difference because the game is so dark and zoomed out. It desperately needed paint jobs, decals, etc on the mechs, to distinguish them from each other. Even the three factions are remarkably similar. Furthermore, there are no hidden collectibles, no secret bosses, none of that. In fact, there are no bosses at all, which seems a wasted opportunity.

Ultimately, the game isn't compelling. This is unfortunate as it clearly has some excellent elements. I personally would love to play a Brigador 2 that bothered to create a compelling story with interesting characters; with levels that had unique & clear design (rather than the randomly generated feel they all have now); with an intelligent progression from small mechs and weak weapons to large mechs and powerful weapons. Maybe even some multiplayer elements, like horde defense co-op, CTF, etc. That game would be frikkin awesome. Unfortunately, Brigador is not that game.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197993971751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1687025665}
review:
Brigador is an isometric shooter, very much drawing on oldschool themes.

There's a fair bit of reading you can do if you're interested in the fluff, but that's entirely optional and the gameplay itself is very simply blowing someone/something up and then leaving the area.

The gameplay itself is excellent, the music and sound is great, and the artstyle is very well done.

The vehicles and weapons also have a significant amount of weight and oomph to them, which makes them feel very satisfying to use.

The only nitpicks I can really point out are the following:

Repetition can happen after playing a while, however, there are significant amounts of missions, vehicles and weapons to keep this in check. Again, it's an isometric shooter, so I'm not sure if I should even bother bringing this up or not, but now you're aware of it if you weren't before.

The music does not seem to have any sort of playlist or loop, so what this means is that if you're taking your time in a mission you will hear one track play to the end from the start of the game and then play the rest of the level in silence, which is actually a bummer since the game has very nice music that adds to the experience. This may simply be a bug I've been unlucky enough to encounter, however.

Overall, one of the best isometric shooters I've ever played, and it's a shame that the game did not sell enough copies to warrant major DLC. (As stated by the devs themselves)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998242045', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1511610734}
review:
This is a totally great game.

Three massive points about it:

1.) You can completely customise the difficulty. Want to destroy everything with a giant mech with overpowered weapons? You can do that. Or you can take a medium mech and have to be more tactical. Or you can take a tiny antigrav tank and zip around. Or you can fight in a paper armoured battle suit. It's incredibly customisable.

2.)  The combat is simple, but incredibly fun. You only have 2 weapons and a special ability, but the massive amount of different weapon types means that every single round can play differently.

3.) Incredible value for money. For a single player game, you can sink hours and hours into it. Reminds me of the game FTL in that way, where you can just keep playing for ages. The difference is that this isn't a randomly generated campaign, you actually have a whole scripted campaign and another mode called Freelance that you can work through. With all the options, you could get a hundred hours out of this game easy.


Overall, a true gem of a game, obviously made by people who cared about it. Great background music, great "lore" that you can unlock, and if you buy the special edition you also get all the music and an audiobook to listen to as well. 

Really, really good game, and incredibly value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968497699', 'num_games_owned': 965, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4291, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1683091435}
review:
Warcrimes, retrowave, human balut, Johnny Five-Aces, what's not to like about this game? 

More seriously, the Up-Armored Edition adds a more comprehensive tutorial as a series of introductory missions to help new Brigadors find their footing, as well as screen absolute controls (to make it control like a twin-stick shooter) and the ability to adjust the game speed. Tanks, wheeled vehicles and walkers are best controlled using the relative scheme (up drives in the direction your vehicle/legs are pointing, left/right turn, etc) while Agravs benefit enormously from absolute (up moves you up, down moves you down) controls.

Don't let early deaths dishearten you, especially in the campaign. There's a reason you signed a death waiver. Try a different loadout, try approaching from a different angle, try slowing the game down and easing into your preferred speed setting, try different control schemes. Once you get comfortable, you'll be committing warcrimes with the best of us.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968598435', 'num_games_owned': 2383, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 2439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1610398684}
review:
Yes, this is a very good robot stompy city game. Everything is destructable except for the outer walls, with weapons or by just crushing it underfoot. There's a variety of vehicles and weapons from different kinds of machine guns to heavy cannons to gauss rifles and lasers - even artillery, rockets and acid canisters. You can pilot (almost) every vehicle in the game including mechs, ground vehicles and antigravity vehicles.

At first I wasn't too impressed by Brigador - sure, the campaign missions were a bit fun if a little too challenging, but after getting through them all I just didn't feel like the game was worth it... Then I tried freelance and it was horribly boring because it was too easy -  I didn't understand how to buy things, pilot difficulty or how map progression worked. After buying a difficult pilot, some good gear/vehicles and a decently long (5) mapset I now totally get it and it's fun!

The customization is simple but kind of neat. All the weapons in the game have a class like "heavy" "main" "turret" or "small". Ammo used is independent of type. Every vehicle gets exactly two mounts of these kinds in addition to varying movement and durablility. So customization is a matter of: pick pilot - pick vehicle - pick 1st weapon - pick 2nd weapon - pick defensive system - go. It's very simple but with tons of different combinations, which I appreciate.

I can't resist comparing freelance mode to a roguelike even though it totally isn't one. You have to complete at least one objective on every map before you can exit to the next one. Your health and ammo carry over. Eventually you can extract at the spaceport, and you only get a good payout if you survive. So there's a (short) permadeath aspect as well as a resource management and risk/reward to consider.

Overall, I was regretting buying this a little but it grew on me and now I'm happy I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964195220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1565610275}
review:
I saw a self described "Roguelite" in my humble bundle, and remembering  the first time I saw Dredmor (I was unimpressed at best), it was the first key from that bundle I tested.

Well, it may be no  Dungeons of Dredmor, but it kicked down the door to my heart anyway.

Well I suppose I should actually say something about the game.

Apparently there is a story mode, i think i played that for a bit but when i found freelance mode i had a good laugh about the campaign and decided to stop being daft and just kill shit, but I did enjoy it.

The Premise of freelance is, how much shit do you want to break, and how mad do you want these guys to be about it.

From here the rogue elements are presented as scaling dificultys, loadout based combat, and the ever so important factor no matter how superficial, it has charm by the barrel. A seemingly basic and benign game quickly becomes a "you fucked up" simulater, and the game is very damnd aware of this, mixing dialogue and imagary to build charecter.

What I really mean is the back story and charecter arcs are tightly developed and don't stand in the path of your destruction, if you weren't interested in reading charecter bio's before you might be tempted after seeing their portrait, its as animated as a still image gets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048422220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1597, 'last_played': 1610250616}
review:
== GAMEPLAY (The mechanical part of the game) ==
You walk around in your mech, tank, or antigrav vehicle and destroy the marked objectives in the map, and you have two weapons and an active ability. In Campign mode, these are chosen for you, but you can choose your own loadout in Freelance mode. Different weapons behave differently against buildings, enemy shields and hull, and different vehicles behave differently to enemy fire and terrain types. This gives the player some things to consider both when choosing their loadout or making tactical decissions in battle. The game is more tactical than anything, since choosing in what order you deal with enemies, how you position yourself, and when you use your active ability is more important to survival than how you use your weapons. Weapons, however, do behave differently mechanically, some weapons have travel speed and others are more of "hitscan" weapons, most shoot in a straight line down to the ground, but others fire like a shotgun spread, or even high-arch projectiles.
6/10 - Good

== AESTHETICS (The audiovisual presentation of the game) ==
If you've heard about this game before, you must have heard about the soundtrack. Have the studio chosen some usual orchestral or rock music, the game could've felt cheap and uninteresting. The original synthwave soundtrack by one of the best artists in the genere, Makeup and Vanity Set (and some others since the Up-Armored update) ultimately gives the game a unique ambient and soul. The graphics are a love letter to 90s to early 2000s isometric sci-fi games. The player and enemy vehicles are 2D sprites with 64 different angles pre-rendered from 3D models with normal maps cooked in for interaction with the game's lighting effects, which give the finishing touch to the cyberpunk setting of the game. The game easily runs at 60FPS, but the pre-made animations for mechs and enemies have a very low ammount of frames. This deliberate choice, along with the semi-uncanny valley illustrations for pilot portraits, give off a very classic and somewhat unsettling feeling to the game, similar to some of Scott Cawthon's (creator of FNAF) earlier works (see: The Desolate Hope).
10/10 - Masterpiece

== CHALLENGE (The thought put into the challenges the game gives to the player) ==
The game gives a lot of opportunity for the player to tweak the difficulty of the game. First, the game speed setting: the player is allowed to change the speed of both themselves and the enemies (from 50% to 100% speed, set to 80% by default). Then there's the pilots: as the player progresses, they can unlock new pilots, and each of them is essentially a different combination of payout and difficulty modifiers, form one that makes it so that no enemies will ever spawn to get only a tenth of the pay, to pilots locked into the highest difficulties at all times in exchange for some big buck, even ones that will start at a low difficulty and gradually increase for each sector cleared, a sector being one of the different levels in each mission. Loadout choice also goes into play: some weapons have a low ammo capacity but deal very high damage (like lasers and explosives), others have a high ammo capacity and high fire rate in exchange for low damage per bullet (like gatling guns and turret guns), which can make ammo management (a very important part of the game) easier. Finally there's vehicle choice: bigger vehicles are louder, but more resilient, while smaller ones are more silent, but fragile. Each vehicle has a different combination of factors to consider: movement speed, movement acceleration, aiming speed, turning speed, hull, shields, temporary shields (an extra shield that fades out over time), etc. Some vehicles are even at a direct disadvantage to others or pose a higher risk to the player, but compensate it by giving an extra payout when the mission is done. It's a big mish-mash of ways to tweak the game to your liking.
Perfect - 9/10

== FINAL SCORE ==
8/10 - Excellent

author: {'steamid': '76561197996587952', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1499276133}
review:
Wow, I don't really understand the critical acclaim that comes with this game. Here are my pros/cons:

Pros:
-Combat is satisfying
-There is customization

Cons:
-combat starts to get stale/tedious after a few hours.
-customization is only available in freelance mode, less than half the length of the main storyline.
-maybe i need to practice, but small, light mechs just kind of generally suck. Going up against large clusters of enemies is nigh impossible
-visuals and soundtrack are really not that impressive. Feels like a sega genesis game.
-repetitive missions. Destroy this structure. Kill this target. Rinse, repeat.
-lore must be purchased with in game currency. It is not really a part of the campaign. This forces me to buy weapons/mechs or lore that consists of text files. The choice is clear for me.
-the mission briefings literally do not make sense. I guess they expect us to read the lore that must be purchased beforehand.
-if you want to complete all objectives in a mission, you will spend more time walking around than actually fighting things.

Neutral/other:
-encourages you to kill innocent civillians by paying you extra.
-all the pilot portraits have really dumb looks on their faces. Why did they think this was a good idea???

Just skip this one... if you want a 2D action game, play hyper light drifter instead. If your heart is set on a mech game like mine was, just go get a ps/ps2 emulator and (re)play the armored core series.

review:
95% Overwhelmingly Positive rating at the time of this posting, and after playing, I can see why it's well earned.  The game is gritty and reminiscent of an older super nintendo style top-down game, but the mechs and mechanics are so well done it keeps it fun and engaging.  There's way more depth to this than the videos do justice to it.  

I'm not a huge fan of retro style games, so I was really on the fence if I'd like this game or not.  The gameplay itself is just fun enough, the maps are erlatively small so far to keep the action moving, and they did a good job building lore into it if that's your thing.  

Plus, you literally can destroy everything but the walls confining the maps.  What's not to like?

review:
目前只玩了前十关，感觉是个相当不错的机甲题材游戏。简单写写目前的感受

优点：
* 操作容易上手，典型的双摇杆射击游戏。不过与普通双摇杆射击游戏的区别是加了射击线与弹着点。感觉还是挺配机甲的。

缺点：

暂时先写这么多，等玩玩再更新。

author: {'steamid': '76561197981197420', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1535133291}
review:
Brigador is great. I came to the game with the expectation of giant stompy robots, but it ended up being a general vehicular mayhem simulator of the highest degree. A large campaign acts as a delivery mechanism for training and challenge missions, but the Freelance mode offers you large, open-ended "runs" to test your mettle with whatever configurations you can cook up, and is arguably the more compelling game mode once you have the basics down.

It's a skill-based game - weapons have distinct firing arcs based on their properties and where they're mounted on your vehicle as well as different colour-coded ammo types, and vehicle facing is important to mitigate how much damage you take. The controls are nonetheless simple enough to get the hang of with a bit of training, but learning to operate vehicles with finesse will take time and practice (which is exactly what I'm looking for in this sort of game).

Special note of the fact that once you're on a map, the game lets go of your hand and you're on your own. Brigador presents your objectives, and its up to you *how* you complete them, or whether you can complete them at all. Several side-objectives let you influence the map in interesting ways too (as well as earning more filthy lucre). Coming up with priorities for what objectives you can actually afford to complete (or end up HAVING to complete due to your actions) lends a nice layer of strategy to what would otherwise be frivolous stompenshoot. The fact that you can destroy literally anything on the map to carve your own path through is not only fun, but useful given the open-ended nature of the maps.

Two minor complaints would be that it's not always terribly clear when you're taking damage or where from, and your firing arcs don't indicate when they're obstructed by terrain, meaning that you may inadvertently waste a lot of ammo demolishing walls instead of your foes. It's also not always clear which Freelance runs you've previously completed. These are minor issues, though, and don't overwhelmingly detract from the game.

If any of this sounds appealing, buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991227587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1623342501}
review:
tl;dr: tons of content and customizability to blow shit up over and over again in a game that drips with STYYYLEEEE, but the gameplay can get repetitive, since the goal of every level is to just blow shit up, shit being an enemy unit or a building. it's really fun to blow stuff up tho

This is a really good game that needs more attention because it's just ass-rippingly awesome. It has great atmoshpere, thanks to the amazing soundtrack (which comes included in the Up-Armored Edition, highly recommended if you're into John Carpenter's music), the cyberpunkish theme, story and the presentation in general (the naming of things like vehicles and weapons and the story together are just fucking cool). 
The controls are tight, there's tons and tons of variability of the difficulty and the gameplay, thanks to different pilots, vehicles and weapons that you can unlock. It's worth mentioning that the game also has all the options to need to customize the way you want it to play, going as far as different settings for different kind of types of vehicles, setting the game's speed and support for controllers. There's plenty of content to support the customizability, there's different types of weapons, vehicles and many-many levels to try out. You can also randomize your loadout. For example, you can get a giant heavy mech with a big ass artillery gun that levels whole city blocks with a single shot or get a tiny hoverbike that you can use to zip around the enemy if you're crazy enough.
Speaking of trying stuff out, the campaign is a must play and not just because the first couple of levels are the tutorials about the game's mechanics. It ramps up nicely and introduces new stuff step-by-step and most importantly after the tutorial levels end, you have the ability to choose from 3 or 4 types of predefined vehicles to play the levels through, which helped me to discover fun combinations to play with in freelance mode.
And the freelance mode is where it gets a bit weak for me, but only because I dislike rougelikes. In both the campaign and freelance mode you play to earn more money to unlock more weapons, vehicles, pilots, levels and some lore about units and other stuff. So you do the same objectives over and over again on the levels to earn money to do it all over again, now with the stuff you unlocked. As I mention before there are tons and tons of stuff to unlock and the customizability of those unlocked stuff is more than you would ever want, the core gameplay is still the same. Enter the level, accomplish the same objectives by blowing them up and then exit the level. As much as I dislike rougelites (rougelikes even more), for me the presentation of the game made up for the repetitive natur of the game. For me it's really fun to play the game for a couple of levels and to just blow shit up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983493062', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1624762063}
review:
I was first intrigued by the graphics style; it reminds me of old Westwood RTS games like Red Alert 2 and Tiberian Sun, so it wins some nostalgia points from me. However, it is so much more beautiful than any of those games ever were. Just looking at the environments and mechs is a treat for me. There's some nice lighting that doesn't really affect gameplay, but it sure sets the right mood and has some nice light/dark contrasts. In addition, the game doesn't stutter for no reason like I've found some other smaller titles tend to do. 

Everything is destructible! Well, except for the level bounds. But everything can be reduced to a pile of rubble, and some vehicles can even use it as cover. (This surprised me.) This allows for some pretty interesting tactics, such as giant mechs crouching down to gain more protection and tiny mechs extending upwards to fire over things. You can have some ace pilot moments if you're getting swamped by enemies in urban areas, as every object has verticality and can block enemy line of sight on you, allowing you to flank a blob of enemies. (Or you can just shoot them through a high-rise with a railgun.)

Controls can feel slightly unresponsive, depending on which vehicles you're using, but it's a system to be mastered. Some vehicles move faster, have better turn radii, but when you get used to the slower ones, it's an absolute joy to perfectly swing your Abbot cannon around and peg an AGRAV zipping around you.

The soundtrack is about 50% of what's great about this game. The quality of the music can really make or break movies and games. Brigador's soundtrack makes the game. 

The only true complaint I have is that most of the pilot portraits are fugly. I never realized so many mercenaries were related to potatoes. Some of the potraits look a little off, can't quite put my finger on why.

Overall, I think this game is going to go down as a classic and I hope that Stellar Jockeys goes on to create more games matching this one's caliber. (Hint: make a strategy game using this game's isometric view and mechs plzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997601921', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1602557974}
review:
An absolutely brilliant game. If I had to summarize what Brigador is, I'd call it a mayhem simulator, where you rapidly and indiscriminately deliver death and destruction in bite-size portions, at high speed.

On the gameplay/difficulty spectrum, this game manages to be something I've spent a long time looking for. It has been a long while since anything has filled the role this game has.

Specifically, Brigador rewards thought and care in how you tackle combat situations, and is harsh in how it treats just walking in the front door--guns blazing. You'll however find that you never fail due to some inherint unfairness. When you lose, it's directly attributable to a mistake you made.

Of course, if you do find the game too hard or easy, it's endlessly tailorable in Freelance mode. Not only does Freelance add an enormous amount of content past the main campaign, it gives you a wide berth in choosing your preferred play-style. You'll find tons of options for your pilot, vehicle and equipment loadout. Every choice plays anywhere from slightly to massively different from the others, and Freelance mode rewards experimenting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025135104', 'num_games_owned': 3459, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1305, 'last_played': 1498357390}
review:
[h1]La trifulca de los días futuros[/h1]

Adquirí Brigador en un Humble Bundle mensual. Unos días después de añadirlo a mi librería, empecé a notar más titulares que hablaban del juego, de sus desarrolladores y el cambio de su suerte. Según la historia, Brigador es un proyecto que se negó a la tentación del kickstarter y después de varios años de desarrollo, logró la mayoría de sus propósitos; creo que el equipo de Stellar Jockeys hizo bien y que fueron sensatos, cautelosos, porque si no luego pasan cosas extrañas como con Chroma Squad.

Sin embargo, no lo niego, la apuesta fue demasiado arriesgada. Supongo que todavía lo es. Pocos juegos tienen desarrollos tan aventurados y felices como este.

Brigador es un juego de sprites isométrico donde rentas a tu piloto a una organización anarquista y manejas mechas, vehículos y tanques para destruir las ciudades de un gobierno autoritario. Hay una historia ahí, pero se construye a base de pocas certezas, bastantes rumores, sin dejar descansar al humor negro y la ironía, lo cual, personalmente, me parece un deleite. La mayoría de los pilotos son mercenarios y tiene un trasfondo entre trágico y cínico.

Estos pequeños fragmentos de historia van acorde con el entorno cyberpunk del juego y engalanan, dan una profundidad sabrosísima, a las ilustraciones de los pilotos (quienes asombran y hacen reír, o sonreír, porque mis preferidos son los que parecen luchadores de bar, aquellos que beben una chelita de más y malacopean para pronto entrarle a los madrazos). Al juego lo acompaña música de sintetizadores muy ochentera; ¿estamos cansados de este renacimiento de los ochenta el cual parece no tiene llenadera? Para nada, Brigador lo hace muy bien.

En cuanto al juego, puedes usar mouse y teclado o gamepad. Sospecho que el mouse y teclado son mejores, o más prácticos, para Brigador pero eventualmente logré configurar mi dual shock 4 para jugarlo cómodamente (importante: tienes que moverle a la configuración hasta que quede, si no, te frustrarás mucho).

Hay tres tipos de vehículos y cada uno tiene diversas opciones a configurar (armas y especiales): los mechas, automóviles y tanques, dependiendo de su tamaño y su movilidad, son más robustos o más ágiles, o quizás son tan débiles que son especiales para situaciones de sigilo y demandan juegos mejor planeados y estratégicos. Los desarrolladores no escatimaron recursos para probar diferentes tipos de vehículos y complacer a jugadores de distintos estilos de juego. Hay un modo campaña el cuál es de pilotos fijos y tiene entre tres o cuatro dificultades (o modos de juego, dependiendo), o bien, puedes jugar al freelancer y armar una serie de mapas continuos para probar una configuración personal y ver hasta dónde puedes llegar antes de morir o de llevarte el botín gordo.

El modo Freelancer es donde brilla el juego y donde pasarás más tiempo. En ambos modos, tanto la campaña como en el freelancing, los pilotos ganan y acumulan dinero que utilizarás para comprar más opciones: mapas, vehículos, pilotos, fragmentos de la historia o estrategias (un bestiario con los vehículos y las cosas que destruyes). Cada cosa, según la configuras, modifica este modo de juego. Los mapas, por ejemplo, entre más dinero inviertes en ellos, abren más zonas y secuencias a visitar. Los pilotos y los vehículos modifican la dificultad del mapa por cada zona vencida además de alterar el multiplicador de dinero. Por supuesto, puedes configurar este modo para escoger todos los atributos del azar y que esto sea una sorpresa o bien, puedes buscar y perfeccionar a tu Brigador con una configuración que te permita pasar las zonas más altas. Hay tantas combinaciones posibles que hay Brigador para rato.

Ojo: algunos vehículos, claro, están diseñados para ser verdaderas máquinas de la muerte, no sólo para los habitantes de Solo Nobre (el planeta que estás liberando) pero también para los propios pilotos. Entre más difícil de manejar sean los vehículos, más altos son los multiplicadores de dinero.

El diseño del juego me recuerda, brevemente, a un juego isométrico que jugué alguna vez: Syndicate. O quizás el primerísimo de los príncipes de Persia. Sí, bueno, pero actualizado a una calidad de 1080p. Las animaciones son fluidas, demasiado bien cuidadas, se nota un trabajo obsesivo, artístico. Reconocerás un placer extraño en apreciar los movimientos de los pequeños hombrecillo de gabardina amarilla a los que aplastas. Es palpable el esfuerzo por dar profundidad y diseño a los vehículos y sus texturas. Los escenarios y edificios recuerdan a los settings de otras obras cyberpunk o distópicas como Blade Runner, Akira o Max Headroom. Pero no sólo hay parques industriales, sucios, pero también hay suburbios y zonas de cultivo que contrastan perfectamente con lo anteriormente mencionado. De los retratos de los pilotos ya hablé antes, pero el realismo con el que están diseñados además de sus historias breves logran conectar con el jugador de la mejor manera: permiten que uno  complete los puntos e intuya las historias.

Lamentablemente el juego no tiene multijugador. Pero es perfecto en un sólo jugador para destruir ciudades en breves ráfagas casuales (de 20 a 30 minutos) o en largas sesiones de juego.

¿Lo recomiendo? Sí. Brigador es destrucción masiva con un diseño neón y retro. Sus modos de juego mantendrán despiertos a los luchadores y a los apostadores por igual.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002571976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1498593017}
review:
Let's cut the fluff, this is a strategy mech/tank war game. Don't expect a story line other than basic stuff to tell you what to do. You do missions, you get paid. You buy equipment. You do longer missions. You challenge yourself for longer and longer missions.

PROs:

Awesome 80's retro wave soundtrack
Awesome strategic mech/tank warfare gameplay with lots of combinations and approaches
Awesome isometric 3D/Pixel style art & graphics
Awesome action
Fast to play
Replayable
Challenging

CONs:

No story really; the campaign just teaches you how to play basically and earn money
Slightly slow load times between missions
No multiplayer

Worth it? Sure, if you like challenging strategy war games and tank battles. There is no perfect build or combination, it's all about how you like to do things, your strategy and how you approach the missions.

This is not for someone looking for a deep story line, meaningful missions, characters and dialog. This game is full of text and fluff but its in the Lore section and you play to unlock it and read about the background of the game. There is a minor story, it can be interesting, but it's not deep and not much to it. So understand this from the front. There are not movie sequences and endings. This is a non-stop mech/tank action strategy war game.

My favorite weapon: Konig

author: {'steamid': '76561197998105505', 'num_games_owned': 5215, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1498508239}
review:
Brigador is one of those games where there's not a whole lot of things you can really say about it, because of how straight forward it is. But that's not a bad thing.

Brigador brings back a style of isometric action games that we've not really seen in some time. If you've ever played the "strike" series (Desert Strike, Nuclear Strike and so on), or the slightly more obscure "Mass Destruction", you know roughly what type of game it is. You're unleashed on the world in a heavily armed vehicle, and your goal is to destroy things. Brigador is not a clone of those mentioned games though, and in most ways, it's a better game. If nothing else, it's a lot faster, and has more going on at all time.  
  
[B]Graphics & Sound[/B] 
The graphics in Brigador is clean, sharp & detailed. While not as technically advanced as many other modern games, Brigador does still look darn good, owing to a strong consistent art style. The screenshots are representative, that is what the game looks like. And while they might look a bit cluttered, it's usually not too hard to figure out what's going on on screen at any given moment. And yes, those are coloured lights that would make a late 90's 3D action game, like Forsaken, green with envy. Unlike those late 90's games, the use of coloured light does not end up feeling tacky though, it works.

Brigador is no slouch in the audio department either. The soundtrack fits well in with the 80's/early 90's style cyberpunk feel that the game has, and helps set the mood. All weapons have suitable sound effects that make them feel like they have some weight behind them, without feeling overbearing and obnoxious. Audio feedback is very important in a game like Brigador, and it nails it. 

[B]Gameplay[/B]
You're playing as an armoured vehicle, be it a tank, mech or some other vehicle outfitted with heavy weapons. And your goal is to cause as much destruction as you possibly can. Each level has its own set of objectives, that usually boil down to "kill X, Destroy Y, then escape", with secondary objectives that are similar in nature. It's all very straight forward, and the game does not really stray from this formula. Depending on if you're playing the campaign, or just randomly generated maps, you either have a set of 3-4 different vehicles to chose from, or you get to design your own from parts that you've unlocked. 
Exactly how you play will depend on your vehicle. Some are light and nippy, and need to always be on the move to avoid incoming projectiles, others are lumbering behemoths that can take a beating. And there's also a good variety in the weapons, with things like mortars, machine guns, heavy cannons, shotguns and so on making up the arsenal. So despite the games rather straight forward gameplay, the variety in playstyles between vehicles still make the game feel like it has a lot of variety. 
The game encourages you to play aggressively in most cases. Collateral damage is not just not punished, but even encouraged, as you'll get greater rewards the more things you end up destroying along the way. And destroying things in Brigador feels far more satisfying than it has any right to do. 

[B]Final Thoughts[/B]
Brigador is a great game. It's easy to pick up and play, and it's just darn fun. It might not be the deepest game on the market, but few games I've played match the sheer amount of fun I've had with Brigador. It's going to be one of those games that will stay on my HDD for a long time, and whenever I just feel like blowing stuff up, I'll start Brigador. So for anyone who's looking for a straight forward action game, I can't recommend Brigador enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997529945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 3846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1700660812}
review:
I knew I wanted to get it the moment I looked at it- the asethetic of the game is basically "Command and Conquer: Tiberian Sun" gets mooshed together with Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon's garish 80's gloss and plays like a isometric MechWarrior. These are all very positive things. From the get go it has an immediate personality in it's presentation that will suck you in, and the carnal combat within will get you hooked. 

So let's break it down.

PROS:
-----------------------------------------------
- Great visuals, unique presentation
- A loving amount of detail has gone into desiging the weird and wild technological machines at your disposal, from the actual visual designs to the variety of weapons and their functions, stats and even flavortext herein. If you like customizing a mech not unlike armored core or such, you're gonna have fun with this.
- Gleeful amount of destructibility in all maps. The world is your sandbox to topple over and stomp.
- Great soundtrack. I'll admit I'm not as into the overt 80's synth stuff as some people, but if you like that kind of music, this is grade A material for you up with the likes of Hotline Miami. 
-Surprisingly fleshed out world building in the descriptions of pilots, locations, weapons, mechs, etc. It's nothing groundbreaking in it's own right, but it provides quite a bit of grim flavoring to what is, at first glance, a seemingly simple game. 


CONS:
-----------------------------------------
-Loadtimes are juuust long enough and the actual missions juuust short enough to give some noticable speedbumps to what is otherwise a fast and addictive game. 

- The weapon trajectory beams and targeting reticule UI. They manage to do a lot with it that helps feed you immediate information on potential targets. However, the trajectory beams are so bright and colorful they wind up distracting you from the actual targeting reticule, making aiming a slapdash process in the middle of a raging firefight. It's something that I think ought to be tweaked, and a minor inconvience overall- nothing game breaking. 


TL;DR :
-------------------------------------------
Can't reccomend it to everyone, but if you love mechs, mayhem, or just enjoy some of that garish neon 80s dystopia, this is a fun distraction that deserves a bit more recognition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052999185', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1058, 'last_played': 1623175793}
review:
Works well on Linux even on somewhat dated hardware.  Gameplay is smooth and diverse.  Want to be an unstoppable killing machine? Go ahead, play a giant stack of cars with tracks under it that can be equiped with two anti-everything cannons.  Want to outsmart your opponents and be sneaky? Play a Tuktuk and go on a stealth operation where a single hit means the end of it all.  Want to joust large tanks with a short-ranged high damage weapon? I found the Tuktuk works for that too.  If you want to be more classy, go for the flying oldtimer instead.  Want to bulldoze through your enemies? Well... you can do that.  Want to stomp out enemies with a mech? You can do it.  My greatest issue would be that the description of the Treehouse promised me loud horns and the Keybind screen even offers a key to sound the horn but I can't hear it at all. I want to honk at them, damnit.

I also really like that the story is seperated from the actual gameplay, so it doesn't interject and slow down what I am doing.  Don't you hate it when you get all pumped up and then a 15 Minute cutscene starts before you are allowed to do anything?  Well, not in this game.  You want action, you can have action.  You want to read why you were fighting anyway?  You can read the story.

Also the graphics are very appealing if you like 2D isometric games.  So many nice details to look at.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001935699', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 11280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7188, 'last_played': 1625585244}
review:
You play as the BADGUY in this. It may become clear when you fire a railgun repeatedly through an apartment building you are using for cover. You may notice when you stomp through a suburban house just to surprise an enemy on the other side. Or maybe when you get the achievement for killing 10,000 civilians.

A very unique game! Isometric but not really 2D as you can shoot over scenery and even enemies. Each of your guns has a firing arc that fades out just short of where it will hit leaving the last bit to you. Each gun also has its own projectile speed so if you are moving and turning your arcs will cross and shift often landing far from each other. Imagine a two gun FPS with separate reticules that shift and change predictably based on your movement. I've never played anything like it.

It is a kind of stealth action hybrid. For instance you could be in direct combat with one enemy while maneuvering around scenery to keep another from seeing you. Each weapon has a distinct report and impact sound volume that will alert enemies which you should always use to your advantage. EVERYTHING is destructible so you can make a noise at the end of the block and then double around crashing through the buildings to get behind the distracted enemies. 

No direct story but full of atmosphere and lore.  Some of the descriptions for random guns have more involving stories than entire other games. It really grabbed me hard. The best deep gameplay I've played in a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971507240', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1498048105}
review:
Neon lights flashing, retro synthwave pumping, metal screaming. Pure intense mayhem. Brigador is an excellent isometric vehicular shooting game that brings the genre back, it is very similar to Bedlam and Bedlam 2: Absolute Bedlam from the '90s, and if those aren't familiar then let's say it's like the original Syndicate, but with mechs, tanks and hovercars.

A wide variety of freelance missions, that you can take on with a wide variety of destructive weaponry custom picked onto your vehicle of choice. Campaign missions are where you can try out a lot of pre-made vehicles with drivers that have their own styles of approaching the battlefield.

Gameplay is straight to the point, move through the destructible environments, the more you destroy the better, engage enemies either directly at the range of your weaponry, or use special abilities and equipment to flank them via stealth, there's a nice amount of playstyle variance. You and the enemies have more armor in the front, so flanking is good and so is keeping the enemy from flanking you. A bunch of different control schemes for you to find the most suitable, be it with keyboard+mouse or with a controller. You can also freely change the game speed to anywhere between 50% to 100%, so that acts as a difficulty slider, or simply putting the tempo of the action to what you find most comfortable. A neat feature.

There's a lot to love in this game, the only thing missing is a multiplayer mode, this would be an absolute blast with at least a 2-player co-op mode. Maybe if there's a sequel we'll get that.

Highly recommended for the top notch action and '80s-'90s retro looks and great music. This is a rare game because of the genre, especially since it's so well made and it's so awesome to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022003807', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1630197023}
review: Game doesn't really capture you, it's fine if all you want to do is blow everything up, but beyond that there's a lack of substance. Menus are a bit awkward and mission progression isn't explained. Aiming is a pain, you've got a cursor-thing but that's not necessarily where the bullets will land. The fact that you can't see any of the stats for a vehicle/weapon until after you've bought it is annoying. It takes a bit to figure out what will and won't immedately kill you in the level, but even then you won't catch them all the time (Gas stations are bad news). Controls are alright, a bit clunky at times though. Music gets old incredibly quickly. The game is so almost good, I want to like it, I really do, but I just can't unfortunately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110827146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1497936670}
review:
Picked up from the humble monthly bundle and decided to give it a shot. Looked fun at first but end the end turned out plain. Perhaps it was some expectation about picking up new guns as a skip from mission to mission but this doesn't seem to be the case. 

The story was boring and skipable. This game says its a roguelite but I don't see this in any way as campaign missions already give a selectable pilot and their mech. What disapoints me most is that there is a good core for a game but nothing in the execution really shines through. Just a game that you can turn your brain off and shoot everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985064110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1497994796}
review:
Picked it up at the humble monthly bundle. Was surprised and looked good.

Sadly, apart from the "destroy it all", there isn´t much going for this game. If you are looking for a "shut down your brain and depress both mouse buttons at the same time", then this game is for you.

The campaign story is unengaging and just a bad excuse for throwing another wave of enemies at you. Every map can be played with one of a small number of preconfigured pilots and their vehicles.

There is no upgrade path ( like more ammo or damage for the weapons you like, no upgrades to character or mech ) and the money you earn you can spend on stuff that there is no way of using. The UI is confusing and doesn´t explain what the bought stuff can be used for - because all that can be bought in the store is already readily available for use in the campaign.

Overall, not a terrible game - just unengaging. It feels like it´s missing the refining touches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051963799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 929, 'last_played': 1592356859}
review: Brigador is a beautiful isometric mech game that has some of the most well refined designs, traditional and new. In addition, the story and world, while a bit shrouded, are very engaging. The story is told in a similar manner to the Dark Souls series. The mechanics are all solid, although I would say it took me a good amount of time to get used to the controls for the hover vehicles, but if one has trouble with the controls, there is a game speed option, so I wouldn't qualify that as a downside, as they have ways to compensate for that. Overall, I can't really think of a reason to give this game less than a 10 out of 10, so I won't. Solid game, If you have the money, buy it, If it's on sale, definately buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049433567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1498217579}
review:
I received this game as part of a bundle and this review is not a comment on the list price of the game.
 
This is the type of game I would have loved as a kid, and I found myself engaged and intrigued by it playing it now. I have always loved mech games, and this game manages to brilliantly avoid the "same-iness" of some mech games by creating three distinct classes of mechs, mech, tank, hovercraft. The game does a great job in creating a sense of weight to your mechs, allowing you to crush a hilarious number of cars and civilians in early stages before introducing you to the mech vs mech combat that is the core of the gameplay. 
 
Unlike many indie games that have some novelty but no real depth in gameplay, or too much depth and no sense of novelty, this game brings you in softly and makes it feel like you are getting a better sense of the combat in the game without getting overwhelmed. 
 
NOTE: I found the game MUCH more enjoyable after remapping a few keys. While the game does support controller, I could not find settings that would let the right analog aim in the right position quickly enough. It is much better with mouse+keyboard, but I personally remapped the special weapon from middle mouse to Q. This configuration REALLY helped me not get so frustrated. I still kinda dislike having primary and alternate as left+right click, since so often you want to be holding down both simultaneously and I don't find that very comfortable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970891056', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1498310555}
review:
I got this game in the Humble Monthly Bundle and man was it a great little surprise when I actually took the time to try it out.

I'd like to call it a tactical isometric roguelike shoot'em up. While you control a single vehicle it kind of reminds me of Syndicate. Everything is destructible and this also plays into how you tackle opponents.

There are basically two modes; campaign and freelance. I haven't finished the whole campaign yet but missions so far have been varied and sometimes challenging. After the tutorial you can choose between three differents characters/vehicles which makes a large difference in many missions. The mission briefings also add background and builds up the dystopically satiric world of Solo Nombre through decent writing.

Freelance is the other mode which pretty much offers infinite replayability. There are a tons of unlockable weapons, missions, pilots and vehicles. These are unlocked by clearing either freelance or campaign missions for cash.

What makes the game actually great though is the actual gameplay and I find it hard to come up with anything to complain about. Controls are crisp, and vehicles actually handles very differently. Most weapons are immensely satisfying to use with great SFX and animations, and different loadouts excel at different tactics. Tying in to this is the destructible environments. Instead of rushing the enemy straight on you could for example make your own path, come in from behind and make a killshot to their vulnerable rear. You can also use smoke or cloaking to avoid enemies or combine it all with luring enemies with sound to set a trap.

When it comes to the art style I like it a lot. I would say it reminds me of old Amiga sci-fi/cyberpunk games. Pilot portraits are great with a zany quality and vehicle design is overall very good. The environments look like dystopian cyberpunk environments and serve their purpose of being levelled to the ground.

In closing I'd say that this game is a real little gem. It's perfect for picking up and playing for a short while if you feel that shooting itch most of us feel from time to time, but it also works for longer sessions, some of the freelance campaigns can take a couple of hours and you can't save in the middle of them which is a small negative. All in all, I'd say you have nothing to lose in Solo Nombre.

review:
It's good.

Every bit of story and equipment is lovingly crafted with an eye for detail. I never thought I'd see gun porn in a giant robot game, but Brigador really surprised me.

The game allows you to commit war crimes with a wide variety of weapons, from radiation beams to poison gas, as well as conventional machineguns, autocannons, laser guns, cannons, mortars, howitzers, and much more. There's even a cluster bomb launcher for when you really need to level everything for five or six city blocks.

Also, the freelance mode lets you choose your own difficulty; you can choose one of around 40 vehicles and dozens of pilots to customize your play experience, then do one of many different runs of varying lengths. You can even adjust the game speed if you're having trouble with the fast pace.

Additionally, the controls have been made more user-friendly, though the original control scheme is still available for those who prefer it.

A definite must-have for anyone who likes giant robots, massive destruction, or isometric action games of any kind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990201480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1626260915}
review:
I quickly fell in love with the gameplay an the mechanics. Destroying things have never been so satistfying (and oh so rewarding). Everything inside the playable area is destructible in some way. Laying waste to properties, committing war crimes with various vehicles is totally awesome.

I want to disagree on complaints made about the maneuvrability and/or controls of the mecha suit and the tank being a little quirky or a bitch to handle (AGRAV being the easiest one to control). Flanking has it's purpose or in some cases shielding or going stealthy to outflank your enemies has it's purpose. The game has its charm and makes you switch up your play style in different campaign scenarios or freelance missions - or play any way you see fit with whatever suits you. All the rigs available have different stats and there is plenty of fun to be had. 

What I enjoyed is the setting. The whole retro/cyberpunk theme in a dystopian planet somewhere in the future plus the general lore is awesome. The overall replayability of this game is high, so there's always a chance to return to the game if you get tired of playing it for a while. 
 
The music will get tiresome after a while, and is lacking a bit in that department for my taste. If it had something like Hotline Miami had music wise with the hard-hitting beats on each level, that would have spiced up the game a little extra.
Also theres a lack of higher difficulty settings and sometimes it can get a bit tedious if you have a standard setup that you enjoy. 

Overall, this is an awesome game. 5/7

author: {'steamid': '76561197999970585', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 852, 'last_played': 1511423414}
review:
Its hard to describe all the feelings I have about this game. It has retro vibe that captures the feel of the early 2000's late 90's game engines. I touches on Tiberium Sun, all the while also hitting some cosmetic notes from Blood Dragon. The ambiance is nice, and harsh, and ugly. The missions are short, or sometimes long. I expected, or maybe more accuratly wanted; a story driven RPG, I got an isometic muder-stomp simulator but I wasnt disapointed. The lore was deep if you explore it. Make sure to do that, its easy to forget you have money to spend in game. There is a constant familiarity that I eventually realized was front mission, front mission for the SNES. Wow, alright. Even though its nothing alike, the vibe is there.

So what the hell is Brigador? An isometric murder-shooting-stomping morally questionable game with the trappings of some cyberpunk, 90s style gritty sci-fi and a bitchin' soundtrack that is actually pretty good to work out to.

I give this game 8/10: would stomp on yellow raincoats again, read the lore after I bought it, and feel a pang of heart ache for imaginary people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001854882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 168, 'last_played': 1497431356}
review:
If you're an old fart like me and have fond memories of ancient PC classics like Traffic Department 2192, Desert Storm, and Raptor: Call of the Shadows, you will love this little indie game. 

It builds a surprisingly rich fleshed out world with a lot of depth, in that early 90's cyberpunk outrun style we all know and love. It feels like there could be a series of movies and books exploring this intriguing place called Solo Nombre.  It's all very believable and morally ambiguous, centering the story around a power vacuum caused by the recently killed dictator of a space colony. It looks and feels very nice and the minature buildings and tiny neon signs are beautifully detailed. 

The missions are short, simple, and focused, usually the game gives you one or two objectives and drops you into an area in which you can carve a trail of horrific destruction as you blow the bejeezus out of enemy vehicles and massacre the tiny ground troops unlucky enough to get in your way. You'll get a lot of bang for your buck as there are quite a lot of missions and environments to progress through and at least 3 game modes to choose from. 

Everything can be destroyed and nothing is safe from your wrath. There's a big variety of vehicles to choose from, all with different strengths and weaknesses. Some are slick high tech walking mechs, some are tanks made of scrap metal, some are just motorbikes or buses with guns welded to them. All are brutally destructive. 

The soundtrack is fantastic with a lot of pumping synthwave tracks and the sounds of gunfire and explosions are very satisfying. 

If you're into retro 90's games with lots of neon and synth, or if you like isometric action games, you'll enjoy Brigador.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983405694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 5948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1656228209}
review:
Great game, it reminds me of Crusader series back I used to play in ancient times.There is nothing good that others so far havent mentioned already. 

However there is one major thing I didnt like and ruins the game big time.The game is bad at explaining what it wants you to do.Mostly it has to do with two things.

-First the UI is by far the worst user friendly I have ever seen, which means it simply needs to be redesigned, in order  the user can understand what to do.Especially there is a thing with the buttons.Instead having plain straightforward captions like 'buy' they use confusing words like 'requisition'.Also they are placed in areas onscreen that few will pay attention to.All in all, the player does not understand what they do, nor what order does he have to use the options in the menu in order to do what he wants, like buy guns, pilots, customize the mech/vehicle and so on.  

-Second thing is info management.While the game goes extensively on and on about the mission, or the pilot bio, or the lore, and all unecessary blabbing, it has no map of the level at all.This is critical, since the game is MISSION based...Moreover, it has scarce info on the weapons (that matter, 'which gun should I buy next?'), only graphs that make little sense.The enemy info has to be purchased with money won during missions.Why should anyone ingame have to pay for such a thing is beyond my comprehension.

If you consider buying it, listen to my advice, devote some of your time first to understand how the game works before diving straight in.Otherwise you might be dissapointed, which is a pity since the game is not bad at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970883414', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1548067046}
review:
This game is intensely good. The game encourages you to constantly gage how much challenge you're willing or able to take on and then always raise the stakes a little higher for greater reward. For instances, your choice of operator determines the starting difficulty and how it ramps up, while your vehicle determines the amount of firepower you can level at said challenge: more expensive operators face greater challenges for more rewards, while more expensive vehicles are substantially weaker and less durable but also grant better reward multipliers. This contrasts with other games that make you work to get the most powerful equipment; in this game, you get some of the most powerful things for free by default, and the rest are quite cheap. If you want to drive what is basically the Tuk Tuk from Just Cause 2, however, that'll run you a price so steep that it's 4x more than next most expensive vehicle, but it'll give you a 10x payout multiplier!

The number of completable objectives on each map is much greater than what you need to move on (and they can have good or dangerous consequences if you complete them), and you can often jump to the final payout mission well before completing all of the maps leading up to it. Every single object that breaks or person that dies adds to your paycheck, but you have to manage your ammo stores and your time may be worth more if spent on the objectives.

This creates a subtle ingraining of Brigador morality: Whatever it takes to get paid and get off world is paramount. You will be financially compensated for stomping on innocents, ramming through slums, and collateral damage, but you will probably find that it's not worth your time to go out of your way to do so. Civilians are worth so little to kill that shooting them on purpose may feel like a waste of resources. So, when you DO go out of your way to destroy the lives of the little people, there can be no room for doubt that you act as perversely as the Auditer or greedily beyond all reason.

Speaking of, the lore in this game is so good. Spacers in particular are genuinely unsettling in creative ways: their mechs are clearly backwards and all of their vehicles sport full-yellow paint jobs (the lore says that yellow on Solo Nobre is associated with peaceful surrender and that wearing it while fighting is utmost sacrilege; I wonder if the Spacers are even aware of that) but with bullseyes on the cockpits (which, again, appear to be on the wrong side of the mech). The aforementioned Auditer is merely the operator you can use to tour each map without worrying about hostile forces, but the lore makes an impressive effort turning him into an unusual and almost horrifying character.

If you do try to use a controller, definitely slow the game speed down. The aiming controls are much better suited to a mouse than a joypad, so a lower speed will give you some extra time to adjust the angle of elevation of your shots. For keyboard and mouse, I use Relative Controls for mechs/tanks but Screen Absolute for agravs (I may switch to Top Right Absolute but I have yet to try it).

author: {'steamid': '76561197992605428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1497233985}
review:
I had been really excited to get this game in the humble monthly. I was looking forward to it from the time I heard about it, but only recently got a chance to play. After playing what felt like 12 introductory tutorial missions, 4 for each mech, I was presented with a mission to chose one and run a new mission, but I couldn't bring myself to care.

They all felt the same. Nothing special or innovative. None had a good feel. The missions were all boring and repetitive with no clear direction beyond 'destroy everything that moves'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025606410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 3612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1699672381}
review:
I'm a bored person, usually. I don't tend to see games in my library and immediately go "Yea, let's play that!"

Brigador has managed to not just be a game I play. Within two hours, it's managed to be a game I'll sometimes click on while paging through my list, and immediately boot up.

Graphically, this feels like looking at a 90s game, but you know how when you don't watch or play or read something for a long time, you come back and it really shows it's age? Brigador feels like a very old game that has somehow managed to dodge that effect. In a world of low-poly 3d and "8-Bit" in name only, this striks a very odd balance that I absolutely adore.

Lore-wise I'm very fond of what they do. Every vehicle, weapon, enemy profile, and article has a small chunk of lore, usually under a paragraph. I feel it fits the game's atmosphere, a mercenary isn't going to know much beyond their objectives unless the actively dig for data.

While I do love this game, it's not perfect, and the gameplay is where I actually have a few complaints. Mechs and tanks control fine, but inexplicably Agravs- armed hovercraft available to pilots- drive incredibly poorly on my machine. There's indication that moving forward in a mech moves you towards the mouse in an agrav, yet they seem to control like tanks no matter what I do. Effectively, this makes them much weaker tanks with the relatively nice ability of flying over low cover and not getting bogged down in debris.

Speaking of debris: in massive fields of it, and those do tend to pop up wherever you go, it's hard to tell what's a flat plane you can walk through, and what's still standing. 

For a game with emphasis on destruction, explosive weapons and elements tend to be a bit lackluster visually. They're still very effective, but the actual blast seems significantly smaller than it should be.

Yet I feel like the best praise I can give here is that even though I have complaints, this is without a doubt my favorite game released this year. I've enjoyed my time with it so far, and the game seems to indicate that I have a very long way to go before I'm scraping the barrel. I hope this is a sign of the rebirth of content-rich singleplayer, because I would love to write more recommendations in the future and be able to say that this was the start of the trend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972270881', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1565357052}
review:
Oh man.

Spent like an hour going through a 7 district level with a little super fast motorbike (Troubador I believe), the Donkey shotgun which deletes people at close range, and a Jerico 70mm vortex cannon, which at long range can be used to snipe giant ball crushing mechs that outgun the hell out of me. Dashed in and around dense city district blowing through walls with the Donkey, speed boosting through powered armour soldiers to watch them get pancaked, use my active camo ability to go all Batman ninja mode only to appear on flanks and donkey punch the losers into the afterlife.

I get through all of this, getting into a zen like flow state where I'm crushing whole armies by being a dirty little turd of a fighter, only to speed boost into a petrol station and kill myself at the space port district, which was the end level. Funeral costs at 13 MILLION bucks, and I make $300,000.

FUCK!

Instant replay though, and back to the drawing board on what kind of new weapons of mass destruction I can make.

Seriously fantastic game.
