author: {'steamid': '76561198053610987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 7409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 83, 'playtime_at_review': 3225, 'last_played': 1712156082}
review:
[h1]汝の足が土を見つけんことを	[/h1]（ソロ・ノブリに伝わる祈りの言葉）

あなたは「偉大なる指導者」が支配していた街、ソロ・ノブリに生きる戦士です。
「偉大なる指導者」の死後、あなたは街の支配権を奪取しようとする組織、SNCの尖兵として戦うことになります。

こういう前書きは置いといて。

このゲームの遊び方は2種類、あらかじめ用意された装備とユニットで戦うキャンペーンモードと
自分で装備、戦場を選んで戦うフリーランスモードです。

戦うごとに報酬が手に入り、報酬を使うことでフリーランスモードでの装備や世界観設定などが入手できます。

戦場に出たら味方は存在せず、周りのすべては敵です。

ちなみに黄色いレインコートの人間は非戦闘員であることを表しますが、気にせず殺しましょう。報酬に上乗せされます。

あなたが操縦するユニットは強力な武装と装甲、そしてシールドに包まれていますが、
囲まれたり、警報を鳴らされたりするとたちまち追い詰められてしまいます。

危険を回避するため逃げたり、遠距離から攻撃したり、ガソリンスタンドの爆発に敵を巻き込んだりといった手段が有効です。
方法を選んではいられません。あなたはたった一機なのですから。

選べる機体も巨大なメック、頑丈な戦車、軽々と飛び回る反重力マシンなど多岐に及んでおります。

武器も静音性や貫通性能などを考える必要があります。

機体と武器とのバランスも忘れないでください。バイクで戦車砲は運べません。

基本的にストーリーは簡素ですが設定などは作りこまれており、武器の解説などもキャラクターのレポートや旅行ガイドからの引用といった形式を取っています。
日本語翻訳も素晴らしい出来であり、翻訳スタッフに感謝したくなります。

2017年に装甲増加版としてアップグレードされた本作ですが、以降も武器や機体のバランスが調整され続けており、開発スタッフの熱意が伝わります。

それではよきブリゲーダーライフをお過ごしください。

それでオーディオドラマの日本語訳はいつになりますかねぇ・・・？

author: {'steamid': '76561198057386857', 'num_games_owned': 4166, 'num_reviews': 820, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1630164228}
review:
Хороший (видно, что с любовью делали) 2D шутер. Одиночная кампания неплоха, хотя, как мне кажется, она скорее, как в стратегиях, знакомит игрока со всеми возможными механиками, нежели является испытанием. Если выбирать удобные под каждую миссию машины, то проблем с прохождением не возникнет. Основа же Brigador — это режим freelance, его можно предположительно заигрывать до умопомрачения, докупая на честно заработанные кровавые купюры новое оружие, пилотов, машины и миссии.
Стоит отметить отличный дизайн, как визуальный, так и игровой. Уровни хочется разглядывать и изучать. Кажется, я столько внимания не уделял детским площадкам и магазинчикам с тех времён, когда первый раз открыл коробку с Tiberian Sun.

Если вы любите shooter-ы и проводить время, закатывая уровни по многу раз ради апгрейдов и ачивок, то Brigador вас не разочарует.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008433256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1668387021}
review:
三輪タクシーで死と破壊をデリバリーする新感覚ドライビングゲーム。

メック(バランス型)タンク(動く産廃)アンチグラヴ(機動戦信者)といった
鋼鉄のけだものフレンズ(概ね自分も使える)や逃げ惑ってる市民や淫売ビルを爆砕しろ。
ミッションは多用で、敵を殺したり何か壊したり敵を殺したり何か壊したり
他にも敵を殺したり何かを壊したりできる。
地獄の見過ぎで心が乾いて戦いに飽きたら
充実してるゲーム内資料を見て暇を潰せる二段構え構成。
遥か未来のお話の割にM2ブローニングが使えたり、他にも
「あっ、これ××だ！」ってなる進研ゼミな武器ラインナップは個人的には好み。

総評：戦闘がヌルい＆ミッションが単調なせいで数時間もするとゲーム内資料を見るだけのノベルゲーと化す。

author: {'steamid': '76561197997331817', 'num_games_owned': 1540, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1497038532}
review:
Un juego con Mechas y algo de estrategia en vista isométrica que hace recordar juegos de la vieja escuela. Controles simples con gráficos vintage y buenos efectos visuales, te hará recordar los gráficos de Diablo II o de Starcraft BroodWar.

Para los amantes de "dispara a todo lo que se mueva" es un "must try". La destrucción de edificaciones y estructuras es muy divertida, y al final de cada misión te dará el récord de daños materiales; querrás dejar todo el escenario limpio como una combinación entre Rampage y Red Faction Guerrilla (pero sin físicas). Puedes probar con distintos tipos de controles por si te es más fácil moverte en modo abosluto o relativo.

La interfaz es muy simple pero es suficiente, le faltan algunos detalles para hacerla más amigable, pero no es algo que afecte la calidad del gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988328010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1102, 'last_played': 1620074953}
review:
This game is a hidden gem. If not for Humble Bundle, I would have never found it. Not sure what caused this game to fly under the radar, but it's a must-buy and worth its asking price for anyone remotely interested in Mechs, Tanks and Mayhem. Features an amazing soundtrack and a destructible environment with lots of explosions. The Freelance missions are the main part of the game. Campaign missions seem to serve more as a sort of tutorial (but a good and lengthy one).

The only quibble I have is the AI - enemies are always gunning straight for you as soon as they see, hear or notice you, I haven't noticed any particular complex strategies on their part. Hopefully more people notice this game so the devs can work on that and release some DLCs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972216686', 'num_games_owned': 828, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1681774183}

author: {'steamid': '76561198111770816', 'num_games_owned': 1199, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1440, 'last_played': 1510040418}
review:
I really appreciate that this game manages to make you feel like a badass based on your skill alone, and the devs didn't feel the need to implement skill trees or some sort of character progression system. It's unabashedly arcade-ish in this mentality, but it still manages to have a surprising amount of tactical depth when choosing how to approach groups of enemies or defended positions.

I haven't played the original release of Brigador but I think the complaints about it being hard to control are overstated. I started playing on the new control scheme but settled for tank controls for all vehicles. The absolute control scheme seems more responsive on a keyboard/mouse, especially for the agravs - it allows you to strafe and circle around your opponents with ease. I imagine the new control scheme would be great for a gamepad, though I'm still skeptical about the agravs. Anyway, my point is, the people who write this off because of the control scheme are giant babies. There's nothing wrong with it, and you have plenty of choices in how you choose to control your vehicle.

Music is another highlight for me. It's really well done retro electronica, cca late 70s/early 80s. Obvious comparisons would be John Carpenter movies, Tangerine Dream soundtracks, maybe Blade Runner in parts. 

Overall probably one of the funnest action games I've played in the past while. It manages to recreate that satisfying MechCommander feeling of playing with giant robots, but replaces its clunky combat with sleek, streamlined, and surprisingly kinetic action - moves have heft and explosions feel punchy and dangerous. 

With this re-release pretty much patching up everything people complained about, including adding an extensive tutorial campaign, even more vehicles, weapons, etc. as well as planning additional content to be released in the near future, this is probably the best time to get this game. I hope it achieves some sort of cult status at some point, because it really deserves it. This game is to the Desert/Jungle Strike series what Shovel Knight was for NES-inspired platformers, imho.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994962355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 14180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4520, 'last_played': 1677527767}
review:
Now that the Up-Armored Edition has been released I figure it's a good time to review this. I've got about 70 hours in the game so far and don't see myself qutting any time soon.

Do you want to play a tank with a cloaking field and invisibly drive over your opponents? Do you want to be a multi-story mech bristling with lasers that wins through sheer firepower? Or maybe an agile anti-grav making hit and run attacks with corrossive chemical weapons? The huge amount of vehicles and weapons means you can play however you want. Huge levels with 100% destructible terrain mean you can carve your own path through the game, either through brute force or stealth.

There's also a ton of difficulty settings in Freelance mode in the form of pilots, each of which has a difficulty rating that is either stable or goes up steadily over multiple levels. In addition you can adjust the game speed in the menus to make things less hectic.

There's been multiple times I've broken out laughing during this game as I suddenly realize the absolute massive damage that's been done to the city during a fight. Though it might not seem like this game has much of a story, the info logs set up a surpisingly deep and darkly satiric setting. For example, you get extra pay for collateral damage. A civilian casualty is worth $50. A decorative shrub is $100.

Also worth mentioning is that the dev support has been incredible post release. There have been multiple updates including weapon rebalances to make sure everything in the game feels fun to use. 

The controls may take a bit of getting used to if you aren't familiar with tank controls (however there are multiple control settings available). But once you do this game has a huge amount of entertaining content. I can't recommend this enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997290149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 1615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3, 'playtime_at_review': 692, 'last_played': 1711370236}
review:
I sincerely think there are a lot of diamonds in the rough on steam, overlooked by the deluge of asset flips and survival games, criminally underrated and deserving of so much more..

Brigador is one of those games. 

High skill cap yet easy to pick up gameplay combined with ungodly replayability and a heaping helping of 'aesthetic', there's not a lot about this game that will leave you wanting, unless glorious vehicular combat isn't your cuppa joe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981609203', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2057, 'last_played': 1699655606}
review:
I had this game sitting in my wishlist for a long period of time, 
and when I finally purchased it, whoo~ boy was it worth my money. 

Drive and maneuver many different vehicles, ranging from, 
heavy mechs, tanks and anti-gravity vehicles. 
Each with their unique gameplay mechanics, harpoints and maneuverability. 
Equip them with dozens of various weapons, like, mortars, cannons, gatling guns, 
missile launchers, rail guns, etc... 

The sheer amount of unlockables is amazing, and I really enjoy playing the freelance mode, 
where you choose everything, from pilot, vehicle, weaponry, sub-equipment and then a mission you want to tackle. 
Upon successfully completing a mission, you'll get money, which you use to unlock items. 

Brigador reminds me a lot of old games like Desert Strike, Jungle Strike and Urban Strike,
but instead of having "destroy these first", "then rescue this", "before time runs out destroy these", 
you are given a vehicle, and told "hey this is your mission, do it the way you like, also, don't worry of destroying buildings". 

The soundscape is fantastic, and together with absolutely beautiful 80's soundtrack, it all greatly falls into an one big great experience.

In the end, Brigador is a satisfying, game of wreacking havoc and destruction everywhere you go, no matter which vehicle you drive, in the neon light streets while blasting your cannons in unison with the great beats of the soundtrack.

Varlet/10

review: Brigador is one of the most unique games I've played in a while, especially because I haven't played a mech game since the original xbox. Destructible environments, large explosions, and fun little gibs from pathetic peasant pedestrians are super satisfying, giving weight to your mech. However, you're small and the map is big. And you're slow, mostly. You accelerate after some time, but 30-70% of my time in missions is spent traveling, looking for targets. There's a lot of variables for difficulty and strategy, but not an overwhelming depth. There are enough weapons and playstyles to find what you like. A little bit niche, being a difficult top-down mech shooter, but it's great for short bursts of gameplay and it has a good soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969505184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1628319339}
review:
Really really fun. Stylish as hell. Controls take some getting used to, but if you are looking for gritty sci-fi look no further.

I think no other game comes as close to giving you a sense of the ludicrous destructiveness of modern firepower. You will fire shells that level entire apartment blocks all the while skirting between buildings and dodging incoming shells.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256583497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1711228933}
review:
Игра понравится тем, кто залипал в детстве в battletech на sega. По сути, это та же самая игра, но со множеством улучшений, персонажей и контрактов по зачистке местности. Одиночная кампания представляет из себя набор миссий, в которых нам нужно разрушать определенные объекты и других роботов, за это мы получаем деньги и покупаем обновления для своего меха, а так же персонажей для свободной игры. В принципе, впечатление от игры положительное. 
Недостатки:
Часто Музыка во время битвы имеет обыкновение заканчиваться, что довольно странно(приходится завершать уровень в тишине)
Приятная графика, но слишком мелкие объекты. Чтобы рассмотреть то или иное здание, нужно хорошенько поломать глаза. Все время хочется приблизить камеру к роботу. 
Ужасающая работа с русскими шрифтами, которые очень сильно портят впечатление. Они на уровне бесплатных игр с андроид маркета. Цвет, размер, расположение. Иногда текст не помещается в рамку. 
На данный момент рекомендую игру. Обзор будет дополнен новыми плюсами и минусами после их обнаружения.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003745518', 'num_games_owned': 2873, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1565677846}
review:
메카닉 물을 좋아하는 사람은 반길 것이고
표시되는 오브젝트를 거진 파괴할수 있으면
흥분하는 분도 반길만한 게임입니다.

2족 보행형, 차륜형, 궤도형, 호버링형 등
63종의 기체가 나오며 능력치가 있는 파일럿도
38명이나 존재 하여 입맛대로 플레이할수 있어
나름 재미 있었습니다.

무기 종류로는 크게 레이저형, 폭탄형, 기관총형의
3가지 버전, 40종을 부무장과 주무장으로 장착할수 있습니다.

하지만 저 많은 기체와 무기, 파일럿을 사용하기 위해서는
기본적으로 캠페인을 진행하여 각 맵에있는 목표와 오브젝트를
파괴하고 받은 금액을 꼬박꼬박 모아서 하나하나 구매해야 된다는
번거러움은 있습니다.

캠페인이 질리면 프리모드를 통한 자금 입수도 할수 있어
자칫 지루해질수 있는 점을 최소화 한 부분은 마음에 들었습니다.

또한 기체 컨트롤이 어렵게 느껴질수도 있는 부분은 자금을 모으기
위한 무수한 재 플레이에 따른 시간으로 극복할수 있는 부분이고요.

거기다 OST도 나름 마음에 들어서 듣는 즐거움도 있었습니다.

게임시작시 모든 무기는 탄약 최대 소지한도가 있어 난사가 어려운 점은 있습니다.
부족한 탄약은 적 유닛을 처치하면 일정확율로 드랍이 되고
맵에 있는 탄약 건물에서 보급받을수도 있습니다.
그렇다 보니 부족하지도 풍족하지도 않은 상황하에서 적이 보인다고 무턱대고 쏘다 보면
금세 바닥을 들어내는 탄창을 보게 될것입니다.
그리고 기체 크기에 따라 탄종도 헤비에서 스몰까지 장착할수 있는 사이즈가 다른데
헤비가 가장 강력하고 스몰이 가장 약합니다.
대신에 잃은 화력을 기동력으로 보충하고 있어서
목적에 따라 기종 운용을 하면 될것 같습니다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073654543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1565936702}
review:
YES YES A MILLION TIMES I WOULD RECCOMEND THIS GAME. It is amazing!!

You go around and blow things up with lazers, bombs, machine guns, you name it. There are lots of vehicles and mechs to control, and using them to destroy literally everything in sight (and I do mean it- you can destroy EVERYTHING) is a BLAST (pun intended) This is one of the most satisfying and one of the most unique games I have ever played. 

If this game looks even SLIGHTLY interesting to you, pick it up. I wasn't sure myself before I bought it, but now I am in love with this game, the lore, its style, and just blowing everything and everyone up. 

The only complaint I have is that the controls can be a bit wonky and hard to get used to but they do not hinder the game at all. In fact, I'd say it makes you feel even more like you're in control of a large unwieldy death-machine. 

In short: This game is a literal blast and I love playing it. It is so satisfying and one of the most pure modern gaming experiences I have ever had.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031489939', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1497062089}
review:
rogue-like game where each win gives you money to buy more shit
shit includes: Tons of pilots, vehicles, weapons, specials, intel, and lore. there are quit a lot of choices, i was impressed

there is an interesting difficutly system here, each pilot gives certain amount of extra pay out but the trade off is the enemy fields harder units to fight you. each vehicle also has something similar except they might give x2 or x1.5 (for example) more pay out compared to normal. they are rated based on how weak they are. the tiny trucks with little guns for example give much higher multiplied bonus if you manage to finish a mission with it. do you like the huge mech with guns that flatten city blocks? x1 bonus for you

graphics are also very good. fully destructible environments and impressive lighting effects

author: {'steamid': '76561197973399782', 'num_games_owned': 793, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1497440063}
review:
This game stirs up all my nostalgia for the classic 1990's mech games. It is very reminiscent of MechWarrior 3050 on the Super Nintendo (one of my favorite games as a kid).

[GOOD]
That soundtrack, holy s**t!
The sheer variety of content is admirable
The missions are varied
Some of the vehicle designs are straight up awesome 
There is almost too much stuff to unlock (in a good way) 
The controls are simple and tight. 
The game is balanced and fun.
great direction, you never are confused about what you are doing!

[NEUTRAL]
Combat can get a little samey
Once you find a build you are happy with all the other the options become pointless
Readability on the screen (graphic style) can be difficult sometimes, not often, but it happens

[BAD]
Sound design aside from music is pretty damn boring
Lore/story needs to be purchased in files like vehicles and weapons? WTF?!
Some of the vehicle designs are straight up lazy compared to others. (opinion!)

Overall Brigador is a solid game that deserves a chance in your library.
I mean, if you are on Brigador's store page, reading this review, something must have stood out 
to you! 

It's inexpensive and fun as hell.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990218499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1697904469}
review:
This may be the only game I regret getting from the Humble Monthly Bundle pack, and not knowing about it before then. I had never seen a single image of this game or of its indev version Matador. I had not seen this on my Steam reccomended list, curators list, or on RPS. I wasn't scouring, but still. I regret getting this in a bundle, because I know I'd have purchased this the moment I saw it at $20, and I would've bought it sooner then that at the current $14. 

Brigador is almost a simple concept; you are a mercenary pilot, and your contract is to topple a South American style dictatorship on a far off colony world. You pilot a mech walker, tanks, tiny power-suits, and even anti-gravity tanks [all in three distinct enough factions]. The weapons feel very real, the controls are incredibly solid, and the combat is incredibly refreshing and difficult. For anyone who fell in love with C&C games like Red Alert or especially Tiberian Sun, they will be visibly aroused by the graphics. The description by devs that this is a 'Kool-Aid man simulator' is remarkably applicable, as the best tactic is often to rush through an apartment block flanking your foe.

I am not even finished with the campaign, of which there are literally a dozen tutorial levels that actually have meat, and two dozen actually missions with 4 different starting configuartions each to complete. You earn money, and funnel that back into puchasing pilots and gear to use in Operations, something almost akin to Diablos dungeons. You can purchase packs of anywhere from 2 to 20+ levels to run through any pilot configuration you choose, earning money based on how difficult you've made it for yourself. That makes for a very nice feedback loop, much nicer then, say, Diablos. You earn only pride for beating a Hell level run with a shitty motorcycle, but you crave that pride. Like starting a Dwarf Fortress map on a glacier, just because.

Another aspect I find absolutely incredible is the dev team. For a small team to place this much effort, polish, and obvious enthusiasm into a $20 package, rather then a watered down $40-$60 game with in-game purchases and DLC level packs gallore. This is an incredible amount of game for the money. Not to mention how responsive to community I have seen them be. Two separate devs came to answer an angry thread about a particularily tricky level, and both took a lot of time to explain as best they could to the player, but also preserving the experience. They didn't say "Yeah theres a command we use to skip levels...". To take the time out of their day like that as a developer is unique. Assasins Creed devs don't do tech support. 

All in all I highly reccomend this game to several people; Mech enthusiasts, C&C junkies, lovers of strategy, lovers of finely crafted menus and UI's, and fans of Just Cause. Just cause they're pretty similar with the dictator thing.

12/10, cannot wait to see what this team does next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073134171', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1497424980}
review:
サイバーパンクの世界を舞台としたアクションシューティング。
「二足歩行型、ホバー型、戦車型」のメカに搭乗できる。
サイバーパンクでお馴染みの「空飛ぶ車」にも乗れて雰囲気が素晴らしい。
キャンペーンモードは38のミッションを淡々とこなしていくもので、バックストーリーもあるが繋がりはあまりない。
別でフリーランスミッションもあるが、物語などなく言われた通りに目標の破壊をしていくのみ。

基本的にミッションで課せられる目的は、「建造物の破壊、目標の破壊、敵兵の破壊、弾薬庫の破壊等」
守備的なミッションは無く破壊することがほとんど、というよりそれしかない。

キャンペーンモードでは機体の兵装が決まっており、特殊兵器であるグレネード・スモーク・光学迷彩等も決まっている。
それが少々残念で、フリーランスミッションでは稼いだ金銭でアンロックしていくことで好きなようにカスタマイズができる為面白みに欠ける。またフリーランスミッションで搭乗者の生き様というか立場というか細かい設定が確認できるので、搭乗者それぞれの生き様をメインストーリーで演じてほしかった(正直これが足りない)。

戦闘自体は難しくなく、戦略的に攻めることを強要されない。メリハリのある作りではなく良く言えば「融通が利く」。
死角から電磁グレネードで動きを止めて一掃とか、壁をぶち破って背後からロケット弾をお見舞いするなど好きなようにできる。あり得ないぐらい切羽詰まる状況に追いやられたり、強すぎる機体が現れることもないので悪く言えば単調。軽くプレイされる方には良いかもしれない。

・他に気になった点などをまとめると、
搭乗者の物語がない。
二足よりホバーの方が有利すぎると感じた。
回避能力に長けているし、特殊兵器を使いこなせば立ち回りもスムーズ。
二足の良さを感じにくい。
爆発物との判別がしづらく、一部の目標となる対象物が見つけづらい(守備兵等)。
ミッションの種類が少ない。
協力プレイができない。
マップが少々広い。

・結果的に言えば、「サイバーパンクの世界観に浸れるかどうか」による。
BGMが素晴らしく世界観をより色濃く染め上げているので、好きな方は良い感じになれると思います。
逆にトップダウン型メックウォリアやアーマードコアのようなイメージをお持ちだと、「普通にトップダウン型のアクションシューティングではないか」と苛立つかもしれません。最終的に「メカに乗る必要あるのか」まで考えてしまうかもしれません。
メカ同士が熱いバトルを繰り広げる事もなく、ただ淡々と進むので人によってはつまらないと感じるかも。
気になるようであればセール時に購入しましょう。

author: {'steamid': '76561197981006217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1496759165}
review:
This struck me as filler for the Humble Bundle on first glance but after seeing the reviews I gave it a shot. The game is fantastic with great looking environments, interesting and varied enemy combatants, and an outstanding soundtrack. The different vehicle classes each require a unique approach to gameplay with well balanced strengths and weaknesses. 

As a new dad it is also a perfect game for me to pick up and dive into during the 15-20 minutes of relaxation I can wring out of a day. My days of 200 hour RPG epics are gone for now, but the bite-sized thrills and progression system of Brigador fill the void nicely.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005503033', 'num_games_owned': 985, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1567643245}
review: The campaign is great, but it really picks up once you go into the Freelance mode, as resource management across multiple missions and trying to win with smaller and smaller vehicles makes you take full advantage of the stealth mechanics that this mech action game has. Of course, you can still always just grab the Ultra vehicles that are 8 different tanks strapped together and just steamroll your way to victory too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005443580', 'num_games_owned': 1281, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1708109914}
review:
Syndicate invited Crusader: No Remorse/No Regret & Desert Strike over for a game of Battletech, but ended up having a threesome instead while listening to 80's synthwave. Almost Three decades later, Brigador was born.

I honestly can't find a single thing to complain about in this criminally overlooked game. It's grainy visuals, tone, lore, completely destructive enviornments, underlying level of strategy and music (the music!) should set an example for other developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971801730', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1516664927}
review: Fantastical old school nostalgic isometric death and destruction. Reminds me of old classics like the Crusader: No Regret series or Gender Wars (A silly old fun game). Can't believe I waited this fucking long to buy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987400749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1092, 'last_played': 1628362524}
review:
体が闘争を求める時起動する、破壊の限りを尽くす。
たのしい。

見下ろし方アクション。ロボットゲーというよりロボットもあるアクションゲーム。
ロボットはもちろん、戦車から反重力ヴィークル、果ては三輪バイクやパワードスーツも使える。
ただし舞台になる星は対空砲がアホみたいに設置されてるので航空機はない。
ロボットにもよるがステルス要素あり、背後からの攻撃は有利になる。
ストーリーは淡泊だがフレーバーテキストが兎に角濃い、凄まじく濃い、読み物として楽しめるレベル。
豊富な武装が使え、それぞれの性能が癖があったりなかったりで武装編成の幅は広い。
ストーリーモードとフリーランスモードの２つがある、前者は後者のチュートリアル的側面が序盤はあるものの中盤から独特の難易度バランスのステージが増えてくる。
後者は広大なMAPで砲台破壊、特定対象抹殺、警備隊皆殺しの達成目標３つのうちどれかをクリアしてMAPから離脱を繰り返し攻略してく。
別に３つ全部クリアしても問題はない。ただし広大なMAP故に高確率でダレる。
シングルオンリー、２０００円程度と考えられないぐらい濃い作品。
本気でオススメ出来る作品です。

author: {'steamid': '76561198010438114', 'num_games_owned': 742, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1492, 'last_played': 1629799285}
review:
Der Geheimtipp schlechthin für Nostalgiker und Fans brachialer Aktion gleichermassen mit genau dem richtigen Hauch an Taktik um das alles gut abzurunden. Defintiv den Preis wert, vor allem jetzt mit der "Up-Armored Edition"

[b][u]Positiv[/u][/b]

+ Sehr grosse Fahrzeug / Mechauswahl
+ Gewalties Arsenal an Waffen
+ Jede Waffe oder Fahrzeug haben ihre eigenen Vor / Nachteile
+ 2D Retrografik mit enormer Weitsicht und abwechslungsreichen, detailierten Levels
+ Bildschirmfüllende Explosionen
+ Kampagne + "Freelance" Modus
+ Lärm von Waffen / Explosionen entscheidet darüber wie schnell euch Gegner finden können
+ Fantastischer Soundtrack
+ 3 unterschiedliche Gegnerfraktionen mit eigenen Fahrzeugen / Taktiken

[b][u]Negativ[/u][/b]

- Ausrüstung / Fahrzeuge können nur im "Freelance"-Modus ausgewählt werden
- Ein oder zwei Levels wirken recht unfair wirkend gegenüber dem Spieler
- Chaos auf dem Bildschirm sorgt recht schnell dafür den Überblick zu verlieren
- Entwickelt eine sehr starke "Nurnoch ein Abschnitt beenden!" Sucht

author: {'steamid': '76561198022810687', 'num_games_owned': 812, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1589998311}
review:
In der neuen Up-Armored Edition eindeutig zu empfehlen, für jeden der isometrische Action mag. Sehr gut gefällt mir, dass seit dem neuen Update das Spiel auch auf Deutsch umgestellt werden kann. Das Gameplay ist meiner Meinung nach sehr gelungen. Die Steuerung von Panzern, Mechs und Antigravs fühlt sich einfach richtig an, die unterschiedlichen Waffen haben alle Vor- und Nachteile.

Die Kampange startet einfach und wird immer knackiger. Sehr motiverend ist der Freelance Modus, in dem man mit verdientem Geld Piloten, Fahrzeuge, Waffen und Missionen freischaltet. 

Grafisch finde ich das Spiel absolut top. Schöne, detailierte 2D Grafik mit aufwendigen Animationen, tollen Lichteffekten und einem sehr konsistenten Style. Sowas wäre früher mit 2D nicht möglich gewesen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037781082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1586924500}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027319794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1500207063}
review:
Fun little game with an awesome soundtrack and premise. Blast to the past arcade mech game play.

Pros:
Great weight to the action - feel like you're stomping around in giant mech or floating along on an antigrav motor bike
Lots of customization options - loads of vehicles and weapons, and you can change the feel of the game drastically by changing game speed
Graphics - tons of character in the vehicle sprites and pilot portraits
Gameplay - smooth as silk isometric action

Cons:
Short main campaign - if you don't like freelance mode you won't get as much out of this game
Repetitive enemies - while there are a lot of enemy types model wise, there's not a lot of character to them so they feel very interchangeable
Awkward mechanics - some weapons and equipment feel a bit poorly implemented - no indication on what buildings explode, weird momentum mechanic for arcing weapons, no ability to change facing in absolute controls, but most are minor complaints

If you're a fan of arcade action, I would definitely give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972566562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 878, 'last_played': 1560299000}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976886701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1658, 'last_played': 1604101438}
review:
My brain is fried.

In the tutorial mission, I pillaged suburbia, splintering trees with giant miniguns. 

Then I graduated to ramming a tank through my enemies - I wasn't qualified for ammunition.

It went on. Sneaking around putting anti-tank rounds into the rears of mechs. Stomping across maps with a minigun turret working away, firing the occasional rocket and watching my mech skid back along the ground from the recoil, to eventually loading up with the biggest baddest machine I could find, fitting it with a massive armour-piercing flechette railgun and a super-mortar, and crawling around levelling city blocks and assassinating targets through concrete walls. 

I'm barely into the campaign and everything about this game already has me snared. It's hypnotic. The writing is great too, and there's so much of it. There's a book's worth of narrative and data in here, and it's all worth reading. Everything adds to the atmosphere. 

I don't know if I can sleep tonight. I've got explosions in my head.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025885314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1596178825}
review:
For me a game is good if it gets you in a vibe: draws you into its world and makes you forget that you are playing a game. It lets you walk around in ludicrous settings in the most fantastic situations that you would never find yourself in in real life; like walking around in a mech stomping around carelessly, or zooming through a huge industrial lot, careful not to get spotted because you know that just a few hits will kill you; strategically and quietly trying to take out your targets. This game does that.

I don't go for long runs - I don't have the time - but even after I played for only half an hour the world of Solo Nobre stuck with me, and that alone was worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970696263', 'num_games_owned': 983, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1497983932}
review:
This game is so much better then I thought it was going to be. It has an excellent mix of fast action and on the fly combat tactics. The visual style is what I would call high res-retro. That is a retro look but done to a nice polish. If you want a game where you can level entire cities and cause utter carnage This is your game. Gamespeed and difficulty settings can take this from mindless carnage to a game of tactics to suit your tastes as well. Good variety of pilots, weapons and maps to play with on a load of maps with a variety of enemies.

I got this in the humble monthly but having played it I would still be happy to pay full price for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965400498', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1695510103}
review:
A very well developed game.  A familiar story/lore, but still offers some unique aspects to enrich the content.  The music fits well, and reminds you of the sci-fi classics of the 80s and 90s (Bladerunner, Robocop, etc.).  I have only played a few missions, but the controls/game mechanics feel right.  I will be enjoying this game for a while.

My only dislike is that there is no coop, or multiplayer game modes.  I hope that it might be possible in the future to add this.  I could see myself playing this with friends in coop, or against them in a skirmish mode.

Look forward to what the future may offer for this game, and other games this Dev team may create.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024954396', 'num_games_owned': 1289, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1498, 'last_played': 1653075543}
review:
Brigador is exactly the kind of game I would've played the absolute, er, beans out of in the late '90s on my PSX and would still remember fondly (and play, occasionally) today, exactly in the same vein as Front Mission 3, Nuclear/Soviet Strike, FutureCop LAPD, G-Police, WipeOut, Colony Wars... I don't mean to imply it's anything like any of those gameplay-wise (it's not completely unlike FutureCop, but it's nowhere near a clone of it), but it's just so well-produced, charming and engrossing like those examples and definitely has a special feel to it. It's also pretty difficult at times, which would've also been appropriate in that era.

The gameplay itself is properly great and much deeper than you might expect; there's all sorts of different tactics to use including hit and run stealth (which I find the most fun but also very difficult to pull off properly), tons of weapons and vehicles, great attention to detail in both the design and writing of the entire game and an awesome soundtrack. There's a [i]lot[/i] of game here, I've played a fair bit and I haven't even finished the campaign yet.

What I love about it is it's maybe one third straightforward isometric twin stick-ish shooter, one third tactical combat and one third puzzle; each campaign mission gives you four pilots to choose from and each presents a wildly different strategy, working out how to complete the mission you just aced using the aptly-named Treehouse, this time using a tracked motorbike with a tenth of the durability and damage output (but ten times more speed) will have you scratching your head for sure. It never gets old! Then there's the Freelancer mode, which is actually the meat of the game, where you get to choose your own pilot, vehicle and weapons and therefore set your own challenge.

The only downsides I can think of are the weapon sight lines can be hard to use at times, especially against Agravs (floating enemies), I've died more than once by accidentally launching a huge artillery shell at a building I'm practically inside because of this. It's difficult to tell which weapon will fire on which mouse button, I feel this could've been handled better, but I get around this by giving most targets both barrels until I learn which is which so that's a minor one. Explosive scenery has also killed me a number of times because it's hard to focus on shooting a large group of enemies and moving at the same time, but you work out how to stop doing that after a few times. I think that's it, I haven't encountered any bugs, cheap deaths or poor balance in my time with it.

In summary, I'd recommend this so strongly that I've bought two copies of it besides my own (technically one was in the Humble monthly but still counts, damn it) to distribute and will buy more when it's full price again to support the devs. 

Although I feel like I haven't said enough about the quality of the writing. Fortunately the Brigador wiki has a lot (if not all) of the lore and intel transcribed so you can see that for yourself even before you buy. I'm fairly sure this gave me goosebumps the first time I read it, being so vivid and evocative as it is (spoilered, but doesn't give away any of the story, in fact there's not actually a story to spoil):

[spoiler]"When Spacers really want you dead they just quietly drop in one of their kill squads, powersuits decked in camo fields, Lockdowns, and Black Hands. Those guns are quiet, those suits are quiet, and pretty soon their targets are quiet too.

If there's anything that keeps me up at night, that's it."[/spoiler]

So cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961914427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1680834123}
review:
This game is awesome. That's it. It's awesome. Everything about it is fantastic with the exception that vehicle customization is somewhat limited. Two weapons plus a special. But that is compensated for by the sheer number of vehicles and weapons so it's a rather moot point and you will surely find a vehicle that caters to exactly how you want to play - and there is a huge variety - hover cars, tanks, walking mechs, and others.

Ok, on to the details:

The graphics are great. Dated in the same way something like Super Meat Boy is dated but perfectly fits the game. Obviously intentional. It's dark and usually night-ish time for some reason. Everything can be destroyed. The only problem with this is that you'll enjoy destroying things so much you'll run out of ammo :) If there's a story, I can't find it. I feel like I am playing the bad guys because I am often romping through residentail areas destroying houses and stepping on fleeing people. Awesome. It's kind of refreshing. The music fits the environments and graphics perfect. Its dark and snythetic 80's dystopian...something. I don't know much about music.

The missions themselves are all "destroy the thing". This is good because shooting guns is awesome and exploding things is great. The only issue with this that I have run into is that some of your objectives blow up real good. I say this is an issue because I've been in situations where I have run out of ammo, the ammo depot was destroyed, and I only have stomp left. My own fault. Again, see my comment about shooting everything.

The learning curve in this game is sort of high. Think of it as a twin stick shooter but the direction of your guns is often independent of the direction your legs/treads are facing. This means you can move around in one direction and shoot in another. This might take some getting used to if you've not played other games that work like this. But there are excellent tool-tips throughout the missions. You walk up to these objects and some text is on the screen. At first I wanted this gone so I could just play but the implementation is perfect and few games do this right. There are even reminders about past tips that are situated perfectly. It's like the game read my mind and was never annoying or patronizing. The text is only on the screen so long as you are close to these objects and the tips/instructions are always helpful. Perfectly designed so if you want to skip it you can and if you need the help, they actually provide good help. And you can go back to these objects at any time if you get lost or need help.

The mechanics in this game also exceed what I was expecting. Mechs can crouch!!!! This helps you avoid fire. Your weapons have an extreme range limit (usually). Far too often you play top-view games like this and your cannon fires all of 60' and disappears. In this your guns may as well have unlimited range - which is how it should be. It means you can properly snipe and use stealth to kill things from far away. Most vehicles have some kind of grenade. Some are smoke or EMP. The arc is helpful. And if you are smart about it, things like smoke deploy multiple projectiles over time so you can move your reticle to spread out the smoke grenades. Very smart and allows for a higher skill ceiling. Going back to movement of your vehicle, it all feels really good. With weapons/turrets separate from treads/feet, they have differing turn rates. Machine guns might turn faster than a cannon (or a mount turns at different speed - not sure yet) so you have to factor that in when maneuvering. You need to keep an eye where your feet are facing relative to your guns. Also, where you point your cursor is where the gun fires on the ground so you can hit small things on the ground quite easily but if the cursor is beyond the target, you could easily shoot over it to hit something behind.

If there was one thing I would add to this game is co-op multiplayer (either local or online or both). Also, if the maps are any bigger than I've experienced (about 2/3 the way through the campaign), a minimap would be helpful but I've never really gotten lost at all. There are indicators at the edge of your screen where stuff is. Sometimes finding/getting to the exit after completing the goals takes a minute but that's it.

9.5/10.

I was given this game by a fellow Redditor after commenting that this game looked awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051325657', 'num_games_owned': 1818, 'num_reviews': 271, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1496655499}
review:
Porté par des graphismes vraiment superbes et une BO extra ordinaire de Makeup & Vanity Set, Brigador est une tuerie pour tous les nostalgiques de Desert Strike et autres jeux dérivés.
Pour les autres, il sera peut être un peu trop exigeant, même si la Up-Armored Edition a amené tout un lot de mission "tutos" pour apprendre le jeu en douceur.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070712973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 777, 'last_played': 1623667747}
review:
Wonderful game that is hard to pidgeon-hole. It's not quite a twin-stick shooter, or a bullet hell, very much its own thing. It's challenging without being too punishing.

Two distinct modes provide plenty of content, and the freelance mode allows for all kinds of loadout variety, some really interesting and distinct weapons and mechs/tanks/agravs alter the gameplay in some unexpected ways. There is a LOT of variety here. A fully destructible mech playground.

The aesthetics and the music are outstanding, as is the general atmosphere and writing (there's tons of lore) - but don't be mistaken by thinking that's all the game has to offer - it's tactical and most importantly fun.

And it has loads of really cool mechs!! Who doesn't love mechs?

author: {'steamid': '76561198015092914', 'num_games_owned': 990, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 694, 'last_played': 1632058909}
review:
Занятная вариация на тему старинных игр. Суть в том, что ты - пилот меха\танка\антиграва, который служит на некую корпорацию и выполняет миссии в кампании или играет в типа "свободный режим", где ставятся задачи и гораздо больше вариативности в снаряжении. 

* Геймплей - ты пробираешься через восхитительно детализированные карты, разрушая всё, убивая врагов и выполняя задачи (сводящиеся в конечном счёте к разрушениям и убийствам). Полно всяких деталей и особенностей типа направления брони, механик тревоги, всего такого прочего.
* Графика - весьма приятная, без излишней пикселизации. Приятная анимация, хорошие для такой графики взрывы, да вкупе с полной разрушаемостью... Я думаю создатели потратили огромное количество сил на визуальную часть.
* Музыка и звуки весьма приятные. 3 часа саундтрека, однако - электронная музыка от каких-то не совсем ноунеймов, как я понял. Напоминает, кстати, слегка Хотлайн Майами, но здесь музыка более фонова.
* Сложность (сама по себе довольно высокая, но порог вхождения адекватный) варьируется довольно необычным образом - с помощью ускорения или замедления темпа игры, особенно актуально для тех, кто [strike]инвалид[/strike] вынужден по каким-то причинам пользоваться геймпадом. Кроме того сложность обуславливается ещё и выбором того или иного пилота\техники.
* Мультиплеера нет. Всё заточено под соло превозмогание, ничего от мультиплеера нет, даже вроде бы досок почёта.
* Сеттинг и лор - гримдарковое sci-fi. Недурно подаётся, но это если читать, озвучки текста нет совсем. 
* Русский язык завезли и ачивы сделали. В общем-то даже не очень бессмысленные.

Итого - отличный 2д шутер-рогалик в специфичном сеттинге, довольно простой в освоении, но сложный в прохождении и в деталях. Из минусов отмечу разве что не совсем понятное управление гусеничной техникой и блеклость элементов интерфейса - зачастую иконки задач и сам текст задач очень сливаются с происходящим на экране. В данном жанре - около 9 из 10, кмк.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026190743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1559689859}
review:
Smashing up a city in a neon-contrast industrial dystopia, tromping through suburbs and factories with equal disdain as you use your various abilities & 'mousehole' through walls (smash, but with finesse) to flank your enemies and take them down in droves. Ranges from zippy speeders to orky tanks to mechs, and all have their specialisations/loadouts. The campaign gives a good intro to the surprising range of challenges and tactical scenarios you'll find yourself in, and the Freelance mode is where you can truly put those skills to the test.

What the 80s dreamed of games being. ..And the 90s, to an extent. this is in no way a mech-simulationist game, but if you fancy isometric destruction with a surprising depth of lore behind it and an excellent 80s-esque synth soundtrack, this is it.

review: A great isometric mech shooter with tons of content. A good set of quick tutorials will get you up to speed quickly and give you a chance to learn the controls before it sets you off into a series of missions in the campaign. Beyond that there's a slew of freelance missions, a huge number of mechs (50+) to purchase as well as different guns, equipment, pilots, and more. It's a huge game, it controls well, and it's a lot of fun. Top it off with a great 80's style soundtrack and it's the perfect game if you just want to run around blowing up everything in sight.

review:
Just awesome. Reminiscent of the 16-bit Strike series but with mechs focused on blowing everything to hell. Great weapon/aiming mechanics and lite-stealth add depth to the combat. The sheer variety of chassis permutations afford multiple playstyles making this very replayable.

Had an absolute blast with the campaign which clocked 8-9 hours, that alone is worth it. 

Feels great with KB+M and features fully configurable gamepad bindings including 3 settings for targeting sensitivity (BRAVO).

I dig the tech noir aesthetic too.

It's a sealed deal man, Brigador is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993403749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1167, 'last_played': 1593357917}
review:
Brigador is an excellent though very challenging game. Depending on your choices (and level of skill!) the action ranges from carefully-planned, slow-paced assassinations to utterly chaotic brawls. Universally destructible terrain and massive chain explosions add to both ends of the spectrum. There are a wide variety of vehicles to choose from (mechs, tanks, and hovercraft are all available) which can be fitted with a similarly large pool of weaponry; some precise, some devastating. Much of the game's difficulty lies in the setup: figuring out which vehicle to choose, which weapons to fit on it, and which power (there are add-on abilities such as smoke projectors and active camoflage) to complete the package. The rest, of course, is in learning how to move and shoot. Also notable is the game's delight in corporatism. Everything--missions, pilots, vehicles, weapons, lore, even the details of your contract--must be purchased. In game terms, this means you slowly unlock a greater and greater repetoire as you complete free-play missions. There is also a serviceable campaign which works to introduce you to various playstyles, but the free-play is the primary experience.

All in all, a good time.

review: This is great! It's not just all shooting, crushing and exploding (there is plenty of that) it's also suprisingly tactical; you'll make use of flanking, suprise, ambushing, hit and run attacks, distraction and concealment to win and this all interacts the huge variety of vehicles at your disposal, from motorbikes to two story tall tanks. There's really nice detailed pixel art to stomp through and a good soundtrack. I knew it was great when I took a Killdozer out and spent my time ploughing through trees, popping out to crush tanks with my mighty ram and then dissapearing back through the trees, everything levelled in my wake.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988353678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1498429044}
review:
This is a fun little shoot-em-up, but where it really shines is the versatility when it comes to vehicles and weaponry.  You've got three basic models - mechs, tanks and hovercraft - but even within those divisions you get a great range of options.  The first tank you'll use is a slow but durable pounder.  The one I've had the most fun playing with is faster than any over the hovercraft I've seen and packs a pair of long range, decently powerful guns... with the tradeoff that it's the only vehicle I've seen thus far that only as a 180 degree firing arc and it'll crumple like a foil can if you get hit by anything major.

If you're leaving story mode behind and playing freelance, you can even design your own loadout.  Individual chasses have their set hardpoints, but you're permitted to use whatever weapons will fit in those hardpoints - assuming you've purchased them, that is.  Don't worry, this isn't full of microtransactions, you spend the cash you earn doing missions to get access to more pilots, chasses, weaponry, special abilities and background lore if you feel like reading it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145795066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1622690758}
review:
If you liked Desert Strike... Let’s face it very few people played Desert Strike, you don’t get the reference, even I didn’t played it, I played Nuclear Strike on PSone instead.


Anyway Brigador is NOT a twinstick shooter, it’s a strategic vehicle shooter, and with this last update revamping the tutorial and new playable vehicles you might be confused as to where to start, and that’s the point of this review:
So go to the options menu and set the controller mode to Relative, also set the gamespeed to 100 if you’re using M&K or 80 if you’re using a controller. 
Relative controls are the way the game is meant to be played; like you would expect a mech or tank to control except the perspective is isometric, but you’ll get used to that in no time.
Then start the campaign, the new tutorial is a bit “slow” mostly because there’s a lot of stuff to learn, after that the campaign ramps up in difficulty quite fast (I’m looking at you level 12).
Aside of that there’s a Freelance mode which is the rouge-like mode: You unlock pilots, vehicles, weapons and some sort of mini campaigns, the easiest pilots are a good way to practice, so pay attention to their difficulty multipliers before you buy a very hard one and get melted at the beginning of the mission.
SOME TIPS: Remember you can hold ‘E’ to turn in the direction your mouse is aiming, it makes navigation much faster when you’re not in combat. It’s also useful if you want to be sure you’re not exposing your rear as a tank since your front is always more armored (as a mech; hold shift to crouch instead). And I mean this: crouching as a mech and always showing your front to the enemy as a tank makes a huge difference in the harder difficulties. Also don’t forget to use your abilities, and ramming/stomping.

What else is there to say? The graphics are amazing, the lightning is like nothing you’ve seen on a 2D game, the vehicle designs are top notch, the soundtrack is genuinely memorable and the lore is cryptic and reminds me of Syndicate. It’s not just “look at me I have neon and synthesizers!!” Actual love and craftsmanship has been put into this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059299820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1626201867}
review:
A gorgeous gritty retro-futuristic aesthetic, a cracking 80's style synth soundtrack and lots of replay value once you get into the freelance operations. I like the lore too, you pick up bits here and there through reading various bits of intel/info (which is one of my favourite ways of finding out about a setting). The controls may take awhile to grasp but once it clicks movement feels satisfying and varied... a light Agrav feels very different to a hulking ultra mech. The devs have stuck with the game since the original launch and have just re-launched it with some additons and improvements and they are going to add even more vehicles over the next few months.

All in all it's a really fun game thats had a lot of hard work and love put into it, if you think you might like it just buy it, you won't regret it.

Also shout out to the devs for such a wicked game, I look forward to seeing more games from you in the future (hopefully in the same setting as brigador since its so awesome!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972040704', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 725, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1496603612}
review:
I played through the first fifteen missions (just over the one-third mark of campaign progress), and although it is clearly a competently-made game, with great music, surprisingly good controls, artistic cohesion, and far more tactical options than are initially implied, I didn't find the gameplay particularly compelling.

Whether it's a great plot (Bioshock, SOMA), a comedic plot (Portal), stealth gameplay (Deus Ex HR/Dishonored), bunches of tempting, persistent upgrades (Neon Chrome and others), there are numerous things that hook me in on a game. Unfortunately, Brigador's campaign contains nothing that makes me want to stick around and play more. Any lore must be purchased in-game using money earned from missions, the missions briefings and overall goals in the game didn't interest or excite me, there are no character interactions or fun personalities, and my reward for completing a level is just playing another level.

It's not a terrible game at all, but simply one that I get no real satisfaction or enjoyment out of, and anyone else of a like mind might have a similar experience. If there was a middling rating instead of a thumbs up/thumbs down, I'd go with that, but sadly there's not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005130199', 'num_games_owned': 1222, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1330, 'last_played': 1679853419}
review:
I'ts like good old Bedlam from my childhood, but with awesome graphics, soundtrack and overall feel to destruction.

Really neat neo-80s visual style, extreme attention to detail in every aspect to preserve overall theme and keep the glance value of dozens of playable vehicles and hundreds of destructable objects; speaking of which, everything in this game is VERY satisfying to blow up having a punch to it.

The OST fits the theme perfectly, keeps the rhytm of the game and doesn't get old after playing for nearly 20 hours. Looking to upgrade to the DDE just for the OST - it really is that good on its own.

Gameplay wise it's fantastic and keeps you wanting to go back and just blow up more things. You get a full-blown campaign, each mission is offered to finish with 4 different vehicles, giving you the choice between full-front assault on the enemy and sneaky hit'n'run tactics, where you can't take your chances to get overwhelemed by the enemy, have to use stealth, strategy and be careful about your surroundings. Or you could just steamroll through the enemy on a 3-story war machine. This is a really great way to offer variety to the gameplay, please different playstyles and easily quadruple the time spent in said campaign.
There's ton of different vehicles and weapons, and each has it's distinct feel an playstyle. Big vehicles and guns are slow and unmaneuverable but hit hard, and smaller guns are fast and precise. You can feel the clunkiness of a rotating tower and the heavyness of a 105 mm shell going through a house.

You're also offered a Freelance mode, for which you unlock vehiles, weapons, abilities and pilots and are free to combine them in different manner. Basically, its own sandbox. Pilots offer a variety of difficulty levels and pacing to the game, either you want things easy, go from easy to hard or crank up the difficulty to 11. 

EVERYTHING in this game has own lore which is damn fun to read and immerse yourself in the world of Brigador.

This game is a gem and a love child of a 5-people team, easily one of the best ones I've played in years. There aren't any games of this genre on my memory and Brigador is King.
Get it for yourself and your friends, it's really worth it. And there's a Linux version!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970633613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1588868842}
review:
Simply put, Brigador is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and executes upon that nearly flawlessly. 

When you first jump in you might think "Okay, so it's an isometric shooter with a ton of destruction." and depending on your preferences that alone might be enough to satiate you. Indeed, that core aspect does play very well. But there’s more than meets the eye here. While that is definitely the case and it definitely does deliver on that front, Brigador is also a game with a hidden depth. 

With a large variety of vehicles and weapons to choose from, all with their own strengths and weaknesses, Brigador offers many ways to realise that massive destruction. Do you want to run a hoverbike with shield shredding lasers and optic camo for a hit-and-run / stealthy glass cannon? Do you want to run a chemical spewing, lead wall blasting tank? How about a mech with cannons designed to snipe through cover? Choosing and tinkering with the method of obliteration is half the fun here.
 
The campaign gives you an environment to learn the ins and outs of vehicle types, weapon types and general mechanics. Freelance mode on the other hand gives you the opportunity to tailor gameplay to your liking, choosing overall difficulty, exact vehicle loadouts (or just randomize it for funsies) and the mission you want to play. 

However, I will say that from what I have seen mission types are a bit lacking across both modes and can generally be put into one of two categories; blow up specified buildings, or blow up specified enemy units. There are side-objectives but again, they’re mostly just variations of those two types. Additionally, I found myself getting caught on terrain occasionally but whether that's down to the game or just my situational awareness in combat not being what it should be, I don't know. 

Stylistically Brigador feels very much like a mid to late 90’s sci-fi game got lost somewhere in time and ended up getting developed in the modern era by mistake. From the general aesthetic to the animations to the music, everything captures those styles perfectly and gives them a nice new coat of paint. In particular the visual style reminds me a LOT of Command and Conquer: Tiberian Sun. 

Much like the mechanical depth of the game the amount of lore might not immediately be apparent, but there’s a lot of world building that went into the universe. Tidbits of information are given to you in the mission briefings, which give you an idea of the interactions between factions and what life is like on the planet and individual cities. Beyond that almost everything is given a backstory available to unlock and read from a screen in the main menu. And I mean almost everything. But if you’re not the kind of person that’s into reading the history of a world, you’re not obligated to. There’s no intrusive cutscenes or anything like that so if you just want to jump in and blow stuff up with no regard for plot or setting, you’re not held back from doing so. 

So all in all, Brigador is a fun, explosion filled game that’s pretty easy to pick up but with enough depth to keep it engaging, despite perhaps being slightly repetitive when it comes to objectives. It’s a game that is mechanically and stylistically on point and gives the player a lot of options. Brigador feels like something that was made with a vision in mind, and a game that used its inspirations to make something new instead of something derivative.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997715737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 1255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1122, 'last_played': 1647963989}
review:
On the day when I didn't want to play Overwatch, Skyrim, or anything at all really, I got email notification from steam about discounted game from my wishlist. "What the hell," I thought - "Somebody told me it was his personal Game of the Year 2016. About time I give it a shot". I gave it a shot and was blown away. I haven't had such experience since "Battletech", "Desert/Jungle/Urban Strike", back in the days of Sega Genesis. Fun, aggressive, destructive. Or maybe cold-blooded, stealthy and devastating? It depends on loadout. But satisfying anyway.

Edit: so I recently listened to audiobook that comes in Deluxe Edition, and I gotta say I just love Ryan Cooper's voice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979966109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1700947785}
review:
Brigador by all accounts a solid AA product.

Its controls are tight, easy to uses, easy to understand, and with enough depth that trying certain vehicles become extremely rewarding with their high skill ceiling required for operation.

The soundtrack is top notch and even a good listen outside of the game, themes similar to Hotline Miami are hard not to draw when it comes with the music but it has its own flavor of the dystopian future Brigador is set in.

The artistic style of the game shows the great care the developers put into the game, retro color grading with high quality models and world assets flow together seamlessly as the chimes of the music ring as you blast your way through the map all the while avoiding detection.

Its a blast, worth $20 bucks or at the least $10 and its hard not to wish for a future for Brigador.
9.5/10

review:
Really impressive. If this game had come out in the Sega Genesis era, you'd never be able to rent a copy from your local grocery store, because I'd have it rented out already. Don't fret, because when I finally got around to returning it, I'd have written tips, cheats, and secrets on all the back pages of the instruction manual as well as a freaky 10yr old's odd devotional to the developers. 
The gameplay perfectly captures so many of that golden era's proudest achievements, simple to get into, yet providing a great depth of loadout possibilities and tactical approaches.
Great setting, plenty of thoughtful lore in place. Nothing too pretentious or heady in the politics of wheres and whys. Doesn't treat you like an idiot, but seems intuitive enough for any idiot to dive into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021024729', 'num_games_owned': 1875, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 802, 'last_played': 1690063591}
review:
key来自HB的月包 非常棒棒的独立游戏
复古 色差 霓虹 美式机甲 这画风太骚 我拿不出抵抗力
作为2D游戏加入很多3D游戏的细节 比如抛物线 惯性 高度 对于破坏力的表现很到位 
三大类载具 机甲 坦克 悬浮车 可装配武器种类丰富 机炮 火箭 榴弹 磁轨枪 激光等等各有特色
不单是暴力强拆 还有潜行要素
在头一个小时内遇到了摇杆无死区 某地图和武器停止工作的问题 然而两天内推出了4个补丁修复好了多种问题
在评论区看到开发者有给很礼貌的回复 再看看业界 这态度简直要发朵小红花

攻击的时候有模拟弹道 瞄准远处开炮不会击中近处的低矮目标
而由于这个原因 手柄也要移动准心而不是类似“双摇杆射击游戏” 所以目前来讲适合键鼠操作

author: {'steamid': '76561197980372381', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1941, 'last_played': 1652005491}
review:
TL;DR: Such a great game. If you're interested at all, just buy it.

I won't go too in-depth with what the other reviewers have already covered. Amazing aesthetic, crazy fun gameplay, tons of variety. A world that is deep, but told 'in the background', somewhat like Dark Souls, through the mech descriptions, pilot backstories, weapon info, mission details, in addition to the lore unlockables. Crazy good soundtrack that I would've bought even if the game never existed.

What I do wanna stress though is how fuckin awesome the developers are. This game is very clearly a labor of love. All the detail they've put into it, the amazing support, consistently adding new content (like this new relaunch that added a bunch of stuff and just improved the game overall for FREE), and the fact that they are always engaging with the players. You don't often see a game that is so loved by the people that created it, and that is what makes Brigador such a brilliant game. 

Please get it so Stellar Jockeys/Gausswerks can keep adding stuff and developing new games. 

PS: For complaints about the controls; they've added alternate styles, but honestly, just practice with the default controls. It can be frustrating at first, but ultimately pays off.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966598434', 'num_games_owned': 1188, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1497106901}
review:
Brigador used to be an OK game with a great art style, a thumping soundtrack and some really neat ideas, but also some crucial problems which caused me to refund my purchase around last Christmas. The devs just pushed through the Up-Armored Edition update, and now Brigador is no longer an OK game. It's now an amazing game. 

The tweaks and additions may not seem that huge on paper, but in practise they make the game so much better. The controls are more intuitive and the game is more fun to play, there's achievements, new pilots, new missions (which do an amazing job of teaching the game) and the game has been extensively rebalanced and tweaked.

It's so great to see developers take a game that could be great if they could just polish it a bit more and then do just that. I am so happy that Brigador is finally as good as I hoped it could be. I definitely won't be refunding it this time :)
developer_response: Thank you very much for giving the game another try, and for leaving a review to that extent. It's easy to find a game that you don't enjoy and be done with it, we appreciate you giving the game another chance. We've listened closely to reviews like your old one and that's how we got to the current version of the game, so cheers. There are more levels, vehicles, and pilots yet to come!

review: I recieved this game from Humble Monthly and it is definitely my favourite lessor known indie title they have bundled in so far. So far I've played around 3 hours(partially offline) and my first impression is a good one. If you've played Mechassualt, then you have in essence played this. The controls are oddly similar but these have been adapted to an isometric point of view, so what you see is 2D but how you aim is 3D. I.e. You need to aim at the guy standing next to you or you'll shoot over him. That seems to be a draw back for many people, but I find the challange welcome. Much like Mechassualt you are placed in a sandbox with quasi-destructable environments. You won't see chuncks flying off where you shoot, but you will see buildings take damage and fall down Rampage style. Over all, this game feels like it could be ported straight to The Sega Saturn and not be out of place. It is definitely worth picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011830301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4096, 'last_played': 1669682251}
review:
Did you like the old Strike series of games on the SNES/Genesis? This game is for you.
Did you like Hotline Miami for it's soundtrack and it's colours? I suspect you'll enjoy this, too
Love twin-stick style shooters, blowing stuff up, and getting paid instead of penalized for collateral damage?
Or maybe you've just longed for the chance to mow down civilians effectively waving white flags while they run from your unstoppable war machine in terror (and also get paid for that, too)?

Welcome, Brigador.

This game is fantastic. Hands down. Does it have it's flaws? Sure it does. It can get a little repetitive, and I would certainly appreciate some quiet, ambient screams from the aforementioned civvies as I crush them under foot or iron tread, or just cut thrusters and drop my whole a-grav on them. But good golly, there's nothing else quite like this out there.

There's little tidbits of the story packed into everything you unlock, and it has this sort of air of mystery like you're on a 'need to know' basis that fits right in with the nature of what you are. 

I don't even know. Buy this game; there needs to be more stuff like this on the market.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961221174', 'num_games_owned': 2279, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1654398661}
review:
This game is awesome. I had no idea what to expect until I read the description on Humble Bundle and it sounded sweet. After installing it, I realize this is the Mechwarrior 3050 spiritual successor I never realized I needed. There are tons of mechs to unlock and different difficulties, and the game mechanics are surprisingly involved for what seems like such a simple game.

Also like MechWarrior 3050, there's a well developed back story (ignoring that MW is part of a 33 year old franchise now).  As the description on the store says, you play as mercenaries from one of three factions fighting against the corporatist jerk government that has basically taken control of the planet and ruined everything for everyone. It's a sufficiently interesting sci-fi backdrop for the gameplay, as far as I'm concerned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058616980', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1587347287}
review:
To sum up Brigador, it's a sandbox mission  based mercenary game where all you do is blow up buildings and enemies with a sick variety of weapons and vehicle chassis; which all inevitably will force you out of your comfort zone to make changes to your tactics for any combination you make for your machine of destruction.

Don't be afraid to die many times... once you learn the mechanics of the game (which won't take long) you feel that every death you make is entirely your fault.

review:
With the full update turning Brigador into Brigador: Up-Armored Edition I figured now would be a good time to voice my opinion on this diamond in the rough.

Immediately the soundtrack caught my attention even before I'd played the game, it's a crackin' synthwave eargasm from start to finish by Makeup and Vanity Set and if nothing else deserves a listen.  Everything sounds good overall; clunking metal footsteps of mecha, chainguns ripping through concrete and the ever delightful sound of a heavy cannon connecting with steel.

With a surprisingly indepth lore, solid controls, good vehicle and equipment variety I'd say take a look.  It's not often you find an immersive mecha title these days afterall.

GREAT LEADER IS DEAD
SOLO NOBRE MUST FALL

author: {'steamid': '76561198044082594', 'num_games_owned': 249, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1595951092}
review:
Brigador is super fun game where you pilot a mech/tank/hovertank/vehicle–with-mounted-weapons and take on a missions with fully destructible environment in an isometric perspective. There is a lot of lore to read (it's well written and interesting) and a lot of gameplay modifiers (a lot of vehicles, with different weapon loadouts, and various pilots) to unlock and use. The game offers a sense of progression as you unlock stuff. There's a campaign mode with a tutorial and some missions with set parameters. There is also a freelance mode, which is more like a sandbox which can last a number of maps depending on how you set your run.

The vehicle types feel different and control differently (the game is based on tank controls) but there are a lot of control options to tweak them to your liking. I play with a controller, and I do just fine. The vehicles themselves offer a lot of variety, have cool visual designs, and awesome lore associated with them.

The artwork for this game is amazing; I've never enjoyed looking at portraits so much. The UI is also quite pleasing. The music is also amazing (awesome John Carpenter-style 80s synth), so the soundtrack DLC is super worth it. 

The devs are also very friendly and approachable. They still support this game, and have had two free content updates so far. I can't believe I didn't know about this game when it first came out. It's shocking how it went unnoticed.

Wholeheartedly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995285260', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1571397235}
review:
This is the sort of game I never knew I wanted until I played it.  An absolutely brilliant take on isometric giant-robot-stompy-action, with style and wit to spare.

The only downside is that some of the mech & vehicle designs are goofy beyond compare (looking at you, Corvids).  All is forgiven once you get your hands on a Broodmare, though.  And even the Treehouse can be pretty epic once you realize the joys of a well-placed Audio-Kinetic Pulse, and exactly what that Ploughman is doing to your enemies.

Controls felt really strange the first time out, but it's worth it to take the time to get used to them.

...shoot, I think I'm gonna go play some more Brigador right now.  Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198096102732', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1524428737}
review:
Brigador é um jogo muito bem bolado com ação em perspectiva isométrica, muitos mechs e veículos variados, com gráficos e efeitos de iluminação bonitos e cenários destrutíveis. Ele lembra, na perspectiva, os jogos Desert Strike e Battletech do Mega Drive, mas em um nível de deatlhes e quantidade de inimigos muito maior.

Ele também vem recebendo atualizações constantes, que refinam a experiência de jogo cada vez mais e adicionam mais e mais conteúdo.

Um must para fãs de mechs, mas faço duas ressalvas: é um jogo DIFÍCIL, que requer precisão e que requer bastante habilidade. Além do mais, apesar de ser compatível com controles ainda precisa de um pouco mais de polimento no seu uso.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012959156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1519241726}
review:
Feel like I'm playing a mash up of Desert Strike (well, Urban Strike more accurately I guess), Walker (ooold amiga game I never actually got a chance to play) and general 16 bit era shooter mayhem (also reminds me of the Mechwarrior game on the genesis/megadrive/snes). There's a certain Syndicate flavour to the game world as well.

Shoot loyalists! Blow up tanks/walkers/buildings! DESTROY EVERYTHING!

The endless destructomatic fun also hides some fairly involved tactical play, use of flanking, defence abilities and special abilties really level the battlefield. Add in some stealth features and directional damage and you have a winning formula for fun, engaging combat.

Game lore also seems very deep and I look forward to delving into it! Coupled with an excellent soundtrack this is a solid reccomendation from me.

Note: the game pre "up armored" edition re release had "Relative" movement and 100% speed as the default gameplay style. I've personally found this to make for a more enjoyable game, screen absolute left me often wandering into corners. YMMV!
