author: {'steamid': '76561198061377149', 'num_games_owned': 1106, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 17982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3861, 'last_played': 1694613985}
review:
There's a lot of great things bout Brigador that have been pointed out by most of the other reviewers here, like the brilliant artstyle and music, fluid gameplay and surprising depth of the game mechanics.

But even with all of that, I doubt I'd have spent as much time in this game as I have - it is in Early Access after all and still lacks quite a bit of content. But thankfully this game is extremely easy to mod. I don't know anything about code, and I never modded any game before, yet in Brigador I was able to make an instagib mod, change all the weapons' attributes and make my own weapons, make enemies tougher, completely revamp the lighting, modify the movement behavior of all player vehicles and change the enemy spawnlists (and thus even get access to unimplemented content that was present in the gamefiles) - and most of those things can be done on-the-fly while in the game. On top of that there's a map editor as well. You could even make your own units, though for that you need experience in either 3D modelling or at least basic spritework - unless you're fine with recombining the existing leg and chassis parts which you can do pretty easily.

In short, pretty much every aspect of the game can be modified either in-game via a really handy and easy to use dev-console, or by basic text file editing in the gamefolder. That alone would already be enough for me to recommend this game, but since it's coupled with an excellent base game as well I really can't stress how much you'll get out of this game if you're even remotely interested in mech and tank games.

review:
Fun game.  Captures the essence of mech-fighting nicely; but from the negative reviews I had concerns about janky controls.  The controls are fine.  WASD is like tank driving and not like a cursor control- i.e. there is a pointer on the ground that indicates relative 'forwards' direction.  Turret is very rapid look and slightly delayed aim based on turret speed.  Since this is early release here are my comments:

~ would like options on how ground/direction indicator is displayed; maybe bigger/color/brightness
~ light enemy AI should have a higher priority on individual survival; seem eager to sacrifice self to do damage to player
~ variable speed option; i think it would be fun to be able to play at 70% normal speed to accomodate how frantic you want the experience to be
~ maybe auto-reload at depot and only require active when scavenging

Looking forward to playing this as it progresses.

Update:  Also hoding down 'e' will essentially make your feet follow your mouse view.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973755794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1623102714}
review:
I'll start by saying I have very little negative things to say about Brigador. The visual aesthetic; a  beautiful mash-up between classic 90's PC mech/strategy games, and the 80's neon retro-wave which has been coming back in a big way. Playing this has made me wonder why this pairing hasn't been before, as when combined with the amazing retro-wave soundtrack it makes an incredible overall look, sound, and feel. The HUD also feels pulled straight out of those old games, presented in a minimalistic fashion that fits perfectly. 

Now the gameplay is what makes Brigador truly stand out. The isometric view coupled with WASD + mouse will likely be slightly disorienting at first to those first picking it up. An hour or two into the game, there are moments where was still tripping up. Keeping evasive while also keeping on target is very challenging-- at first. Always keeping yourself properly oriented is a challenge-- at first. 

Oh, and let's not forget about aiming and shooting. THAT was very hard to get the hang of. I'm still getting better at it, too, which is satisfying in the way that good, challenging games are. However, I DO believe that the "aiming system" can be improved. After the number of hours spent playing-- essentially the amount of time it took me to beat 'The Tears of the Ancestors' mission-- I'm still only 90% sure I'm going to hit a guy AFTER I take my time getting oriented and ranged in. The isomentric view makes some angles very awkward for aiming. 

The only suggestion I can think of is to make the path of the projectile more clear by showing the point of impact. I will often overshoot or undershoot distant targets (with things like a basic tank-style cannon) because while I know my direction is correct, the "height" is harder to guage. 

Also, that mission was damn hard. DAMN hard. My vast majority of my 4-5 hours played were trying to beat that mission. However, after finally beating it, I felt two things: a disappointment that I didn't get another story mission to beat myself over the head with, and an overwhelming sense of satisfaction that I managed to beat the stage by incorporating all aspects of the game's depth. 

I used stealth and evasion, shooting through objects such as trees and buildings to hit enemies that couldn't see me, to take on the overwhelming amount of enemies. It was incredibly satisfying to overcome the mission by playing smart. 

That being said, I was still a little bummed out to have not gotten another story mission, but this game is in Early Access for a reason, so I'm not knocking the game or devs for it. Of course more missions/content and balancing will be coming.


Here's a TL;DR to wrap it up. 

-The visuals and music are fucking incredible. 
-Gameplay is complicated and must be learned through practice. Lots of practice. 
-Guaging distance (not direction) when aiming your shots is the hardest part about the controls. I believe this can be remedied. 
-The game is HARD in a way serious players will really dig into. Not sure about casual players.
-Surprising amount of depth; makes for satisfying gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982025140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 9384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1707467525}
review:
Early Access Review:

A solid little title.

Probably best described as a good blend of SCHMUP and Strategy isometric shooter, Brigador is currently sitting in my 'Gem' folder - and it's only in Early Access.

Pumping, pulsing electronic soundtrack; neon lights from environment and gunfire; beautifully rendered sprite environment (which is fully destructable and with multiple stages of damage being detailled just as finely through their beautiful art style).  People have compared it to Syndicate although I never played.  It feels more like a Crusader mixed with Mech Commander to me.

Pilot one of several mechs/tanks/hovercraft with a selection of primary/secondary weapons and a special skill (stealth/assault modifier item) and murder your way through a city for the good of the people!

There are -currently- 4 'zones', of which the first three contain 4 levels.  The final zone being the 'Solo Nobre' of the trailers which has 12 levels within.  There is currently no save feature, so running an assault on Solo Nobre is quite the marathon (if you can make it in and out alive).  Enemies initially are light and sparse but quickly ramp up to heavy and thick in numbers as you progress, creating a tense and exhilerating environment to literally shake to the ground.

At this point in time, it still feels 'bare' in that there is no story, the pre-mission screens are sparse and look like under construction, certain assets appear to be missing, and it's really just 'the game' without bells or whistles at the moment.  

The game however plays and feels excellent and is still having things added to it.  

If you're a fan of shmups, isometric action/tactics (real time) or cut your teeth on Mechwarrior or Heavy Gear (or the like) as i did as a child, this is definitely something to either get, or watch the price on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027373027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1498049014}
review:
Did you ever play Desert Strike or Jungle Strike back in the 90s? Did you ever wonder what it would be like to play as a tank instead of a helicopter? If you did this game might be for you.

 If you didn't Brigador is a great isometric tank/mech/antigrav piloting game where, at the moment,  you can only do runs on a smaller number of maps(more will be added) with two objectives: Kill enemy captains or destroy orbital cannons, both are available which to complete is up to you. There will be pilots and pilot centric missions added later with a shop system to buy weapons and such ingame. Devs plan to have a large number of vehicles and weapons added with a decent number ingame already.

Most common complaints ive seen deal with the tank controls, which take a bit of getting used to but once you do I think they are the best choice for this type of game. 

Now, as for what you can do with the game and some of the most fun things I see in it.
-Ambushes with smoke grenades
-Lobbing artillery barrages over walls to decimate an unwary group of enemies
-Dropping an EMP grenade in the middle of a group of antigrav tanks and going to town on them
-Squishing infantry with a tank
-Squishing tanks with a mech
-Plowing through walls in the tanks and mechs
-Piercing walls and subsequently my enemies with a powerful rail gun
-Bombing an orbital cannon with two shotgun cannons 
-Using active camo to hightail it before enemies arrive
-Driving an old chevy turned into a antigrav racer, turned into a hit-n-run vehicle armed with ridiculously large guns
-Finding out what parts of the destroyable terrain explode much more violently than others
-Learning those little guys with lasers do actually hurt 
-Frying those little guys with my laser
-Learning armor facing does in fact make a difference for tanks
-Running over innocents that look like they are all wearing yellow raincoats
-Running out of ammo and ramming an enemy tank to death from behind
-HATE motorcycles
-Stray projectile blows up an ammo depot I desperately needed
-Blows up an ammo depot I was about to use by driving into it
-Chain reaction of exploding buildings caused by myself or anyone else
-Realize antigrav tanks can strafe
-Strafe into explosives by accident while dodging enemy fire

In case you forgot while reading those, this is all things I liked. Theres not much I dont like about this game, I definitely recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975466250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1511185156}
review:
Brigador is the ambitious and exciting debut from independent developer Stellar Jockeys, boasting lavishly rendered isometric spritework whose variety of design styles and nighttime-neon colour palette fit perfectly with an unforgiving, crisp control scheme to remind me of the classics of the 1980's and 1990's (Akira, Mechwarrior, Blade Runner) in both gameplay and looks. 

It's important to note that the game is in early access, the way the term was likely intended to be used. The developers are actively following a development roadmap that sees them churning out maps and vehicles as they continue to build the game around the existing skeleton you can play here. Yes, the current experience is rough if you are expecting a paid beta experience: the menus are barebones, most of the sound effects are missing, there's a lot of functionality on the cards such as an unlock system and selectable pilots that we won't see for a while. That's okay, because it means the majority of work has gone into fine-tuning the game's systems to create an enjoyable and frentic experience best likened to a curious mix of [i]Syndicate Wars[/i], [i]Desert Strike[/i], [i]Future Cop: LAPD[/i] and the [i]Mechwarrior[/i] titles on the Super Famicom which featured similarly isometric views and wanton destruction.

Brigador's difficulty is, once you're familiar with the simple controls and the flow of the game, somewhat self-imposed. You can identify pretty quickly which of the game's vehicles (tanks, mechs and antigravs) gels with your playstyle the most and then which weapons you find the most useful on top of that. Whether you go with the same pair of big, kick-ass cannons in every run or try to mix it up a little is up to you, and the vehicle mounts available. The longer you stick around, and the more maps you complete, the more difficult the enemies you'll find coming at you. If you're low on shields and ammo and aren't feeling like you can weather another big fight, the option is always there to hit up the spaceport as your next map and fight your way to an escape.

The soundtrack, by New Retro Wave artist Makeup and Vanity Set, is pretty damn good. It's not just playing at the 80's throwback fad half-heartedly, it's lurid and drenched in neon with big, dramatic synth. The only downside is the song selection is another aspect under development: the game just picks from a playlist right now and runs through it. What's there is great, though, and helps make up for the lack of sound effects currently implemented.

The game is by no means perfect, but it's short and sweet and to the point. For something so heavily under development, what's playable is incredibly crisp and very enjoyable. Whenever you die, it usually feels like it was something you did wrong rather than getting caught out by imbalanced mechanics or shitty bugs. The onus is on Stellar Jockeys to keep the pace of development up, because the quicker this game's skeleton is built on, the quicker the attention is going to snap to it. If you're scared off by the very minimal trappings of a game under construction then you probably don't want to buy Brigador just yet. On the other hand, if you like the idea of tossing some change to a handful of guys making a very earnest and solid shooter with a bumping soundtrack, go for it. Unlike most of the early-access survival FPS pixel garbage on Steam, this is actually fun and cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998994075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1575845587}
review: Grief is a watery emotion, prone to slopping over the side of any container it occupies--and so it takes a project like Stellar Jockeys' Brigador, with gameplay that moves fluidly, to truly capture it. Though it only comprises four major areas, the levels contained are so finely crafted that it's a work worth returning to, playing again and again, and exploring within. It is a work about grief, yes, but a work wholly without self-pity, a work that urges slowly forward. It is a work about how grief ebbs eventually, with attention and time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999656616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 938, 'last_played': 1496489954}
review:
[h1]filled with vehicular tachtical action![/h1]
[b]Is there anyone who have felt like operating combat vehicles  by yourself while playing Mech Commander?
I am that one, and this game makes the desire come true with cool visual and addictive soundtrack.[/b]
 
This game, 'Brigador', brings you to series of vehicular combat in futuristic urban environment.
You are a mercenary pilot of mechs, tanks or anti-grav crafts, and you just engage in subversive activities on the city of a colonized planet.
Being more specific, Objective is eliminating a certain number of garrison, terminating all captain units, or destroying all orbital guns in the sector.
After that, you will escape with your life and reward by getting to a sector gate or a evac-spaceship.

[b]The combat mechanics are simple but deep, and they are quite skill-based. [/b]
[h1][Movement and Shooting][/h1]
Turret rotation and legs operation are separated (like 'Mechwarrior' or 'WoT'). 
Operating turret by mouse, steering by [W][A][S][D] keys.

When you drive anti-grav assault guns, chassis rotation is operated by lateral mouse movement, and [A][D] keys are used for strafe exceptionally.

Maneuverability varies by vehicle spec.. 
The heavier or the more robust the machine is, the lower maneuverability it has.

The player vehicles carry 2 guns and 1 special equipment (smoke/EMP/optical camouflage) . 
Mouse Button 1 for firing gun 1, Mouse Button 2 for firing gun 2, and Mouse middle button (wheel click) for activating equipment. 
Guns and equipment have various ballistic specification.

aiming might be felt hard cause inertia works slightly, but I like this realism.

[h1][Resource management][/h1]
You have to manage health, shield, ammo, and cooling/reloading time.
Health is not regenerative during a contract(series of missions), but shield energy can be refilled by enemy drops. 
Ammo also can be recharged by enemy drops and ammo stations located in the sector. 
Guns and equipment have reload/cooling time. take care of it.

[h1][Damage variety][/h1]
Damage dealt varies by the status of caution (detected by foe or undetected). 
Also it varies by hit direction. 100% for front, 140% for side, and 200% for rear.
If you sneak up behind the enemy, you can knock it down easily.

[h1][Destroyable environment][/h1]
You can make your path and line of fire by smashing shacks, houses, walls, barricades, plants, and etc.

[h1][Explosive objects][/h1]
You will see some explosive objects in the sector, e.g. gaspipes and ammo stations. You can utilize them as powerful weapons. In some cases, you may  suddenly kill yourself by ramming into those explosives  as well.


This game is simple but still offers a many choice of tactics.
It may rely on chassis spec, weapons, equipment, resources and situation(enemy position/environment).
I really love those choice and making attempts.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992733052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1648841270}
review:
Depuis 2016, je relance de temps en temps.

Contrairement aux apparences initiales, ce n’est pas un "twin stick shooter" rapide et bourrin, c’est bien plus lent et tactique, et c’est très bien ainsi merci.

Les commentaires sur les contrôles "bizarres" ne sont plus d’actualité. D’une part, dès le début les contrôles étaient bons, en "mode tank", il fallait seulement se donner 10 minutes pour s’habituer. D’autre part, depuis, les développeurs ont ajoutés de nouvelles options pour adapter les contrôles à tous les goûts.

En attendant la suite, Brigador Killers, normalement pour 2020/2021, j’ai une fois de plus relancer le jeu, et après 4 années, il vieille très bien, et restera à mon avis intéressant encore longtemps. Les choix visuels également font qu’ils ne souffrent pas vraiment du temps, contrairement aux jeux "photo réalistes" qui sont dépassés par une nouvelle technologie ou technique le jour de leur sortie.

Bref, Brigador, c’est bon.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slSNpVnrnrA

author: {'steamid': '76561197997475039', 'num_games_owned': 523, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1516859119}
review:
This is a prelim review for early access, just to get the word out.  Brigador is an isometric vehicular shooter with fantastic production values and excellent look and feel.  The devs have focused early resources on the core gameplay, which is really quite good.  Even with the small subset of weapons and vehicles now available, the game manages to pull me back every so often just so I can experience that kick-ass, blow shit up feeling one more time.

That gameplay features a modest number of player vehicles which fall into three categories: Mechs, Tanks and Anti-gravs.  Mechs have high acceleration and modest speed, but have a powerful stomp attack that is devastating to grounded enemies and the environment.  Tanks can boost for short periods to plow through the same at high speed (although the 'Dragon' actually slows down, it pretty much obliterates anything it touches).  Anti-gravs are unique in that they turn their entire chassis to aim, but they can move in any direction and can float over short obstacles.  They also slam the ground, but typically deal substantially less damage than the mech or tank equivelant.

The weapons available have varying statistics of shield damage, hull damage, environment damage, penetration and rate of fire.  At this point, ammo doesn't appear to be used to balance weapons, but is simply commensurate with the rate of fire.  Each vehicle can mount two weapons.  Usually these are weapons of different size categories, but some vehicles have two of the same mount.  The weapon balance is currently spotty, due to the fact that the unlock system has not yet been implemented and we're likely several balance passes away from 1.0 as it is.  Some weapons are fantastically effective, like the tank cannon (can't remember its actual name), while others are less than spectacular (the 8mm burst-fire, for example).

Brigador features a host of mechanics that really bring the visceral combat to life.  The AI is excellent in that it relies on line of sight, as well as the sound of weapon fire to locate the player.  The enemies start off basically flat-footed, many with their shields unpowered.  If you get the drop on them, you can take down quite a few hit-and-run style.  The moment you join battle though, nearby enemies will start closing in to investigate.  If you hide at this point, it's quite doable to avoid contact or better yet, lead your enemies into a killzone of your choosing.  Attacking enemies from behind is literally twice as effective as shooting their fronts, so it's often better to hit them on your terms than to simply charge into the middle of them.  You can use the environment to your advantage by setting off devastating chain reactions from explosive structures or by attacking the enemy through the very obstacles blocking them from returning fire.  Even the height of individual units is important, with the 'tower-like' enemies being able to spot and return fire over low-obstacles, whilst the tanks and infantry are stuck moving to get a shot.

As other reviewers have said, the price point is high for the content the game currently has, but let's be frank; This is Steam.  The dev needs to set their price point high if the game is going to display value to potential backers, and so that it can still be an equitable return when the inevitable Steam sales roll through.  It also means that they can get additional resources early on and not live in squalor hoping their game will make it big when it leaves early access, which we all know is /far/ from a guarantee; It's a fool's gamble.  For what it's worth, the game in its current state easily convinces me that the dev can fulfill their remaining content goals within the six months they've given themselves.

EDIT: Oh, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the excellent original score.  It's a high-tempo, arcade-style throw-back to 80's action movies that suits the aesthetic and general tone impeccably.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963563784', 'num_games_owned': 894, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1445964135}
review:
Brigador has just released on Steam Early access and we're taking a quick look at it in its current early stages. 

Brigador is a isometric tank shooter with a few different play styles. You can play brigador sneaky deaky like and cloak or if your the Arnold type rush in guns blazing.

Currently there are 9 vehicles to pilot ranging from hover tanks, to mechs, to something that looks straight out of a red necks fantasy... yep an el camino with a giant monster cannon.

Your goal in one of these vehicles is to either sneak or shoot your way into various locations and destroy the glorious leaders cannons, generals, or just massacre a percentage of his army.

The controls are a bit difficult at first to get used to as you must handle your turret, your legs/tank (which rotate separately) while maintaining aim with your guns and their ranges. Meaning 3 things at once which I am rather poor at.

If this hectic gameplay isnt your style there are hover tanks you can use that have locked turrets. Keep in mind the developers have promised 40+ new vehicles coming before Brigador leaves steam early access.

That being said after a few hours with the game the controls get simpler. I found the sniping / sneaking gameplay to be my forte as it let me move slowly and set things up as opposed to the large hectic fights where I ended up slamming into the walls screaming at my keyboard.

Overall I think Brigador is a solid game for being at the early stages of development. I do think the price point is a bit high but once the game is finished it will definitely be worth that cost.

My only real complaint with the game was the controls and thats more my fault at being an old man than the fault of the game.

My full video review is linked below
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJehhe4PT1U

author: {'steamid': '76561197990017174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1615584878}
review:
If you've ever played mechcommander, mechwarrior, future cop or really any game with a mech on the cover you'll likely enjoy Brigador. If you liked classic westwood C&C games environments, attention to detail and music, Brigador will likely give you nostalgia. If you simply like quick and easy to play action games like nuclear throne or spelunky, Brigador is going to appeal to the same style of fun.

In a way the game is incredibly simple, you can just run in and shoot things until you get to the end, but it's so well made that the simplicity only really helps the game. You pick a vehicle, two guns and a special weapon (I recommend smoke grenades with the tauro mech) and need to complete one of three objectives per area, all of which involve blowing things up. Enemy AI allows for you to either stealth your way in or out, maneuver your way around at high speeds dodging shots, or simply bust your way through walls crushing anything in your way. 

Despite all this, the game is tough: you cannot regain health at all except by killing enemies to regain your shields, so avoiding damage by killing fast or playing smart is essential if you want to get to the end and off of the planet. Ammo management is also an issue, as you need to either harvest it from your enemies without blowing it up first or regain it from depots that correspond to your ammo type, which are often surrounded by enemies. Keep in mind that if you don't need the ammo type, you can just use the depot as an explosive to still save you some shots. An added layer of difficulty comes from optionally playing as lighter, more agile mechs that definitely require finesse to control compared to other options such a pillar of scrap on treads. You can expect any vehicle to reward you if you use it right however.

As a game Brigador is definitely fun, as a mech game Brigador plain rules. The perspective, graphics, explosions, destructible environment and hordes of enemies you take down really make it feel like you're a piece of heavy weaponry and not just a reskinned human. If you like mechs, buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983548320', 'num_games_owned': 3595, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1650188800}
review:
Brigador is a tactical isometric shooter where every thing in the environment is destructible. At the time of this review, the game is still incomplete but shows a lot of promise in it's well designed gameplay.

Brigador is a challenging game to say the least. A player's first inclination is to shoot everything in sight, but you'll quickly learn that strategy will get you killed pretty fast. Your ammo is limited, your HP don't regenerate, and the game features a perma-death system. With out careful planning and strategic thinking, you'll become scrap metal in an instant. The game has a high learning curve, and an equally high skill ceiling. The game makes no concession to casual players.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Hf5arkwBc8&ab_channel=aldershot8008
The goal of the game is to enter an enemy territory, shoot out 3 of their cannons, and then get the hell out of there. It sounds simpler than it actually is. In any given map, there will be tons of enemies swarming to blow you up if you're not careful, as well as environmental hazards. Gas pipes, oil stations, and other things can easily blow up in your face ending your run. Then there are mud, tracks, and sand that will slow you down. Though there are hazards, the environment is completely destructible, allowing you to make your own path to the goals, avoiding the dangerous main roads. 

Before even starting your mission, you'll be able to pick your vehicle, weapons, and special abilities. there are 6 different vehicles that are variations of 3 different types, tank, mech, and hover. Tanks have good Armour and speed, while mechs can use a powerful stomp, and hovers can strife and are the quickest, but they're balanced with low armour and HP. They all have their own unique characteristics and stats, and the same can be said about the weapons and specials as well. The game offers a fair degree of customization and experimentation, allowing the player to tailor their ship to their play style.

Brigador also features detailed but visually clear sprites in an isometric environment. The aesthetics have a classic PC look to it, and it's one of my favorite elements of the game. The art is interesting, full of nuance, and does a good job at communicating it's overall theme and atmosphere of a dystopian future. The sound design is also quite pleasing, with an appropriately futuristic OST and sound effects that has impact. However, since the game is in early access, some sound effects aren't implemented and is distracting from what is an otherwise polished presentation.

There's a lot of stuff to like about the game, it's presentation, it's skill oriented gameplay, and the destructible environments, however in it's current state, the game does feel incomplete. Currently, there is only one mode to play, endless mode, nothing to unlock, no stat tracking, and no story mode. So basically, the game is bare bones feeling very very beta. Of course it's in early access and these things are to be expected, but it is something worth mentioning for any one expecting a complete game. Bragador does not feel complete. There is a lot of room to grow and I am excited to see where it goes. One feature I really would like to see added is some kind of multiplayer. But until the game is further updated / released, it doesn't give much incentive for the player to keep playing, other than it's core gameplay, and maybe experimenting with different combinations of weapons and ships. 

Overall, Brigador is a very promising game, that in my opinion, has the potential to be a cult favorite. All the game need to do now is to fill itself out a little. Give the player a reason to come back regularly. We'll see how it'll turn out once it's a full release, but so far, so good.

Pros:
- Great classical looking visuals
- Challenging and rewarding gameplay
- Destructible environments
- customization

Cons:
- Missing sound assests
- limited game modes
- Feels incomplete

Brigador hours played: 3
Completion Status on Brigador: N/A
This copy of The Brigador was given by the developer

author: {'steamid': '76561197973265826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1566917999}
review:
Cool game. It plays like if Syndicate and Future Cop LAPD had a baby, it's really fast, fun, and challenging plus it has an amazing sound track and really cool detailed sprite work.

It's still a little rough around the edges since it's only just launched on early access but unfinished UI elements and weird sound and level transitions aside, the gameplay is completely solid and well worth checking out. It has that awesome addictive quality where I want "just one more run" every time I die (and you will die, often), and with so many functionally different vehicle and weapon loadout options no two runs ever play the same.

I definitely recommend this, especially to anyone that enjoyed old 90's iso shooters, or anyone that enjoys action rogue-lite shooters like binding of isaac.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966124980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1549587264}
review:
[b]Confession:[/b]

Slightly biased towards the devs of this game, but only because I've watched them polish this game for quite a while. What it started from, the assets they hand crafted themselves (didn't borrow or steal), the fact they got a great musician that actually fit their game to work with the sound track and so forth sell me a game. I think of it as investing in someone's idea and dream as much as buying a product. They always chatted me up and answered my questions, so I  pre-ordered this long before Steam was even a reality. I'd probably give them a positive review even if the game were a steaming heap.... which it's NOT.

[b]Controls:[/b]

While this game can be a frantic iso-mecha-tric shooter, the controls are very much akin to tanks and mecha. Which means A and D will swivel the torso, W and S and will move front to back,  while mouse actually moves the aim. This takes quite a bit of getting used to, but tip is to look at the spotlights that the vehicle shines on the ground. One will be for the body/movement and one will be for aiming. The problem as it stands now is they can be harder to distinguish, become blocked by terrain/obsticles and generally get disorienting. I wouldn't have the game control any other way, however. It's true to the idea behind the vehicles and its something a bit fresher feeling over the generic point/click/move. There is a skill curve that makes sense and it's not just throwing square wheels on a car to make it harder to drive. This game will be something you will get better at playing as you play it. If you want a game you can sit down and be great at and win immediatly, then consider something else.

Tip: I'd recommend starting with the tank as the graphic serves a much better indication as to how to control it.

[b]Tactics:[/b]

The control set actually lends itself to a slightly slower gameplay that requries a bit of tactical movement on the players behalf. This isn't a game where you will endlessly kill mindless enemies. Your ammo is quite limited, though can sometimes be refilled by random towers or rare drops. Position matters where you shoot the enemy. Charging things without considering that you are just wasting ammo by shooting them from the front is bad form. You do more damage from the side or the back, so dodging and timing shots can be much more benefical over going pure John Rambo. There are also "Special" weapons. Smoke bombs which obstruct enemy view so it can help escape and positioning. Camo for the sneaky type and EMP grenades that I just rarely use.

Tip: To save ammo, use your melee attack on smaller enemies like footmen and in desperation against light craft. Stealth can combine with this for fun results.

[b] World Design [/b]

Isometric was just a perfect choice. It's very reminiscent of the 16/32 bit era of "Strike" games which pleases me greatly. Everything can be destroyed and you can carve a path through the level with your machine. Each weapon can affect the enviroment differently and of course there's explosive structures that can be used tactically. 

Tip: Blow everything up. It's cathartic.

[b]Soundtrack:[/b]

As a huge fan of synthwave/cyberpunk music, I was already a fan of Makeup and Vanity Set. His soundtrack for this game just helps a great deal setting the atmosphere. It's always nice to see a game seek someone that works better than just getting someone to fill in because their cousin can make beats. The soundtrack is very much part of the game. It's not just an afterthought asset at the bottom of the budget. Devs take note!

[b]Content:[/b]

As far as content, there is much much more to be added. I'll update this review accordingly to reflect this. Right now you can do basic runs and it's generally a sandbox with everything unlocked. You have complete mission freedom. You can kill a set number of enemies, find the commanders and kill them all or take out a few of the orbital cannons and advance to the next. In the future there will be unlocks and money as well as many more missions and tilesets. Also coming will be controller support, which may be a better alternative for the controls for some.

[b]Verdict:[/b]

A very thought-out design from top to bottom. The dev/brother team knew what they wanted to make and executed in a masterclass fashion. They have built an amazingly solid housing for their game. Now, the rest is just moving some more content into it and making the price tag more tempting.  The price doesn't bother me in the least. In a world of cheap sales, that only bring disposable titles or F2P games that are more timetraps than video games, I'd always pay premium for something like this. 20$ is hardly "premium" pricing though. I would have paid half that for the soundtrack alone.  This is a game I can revisit because after all it's actually a video game. Not storybook on rails or a grindfest because grinding because modern video games. Also: MECHA!!.. extremely underused theme.

review:
最初に結論ですけど、すぐ買わなくて良いボリュームです
2,000円という強気な値段に見合っていません。

この辺でしょうか。

あとはコレに未実装パーツ、武装が追加されて、欲を言えばCOOPや

そういう部分をひっくるめて、このゲームがもっと売れてくれる事を祈ります。

author: {'steamid': '76561197992384886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1496447780}
review:
This is a really fun, frenetic isometric action game. The controls are tight and responsive, although they may take a bit of getting used to. Enemies are diverse in both attributes and behavior, and the environments are dense and interesting. I really respect the devs for choosing to not color every explosive element red, although I cursed their names the first time i discovered this fact.

The graphics are excellent. I don't know what voodoo magic allows such accurate-looking lighting effects in a 2d game, but it is strong, and arcane. You really have to see it in motion to appreciate it. The overall visual density is high, and honestly pretty busy, but it gets much easier to read the action after a few games.

The game presents a stiff challenge, but not an unfair one. At first you'll find yourself overwhelmed by all the threats coming at you from every direction, but soon you'll learn how to use the environment to your advantage and manage the flow of battle. Smoke is your friend!

There are six vehicles to choose from in the current build (there have been more in pre-release builds and certainly will be again) and many different weapons, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. This level of choice is one of the game's greatest strengths, but may also be the biggest stumbling block for new players, since it's easy to choose a loadout that doesn't have good synergy, and get completely owned.

Pro tip: try the loyalist mech "Touro" with the cannon "Abbot", machine gun "Mae Dois", and smoke launcher. It's a very powerful combo. But definitely don't stick to it! Try all kinds of things and have a great old time.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes arcade or action games, as well as anyone who thinks trucks, tanks, and mechs are cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971370408', 'num_games_owned': 756, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1444858270}
review:
When I was first presented with the opportunity to cover Brigador, I’ll admit, I had no clue what it was. I did a little bit of research and discovered the upcoming game, being developed a group of four guys under the name ‘Stellar Jockeys‘, striven to be a isometric hybrid of ‘Syndicate‘ and ‘Mechwarrior‘. After reading that I was determined to jump into Brigador without any further knowledge of the game and see how much fun I had, and let me tell you; I had a ton of fun.

Damn is Brigador a beautiful game. The game is set in the bright and bustling isometric cityscape of Solo Nobre. At launch there are nine very detailed levels/districts to Solo Nobre, each with their own unique but similar layout. At the beginning of each mission (dubbed contract’s in the game), you choose from one of three categories: tanks, mechs, and anti-gravity vehicles. The tanks are typically defensive, the mechs primarily offensive, and the anti-gravity vehicles are fast. Each mech has it’s own weapons and play style as well as toughness when taking damage.

From here you’re thrown into the contract you selected and begin dishing out massive destruction to anything and everything in the district. The entire map is fully destructible, including attacking enemy vehicles, all of the buildings and enemy defenses, and even the civilians attempting to flee the city from your carnage. There are quite a few unique weapons in Brigador, all of which take some getting used to. You move using the W-A-S-D and a mouse, but it’s not as simple as it sounds. The movement is similar to Resident Evil in that you use the A and D keys to rotate your vehicle in places, W to move forward, and S to move backwards. You have a red and a blue line that project from your vehicle in different arcs and help show you where your weapons will be fired. Using this system you can aim high, low, and even around buildings to take out aerial or ground enemies at command.

Brigador is tough. On top of the intricate(but fair)movement system, the enemies themselves are quite challenging. By design, there is no saving or restarting, so you must play through the district’s clearing out enemies and completing the objectives of your contract to move forward. While keeping track of your ammunition is certainly important, there are ammo stations scattered across each map, and defeating some enemies will result in them dropping ammo packs to replenish your ammo. That being said, successfully completing a level carries over your current ammunition counts and health, meaning to ‘beat’ the game you would have to complete each district in one sitting and straight playthrough.

If you’re a fan of isometric ‘top down’ shooter type games, Brigador is definitely for you. As I mentioned before, it’s an extremely beautiful game, and a ton of fun. Destroying the city of Solo Nobre while wiping out your enemies and completing your contracts does require a bit of strategic shooting, but is enjoyable the whole way. While the game itself was a bit too difficult for me to successfully clear all districts in one sitting, I feel as though that’s necessary with a game like Brigador. The only thing I’d ask for is perhaps more of a story or campaign rather than just “Complete Objectives in all Districts’, but after playing through all of them there is definitely the feeling of some repetition.

Brigador enters early access on October 20th at the price of $20 on Steam and Humble and plans to add more content throughout the early access stage.

This review score is based on its Early Access launch. We may or may not do another review for this game once it enters the full retail launch phase.

http://gametabloid.com/review/brigador

author: {'steamid': '76561197976565059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 11699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4490, 'last_played': 1624925443}
review:
The soundtrack is good. The visuals are good. The mechanics are good. The map design is good.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dl0O9iohLRw

Brigador's a good mech game, which seems to be a rare commodity these days. It's an isometric shooter with systems bigger and more complex than 'put your mouse on the bad guy robot and press the button,' the biggest of which is the aiming system, since it's three-dimensional. You can overshoot or fall short of targets, and the camera works in conjunction with this. Unlike another recent top-down shooter with a banging synth soundtrack, the shifting camera won't give you motion sickness, and you won't get oneshot from offscreen. Differing armor values for front, sides, and rear (for enemies AND for players) means that flanking isn't just viable, it's vital, and different acceleration, handling, and speed while traveling in different directions in different vehicles means that even two vehicles of the same class feel and play differently. 

Your tower tank can plow through enemy and environment alike while absorbing blow after blow; your mech can peek and retreat around corners, fire over low walls or crouch to hide behind them, and stomp anything that dares get close; your main battle tank is fast and maneuverable with a low profile and a speed boost for hit-and-run attacks; and your antigrav can weave in and out of buildings, strafe targets without exposing vulnerable side armor, or belly flop on enemies who make the mistake of letting you get close. 

I've been playtesting the game since early alpha builds and the progress it's made is astounding. The game is gorgeous and never stops being fun to play. 60 hours later I still constantly get the itch to boot it up and throw together a new build to see how far I can get with it. There's really no game on the market that plays quite like it. This game is good and you should buy it.

Also protip: equip the Parliament.

review:
The core gameplay is frantic, satisfying, and simple to pick up.  High skill curve.  Treaded vehicles, walkers, power armor and hovercraft offer a pretty wide variety of playstyles.

The big negative I will list for this game is that the controller support, as currently implemented, is honestly pretty bad.  I highly recommend that you play with the default mouse and keyboard scheme.  

Do you like to actually play video games?  You'll probably like Brigador.   Spraying down McMansions with white phosphorous while trucking over picket fences in the Killdozer never felt so good.

Grande.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972309272', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1547838352}
review:
Brigador is really cool. I've been playing it for a long time and it's gotten better and better. It's a great looking game with tricky but well crafted controls, and strong, intuitive mechanics. and a lot of work has gone into making it hard without making you hate it or want to quit. This isn't a roguelike, but you will need to cultivate true roguelike spirit to play Brigador: you will die often, it will always be fair and your deaths will come from your own mistakes or overconfident actions, and the only good response is to roll up a new brigador and try again. There are a ton of vehicles and guns and the combinations lead to pretty wildly divergent playstyles. 

The 'setting' and 'lore' are all under the surface. you won't be reading morrowind books here, you'll just get a feel for the world from the experience of playing in it and destroying your home city and everyone you ever cared about or knew for a fat stack of cash and a ticket offplanet.

I look forward to the brigador dating sim sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066305221', 'num_games_owned': 1879, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1471788198}
review:
There is something incredibly satisfying about crushing both buildings and tiny little people beneath your mighty mechanized feet in the beautifully grimy city of Solo Nobre. What's more you won't care if you get blown up as it gives you an excuse to spawn in with a new vehicle, a new loadout and once again cause endless chaos and destruction.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z8Ef9gOoERI

Yes, this is very much an Early Access game and feels a little rough around the edges. It would definitely benefit from a little bit of polishing here and there, more maps, more vehicles and maybe a slightly easier way to tell which way you are pointing but the game definitely has legs... Big, mechanized legs ready to crush all oncomers.

Definitely worth keeping an eye on.
